title: Brokers Opposing S.E.C. Plan on Customer Disputes
description: WASHINGTON, March 31A controversial plan of the Securities and Exchange Commission to develop a national system for resolving disputes between customers and their brokers has run into overwhelming opposition from the securities industry. Its survival may rest with the position taken by Harold M. Williams, just nominated to be the commission's new chairman.

title: Rebels Sold to Fyffe
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 31 (AP) The Montgomery Rebels announced today the sale of the Southern League baseball team to Paul G. Fyffe, a radio station owner from Rainesville, Ky. The 42yearold Fyffe said he intended to retain all team personnel. Fyffe also is owner of a Class A Appalachian League franchise in his home town and is involved in the oil distribution business.

title: Great Western United Cites Restraining Order
description: The Great Western United Corporation said yesterday that the United States District Judge in Dallas issued a temporary restraining order restricting Idaho, New York and Maryland from enforcing their takeover statutes in connection with Great Western's proposed cash tender offer for up to 2 million shares of the Sunshine Mining Company at $15.75 a share.

title: Italian Senate Approves Austerity Program
description: ROME, March 31 (UPI)The Italian Senate today approved a tough austerity program demanded by the International Monetary Fund as collateral for a $530 million loan to buoy the nation's economy. Communists abstained in the voting.

title: Art of Yugoslavia Shown At Queens Science Hall
description: An exhibition of 99 prints by 33 Yugoslav artists will go on view tomorrow at the Hall of Science in Flushing MeadowsCorona Park, Queens. The show includes lithographs, serigraphs, etchings and aquatints.

title: Jazz: Joe Venuti's Got Gershwin
description: Joe Venuti, the jazz violinist, whose repertory usually consists of whatever anyone in the audience wants to hearalthough the requests tend to be for traditional jazz standards and show tunes of the 1920's and 30'sis including a long set piece in his performances at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55thStreet, where he will be playing for the next two weeks.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 1, 1977

title: New Mexico Gold Search Called Off a Day Early
description: WHITE SANDS MISSILE RANGE, N.M., March 31 (AP)The search for a legendary treasure was abandoned today, a day ahead of schedule,after discouraged workers could not find an entryway to the mountain.

title: A HOUSE PANEL APPROVES COMPROMISE ON BOYCOTT
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (Reuters)A House committee today approved compromise legislation designed to counter participation by United States businesses in the Arab trade boycott of Israel without upsetting American relations with Arab countries.

title: Three Arms Development Options Seen for Carter
description: In a news conference after the Soviet rebuff to American arms proposals. President Carter said he might be forced to speed the development of American strategic weapons it the Russians did not negotiate in good faith in Geneva in May.

title: Peter Rabbit Looks Back at 75
description: My dear Nel. I don't know what to write to you so I shall tell you a story about four little rabbits whose names were Flopsy, Mopsy, Cottontail and Peter. Addressing these lines to a fiveyearold in 1893, Beatrix Potter began the saga of history's most illustrious bunny. Her book, The Tale of Peter Rabbit, first published commercially in 1902, has sold an estimated 20 million copies, been translated into 13 languages including Braille, and given a lift to the status of rabbits everywhere, to say nothing of the hearts of little children.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: *As reported; not adjusted for transfers of loans to affiliated companies. **Over $100,000 RRevised.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Judge Benjamin Altman of Manhattan Criminal Court visited a pornography bookstore at 670 Eighth Avenue yesterday and signed warrants for the seizure of three peep shows that he said portrayed children in sexual acts. Two employees were arrested by police oficers who, with Assistant District Attorney Myls Malman, accompanied the judge.

title: 3 Teaneck School Officials Now Proposing Revisions In Sabbath Prohibitions
description: TEANECK, N.J., March 31Three school board members who had approved restrictions on Sabbath activities called last night for changes in the policy because of divisions it had created in the community.

title: Zaire Admits Loss of Town, Changes Area Command
description: KINSHASA, ZAIRE, March 31 (AP)The Government of President Mobutu Sese Seko today conceded the loss of an important southern town to invading Katangan exiles, announced that it had dismissed the Zairian Army commander for the region and imposed censorship of news dispatches on the situation there.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: The Hertz Truck Division to Ted Bates & Company, for advertising in the United States.

title: Reynolds Unit in Pact On Jamaica Bauxite
description: The Reynolds Metals Company and its subsidiary, Reynolds Jamaica Mines Ltd., said it had signed a longterm supply contract with the Government of Jamaica establishing a bauxite mining partnership.

title: Bonds Move Toward a Price Rise And a Decline for Interest Rates
description: The credit markets moved toward higher prices and lower interest rates for a second day yesterday as many bond dealers speculated that a pronounced advance might be under way. At the same time, however, the volume of bond sales to bona fide investors was reported to be light, and a new issue of General Telephone Company of California bonds yielding 8.45 percent sold slowly. Late in the afternoon, the Federal Reserve reported a decline in the nation's basic money supply but an increase in the more broadly defined money stock and in New York City bank loans. To many bond dealers, these figures neutralized each other, and the fixedincome market made no pronounced response as it sometimes does on Thursday afternoon.

title: GROMYKO CHARGES U.S. SEEKS OWN GAIN IN ARMS PROPOSALS
description: MOSCOW, March 31Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko accused the Carter Administration today of having made false and unrealistic armscontrol proposals that would give unilateral advantage to the United States.

title: Hearing for Jockey Banned in 1974 Retraces Steps Over Muddy Track
description: With enough talk of joints, flakes and dropsy cases to fill a Dick Francis horseracing mystery novel, the hearing of Sandino Hernandez before the New York State Racing and Wagering Board continued yesterday on its Whodunit course.

title: Sunpower on the Way to a Land Of Dusty Mesas and Cold Beer
description: GOLDEN, Colo., March 31On a road that snakes up the foothills of the Rocky Mountains west of Denver, one can look eastward to an archetypal, oddly bleak High Plains vistatier upon tier of squat ranch houses shaded by imported trees, two irregularly flat brown mesas rising above them, and a solid, concrete factory massed in between.

title: Stage: Inside The Shadow Box
description: DEATH IS THE ONE common thing we all live withthe one certainty in an uncertain world. And unless accident or the unexpected intervenes, terminal illness is a way of life. We all experience it, either in our own bodies, or observe it in the deaths of loved ones, friends or acquaintances. It is nothing to be afraid of, yet for most of us the slightest shiver of some intimation of mortality is almost unnaturally chilling.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 1; 1977

title: WALTER M'GINN, ACTOR, IS KILLED IN AUTO CRASH
description: Walter McGinn, a widely praised character actor, died early yesterday in a Los Angeles hospital from injuries suttered an hour earlier in an auto accident. He was 40 years old and had homes in Los Angeles and New York.

title: Knicks Stay Alive, 135 to 131
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 31  Walt Frazier has caught a lot of heat during the New York Knicks' National Basketball Association campaign.

title: Amy Carter to Accept Elephant
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)President Carter's daughter, 9yearold Amy, will formally accept an Asian baby elephant on behalf of the children of America at the National Zoo here Saturday. The sixmonthold elephant is a Bicentennial gift from Sri Lanka. Eightyearold Punitha Gunaratne of Sri Lanka will present the elephant, which is named Shanti.

title: Berlioz Done on an Epic Scale
description: There must be easier ways of raising money than the one selected by the National Council on Crime and Delinquency, but they couldn't possibly be so musically exciting as the mass migration that will bring some 600 faculty and student performers to the stage of Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon at 2 o'clock. Their mission: a presentation of the Berlioz Requiem on the gargantuan scale envisioned by the composer himself.

title: A Belle of Belgravia Arrives
description: Meg Wynn Owen, who is appearing in the McCarter Theater Company's revival of Noel Coward's Design For Living, which just opened on the Princeton University campus, found that her own current design for living began in 1975.

title: In Memoriam
description: BESDINESophia passed away on March 30, 1970. Another year has flown by and it Is seven years since you left us. Your memory is dear and we all REMEMBER MAMA.

title: China Buys Soybeans, 200,000 Metric Tons
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)China has bought 200,000 metric tons of soybeans that could come from dwindling United States supplies, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: PAPER COMPANY ADMITS QUESTIONABLE PAYMENTS
description: MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., a large Canadian timber and paper company, disclosed yesterday that it had made $3.27 million of questionable payments during the last five years, mainly involving possible circumvention of foreign taxes.

title: Tracy Austin, 14, Upsets Net Star
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., March 31How can anyone so young be so good?

title: In Moscow, Harsh Words
description: MOSCOW, March 31In the wake of the failure to make progress toward a new agreement to limit strategic arms, Moscow's relations with Washington have reached their most delicate, if not vulnerabie, point since strains in dtente appeared in 1974. Only hours after Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance wound up his visit, the mood in Moscow has changed from regret to recrimination, with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, calling an extremely rare news conference to blame the United States for lack of movement in the arms negotiations.

title: Foreign Units of U.S. Companies Cut Estimates of Capital Spending
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)Foreign affiliates of United States companies have cut back their estimates of capital spending this year, the Commerce Department announced today. However, the department said, foreign affiliates still projected a 12 percent increase, which would be a reversal from last year when capital spending fell by 4 per cent.

title: PRESIDENT REJECTS SOVIET CONTENTION
description: WASHINGTON, March 31President Carter wants his proposals for arms reductions considered by the Soviet Union at Geneva in May and dismisses Soviet contentions they are onesided, his press secretary, Jody Powell, said today.

title: Continental Phone Pact Gets Contract From Iran
description: Iran has awarded a $320 million contract to a joint venture of a subsidiary of the Continental Telephone Corporation and FortresIcas, an Iranian engineering and construction firm, for the design and installation of a major telephone cable network in Teheran.

title: Receivership Confirmed At Fontainebleau Hotel
description: The Fontainebleau, a Miami Beach hotel, has been held in secret receivership since January, Circuit Judge Dan Satin of Miami Beach said yesterday. The judge said that he named attorneys representing the Fontainebleau owner, Ben Novack, and the Roland International Corporation, to operate the hotel.

title: A Musical Feast Is Spread for the Easter Season
description: AGER MUSIC LOVERS can look forward to a profusion of quality concerts in churches and halls over the Easter holiday season. Bach's St. Matthew Passion, St. John Passion and Easter Oratorio, Handel's Messiah, A German Requiem by Brahms, Dvorak's Te Deum and a surprising array of Gregorian chants, which seem to be enjoying something of a revival, are among the performancesmost of them freeoffered in the week ahead.

title: INDICTMENT DISMISSED IN BREWERY BRIBE CASE
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 31A Federal judge here has dismissed an indictment of the Falstaff Brewing Corporation, the local Dixie Brewing Company and a beer industry lobbyist for allegedly conspiring to use a $30,000 bribe to obtain the passage of legislation benefiting the companies.

title: Albany to Remove Medicaid Coverage For Podiatry Fees
description: ALBANY, March 31The Legislature today approved Governor Carey's proposal to eliminate podiatrists, chiropractors and some other optional services from Medicaid coveragesort of.

title: Belmont Park Welcomes Seattle Slew
description: The sun already had brilliantly lighted the race track yesterday, even though it was not quite 7 A.M. There was only a trickle of cars moving along Hempstead Turnpike.

title: Leader of Losing Congress Party Appeals to India's New Government
description: NEW DELHI, March 31 Y. B. Chavan, the new leader of the defeated Congress Party in Parliament, appealed to the new Government today not to be vindictive.

title: G.A.O. Study Asks Greater Control By Congress Over the Smithsonian
description: WASHINGTON, March 31A General Accounting Office report on the Smithsonian Institution, released today, calls for far greater financial accountability to Congress and for the dissolution of two private corporations set up by the Smithsonian to avoid Federal restrictions on appropriated funds.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Episcopal Leaders Badly Split in Fight On Hispanic Panel
description: A heated dispute involving the Hispanic Affairs Commission of the Episcopal Church is creating deep splits within the national office and threatens to divide further the church's 2,8 million members.

title: MONEY SUPPLY FELL IN MARCH 23 WEEK
description: The nation's money supply, narrowly defined, fell $1.1 billion in the week ended March 23, after a $3.3 billion increase in the previous two weeks, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

title: Briscoe Defeats Mateo
description: PARIS. March 31 (AP)Benny Briscoe of Philadelphia beat Jean Mateo of France on a technical knockout tonight when the referee stopped the middleweight fight at the start of the 10th round with Mateo's right eye completely shut. Briscoe and Mateo slugged it out before an estimated crowd of 2,000 at the Paris Pavilion. The fighters weighed 160 pounds each.

title: Carter Energy Plan Said to Stress Efficiency Rise and Fuel Scarcity
description: WASHINGTON, March 31Use less and pay more is one drafter's capsule summary of the national energy plan President Carter intends to propose to Congress on April 20.

title: Czechs Quietly Put Newspapers From West on Sale on Newsstands
description: PRAGUE, March 31 (Reuters)Czechoslovakia has quietly put on sale a number of Western newspapers in what a Government spokesman today described as a move to conform with the Helsinki convention on EastWest cooperation.

title: The New Plumbers?
description: WASHINGTON  Adm. Stansfield Turner, the new Director of Central Intelligence, scored points with some members of the Senate Intelligence Committee when he recently made the following comparison:

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Four persons, including a highly decorated Newark police officer, were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges that they conspired to kidnap a Staten Island executive and rob his payroll company.

title: Screen: "Terror Over the Super Bowl
description: THE DATE is Nov. 12. We know because an opening credit card informs us of this fact and during the rest of John Frankenheimer's "Black Sunday" more cards are forever telling us datesNov. 14, Nov. 17, etc.as if to suggest that time is running out instead of just running on. The film, which had a single showing at Loews State 1 last night, begins regular showings at the State and Tower East today."Black Sunday," the screen adaptation of Thomas Harris's best-selling suspense novel, starts in Beirut where members of the Black September, the Arab terrorist group, are plotting to dramatize the Palestinian liberation cause by hitting Americans "where it hurts, where they feel most safe."Their plan, as we come to learn it, is to kidnap a friendly old Goodyear blimp, load it with high explosives and dartlike shrapnel and send it put-putting over the Miami Super Bowl to assassinate the United States President and 79,999 other football fans. The question is not whether they will succeed as much as how they will fail, and at what last split-second.Though "Black Sunday" is vastly superior to such junk movies as "Airport '77," "The Domino Principle" and "Two Minutes Warning," it belongs to that same category of film so involved with techniques and logistics that even when it generates some awe it is never once surprising."Black Sunday" is a Disneyland exhibit where people look real but are made out of rubber activated by transistors. It is a superior example of a kind of contemporary film making that has become much less involving and fun as its subjects have become more seriousand you can't get more serious than Presidential assassination and terrorism on the scale threatened in "Black Sunday."Why doesn't it work for me?I suspect it has to do with the constant awareness that the story is more important than anybody in it. The screenplay, written by Ernest Lehman, Kenneth Ross and Ivan Moffat, has the efficient manner of something hammered outas they say in Hollywoodin a story conference. The characters don't motivate the drama in any real way. They are cut and shaped to fit it, and if the cast of "Black Sunday" were not so good, and if Mr. Frankenheimer were a less able director, the movie would be unendurably boring.The film moves from Beirut to Los Angeles and Washington, then back to Los Angeles again and finally to Miami, cutting between the activities of the principal plotters (Bruce Dern as a psychotic Vietnam veteran and Marthe Keller as a Palestinian fanatic) and the Israeli intelligence officer (Robert Shaw) who has gotten wind of the plan during a commando raid on Black September headquarters in Beirut. We watch one side, then the other as if we were spectators at a Ping-Pong game.Mr. Shaw brings to the role a mixture of tough resolve and weary skepticism that are as much his own contribution as the script's. Mr. Dern, slimmed down to skeletal proportions, is so convincing as the former prisoner of war who now flies Goodyear blimps that he effectively reminds us of Mr. Frankenheimer's best film, "The Manchurian Candidate," though "The Manchurian Candidate" was about brainwashing and politics and "Black Sunday" is about blimps (as much as anything else).The action sequences, including the climactic attack on the Super Bowl (where we recognize a President who looks very much like Jimmy Carter) are well staged without being especially convincing. The film's best sequence has nothing to do with the action. It's the quiet recollection by Mr. Dern of his feelings when, as a prisoner of war, he received a snapshot of his wife and children and immediately realized that his wife had taken a lover.Miss Keller has some difficulty portraying a Palestinian terrorist, looking, as she does, as beautiful and healthy and uncomplicated as a California surfer. She also shares a speech problem with the young Marlene Dietrich (Beirut is "Baywoot" and arranged is "awanged"), while lacking Dietrich's camp majesty.

title: PODGORNY SIGNS PACT ON MOZAMBIQUE VISIT
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique, March 31 (AP) The Soviet Union and Mozambique signed a treaty of friendship today. It was the first treaty signed by this East African state since it became independent of Portugal in 1975.

title: Insists on a Contract by Start of Season
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31Dave Kingman, holding out for the richest contract in the history of the New York Mets, challenged the team in effect tonight to sign me or trade me, and said he would play out his option if they did neither.

title: Former Pakistani Official Loses Seat in Vote Fraud
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, March 31 (Reuters) A former federal minister lost his seat in the newly elected National Assembly today because of what an independent commission called grave voting illegalities.

title: High Waters Expected For Trout Season Debut
description: Waters in many parts of New York State are expected to be high and fairly rough today for the opening of the trout season. But, despite high waters caused by melting snow, a good turnout of anglers is expected.

title: Conrail Lost $139 Million in the Final Quarter of 1976
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation, comprised of six bankrupt railroads in the Northeast, reported yesterday a net loss of $139 million on revenues of $802.2 million for the three months ended last December.

title: Vance Assures Two Allies That Detente Is Still Alive
description: LONDON, March 31Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance assured American allies in West Germany and Britain today that dtente with the Soviet Union was still alive despite the failure to make progress in negotiations for a treaty limiting strategic arms.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 11%
description: WASHINGTON. March 31The Department of Commerce reported today that total retail stores sales last week were about $13.41 billion, up 11 percent from last year's $12.13 billion. Department store sales were an estimated $1.24 billion, up 8 percent from the yearmiller $1.15 billion.

title: Washington Star Makes RadioTV Swap
description: WASHINGTON, March 31Joe L. Allbritton, the millionaire Texas banker who three years ago boughtand has so far savedthe financially imperiled Washington Star, disclosed today that he had completed the Governmentordered divestiture of the newspaper company's television and radio properties by trading WMALTV here for KOCOTV in Oklahoma City. Both stations are affiliated with ABC.

title: Post Switches to Creamer
description: Rupert Murdoch's New York Post has just switched its advertising account to Creamer/FSR, largely, it appears, because George Lois is its new president.

title: United Technologies Planning To Proceed With Babcock Bid
description: Harry J. Gray, chairman and president of the United Technologies Corporation, yesterday informed George Zipf, chairman of the Babcock & Wilson Company that United planned to proceed with its intent to acquire Babcock & Wilcox shares.

title: A Happy Ending and Beginning in New Delhi
description: NEW DELHI, March 31Of the 19 Cabinet ministers whom Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai chose during his first week in office, more than half were, like him, in jail as political prisoners for most of the harsh 19month period of emergency rule that just ended. But most seemed curiously forgiving about it all in the opening days of Parliament, as they cheerfully greeted their colleagues from what used to be the government side.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Sunday
description: DAYS or BEES AND HONEY

title: Queens College Library to Show Lincoln FuneralCeremony Bills
description: Outside the Municipal Building a year ago, Dr. Leo Hershkowitz, a history professor at Queens College, saw canvas laundry hampers full of old city records being dumped into trucks bound for an East Bronx pulp mill. He went to the mill the next day and got permission to try to keep ahead of the papershredders working on the 25foothigh mound.

title: Neighbor Is Charged With Slaying Of Woman and Two Girls in Bronx
description: A 22yearold furniture mover was arrested yesterday and charged with the knifeslaying of a 25yearold woman and her two young daughters in their Bronx apartment 11 days ago. The police said an argument between the suspect and the woman led to the slayings.

title: ABDEL HALIM HAFEZ
description: LONDON, March 31 (AP)Abdel Halim Harez, the Egyptian singer who was hailed as the Middle East's king of Arab popular music, died here last night during treatment for a liver illness, the Egyptian Embassy announced today. He was 45 years old.

title: SADAT IN WEST GERMANY ON HIS WAY TO THE U.S.
description: CAIRO, March 31President Anwar elSadat flew to West Germany today on his way to the United States for three days of talks with President Carter and other Administration and Congressional lerders.

title: I.R.S. Employee Gets Jail Term For Accepting Gifts From Gulf
description: PITTSBURGH, March 31 (AP)Cyril J. Niederberger, 69 years old, has been sentenced to six months in jail and fined $5,000 for illegally accepting gifts from the Gulf Oil Corporation, while working for the Internal Revenue Service and auditing Gulf's taxes.

title: Austerity Budget of $1 1.5 Billion Adopted by New York Legislature
description: ALBANY, March 31The Legislature spent the entire day today passing an $11.5 billion budget that is, as a political compromise, a work of art.

title: Inside, a Cauldron
description: I am planning the garden, primroses or day lilies. But what about the pistol? The pistol? Yes, the pearlhandled pistol I plan to use for defense in the subwaywhen the punks try to terrorize, and the passengers are terrified, I want to pull out my little pistol and shoot in selfdefense. No one will care, everyone will cheer. We are all decent lawabiding citizens.

title: Parker Agency Denies Reports of Shutdown
description: The word spread yesterday that Parker Advertising, which will be losing the $35 million Datsun account this summer, would close its doors for good on July 1. This was emphatically denied yesterday by Ed Denker, vice presidentclient services of the Palos Verdes Peninsula, Calif. ad agency, who said, There's been no decision on this.

title: Construction Plans For a Subway Link At 63d St. Opposed
description: Citing fears of traffic jams and intolerable noise, some 700 residents, business operators and members of Community Planning Board 8 met last night to voice opposition to construction of the 63d Street subway link.

title: INTELLIGENCE BUDGET TOTALING $6.2 BILLION IS REPORTED SOUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, March 31The Carter Administration has requested $6.2 billion for the nation's intelligence operations in the budget for the fiscal year 1978, according to sources close to the Senate Intelligence Committee.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, March 31New Jersey's unemployment rate slipped unexpectedly to 9.9 percent in February from 10.1 percent the previous month, the first time since January 1975 that it had dropped below double digits, John J. Horn, Acting Commissioner of the State Department of Labor and Industry, reported today.

title: In Washington, Challenge
description: WASHINGTON, March 31The sense in Washington today is that President Carter is being put to the test by the Soviet leadershipa test that, perhaps unintentionally, he brought upon himself with his vigorous public diplomacy on human rights and arms control. This is Khrushchev and Kennedy all over again, commented one experienced Congressional observer, recalling the testy confrontation between the late Soviet leader, Nikita S. Khrushchev, and President Kennedy at their first meeting in Vienna in 1961.

title: Highlights of the State's Budget
description: ALBANY, March 31Following are the highlights of the state budget for the fiscal year that begins tonight. The $11.5 billion budget, up about $450 million from the current year and some $100 million from Governor Carey's original proposal is contained in 25 separate bills ranging from the abolition of the Bingo Control Commission in one bill to the appropriation of $7 billion in socalled local assistance in another.

title: Television
description: TOP WEEKEND FILMS

title: As Tide of North Sea Oil Floods In, So Does Hope for British Economy
description: LONDON, March 31Britain's longawaited tide of North Sea oil has begun flooding ashore and in such quantities that experts predict Britain will be selfsufficient in energy in three years, and maybe even in two. It would be the only major Western nation to enjoy this status.

title: Argo Merchant Oil Spill Caused Minimal Damage
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)The 7.7 million gallons of oil spilled from the tanker Argo Merchant last December off the coast of Massachusetts caused minimal biological and esthetic damage, Government report said today.

title: Antique Dresses Span Generations
description: Fashions of the 30's, 40's and even the 50's are being discovered and worn with pride by the generation that grew up in the 60's.

title: REPORTERS ON COAST WIN SERVICE AWARD
description: CHICAGO, March 31 (AP)Two Los Angeles Times newsmen, George H. Reasons and Mike Goodman, have been named winners of the Distinguished Service Award of the Society of Professional Journalists, Sigma Delta Chi, the society announced today. The award was in the field of general reporting.

title: HughesC.I.A. Burglary Trial Opens
description: LOS ANGELES, March 31Jury selection began yesterday in the trial of Donald R. Woolbright on charges of receiving stolen property and attempting to extort $1 million from the late Howard R. Hughes's Summa Corporation.

title: Yanks Sign Chambliss and Nettles Returns
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 31 The Yankees infused a little harmony into their tumultuous ship today when Graig Nettles returned to play and Chris Chambliss put his signature to a fiveyear contract.

title: Illness in Louisville Area Laid to Chemical Fumes
description: LOUISVILLE. Ky., March 31 (AP)More than 50 persons along the Ohio River in the Louisville area have become ill in the past few days, apparently from chemical fumes, the authorities said today.

title: Investigation Is Ordered by F.P.C. Of Columbia Gas Shortage Claim
description: WASHINGTON, March 31(AP)  The Federal Power Commission today ordered an investigation into allegations that a major natural gas pipeline company's shortage of gas was the result more of bad judgment than of the harsh weather.

title: No Fear of Fiddling
description: Singers can express emotions with their faces when they're performing, but instrumentalists have to be stonyfaced or they're treated as freaks. It doesn't seem right to me. The complaint comes from Gary Karr, who is generally considered the finest solo player of the double bass around these days.

title: At the Movies
description: NICK NOLTE may be nothing more than your ordinary, everyday, average blend of Marlon Brando and Robert Redford. Nevertheless, he has Hollywood moguls competing frantically for his services, thanks to his charismatic, starmaking performance last season as the rebellious kid brother in television's Rich Man, Poor Man. By this time next year, his blond, blueeyed, slightly sullen good looks are apt to be familiar to even those movie purists who would sooner face the pillory than sit home watching a commercialspocked miniseries. On June 17, the 36yearold actor will be seen on the big screen as a brazen adventurer in The Deep, Peter Yates's film of the Peter Benchley best seller. And starting next week Mr. Nolte will tangle with heavy drugs and Tuesday Weld when he takes on the role of the hardened Vietnam veteran in Karel Reisz's The Dog Soldiers.

title: Saturday
description: STEPS FROM ALL OVER

title: Management
description: Forty law firms rejected Harold Krents, a Harvard Law School graduate, when he applied for a job a few years ago, apparently because he is blind

title: The Screen: Brothers, Prison Drama
description: ANGER IS THE STRIDENT keynote in Brothers, the thinly disguised dramatization of some bloody, black militancy of fairly recent history in California. Hatred, like love, cries for balanced treatment, but Brothers, which opened at the Fine Arts and National Theaters yesterday, is dedicated to venting its outrage unalloyed and largely without benefit of doubt.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, March 31, 1977

title: Why Moscow Failed
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 There are several reasons why the U.S.Soviet strategic arms control talks in Moscow failed to reach an agreement almost had to failand why it is probably a good thing that they did fail at this particular time.

title: 10 Hemisphere Countries Said to Shackle Press
description: CARTAGENA, Colombia, March 31 (UPI)A report prepared for approval by the InterAmerican Press Association today says freedom of the press does not exist in 10 of 26 countries surveyed in the Western Hemisphere.

title: GROMYKO CHARGES U.S. SEEKS OWN GAIN IN ARMS PROPOSALS
description: MOSCOW, March 31Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko accused the Carter Administration today of having made false and unrealistic armscontrol proposals that would give unilateral advantage to the United States.

title: The President's Yacht Is Headed for a Sale
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)President Carter has requested Defense Secretary Harold Brown to sell the Presidential yacht, Sequoia, as part of his austerity campaign, it was learned today.

title: Aides to Bell Call for Indictments Of F.B.I. Officials Over Breakins
description: WASHINGTON, March 31A team of Justice Department lawyers has recommended to Attorney General Griffin B. Bell that the department seek criminal indictments against at least six present and former officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who authorized illegal breakins by bureau agents in New York.

title: Film: 'Horse Thieves' to the Rescue
description: THE LITTLEST Horse Thieves," which opened at the Radio City Music Hall yesterday as the theater's "new" Easter attraction (its "old" one, "Mr. Billion," having been a box-office flop), is a sweet-tempered, charming Walt Disney comedy about three children possessing the kind of modest pluck one associates with children's stories written at the turn of the century.The time, indeed, is 1909 and the setting is an idyllically pretty, mostly dust-free Yorkshire. The story is about the efforts of the two young stepsons of a coal miner and the spunky daughter of the mine manager to save the lives of the pit ponies who have been rendered obsolete by new mine equipment. With the help of a volume called "The Wonder Book of Science," the children successfully restore to use the winding engine in an abandoned mine shaft, thus to steal the ponies out of the mines before they can be sent away to the glue factory.Andrew Harrison and Benjie Bolgar play the two boys with the sort of gravity that doesn't allow for cuteness. Chloe Franks is the young heroine, a little girl who has to put up with a nanny who says things like "Mercy me, we are Miss Grubby Paws today, aren't we?" Most prominent among the older actors are the late Alastair Sim as the mildly eccentric old lord who owns the mine and Geraldine McEwan, who plays the bossy nanny.The screenplay, written by Rosemary Anne Sisson, was directed by Charles Jarrott, whose stately earlier credits ("Anne of a Thousand Days," "Mary Queen of Scots") give no hint that he could scale down his talent to embrace this movie's genuine feelings for childhood adventure. In its own unpushy way, "The Littlest Horse Thieves" also manages to be as intelligent about miners' rights and social caste as it is about beneficial rights due to faithful, over-age pit ponies.

title: Spring Borrowing by Albany Is Upheld by Court of Appeals
description: Less than 12 hours before the start of New York State's new fiscal year, the State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that the state could go to the shortterm money market to borrow nearly $4 billion until tax revenues were collected.

title: Notes on People
description: After serving 57 days of a 60day sentence for defacing the Pentagon in a protest against the nation's nuclear arms policies, Philip Berrigan was released yesterday from the Arlington County jail in Virginia. He had been arrested for defacing pillars of the Pentagon entrance with blood, which he said was his own, in the protest last Dec. 28. Mr. Berrigan was at the forefront of the antiwar movement. both as a priest and after he left the priesthood to marry a former nun, Elizabeth McAlister. She remains in jail, serving a 90day sentence. Mr. Berrigan's brother Daniel, a Jesuit priest, was released last month after serving time on similar charges.

title: Miss or Mrs. Won't Be Required on Bonds
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 (AP)Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal has rescinded a regulation that required women to be identified as Miss or Mrs. on savings bonds.

title: AXELSON DECLINES CONTROL BOARD POST
description: Kenneth S. Axelson, the J. C. Penney executive who withdrew as President Carter's nominee for the post of Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, yesterday turned down Governor Carey's offer to be reappointed as one of three private business members of the State Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: More Funds Sought to Finance Other Nations' Military Training
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)The Carter Administration asked Congress today for $35.7 million to finance other countries' military training because it is a valuable tool of foreign policy.

title: G.M. Chief Says Study Found No Slush Funds
description: Thomas A. Murphy, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday that a sixmonth investigation of transactions over the last five years had turned up no evidence of illegal or unethical business practices.

title: New Ottawa Budget Takes Aim at Prices And Unemployment
description: OTTAWA, March 31The Canadian Government introduced a budget in the House of Commons tonight that cautiously sought to stimulate the economy and to alleviate unemployment while holding back inflation.

title: In Washington, Challenge
description: WASHINGTON, March 31The sense in Washington today is that President Carter is being put to the test by the Soviet leadershipa test that, perhaps unintentionally, he brought upon himself with his vigorous public diplomacy on human rights and arms control. This is Khrushchev and Kennedy all over again, commented one experienced Congressional observer, recalling the testy confrontation between the late Soviet leader, Nikita S. Khrushchev, and President Kennedy at their first meeting in Vienna in 1961.

title: Money
description: Thursday, March 31, 1977

title: Newark Ordered to Start at Once To Revaluate All Private Property
description: TRENTON, March 31The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the revaluation of privately owned property in Newark must begin immediately as required by law and that the cost of the project be diverted from state aid due the city.

title: 10th Stock Decline in 11 Sessions Plunges the Dow to 14Month Low
description: Stock prices continued to erode yesterday, posting their 10th decline in the last 11 sessions in extremely slow trading.

title: Califano Concedes Error in Advocating Job Quotas
description: Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said yesterday that he had made a mistake when he said he advocated racial and sexual quotas as a means of redressing past discrimination.

title: Student Demonstration And Fire Close College
description: HOLLY SPRINGS, Miss., March 31 (UPI)  Rust College was closed indefinitely, and all 800 students were sent home today after a demonstration and early morning fire that caused an estimated $500,000 damage to the administration building.

title: STRAUSS IS LEANING TO SOME PROTECTION ON IMPORTS OF SHOES
description: WASHINGTON, March 31Robert S. Strauss, the nation's chief trade negotiator, suggested today that President Carter was moving toward a compromise on the hotly controversial question of shoe imports, now magnified into a leading signal of the new Administration's intentions in international trade.

title: 22 Pakistanis Die as Bridge Falls
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 31 (UPI) At least 22 people drowned today when a drawbridge collapsed under a bus crossing the Indus River in Punjab province. The bus, carrying 30 people, was crossing the bridge when it plummeted into the river about 200 miles southwest of here in Dera Ghazi Khan. Four persons were rescued, and four others still missing.

title: Tightening of YearEnd Supply Nudges Soybean Futures Prices Higher
description: The three oldcrop soybean contractsMay, July and Augustshowed strength yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, rising 8 to 11 cents a bushel. At the close, for example, July was quoted at $8.98 a bushel, up from $8.87 on Wednesday.

title: Music: Disarming Rostropovich
description: THERE ARE A FEW musicians of such Olympian quality and reputation that they become difficult to listen to. Difficult to listen to objectively, that is. Mstislav Rostropovich, the cellist, conductor and pianist, is just a disarming paragon. The versatile Mr. Rostropovich, in his cello recital at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, did a few things that would have made this listener bridle if they had been done by a lesser virtuoso. But, coming from him, nothing seemed really wrong.

title: Out of Doors
description: IF MARINE LIFE interests you, now's the time to do the homework that will enhance your summer excursionswhether with rod and reel in the pounding surf, mask and snorkel along a rocky shore, or bucket, net and specimen vials in some tidal pool. A splendid place to do this is at the Mystic Marinelife Aquarium in Connecticut, which is about a two and a half hour's drive north of New York City.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: THE designation of superspectacular for this week must go, without doubt, to Franco Zeffirelli's production of Jesus of Nazareth, the multimillion dollar film carrying, for safety's sake, the endorsements of Catholic, Protestant, Jewish and Mormon officials. When the interpretation of Jesus was criticized recently by some small religious groups who hadn't even seen the film, General Motors quickly withdrew as sponsor and all public relations hell broke loose in the corridors of NBC and the two coproduces, ITC, Sir Lew Grade's British organization, and RAI, Italy's broadcasting system.

title: THREE QUEENS SECTIONS SEE ROAD FUNDS AT WORK
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday that construction work had begun on 1.5 miles of street repairs, financed by Federal publicworks funds, in the Flushing, Maspeth and Glendale sections of Queens.

title: Son Born to Cathy Sulzberger And Dr. Joseph G. Perpich
description: A son was born to Cathy Sulzberger and Dr. Joseph G. Perpich of Chevy Chase, Md., yesterday at the Columbia Hospital for Women, Washington. The child's mother, who has retained her maiden name, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ochs Sulzberger of New York. Mr. Sulzberger is chairman of The New York Times Company and president and publisher of The New York Times.

title: Folk Programs Sunday At L.I. Whaling Museum
description: Stout, a folkmusic group, will sing sea chanteys and folk songs on Sunday at 1, 2 and 3 P.M. at the Whaling Museum, Route 25A in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. Admission is 75 cents for adults, 25 cents for children 6 to 14 years old and free for under 6's.

title: Mozart Marathon Draws To a Breathtaking Close
description: Though it is widely agreed that Mozart wrote more outstanding chamber works for winds than anyone else, it seems that this season's fourconcert Mozart series by the Festival Winds marks the music's first complete local survey. The series ends tonight at 8 P.M. in the Metropolitan Museum's Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium. (Tickets, $6, are available at the museum: 8795512.)

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times on March 24 reported incorrectly that children should receive initial immunization against diphtheria at 18 months of age. Health officials say the initial series of shots should be given at 2, 4, 6 and 18 months of age.

title: Byrne, N. J. School Miler, In No Rush to Hit 4 Minutes
description: If Kevin Byrne had continued as a high jumper, he feels he might be clearing about 6 feet 8 inches this year. But running became his forte, specifically the mile, and now the senior at Paramus (N.J.) Catholic is the outstanding scholastic miler in the country. With the outdoor season about to begin the question is: When will Byrne run his first subfourminute mile?

title: How Hit Musicals Grow Older
description: THE MIDDLE AGE of a Broadway musical, like that of a human being, is part wrinkles and part surprises. Some lines sag and others are as firm as ever. Some shows keep their looks and others begin to let themselves go.

title: Trudeau Aide Calls Separation Unlikely
description: OTTAWA, March 31, (AP)  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's office today described as extremely unlikely a report that he and his wife, Margaret, have agreed to a separation.

title: Sydney A. Weinberg, 67, An Inventor of Techniques In XRay Motion Pictures
description: Sydney A. Weinberg, an inventor who specialized in developing techniques for the projection of Xray motion pictures, died on Tuesday at his home in Brighton, N. Y., a suburb of Rochester. He was 67 years old.

title: Judge Strikes Down Limits on Liability In Nuclear Mishaps
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)A Federal district judge declared unconstitutional today the law that limits the financial liability of power companies for nuclear accidents.

title: Publishing: Fair For Rare Bookmen
description: WHAT PRICE TAG would you put on 15 pages in George Gershwin's own handwriting, containing musical notes, sketches and ideas for an orchestral tone poem called An American in Paris? How much is a first edition of Freud's Interpretation of Dreams worth? What's the value of a two volume, leatherbound set, printed in London in 1789, of the autobiography of Olaudah Equiano, an Ibo who was kidnapped into slavery as a child in West Africa and grew up to buy his own freedom as a man in the West Indies?

title: Hanafi Leader, Freed After Siege, Jailed for Threatening Bloodshed
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) Hamaas Abdul Khaalis, free since his Hanafi Moslem band held 134 hostages three weeks ago in a siege in which one person was killed, was jailed today after a judge was told that a police wiretap had recorded bloodcurdling threats by Mr. Khaalis.

title: Books: New Wings, Old Seagull
description: LOTS OF PEOPLE wrote off Richard Bach's Jonathan Livingstone Seagull as pop philosophy, but it sold millions of copies and was read aloud at weddings, funerals, bar mitzvahs and other solemn occasions necessitating appropriate inspiration. Personally, I found it over my headall that allegorical, idealistic stuff. I mean give me a book with a racy storya good flick on the box and a can of beer. If you want inspiration, call DialAPrayer.

title: ExDetective Gets 3 Years
description: A retired narcotics detective, linked by Federal authorities to the theft of 400 pounds of narcotics from the New York City police property clerk, was sentenced yesterday to three years in prison and a $20,000 fine for incometax evasion. He could have got 11 years. The defendant, iVncent Albano, 44 years,, old, of 75 Bay Street, East Atlantic Beach, L.I., pleaded guilty last October to three counts of an indictment which had charged him with evading taxes of more than $77,000 on unreported income of $194,000 between 1970 and 1975.

title: Filipino Pilot Claims Blackout in Killing of 7
description: ZAMBOANGA, Philippines, March 31 (UPI)A pilot who shot to death seven persons aboard his plane ferrying troops to the southern Philippines said today that he had had a mental blackout and recalled nothing of the shooting spree.

title: Books of The Times
description: IT IS THE thesis of this exasperating book that Robert E. Leethe marble man. as Stephen Vincent Benet called him and as Edward Valentine rendered him in the recumbent figure in Lee Chapel at Washington and Lee Universitywas more complicated than many of his biographers have made him out to be. We are told that Lee repressed a lot; that he often thought of himself as a failure; that his wite was a trial; that his generalship, while very good on defensive, left something to be desired when it came to attacking; that his image, of the warriorChrist in a Lost Cause against overwhelming odds, was engineered after the Civil War by a sort of Virginia mafia, a collection of enthusiasts, selfservers, provincial zealots and traumaridden solaceseekers who would have us believe that theirs was the Garden of Civilization and Lee its unflawed flower, its bloody chivalric rose

title: Califano Concedes Error in Advocating Job Quotas
description: Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said yesterday that he had made a mistake when he said he advocated racial and sexual quotas as a means of redressing past discrimination.

title: Warm Weather Is Most Upsetting Factor To Platform Tennis Players at Forest Hills
description: A cold front and gusty winds had sent temperatures drooping, but not nearly enough to suit the purists on hand at Forest Hills yesterday for the start of the $30,000 world platform tennis championships.

title: Trade Show Caravan
description: Following the Mohammed/mountain theory, Mass Marketing Systems, Mountainside, N. J., is bringing trade shows to customers. Its Health Care Caravan of one or more rented, specially constructed trucktrailer units will, during 1977, be making three swings  Southeast, Midwest and SouthwestWestvisiting 40 major hospitals on each swing. Employees who usually cannot be reached through regular trade shows will get to see displays of hospital equipment or pharmaceuticals. Each van can accommodate up to nine exhibitors with a fivefoot module going for $8,450 per tour.

title: LIABILITY FOR OIL SPILLS BY LIBERIAN SHIPS URGED
description: In the wake of December's Argo Merchant oil spill, investigators proposed yesterday an eightpoint program to hold Liberian flagship owners and operators accountable for their vessels.

title: Senators Vote to Ease Ethics Code
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)The Senate, closing out two weeks of debate, poked another potential loophole in its prospective ethics code today by voting, 79 to 9, to revise proposed restrictions on members taking expensepaid trips abroad.

title: Glamour of the Women's Golf Tour Is Stained by Tears and Drudgery
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 31Carol Mann is 6 feet 3 inches tall, slim as a No. 2 iron, and has banked half a million dollars by whacking a golf ball across more courses than she can remember.

title: Recovery in Florida's Real Estate Market
description: MIAMIThe weather was exhilarating, the crowd was big, and a carnivallike atmosphere prevailed last Saturday morning in a small community some 20miles north of here. It was south Florida's first apartmentbyapartment public auction of a financially troubled condominium. After five hours of typical auction ritual in which many of the 1,000 registered bidders participated, all 160 units of the threebuilding Bristol Court complex in suburban Lauderdale Lakes were sold. The transactions, which were wrapped up on the spot, netted the trust company that held the property more than $2 million, or about 55 percent of the builder's suggested list price on the sixyearold project.

title: Text of U.S.Soviet Communique
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (Reuters) Following is the text of the United StatesSoviet communiqu issued today upon the conclusion of talks in Moscow on strategic arms:

title: People and Business
description: In his first address before mainland businessmen since taking office, Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo of Puerto Rico told a luncheon gathering yesterday that, while his prostatehood administration did not plan any type of sweeping reform that would eliminate tax exemption altogether, tax exemption should be looked upon as a privilege.

title: Gold Price Shows Decline On European Markets; Dollar Closes Mixed
description: LONDON, March 31 (AP)The price of gold dropped in London and Zurich while the dollar had a mixed day on European money markets today. Gold, fluctuating around $150 an ounce over the last month, closed at $148.875 in both London and Zurich, Europe's major bullion markets.

title: Restaurants
description: OH, WHAT A DIFFERENCE a chef can make! Last September the small and charming La Colombe d'Or opened on 26th Street just east of Lexington Avenue, with an enchanting Provencele dcor, and a menu to match. The setting with its brick walls, a pretty, cotton print for banquettes and curtains, plants and a handsome tin ceiling proved far more successful than the food which was, unfortunately, strictly nostar.

title: 2 States Report No Vote Frauds Under New Law
description: MADISON. Wis., March 31Raymond J. Holton showed his student identification card to a clerk at City Hall this morning and was able to cast his absentee ballot for next Tuesday's election.

title: Commodity Price Index Declines 2.2 From the WeekEarlier Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 219.2 from 221.4 last week.

title: New Identification Cards Issued to Aliens in U. S.
description: MIAMI, March 31The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service today began issuing Its new alien identification cards, which it hopes will end widespread fraudulent use of immigration documents.

title: U.S. Calls Action a Blow
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  The Brit ish decision was criticized by a Defense Department official here today as a move that seriously damaged the effort to achieve greater weapons standardization in NATO.

title: Diamond Shamrock Unit Lifts Liquid Caustic Soda Prices
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation's Electro Chemicals division announced yesterday new prices for liquid caustic soda effective today to spot customers and as terms permit to contract customers. The new prices reflect a maximum $10 a ton increase for 50 percent liquid caustic soda and a maximum $15 per ton increase for 73 percent liquid caustic soda.

title: WBAI Will Resume Broadcasting Tonight
description: Radio station WBAIFM, which was forced to stop broadcasting seven weeks ago because of a dispute between its management and staff, will resume its operations sometime tonight if the equipment is in working order, the station manager said yesterday.

title: States Are Found to Save Money By Marijuana Decriminalization
description: WASHINGTON. March 31 (AP)Harsh penalties do not keep people from smoking marijuana, and moderate use probably poses no substantial health hazard, a new Governmentfinanced report says.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: This Jazzman Gets Olderand Better
description: When someone offers him an engagement, the first concern of Ruby Braff, the diminutive jazz cornetist, is the pianist he will be playing with.

title: G.M.'s Chief Opposes Penalties on Big Cars
description: BALTIMORE, March 31 (Reuters)Thomas A. Murphy, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation, took exception today to proposals to penalize drivers of big cars as a means of saving energy.

title: City Councilmen Vote to Dismantle Superagencies Formed by Lindsay
description: New York City's era of superagencies, which began 10 years ago in a move meant to make the municipal government more efficient, ended yesterday when the City Council overwhelmingly passed legislation dissolving and restructuring the massive bureaucracy.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 31, 1977

title: Highway Administrator Named
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)President Carter announced today that he was nominating a Kentucky trucker, William M. Cox, to be head of the Federal Highway Administration. Mr. Cox is vice president of Ligon Specialized Hauler Inc. of Madisonville, Ky., a common carrier operating some 700 tractortrailer units.

title: News Summary
description: The Carter Administration was attacked by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union for making what he said were unrealistic proposals on arms control in which unilateral advantages were given to the United States. Mr. Gromyko held a news conference to explain his Government's rejection of two arms control proposals presented by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance. He was both sarcastic and annoyed as he presented the Soviet views. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: SOVIET SAID TO OBSTRUCT U.S. INITIATIVE ON AFRICA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 31A United Stales official said tonight that the Soviet Union was telling African countries not to go along with an American proposal that the Security Council issue a Declaration of Principles opposine racism in southern Africa.

title: Lawyers Now Confuse Even the Same Aforementioned;
description: Lawyers and judges seem to have a peculiar cant and jargon of their own, that no other mortal can understand, Gulliver said of the people he met in his travels.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: FOR A TRUE TASTE of New England life just 60 miles from Manhattan, the little town of Ridgefield in Connecticut, tucked along the northeast corner of Westchester County, is hard to beat. It offers more than a score of historic homes, casual shopping including specialty stores, pleasant strolls, elegant dining and a beautiful countryside.

title: Top Legislators Keep Projects From Being Cut
description: ALBANY, March 31The real measure of budgetmaking power is not what gets cut out, but, especially in an austerity era, what gets put back in.

title: BRITAIN GOING AHEAD WITH ITS RADAR PLAN
description: LONDON, March 31Britain announced today that it had decided to go ahead with its own airborne radar defense system rather than wait for an American system for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as a whole.

title: U.S. HEALTH IS GOOD Bill COULD BE BETTER
description: WASHINGTON, March 31In terms of such fundamentals as death rates and life expectancy at birth, American health has never been better, according to a compilation of data from the National Center for Health Statistics. But the center's analysis said that there was still much need for improvement.

title: Wendy Yoshimura's Father Pledges House for Bail
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 31 (AP)Wendy Yoshimura's father has pledged his home to help his daughter stay free on bail while her conviction for illegal possession of weapons and explosives is being appealed, a judge said today.

title: Broadway
description: GEORGE C. SCOTT will be replaced in Sly Fox on May 10, and while ordinarily there is that hint of second best when a producer speaks about a replacement, no matter how vehemently a producer says otherwise, the replacement for Mr. Scott may be spoken of without opprobrium. He is Robert Preston, and he has been some kind of a star ever since he was in the movie Union Pacific at the age of 19. Eventually, of course, there was The Music Man, and before and after that were plays and movies, too. Now there will be Sly Fox, and the question may be how Mr. Preston will be different in the play from Mr. Scott. This is a tricky question in theater, and not to be taken lightly; Besides, no one knows the answer.

title: Episcopal Leaders Badly Split in Fight On Hispanic Panel
description: A heated dispute involving the Hispanic Affairs Commission of the Episcopal Church is creating deep splits within the national office and threatens to divide further the church's 2.8 million members.

title: Accounting Firms Challenge Criticism
description: The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants attacked yesterday a staff study of a Senate subcommittee that charged the nation's largest accounting firms with controlling and exploiting the profession's rulemaking powers in order to serve their large corporate clients.

title: Irving Spiegel of The Times Dies; Expert on Jewish Affairs Was 69
description: Irving Spiegel, for more than 30 years The New York Times's expert on Jewish affairs and, for many years before that, a generalassignment and police reporter, died yesterday of heart failure at Albert Einstein Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: Friday
description: RIVERSIDE DANCE

title: About Real Estate
description: We provide the money. You do what you want.

title: Purloined Annual Report
description: Somewhere there is an unhappy thief or thieves. It Is he, she or they who, having successfully broken into and having escaped from a storage facility at the John F. Kennedy International Airport, discovered that the swag included 2,000 copies of the annual report of the Interpublic Group of Companies. And that happens to be the only way to make an annual report hot.

title: Bean Leads By Shot on 67 At Greensboro
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 31 (AP) Andy Bean, who scored a starttofinish victory three weeks ago in Miami, fought gusty winds for a fiveunderpar 67 and took a onestroke lead today in the first round of the $235,000 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.

title: Farmers' Prices Up For Fourth Month; Latest Increase 1%
description: WASHINGTON, March 31(AP)Prices farmers get for raw products as they move into the consumer pipeline rose 1 percent between Feb. 15 and March 15, the fourth consecutive monthly increase, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: New Set of Cyprus Talks Is Opened in Vienna
description: VIENNA, March 31Representatives of the Greek and Turkish ethnic communities in Cyprus resumed talks today to seek a federal solution to their dispute.

title: Texas Insurer to Meet On Bid for Richmond
description: The executive committee of the American General Insurance Company is scheduled to meet today to consider restructuring the offer the company made Tuesday to acquire the Richmond Corporation, a muchwooed Virginia insurance holding company.

title: MONDALE ASKS DEMOCRATS TO BACK CARTER PROGRAMS
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)Vice President Mondale appealed today to state Democratic leaders to support the Carter Administration's programs to revise the election system and stimulate the economy.

title: GiantsJets Exhibition Is Slated for New Jersey
description: The Jets and Giants will move their annual miniwar to New Jersey for the first time this year when they meet in an exhibition game at Giants Stadium over the Labor Day weekend.

title: INTELLIGENCE BUDGET TOTALING $6.2 BILLION IS REPORTED SOUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, March 31The Carter Administration has requested $6.2 billion for the nation's intelligence operations in the budget for the fiscal year 1978, according to sources close to the Senate Intelligence Committee.

title: Steel Imports of 1.1 Million Tons Up 11.3% in January From '76 Level
description: January steel imports reached 1.1 million tons, a gain of 11.3 percent over the yearearlier level, but 17.8 percent lower than in December 1976, the American Institute for Imported Steel reported yesterday. Charles Stern, president of the trade association, said that the fluctuations could be attributed largely to a depressed import situation a year ago and also to the gains made late in 1976.

title: Armco Will Reopen Houston Pipe Mill
description: The Armco Steel Corporation announced that a Federal program aimed at creating jobs in areas of high unemployment would permit the reopening of its pipe mill in Houston that has been shut since 1975. George W. Hansen, vice president, said that about 200 steelworkers would be back at work May 2 to fill a $5.8 million Federal Energy Administration contract for 42 miles of 36inch line pipe. The pipe is needed for the agency's program to stockpile crude oil reserves in salt domes along the Gulf Coast.

title: Management
description: Increased militancy is evident among the handicapped as they compete for jobs. Already 1,900 complaints of discrimination by management have been filed under the 1973 Rehabilitation Act. Page D9.

title: After the Early Rush, the E.R.A. Is Now at a Standstill
description: Five years after it was passed by Congress and three months into a year that its advocates had hoped would see final ratification, the equal rights amendment appears to be suffering from a case of arrested growth.

title: Upgrading of a Rail Corridor Starts
description: ODENTON, Md.,. March 31At a dusty site midway between Washington and Baltimore. Paul H.. Reistrup, the president of Amtrak, and Brock Adams, Secretary of Transportation, looked on today as work was begun on the $1.9 billion, fouryear upgrading of the WashingtonNew YorkBoston rail corridor.

title: Bridge: Transfer Bids Are Favored After a NoTrump Opening
description: A recent survey showed that more than half the New York experts favor Jacoby transfer bids in response to notrump bids. Two of a red suit shows at least five cards in the next higherranking suit, so that diamonds shows hearts, two hearts shows spades. A twospade response promises a minorsuit hand.

title: Cragg, Miss McIngvale Win Title Diving Events
description: AUSTIN, Tex., March 31 (AP)Two Olympic divers picked up individual honors yesterday at the national Amateur Athletic Union indoor diving championships at the Texas Olympic Swimming Center. Cindy McIngvale, bronze medalist from the threemeter board in the Montreal Olympics last summer, won the women's threemeter event with 690.94 points. The title was the 25th for the 26yearold Miss McIngvale. The record is 26, and she has competition remaining in the onemeter and the 10meter tower events.

title: Poverty and Disease in Carolina Low Country Belie the New South Boom
description: BEAUFORT, S.C.  South Carolina's Low Country is a sobering reminder that not all of the vast region below the MasonDixon line is a booming New South. Statistically, Southerners remain the poorest, sickest and worsteducated regional population segment in the country, and it is arguable that these grim facts are nowhere more evident than they are here, despite the successes of federally underwritten efforts to combat poverty and disease.

title: People in Sports
description: Surgery on his left knee that will prevent Mark Fidrych from pitching for the Detroit Tigers until early June was performed yesterday in Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit. The operation was described as routine by Dr. David Mitchell, who repaired the righthanded pitcher's torn medial cartilage.

title: Mr. Randle, Meet Mr. Shires
description: MIAMIHitting people and breaking their bones is frowned upon in the best circles but not in professional football, where it is a common occurrence. In baseball it is not to be tolerated. That is, it is not to be tolerated if the hitter is a player and the victim a manager or umpire. If a manager named Frank Robinson or Billy Martin flattens a pitcher, he is not suspended or fined or scolded and all is soon forgotten. When the headlines announce that Len Randle, a member of the Texas Rangers, has filed a grievance against the club after punching Frank Lucchesi, the manager, into the hospital, the impulse is to hoot incredulously, unless you look beyond the headline. Randle has been suspended indefinitely pending a hearing before his employers. That is proper. He will be disciplined, and should be. However, the penalty should be commensurate with the offense. To ensure against excessive penalties, the basic agreement between players and owners gives the player the right to an impartial hearing, provided he asks for it by filing a grievance.

title: Letters: On Human Rights Covenants
description: Your March 20 editorial Rhetoric and Reality, among other things, takes the President to task for promising to win American ratification for the International Covenants on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights and on Civil and Political Rightsdocuments that the United States has refused to sign because their provisions seemed to justify denials of rights that Americans deem important.

title: Westgate Sues Accounting Firm, Citing Costly Professional Errors
description: SAN DIEGO, March 31(AP)A nationally known accounting firm is being sued by trustees of the WestgateCalifornia Corporation and its subsidiaries, whoclaim $15 million was lost because of negligence by the firm, Alexander Grant & Company.

title: TEANECK PROPOSES SABBATHLAW CHANGE
description: TEANECK, March 31  Three school board members who had approved restrictions on Sabbath activities called last night for changes in the policy because of divisions it has created in the community.

title: Reserve Report
description: In Billions DAILY AVERAGES

title: National Guard Planes Grounded
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)The Air Force said today that about 350 F100D Super Sabrejet fighters flown by Air National Guard units had been grounded until an investigation of their fuel system could be completed. Spokesmen said that the investigation had been touched off by a crack that caused a fuel leak resulting in partial power loss to an Oklahoma Air National Guard plane earlier this month.

title: Know Thy Enemy
description: WESTPORT, Conn.To revisit Argentina after more than three years' absence is a revealing experience.

title: Music: Crumb's Sequence
description: GEORGE CRUMB'S Dream Sequence (1976), which received its New York premiere at Wednesday's concert of the composer's music at the Whitney Museum, seems just that.

title: Reorganization Bill Sent to Carter
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)Congress gave President Carter the authority he sought to reorganize Federal agencies when the Senate voted without dissent today to send the bill to the White House for his signature.

title: Round Valley Reservoir a Deathtrap for Unwary
description: LEBANON, March 31The Round Valley Reservoir. New Jersey's deepest lake, has become a deathtrap in recent months for unwary fishemen and conoests, just as the state was trying to turn it into a major recreation area.

title: Excerpts From Gromvko Statement on Vance Talks
description: MOSCOW, March 31 (AP)Followfrig are excerpts from the text of a statement today by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, as translated from Russian by the official press agency Toss.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: The Voices of America
description: The United States has long addressed the peoples Communist Europe in three broadcast voices and President Carter wants to turn up the volume. The governments on the receiving end object, but if there is any value in the EastWest propaganda contestand we think there isthe evolving American effort has become reasonably rational and deserving of increased support.

title: Williams of Pratt Is Impressive As New York Stars Roll, 133122
description: Larry Williams of Pratt was in with some big company in the Big Apple Classic charity basketball game at St. John's last night, and there were a lot of important eyes on him belonging to scouts from the National Basketball Association. He may have opened a few of those eyes.

title: Art: Potpourri At Fourcade's (II)
description: XAVIER FOURCADE'S first house miscellany at 36 East 75th Street was a difficult act to follow, so startling was the mix of big and small, old and new, familiar and unknown.

title: Holiday Week Calendar for Churches and Concert Halls
description: Following is a list of sonic of the special services with music, as well as other events, planned for the Easter holiday in churches and concert halls in New York City.

title: New Face
description: HE GLIDES around the stage like a hungry python looking for a meal. Sinuous, oozing malevolence, he is the personification of nameless evil. Except that he has a nameMefistofeleand he is being performed with devilish elegance and skill by the basso Samuel Ramey in the New York City Opera's popular production or the Boito opera.

title: British Tories Win Key ByElection
description: LONDON, Friday, April 1The Conservative opposition inflicted another painful defeat on the Government of Prime Minister James Callaghan last night, winning a parliamentary seat that had been a Labor Party stronghold since its creation.

title: Selling the Army's Recruiting Service
description: Please excuse the heresy, but there are some things that advertising can't sell. In many cases the most that can be expected of advertising is that it awaken enough interest to generate a lead for a salesman to follow up on.

title: Guitars in the Cathedral
description: Carl Ash and Mark Scanga will offer a program of classical guitar music tomorrow at 2 P.M. in the Cathedral of St. John the DiVille, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. Admission is $2. The concert, part of the Auchincloss Rug Concerts series, will be in the cathedral museum.

title: Crash Black Boxes Flown to U. S.
description: SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE, Canary Islands, March 31 (AP)Four electronic boxes and a tape recording that may answer some of the questions about aviation's worst disaster were flown to Washington today on a Spanish military plane.

title: Noted Scientist Ends His Exile After 25 Years
description: Even keeping in mind the ancient Greek admonition against judging any man happy until he is dead, it would seem safe to say that the long odyssey of Joseph H. Cort has ended without bitterness and with the possibility, at least, of scientific accolade and wealth.

title: A Budget Fix Is Not a Mass Transit Policy
description: Does the Carter Administration have a serious policy on urban transportation or is it merely looking for expedients to hold down the budget deficit?

title: Internal Security Panel Abolished in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)The Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Internal Security quietly faded away today as a result of a committee reorganization.

title: In Moscow, Harsh Words
description: MOSCOW, March 31In the wake of the failure to make progress toward a new agreement to limit strategic arms, Moscow's relations with Washington have reached their most delicate, if not vulnerable, point since strains in d tente appeared in 1974. Only hours after Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance wound up his visit, the mood in Moscow has charged from regret to recrimination, with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, calling an extremely rare news conference to blame the United States for lack of movement in the arms negotiations.

title: EXCONSUMERS AIDE CHARGED WITH THEFT
description: A former official of New York City's Consumer Affairs Department was arrested yesterday in the theft of $35,000 in fines that had been paid to the department by private carters.

title: Noted Scientist Ends His Exile After 25 Years
description: Even keeping in mind the ancient Greek admonition against judging any man happy until he is dead, it would seem safe to say that the long odyssey of Joseph H. Cort has ended without bitterness and with the possibility, at least, of scientific accolade and wealth.

title: PARETVTS/CHILDREN
description: When it was disclosed recently that two girls had died of diphtheria, the New York City Health Department began receiving numerous calls from frightened parents who wanted to know how to immunize their children against the disease. Virtually all of their children it turned out, had already been immunized.

title: G. & W. IS SUED ON OFFER FOR MADISON SQUARE STOCK
description: In a class action seeking damages of $43.5 million, Amy Kohn of Boston yesterday sued Gulf and Western Industries Inc. in Federal District of New York in an effort to block G.&W.'s offer to buy. Madison Square Garden shares at $10.

title: Mayor of Honolulu to Enter a Plea Of Not Guilty Today in Bribe Case
description: HONOLULU, March 31Mayor Frank Fasi says he will plead not guilty in Circuit Court tomorrow to the charge that he arranged a bribe of $500.000 from a real estate developer and collected part of it..

title: G.O.P. LIBERAL GROUP OPENS A FUND DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  Liberal Republican activists are organizing a national drive to recruit and help finance candidates of their political persuasion in the 1977 and 1978 elections, soliciting funds from Democrats and independents in the process.

title: N.F.L. Limits Number of Hits On Receivers
description: PHOENIX, March 31The National Football League adopted four minor refinements of the playing rules today, tabled three others, rejected two and decided that the use of television replays to help officals make their calls was not practical at the present time. The league also placed Seattle in the Western Division of the American Conference immediately instead of waiting until 1978. That step makes no practical difference, except for the place in which the Seattle record will he listed, since the secondyear expansion club is playing a specialschedule pattern in 1977.

title: 2 Nominated for Indy Race
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 31 (UPI)Gordon Johncock, the defending national driving champion, and Wally Dallenbach were nominated today for cars entered in the May 29 Indianapolis 500mile race. Johncuck, of Phoenix, Ariz., who won the 1973 race, and Dallenbach, of Basalt, Colo., will drive cars entered by the GoodyearPatrick team.

title: A German Century Of Art on Display
description: ONE OF THE things that we have in the galleries this weekend is 100 Years of German Art. There is no one show of that name. No one got together with anyone else to make such a conspectus. But what we get, nonetheless, are three shows, three decades and three Germanies. Not one of those Germanies is the regimented unanimous nation that gave us so much trouble through so much of the last hundred years. They are free Germanies: paradigms of the creative impulse, no matter how we may finally rank them in the hierarchy of creative achievement.

title: Ruby Introduced Oswald as C.I.A. Agent, Woman Tells House Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)Investigators of the House Assassinations Committee told committee members in a secret briefing this month that a woman who worked in a Dallas nightclub before President Kennedy was assassinated was willing to testify that Jack Ruby introduced Lee Harvey Oswald to her and to others as Lee Harvey Oswald of the C.I.A.

title: Memorial Services
description: GUESTFrank. A memorial mass in honor of Rear Admiral Frank B. Guest, Jr., USNR, Commander, Military Sealift Command, Atlantic, will be celebrated by Bishop James Killeen of the Military Ordinariale on Monday, April 4 at 12:45 P.M. at the Holy Family Church, 315 East 47th Street, New York City. The family will receive guests in the reception area of the church before and after the mass. The family has requested that expressions of sympathy be made in the form of donations to the American Cancer Society.

title: Antiques
description: EMILE GALLE and Ren Lalique, two luminaries of the French design scene, overlapped each other's careers at the turn of the century. But, as can be seen in an auction today and in two books published recently, they conceived and produced dramatically different works.

title: EFFORT MADE TO END IMPASSE ON JOBS BILL
description: WASHINGTON, March 31House and Senate leaders met today and appeared to be nearing a compromise that would break a threeweek deadlock that has stalled President Carter's $4 billion public works employment program.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Art People
