title: An Ambitious New Series Brings the American Short Story to TV
description: what the novel was to England and France, the short story has been to America. Tuesday evening at 8 on Channel 13, lovers of the American short story will be able to watch a dramatization of F. Scott Fitzgerald's Bernice Bobs Her Hair, adapted and directed by Joan Micklin Silver and starring Shelley Duvall and Bud Cort. The presentation will mark the premiere of a sixpart series under the umbrella title of The American Short Story.

title: ...Poor Nations Are the Buyers
description: RIO DE JANEIROIt might have been expected that the sudden rise in oil prices in 1973 would stimulate purchases of armaments by the Middle Eastern oil countries, and that has indeed occurred. However, it might also have been expected that the added burden of more expensive petroleum, inflated prices for manufactured imports and rising balance of payments deficits might have curbed arms purchases by the nonoil producers among the developing nations. That has not happened. In fact the poor countries are increasing purchases of foreign armaments at a faster rate than any other group of nations, often to the severe detriment of their standard of living. Last year, for example, developing countries that do not export oil accounted for almost a quarter of United States arms salesagainst only 5 percent in 1974.

title: A Just Policy For Welfare
description: MUCH DISCUSSION is going on in Connecticut about the level of payment to our citizens on welfare. At present those payments are generally tied to 1971 costofliving index for basic subsistence. People can't make it on that amount. There are many different proposals concerning the level to which payments should be raised. Discussion on these proposals has created a plethora of charts, figures, graphs and statistics that center mainly on the economic aspects of the question: How much will it cost, where do we get the money, is it fiscally responsible?

title: Guadalajara: The Biggest Small Town in the World
description: Not much moved by press stories of Mexico's political miseries, gyrating economy, rising crime rate and flattened tourism, my wife, Gerda, and I decided to take a 1977 breather in Guadalajara, Mexico's second largest city, 600 miles from the Texas border and 350 miles from Mexico City.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayChicago International K.C. dog show and obedience trial, International Amphitheatre, 4300 South Halsted Street;8 A.M. to 8 P.M.: 3.811 dogs.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: I strongly object to the county administration's trying to make it appear as though the Committee on Budget and Appropriations chose to reduce the money appropriated for the parks summer help program [March 6]. Nothing could be further from the truth. In fact it was the original suggestion of the Board of Legislators that additional funding be appropriated for summer youth employment and for assistants at the Devreaux Marshlands and the Muscoot Reservation. The last two posts were vetoed by the County Executive, and the Board revised its recommendation to increase money for summer employment when the County Executive assured legislators that there was sufficient funding in the 1977 budget for that purpose.

title: Security Is at Issue in Nurses Trial
description: DETROIT, April 2It was late at night. The Ann Arbor, Mich., Veterans Hospital was quiet. Only a small staff was on duty a guard checking doors, a phone operator off the main lobby, an administrator in a backoffice, several doctors attending patients and one or two nurses in most of the 13 wards. Perhaps 55 employees in all were scattered throughout the 10floor, multiwing institution.

title: 5 Guilty in East Chicago Fraud
description: HAMMOND,, Ind., April 2 (UPI)A Federal court jury yesterday found five men guilty of charges stemming from the theft of $8.3 million in a $25 million sewer project in East Chicago. They were the former East Chicago sanitary district superintendent, Cornel A. Leahu; Ernest Hamilton and Charles Schubert, directors of RSH Associates Engineering; Charles Fitzgerald, president and director of the Fitzgerald & Stutz construction concern, and Alfred Kovach, who was an aide to former East Chicago Mayor John Nicosia.

title: Wanted: A Home For New Lyric Theater
description: Last week on this page, a letter signed by 10 composers and directors, all of them creatively involved with American musical theater, brought up several interesting points: 1) most of the major works written for the lyric stage in this country over the past 40 years have been produce? by America's theaters rather than our opera houses which have become hopeless in this respect; 2) since the financing of high quality musical theater on a commercial basis is now virtually impossible, the establishment of a permanent and nonprofit theater is necessary in order to revive worthy works and to encourage new ones; and 3) music theater is, the letter concludes, an ancient and very contemporary art form and it only needs a chance to continue evolve and touch people.

title: GARDENING
description: Just when everything seems to be going rightspring is here, the lawn has been fertilized and some of the first vegetable crops are plantedthere comes news that', for gardeners, trouble is brewing.

title: In Memoriam
description: CANTORJulius. In Cherished memory of beloved husband, father and grandfather, Died April 7, 1947.

title: Mrs. King and Miss Evert Gain Final
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., April 2 Early this week, the 33yearold Billie Jean King said there was no way she could reach the final of the $110,000 Family Circle Magazine Cup tennis tournament. and that she had entered solely to get match tough.

title: Suburbanites Who Like Imports
description: A number of suburban Westchester County families have switched from big American station wagons to smaller imported carsand like what they find in the way of convenience, practicality and quality.

title: The Merger Tempo QuickensIn Public and Private
description: Corporate merger hunters, Wall Street's breed of cloak and dagger operatives, mounted two attacks last week. One was an open frontal assault and the other remained wrapped in secrecy.

title: The New Ethics Code Strictly Limits Outside Earnings
description: WASHINGTONThe most intense debates in both the House and Senate on the code of ethics have centered on the provision that would limit a legislator's outside earnings to $8,625, or 15 percent of his official salary. The debates have drawn attention to the importance of outside income to members of Congress and pointed out some important differences in the ways that they earn it.

title: Music: Lincoln Chamber Society
description: Had everything proceeded according to plan, the program of Lincoln Center's Chamber Music Society Friday night in Alice Tully Hall would have followed the society's wellestablished pattern: a Baroque work (Handel's Sonata in G minor for Oboe, Violin and Continuo), a standard classic (Schubert's Trout Quintet), a revival from the Romantic period (Bottesini's Grand Duo Concertante for Violin, Contrabass and Piano) and a contemporary work (the world premiere of Stephen Burton's Piano Trio).

title: OffSeason Along the Nile:
description: My friend Stephen suffered a tourist's nightmare when everything went wrong during his threeday offseason group tour of Aswan, an Upper Nile winter resort 500 miles from Cairo. He was roused at 3 A.M. for an hour's flight to Abu Simbel where only 45 minutes were allotted to see the monuments. He watched all 18 of his fellow travelers fall ill to stomach disorders after the secondclass hotel served the same miserable meal three nights in a row. And he could not even seek refuge in his room, since two persons in the tiny double were one too many.

title: The ABC's of Flying To Miami by Charter
description: Along with the birds, many thousands of us fly south each year to escape wintry blasts. The season, it's called in Florida. For those who headed for Miami during the 197677 season, there was a new flight optionthe A.B.C., for advancebooking charter. It was cheap; I tried it; I liked it.

title: GARDENING
description: Just when everything seems to be going rightspring is here, the lawn has been fertilized and some of the first vegetable crops are plantedthere comes news that, for gardeners, trouble is brewing.

title: On the Many Virtues of Growing Hybrid Broccoli
description: When a vegetable plant produces good crops five months out of the year, even though our frostfree season is only four months, it deserves a place in my garden.

title: At Rutgers, It's the Sound of Chopin
description: WHEN the Rutgers University Orchestra sounds the last note of Frederic Chopin's Concerto No. 2 for piano and orchestra next Nov. 20,a feat never before achieved will be complete.

title: Bartram's Garden: The Legacy
description: On the lower Schuylkill River in an industrialresidential area embodying some of Philadelphia's worst features is one of early America's surviving glories: pioneer botanist John Bartram's house and garden. The Schuylkill at this point is polluted with industrial wastes, its banks fringed with unsightly encroachments of industry and commerce. Yet here in the southwestern part of the city the spirit of The American Linnaeus lives onhis restored 18thcentury house a sentinel guarding his legacy, his garden a continuing living link with the past.

title: Bridgeport JaiAlai Canceled by a Strike
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 2 (AP)Striking jaialai workers here manned picket lines today, forcing officials to cancel the matinee and evening performances and closing the arena until further notice.

title: Urban vs. Suburban
description: LAST month, I attended a conference at Kean College and Livingston College sponsored by the Union County and Middlesex Cultural and Heritage Commissions, agencies of the Boards of Chosen Freeholders. The seminars were advertised as a means of preserving communities. For two days, I heard of Federal, state, historical preservative, financial, legal and local techniques for saving the neighborhoods of Union and Middlesex Counties.

title: Lev N. Revutsky, Composer, 87; Taught at the Kiev Conservatory
description: MOSCOW, April 2 (UPI)  Lev N. Revutsky, the Ukrainian composer, has died at the age of 87 after a grave and prolonged illness, according to Kiev newspaper.

title: Law Gives New York Businesses Preferred Status on State Work
description: ALBANY, April 2A bill that was quietly passed by the Legislature last year will go into effect this month, giving New York State businesses preferential treatment in terms of state purchasing.

title: Red Rum Wins at Aintree 3d Time
description: AINTREE, England, April 2 (UPI)Red Rum, the wonder horse of steeplechase racing, more than lived up to his trainer's prediction today and won the historic Grand National a record third time in the most onesided running in 20 years.

title: PLANNERS QUESTION HUDSON WATER PLAN
description: An independent planning group for the tristate New York metropolian area raised doubts last week about the proposed $3.7 billion plan to skim water from the Hudson River and supply Westchester County, New York City and Nassau County. The group suggested that water conservation and sharing might be a better idea.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN a tall extension ladder is used around the outside of the house to climb up on the roof, or to get up to one of the dormers, one commonsense safety precaution usually recommended is to have an assistant hold the bottom of the ladder to keep it from slipping when the person who is climbing is up near the topespecially if he must step off the ladder and onto the roof to get the job done.

title: K.L.McAlpine Has Nuptials
description: St. Luke's Episcopal Chapel in Darien, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Kimberly L. McAlpine, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Wallace A. McAlpine of Toledo, Ohio, to William J. Clark Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark of Rowayton, Conn. The Rev. James E. Annand performed the ceremony.

title: Article 19  No Title
description: Anthony Noto, above, and Louis Howard, Suffolk legislators, think President Carter's limited amnesty went too far. Ron Kovic, right, disabled veteran, says it did not go far enough. David Minugh, deserter, with his wife in Sweden. To their left: His mother and father, who was disillusioned with Washington. Bottom: Roselle Stewart, whose son was punished for his antiwar stance.

title: WOMEN'S WAGES FALL EVEN FARTHER BEHIND
description: Despite changes in the nation's economy and technology, women workers remain segregated in occupations and the earnings gap between women and men is widening, according to a report based on Federal data and other studies by Louise Kapp Howe in a new book, Pink Collar Workers.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN ia tall extension ladder is used. around the outside of the house to climb up on the roof, or to get up to one of the dormers, one commonsense safety precaution usually recommended is to have an assistant hold the bottom of the ladder to keep it from slipping when the person who is climbing is up near the topespecially if he must step off the ladder and onto the roof to get the job done.

title: Miss Chlumsky Fiancee Of Paul Arthur Stevens
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Chlumsky of Naples, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Lynn Chlumsky, to Paul Arthur Stevens, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Lawrence Stevens of Cresskill, N.J.

title: Marriott Comes to Stamford
description: THE LANDSCAPING around the new Marric?t Hotel in Stamford was behind schedule thanks to the rough winter but inside the 18story structure, the myriad chores that go into a hotel opening were completed on schedule by a task force brought in from around the country as well as from Europe and the Middle East.

title: A Village in Fear
description: THE dozen shopkeepers at Vista Center in Lewisboro admit that strangers entering their shops lately make them nervous. Like Betty and Nate Chatterton of New Canaan, Conn., who own and operate the Tag Sale Market Place in Vista, they are worried about increasing burglaries in the center, just as they and the rest of the community were shaken by the murders on March 2 of two townspeople, 31yearold Bonnie Minter and 38yearold Shelia Watson.

title: 45 Posthumous Dream Songs
description: JOHN BERRYMAN wrote in 1948, about Dylan Thomas, that what is eccentric is imitated from Tomas more often than what is normal and profound.

title: Mary Duke Fiancee Of Robert Davis Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Duke Jr. of Baltimore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Deborah Digges Duke of New York, to Robert MacLean Davis Jr., son of Mrs. Davis of Fort Myers, Fla., and the late Mr. Davis.

title: ARTHUR N. OTIS
description: Arthur N. Otis, chairman of the board and director of the Merchants Refrigerating Company, at 850 Third Avenue, died Thursday in Sarosota, Fla., at the age of 83.

title: DINING OUT
description: ANN's CLAM BAR really is not a clam bar at all. In fact, the attractive menu drops Clam Bar entirely. Seafood is still important, but Ann's is actually a fullrange Italian restaurantand has been for many years.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BELL & BARTER THEATER. Church Street, RockawayHot I Baltimore. Friday through Sunday, 8 P.M. (through April). $3.50; students and the elderly, $3; group rates. (201) 6279727.

title: Nancy Munder Is Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Munder of Fort Salonga, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Lynn Munder, to Joel Kirk Pondelik, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Pondelik of Riverside, Ill. A wedding in July is planned.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: men's room); it declares the theater a game, with silly but useful rules, and asks us to take delight in the game and the silly rules both. What is particularly remarkable about Miss Dannerin how many respects have I found her remarkable by this time?is that she is able to put manner and meaning together, to stylize herself sufficiently to let us know that we are playing for kicks and not for keeps and then to hint thatbehind it allthere's a living, breathing sensibility capable of being cut to the quick. Elegant work.

title: Images of Yesterday
description: THIS WAS CONNECTICUT Images of a Vanished World is much more than an anthology of photographs of the state from mid19th century to World War I. It is an eloquent visual essay sketching Connecticut's historical development during the time when its beautiful countryside and old towns were feeling the impact of the Industrial Revolution and automobiles and railroads.

title: Austerity Stalks Library Stacks
description: ECONOMIC strains have hit Westchester County along with the rest of the nation. As city, town and village governments have found it politically expedient and financially prudent to tighten their belts, among the first Objectives of new budgetary strictures Were the county's public libraries, most of Which have been primarily supported by property taxes paid by residents Of all communities.

title: An Irish Flautist Is Cultural Rage In LondonEven on the TShirts
description: LONDON, April 2A bearded Irish flute player, of all things, is the new wunderkind of the British musical scene.

title: Both Sides Amit Failure
description: GENEVA, April 2 (Reuters)Industrialized and developing countries alike admited failure tonight in their efforts to agree on a projected international common fund for financing commodities.

title: What's a Week Without the Blues?
description: GRANDDAD explains how it happened: It all started back in 76. Old was bad, so the General Assembly decided to repeal some old laws. Blue laws, they called them. Without the blue laws, business could be done seven days a week. Sundays had been like holidays, but without the old law anything could be done on Sundays.

title: COURT RULES DEFENDANTS MAY CHALLENGE AFFIDAVITS
description: CONCORD, N.H., April 2The New Hampshire Supreme Court has overturned the 1974 conviction of a man for possessing more than one pound of marijuana and has granted defendants the right to challenge police affidavits used to obtain search warrants.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Nazi Bookstore Wrecked on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 2 (UPI)A Nazi bookstore was demolished last night by about 50 persons swinging tire irons and axes. Two men were arrested, Morris Weiss, 55 years old, a survivor of Auschwitz who lost his entire family in the death camp, and his son. Allen, 24. They were charged with assault and malicious mischief.

title: Brief Period of Unemployment
description: In appointing Nikki Van Hightower as affirmative action specialist only minutes after the Houston City Council abolished the post she held as women's advocate, Mayor Fred Hofheinz has demonstrated what a little male determination can do. The allmale councillors were irritated by Mrs. Van Hightower's participation in demonstrations for the Equal Rights Amendment and abortion. The Mayor's assertion of his right to hire and fire will give Mrs. Hightower the same salary and the same functions she had in her old job, the only such post in major American cities.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: Saturday, April 2. 77th day. Weather showery for five races, rainy thereafter; track fast for five races, muddy thereafter. 1977. by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: Elkhound Gains Final At Chicago
description: CHICAGO, April 2Ch. VinMelca's Nimbus, owned by Patricia Craige and Harold Shuler of Monterey, Calif., outdistanced the other hounds in a very competitive group tonight at the International Kennel Club's allbreed show in the Amphitheater.

title: Viscount Radcliffe Dies at 78; A Distinguished Legal Authority
description: WARWICK, England, April 2 (AP)Viscount Radcliffe, one of Britain's most noted legal authorities, died today at his home here. He was 78 years old.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: THERE WAS an April morning when I stood alone, higher than any other person in Connecticut. It had been raining when I left my car back in Salisbury, turning to snow the moment the trail emerged from the trees onto the open, windscoured rocks of Bear Mountain's southern flank. Now, crouched in the shelter of the huge, tapering monument that marks the summit, I started toward nearby Mount Frissellwith a ridge just over 2,316 feet above sea level it includes Connecticut's highest elevation before peaking across the border in Massachusetts. But Frissell lies off the Appalachian trail proper and in that weather it was nardly likely anyone had bushwhacked to the top.

title: Francesca Plain Is Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Plain of Passaic, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Francesca Plain, to Myles Barry Fink, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joel C. Fink of Smithtown, L.I. The future bride is a music teacher at St. Mary's High School in Rutherford, N.J. Her fianc is serving an internship with the Housing and Development Administration of New York City.

title: Quebec's EnglishSpeaking Citizens Fearful of Plan for French Society
description: MONTREAL, April 2Almost unanimous hostility was the reaction today in the Englishspeaking community of Quebec to an opening move by the provincial Government to end bilingualism and to establish a basically French society.

title: New Faces of 1977
description: EVERY YEAR or two, a new crop of young politicians springs up in Fairfield County and throughout the nation, eager to test their ambitions and their abilities. Some are fated to sink quickly back into the obscurity of private life, some go on to busy, but undistinguished, careers in public life, and some, a very few, seem to almost burst upon the political scene and begin a rapid climb up the political ladder.

title: Dave Anderson
description: He never could jump high enough to dunk the ball. His hands never were big enough to palm the ball. But he has been the purest basketball player of all. Bill Bradley understood and appreciated the game for the game. And now it's almost all over. He's starting his last week of work for the New York Knicks today in a matinee in Madison Square Garden that's a cruel reminder of the glory years. Many of the Knicks big playoff games at the Garden were in April and May on warm Sunday afternoons. Bill Bradley remembers those warm months.

title: SHOP TALK
description: YOU may have started with stamps, bottle caps, baseball cards or dolls. But once bitten with the collector's bug, you're hooked. This passion for collecting can be allconsuming, lead to lasting friendships, lifetime correspondence or, in rare instances, a business.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: Article 11 No Title

title: New York Legislature Approves a Sharp Increase in Budget of the Crime Victims Compensation Board
description: ALBANY, April 2The state's program to compensate victims of crime for medical bills and for loss of earnings they incur as a result of injuries was given a new lease on life this week when the Legislature, in a lastminute reversal, voted to increase sharply the budget of the Crime Victims Compensation Board.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Asbury Park and Belmar, deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook time.

title: A New Kind of Fiddler
description: MALVERNE

title: The Plight of Alcoholic Women
description: DO YOU add a little vodka to your morning orange juice to help get rid of the blahs or to relax after the kids are off to school?

title: CHESS
description: Shifting an attack from one wing to the other is a strategy originally developed to a fine science by Alexander Alekhine, world champion from 1927 to 1935 and from 1937 until his death in 1946. The need for such elusiveness arises when there are possible targets for attack in separate sectors of the enemy position, but none so weak that it can be taken by storm.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This analysis is based on reports from representative wholesalers and chains with more than 10,000 outlets in the United States.

title: Beetlemania, or Love for a Bug
description: There are Alfa Romeo aficionados, Mercedes mavens, Ferrari freaks. But Beetle boosters take a backseat to no one in enthusiasm for their cars.

title: Dancers Takes The Big StepThe New York Debut
description: Since 1970, Dennis Wayne has relentlessly pursued his vision for a dance company that would be different from all others. While a dancer with the Harkness, Joffrey and American Ballet Theater companies, he did a series of dry runs, forming small groups, reluctantly abandoning them, but always with his basic enthusiasm for the idea undimmed. Finally, last October, he took the plunge on a fulltime basis. With the help and support of principal angel and balletomane Joanne Woodward and second angel Sid Kantor, a fashionhouse executive, he formed Dancers, The undeniable fact that other dance companies are going through economic crises does not deter him.

title: Radio
description: 89 A.M., WKTU: Mellow Child. Children's stories and songs.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN a tall extension ladder is used around the outside of the house to climb up on the roof, or to get up to one of the dormers, one commonsense safety precaution usually recommended is to have an assistant hold the bottom of the ladder to keep it from slipping when the person who is climbing is up near the topespecially if he must step off the ladder and onto the roof to get the job done.

title: 328 Killed, Many Hurt, In Bangladesh Storm
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, April 2 (Reuters)At least 328 people were killed and more than 1,000 injured in a tornado that battered a wide section of Bangladesh yesterday, authorities said today.

title: 3Way Fight for Mine Workers Presidency in June Heightens Fears of Damaging Coal Strike in December
description: POINT PLEASANT, W. Va., April 2The election campaign for the presidency of the United Mine Workers of America is so far stirring little interest among miners In the coal fields here, although it is considered likely to have nationwide repercussions later this year.

title: After Vietnam, a War of Emotions
description: FOR Sidney and Ruth Schwarzmann of Nassau County, the war in Vietnam did not end when the last troops came home. Or when former President Gerald R. Ford declared his clemency program. Or when President Carter, on his first full day in office, signed a pardon for some Vietnam war resisters.

title: Dial M for Manners?
description: WASHINGTON, April 1, (UPI)The latest edition of a governmentpublished telephone directory used by Treasury Department employees has tips for improving telephone manners.

title: Dr. Theodore R. Flaiz, 80; A Former Medical Missionary
description: Dr. Theodore R. Flaiz, a retired medical missionary and director of the worldwide medical program of the Seventhday Adventist Church, died March 26 after attending a worship service near Portland. Ore. He was 80 years old.

title: Ballet: Bejart's Sonate a Trois
description: On April 27, 1957, in Essen for a French company called Ballet des L'Etoiles, Maurice Bjrt created his Sonate Trois. It was one of his first major works, and has been presented by a number of companies across the world. For some reason it has had to wait practically 20 years for its American premiere, which came at the this Theaater on Friday night. It was the novelty of the final program given by Mr. Bejart's Ballet of the 20th Century.

title: Japanese Lead Surge in Sales Of Imports
description: DETROITDub Harris didn't let slip the opportunity to make his pitch, even as he ate a lunch of carryout fried chicken at his desk at Westwood Motors just outside Detroit, where he sells Honda automobiles.

title: DINING OUT
description: HOW is one to rate an Italian restaurant that covers cannelloni with a halfcooked sauce still tasting of flour, yet for the same meal flames a duck with triple sec so that its crisp??skin crackles under your fork and orangesimmered liquid bathes its tender meat?

title: GARDENING
description: IT would be difficult to live in the midst of the Island's aerospace complex and remain unaware of the scientific and technological advances of the last two or three decades. Horticulture has been an important part of our heritage and has attracted increased interest in recent years, yet few gardeners are aware that the advances in horiticulture during this same period have been just as striking as those in other fields.

title: The Effect of Five Actresses on a PlayinProgress
description: Paul Zindel's new play, Ladies at the Alamo, is about five very strong women who are all involved in a sometimes vicious, often hilarious power struggle to gain control of an important theater complex in Texas. The production stars Estelle Parsons, Eileen Heckart and Rosemary Murphy and will have its Broadway premiere Thursday at the Martin Beck.

title: Births
description: Carpenter

title: Epilogue
description: In April 1936, Bruno Richard Hauptmann was executed for the 1932 kidnappingmurder of the Lindbergh Jr. baby. Over the years, as is usual in sensational crimes, doubts about the case have been raised. A letter written by Mr. Hauptmann has now been discovered, and it once again calls into question his guilt or innocence. In December 1935, while awaiting execution in New Jersey's Trenton State Prison, Mr. Hauptmann wrote the 5,000word letter in German to his mother, and in it he insisted upon his innocence. The letter was never mailed. Instead, it was retained by the warden, Col. Mark O. Kimberling, because in his view the letter might have won Mr. Hauptmann sympathy and embarrass state officials already under criticism for the carnival atmosphere in which the trial was conducted. The letter remained in the warden's personal file until his death in 1964, and was kept by his wife until she died.

title: 22Man Police Force in New Paltz Is Suspended After Insurer Cancels Its Liability Policy
description: The 22man police force of New Paltz, N.Y., remained off the job for a second day yesterday, suspended by village and town officials after a liability insurance policy covering the force was canceled by an insurer.

title: Due Process and the Legislature
description: SOON the New Jersey Legislature will once again be tested for its devotion to the concept of due process of law, It has been similarly challenged at least seven other times in the last 20 years and has been found wanting.

title: Tenors Come and Go, But Bergonzi Is Still Bergonzi
description: Carlo Bergonzi is no fool. I look in the mirror and I see myself, the rolypoly tenor exclaims. I know I'm not Tyrone Power. Camouflaged within a smartlytailored, threepiece plaid suit, the 53yearold musician is amiably reporting on the only aspect of his art that has ever come under heavy critical fire. I know they say Bergonzi just stands there, the singer continues, but I do it on purpose. With my build, if I did any more I would look like an idiot.

title: Testing Service
description: AUTOMOBILE mechanics, radiologists, television repairmen, lawyers, accountants, psychiatrists. realestate brokers and cosmetologists are but just a few of the occupations and professions on whom the :public must rely.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: Whether coincidentally or by collusion, the Museum of Modern Art has chosen the best possible season for its show of British drawings from its collections. The show will be there through May 31, and it is a symptom of the slight case of Anglomania which prognosticators foresee for the eastern seaboard this spring.

title: Events Today
description: THE RELUCTANT DRAGON Musical marionette show; 12:30 and 3 P.M., Cottage Marionette Theater, Swedish, Central Park at Central Park West near fist Street. (Admission free. but contributions will be accepted. Reservations, 938.9093.)

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONJust about the time a man from Plains, Ga., moved in at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, a man from Minneapolis turned up at 1775 Massachusetts Avenue at what is sometimes called the other Government. No long lines of tourists wait outside 1775 Massachusetts Avenue, the home of the Brookings Institution. It represents not raw power, as the White House does, but the genteel influence of a university without students.

title: Champion of the Putnam Charter
description: JUDITH AGOR AYDELOTT is 35yearold firstyear law student, tennis and skiing enthusiast, organist, pianist, former choir director and onetime littletheater actress. She is also chairman of the Putnam County Charter Commission.

title: Student Bus in Georgia Accident
description: CARNESVILLE, Ga., April 2 (AP)A bus carrying about 40 students back to New Orleans from a school trip to Washington ran off Interstate 85 early today and struck a culvert. The authorities said that all aboard were taken to a nearby hospital but there were no reports of serious injuries.

title: Pride and Integrity: Pro Basketball Has Changed
description: Toward the end of my new book, Red Auerbach: An Autobiography, I'm asked hypothetically whether I could return to the bench and coach the way I did during my 20year career.

title: It's the Best of the Wurst
description: FOR nine years Werner's Pork Store at 359 Willett Avenue in Port Chester (a village best known for Italian food products) has been like a knoedel afloat in marinara sauce. My customers come from all over Westchester and Connecticut, they know quality and they know where I am, said Werner Heinemann, a heavyset man who originally came from Leipzig.

title: Red Smith
description: FLAMINGO, Fla.Jim Mason, a husky man with a deep tan, was wearing a blue baseball cap with the NY monogram of the Yankees. Up to this year a man of the same name played shortstop with the Yankees, but unless he had aged noticeably over the winter and put on pounds it seemed improbable that this could be he. That's my nephew, this Jim Mason said, my brother's son. Good kid. He's in Canada now with the Toronto Blue Jays. Uncle Jim Mason is a guide who has at least a nodding acquaintance with every fish, bird, reptile and varmint in the millionacre wilderness of water, saw grass and mangrove that makes up the Everglades National Park. Out of Georgia originally, he has lived in this country for 30 years, and he stays here right on through the summer, when, according to local testimony, you can make a swing with a pint cup and catch a quart of mosquitoes. Jim says the mosquitoes will be moving in any day now after the first good rain but they're not so bad if you use a good repellent. He says there is stuff on the market now that beats the stuff Uncle Billy Roberts made famous. Uncle Billy always ate half a plug of Brown's Mule chewing tobacco at breakfast, and mosquitoes didn't bother him at all.

title: FICTION
description: IN some Southern regional writing, there is a tendency to bypass the ordinary processes of individual development in favor of an aura of mystery, as if the shape of human action was determined primarily by occult forces in the atmosphere, climate or topography of a place. Characters possess only indigenous qualities, like indigenous animals or plants. Instead of personalities, they have traditions. Some of the rhetoric of such writing may be seen as a substitute for psychology, as an attempt to bluster up a personality out of supernatural rather than natural influences.

title: Lee Morris Is Married to Robert Birdsong Jr.
description: The Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Lee Frances Morris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Morris of Dersingham, England, and Gladwyne, Pa., to Robert Boyd Birdsong Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Birdsong of Caldwell and Normandy Beach, N.J.

title: The Enchanted Ice World Of Alaska's Glacier Bay
description: The clouds hover above the snowcapped peaks of Alaska's Fairweather Range. The waters of the bay are blue and clear in the afternoon sun. Suddenly a small piece of white abstract sculpture floats by the boat: our first iceberg. Now the anticipation we have felt all day turns to excitement; we don jackets and raincoats, grab binoculars and cameras and go out, some of us on the small deck behind the cabin and some topside, where the view is even more spectacular but the wind bitter, though it is midJuly.

title: Dana Kallmunzer Is Bride Of Dr. William E. Perkins
description: St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church in North Hollywood, Calif., was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Dana Kallmunzer of Los Angeles, daughter of Dr. Bohdan Kallmnzer of Prague and Hana Hodek of Hollywood to Dr. William Eliab Perkins, also or Los Angeles, son of Dr. ana Mrs. James Eliab Perkins of Baltimore. The Rev. Michael G. O'Halloran performed the ceremony and the Rev. Jaroslav Popelka assisted.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on emergency unemployment compensation bill, to extend the Unemployment Compensation Act, which passed, 84 to 11, March 30.

title: A Letter to Society
description: THIS is written in hopes of enlightening someone to my endeavors to accomplish a debt that my inner self feels it owes. I was convicted or seconddegree manslaughter and received a sentence of three to six years in the only woman's prison [the Bedford Correctional Facility] in New York State. At the time of my incarceration I was fully aware that I had taken a lifealthough of no fault of mine, for it was selfdefense.

title: Harmony and Discord
description: WHAT happens when a community orchestra goes professional?

title: James DeWoody 2d And Beth L. Rudin Set May 30 Bridal
description: Lewis Rudin of New York and Mrs. David Begelman of Beverly Hills, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beth Laurie Rudin. to James Carlton DeWoody 2d of New York. The future bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. James C. DeWoody of Texarkana, Tex.

title: CHRO?? CONVALESCENT HOSPITAL
description: Carmen A. Tortora, Administrator

title: Notes: A New Project to Help Out Young Opera Singers
description: Kurt Herbert Adler, general director of the prestigious San Francisco Opera, was in town the other day, and he talked about a new project that his company is involved in together with Affiliate Artists. The latter organization, which in 10 years has seen its budget grow from less than $100,000 to over $1 million, spends its energies placing artists of all sorts (singers, instrumentalists, actors, dancers) in communities of all sorts (schools, towns, industries) in order to develop a cultural rapport.

title: Joseph Peter Molinari Sr., 75; State Supreme Court ExJustice
description: ONEONTA, N.Y., April 2 (AP)Joseph Peter Molinari Sr., a retired State Supreme Court justice, died Friday at Crouse Irving Memorial Hospital in Syracuse. He was 75 and lived here.

title: The Crime of Truancy: Who's Responsible?
description: UNDER New York State law, a youth under the age of 16 can be judged a Person In Need of Supervision (PINS) if he or she does not attend school, The offense of truancy can range in severity from hooky on a warm spring day to complete avoidance of school. Lateness and cutting classes, while less severe, are also forms of truant behavior.

title: Elizabeth Harvey Is Engaged to Michael Shapiro
description: Judge Alexander Harvey 2d of the United States Court for the District of Maryland and Mrs. Harvey of Baltimore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Harlan Harvey, to Michael Edward Shapiro, son of Mrs. Edward A. Shapiro of New York and the late Mr. Shapiro. A June wedding is planned.

title: LETTER FROM NORTHWEST CONNECTICUT COMMUNITY COLLEGE
description: WHAT can one say about a college where whole conversations are carried on without any of the parties speaking a single syllable aloud? What can one say about class lectures delivered in total silence?

title: Dean Makes Them Dizzy
description: JONAH ZUCKERMAN was rebuffed in repeated attempts to deal his 1956 Jackie Robinson for a free agent. Duane Schroen sold the shirt off his backan authentic Al Kaline jersey. Beth Zoile wanted Dizzy Dean cards and buttons because the pitcher was absolutely crazy and obnoxious. Greg Bucking just wanted to eat lunch.

title: CHINA SEEN AS RAISING THE STATUS OF CHOU
description: NANKING, ChinaFrom a photoprocessing plant in Peking, thousands of copies of a picture of three dead leaders have been sent throughout China and can be seen posted in factories and schools. The photograph shows Prime Minister Chou Enlai, flowers in his arms, being welcomed years ago at an airport by Chairman Mao Tsetung and Marshal Chu Teh, who was then Army Commander in Chief.

title: Some Israeli Politicians Soliciting Funds in U.S. Without Registering
description: A number of prominent Israeli politicians and their associates have been soliciting money in the United States for political campaigns at home, possibly in violation of American law requiring registration.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: City Narrows Search for Aide To 3 Choices
description: The sixmonth search by the New York City Council and the Board of Estimate for a $45,000ayear director of a new office to oversee city agency expenditures has failed to move off dead center, Thomas J. Cuite, Council majority leader, said yesterday,

title: Article 18  No Title
description: Article 18  No Title

title: What's Doing in the BERKSHIRES
description: SPRINGFor many years the Berkshire Hills of western Massachusetts have been the celebrated summer playground of the muses. In fall the forest foliage awes droves of visitors, and this past winter the ski areas proved so popular that their managers sometimes closed off access roads to prevent overcrowding on the slopes. But Berkshires people think of spring, which is about to assert her lure, as their time of special splendorthe time when the hills literally come to life. It's the season of the Mayflower (what other could be the state flower of Massachusetts?), known elsewhere as trailing arbutus; the painted trillium, ladyslipper and apple blossom. Flowers bloom among the craggy rocks, and the brooks, breaking out of their long siege of ice, do more than babble: they crackle. All Berkshire County, a 45milelong, northsouth strip of the state, is one big spring garden open to anyone ready to tour or tramp its byways and woodland trails. Great Barrington, the southern gateway to the area, sets the tone. The visitor driving up U.S. 7 in late May finds the length of Main Street banked by rows of flowering crab apple trees.

title: Heads of 5 Lands to Confer
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique, April 2 (AP)Leaders of Tanzania, Zambia, Mozambique, Angola and Botswana will meet here Sunday to discuss the visits of Presidents Fidel Castro and Nikolai Podgorny, informed sources said.

title: Mohawk Valley Auctions
description: For the past hour, the old farmhouse has been yielding quilts and crocks, trunks and rockers, tables, tools and glassware. Beneath hundredyearold trees, farmers, townspeople and antique dealers are arranged on the grass in front of the porch. Some are collectors, some are curious. All are entertained by the auctioneer's banter.

title: In Europe at War's End
description: EUROPE in the year 1946 couldn't wait get some new writers. After a sixyears severance from normal exchanges, publisher gazed at publisher with a wild surmise. Theatrical managers, likewise: People longed for new voices with whom to spend the evening. It was the time of JeanPaul Sartre No Exit and of Albert Camus's Caligula, and never were two new plays more gratefully received. Every theater in Europe wanted the rights to Camus's psychopathic young Emperor and to the unwieldy trio whom Sartre had locked in limbo.

title: Greenwich Zoning: Delicate Balance
description: THE rural back country of Greenwich, with its imposing estates and homes on minimum fouracre plots, is again shaping up as the focal point in a zoning fight. Four years after plans by the Xerox Corporation to put up a headquarters building on a 102acre site in the residential area ran into decisive local opposition, town officials are preparing to deal with the implications posed by that opposition.

title: Roberta Zitman Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Roberta Zitman to Thomas Pannone, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Pannone of Waterbury, Conn., has been announced by the parents of the prospective bride, Mr. and Mrs. William Zitman of Forest Hills, Queens. A wedding in August is planned.

title: SchoolinNorth Salema CenturyAgo
description: EACH day began with reading in the Testament. During this fiveminute interval, passages selected by the teacher were read aloud by designated pupils. Every pupil, sooner or later, had to be sufficiently skilled in reading to be able to master two verses.

title: Yanks Have Little to Fear But Themselves in Race
description: If the Yankees don't selfdestruct in five seconds, they should win their second straight American League pennant this year. They are that strong, but they also are that volatile.

title: Engagements
description: BuslikAdler

title: Cherry Blossoms: Festival in Newark
description: STARTED on a shoestring last year by a group of young people living in the vicinity of Branch Brook Park, the Newark Cherry Blossom Festival is now enjoying incorporated status, has a paid administrative director and is receiving wider support than ever from the people and the business community.

title: Giants, Jets and Redskins Still Await Decision
description: From the standpoint of the Giant and Jet followers, the annual meeting of the National Football League's owners, which concluded on Friday at Phoenix, left unresolved the major, burning issue. That would be the debt, if any, that the Giants might owe in terms of future draft choices to the Miami Dolphins for the Giants acquisition last year of Larry Csonka, and similar possible debts that the Washington Redskins might owe the Jets for John Riggins and the Jets in turn would pay to the Minnesota Vikings for signing Ed Marinaro.

title: ART MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: TV VIEW
description: Nearly three years in the making, at a reported cost of $12 million, featuring a cast of international names, and already the object of some controversy, Franco Zeffirelli's sixhour film Jesus of Nazareth today becomes, as the roll of the marketplace dice would have it, a Big Event on NBCTV. The first half will be shown from 8 to 11 P.M. on this Palm Sunday; the concluding three hours will be presented a week from today on Easter Sunday.

title: A Taut Novel of Disorder
description: IN the title essay of her superb collection, Slouching Towards Bethlehem (1968), Joan Didion draws back briefly from her painful study of the HaightAshbuty dropout to comment on the possible meaning of the social hemorrhaging she has been observing at close range. The drifting, inarticulate children of the 1960's, drugbesotted and prematurely aged, take on for Didion an almost allegorical significance. They are the pitiful casualties of an immense and perhaps inexplicable social change an atomization prophesied by such visionary poets as Yeats, who wrote in The Second Coming, Things fall apart; the center cannot hold;/Mere anarchy is loosed upon the world. Such apocalyptic murmurings have always been with us, the complacent or indifferent are quick to say; what genuine evidence have we for making such statements? Joan Didion's books offer the evidence. Her third and most ambitious novel, A Book of Common Prayer, investigates the consequences of this breakdown over the past two decades, particularly on parents and children.

title: Fashion
description: Sometimes. I look in the mirror and say. Why the hell do they make such a big fuss about me?

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Theater

title: William Bursten to Wed Michele Mandelbaum
description: The engagement of Michele Mandelbaum, a candidate for a master's degree at Adelphi University, to William C. Bursten, a special assistant state attorney general, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. ??ing Mandelbaum of North Woodmere, L.I.

title: Cosmos Romp at Meadowlands, 90
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 2The Cosmos matched the steady rainfall today with a shower of goals on the first day of soccer at Giants Stadium in the Meadowlands.

title: Two Public Hearings Planned by Council
description: The following public hearings will be held by New York City Council committees this week:

title: It's Baseball Time, and Maybe the Game Will Be the Thing
description: Players will continue to complain about their contracts, and owners will continue to cry about their expenses. But there is at least the slight possibility that, starting Wednesday, games on the field will overshadow economic battles off the field.

title: Failing off the Train
description: BITS of apparent insanity can keep us oriented: a man faking soup labels, a man writing a play about men doing nothing, a poet writing an incompetent poet's poem, a man forcing grammar and syntax to simulate, as clockwork simulated the movements of a duck, a few words exchanged in a New Jersey bar. These things, once done, seem to have unaccountably happened (who would take trouble over them?), for Art too pretends to withdraw the conceiving person, while reconstituting spontaneities so that they look like behavior. If you are wise you are not deceived. Assaying for traces of the controlling person whatever offers itself to you as experience, you seek equilibrium in a universe constituted wholly of things synthesized out of facts: magazine articles, nonfictional fictions, doctoral theses, judicial testimony; published nonbooks and reported nonevents; retouched photographs, dubbed recordings, actors, talking dolls; the Ulysses of Joyce and the Cantos of Pound; Beats (pop Franciscans), psychedelics (pop mysticism); Disneyland, the Labyrinths of Borges; interviews, autobiographies, newspapers, surveys; Gulliver's Travels, core curricula; Piltdown Man and the Noble Savage: those eminent writers of fiction Charles Dickens and Charles Darwin; those prolific disseminators of artifacts the Campbell Soup Company and Pablo Picasso; flight simulators, dioramas; and books suck as the one you have just finished reading.

title: River Trip Tips
description: There are three outfitters in Connecticut providing equipment and lessons needed by beginners and those with more experience who want to learn new techniques. There are also numerous other businesses that simply rent boats.

title: 600 South Korean Civil Servants Ousted in Anticorruption Drive
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 2The South Korean Government has recently dismissed about 600 civil servants on charges of corruption and other acts of malfeasance, a senior government source confirmed today.

title: Letters: In Trouble Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: CORPORATIONS FRET ABOUT NEW YORK TAX
description: New evidence that high taxes are a major cause of the flight of big corporations from New York City was made public yesterday by the State Senate Labor Committee.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Leon Uris
description: Leon Uris's editor, Ken McCormick of Doubleday, considers Trinity his bestwritten novel. And Leon Uris agrees. Unhesitatingy.

title: When Whalers Were at War
description: AN HISTORIC reminder of a littleknown phase of the Revolutionary War on Long Island Sound is fast taking shape through efforts of the Darien Historical Society.

title: Duvillard Wins Pro Ski Second Straight Year
description: SNOWBIRD, Utah, April 2 (AP)Henri Duvillard, the French skier, won the giant slalom at the $40,000 Hawaiian Tropic ski championships today and earned 35 points, more than enough to give him his second straight world pro skiing championship.

title: The Haunting Memory of a Son
description: SOUTHAMPTON

title: Plan to Dam the Euphrates River Prompts Fears for Ancient Relics
description: ON THE EUPHRATES RIVER, TurkeyAlmost 2,000 years ago the Romans established the eastern boundary of their empire along this great river as it twisted its way through Asia Minor. When the Byzantines succeeded the Romans, the river remained the frontier of the Christian world until the Turks stormed out of Asia in the 11th century.

title: Enigmas That Can Be Worn
description: TO THE UNINITIATED, it is an astonishing sight to see people standing three or four deep waiting to get into a jewelry store, but to those who know Jose Grant, it's the normal run of things on a Saturday.

title: For Tour Operators: Disappointment
description: The first winterseason A.B.C. flights between the Northeast and Miami were not, from the tour operators point of view, a total success. Several firms ran only half as many flights as they'd hoped, and one dropped out of the program altogether. They offer three explanations:

title: Food
description: In the next few dayspursuant to the traditional Easter feastthe remains of that once plump and clovestudded ham may loom rather large in the refrigerator. And while there is much to recommend in a cold ham sandwichparticularly when smeared with homemade mayonnaise or hot mustardthe moment may come when that, too, palls on the palate.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT'S RECESS time at college about now, and the kids are coming home, Just like old times, including the question you had believed to be settled by their emigration from the house: Who will get the car?

title: Sharon Sides to Be Wed To Peter Suydam in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Burton E. Sides of Mebane, N. C., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Sharon Jeanne Sides, to Peter Van Cortlandt Suydam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lispenard Suydam of Bellport, L. I., and South Bristol. Me.

title: Burial of Pilot Ends A Family's Anxiety
description: VIRGINIA, Minn., April 2Tom Kolstad was buried again today. But this time it was at home, in the slowly thawing ground of the family plot in Calvary Cemetery. And this time his own people were around.

title: RELIGION
description: A religien professor surmised recently that most current theologians, if they agreed on little else, would readily admit that their discipline had been through exceedingly hard times. Even so, while the concept of God survived the wave of Christian atheism a decade ago, at least in the popular mind, those whose profession it is to speak formally of God fell into a markedly unproductive period. The output of noteworthy materials during the past few years has been meager indeed.

title: Juilliard's 20th Century Series Presents 4 New Musical Works
description: There were four new works in the 20th Century Music Series concert put on by the Juilliard School in its theater on Friday night, and they were of diminishing interest almost in the order in which they were performed.

title: You Can't Tell a Booklet by Its Coverup
DINING OUT
description: THERE could be a sign outside Arturo's in Bellerose announcing last restaurant before New York City. It's a fine place to fill up. The food is carefully prepared and impeccably served, something of a reviewer's dream, leaving ,no room for nagging doubts, second thoughts or debates. Arturo's has my wholehearted recommendation. Dining there is thoroughly enjoyable.

title: The Forgotten Crisis Remembered
description: Was it really only two months ago that New Yorkers winced at the news of old men freezing to death under their thin flophouse blankets; that a million workers were laid off for lack of natural gas at their plants; that schools in Columbus closed for a month for lack of heat? It was an honesttoGod energy crisis then. Now the forsythia has flashed into electric yellow, the bitter winds have turned soft and it is becoming, again, the forgotten crisis. But crisis it remains, and it is becoming worse.

title: Relieving Pain: Morphine Can Be Improved Upon
description: Doctors at Veterans Administration hospitals have confirmed a discovery made 30 years ago but since disregarded: Amphetamine plus morphine is more effective than morphine alone in relieving pain.

title: FOOD
description: EVERY European nationality has its Easter specialties, annual attractions to grace the holiday tables. Some are symbolic of the solemn observance while others are clearly seasonal, depending on the spring lamb, herbs, fresh cheeses and eggs that accompany the end of winter.

title: I think everybody's worried about her, but they just don't talk about it.
description: (Continued From Cover)

title: The Collision At Tenerife
description: The collision on the ground of two Boeing 747 airliners at a foggy airport in the Canary Islands has left more than 570 persons dead, and although the crash appears to be the result of pilot error and not airport safety procedures, the adequacy of those standards is already under debate.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: NOBODY was talking publicly except in polite generalities, but strains have developed in the coalition supporting the National Book Awards, which will be announced April 11. Two years ago the awards were taken over by the National Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, with financial support from various booksellers' and publishers' trade associations. Now, after only a year, problems in communication have developed between the Academy and the publishers. The rift isn't irreparable, but the crux of the matter seems to be the august Academy's determination to avoid commercialization and maintain its dignity and control over the awards, and the publishers' desire to draw greater publicity attention to the event. Or as one in the publishing camp put it, to make this a public event, rather than the Upper West Side book awards, a reference to the Academy's headquarters on West 155th St., Manhattan.

title: Hearings This Week By Legislative Panel
description: The following public hearings will be held in the New York metropolitan area by state legislative committees this week:

title: Orchids, Asparagus: An Unlikely Kinship
description: NO ADMIRER of blossoms would mix a bouquet of orchids and asparagus stalks. Nor would a culinary artist boil an orchid for a vegetable course. But in the agricultural research world of New Jersey, the orchid and the asparagus have formed a most unlikely kinship.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Why Science Is Experimenting With Animals to Learn About Humans
description: WASHINGTONFor more than two decades saccharin has been fed to laboratory rats and mice, producing bladder tumors in a small number of experimental rodents, yet only last month did the Federal Government propose a ban on the use of the artificial sweetener by humans because of Canadian tests involving huge doses of the chemical.
