description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Help at the End of the Line
description: HEMPSTEAD

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THE week's economic and financial news seemed baffling, frustrating, even doublecrossing. The national economic indicators pointed up, but the stock market went down. The Commerce Department's key index of leading indicators increased. 0.4 percent in February, showing how early the economy began bouncing back from the severe winter freeze that had dropped the same index 1.2 percent in January.

title: The Case of Robert E. Lee
description: THE marbling process was the work of many hands, not all of them pious, the product of mixed motives, not.all of them worthy. When it was completed, however, Americans would acclaim a rebel chieftain who threatened destruction of their capital for four years as a national hero on a par with Washington and Lincoln; white Southerners would come as near to canonizing a saint as Protestants ever did; and Virginians would worship a god figure, a religious symbol which they and others regularly compared with Christ. They will not willingly be disabused.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayHuntington Spring and Junior Olympics; Thomas School of Horsemanship, Round Swamp Road, Melville, L.I. Green, junior, special and children's working hunters; team military jumping, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Sports Car Association Will Change Leadership
description: Now that the Citicorp CanAm Challenge Series has been restored for 1977, a change in the direction of leadership In the Sports Car Club of America's national staff is assured.

title: Penn Heavyweight Crew Triumphs on West Coast
description: SAN DIEGO, April 2Harvard University, the winner for the last two years of the San Diego Crew Classic, was not here today to defend its title, but the Crimson presence was felt. An ad placed by Harvard in the racing program read Good luck to the IvyCornell, the University of Pennsylvania, Princetonwe shall return in '78, so enjoy it while you can.

title: Robert Caster Is Fiance Of Beth C. Coopersmith
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Coopersmith of Reading, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beth C. Coopersmith, to Robert M. Caster of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Caster of Reading.

title: Amateur Stargazers Build Observatory
description: A MATEUR astronomers will be able to study the moon, the stars and the heavens from a new observatory being built at Washington Crossing State Park by members of the Amateur Astronomers Association of Princeton Inc.

title: A Wildcat Strike by I.L.A.Disrupts Liner's Disembarking Passengers
description: Several hundred arriving voyagers were delayed in leaving a Hudson River pier, and had to drag heavy luggage off the ship as a result of a fourhour wildcat strike yesterday morning by 300 longshoremen.

title: INTERVIEW
description: IT'S going to be difficult to go back, lamented Charles Munat, a 42yearold executive of Xerox Education Publications, who is now, with the blessings and salary of Xerox, on a oneyear leave from the corporation and helping teenagers at Long Lane School, the state's facility for children who have committed crimes.

title: Paradise
description: Its vanished trees once pandered in whispers to the last and greatest of all human dreams F. Scott Fitzgerald

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: After having read Daniel Laskin's essay, Trenton: Some First Impressions (Feb, 27), I feel compelled to respond thereto,

title: An Age of Industrial Psychiatry
description: Industry and psychiatry, two of Americas most popular institutions, have expanded until they overlap. From this merger of business and professional disciplines have come company shrinks, psychological consultants and psychiatrists who have left their practices behind and risen to top executive levels.

title: Future Events Much to Do Before May
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained front the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Deborah Schein Fiancee Of Richard Seidenstein
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Schein of Dallas have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Schein, to Richard A. Seidenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Seidenstein of New Rochelle, N.Y. The wedding is planned for July 30.

title: Margaret Orbe Wed To Joseph Scelzo Jr.
description: Margaret Mary Orbe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence F. Orbe Jr. of Glen Ridge, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Joseph F. Scelzo Jr., son, of Mr. and Mrs. Scelzo of Oradell. N.J.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: ABDEL HAFEZ, 46, OF EGYPT, ARAB WORLD'S TOP SINGER
description: CAIRO, April 2Abdel Halim Hafez, the combination Elvis PresleyFrank Sinatra of the Arab world, was buried here today to the shrill cries and anguished chants of tens of thousands of his fans.

title: Court Bars License Suspension For Refusal to Take Alcohol Test
description: BOSTON, April 2 (AP)Massachusetts drivers can no longer have their licenses suspended for refusing to take a Breathalyser test when the police suspect them of being intoxicated, a Federal court has ruled.

title: Solzhenitsyn's Wife, in Vermont, Deprived of Her Soviet Citizenship
description: MOSCOW, April 2 (Reuters)Natalya Solzhenitsyn, the second wife of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn who now lives with the deported Russian writer in Vermont, has been stripped of her Soviet citizenship.

title: In Belfast, a Power for Peace
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland The doubledecker Shankill Road bus halts at the security checkpoint in downtown Belfast. As soldiers in their drab green uniforms and tains clutch their guns and patrol the street, a policeman jumps on board. He walks through the bus, peeking under seats, searching for bombs and incendiaries. All clear. The barrier slowly lifts. The bus moves.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The American League champion Yankees open the season at 2 P.M. Thursday against the Milwaukee Brewers. After an off day for Good Friday, the series resumes with 2 P.M. games Saturday and Sunday. The Mets play their home opener April 12 against the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Amy Gosling To Be Bride
description: Amy Allen Gosling and Lawrence Alan Cooperstein, secondyear students at the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry, plan to be married June 26.

title: Lynn Rybak Plans To Be Wed in May
description: Lynn Barbara Rybak, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Rybak of Whitestone, Queens, and Robert Aram Kazarian plan to be married next month at St. Illuminator's Armenian Apostolic Cathedral in New York.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 A.M. (Channel 2) Face the Nation: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, Senate minority leader.

title: REP. FRED RICHMOND: A BROOKLYN FARMER
description: WASHINGTON, March 16He's a wellneeded, selfstyled hick from Brooklyn who is on the House Agriculture Committee and can frequently be found baling, hay or milking cows on his frequent trips to the hinterland.

title: Podgorny on Side Trip to Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 2 (UPI)President Nikolai V. Podgorny extended his African tour today to make a surprise visit to Somalia where Moscow maintains major naval and military installations.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: Here are some reminders. . . . Dormant spray to control scales and mites. ... Crabgrass controls spread before lilacs bloom. . . . Fungicide on peaches to control leaf curl and brown rot. .. Uncover perennials and strawberries protected with winter mulch. . . . Prune and feed roses.

title: BRIDGE
description: If there is one area more than any other in which experts miss golden opportunities, it is in defense when deceptive moves are available. This is largely because such plays must be made without apparent thought: They must be stored away in the expert's memory, waiting for the right moment to pop up.

title: Charles Moore Dancers Present Fine Tribute to African Pioneer
description: A firstrate program of African dance that was in itself a tribute to a pioneer in that field was provided by Charles Moore's company Friday night at Pace University's Schimmel Center for the Arts.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market drifted slightly lower last week in continued lethargic trading.

title: Measuring the Moscow Failure
description: It was an open failure openly arrived at in Moscow last week because President Carter chose not to risk a secret success in arms limitation that might later be misunderstood and rejected. He can be secondguessed on that choice, but not by those who just a few weeks ago held that he was blind to Soviet intentions and ready to give away the American store of weapons or by those who wanted a President who would make the American people and Congress his partners in the most delicate diplomatic enterprises. Confronted by an essentially public proposal to curb the weapons race, the Russians felt compelled to respond with an equally public rejection. So a deadlock of nearly two years continues, as do the negotiations. This poses a severe test not only for the rival Governments but also for the public that claims a right to know what is going on. The price of admission to these bargaining sessions is a cool temperament.

title: Around the Nation
description: DUGWAY. Utah, April 2 (UPI)The Army plans to dispose of 1,500 small nerve gas bombs at the Dugway Proving Grounds in western Utah this spring.

title: Edwards Takes 4Shot Greensboro Lead With 204
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., April 2 (AP)Danny Edwards, a slender 25yearold seeking his first pro title, broke out of a threeway tie with a fourunderpar 68 today and established a fourstroke lead in the $235,000 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament. Edwards,who played in the Far East for a year before gaining his American playing rights three years ago, pulled away from challenging Hale Irwin and Larry Nelson with a 204 total for 54 holes over the 6,984yard Forest Oaks Country Club

title: Pakistan Gains Control In W. Indies Cricket
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 2 (Reuters)Capt. Mushtaq Mohammad hit a century and then grabbed two West Indies wickets for only three runs as Pakistan took firm control of the fourth cricket test match here today. At close of play on the second day, West Indies had crashed to 107 runs for five wickets as it chased Pakistan's firstinnine score of 341.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Effort Is the Main Thing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Long Island/This Week
description: CENTEREACHExhibition of Bicentennial tallship paintings by Jess Wright; through April 30; Mondays through Thursdays 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Fridays, Saturdays 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Middle Country Public Library, 101 Eastwood Blvd.

title: Mormons Told to Refuse Welfare
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 2 (AP)An official of the Mormon church said today that church members should refuse unearned welfare assistance, including food stamps, from local or national governmental agencies. Erza Taft Benson, president of the Council of the Twelve of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints (Mormon), told the church's annual conference such programs were characterweakening.

title: MUSIC
description: COMPETITIONS are unkind, unfair and probably fattening; but until somebody comes up with a better system for pinpointing worthy talent, they are here to stay Certainly they are flourishing in Westchester and Fairfield, where a number of contest winners will be reaping the performance rewards of victory this month and next. Other young players will collect their recently won prize appearances next season, and at least two competitions are still very much up for grabs.

title: A Loser Becomes A Spiritual Leader
description: IN HIGH school, I was one of those kids whom people call a loser, says Lee Lozowick, a sometimes flippant, sometimes deadserious young man who is the founder and leader of the religious Community of Hohm, a group of 25 to 30 followers in New Jersey.

title: A Catholic College Helps Serve Seder In a Home's Strike
description: Eileen Blake. a sophomore at the College of Mount St. Vincent, attended her first seder last night, as she helped make Passover possible for 700 patients at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Give New Blood A Chance

title: Costs Are Not Down, But Up, With Changes to Come
description: Like hangover cures, campaign pledges and the rotary engine, nofault automobile insurance may have promised more than It possibly could deliver. Or it may have been merchandised badly. Or it may have been flawed from the srart.

title: British Football
description: First Division

title: NEW CHIEF SEEKING TO REVITALIZE V.A.
description: WASHINGTON, April 2Of all the gray, faceless bureaucracies in Washington, the Veterans Administration has a reputation as perhaps the grayest and most faceless of them all.

title: Holders of $10 Million In City Notes Receive Approval for Repayment
description: The owners of nearly $10 million worth of New York City shortterm notes were given formal approval by the city Friday to present their notes for repayment later this month.

title: Italian Easter Pie
description: PIZZA RUSTICA, a golden cheese and meat pie, is a symbol of Easter celebration that ties many ItalianAmerican families to Italy and their long past. One family that keeps the tradition alive is the Saparitos, who operate an Italian restaurant in New Rochelle.

title: TV Portraits Of Six Families
description: As a hardcore, printbelieving reporter, I have to admit: Yes, it can be done. Yes, real people can be their real selves on film, complete with fights, tears, hugs, soft words and tough. I say this on the eve of the telecasting of the first hourlong program in a sixpart documentary series called Six American Families, which will make its debut tomorrow at 8 P.M. on Channel 13. (In addition to its being carried on other PBS stations across the country, the series will also be broadcast on the five Westinghouse/ Group W stations.)

title: Flood ControlFirst Step Is Near
description: AFTER nearly 50 years of delay and environmental conflicts punctuated by one disastrous flood after another, Federal and state officials are on the verge of implementing the first stage of a floodcontrol plan for the Passaic River.

title: ALLOUT EFFORT CUTS FINNS HEART ILLNESS
description: HELSINKI, March 31 (UPI)A rural county in eastern Finland has for years recorded one of the world's most morbid statistics: More people died there from heart disease than proportionally anywhere else in the world. But no longer.

title: LETTER FROM MANHATTARVILLE COLLEGE
description: IT was the portfolio idea that attracted me to Manhattanville three and a half years ago It was a good idea, but now it's like the electoral collegeobsolete as he? It died before it had a chance to be what it could be.

title: Chinese Boycott Match In PingPong Diplomacy
description: BIRMINGHAM. England. April 2 (AP)Politics intruded upon the world table tennis championships today as the powerful Chinese team withdrew its No. 5 player from a match against an Israeli, Shlomo Mendelson, who emigrated to Israel from the Soviet Union seven months ago. Mendelson was awarded the match by default.

title: Mark Crouse to Wed Ann Esther Schechter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving Schechter of St. James, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Esther. Schechter, to Mark Wessel Crouse son of Dr. and Mrs. John C. Crouse of Woodside, Calif. The couple plan a late spring wedding.

title: Two Film Addicts Get Their Fix
description: HUNTINGTON

title: Petropolitics at Work on Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTONWhen Representative Robert C. Krueger of Texas decided to sponsor legislation that would end Government price controls on new natural gas, he stopped wearing Western boots.

title: The Story of a Marriage
description: 228 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $8.95.

title: Nicklaus and 75 Others Begin Run at Masters Thursday
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 2The Masters tournament, Bobby Jones's 1934 creation that is now the first major championship on the golf calendar, will begin here next Thursday. Favorable spring weather has helped create flawless conditions on the course of the Augusta National Golf Club as well as an exceptionally good showing of color from Augusta's azalea, dogwood, peach and other plants and flowering trees.

title: Sneva Tops Unser To Win Texas 200
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., April 2 (AP)Tom Sneva outdueled Al Unser in the final laps today to win the 200mile Texas Grand Prix auto race. The victory was worth $13,179.

title: THEATER
description: LIFE AS A DREAM and death as the only reality is a theme best suited to faces with a few lines and sorrows etched into them But, by its own admission, one of the strengths of The Company Storethe student arm of the Hartman Theater Companyis the youth of its members And this goes a long way toward explaining why  despite satisfactory staging by Wendy Chapinthe com pany's second production of its first seasonEugene Ionesco's Exit The King'falls short of success. The bright young faces of The CompanyStore suggest a school play rather than a performance at professional level.

title: World of our children
description: A decade ago, the fact that it is Passover wouldn't have meant much to me. My parents were proud of being Jewish, but they never had a seder  the ceremony that commemorates the Exodus from Egypt. When I was invited to seders by friends, I found them alien and somewhat tedious. Besides, I was embarrassed by my ignorance of the Jewish traditions.

title: Margaret Connelly, Teacher, Married to Robert L. Smith
description: Margaret Mary Connelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Connelly of Brooklyn, was married yesterday morning to Robert Luke Smith in St. Ephrem's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. Mr. Smith is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Luke V. Smith, also of Brooklyn.

title: Action Comes at Time of CruiseTrade Loss
description: The wildcat longshoremen's strike at the Passenger Ship Terminal yesterday came at a time of recrimination over who is to blame for New York's loss of cruise trade, the last vestige of the city's great era of passenger shipping.

title: Fashion
description: Winter's been dreary, but spring will be cheery; all the signs point to it. Already the stores are full of bright new clothes, luring us in. But the faces that look back at us from dressingroom mirrors still straddle the seasons, wilted and tattletale gray after months of exposure to icy winds and indoor heat. Our new wardrobes deserve better.

title: Horses for All In Riding Boom
description: WHEN Jill Gottlieb is not talking or thinking of horses she is riding one near her home in White Plains. She goes to the stables as often as possible, sometimes every day.

title: Putnam Ponders Who's to Govern
description: PUTNAM COUNTYa virtual terra incognita separating Northern Westchester from Dutchess that has been one of the fastestgrowing regions in the United Statesis gradually advancing toward what could be an extensive renovation of its obsolescent government.

title: New Lobbyists Organize An OldGirl Network
description: WASHINGTON  Five years ago, when Susan Friday was hired by the National Milk Producers Federation as a legislative representative at the age of 26, she said, Every lobbyist I knew was a man. She discovered later, she said, The assumption on the Hill was that I must be the boss's girlfriend, and wasn't it cute that they let me cover the hearings.

title: Alan Ayckbourn Has Them Laughing Again in London
description: LONDON

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: PAPERBACKS
description: The Tasaday are a primitive tribe so innocent that they have no word for bad, only not good; no word at all for war or evil. This book is an account of their contact with the rest of the world during the three years after they had been discovered. John Nance, an Associated Press reporter in the Philippines, accompanied most of the 197073 expeditions, which descended on the Tasaday from the sky carrying small machines that made pictures and others that recorded the musical language and laughter of people who saw no reason to fear their visitors.

title: STAMPS
description: The nations of the world have come together for the first time to face up to a growing crisis of water, one of the essentials of life. The event has been marked by the United Nations with a set of four commemoratives stressing the need for humanity to preserve its precious store of water now and for the generations to come.

title: Can a Shot of the Secular Bring New Life to Seminaries?
description: A RECENT Gallup Poll on religion in America found that, while belief in God or a universal spirit remained roughly stable during the last 30 years, regular church attendance has been persistently declining.

title: A Mesage From Mao's Widow
description: THIS is a strange, sad book. It is Chiang Ch'ing's attempt to reach out to the world as herself, woman and revolutionary, rather than as Mrs. Mao Tsetung, the former film actress. It is also Roxane Witke's attempt to relay that message out of China and into the West, and to make the message both significant and respectable by treating the material as soberly as a historian.

title: Louis G. Hecht Jr. To Wed Nancy Glick
description: Mrs. Fred E. Manulis of Palm Beach, Fla., and New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Nancy Glick, to Louis Gerstley Hecht Jr.. son of Mr. and Mrs. Hecht of Baltimore. The wedding is planned for June 25.

title: McGinn Rites Scheduled
description: A memorial service for Walter McGinn, theactor, who died Thursday at the age of 40 in an auto accident in Los Angeles, will be held at 11 A.M. Thursday in the Anspacher auditorium at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater complex. 415 Lafayeete Street, at Astor Place. The service will be conducted by Joseph Papp, executive producer of the festival.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BETHELWatercolors and constructions by Robert Andrew Parker. Bethel Gallery, 186 Greenwood Ave. Wednesdays through Sundays 11 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Starts today.

title: Shedding Pounds In a Grand Manor
description: THE white gabled brick building overlooking Manhasset Bay in Port Washington could be a quaint resort hotel. Its 14 bedrooms have gaily colored quilts on the beds, fresh curtains at the windows and color television. There is a beauty salon, a game room, a massage room and an outdoor swimming pool.

title: POLITICS
description: IF THIS WERE England, the clamor rising in the background might be mistaken for the distant cry of the hounds and the sound of the hunting horn, and it might be reasonable to expect, sooner or later, to see a fox scurry out toward the northern suburbs of Hartford or the hills of Litchfield and safety. But the hunters in this event are the state's employers, led by the Connecticut Business and Industry Associ tion and the quarry is neither fox, nor stag, nor otter, but the loafers and fakers whom the employers contend they see in the long lines of the unem ployed, collecting unemployment compensation.

title: Air Force Reverses Decision To Close Pacific Headquarters
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)The Air Force has reversed a decision made more than two years ago to disband headquarters of the Pacific Air Forces in Hawaii.

title: President Greets Vance in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  President Carter greeted Secretary of State Cyrus R, Vance tonight on his return from his Moscow mission and pledged that despite the failure to make progress on strategic arms limitations, We'll do everything we can to strengthen ties of friendship and

title: Basque Cycle of Violence Unbroken in PostFranco Spain
description: ZARAUZ, SpainThe violent torment of the Basque people seems to have no end. Spain inches toward democracy, but in the beautiful green hills of the northern Basque provinces, Spain is considered another place. to the south. Here it is the beatings, tortures, the prisoners and the deaths that are counted.

title: POLITICS
description: ONE nice thing about political campaigns is that they are unrehearsed. Despite the presence of campaign experts who say that this action will get that response, candidates are constantly being surprised when their wellorchestrated moves bring a different response from the one they had hoped for,

title: Reporter Who Testified Spent a Decade Studying Kennedy's Assassination
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 3 (AP)Willem Oltmans, the Dutch reporter who testified before the House Assassinations Committee last week, says he has spe ntmore than a decade investigating the assassination of President Kennedy.

title: Kopelev Reports His Expulsion From the Soviet Writers Union
description: MOSCOW, April 3 (AP)Lev Kopelev said today that he had been expelled from the Soviet Writers Union, apparently as a reprimand for his support of dissidents.

title: FORGERY IS CHARGED IN HAUPTMANN CASE
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., April 1A handwriting expert charged today that ransom notes used to convict Bruno Richard Hauptmann, electrocuted April 3, 1936, in the Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. baby kidnapmurder, had been overwritten with changes she said amounted to forgery.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: CARTER AIDES TO MAP NEW POLICY ON ALIENS
description: WASHINGTON, April 3Top officials of the Carter Administration are scheduled to meet Tuesday to begin shaping a new United States immigration policy that could have significant consequences, not only for the six million to eight million illegal aliens now in this country but also for employers and nativeborn workers.

title: City. U. a RemedialWriting Leader
description: Last May, newly admitted students at the City University of New York were asked to write an English placement exam, and one student began his essay:

title: Rewarding Program Assembled By Toby Appel for Viola Recital
description: Owing to the relative scarcity of solo violists and music written for the instrument, one can generally count on some fresh discoveries at almost any viola recital. Toby Appel assembled an especially interesting program for his recital at Alice Tully Hall Saturday afternoon, primarily devoted to works by 20thcentury composers, two of whom, Ezra Laderman and Rebecca Clarke, were in the audience.

title: The Big Thicket of Texas Is a Critical Year Away From Preservation
description: KOUNTZE, Tex., March 27There is a place not far from here where the ecology of the Southwest meets and mingles with that of the Southeast, where cactus and yucca plants native to the arid sands of New Mexico and western Texas flourish practically side by side with ferns and orchids more at home in the Florida Everglades.

title: Tremors Shake Northeast Italy
description: UDINE, Italy, April 3 (AP)  Four tremors shook a wide area of northeastern Italy's earthquake belt today, causing no injuries but sending villagers fleeing into the countryside, authorities said.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Bleacherites of the old Ebbets Field would have felt at home yesterday in the Queens schoolyard where four tavernsponsored teams opened the season of what some irreverent softball fanatics call the ginmill league. home of the Mets, was the dream of professional ballplayers, with sunshine driving away early clouds and sending the temperature high into the 60's for the games.

title: Chief of Protocol At U.N. Ignores It In Farewell Fete
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 3The United Nations' chief of protocol, Sinan A. Korle, retired last week, bowing out with a farewell party for those he calls my genuine friends.

title: Soaring Polish Debt Worries the West
description: WARSAW Poland's soaring indebtedness to the West is causing concern in both the Communist, bloc and the West and has resulted in a scaling down of investment in this country.

title: Benjamin Appel, 69, Novelist, Dies; Wrote Over 25 Works of Fiction
description: Benjamin Appel, a novelist with more than 25 works of fiction to his credit, died yesterday at Princeton (N. J.) Hospital after a short illness. He was 69 years old and lived in Roosevelt, N.J.

title: Afrikaners Dig In Against Threat to Their Rule
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 3Like the Boer settlers in the old days hunkering down behind their ox wagons for a battle with the Zulus, the Afrikaners who rule this troubled land are strengthening their defenses against the mounting threat to white supremacy.

title: Group Warns on Soviet Expansion
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The Committee on the Present Danger, a public interest group, warned today that the Soviet Union would continue an expansionist policy regardless of any agreements concluded with Western powers, including, accords to limit strategic arms.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 4, 1977

title: Suffolk Scores, Cauthen Doesn't
description: BOSTON, April 3 (AP)Steve Cauthen Day was big and profitable for Suffolk Downs, but not for Cauthen, who failed to win a race in six tries. The crowd that gathered to sec the 16yearold jockey with 186 victories bet $562,956, the highest handle at Suffolk in six years. The attendance of 15,797 was the largest since 1973.

title: In Memoriam
description: PRIEDMANDr. Gedide A. Aug. 2, 1869April 4, 1927. Compassionate physician and devoted father. Lovingly remembered by your daughters Miriam Monkin, Esther Delcourt and Hazel Casper.

title: Red Smith
description: Back in the 1920's, Phil Beiber writes, Walter Reath: was the wealthy owner of a chain of movie theaters, a highbracket horse bettor and an expert on how and when to gamble. He had connections with knowledgeable trainers, and he loved to put over fast deals. For insurance, he always insisted that anybody bringing a proposition to him put up his own money. Then Walter would bet an equal amount for him.

title: CBS Plan to Move Program Staff To Coast May Presage a Trend
description: The decision by CBSTV last week to move its programming and businessaffairs departments to the West Coast is likely to mark the beginning of a migration to Southern California of certain other operating units of all three networks.

title: Letters
description: One aspect of the astonishing Indian election seems to have received little attention.

title: Music:Enjoyable
description: Mordecai Shehori, an Israeli pianist who now lives in New York, made his New York debut in 1974 and gave another recital in Carnegie Recital Hall late last season. Saturday afternoon he appeared as part of a youngartists series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and made a pleasing impression.

title: New York Accused Of Failure to Spend U.S. Community Aid
description: Tens of millions of dollars in Federal communitydevelopment funds allocated to New York City are lying unspent or are being misspent, according to a coalition of 250 community and antipoverty groups in the city.

title: Oklahoma, Indiana State Tie for Gymnastics Title
description: TEMPE, Ariz., April 3 (AP)Highlighted by a pair of brilliant 9.80 performances on the horizontal bar by John Hart of the University of California, Los Angeles, the National Collegiate Athletic Association gymnastics championships came to a close last night with a tie for the team title.

title: Patrons Take Wing as Cockfight Is Raided in Bronx
description: A raid on a cockfight at a crowded afterhours social club in the Bronx was reduced by authorities to a flight of customers and a flapping of wings early yesterday when a stakeout policeman apparently was recognized. Most of the 300 patrons disappeared before the police could move in, and 25 birds vanished along with them.

title: Chirac Predicts Fall of France's Fifth Republic if Left Wins Election
description: PARIS, April 3Jacques Chirac, the former French Prime Minister, predicted today that if the left won parliamentary power in the next elections, as is widely expected, it would be the end of France's Fifth Republic.

title: SOLAR ERA ARRIVING, ENERGY EXPERT SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The transition to a solar era can be begun today, writes Denis Hayes in an optimistic appraisal of the future of sunshine and related energy forms published this weekend by the Worldwatch Institute, a foundationfunded environmental watchdog group.

title: Pennsylvania Boxers Win
description: HONOLULU, April 3 (UPI)Pennsylvania won the team title in the annual national Golden Gloves boxing tournament yesterday. Knoxville, Tenn., was second and Detroit third.

title: Celtics Gain N.B.A. Playoffs With Cavaliers
description: BOSTON, April 3 (UPI)Jo Jo White scored 6 points in a fourthquarter spurt that enabled the Boston Celtics to defeatthe Philadelphia 76ers today for the first time this season, 9690, at Boston Garden.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHING TON, April 3 (AP)The Defense Department has used only a tiny fraction of its massive procurement budget in areas of high unemployment, despite a 25yearold Federal policy ordering such action, a study released today said.

title: Dayan Announces He Will Support Labor Party in May 17 Elections
description: TEL AVIV, April 3 (AP)Former Defense Minister Moshe Dayan announced his support today for the governing Labor Party in the May 17 elections, ending speculation that he would join the opposition.

title: Cosmos Top Tampa, Win Tomnament
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 3The only thing the Cosmos wanted to do after winning the Tournament of Champions today was to rest.

title: Mr. Califano on Quotas
description: The word quota, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Califano has discovered, is a nervejangling word. Last month he told an interviewer for this paper that employment quotas can and do work to reverse patterns of job discrimination. As anyone who has followed the issue might have predicted, that stirred up quite a storm. A group of educators from prestigious universities around the country asked President Carter to disavow Mr. Califano's statement, which they interpreted as an intention to discriminate against whites and males.

title: Evicted Merchants Find Aid For Building Mixed Blessing
description: Up to now the city's fiscal crisis had been something of a blessing for people like Dave Trotter and George Antypas they were able to keep their thriving businesses.

title: South Africa Is Charged With Systematic Torture In SouthWest Africa Jails
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 3Amnesty International has charged that torture is being routinely used by South Africa in the interrogation of political prisoners in SouthWest Africa, the territory known here as Namibia.

title: Assertions About Oswald Confronting House Group
description: WASHINGTON, April 3Last Tuesday, George de Mohrenschildt, a 65yearold selfstyled promoter who enjoyed the company of rich men and beautiful women and had a sometimes dangerous habit of sketching and photographing defense installations in various countries, was killed by a shotgun blast in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Andretti Victor in Long Beach Prix
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 3Mario Andretti trailed Jody Scheckter for 76 laps of the 80lap Long Beach Grand Prix today, then lunged ahead of the South African at the beginning of a hairpin turn and went on to win the Formula One auto race through the streets of this southern California city.

title: Light Before Heat at MitchellLamas
description: The problems of the MitchellLama housing in New York State pose some of the thorniest questions facing public officials today. The program was devised in 1955 as a way to provide private housing for families who earned too much for public housing but too little for the normal market. Its apartment houses have been funded by the state and city with $4 billion borrowed from the public.

title: Airline Tickets Warn on Bumping
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)Airline passengers found new signs at ticket counters today, warning them they might be bumped from a flight. The warning was also printed on tickets and displayed at travel agents' offices. The Civil Aeronautics Board issued the temporary ruling a month ago, to be effective beginning today. The ruling applies to all airlines, foreign and domestic, but covers only tickets sold in the United States.

title: McGinn Rites Scheduled
description: A memorial service for Walter McGinn, theactor, who died Thursday at the age of 40 in an auto accident in Los Angeles, will he held at 11 A.M. Thursday in the Anspacher auditorium at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater complex, 415 Lafayeete Street, at Astor Place. title: A Turning Point
description: WASHINGTON  Informed press speculation has made people aware that President Carter's energy program is likely to involve big taxes, higher prices, stiffer regulation. But those are details. They do not really convey the profound nature of what Mr. Carter may attempt.

title: Leonard Silk
description: The nation waits anxiously for the Carter energy plan. It is taking shape as a spartan, threatening program that one drafter has laconically encapsulated as use less and pay more. Though the particulars remain in flux, nothing in the infighting over details suggests any important reversal in the fundamental Carter strategy between now and April 20, when the proposals are to go to Congress. What will that energy policy do to us? Will it impose a drag on the economy's growth for decades to come? Will it smother jobs and leave breadwinners jobless? Will it ignite new spirals of inflation?

title: Vancouver Symphony Plays in Its First Hall
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, April 3 (UPI)  The Vancouver Symphony Orchestra took up residence in its own concert hall for the first time in its 46year history last night, with a gala opening concert at the renovated Orpheum Theater.

title: Priceless Musical Manuscripts Are Reported Found in Poland
description: LONDON, April 3 (AP)A priceless collection of manuscripts of music by Mozart, Beethoven Bach and others that has been missing since World War has been found in Poland. title: Books of The Times
description: How strange to learn that Ted Gold was a devoted baseball fan. Ted Goldthe Columbia University S.D.S. leader who joined the Weatherunderground and then got blown up in that brownstone an 11th Streetwas a fanatic follower of the San Francisco Giants. He read the box scores every morning. He once said that he would have to wait until Willie Mays retired before he could become a true Communist. Strange. Did he think he could orchestrate a revolution and still go on rooting for capitalist baseball? Had he never learned to put aside childish things? It's not strange; it's ridiculous.

title: 'Aguirre, the Wrath of God' Haunting Film by Herzog
description: In 1560, not quite 20 years after the death of Francisco Pizarro, who had conquered Peru for Spain, an elaborately provisioned party of conquistadores set out from Quito to find the land of El Dorado. It was a fearful journey first to cross the Andes but even worse on the other side. Those who didn't starve, drown or die of fever in the Amazon jungles were in constant danger of being killed by Indians.When it became apparent the entire expedition could not go on, a small task force was commissioned to continue down the Amazon for a week. In command were Pedro de Ursua and his aide, Lope de Aguirre, sometimes referred to in history books as Aguirre the Madman or Aguirre the Traitor. They never returned.Exactly what happened afterward is unclear but it seems that Aguirre murdered Ursua, declared the little band's independence from Spain and crowned a man named Fernando de Guzman, the ranking nobleman among them, "Emperor of El Dorado." He eventually murdered Guzman and was himself murdered by his own men when they at last reached South America's northeast coast.This story, one of the more bizarre and bloody footnotes to the history of the Spanish conquests, is the basis for Werner Herzog's absolutely stunning 1972 German film, "Aguirre, the Wrath of God," which opened yesterday at the D. W. Griffith Theater. The movie was shot by Mr. Herzog ("The Mystery of Kaspar Hauser," "The Great Ecstasy of the Sculptor Steiner," "Even Dwarfs Started Small") on locations of breathtaking beauty (and, I must assume, of horrendous difficulty) in South America, but it's no ordinary, run-of-the-rapids adventure."Aguirre, the Wrath of God" is simultaneously a historical film (to the extent that it follows events as they are known) and a meditation upon history. Aguirre is truly mad, but as played by Klaus Kinski, whose crooked walk and undiluted evil recall Laurence Olivier's Richard III, he is the essential civilized man, a fellow who, in Mr. Herzog's vision of things, must be lunatic.There's an eerie moment in the middle of the film when the Emperor, sitting in rags under an improvised shade on the makeshift raft that is carrying the party down the Amazon, picks at his fish dinner (the other men are starving) and thinks with satisfaction that his "empire" is now six times as large as Spain's. No matter that he too may never eat again, nor that his empire is jungle swamp, the sense of power is so intoxicating that it overwhelms all other considerations.It's as if Mr. Herzog were saying that civilizationour assumption that we have conquered nature or even come to some accommodation with itis as ridiculous as the Emperor's pleasure.From the film's opening sequence, when we see the conquistadores, their women (including Ursua's wife being carried in an elegant litter) and their Indian porters making their way down an Andean slope, looking like the inhabitants of an ant palace, to the concluding shots of Aguirre on his raft in the company of hundreds of tiny marmosets, Mr. Herzog views all the proceedings with fixed detachment. He remains cool. He takes no sides. He may even be slightly amused. Mainly he is a poet who constantly surprises us with unexpected juxtapositions.The film is incredibly rich and lush looking. It is tactile. One can feel the colors of the jungle and see the heat. The conquistadores endure terrible trialswhirlpools, Indian attacks, rebellion within their own ranksyet the mood of the film is almost languid. Ursua's faithful, loving wife, played by a classic beauty named Helene Rojo, throws no tantrums when her husband is executed. She watches and waits, and when the opportunity arises, she walks off to her own death in the jungle as if going to a tea.Contrasting with this peculiar languor is the radiant madness of Aguirre, who hypnotizes his soldiers into following his wildest instructions, who sneers at men who seek riches when power and fame are all that matter, who aspires to be nothing less than the wrath of God and who, at the end, is planning to create a new dynasty by marrying his dead daughter. He's mad but he's a survivor.This is a splendid and haunting work.

title: Henn Outduels Satullo In Power Boat Race
description: ST. PETERSBVRG, Fla., April 3Preston Henn of Pompano Beach, Fla., won the Swift Hurricane powerboat race today, beating the secondplaced finisher, Sandy Satullo of Fairview Park, Ohio. by 14 seconds.

title: Borg Defeats Vilas In 4 Sets at Nice
description: NICE, France, April 3 (AP)Bjorn Borg of Sweden survived a sluggish start today and beat Guillermo Vilas of Argentina. 64, 16, 62, 60, in the final of the Nice tennis tournament, Europe's first clay court event of the season.

title: Island Used as Bomb Range Is Symbol of Hawaii Protest
description: LAHAINA, Maui, Hawaii, April 3The sleeping giant of this state's political, and economic life, the Hawaiian and partHawaiian minorities, is stirring. The restlessness focuses on Kahoolawe, a 45squaremile island 7.5 miles Off Maui that the United States Navy has used as a bombing range since 1941.

title: TV:Six American Families Talk
description: The television documentary may be on the verge of mass acceptance as a tool in a process somewhere between selfanalysis and group therapy. The average citizen's willingness to display private feelings on a public screen is startling, if not appalling. Several years ago we had public television's An American Family, with its ensuing controversy and recriminations in the national press. Since then the intimate television portrait of the ordinary individual has proliferated rapidly.

title: Disbursement of Bergen Funds
description: Northwest$444,000: Allendale, Arlton Ave. reconstruction, $4,000; Glen Rock, central business district improvements, $60,000; Mahwah, Stag Hill daycare and afterschool tutorial programs, $34,900; Oakland, storm drains and sidewalk improvements in floodprone Pleasureiand district, $165,000; Waldwick, drainage and road reconstruction on Hewson and Harrison Avenues, $75,000. Regionwide Health clinics and home nursing visits, $70,000; home improvement program, $54,000; contingencies, $11,100.

title: For Korean Lepers' Children, It's America the Beautiful

title: THERESA M. HYMAN

She was 83 years old and formerly lived in Rockville Centre, L. I. Besides her husband, Mrs. Hyman is survived by a daughter, Dorothy H. Roberts, and two grandchildren.

description: LOS ANGELES, April 3A mood of paradoxical passivity can be detected in the City of Angels on the weekend before Tuesday's mayoral election.

He thumped the table, complaining bitterly and at length about American actions on a lessthanstrategic matter that threatened dtente. Just like the Nazis, he charged, and railed on uninterrupted for fifteen minutes.

title: Topics
description: After years of banishment as a German capitalist composer, Beethoven has again been heard in Peking. The playing there of two movements of the Fifth Symphony will do nothing for the composer's reputation, but it should enhance the lives of music lovers who had to make do, under Chiang Ching's cultural leadership, with revolutionary operas scored according to the doctrines of Mao.

title: Bangladesh Tornado Toll 600.
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, April 3 (Reuters) More than 600 deaths from a tornado that struck Bangladesh Friday have been confirmed, authorities said today. Hardesthit was the Madaripur district 80 miles southwest of here, where relief officials said 596 people had died, 200 them when a motor launch capsized i the Meghna River.

title: Commodities: Soybean Peril

title: Opera: Met's First Samson et Dalila of Season
description: Samson et Dalila, the last opera to enter the Metropolitan's repertory this season, had its first performance Saturday night. Although the production dates back over a dozen years, it is still a handsome affair. Robert O'Hearn's Biblestory sets remain lavishly colorful and Nathaniel Merrill's straightforward direction takes the opera's rather monolithic tableau nature at face value without imposing any fancy interpretations  even the temple caves in at the end with alarming realism.

title: BABCOCK IS FIGHTING UNITED TECHNOLOGIES ON PLAN FOR TENDER
description: The struggle for control of the Babcock & Wilcox Company turned into open warfare yesterday.

Engel, the Federal prosecutor in the case, Mr. Meyers was charged with failure to report $112,000 in income for the two years. The 37yearold defendant was described as an independent floor broker with his own seat on the New York Stock Exchange.

The vote to quit striking and resume negotiations was 186 to 67, said officials of Local 32E of the Building Services Employes Union, which represent 380 arena employees.

title: Monty Waters in Loft Jazz Series
description: The Ladies Fort, 2 Bond Street, is sponsoring a loft jazz festival this month, with a different group performing each evening at 8. According to flyers, the festival is devoted to artists deserving wider recognition, and Monty Waters, who directed a 10piece band at Ladies Fort on Sunday, certainly falls into this category. lid was a leading saxophonist in an Francisco in the 1960's, and since he came to New York, during the latter part of that decade, he has worked with a number of groups. Most recently, he has been heard with the jazz vocalist Joe Lee Wilson and with his own groups, but he has not yet become widely known. A recent release on a Japanese label seems to have been his first album as a leader.

The Chicago Black Hawks, the club with the worst regularseason record of any playoff team will be the Islanders opponent in the twoofthree games series.

Performing more than 50 songs written by John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison and Ringo Starr, the four young actors will be the key figures in a combination of multimedia and simultaneous live music performance that will recreate the frenzy .. . that surrounded the tumultuous 60's.

description: ROCK HILL, S.C., April 4 (AP)The Catawba Indians, who say they own some 144,000 acres of land in York and Lancaster counties under a 1763 treaty, say they are going to ask Congress to settle their claim.

Ford Sr. the Mount Vernon Water Commissioner.

On a cold, gray day all too reminiscent of a cold, gray season of winter racing, it was decided that Saturday's Gotham Stakes, a race to which Seattle Slew might add the hint of mint juleps and spring in Kentucky, would be staged on the inner dirt oval.

This marks a subtle but significant shift in the White House perception of

title: Jobless Reduced to 17 In Tiny Liechtenstein
description: VADUZ, Liechtenstein, April 4 (UPI) This principality of 23,700 people and 62 square miles said today that it was doing all right economically despite troubles elsewhere in the world.

title: Stricker Upsets Thoeni
description: VALMALENCO, Italy, April 4 (AP)Erwin Stricker of Italy won an international giant slalom ski race today, finishing ahead of Andreas Wenzel of Lichtenstein. The fourtime World Cup winner, Gustavo Thoeni of Italy, placed third.

title: Priscilla Smith Will Play 2 Roles in Agamemnon

John Cazate, whose film credits include The Godfather and Dog Day Afternoon, will play opposite Miss Smith in the role of Agamemnon and Aegisthus.

description: WASHINGTON, April 4 New York's freshman Senator, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, bided his time; making no big noises. He listened and achieved his campaign goal of making it onto the important Finance Committee, where. he did shirtsleeves acquired a threestory franie town house in  integrated deighborhood within walking distance of the Capitdl ind quietly entertained a few old friends. His was something of .a! low profile, and in .the words of a colleague he was not id bumptious as we thought he would be.

title: Amtrak Increases Price of Passes Up to 76 Percent for the Summer
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (Reuters)The National Railroad Passenger Corporation announced today increases of 66 to 76 percent in its unlimited travel rail pass tickets in the summer peak travel months.

description: Taking a leaf from critics and guidebooks, New York City Health Department has decided to start giving stars to restaurants that pass its inspections, in addition to publicizing those that flunk them.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: The best selling book in the United States at the moment is not Roots'; it is Your Income Tax. Small wonder. There was a time when taxpayers were supposed to sharpen their pencils on April 14 and make out their taxes; now the process is so complex that half of our 85 million returns are compiled with professional help. The instruction sheets for the first page of Form 1040 consist of four pages, with 15 cautions, 206 if clauses, and references to 39 other I.R.S. forms. A private computer service sells tax regulation information; its biggest customer is the I.R.S. That agency now has 82,000 employees and issues 4,050 different kinds of forms. As in the declining days of the Ming Dynasty, clans compete for exemption and complexity abounds. Some observers believe the system is about to break down.

description: TRENTON, April 4The Assembly's Republicans on the State Legislature's Joint Appropriations Committee proposed today a net reduction of $83.6 million from Governor Byrne's $4 billion budget.

Who would. have guessed say as little as 20 years agowhat Noel Coward's reputation would be today. He was regarded as thin, witty, bitter and slightly acidulated, a reputation that, one would have thought, might have disappeared in a puff of elegant smoke from his own cigarette holder.

title: Mexico to Renew Export Tax Gains
description: MEXICO CITY, April 4 (Reuters)The Mexican Government will reintroduce tax advantages for exporters, suspended six months ago after the devaluation of the peso, the Commerce Ministry announced. Exporters will be able to reclaim up to 100 percent of corporate taxes. The exact percentages will be announced shortly by the ministry.

description: WASHINGTON, April 4  Gen. Andrew J. Goodpaster is the first military man ever called out of retirement to head the United States Military Academy at West Point. General Goodpaster, who retired in December 1974 with the rank of full general, will return to active duty as lieutenant general, but friends say that he is happy to be back in the Army. According to one, he is delighted with this particular assignment.

description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 4 (AP)The Government of Zaire broke off relations with Cuba today, charging that it had uncovered evidence that Cuba was involved in the invasion of Shaba Province by rebels based in Angola.

Reynolds Industries debentures were priced to yield 8 percent; Wells Fargo & Company debentures were scheduled for sale today instead of tomorrow and priced to yield 8.60 percent, and Eastern Air Lines postponed for a week its $50 million offering of convertible debentures.

title: Moynihan: How He Won His Senate Spurs
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 New York's freshman Senator, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, bided his time, making no big noises. He listened and achieved his campaign goal of making it onto the important Finance Committee, where he did shirtsleeves work. He acquired a threestory frame town house in integrated neighborhood within walking distance of the Capitol and quietly entertained a few old friends. His was something of a low profile, and in the words of a colleague he was not as bumptious as we thought he would be.

title: Nuclear Test Postponed
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 4 (AP)An underground nuclear test scheduled for today was postponed because of unfavorable winds, the Federal Energy Research and Development Administration said.

title: People in Sports
description: Six witnesses testified yesterday behind closed doors in Arlington, Tex., at a hearing concerning last week's slugging of Manager Frank Lucchesi by Lenny Randle, a second baseman for the Texas Rangers.

title: GUZMAN RESIGNS AS HEAD OF PROGRAMS AT WBAIFM
description: Pablo Yoruba Guzman, whose selection as program director at WBAIFM contributed to a controversy that shut down the radio station for almost two months resigned yesterday, the station announced.

title: Drought in Northwest Perils Hydro Power
description: SAN FRANCISCOThe continuing drought, which has blanketed the Northwestern section of the United States, has raised the specter of widespread power losses as the reservoirs on which this region depends for much of its electricity become depleted.

title: For Basques, After 40 Years, Day of Truth Is Almost at Hand
description: GUERNICA, SpainFor four decades the big lie has hung over this Basque town, whose very name has become a symbol of the horror of total war in this century.

title: J. TERRY BENDER
description: J. Terry Bender, a former specialcollections librarian and associate professor of library services at Hofstra University, Hempstead, L.I., died Sunday in Franklin General Hospital, Valley Stream, after short illness, He lived at 565 Fulton Avenue, Hempstead, and was 51 years old.

title: Dentyne Gum Account To Young &
description: Young & Rubicam, which began working for WarnerLambert about 18 months ago on smallish projects, has been named agency. for Dentyne chewing gum, out of the American Chicle division with about $5 million in billings.

title: DelBello Sees a Political Motive In Allegations on Waste Disposal
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 4Westchester County Executive Alfred DelBello, responding to Republican charges that he had mishandled negotiations on a multimillion  dollar waste  disposal system, today disclosed details of the negotiations, and countercharged that the Republicans, aware of those details, were trying to embarrass him politically.

title: 30 INDICTED IN QUEENS IN HEROIN CRACKDOWN
description: Thirty persons were indicted yesterday in what was said to be a $50 millionayear heroin operation that led from Queens to Asia and back. Among those indicted was a man accused of running the operation from his prison cell.

title: On Discharging a Vietnam Duty
description: Some aspects of President Carter's order to the Defense Department to review and upgrade an estimated 432,000 otherthanhonorable Vietnamera discharges can be squared with his earlier promise to close the book on that unhappy period.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: British and French officials told New Jersey legislative committee yesterday that the Concorde supersonic jet could net land at Newark International Alrport Unless the runway was lengthened.

title: Sadat Outlines Terms
description: PARIS, April 4  In an interview published in Le Monde today, President Sadat said that some minor rectifications could be negotiated on Israel's West Bank border but that there could not be even centimeter of change on the Sinai and Golan Heights frontiers.

title: CHARLES H. COSTER
description: Charles H. Coster, a former United States vice consul in Florence, died there on Sunday. He was 79 years old.

title: Yanks Beat Mets Despite. Kingman's 2
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.,April 4If a powerful batting demonstration can sway management into agreeing to skyhigh salary demands, lanky Dave Kingman presented some mighty arguments in his behalf at Fort Lauderdale Stadium tonight.

title: Folk Documentaries Capture Intimate Scenes
description: Two young film makers were shooting a black religious service in the home of a Centerville, Miss., faith healer late one night when the unexpected happened. In the midst of pressing, sweating bodies and overpowering gospel singing, the faith healer passed into a trance state and began speaking "unknown tongues," a rapid-fire form of utterance that comes directly from the subconscious."Some people carried her out of the room into another, smaller room," one of the film makers, Bill Ferris, remembers, "and we went in there, plugged a light in and fastened it to the door. It gave us just enough light to shoot. When you're making documentary films, you have to be ready for the unexpected to happen."Mr. Ferris and Judy Peiser, his fellow film maker, were ready, and the dramatic, unforgettable footage that resulted found its way into their film "Fannie Bell Chapman: Gospel Singer," a 42-minute color documentary.The Chapman film and two other recent works by Mr. Ferris and Miss Peiser, "Give My Poor Heart Ease: Mississippi Delta Bluesmen" and "Two Black Churches," will be shown today at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53d Street, and at the Museum of Modern Art. The Donnell Library showing is at 12 noon and admission is free. The Museum of Modern Art showing is at 6 P.M. and, because Tuesdays are donation days at the Modern, the patron decides how much to pay.Striking InsightsThe "unknown tongues" sequence in the "Fannie Bell Chapman" film is one of a number of unusually intimate scenes that have been captured on film by Mr. Ferris and Miss Peiser. Working out of the Center for Southern Folklore in Memphis and at Yale University, where Mr. Ferris teaches folklore, aided by the Yale Media Design Studio and foundation financing, Mr. Ferris and Miss Peiser have rapidly established a reputation as two of the more-creative film makers documenting American folklore.Their deep penetration into the homes and communities of their subjects is practically without precedent: The "tongues" episode, a holy-dance and faith-healing service from a New Haven church, in "Two Black Churches," and the footage of a back-country juke joint and a prison-farm work gang in "Give My Poor Heart Ease" offer some of the most striking insights into black folk culture in America ever captured on film.Bill Ferris first began recording Fannie Bell Chapman's gospel music in 1967, and he visited the Chapman family repeatedly before filming began. "I was struck by their music," he says, "and by the warmth of the family. The whole dimension of faith healing wasn't evident until we were already filming." In other scenes in the film, Mrs. Chapman builds altarlike structures out of milk cartons and makes tablecloths by typing together plastic six-pack rings, talking all the while about the visions she receives and about her healing abilities. "I cut sickness as fine as cat's hair," she explains, chopping with her hands so rapidly that they become a blur."Once we've started filming in a community," Miss Peiser says, "we go back and show the people rushes, and ask them what they think we should include. The folk artists are the first to see the finished films and the first to receive copies."Mr. Ferris concedes that filming in a community effects some changes as primarily salutary. "When we film a folk artist," he says, "the community begins to see the person more as a real artist. It means that folk traditions are revitalized. I think the most important thing for the film maker to do is to develop a friendship with the people he's filming, to become sensitive to their feelings. Then when you're working with the camera, if things aren't quite right, you sense it. You also begin to be able to sense when things are going to move in an unexpected direction, and of course you have to be ready to move with that unstructured flow."Mr. Ferris and Miss Peiser are not the sort of folk purists who try to find isolated communities that have been relatively unsullied by outside influences. "Give My Poor Heart Ease" is a particularly valuable film on the blues because it sketches a continuum, from the place of semiprofessional bluesmen in rural Mississippi to the show-business world of B. B. King, a successful blues star. In the course of the 20-minute film, a rural barber, a prisoner at the notorious Parchman Farm, and a clothing salesman on Memphis's Beale Street offer their own interpretations of what it means to sing and have the blues.Part of a Series"Two Black Churches" contrasts services at a Baptist church in Rose Hill, Miss., where old hymn tunes from the Rev. Isaac Watts's hymnal are sung, with the more contemporary and unrestrained services at the St. James United Free Will Baptist Church in New Haven. The minister of the urban church characterizes worship in terms of "grooving" and "doing our thing," and the music is provided by electric guitars and a choir. At the end of the New Haven service there is a "laying on of hands" sequence in which the minister uses upper spinal manipulation to make a young man get out of a wheelchair and walk. The minister's wife begins to gyrate uncontrollably in the throes of spirit possession. According to a review of this film in the Journal of American Folklore, "the scenes of spirit possession and healing . . . are outstanding, and the camera work in them is brilliant."The films by Mr. Ferris and Miss Peiser are part of a continuing series of showings of independently made social documentaries, the What's Happening Series. All the showings are on Tuesdays, at noon at the Donnell Library and at 6 P.M. at the Museum of Modern Art. Bill Ferris feels that the showing of such films is particularly important."The voices of the people in these films are normally invisible to the media," he says. "You don't see or hear them on network television, rarely on public television, never in the movies or on the radio. You can look at them purely as entertainment, but they're also a means of leading into a more-sophisticated view of what it means to be a member of a folk or minority culture in America."

title: Use of Torture in SouthWest Africa Denied by the South African Police
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, April 4 (Reuters)South Africa's chief deputy commissioner of police today denied allegations by Amnesty International that police interrogating detainees in SouthWest Africa used torture.

title: U. of Pennsylvania to Lose License for Radio Station After Finding of Obscenity
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)A Federal Communications Commission administrative law judge today ordered that the license of the University of Pennsyl' vanie's campus FM radio station not be renewed because of lack of supervision by university officials.

title: Blacks and Republicans
description: WASHINGTON  Through choral repetition of the refrain black America elected Jimmy Carter, liberal politicians have created, and are exploiting, a powerful myth. Even otherwise canny politicians like Robert Dole have risen like trout to take the bait.

title: Edward Barrett, 77; Politician in Illinois Convicted of Bribery
description: CHICAGO, April 4(UPI)Edward Barrett, a power in Illinois and Chicago Democratic politics until he was convicted of bribery, mail fraud and tax evasion, died today. He was 77 years old.

title: Listing of Survivors In Georgia Jet Crash
description: ATLANTA, April 4 (UPI)Following are a list of the crew members aboard Southern Flight 242 that crashed today at New Hope, Ga., and their conditions, and an unofficial list of others injured in the crash.

title: Notes on People
description: The Secret Service announced yesterday that President Carter had ordered it to stop providing protection for the former Vice President, Nelson Rockefeller, and for Susan Ford, but to continue protection for Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, for at least two to four more weeks. At the time he was sworn in, Mr. Carter directed the Secret Service to give protection to Mr. Kissinger and Mr. Rockefeller for up to six months, and he authorized protection for Miss Ford, a student at the University of Kansas, at her father's request: Secret Service agents were withdrawn from protecting Miss Ford on March 23 and from Mr. Rockefeller on Feb. 22.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 5, 1977

title: Women Prisoners Sue to Keep Out the Men Guards
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., April 4Several prisoners at New York State's only women's prison have sued in Federal Court charging that they have been humiliated, degraded and embarrassed by the presence of male guards in their housing units.

title: Tipton Begins Final Season As Coach of Army Baseball
description: Army will begin its 20th and last baseball season under Coach Eric Tipton today when the Cadets play City College at West Point. Conditions should be about normal for Army baseball  barely above freezing with strong wind whipping off the Hudson River. Earl (Red) Blaik was the head football coach and athletic director at Army in the spring of 1957 when it was decided the Cadets should enter the Eastern Intercollegiate Lightweight Football League. That is better known as 150pound football.

title: Farmhands Seeking a Union Walk 400 Miles to See Texas Governor
description: AUSTIN, Tex, April 4On a sweltering summer day nearly 11 years ago, a band of MexicanAmerican farm workers set out on foot from the lush Rio Grande Valley to carry their hopes for an organized labor union to John B. Connally, then the Governor of Texas. Mr, Connally advised them in advance that he would not be at the Governor's mansion when they called.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Xerox Corporation announced that it was reducing prices in the United States for its 3100 copier by $2,000 to $5,500. Prices also were recluted by $2,200 each on the Xerox 3107 reduction copier, making its cost now $8,300, and on the Xerox 3100 LDClarge document copiermaking its new price $6,700. Still another copier, the Xerox 660 tabletop model, was reduced from $2.500 to $2.195.

title: Sharper U.S.Soviet Duel in Africa Is Seen in Wake of Podgorny Trip
description: MOSCOW, April 4President Nikolai V. Podgorny returned to Moscow today after a twoweek tour of Africa that has underscored the likelihood of sharpened competition between the Soviet Union and the United States on the continent.

title: SENATE PANEL CUTS JOBS ASKED BY CARTER FOR 79
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)The Senate Budget Committee adopted today proposal that sharply cuts back the number of public service jobs President Carter wanted to be available in 1979 under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act.

description: Article 4  No Title

title: Message Is In From Paris Bubbly, Bloused and Billowy
description: PARIS,April 2The readytowear collections are shown here in a carnival atmosphere resembling a state fair, with musical accompaniment ranging from Meyerbeer to Guy Lombardo and such accoutrements as smoke bombs on stage. The first hazard is getting in the door, and store presidents are often left forlornly waving their tickets while fashion groupies enter unchallenged.

title: E W. SCRIPPS SEEKS MEDIA INVESTMENT
description: The E. W. Scripps Company of Cincinnati, a privately held company, announced yesterday that it had proposed a merger with the Media Investment Company for cash amounting to $52 a share for the 583,268 outstanding Media common stock.

title: AddictProgram Chief Suspended Amid Charges of Abuses in Bronx
description: Robert Munoz, the executive director of a drugaddiction rehabilitation program in the Bronx, went on temporary leave without pay yesterday pending completion of investigations into the controversial program.

title: NEWYORK'S CUTBACKS ON MEDICAID BACKED
description: The Medicaid cutbacks promulgated by the New York State Department of Health were endorsed yesterday by the Federal Government after the regional office of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare eliminated some of the cuts sought by the state.

title: TV: The American Short Story Impresses
description: The American Short Story, which begins tonight at S on pbblic television, represents a longoverdue recognition of the obvious. The short story has been the special creation and pride of American literature, but the form has been virtually ignored by television, the great devourer always in need of fresh ideas. A rich source of programming material has been largely and inexplicably ignored while the medium has turned. to assemblyline factories and the hacking out of sitcorns and actionadventures.

title: The Bird Is Restless
description: DETROIT, April 4 (AP)  Mark (the Bird) Fidrych, injured mainstay of the Detroit Tigers pitching staff, held a new conference today to announce he was lonely and tired of hospital life.

title: Caso Says He Would Turn Down A Nomination by Conservatives
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 4Ralph G. Caso, the embattled Nassau County Executive, withdrew his name today from consideration for the Conservative Party nomination for reelection.

title: Books of The Times
description: Good morning. It's time for feat and loathing in the commercial novel. In the near, corner, wearing paranoia and exclamation points, is Robert Ludlum of The Scarlatti Inheritance and The Rhinemann Exchange. In the far corner, wearing greed and Hurricane Ella, is John D. MacDonald with his 49th book.

title: 33 Are Injured as Bombs Explode in Two Restaurants in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 4 Bombs exploded in two restaurants here today within a minute of each other, injuring 33 people, including some children.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Even as a magnificentlyequipped fly fisherman is stalking a trout with gossamer leader and artificial fly in some Eastern stream, a South American Indian is probably preparing a fishstunning potion with which he will gather his evening meal.

title: Radio City Plans Pop Art Festival
description: Radio City Music Hall, which in the last five years has been presenting stage acts with increasing frequency, has announced a Radio City Music Hall Pop Arts Festival, a twiceayear, sevenweek program of varied entertainment that will include jazz, pop semi classical concerts, rock and ice shows, and children's programs. The opening series will run from Sept. 15 to Nov. 3.

title: Florida's Citrus Losses From the Freeze
description: LAKELAND, Fla.Within the next two months, the harvesting of the 197677 citrus crop will be completed throughout the state, and growers will close the books on a very trying year.

title: Theater: Happy Haven, Spoof of Welfare State
description: Of all the significant contemporary British playwrights, John Arden has had perhaps the most difficult time finding an ,American platform. Only few of his many plays (such as Salleant Musgrave's Dance and Live Like Pigs') have received New York productions.

title: Desai Asks Indians Help in Meeting Gigantic Tasks
description: NEW DELHI, April 4Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai, in his first substantive address to the nation since he took office 11 days ago, asked tonight for the people's support in the gigantic tasks of developing India and ending destitution within 10 years.

title: DR. MERVYN ARMSTRONG
description: Dr. Mervyn V. Armstrong, a retired clinical professor of obstettics and gyne cology at Long Island College of Medicine, now the Downstate Medical Center of the State University of New York, died Saturday in his home at 176 Riverside Avenue, Amityville, L. I. He was 85 years old.

title: Eugene Zador, Opera Composer And Creator of 120 Film Scores
description: Eugene Zador, who combined a prolific career as a composer of film scores with ambitious creations in the field of opera, concertos and musical compositions for leading musical groups in this country, died Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 82 years old.

title: Vietnam Veteran Buried on L.I. 10 Years After Death in Aircraft
description: BELLMORE, L. I., April 4 (AP) Navy Lieut. William Kienert was buried in the Long Island National Cemetery in Pinelawn, L. I., 10 years after his death.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article referring to remarks attributed to Gen. George S. Brown that appeared in The Times last Tuesday, Ranan Lurie, who made public the general's remarks, was erroneously identified as a contributing editor to Newsweek International. Mr. Lurie, cartoonist, is no longer associated with that publication.

title: Police Stage Ceremony to Make Retirements Less Impersonal
description: It was all very impersonal, Fred Thomas said yesterday, recalling his retirement last Oct. 4 from the New York City Police Department. They take your gun and ycur shield. Then you walk out the door and you're lost.

title: Saccharin Ban Scored By Kennedy as Threat To Other Prohibitions
description: NUTLEY, N.J., April 4Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that the public outcry over the Food and Drug Administration's announced intention to ban saccharin, the widely used artificial sweetener, could jeopardize laws prohibiting the use of food additives known to cause cancer in laboratory animals.

description: TEL AVIV, April 4An official here: acknowledged today that Israeli gunners on the Lebanese frontier briefly joined the battle this morning as Palestinian guerrillas and Christian militia units fought with artillery and mortars in the Taibe area, about two miles from the border.

title: Goodpaster Will Leave Retirement To Be West Point Superintendent
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The Defense Department announced today the recall from retirement of Gen. Andrew J. Goodpaster to take over as superintendent of the United States Military Academy. The appointment comes at a time when the institution's reputation has been clouded by cheating scandals and internal friction.

description: WASHINGTON, April 4Representative Donald M. Fraser, asserting that he was astonished by the brazenness of South Korean intrusions into American life, said today an investigation had been started to identify the sources of discord, corruption and distortion of national interests in United States relations with South Korea.

description: WASHINGTON, April 4In his arms proposals to the Soviet Union, President Carter has implicitly accepted the longstanding contention of the Joint Chiefs of Staff that heavy Soviet missiles with multiple warheads could pose a threat to the

title: Diplomats in China Talk of Indications Of a Major Move
description: HONG KONG, April 4On the eve of the first anniversary of the large demonstrations last year that led to the ouster of former Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping, diplomatic sources in Peking reported today that, although the city was quiet, there were signs of possible preparations for a major political announcement.

title: Program for Energy Conservation Offered by Byrne to Cut Fuel Cost
description: TRENTON April 4Governor Byrne released today a New Jersey energy conservation plan that he said would save consumers $278 million a year in fuel costs by 1981.

title: 30 INDICTED IN QUEENS IN HEROIN CRACKDOWN
description: Thirty persons were indicted yesterday in what was said to be a $50 millionayear heroin operation that led from Queens to Asia and back. Among those indicted was a man accused of running the operation from his prison cell.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 9monthold child was recovered by New Rochelle police and a 17yearold girl was arrested on charges of kidnapping the child from a birthday party. Police Lieut. Adrian Kellard said the child, Keith Fairey, was in healthy condition and he was returned to his foster parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Black of New Rochelle.

title: Facing the Fear of Crime
description: The fear of crime can become so tangible in the life of a coMmunity that attains the significance of crime itself. That point has been reached in New York with regard to crimes against the elderly. Facts about pattern's of crime are hard to come by. Statistics indicathig that the elderly are less victimized than other groups are Small compare To the victims, their neighbors and relatives. The elderly are not only more :vulnerable to atteck, they are the most vulnerable to fear: Their lives and places of residence are fixed; emotionally and financAlly their roots run deeper than those of younger citizens. They live with memories that reach back farther to a different city and safer environment, memories that haunt the present reality.
