description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)The Senate Banking committee approved an antiboycott bill today as some Senators accused President Carter of favoring loopholes in such legislation and ignoring a campaign promise to work for an early end to Arab discrimination against United States companies.

title: Over a Million Units Marketed in Month
description: DETROIT, April 5The nation' domestic automobile producers reporting a 7 percent gain in lateMarch sales, said yesterday they sold more than 1 million cars last month, the first time car sales have passed that point since before the Arab oil embargo of 1973.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: THERE'S AN elegantly foolish little situation in The New York idea, Langdon Mitchell's jolly artifice of 1906 that is currently being used to introduce us to the new and impeccable acting company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The situation lasts for exactly 60 seconds, which means that it plays in less time than it will take me to tell you about it. I'm going to tell you anyway, because I sense a point lurking about here, somewhere.

title: Mini Skirts Make Maxi Impact in Paris
description: PARIS The short skirt story is gaining momentum in fashion here.

title: Favorites Eliminated From NorthSouth Golf
description: PINEHURST, N.C., April 5 (AP)Many of the favored players were eliminated today in the raindelayed and windswept first round of the 75th North and South women's amateur golf tournament. The casualties included the defending champion, Carol Semple, Carolyn Hill, last year's medalist, and two former champions, Nancy Roth Syms and Alice Dye

title: TV: Joey a Tearful, Worthwhile Drama
description: SOMETHING FOR Joey, on CBS tonight from 9 to 11, is based on actual events in the lives of the people portrayed. Those people are primarily John Cappelletti, the football player, and his kid brother Joey, a victim of leukemia. In accepting the 1973 Heisman Trophy, awarded annually to the best college football player, John Cappelletti startled an audience of dignitaries and celebrities with a tearfilled and moving tribute to Joey. This film, produced and written by Jerry McNeely, fills in the background of that very personal something for Joey. A postscript discloses that he died in April 1976.

title: Connecticut House Defeats Bill Banning Bias Against Homosexuals
description: HARTFORD, April 5 (AP)The Connecticut House of Representatives rejected today a bill outlawing discrimination against homosexuals.

title: Garden Announces a National CableTV Agreement
description: Cable television, which has not yet reached all of Brooklyn, will use terrestrial microwaves and a stratospheric satellite to broadcast live Madison Square Garden's entire sports schedule to virtually all of the continental United States.

title: About Real Estate
description: After a fouryear period of new ownership and management, the Bing & Bing properties in Manhattan have changed hands again. The buyers are unidentified investors who apparently include members of the Bing family.

title: Amex Workers to Vote On Union Representation Between 2 Rival Locals
description: A bitter labor battle is expected to end today when unionized workers at the American Stock Exchange vote on a move petitioned for by some employees to drop Local 153 of the Office and Professional Employees International Union as their bargaining agent.

title: Peanuts, Popcorn and Bankrolls
description: Time was when a certain segment of the populace would have been speculating during the last few weeks about the state of Catfish Hunter's right arm or the inability of the Mets to get some hitters. Time was, as Philip Roth has observed, when there were 48 states, network radio and eightteam leagues. But no moreTime was, also, when the owners controlled all of baseball and only the Sultan of Swat earned $80,000 a year. Also no more. Now, spindlylegged infielders can command $80,000; real sluggers and unhittable pitchers sign multimilliondollar contracts.

title: Pop: Kenny Rankin, Fireside Banterer
description: KENNY RANKIN sang with an orchestra conducted by Don Costa at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday, and somehow he managed to convey the impression that his listeners were guests in his living room. Dressed in jeans and with his shirtsleeves rolled up, bantering about his youth on West 160th Street, ambling between a piano on one side of the stage and a stool where he sat playing guitar on the other, Mr. Rankin purveyed a cool brand of pop with the aplomb of an angler swapping fish stories.

title: Experts Puzzled by NearSimultaneous Engine Loss
description: Safety experts generally agreed yesterday that violent weather led directly to Monday's crash of a Southern Airways twinjet airliner near Atlanta.

title: Deaths
description: ADELIZZIJoseph M. In Colchester, Ct., on April 1, 1977, husband of the late Alma Louise Schultz of Montville, father of Mrs. George (Martha) Ulhloin of Woodbridge, Ct., Mrs. John (Vita) Shugrue of Hamden, Ct., Mrs. J. Craig (Margaret) LaVin and Mr. Joseph M. Aedilizzi, Jr., both of New Haven, Ct. also survived by nine grandchildren; a sister, Rose M. Adley of East Haven, Ct., and a brother, Ralph J. Adler of North Haven, Ct. Predeceased by brothers, Daniel J. Adler and Michael Adler. Private funeral services from the Church and Allen Funeral Home, Montville, Ct. It is requested that flowers be omitted and that Memorial Contributions In Mr. Adellzzi's name be made to the American Heart Association or the Connecticut Junior Republic, Litchfield, Ct.

title: Labor Dispute Shuts 5 Times Sq. Movies
description: A labor dispute involving stagehands resulted in the closing of five Times Square movie theaters yesterday.

title: Khaalis's SonlnLaw Is Released From Jail on Bond and a Promise
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)Abdul Aziz, the soninlaw of Hamaas Abdul Khaalis, the Hanafi Moslem leader, was released from jail today on $5,000 cash bond and his sworn promise to show up for court appearances.

title: Atrittnriat prttirrn
description: CLINTONCarol Joseohone. First anniversary memorial Mass celebrated Wednesday, April 6, COO P.M., Chaoel of the College of MI. St. Vincent. Amat, Amamus.

title: Chris Evert's Brother Victor in Easter Bowl
description: John Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., brother of Chris, advanced to the boys 16 second round of the annual Planters Easter Bowl junior tennis tournament yesterday by defeating Rusty Wright of Scarsdale, N. Y., 62, 61.

title: Reggie's 'Got a Shot' at Hitting 50
description: In a war, it would be known as an open city. It doesn't belong to anybody. That's the way New York is now sports. The city is there to be taken. The Mets have lost their charm. Joe Namath is on waivers. The Giants have more hope than faith. The Knicks aren't even in the playoffs and Dr. J. is in Philadelphia. The Islanders haven't won the Stanley Cup and the Rangers haven't won anything. Steve Cauthen is still an apprentice. Seattle Slew is only passing through. The city is there to be taken. And if anybody has an opportunity to take New York, it's Reggie Jackson, the Yankees new right fielder for the season opener with the Milwaukee Brewers today. All the chemistry is there except for the one element that only Reggie Jackson can supply, the one Yankee requireshome runs. That was obviJackson drove up to Yankee Stadium in his and the kids surrounded him for autoyesterday's workout.

title: Hers
description: THERE eminent psychohistorians have already finished interpreting the results of India's election, in which Indira Gandhi and her son Sanjay fell from grace and out political power. Dr. J. S. Mindblow of Harvard, whose book went for $1.2 million, concludes that Indira lost because she was possessed by an orthodox Hindu shedevil. Dr. R. V. Doppelgang of Yale, whose total package of hardand softcover rights went for $2.1 million, diagnoses Indira as an ordinary victim of raging, aging female hormones, which gave her son an acute genderrole identity crisis.

title: Keith Carradine: People Think I'm Really a Cad
description: IN THE BEGINNING, he was John Carradine's son, or David Carradine's brother. Nowadays, he's more likely to be thought of as Keith Carradine, That Cad in the Movies Who Uses Women Like Kleenex.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: RESOURCE (Se???Land) Bremerhaven April 16;??? from Pt. Elizabeth, N. J.

title: U. S. READY TO CEASE PUSH FOR PUITONIU1111 AS FUEL IN REACTORS
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The Carter Administration is expected to announce tomorrow that it is stopping indefinitely efforts to develop plutonium as a fuel in nuclear power reactors in the United States.

title: Tough Talk Reported Between Carter and Labor
description: WASHINGTON, April 6President Carter, whose relationship with organized labor has been increasingly abrasive, met today with leaders of the A.F.L.C.I.O. to hear their complaints and explain his positions:

title: Corporate Bonds Give Investors Unusually Wide Choice of Yields
description: The corporate bond market yesterday gave investors an unusually wide range of yields to choose from. TripleA taxexempt bonds backed by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company were sold at yield slightly below 5 percent, while Credit Markets the Texas International Company, a n Oklahoma Credit City oilfi el d equipment Markets manufacturer, sold an issue of subordinated debentures regarded as speculativethat were priced to give an 11 percent rate of return.

title: Snug Harbor Arts Center Is Backed
description: The State Senate Finance Committeenormally a cutanddried panelwent to Staten Island yesterday and heard from an array of arts personalities who testified on behalf of the embryonic Snug Harbor Cultural Center.

title: Political Unrest Finds Its Way to a Pastoral Corner of the Cnaries
description: TEROR, Canary Islands, April 2Five centuries ago, a resplendent Virgin Mary, with an infant Jesus in her arms, appeared in a towering pine tree in a place called Aterura to a people that no longer exists.

title: Books: Song Pair
description: It used to be thought that Dietrich FischerDieskau was one person, handsome German baritone who could sing his way through a foothigh pile of songs in a single breath, record the entire vocal literature of any nation in an afternoon and in middle age turn to conducting symphony orchestras and writing scholarly volumes. Insiders have begun to suspect, however, that at least three indefatigable geniuses are behind this corporate mask, Mr. Dietrich, Mr. Fischer and Mr. Dieskau, and that each is assisted by a horde of hardworking trolls. How else to explain how the world's busiest recording artist is able to publish, on the heels of his recent dual biography, Wagner and Nietzsche, his meticulous and absorbing pair of books? Moreover, these are not the twilight efforts of a retired artist: The Schubert study was published in Germany in 1971, and the lieder collection came out there in 1968, when Mr. FischerDieskau was at the peak of his concert and recording industry.

title: Havlicek Passes 25,000
description: BOSTON, April 6 (AP)  John Havlicek took a pass from Jo Jo White and scared on a layup during the second quarter tonight against the Houston Rockets to break the 25,000point barrier for his National Basketball Association career. Only Wilt Chamberlain, Oscar Robertson and Jerry West had previously scored more than 25,000 points. The victory gave Houston the Central Division title.

title: G.O.P. Now Scores Carter Vote Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  President Carter's proposal to allow previously unregistered voters to register on Election Day ran into virtually unanimous Republican opposition today at its first hearing in Congress.

title: With Big Man Back, Knick Fans Are 10 Feet Tall
description: It's like old times. He's back on the sidewalks of New York, and the people are stopping him, yelling to him, embracing him with their wellwishes. Three weeks ago it was on Seventh Avenue, and the kid called: Willis, it's great to have you back. We're set now.

title: Senate Panel Offers Budget Containing $63.2 Billion Deficit
description: WASHINGTON. April 6The Senate Budget Committee today recommended a budget with a deficit of $63.2 billion for the next fiscal year after urging token cut of $300 million in President Carter's defense budget.

title: GOOD FRIDAY
description: Tomorrow is Good Friday. The following is a list of activities that will be affected:

title: Easy Victor in St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS, April 6 (UPI)Democratic State Senator James F. Conway was elected Mayor yesterday, defeating his Republican opponent, James A. Stemmler, and Representative William L. Clay, Democrat of Missouri who ran a writein campaign aimed at black voters.

title: All but Two of Zoo Animals Found Dead at Jungle Habitat Are Buried
description: WEST MILFORD, April 6All but two of the dead animals that had been lying above ground for weeks at Jungle Habitat here were buried in mountaintop pits today under the supervision of local sanitary inspectors.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)The Carter Administration asked Congress today to impose Federal controls on a controversial form of genetic research.

title: Bergland to Alter Reporting Policy On Grain Exports
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI)  Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland disclosed today he had dropped a Ford Administration policy of announcing big grain and soybean sales to Russia and China within 24 hours of the time the Government learns about them from exporters.

title: NVF Announces Delay In 1976 Annual Report
description: The NVF Company, a manufacturer of vulcanized fiber, laminated plastics and fine papers, announced there will be a delay in furnishing stockholders with an annual report for 1976.

title: Maryland Strike Continues
description: BALTIMORE, April 6 (UPI)Union and management negotiators met for several hours today without reaching an agreement to end the strike against three Maryland race tracks.

title: A Triumphant Decent Man
description: LOS ANGELES, April 6The first time he ran for Mayor of Los Angeles in 1969, Tom Bradley sent voters brochure containing a photograph of himself beside the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Over the picture, Man in the News printed in the largest type Man in his appeal for votes, were the words: A Decent in the Man!

description: NEW ORLEANS (102) Coleman 8 7.2 12, Griffin 2 3.4 7, Kelley 4 3.7 11, Walker 5 00 10, Marovich 15 22 30, N. Williams 9 1.2 19, Howard 2 1.2 5, Moore 0 00 0. Totals 45 1219 102. BUFFALO (107).

title: Details Released by Justice Dept. Of Settlement on Wydler Spending
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The Justice Department today released a series of documents outlining an outofcourt settlement in which Representative John W. Wydler, Republican of Garden City, L.I., agreed to repay the Government $25,000 that the department alleged he had improperly charged to his office account.

title: News Summary
description: Egypt's President predicted normalization of relations between Israel and the Arab states following signature of a final settlement ending the state of war in the Middle East. At a Washington press conference after two days of talks with President Carter, President Anwar elSadat seemed to be trying to take positions closer to President Carter's, but he indicated differences on details. [Page A1, Column 1.]

title: 2 Missouri U. Surgeons Report a Medical First In Transsexual Operation
description: Surgeons at the University of Missouri reported Monday that they had performed the first femaletomale transsexual operation in which the patient was given a penis capable of erection.

title: St. Joe Minerals Unit Plans Coal for Utilities
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation said its coal subsidiary, the A. T. Massey Coal Company, had agreed to furnish 3.5 million tons a year of lowsulfur coal to two major Southeastern utilities.

title: Islanders Resume OntheRoadat.Home Series
description: When the Nassau Coliseum scoreboard flashes the attendance tonight during the second game of the National Hockey League playoff series between Chicago and the Islanders, it should also add.

title: F.E.A. Lagging on Oil Penalty Fees
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)The Federal Energy Administration has collected only $3.5 million on oil industry overcharges totaling some $500 million, the General Accounting Office reported today.

title: Pop: Galper, Busy Pianist
description: Had Galper, who is leading his own jazz group at the Village Vanguard for the first time this week, is a strong, forceful pianist who manages to combine the ruggedly powerful twohanded attack of the early blues and swing era pianist with the long, flowing, linear style established by Bud Powell and his followers in the bebop period.

title: Stage: Cold Storage
description: AMAN IS handcuffed to chair. It is 1941. In a Portuguese police station. The man is a German Jew about to be deported to Germany. He is talking to an unseen 8yearold boy. The man is captured but in a sense freeeven the chair he is handcuffed to is not bolted down to the floor. He is, as he says: caught in a fantasy wrapped up in a paradox.

title: Burroughs Is Asked to Pay $42.5 Million in Customs
description: The Burroughs Corporation reported that the United States Customs Service is seeking S42.5 million in civil penalties against it for alleged underpayment of duties on imported products.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN BOTH THESE collections, the stories avoid punch lines and hypodermic needles. They haven't been machinetooled to spring nasty surprise. The people in themand they are people, not theories or slogansaren't struck by lightning, nor do they fall on swords. Awareness is something quieter. It is as if with our hands we make a bowl of attention, into which a cool intelligence is poured.

title: Navy Rushes to Complete Work On First U.S. Indian Ocean Base
description: DIEGO GARCIA, April 6The United States Navy is rushing to complete America's first air and naval facility in the Indian Ocean on this coral island 400 miles south of the Equator.

title: Supplies of Water Called Improved In Much of Nation
description: WASHINGTON, April 6Water supplies improved substantially in March,1 with stream flows and ground water levels higher across much of the country the United States Geological Survey said today.

title: PARKCHESTER BATTLE LOST BY LEFKOWITZ
description: The New York State Court of Appeals has declared invalid a move by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to block Harry B. Helmsley's effort to convert all of the huge Parkchester apartment complex in the Bronx from a rental complex to a condominium.

title: Judge Grants a Stay On Conrail's Service
description: TRENTON, April 6A Federal judge issued an injunction today against the continued posting of servicediscontinuance notices by Conrail at New Jersey railroad stations, The writ, by Judge Clarkson S. Fisher, ends the threat of service curtailment at the end of a 60day warning period, Judge Fisher also ordered the dispute between Conrail (the Consolidated Rail Corporation) and the New Jersey Transportation Department to go to Federal mediation within one week, and be asked for a further report after 30 days.

title: City U. Will Require 3R College Tests
description: The City University disclosed yesterday that it would begin testing students next fall to make sure that they could meet minimum standards in the basic areas of reading, mathematics and writing.

title: Meadowlands
description: FIR5T$7,500, pacecl., mile.

title: SADAT SAYS HIS GOAL IS A NORMALIZATION OF TIES WITH ISRAELI
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said today after two days of talks with President Carter that everything will be normalized between Israel and the Arab states once a final settlement was signed ending the state of war in the Middle East.

title: City Approval Expected On U.S. Open Tennis Shift
description: The city is expected to approve tomorrow the United States Tennis Association's bid to renovate the old Singer Bowl in Flushing Meadow Park in Queens and move the Open championships there from Forest Hills next year. The U.S.T.A. is prepared to spend more than $5 million to expand the seating of the bowl, which was renamed Louis Armstrong Stadium several years ago, from 12,000 to 20,000. Sixteen to 32 lighted courts and four to eight indoor courts would be installed.

title: Inco Is Reducing Prices Of Some Nickel Products
description: Inco Ltd. has announced downward adjustments in the prices of certain of its nickel products. The prices of electrolytic nickel pellets are being reduced from $2.41 to $2.35 per pound. The company's Incomet grade was reduced from $2.23 to $2.11 per pound. The prices are effective for secondquarter delivery for confirmed orders received in April. Inco also confirmed that the price of nickel oxide sinter 75 was reduced from $2.20 to $2.07 per pound, effective April 1.

title: Teamsters' Officials Meet As Dissidents Ask Chief's Ouster
description: WASHINGTON, April 6Hundreds of teamsters union officials gathered here today at a meeting hastily called to rally support for the union's beleaguered president, Frank E. Fitzsimmons, and to discuss ways to improve the union's public image.

title: Queens in the Mayoral Election
description: Queens, now the county with the greatest number of voters in the state, is likely to be the pivotal battleground in the coming mayoral election and, as a result, will have an important influence on the issues that dominate the campaign.

title: Frederick C. Mezey Weds Lucinda Christian Porter
description: Lucinda Christian Porter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Porter of Syracuse, Skaneateles, N.Y., and Snow Hill, Md., was married yesterday afternoon to Frederick Charles Mezey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Mezey of New Brunswick, N.J. Civil Court Judge Sheldon S. Levy performed the ceremony at the St. RegisSheraton Hotel.

title: At Your Service and Marble Cutting
description: IT IS NO accident of design that same city blocks present almost unbroken streetlevel facades of marble, or foyers that stretch away in glossy marble vistas. Marble is still a preferred material for bank directors tables. It is durable enough to withstand wind and soot and stiletto heels, and there is an element of cool aristocracy to that highly polished veined stone.

title: Letters: On the Electoral College
description: Your negative response to President Carter's proposal to abolish the Electoral College [editorial March 23] seems an unusual affirmation of an unsatisfactory status quo. You imply that the only advantage of abolishing the Electoral College would be to guard against the possibility that the popularvote winner would be the electoral loser, yet that has happened three times in our history. With some minuscule voting shifts last fall, it could have happened again. That danger therefore is a real and present one, and there is little justification for continuing to run it.

title: Low Immunization Figures Are Attributed to Apathy of Public, Health Professionals and Government Aides
description: Health experts said yesterday that apathy of the public, health professionals and government officials was the principal reason for the dangerously low levels of Immunization that are causing or threatening epidemics of preventable diseases throughout the world.

title: Jungle Habitat Buries All But Two Animals
description: WEST MILFORD, N.J., April 6All but two of the dead animals that, have been lying above ground for weeks at Jungle Habitat here were buried in mountaintop pits today under the supervision of local sanitary inspectors.

title: CARTER IS REBUFFED BY HOUSE ON RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The House of Representatives adopted human rights language opposed by President Carter as it approved a $5.2 billion international aid bill today.

title: Film: The Devil Fumbles a Passing Soul
description: AUDREY ROSE" is supposed to be about reincarnation, but it's really about the potentially dangerous side effects when a soul passes from one body to another without a proper interval. Lightheadedness, depression, disorientation and worsethey sound like the warnings on a bottle of prescription tranquilizers.The new film, directed by Robert Wise with a perfectly grave face, is about Ivy, who, in 1965 at the age of 5, was killed with her mother in an automobile accident in Pittsburgh and two minutes later was born again in New York and was named Audrey Rose, the daughter of upwardly mobile parents who live in the Hotel Des Artistes.Two minutes, this film clearly understands, are not enough time for anyone, least of all poor little Ivy, to have a karma cleaned, pressed and packed and still arrive in New York from Pittsburgh on schedule. No wonder Ivy/Audrey Rose is a mess.When the movie begins, Audrey Rose is 11 years old and pretty as a picture, but she has these dreadful nightmares about being in a fiery auto accident. They are particularly severe when her birthday rolls around. She beats her head hysterically against rain-splattered windows and burns her hands on cold radiators, behaving more or less like someone possessed."Audrey Rose," which opened at three theaters yesterday, is the first movie to expose ineptitude in the traffic-managing of domestic souls. It's a subject that might well be investigated by the Interstate Commerce Commission because the job has been bungled by Mr. Wise and Frank De Felitta, the man who wrote the screenplay and the best-selling novel on which it's based.On closer examination, though, "Audrey Rose" turns out to be less about the side effects of all-too-hasty soul transfers than a demonstration of those dangers. The soul of the movie is that of "The Exorcist" instantly recycled.Playing the Ellen Burstyn role is another fine actress who is wastedMarsha Masonwhile Anthony Hopkins, the English actor who was so splendid on the stage in "Equus," plays the role of the exorcist, and he's terrible. Actually he's not an exorcist, but the father of the long-dead Ivy. He is a scientist who has been to India to study up on souls and knows what to do to separate Ivy from Audrey Rose.The father of the little girl in "The Exorcist" remained off screen, and Audrey Rose's father, as played by John Beck, is such a nonentity that it amounts to the same thing. It even appears that Susan Swift, who has the title role, has been photographed to resemble Linda Blair at her most bedeviled. I'd like to know the exact hour and minute this movie was born.I suppose that's not really important, but it is depressing to see money and intelligence thrown away on material of this hustling, completely unimaginative sort. Mr. Wise does nothing to transform it. Instead he meets every clich of the script with one of his own, and even manages to pull off a climactic courtroom scene of absolutely no suspense. That's not easy."Audrey Rose," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains an unpleasant sequence in which the troubled heroine attempts to crawl into a bonfire.

title: Amex Workers Vote To Drop Union Local
description: The Committee for the Best Interests of Amex Employees, a group of American Stock Exchange workers dissatisfied with the representation by Local 153 of the Office and Professional Employees International Union, won its battle yesterday to drop the local as bargaining agent.

title: SOVIET ARMS BUILDUP SEEN BY C. I. A. CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The Soviet rejection of United States proposals for limiting strategic weapons deployment may be linked to Soviet progress on new family of nuclear arms, according to Adm. Stansfield Turner, Director of Central Intelligence.

title: The Couple Assumption
description: THERE is a veiled paradox at the heart of New York's cultural life that should (finally) be pulled out into the open by New York's women, and given a hard look. Without force of lawbut with all the unfathomable power of folklore it effectively excludes thousands of New Yorkers from fully enjoying the city's wealth of arts, impedes the healthy growth of audiences, and subtly contributes to the general unhappiness.

title: Leonard Silk
description: Can a democracy, such as the United States, plan ahead for decades to come? This is the crucial question that haunts President Carter and his inside and outside advisers as they struggle to bring forth a longterm energy program for the nation. Consider just one of the complexities: United States dependence on imported oil. In 1970, the United States depended on foreign oil for 23 percent of its total oil consumption, but by 1974the year of the Arab oil boycottthe figure had risen to 37 percent. Project Independence was the Nixon Administration's, and then the Ford Administration's, response to that problem. In 1976, oil imports constituted 44 percent of total United States consumption. This year imports are accounting for almost half the nation's consumption.

title: PETER G. KONTOS, FOUNDER OF EDUCATIONAL CONCERN
description: Peter G. Kontos, founder and board chairman of the EDR Corporation of Cleveland and Atlanta, died Sunday in a hospital in Atlanta after a long illness. He lived in Cumming, Ga., and was 41 years old.

title: BASEBALL'S SNOWY INAUGURAL:
description: BASEBALL'S SNOWY INAUGURAL:

title: U.S. READY TO CEASE PUSH FOR PLUTONIUM AS FUEL IN REACTORS
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The Carter Administration is expected to announce tomorrow that it is stopping indefinitely efforts to develop plutonium as la fuel in nuclear power reactors in the United States.

title: TV: Stars, Nonsense; No Excuse
description: DON RICKLES, whose insult humor never strays completely from the truth, tonight looks into a television camera and moans, I can't believe it40 million shows and I had to get on this one. The twohour production he refers to is People's Command Performance: 1977, which gets under way at 9 o'clock on CBS. It springs, not quite whole, from a peculiar television category that can be labeled the manufactured special.

title: American General Adds Cash Option to Richmond Bid
description: Merger News merry the Continental Can Company, announced a merger agreement. Immediately, American General, which owns 9.7 percent of Richmond's shares, came up with a counteroffer for Richmond.

title: BRADLEY REELECTED LOS ANGELES MAYOR
description: LOS ANGELES, April 6Tom Bradley, the son of a Texas sharecropper who survived bitter racial attacks four years ago to become the first black Mayor of Los Angeles, swamped 11 white challengers yesterday to win a second term without being forced into a runoff election.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTONAt Quonset Point, R.I., about 20 miles south of Providence, the General Dynamics Corporation and the State of Rhode Island have the kind of deal that makes other companies and manpower officials in other states drool with envy. The Federal Government, however, is less than pleased.

title: With Big Man Back, Knick Fans Are 10 Feet Tall
description: It's like old times. He's back on the sidewalks of New York, and the people are stopping him, yelling to him, embracing him with their wellwishes. Three weeks ago it was on Seventh Avenue, and the kid called: Willis, it's great to have you back. We're set now.

title: 6 Sugar Concerns Charged With Price Conspiracy
description: Federal antitrust suits against six sugar refiners charging them with conspiring to increase and fix prices of sugar in Massachusetts and throughout the Northeast were filed yesterday by Francis X. Bellotti, Attorney General of Massachusetts, in Boston Federal District Court.

title: It's Not Who
description: PARIS WERRING pants is no longer a daring venture. Ten years ago it was an experience. Restaurants blocked their hastily set up dress codes.

title: The HighFashion Florists
description: Here is some basic information about the top boutique floriststheir styles and their charges (all of them emphasize that you don't need a letter of reference to become a customer). There is no significance to the order of listing.

title: Letter From Home
description: NEW HAVEN I'M SITTING in the fronton at Bridgeport watching my first game of jai alai. I already know that it won't be my last. The sport  being played by four lithe Basques is one of the most beautiful I have ever seen, and everyone around me is having, a, good time. It is the sort of good time that American families used to have when they went out bowling at night instead of staying home with televisionTVwatching is a private and passive act, but the American is a social have the feeling tonight that jai alai is giving us back some of our sociability.

title: Summaries of Finals
description: 200 Yard Backstroke4, John Nab?, University of Southern California, 1:46.57; 2, Tim Shaw, Long Beach, Calif., 1:43.49; 3, Dan Harrigan, Raleiro, N.C., 1:43.96; 4, Robert Tierney, University Southern California, 1:49.32; 5, Tom Wolf, Baltimore, 1:50.95; 6, Scott Gordin, U.C.L.A. 1:51.79; 7, Keitn Dickson, Gainesville, Fla., 1:51.57; 8, Cress tampleton, Indianapolis, 1:52.03.

title: Castro and Soviet Leaders Confer
description: MOSCOW; April 6 (Reuters)President Fidel Castro of Cuba and Soviet leaders held a second round of talks here today, apparently mapping their African strategy.

title: Marinduque Held Remiss On Some Commitments
description: The Marinduque Mining and Industrial Corporation said it had been advised by its independent auditors that it was not in compliance with financial covenants relating to maintenance of specified amounts of working capital and stockholder equity under a loan agreement with the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and Citibank.

title: Twas a Busy Day in Jersey
description: The signs were mostly of spring yesterday cherry blossoms, crew practice and getting a church ready for Easter. But for firemen in East Orange, it was risks as usual.

title: Model Rooms in Bloom
description: The humidity is high in Lord & Taylor this month. The store has worked a new twist on the personalization of model rooms. This season's crop of rooms (on display until midJuly) have had plants chosen for them by five prominent members of the Friends of the New York Botanical Garden.

title: COSMIC JOKE
description: COLD STORAGE by Ronald Ribman. Directed by Joel Zwick; settings by Ken Lundell; costumes by Ruth Morley; lighting by Edward M. Greenberg; production stage manager, Richard S. Viola Presented by the American Place Theater, Wynn Handman, director; Julia Mlles, associate.direcior, At 111 West 46th Street.

title: West Bank Arabs Demonstrate
description: NABLUS, Israeli Occupied West Bank, April 6 (Reuters)Israeli troops used tear gas to break up a demonstration by hundreds of young Arabs protesting Jewish settlement in the occupied territories. The youths, who gathered in the town square in this main town on the West Bank, stoned Israeli soldiers and Arab merchants who did not close their shops. There were no reports of arrests or injuries. The demonstration followed march by thousands of Israelis through the Samarian hills on the West Bank yesterday to mark their opposition to any withdrawal of Jewish settlers.

title: A Historical Frame of Reference
description: WASHINGTON When Pat Murray bought 120 acres of farmland five miles west of Peotone, Ill., in 1969, he had no idea that the old shack he found on the propertyand planned to tear downwould one day become a museum piece.

title: Oil Minister of Emirates Says 3Tier OPEC Price May Result at Meeting
description: ABU DHABI, April 6 (AP)The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries may find itself with a threetier oil price at its July meeting in Stockholm, Mana Saeed Oteiba, Oil Minister of the United Arab Emirates, said today in an interview.

title: Emotional Disorders and Mental Illness: Psychiatrists Debate CauseEffect Relationshifi
description: Freud got it the wrong way around, some psychiatrists are now asserting. Emotional disorders do not cause people to think in the bizarre, illogical patterns typical of mental illness. Rather, it is illogical or otherwise defective thinking patterns that cause emotional or behavioral problems.

title: Gold Rises to $149.18 At I.M.F.'s Auction
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI)The International Monetary Fund auctioned 524,800 ounces of fine gold today for an average price of $149.18 an ounce, up from the $148.60 an ounce it got at its last sale. The Fund said the estimated $57 million raised in the monthly auction would be used to help lessdeveloped nations. It has raised $506 million since its auctions began last year.

title: People in Sports
description: A $10,000 fine, the maximum penalty in professional tennis, was given to Vitas Gerulaitis for his irresponsibility in failing to appear at the Monte Carlo International tournament in Monaco.

title: Instant Garden
description: To give northern gardens a real headstart, one trick is to buy fieldgrown plants from the South. Fieldgrown specimens are often hardier and less weather susceptible than the greenhouseforced plants available at local nurseries. And some of the more unusual varieties can be raised this way too. Evans Plant Company, P.O. Box 1649, Tifton, Ga. 31794, for instance, will ship such plants as Sweet Banana yellow peppers, Hungarian Wax and Red Cayenne peppers, Vates collards, kale and climbing tomatoes. Most of their varieties have a minimum order quantity of 50 plantsbut at $3 to $4 for 50 plants, shipping included, they're inexpensive enoughyou can give the extras to your neighbors.

title: Navy Rushes to Complete Work On First U.S. Indian Ocean Base
description: DIEGO GARCIA, April 6The United States Navy is rushing to complete America's first air and naval facility in the Indian Ocean on this coral island 400 miles south of the Equator.

title: Market Place
description: Shares of Sears, Roebuck & Company hit their lowest level since 1974 yesterday, apparently reflecting among other things fears that Sears might someday be forced to reduce holdings of its own shares in its employee pension program.

title: Hillel Bernstein, 85, Newsman Who Wrote Books and Articles
description: Hillel Bernstein, a former newspaperman and author of the novel L'Affaire Jones, among other books and magazine articles, died Tuesday of an apparent heart attack in his home in Colebrook, Conn., after a long illness. His age was 85.

title: How a Psychiatrist Analyzed Nixon
description: THE INSIGHTS of psychoanalysis and the hard facts of history have resulted in a relatively new approach to biography called psychohistory. Because delving into the mind to offer explanations about motives and actions is not an exact discipline, psychohistory is a controversial subject, an art as much as a science.

title: Investors Finance Nixon TV Interviews
description: SAN DIEGO, April 6The filming of Richard M. Nixon's television interviews with David Frost is being financed by a group of 19 investors, almost all of them San Diegans, who have put up approximately $270,000 to cover all technical production costs of the fourpart series.

title: Golf's Spring Rite, the Masters, Starts Today at Augusta
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6In a country troubled by, among other things, income tax deadlines, inflation, recession, strategic arms limitation, a brutal winter and baseball holdouts, a welcome respite will open for business tomorrow.

title: A Legacy Of Mistrust
description: BOSTON, April 6Three times during a recent visit to Washington, in three very different contexts, I was told about the same problem. New Government officials said they had found that what they could do was narrowly controlled by detailed and rigid legislation.

title: President Backs Consumer Unit With Wide Role
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  President Carter endorsed today a proposal to set up an independent agency within the Federal Government to represent consumers.

title: Television
description: 6:10 (2,7)News 6:20 (5)News 6:30 (2)Sunrise Semester (4)Today's Army (5)Withit (7) Listen and Learn (11)The Little Rascals

title: 3 SAID TO BE IN LINE FOR PORT AGENCY JOB
description: The search for a successor to A. Gerdes Kuhbach as executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has narrowed to three men, sources close to the screening process said yesterday.

title: Poor Little Girl
description: AUDREY ROSE, directed by Robert Wise; screenplay by Frank De Felitta, based on his novel; produced by Joe Wizen and Mr. De Fetter director of photography, Victor J. Kemper; music, Michael Small; editor, Carl Kress; distributed by United Artists. Running time: 113 minutes. At Loews State 2, Broadway at 45th Street; Loew's One, Third Avenue near 86th Street and UA Eastside Cinema, Third Avenue at 55th Street. This film has been rated PG.

title: Hats to Keep Bulbs in the Shade
description: This Easter, hats are back. Brims are wide, worn down with one side flipped up,. All sport bands; some boast flat bows. Crowns? Most are round and firm bat oneon a fedorais creased with great swagger.

title: Mets Pick Seaver to Oppose Cubs at Chicago
description: With no anticipated defections but with another player addition, the Yankees begin their first pennant defense in 12 years today. This defense, they hope, will turn out better than the one in 1965 when they finished sixth.

title: Soviet Denies Human Rights Issue Led to Rejection of U.S. Arms Plans
description: MOSCOW, April 6A Soviet foreign affairs weekly has denied that the Kremlin rejected the recent American proposals for a new accord limiting strategic weapons in retaliation for the Carter Administration's criticism of human rights abuses.

title: Judge Calls a Meeting Of Lawyers in Jets Shift
description: Chief Judge David N. Edelstein has called back the contingent of lawyers for the city, the Mets, the Jets, the National Football League and the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority in an attempt to settle the case without a court hearing.

title: CARTER IS REBUFFED BY HOUSE ON RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The House of Representatives adopted human rights language opposed by President Carter as it approved a $5.2 billion international aid bill today.

title: Big Board and Amex Issue Reports Of Changes in Stock by Insiders
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in stock ownership by large stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies.

title: Owners of Seattle Slew Hedge Gotham Verdict
description: Just when management was getting ready to fire some promotional salvos, the custodians of Seattle Slew decided yesterday not to run their undefeated 3yearold colt in Saturday's Gotham Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: Seller Beware
description: If you're thinking about taking a purchase money mortgage on your house, let your lawyer and tax accountant dot all the I's and cross all the T's: Sharppenciled tax calculations and mortgage terms are crucial.

title: West German Y outh Found to Be Ignorant About Hitler Period
description: FLENSBURG, West GermanyA private study on what children know about Hitler has caused a stir because of the ignorance and confusion displayed. Dieter Bossmann, a Flensburg teacher who made the survey, found that Hitter had become a dim figure of the past for the average youngster.

title: YURI ZAVADSKY, ACTOR AND DIRECTOR, 82, DIES
description: Yuri Zavadsky, a onetime Stanislavsky protg who had headed the Moscow Soviet Theater since 1940, has died at the age of 82, according to Tass, the official press agency.

title: Holzer Finances Studied
description: A spokesman for Adela Holzer the theatrical producer, confirmed yesterday that her financial affairs were under investigation, but insisted that none of her theatrical activities were involved.

title: LEBANESE LEFTISTS KEEP UP PRESSURE
description: BEIRUT, April 6  Palestinian and Lebanese leftist Moslem militias maintained their pressure today on key positions of rightwing Christian forces near the Israeli border in south Lebanon.

title: Japan Again Intervenes to Check Yen's Advance in Hectic Trading
description: TOKYO, April 6After two days of hectic trading that pushed the yen to its highest value here in three years, trading pressure on the Japanese currency eased today after renewed Government intervention to stem what officials called much too rapid rise in the currency's value.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5;30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33500: WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORM% ERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 93300; NASSAU CO. (516) 747.0500; SUFFOLK co. (516) 1800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: News Summary
description: Egypt's President predicted normalization of relations between Israel and the Arab states following signature of a final settlement ending the state of war in the Middle East. At a Washington press conference after two days of talks with President Carter, President Anwar elSadat seemed to be trying to take positions closer to President Carter's, but he.indicated differences on details. [Page A1, Column 1.]

title: Home Beat
description: IT WON'T be your usual preview. Sybils, the new supper club designed by Sarah Tomerlin Lee and opening in midApril, is rolling out the red carpet beforehand for the beautiful people, the construction trades (carpet installers, painters, paperhangers, plasterers, electricians, carpenters, etc.) who contributed to its good looks.

title: Newly Owned 49ers Drop Clark as Coach
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 6 (AP)Monte Clark, who turned the San Francisco 49ers into a winner in his only year as a National Football League head coach, was dismissed today with three years remaining of his contract.

title: Bicyclist Hit by Car and Robbed
description: SAN ANTONIO, April 6 (UPI)A motorist ran down a 16yearold bicycle rider, rifled the stunned boy's pockets then stuffed the bike in the trunk of his car and sped away, the police reported today. Officers said that Antonio Pena had suffered leg and rib injuries when hit by the car last night.

title: JAVITS TO OFFER TAX PLAN IN LIEU OF CARTER REBATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 6Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York and five other Republicans said today that they would try to defeat President Carter's proposed $50 tax rebate with a proposal for a permanent reduction in personal income taxes for all taxpayers.

title: U.S. Uranium Supply Figures Disputed
description: Estimates of the size of the nation's supplies of uranium have become increasingly controversial as the Carter Administration prepares to release its comprehensive energy proposals on April 20.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Slightly Defensive and Greatly Relieved
description: NEW DELHI, April 6Indira Gandhi, breaking a twoweek silence in an interview published here today, said that was a big relief to be out of public life, and that she had no immediate plans to get back into it.

title: BRONX DRUG PROJECT LOSES ITS STATE FUNDS
description: The New York State Office of Drug Abuse Services announced yesterday that it would not give the New York City Addiction Services Agency $820,000 to renew its contract with the controversial Hispanic Association for a Drug Free Society (S.E.R.A.). This represents more than a quarter of the total amount of public funds received by the association.

title: Guards End Strike After a Warning From Gov. Grasso
description: HARTFORD, April 6Prison guards in Connecticut voted tonight to end their threeday strike, the first in the state's history.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 7, 1977 SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. on complaint of Benin. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Committee on Conferences3:30 P.M.

title: CUNNINGHAM'S BACK TAXES UNDER I.R.S. INVESTIGATION
description: The Internal Revenue Service is investigating the income tax liability of Patrick J. Cunningham, chairman of the Bronx Democratic party, for various taxable years and is demanding that he pay $16,215 in hack income taxes for 1972, according to documents filed in United States Tax Court in Washineton.

title: Gold
description: Selected world gold prices Wednesday. London: morning fixing $147.20, off $1.45: afternoon fixing $148.60, elf $0.05. Paris: afternoon fixing $149.05, off $1.50. Frankfurt: close unavailable.

title: Slow Economic Growth Seen in Western Europe
description: GENEVA. April 6The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe predicted today that Western Europe's rate of economic growth would be modest in 1977 and that unemployment might rise to a postwar record.

title: GILBERT PARTLY CLEARED IN BRUCE SECURITIES CASE
description: Edward M. Gilbert, who spent 25 months in jail for securities violations, did not really intend to steal money from his company, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has ruled in New York.

title: Concerto By Adam
description: CLAUS ADAM, during his many years as cellist of the Tuilliard String Quartet, maintained a parallel career as a composer, no doubt with some difficulty. Since leaving the quartet he has been concentrating more of his time and energies on writing music, and one fruit of his labor dropped off the vine on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, where the National Orchestral Association gave the first performance of his ConcertoVariations, a 1976 piece commissioned by the association.

title: Pornography Store Closed After Yearlong Dispute
description: The yearlong legal battle by New York City to oust one of the largest hardcore pornographic stores in Times Square ended yesterday when the store's operators agreed to close down. A police substation will replace it.

title: Business Records
description: ABBOT FABRICS INC., 1412 Broadway, N.Y. Liabilities, $2,613,521; assets, $2,891,059. Signed by Edward Roth. s?e n, President.

title: Eyewitness Testifies in Case of Banned Jockey
description: Attorneys for Sandino Hernandez continued to play a long shot yesterday that they could prove the jockey innocent of having an electric battery, or joint, in the Belmont Park paddock before he was scheduled to ride on Sept. 20, 1974.

title: ABCToo Many Hits to Handle
description: With a superabundance of hit shows in its current primetime schedule, ABCTV, in preparing for next fall, faces a dilemma the rival networks could envy.

title: SOL PERLMAN
description: Sol Perlman, a manufacturer of ornamental iron, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 40 East 84th Street.

title: President Signs Bill to Permit Government Reorganization
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  President Carter signed today legislation that will permit to begin reorganization of the executive branch of Government, and his assistants described the process that will be used in planning such changes in the organization.

title: SADAT SAYS HIS GOAL IS A NORMALIZATION OF TIES WITH ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said today after two days of talks with President Carter that everything will be normalized between Israel and the Arab states once a final settlement was signed ending the state of war in the Middle East.

title: Marriptt Is Sued On Its Retirement Plan
description: The Marriott Corporation and trustees of its employees profit sharing plan were charged in a suit filed in Baltimore Federal District Court with violating their fiduciary duties by investing too many of the plan's assets in Marriott Corporation stock.

title: Outclassed So. Dakotans A Hit With Cuban Fans
description: HAVANA, April 6Though they obviously have little to show their Cuban hosts in the way of basketball techniques, the visiting South Dakota squad has proved a hit in its goodwill tour here.

title: Federal Paper Board Plans Price Increases
description: The Federal Paper Board Company of Montvale, N.J., said it would increase prices for all grades of recycled paperboard by $15 to $20, a ton, effective with shipments of April 25. The company said it was also raising prices of folding cartons by 8 percent.

title: Sadat Seeks Normal Links to Israel,
description: He said. But he added that Egypt should not be asked to include such normalization as trade in an actual final.

title: Gromyko to Visit India
description: NEW DELHI, April 6 (UPI)Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union will pay an official visit to India April 25, India's Samachar news age nay reported today.

title: About New york
description: The grayhaired man came through the rain of Chelsea with a flaky vinyl satchel full of papers sorted into rubberbanded packets, as nervous as if he were about to confront his unmaker, and sighed and fidgeted and finally got help in the annual tax accounting to government for his confusing, pathetic business.

title: Ford Says Rhetoric Might Be a Factor In Rebuff on Arms
description: ANN ARBOR. Mich., April 6Former President Gerald R. Ford said here today that the recent breakdown in talks between the United States and the Soviet Union on a new treaty to limit strategic nuclear arms might have been the result of too much optimism on the part of the Carter Administration and too much rhetoric before and after the talks started, particularly about human rights.

title: Naber Wins 14th A.A.U. Title, Misses Backstroke Record
description: CANTON, Ohio, April 6 (AP)John Naber easily captured his 14th national Amateur Athletic Union swimming title tonight, but the Southern California senior was disappointed over his time in'the 200yard backstroke.

title: World News Briefs
description: CAPE TOWN, April 6 (Reuters)Prime Minister John Vorster will meet the ambassadors of the United States, Britain, France, West Germany and Canada here tomorrow, a spokesman for his office confirmed today.

title: Soybean Futures Prices Rise to a FourYear High as Supplies Dwindle
description: Prices of the dwindling supply of 1976crop soybeans rose to the highest level in nearly four years in volatile trading on the Chicaeo Board of Trade yesterday.

title: 20,000 Youngsters Apply for Summer Jobs
description: With 700 tired and shivering young people lined up for their first chance to enroll for this summer's New York City youth jobs, a West Side principal unlocked the doors of his junior high school at 3:30 A.M. yesterday to shelter the anxious jobseekers, among whom were about 200 girls. Some had waited since 1 P.M. Tuesday.

title: Soglin's 3dTerm Victory Indicates Madison Likes Its Radical Mayor
description: MADISON, Wis., April 6Voters here indicated yesterday that they felt comfortable with their youthful, onceradical Mayor, reelecting Paul R. Soglin to a third twoyear term.

title: ExMarine Sentenced For $500,000 Theft
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 6Richard Charles Rees, a decorated Vietnam War veteran and former Brinks armored car guard who walked off with $500,000 here last year and spent it in a 10month spree through the Southwest, was sentenced today on bank larceny charges to 10 years in Federal prison.

title: How to Keep Your Easter Plants Blooming
description: FLORIST shops and garden centers look dreamy this week, with all sorts of spring plants in bloom for Easter. There are lilies, azaleas, tulips, hyacinths, cineratias and hydrangeas in a panoply of spring colors.

title: Unions and Employers Join in Fight Against Halt in Redwood Cutting
description: EUREKA, Calif., April 6The white smoke from the pulp mills mixes with the persistent fog that hangs here on the coast just below the Oregon border.

title: 20,000 Youngsters Apply for Summer Jobs
description: With 700 tired and shivering young people lined up for their first chance to enroll for this summer's New York City youth jobs, a West Side principal unlocked the doors of his junior high school at 3:30 A.M. yesterday to shelter the anxious jobseekers, among whom were about 200 girls, Some had waited since 1 P.M. Tuesday.

title: Prague Is Said to Tell Dissidents That They May Be Allowed to Leave
description: VIENNA, April 6Various prominent signers of the Czechoslovak human rights manifesto known as Charter 77, some of whom are now in prison, during the last few days have been given to understand by the authorities that they may be permitted to leave the country, according to reliable information from Prague.

title: Disks: Berio, Bach And Bing Crosby
description: If one were to make a list of cornpleat musicians of the second half of the 20th century; Luciano Berio's name would surely demand a place near the top, The Italian composer, who is now 51 years old, immersed himself early in the three major movements of his timeserial, electronic and aleatoryand mastered them all. Then, having done that, he pretty much abandoned doctrinaire approaches and, for the last 15 years or so, he has seemed simply to be writing music as he feels it.

title: The GoodHumored Gardener
description: By Annilca Hohma nn and Treaska Blase,  1975, The Yeoman Group

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: GRAINS & FEEDS

title: Seattle Festive In Welcoming Baseball Back
description: SEATTLE, April 6Major league baseball returned to Seattle today in a fit of festive civic enthusiasm that promised longterm success where there had been abysmal failure only seven years aeo.

title: EXBEATLES MANAGER IS INDICTED ON TAXES
description: Allen Klein, former manager of the Beatles and other popular performers, was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on charges of evading $125,000 in Federal income taxes in an alleged scheme to sell promotional records.

title: Romulo, Drowning
description: WASHINGTONCarlos Romulo is an authentic hero of World War II. A Pulitzer Prizewinning newspaper editor, the loyal aide of Gen. Douglas MacArthur, he was one of the founders of the United Nations and author of its 1947 freedomofinformation declaration.

title: Army Chief Suggests Drafting of Women
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)Women have proven to be such an asset to the Army that serious consideration may be given to drafting them if Congress restores conscription, according to the Army chief of staff.

title: Family Money: HOW to Sell Your Home and Avoid High Taxes
description: THE WOMAN we'll call Margaret Dunbar is a 66yearold widow who learned the value of the dollar the hard way. When her husband died 13 years ago, she ran the family business for a time, scrimped to get the children through college, and then suddenly found herself with a goodsized suburban home that had became a financial burden.

title: Banker Sees No Danger of Default By Developing Nations on Loans
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UP1)A leading banker specializing in foreign loans said today he knew of no developing country in danger of failing to repay its debts to commercial banks.

title: A Healthy Shock for City and Nation
description: A most comprehensive Federal examination of New York City's economyby the General Accounting Office for the Congresshas hit officialdom here like a pail of cold water. The immediate effect was shocking, but the longterm effect should be wholesome, even helpful.

title: In Memoriam
description: AD7LMANLcon L., dlod April 7, 1974. In chorlshed memory of a truly great and wonderful man. Missed and loved forever.

title: U.S. Wouldn't Bar A Communist Role In West's Cabinets
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The State Department said today that the United States would not intervene in West European countries to prevent the participation of Communists in government but would'be concerned if they came to dominate those governments.

title: Selling Pressure in Sears Pushes Dow to Lowest Level in 15 Months
description: Selling pressure in Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, helped push the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday to its lowest level in nearly 15 months.

title: When Sunday Afternoon Was a 7thInning Stretch
description: MILL VALLEY, Calif.Before the appearance of freeways, the disappearance of porches, the obsolescence of brickwalks, sidewalks, and cakewalks, we washed the Hupmobile on Sunday mornings, ate a chicken dinner, then drove over to the ball game. If we parked in the shade out in center field we had a good head start on the fielder in chasing home runs. If we parked behind the chicken wire backstop we were closer to the action and the water fountain. Between innings we could listen to the major league game on the radio.

title: Toyota Will Increase Auto Prices in U.S.
description: The Toyota Motor Sales Company, the sales arm of the Toyota Motor Company, said it plans to increase its retail car prices in the United States to make up for exchange losses stemming from the recent rise in the yen against the dollar. Officials declined to give details of the planned increases.

title: Butter, Not Guns, for Mr. Sadat
description: President Sadat of Egypt has a new very dear friend in Washington, an embrace that needs to be understood as well as appreciated. For all the charm and hospitality of Jimmy Carter's White House, his is a friendship of need and convenience. It is the same friendship that was so ostentatiously pressed upon Henry Kissinger's cheeks on the banks of the Nile. The United States can and should reciprocate these sentiments, but it need not purchase them with arms.

title: Sound
description: AFTER A DECADE of slow and sometimes painful maturation, cassettes have emerged as the dominant medium for home recording. At the latest count, cassette decks outsold reel recorders by a ration of 10 to 1.

title: City U. Will Require 3R College Tests
description: The City University disclosed yesterday that it would begin testing students next fall to make sure that they could meet minimum standards in the basic areas of reading, mathematics and writing.

title: Dollar Is Off a Bit In Major Markets; Gold Holds Steady
description: LONDON, April 6 (AP)The dollar eased slightly on all major European money markets today. The price of gold remained steady following a drop of $2 an ounce yesterday.

title: LAG IN NEW PRODUCTS IN CITY FOUND TO CUT AREA INCOME GROWTH
description: The innovative, risktaking people of New York City are no longer developing the new products that once bolstered the region's economy and the result has been a growth lag in the personal income level in the metropolitan area, according to a study from the Conference Board.

title: RICHARD C. LARKINS
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 6 (AP)Richard C. Larkins, retired athletic director of Ohio State University, died today after a heart attack. He was 67 years old. Mr. Larkins, who was graddated from Ohio State in 1931, retired JO 1970 after serving as athletic director ??r, 14 years. He was responsible for impending the program to 18 varisity sports and was prominent in the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: DR. EARL C. ELKINS
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., April 5 (AP)Earl C. Elkins, founder of the Mayo Clinic's school of physical medicine and a leader in the field of physical medicine and rehabilitation, died today at Methodist Hospital here. He was 72 years old. He had been ill for some time with chronic lung and heart diseases.

title: GOOD FRIDAY
description: Tomorrow is Good Friday. The following is a list of activities that will be affected:

title: GARDENING: IN AND OUT
description: Grow your own tomatoes and chances are you'll rarely again buy the tasteless pink cue balls passed of as the vegetable at the local supermarket. Still, at least tomatoes can be found there. It is possible to purchase them. The same cannot be said very often, if at all, for salsify, yellow peppers, Jalapeno chilies, fennel (a superb salad accent when plucked fresh from the garden), or for that matter such horticultural novelties as spaghetti squash.

title: Bridge
description: It is well known that duplicate bridge is a game of tops and bottoms, and a player whose score card lacks single good result is said to be topless.

title: Advertising
description: Advertising executives are divided on the question of whether or not former agency people serving as consultants to a client seeking a new agency can do so without bias. Those on one side cite human nature while those on the others speak of integrity.

title: Radio

description: BENKARDFranklIn Bartiettt, on Sunday, April 3, 1977, husband of Laura Dupe Benkard, father of Joan B. Jackson and and James W. B. Benkard, also survived by eight grandchildren. Memorial service Thursday, April 7, at P.M. at St. James Church, Madison Ave. at 71st St. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests that contriburions may be sent to Harlan Fiske Stone Scholarship Fund of Columbia Law School.

title: Design Notebook
description: DO ARCHITECTS consider irrelevant? Composers would sooner dismiss concertos, you might think, but every so often a current of thinking runs through the profession that argues that houses at least the private, singlefamily kindare detached from the greater social concerns that architects are supposed to espouse. The individual house has no place in American culture anymore, John Dinkeloo, a partner in Kevin Roche, John Dinkeloo & Associates, said not long ago, and he was speaking for a fair number of his colleagues.

description: Longshoremen removed their picket lines yesterday from the Hudson River pier at 36th Street after the city took a controversial precondition out of a proposed contract with a cargo company seeking to lease the pier.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Five persons from Philadelphia and New Jersey have been indicted on charges of operating an autoinsurance policy scheme that defrauded the State Farm Insurance Company of $8,000. A 13count indictment charged that the defendants falsely reported the insured autos as stolen to collect their value under policies held with State Farm. The autos, in fact, were not stolen but had been disposed of by the defendants, the indictment charged.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SPURS AND CURS A picturesque Old West is the new free attraction at the Kodak Photo Gallery, that rewarding showcase at 43d Street and Avenue of the Americas that many midtown pedestrians somehow bypass, In tracing the mystique and lingering influence of an era, The American Cowboy in Fact and Fiction features 175 photographs, art work and slide projections and such artifacts as saddles, branding irons and lariats. The show runs until June 4. Gallery hours are noon to 5 P.M. on Mondays and from 10 A.M. on Tuesdays through Saturdays.

title: House Panel Votes to Raise Props On Wheat, Corn Above Carter Bid
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI)  Overriding its veteran chairman, a House subcommittee today voted to raise 1977 and 1978 wheat and corn support target prices far beyond levels recommended by President Carter.

title: Geronimo's Homer Off Randy Jones Deciding Blow
description: CINCINNATI, April 6 (AP)Cesar Geronimo drilled a tworun homer and Ken Griffey rapped three hits, leading the Cincinnati Reds to a 53 victory over Randy Jones and the San Diego Padres today in baseball's traditional regularseason opener.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street. the Bronx, 2 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 11, 2 P.M.) (RadioWMCA: 1:55 P.M.)

title: DoItYourself Q & A
description: Q: I live in an old house that has steam heat and my problem is that on each floor steam comes quickly into two or three radiators, but more slowly to the others on that floor. If I set the thermostat at 70, the slow radiators never get warm; if I turn it up to 77, all of them get hot, but the first ones overheat the room they are in. Is it possible to regulate the flow of steam to balance the heat more evenly?R.C.. Bavville. N.Y.

title: PREGNANCY BENEFIT BILL IS DISPUTED AT HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI)Women's rights groups and organized labor urged Congress today to counter a major Supreme Court ruling by amending the 1964 Civil Rights Act to make the law clearly prohibit job discrimination because of pregnancy.

title: The Flower Powers
description: WHILE THE Chinese call this the year of the snake, accomplished trend spotters say this is the year of the florist, superseding the year of the fashion designer, the year of the hairdresser, the year of the decorator, the year of the sheet designer and the year of the plant person.

title: Legislature Weighs a Plan to Pay Local Taxes on State Buildings
description: TRENTON, April 6A program that could bring added tax relief to local property taxpayers is under consideration by the Joint Appropriations Commitee of the State Legislature.

title: Personal Beauty
description: MEET THE authors. In this corner, in the black leotard, Allegra Kent, the dancer iwith the New. York. City Ballet, who is not quite. 5 feet 4 and weighs 100 pounds. In the tight, blue jersey Tshirt and ruffled skirt, Stella Jolas Reichman, 5 feet 8 and 200 pounds.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, April 66The State Supreme Court upheld today a 1974 ruling by its Advisory Committee on Professional Ethics forbidding a county freeholder who is a lawyer to represent a criminal defendant in the county in which he holds office.

title: CRUDE OIL IMPORTS FALL TO NORMAL LEVELS IN WEEK
description: The American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday that crude oil imports were back to normal levels last week after having set record highs the week before, although still well ahead of last year's levels.

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: Among the freshestlooking table linens around are those CacheCache makes up from its own fabrics. There are two cotton florasboth the essence of spring. English Garden offers nosegays of bright flowers on a white ground. Sharon has scatterings of rather Chineselooking orange and yellow flowers on grass green. Or you can get the linens made up in white piqu. Some of the designs, like placemats and napkins, are scalloped in contrasting binding. You can also order the linens in solid colors with any binding. Placemats (fabric or laminated) are $5, napkins are $5, cocktail napkins are $2.50. There are also trays from $18 to $25, straw French bread baskets with fabric liners, $20, and laminated coasters, $7.50 for six. Or you can have a round cloth made to order. In white piqu, with a color border, a cloth covering a 3footdiameter table to the ground is $55; the same size cloth in a floral is $75. CacheCache is at 758 Madison Avenue (between 65th and 66th Streets).

title: Williams Leans To S.E.C. Role On Capital Aid
description: WASHINGTON, April 6Harold M. Williams, nominated last week to head the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today he was attracted to the idea that the agency be given broad responsibility to ensure that American business is able to find the capital it needs to finance inyestment in new facilities.

title: New York State Employees Plan For a Possible Strike on April 18,
description: The Civil Service Employees Association, representing 145,000 state employees, began making plans yesterday, for a possible strike on April 18 after rejecting the Carey administration's most recent nay offer.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Reports
description: For perlods ended Feb. 28 unless otherwise indicated. (N) Indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) OvertheCounter.

title: Detroit Bank Planning Ford Stock Purchases
description: The Manufacturers National Bank of Detroit said that as trustee for the Ford Motor Company's savings and stock investment plan for salaried employees, it has agreed to acquire between 200,000 and 300,000 shares of Ford commun stock from the estate of the late Eleanor Clay Ford, mother of Henry Ford 2d, the company's chairman.

title: Editorial Asks Beame To Shun Reelection
description: The Daily News has called on Major Beame to formally rule himself out as a candidate for reelection.

title: A Sullivan Room Is Recreated in Chicago
description: CHICAGOA room in the justcompleted addition to the Art Institute here has 400 cast ironframed skylights, eight columns with elaborately ornamented gold capitals, and stenciled ceiling ornament so intricate that it An Apprasial contains 55 separate colors. The room is not quite in An the style of Skidmore, OwAppraisal ings & Merrill, the addition's architects, but there is a good reason for that. It was designed, not by Skidmore in the 1970's, but by Louis Sullivan and his partner, Dankmar Adler, in 1893. The elaborate room was the trading room in the Chicago Stock Exchange, one of this city's great early skyscrapers and a major building in the history of American architecture.

title: Litton Ingalls Unit Accused of False Claims
description: A Federal grand jury has charged that the Litton Industries Ingalls Nuclear Shipbuilding division had lodged fraudulent claims against the Government in its continuing dispute with the Navy over shipping claims. The indictment, handed down by the grand jury in Alexandria, Va., charged that the claim involved delays in construction of three nuclearpowered attack submarines and submission of subcontracting costs not in the contract. If convicted, Ingalls could be fined a maximum of $10,000.

title: Cancer Project Shows Home Care For Dying Child Helps Families
description: SARASOTA, Fla., April 6Seth died as we had often talked aboutcuddled in our arms before a blazing fire in utter quiet and peace. We have such good feelings about the peace of that moment that it has been immeasurably easier to deal with this reality.

title: Visionary Painter Has a Cause A War on Global Ugliness
description: ANNETSURMARNE, FRANCE VICTOR VASARELY'S paintings and art objects have commanded impressive prices for many years, but he believes that the individual artist is out of date because no single creator can relieve the visual pollution that has made ugliness a worldwide affliction.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BASEBALL'S SNOWY INAUGURAL: Before the National League season opener could be played, a Cincinnati groundskeeper had to clear the infield of a threeinch snowfall. With the windchill factor at 14 degrees, the

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday Prime rale: 6.

title: Fresh Flower Secrets
description: Flowers with woody stems like lilacs and apple blossom wilt quickly. To retard wilting, you must cut the branches to the right length, with a sharp knife (breaking or crushing the stein will break the cells and foul the water), split the bottom of the stem vertically a few inches and scrape the stems with the same sharp knife. Then stand the ends of the stems in boiling hot water for 20 to 50 seconds, scalding ??? Next, condition the stems in coal or lukewarm (not cold) water while standing in a cool place.

title: How to Take Care Of Marble at Home
description: Home care of marble is easy.

title: JAMES W. JARDINE
description: CHICAGO, April 6 (UPI)James W. Jardine, Chicago's first water commissioner, died last night of an apparent heart attack, He was 68 years old.

title: Along Columbus Avenue Treasures and Trash
description: THERE IS not much that a turnofthecentury wooden icebox can do for a head of lettuce. But dust it off, fit it with shelves, and it can become an ingenious bar, stereo cabinet, or a place to hide the television.

title: Herbert Brucker Dies at Age 78; Long Defended Press Freedom
description: Herbert Brucker, journalist, teacher and one of the country's leading defenders of freedom of the press, died of cancer Tuesday in Hartford. He was 78 years old.

title: A McCarthy Era Tactic in the Assassination Committee
description: WASHINGTONThe House Select Committee on Assassinations made a grandstand play last month that was reminiscent of the McCarthy era.

title: More Appalachia T owns Imperiled As Flood Crests Move Downstream
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 6Thousands who fled to high ground yesterday before one of the Appalachian region's worst spring floods came down from the hillsides this afternoon under snow flurries to pick despairingly through sodden houses in scores of flooded valley coal towns.

title: Apartment Building for the Blind Is Planned for Site in Manhattan
description: The first apartment building in New York City designed for the exclusive use of the blind will be built on a vacant site on West 23d Street, officials of the Associated Blind Inc. said yesterday.

title: Calif ano's Goal Is to Lift Immunization Level of Children to Over 90%
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The Carter Administration announced formally today its plans to immunize 20 million American children against major childhood diseases by the fall of 1979 and to establish a permanent system to insure the immunization of the three million born each year.

title: Pop: Dream In Sequence
description: IN TANGERINE DREAM, the Ger man spacerock band that made its first New York appearance at Avery Fisher Hail on Tuesday, most of the instruments traditionally associated with rock have been replaced by keyboardcontrolled electronic.. simulations. One hears a thudding bass drum, metronomic cymbal and tinny snare, the sound of an electric bass and the accompanying textures ofhorns and strings.

title: Dramatic Turnaround of a Canadian Pulp Enterprise
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, March 28After a string of losing years, the comeback of a once badly ailing wood pulp enterprise at Prince Rupert, in northern British Columbia, is being hailed here as one of the most dramatic turnarounds in the history of the Canadian forest products industry.

title: TARGET IS ATTAINED IN FISCAL EXCHANGE
description: Its target of $400 million reached, the Municipal Assistance Corporation yesterday brought to an earlierthananticipated close the socalled exchange offer in which owners of shortterm New York City notes had been given the chance to exchange them for M.A.C. bonds.

title: British Are Urged to Provide Camps for Gypsies
description: LONDON, April 6An officially sponsored report published today called for the Government to provide permanent campsites for the gypsies of England and Wales where they can park their caravans without harassment.

title: Seattle Slew Status Unclear
description: The owners of Seattle Slew hedged on their decision on whether to run the unbeaten colt in Saturday's Gotham Stakes a few hours after the train er said he would not run. Page B6.

title: The Standings
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME California 7, Seattle 0. Other teams not scheduled.

title: Post Office Restoring Shahn Murals in Bronx
description: The National Postal Service, which has many people doubting its competence these days, has managed a major act of artistic preservation in the Bronx by restoring a set of 13 massive wall murals by Ben Shahn and rescuing them from the designing instincts of government architects.

title: Anyone for KiteFlying?
description: The New York Times/Chester Mains Jr.

title: President Backs Consumer Unit With Wide Role
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  President Carter endorsed today a proposal to set up an independent agency within the Federal Government to represent consumers.

title: Notes on People
description: THE President's son, Jack Carter, who received a less than honorable discharge from the Navy, said yesterday he does not intend to take advantage of his father's new program to have upgraded undesirable or general discharges given Vietnamera servicemen.
