Mr. Carter, who got a general discharge from the Navy for having smoked marijuana, said The first and most obvious reason he won't ask to have his discharge changed is that his father authorized the program. I don't want people to think that he did that tor me, because he didn't, Mr. Carter said on the Good Morning, America television show. As far as I'm concerned, it doesn't make a great deal of difference.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Paul Fluitt, who pleaded guilty last February to mugging a 91yearold man in the Bernard Baruch Houses on the Lower East Side, was sentenced to three to six years in prison by Justice Burton B. Roberts in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. Mr. Fluitt, who is 27 years old and lives in Central Islip, L.I., was on parole at the time of the mugging last May, having just been released after three years in prison for a previous robbery at the Baruch Houses.

title: Events Today
description: LADIES AT THE ALAMOby Pahl Zindel; directed be Frank Perry; starring Estelle Parsons, Eileen Heckart and Rosemary Murphy; at the Martin Beck Theater, 302 West 45th Street, 6:45.

title: Is Queens Population Up? Chamber's No Challenged
description: Community leaders assailed the Queens Chamber of Commerce yesterday in a ruckus over whether the borough's population is still growing.

title: Rhodesian Regime Takes Its Case to Black Grade Schools
description: KAFUSI, RhodesiaWhen a truckload of Government soldiers armed with automatic rifles rolled up to the Mawaza Primary School in the dusty bushland near here the other day, some of the black pupils scattered, fearful that the men in camouflage uniforms had come to kill or abduct them.

title: People and Business
description: Michael Pertschuk, 44yearold Capitol Hill veteran, was confirmed yesterday by the Senate as chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Letters
description: The recent rebuff of the United States by Moscow provokes a series of questions. These are especially pertinent in view of the contention of successive Presidents that we are the most powerful nation in the world.

title: Fred Bauer, 93, in Tennessee; SpanishAmerican War Veteran
description: MEMPHIS, Epril 5 (AP)Fred Bauer, one of the youngest veterans of the SpanishAmerican War, died Sunday night at Veterans Hospital. He was 93 years old.

title: FRENCH CIRCLES CITED FOR RAID AGAINST BENIN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 6Benin's delegate charged in the Security Council today that reactionary, neocolonialist circles in France and their African accomplices were responsible for an armed January attack by foreign mercenaries against his small West African country.

title: Jersey Obtains a Stay On Conrail's Service
description: TRENTON, April 6A Federal judge issued ???? today against the continued posting of service discontinuance notices by Conrail at New Jersey railroad stations.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Leonard Silk discusses the dependence of the United States on imported oil as one of the complexities of longterm planning in an energy program. Page D5.

title: Young Calls Britain  A Little Chicken On Racial Matters
description: LONDON, April 6Andrew Young, the outspoken United States delegate to the United Nations, told a British television audience last night that their country was a little chicken on racial questions at home as well as in Rhodesia and South Africa.

title: The Standings
description: American League

title: In Memoriam
description: GAYLE, FAMILY, LEE LONDONDr. Emanuel. In loving ret membrance of a memorable father and grandfather. Jacqule, Maury, Kathie and Bob.

title: People and Business
description: The General Foods Corporation, a leading producer of packaged foods and groceries, announced yesterday the election of Ross Barzelay as president. He succeeds James L. Ferguson, who remains chairman and chief executive officer.

title: New Face
description: Nobody told Kirk Douglas to fill in the dimple on his chin, said Steven Keats, so why should they tell me to fill in the gap between my two front teeth? I can put caps on them, the same as I can put a hump on my back. That's what an actor does; he changes physically and psychologically from role to role.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The founder of the Church of the New Revelation vehemently denied reports yesterday that his taxexempt organization served as a front for a nationwide homosexual pornography ring. Adam Starchild, founder of the Kearnybased church, said the reports were frustrating, embarrassing and untrue. He said he had founded the church to enable people to worship in small groups at private homes rather than in large congregations.

title: Talmadge Gives Food Stamp Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)The chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee said today that he would introduce egislation to extend the present rules for the food stamp program for one more year and then to convert the stamps to cash grants that could ho used by recipients for any purpose.

title: Ben Peterson, Adams Gain in A.A.U. Wrestling
description: AMES, Iowa, April 7 (AP)Ben Peterson, an Olympic gold medalist, led a group of former National Collegiate champions who scored first round victories today in the National Amateur Athletic Union freestyle wrestling championships.

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. Donald Kennedy, who was sworn in yesterday as head of the Food and Drug Administration, told employees of the agency, now embroiled in controversy over its recent order banning saccharin, that friends had suggested he was taking on the captaincy of the Titanic. Dr. Kennedy, on leave from Stanford University, said that his Ole goal would be restoring public confidence in the F.D.A., and that in the future there would be the strongest and clearest public explanations of agency actions and decisions. Dr. Kennedy said he would take no position on the saccharin ban at this time, but added that it would be the subject of a lot of sober thought at the agency.

title: ExHirsch Partners Fail in Appeals Suit
description: A decision dismissing damage claims against the New York Stock Exchange and a major public accounting concern was affirmed in Manhattan yesterday by a Federal appeals court that said the securities laws were not enacted to protect sophisticated businessmen from their own errors of judgment.

title: Renee Richards Reports She Has Passed Sex Test
description: Dr. Renee Richards says she has passed a sexchromosome test.

title: Sports Today
description: Yale at Columbia, 3 P.M. (Radio  WKCR, 2:55 P.M.)

title: Untied Press International
description: DUTCH BURY VICTIMS OF TENERIFE CRASH Bodies of 180 victims of the Canary Islands collision between a Pan American jetliner and a KLM plane are buried in Amsterdam. The other 68 dead will be buried privately.

title: Search for Most Wanted Person Was Involved in F.B.I. Indictment
description: One of the longstanding members or the. Federal Bureau of Investigation's list of 10 most wanted persons is Bernardine Rae Dohrn, leader of the Weather Underground, a terrorist group that has said it was responsible for numerous bombings.

title: Closings on Good Friday
description: All securities and commodity exchanges in the United States and Canada will be closed today because of Good Friday. Banks in New Jersey and Connecticut will be closed but New York banks will remain open. All Federal offices will be open and postal services will operate normally.

title: Publishing: Fascination of Evil
description: Hitler was probably the weakest leader Germany has known in this century. he took ineffectual measures against his enemies inside Germany Hitler ordered that there was to be no extermination of the Jews. the killing was partly of an ad hoc nature Hitler was a less than omnipotent Ferther and his grip on his subordinates weakened as the war progressed The biggest problem in dealing analytically with Hitler is the aversion to him as a person created by years of intense wartime propaganda and emotive postwar historiography.

title: Saving Lives, Not Gasoline
description: DANBURY, Conn.The hospital I'm associated with is situated off a major highway, and I am frequently called upon to mend the broken bones and torn faces suffered in automobile accidents. Too often, the thought recurs to me, This accident was preventable.

title: For Children
description: BRING SAILING BACK INC., program by Nicholas V Van Nes, to Introduce children and parents to sailing on the 70.foot yawl Petrel, which has a 93.toot mainmast and a crew or rive and accommodates 35 persons who are encouraged to help with the sail. ing. Petrel sails from Gangway A behind the Coast Guard Station in Battery Path for Staten Island, ??? Island And Governors Island, 1.30 to 3:30 P.M. and 4 to 6 P.M. on Saturday and Sunday. Children. 1? and younger, and the eternally, 54; adults, $6. Call 8251977 or 525.1979 for reservations.

title: Summaries of A.A. U. Swimming Finals
description: 200Yard Freestyle1, Jim Montgomery, Bloomington., Ind., 1:35.67, American record; previous record, 1:36.16, by Bruce Furniss, University of Southern California, 1977; 2, John Haber, U.S.C., 1:36.21; 3, Andy Cohn, Univ, of Tennessee, 1:38.10; 4, Mark. Greenwood, U.S.C., 1:38.36; 5, Steve Pickell, U.S.C., 1:38.76; 6, Doug Lambert, Univ, of Tennessee, 1:38.82; 7, Bob Sells, Univ, of Tennessee, 1:39.43; 8, Steve Nelson, U.C.L.A., 1:39.71.

title: Land Reform Fades in E1 Salvador
description: USULUTAN, El SalvadorAfter last year's land reform scare, the mood in the Hacienda La Carrera is again relaxed. Production is almost back to normal, two military guards carrying automatic rifles barely glance at the working peasants and even the farm's supervisors are carrying pistols more out of habit than need.

title: Carter Names 10 as Ambassadors, Accepting Advice of New Board
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)President Carter's first major ambassadorial appointments are going to the Governor of Wisconsin, former Senator Mike Mansfield; two educators, three career Foreign Service officers and two Georgians.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 7 (AP)Iran's official news agency said today that 170 people had been counted dead so far in yesterday's earthquake in a rugged mountain region of western Iran.

title: New Face
description: Stephen Collins has a handicap that never wins him much sympathy. Mr. Collins looks like the AllAmerican Boy a regular Jack Armstrong. That's not exactly a crippling burden in show business, he admits, but he says it can make life difficult for a serious actor. It's what I call the Richard Chamberlain problem, he said. You have to spend your life convincing people you can act, as well as stand there and look good.

title: Music: Barenboim, the Prodigy, Grows Gracefully into Late Youth
description: DANIEL BARENBOIM has been a brand name on the international music scene for more than 20 years, although he is now only 34, and as he totters into what may be called late youth he continues to get better. The pianist and conductor, back as a guest leader of the New York Philharmonic on Wednesday for a threeweek engagement, made a graceful bow as soloist in Beethoven's earliest piano concerto, accompanying himself expertly in the 18thcentury manner from the keyboard.

title: ROKATYN URGES CITY TO ISSUE OWN NOTES
description: Flushed with the success of the $400 million offering of Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds, Felix G. Rohatyn, the M.A.C. chairman, urged yesterday that New York City try to issue its own notes to the public to meet some of its shortterm borrowing needs this summer.

title: Lucchesi Unreceptive To Randle Apology
description: BALTIMORE, April 7 (UPI)Manager Frank Lucchesi of the Texas Rangers spurned today any apology from Lenny Randle after the utility infielder decided not to appeal his suspension and fine for punching Lucchesi last month.

title: Williamson, W.Va., Is. Staggering In Aftermath of Heavy Flooding
description: WILLIAMSON, W. Va., April 7When the waters of the Tug Fork started rising on Monday afternoon the river quickly topped the flood wall here. The inundation of this city of about 7,000 persons came so quickly that no one had time to save anything.

title: Ritchie Joins Texas Staff
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 7 (AP)Richard Ritchie, who led Texas A. and I. to three national small college football titles and a 39game winning streak, has been hired to coach University of Texas quarterbacks. He will serve as a graduate assistant. Ritchie quarterbacked the veer formation. Texas shifted to that formation in spring training, which ended last Saturday.

title: Commodity Price Index Declines 0.1 From the WeekEarlier Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell slightly to 219.1 from 219.2 last week.

title: Tea Helps to Buff a Victorian Aura
description: New Yorkers seem to be going to a lot of tea parties these days. Not to drink tea, necessarily. Given a choice, they're more likely to head for the bar than the tea tray. But it's chic to call a gathering a tea party, even if it happens at 6:30 and is held in a department store.

title: Edelstein Works His Political Savvy Into His City U. Post
description: There is a 30yearold story told about a much younger Julius C. C. Edelstein, vice chancellor for urban affairs of th City University of New York, when he was political adviser to the first President of the Republic of the Philippines, the late Manuel Roxas.

title: Ailing Stockton Is Off Cup Team; Tanner, Smith and Lutz Added
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., April 7Eight days before the United States meets South Africa in the American Zone, North Section final of the Davis Cup, Capt. Tony Trabert has changed three members of his fourman team.

title: ExF.B.I. Man Indicted by U.S. InMail Opening
description: WASHINGTON, April 7A Federal grand jury in New York today indicted John J. Kearney, a former supervisor in the Federal Bureau of Investigation, on charges that agents working under his direction had illegally opened mail and tapped telephones in their search for Weather Underground fugitives.

title: The Pop Life
description: MANY ROCK CRITICS take a jaundiced view of the classical, middleoftheroad idiom of Emerson, Lake and Palmer. The trio's portentously entitled new twodisk album, Works, Volume 1, has been savaged in the British press: critics don't know what to lambaste firstKeith Emerson's highbrow pretensions, Greg Lake's dopy sentimentality, Carl Palmer's noisy percussiveness or the combined group's inflated classical rock. The public, on the other hand, seems to be gobbling it up, and the group plans a fulldress tour in this country starting May 29, with New York dates at Madison Square Garden set for July 7, 8 and 9 (tickets not yet on sale).

title: Indians Down Red Sox on Chopper in 11th, 54
description: BOSTON, April 7 (AP)Frank Duffy charged home on Duane Kuiper's I I thinning chopper, barely beating the throw and giving the Cleveland Indians a 54 victory over the Boston Red Sox in their American League opener today.

title: Books: A Woman of God
description: If the people called Shakers are now remembered with quaint fondness and respect, then it is worth recalling their early sufferings at the hands of a society that regarded them as a menace. Scourged for their opposition to sexual intercourse, reviled for ecstatic religious practices and unorthodox beliefs, they survived the first years of their existence in the 1770's only by the fiercest devotion and the phenomenal example of their founder, Mother Ann Lee.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Given the propensity of Americans to divorce and remarry, one would think they could live comfortably with the fact of being stepparents.

title: Around the Nation
description: The police arrested 128 striking teachers at four Kansas City, Mo., high schools yesterday for blocking driveways, shouting obscenities, throwing eggs and interfering with police officers, United Press International reported.

title: TEANECK PANEL ACTS ON SABBATH CURBS
description: TEANECK, April 7The Board of Education expressed a willingness last night to replace its restrictions on schoolsponsored activities on the Christian and Jewish Sabbaths with a new scheduling policy that avoids mentioning religion.

title: News Summary
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, who in charge of Israel's caretaker Government, withdrew as the Labor Party's candidate for the prime ministership in the May 17 elections. His withdrawal was announced following Israeli newspaper reports that Mr. Rabin had lied about the amounts he kept in bank accounts in Washington. Such deposits are illegal under Israeli currency laws. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Pirates Retire No. 40, Long Worn by Murtaugh
description: PITTSBURGH, April 7 (UPI)The Pittsburgh Pirates bade a last goodbye today at Three Rivers Stadium to the man responsible for their longtime reputation as a slueeine team.

title: EASTERN AIR LINES HAS 92% RISE IN NET
description: Eastern Air Lines earnings rebounded in the first quarter this year with net income of $18.6 million, or 94 cents shareup 9, 2 percent from the restated $17.8 million, or 93 cents a share, earned in the initial three months last year and reversing a loss registered in the fourth quarter last year.

title: What Sets Storms to Rolling in His Soul
description: For white America to understand the significance of the problem of the Negro will take a bigger and tougher America than any we have vet known.

title: Green Leads by Two Shots on 67 at Windy Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7The winds blew and swirled on this sunny spring day, and they made the opening round of the 41st Masters Tournament an uncomfdtable experience for its select field of 77 players. Only three managed to shoot in the 60's on the magnificent tree lined course of the Augusta National Golf Club.

title: Japan May Curb Exports of TV's
description: TOKYO, Friday, April 8Agreement to was expected to be reached here today between Japanese and American negotiators to restrain the export of Japanese color television sets to the United States.

title: Bus Drivers Go on Strike Against a Commuter Line Out of 42d St. Terminal
description: More than 200 drivers and maintenance workers struck the Short Line Bug Company early this morning.

title: FORMER RCA CHIEF FAILS TO ATTEND ARRAIGNMENT
description: Anthony L. Conrad, the former chief executive officer of R.C.A., who resigned from the corporation last September, after explaining that he had failed to file personal income tax returns for a fiveyear period, did not appear at his scheduled arraignment yesterday on criminal charges brought by the state of New York.

title: India's Leader Stresses SelfReliance for Third World
description: NEW DELHI, April 7Prime Minister Morarji R, Desai opened a conference of half the world's nonaligned nations here today with the advice that we must persist in solving our own problems, rather than depend on the charity and benevolence of others.

title: STAGEHANDS END STRIKE AT 5 TIMES SO. THEATERS
description: A strike by stagehands that closed down five Times Square theaters Wednesday and Thursday was settled last night and management reported that the theaters would be open today.

title: A Guide to Spending An Easter Outdoors In Suburbia
description: Easter weekend means spring, an invitation for getting out of the house. This weekend the great outdoors is coming alive after a wintry slumber. Cherry blossoms and lilies beckon in parks and conservatories. Bike paths are again flashing the green light for big wheels. Forest trails are awaiting walkers first footfalls. Those suburban restaurants you never got to in the cold are heating up treats for the palate. Surely, this is all alibi enough to put off uncovering the garden furniture for another week and hitting the roads around you. For early spring al fresco, the regional correspondents of The New York Times here reveal where they steal off to on their weekends.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Friday.

title: Fluorocarbons In Aerosols Face Government Ban
description: Two Federal agencies, in a move designed to preserve the earth's protective ozone, are drafting regulations that would ban nonessential uses of fluorocarbons as spraycan propellants. They will be issued by the Food and Drug Administration and the Environmental Protection Agency by April 26 unless unforeseen obstacles arise, according to officials In Washington.

title: Soviet Bloc Is Sharply Altering Its Economic Plans, Study Finds
description: GENEVA, April 7The Soviet Union and its Eastern European partners have had to alter sharply their economic plans because of economic troubles in the West, United Nations economists said today in a special study.

title: Dollar Up Bit Against Yen For Second Straight Day; Old Is Up in Europe
description: TOKYO, April 7 (AP)The dollar gained slightly against the Japanese yen on the foreign exchange market here today for the second straight day, but still has made up less than onetenth of the ground it lost on Monday and Tuesday.

title: Bridge:
description: The mathematics of bridge can be surprisingly mysterious, and players are often deceived in this area, not only at the table but also in retrospect with time to think. Some principles that are obvious in theory may be tricky to apply in practice.

title: West German Prosecutor Is Slain Led Fight Against Urban Guerrillas
description: KARLSRUHE, West Germany, April 7Assassins riding a motorcycle pulled alongside a limousine carrying West Germany's chief prosecutor today and sprayed it with submachinegun fire, killing him and his driver and critically wounding another official.

title: Officials React With Relief
description: Some energy industry officials reacted with relief yesterday at President Carter's decision to continue research on the breeder nuclear reactor and to slow, rather than cancel outright, the industrial breeder demonstration plant on the Clinch River near Oak Ridge, Tenn.

title: Learning the Ways of Grindstones and Mill Wheels
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y.As in Colonial days, they trooped into the grist mill on the banks of the Pocantico River here. But instead of toting sacks of wheat and corn to be ground into flour and cornmeal, they brought notebooks, pens and hundreds of questions.

title: Art: Through Dubuffet's Eyes
description: WHO WOULD have thought in the spring of 1939 that in the spring of 1977 the most rewarding painter in Paris would be Jean Dubuffet, who in 1939 was already pushing 40 and had not so much as made his debut as an artist? Dubuffet at that time was a wine merchant much in favor among intellectuals. But as a painter? As the most gifted and original painter to have been born in France in this century? Nobody would have gone along with it.

title: Runaway Egg Hunt in Queens Turns Into Pandemonium
description: Hundreds of childrenand many of their parentsconverted an Easter egg hunt in Flushing MeadowCorona Park, Queens, into a halfhour of pandemonium yesterday in which children wept, parents shouted and a park official tried to call the whole thine off.

title: About Real Estate
description: Where the centuryold annex to the Central Commercial. High School once stood, construction of a combined office building and apartment house about to begin. Groundbreaking is scheduled within 60 to 90 days, said Steven Goodstein, a principal in the Goodstein Construction Company.

title: 140 Escape Train Derailment
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)The engine and all six cars of Amtrack's James Whitcomb Riley train derailed today near Frazier, W. Va., but none of the 140 passengers were hurt, an Amtrack spokesman reported.

title: Art: New Power in Old Metal
description: THERE ARE certain works of art that remained lodged in our memories from the first moment that we see them. They leave us with a fond memory, a vivid mental picture, and a sense of a certain moment in time. Because of this, perhaps, we tend to assume that such objects continue to enjoy a public career long after we have first seen them. They must  so we think, when we think or them  be sitting somewhere in a museum, a private collection or some remote public place. We may not have encountered them in years, but we assume they must be out there, somewhere, where others have been enjoying them too.

title: Baseball Hits Photographer
description: CHICAGO, April 7 (UPI)Ray Foli, a 43yearold United Press International photographer, was struck on the side of the head by a baseball and may have suffered a fractured skull before today's MetsCubs game. The ball was thrown by Leo Foster of the Mets during pregame infield practice and sailed over first base into the enclosed area reserved for photographers.

title: Market Place
description: Some insurance stock analysts who have watched the efforts to return the Government Employees Insurance Company to its past glory are beginning to view the company as a speculation with some merit.

title: Pop Music: Baby Jane Dexter
description: BABY JANE DEXTER, a big woman with a big voice, is giving a scattershot performance at the Ballroom, West Broadway below Houston Street, where she will he appearing for the next three weeks. She tries a little bit of everything, hitting and missing without establishing any consistent pattern or defining positive personality.

title: Yasir Arafat Is Openly Received by Brezhnev
description: MOSCOW, April 7 (UPI)Leonid I. Brezhnev met publicly for the first time today with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, in a display of heightened Soviet concern over the Palestinian role in a Middle East peace settlement.

title: The New York Times/William E. Saura
description: TESTING FOR POLLUTION: Members of the U.S. EnvironmentalProtection Agency placing a pollution detector in the waters off Jersey City yesterday. The device will rest on the bottom and transmit data through an antenna on a float, being held at left.

title: At the Movies
description: PICTURE CAROL BURNETT as the mother of the bride, a nouveau riche matron nervously straining to make an elegant impression on the equally wealthy mother of the groom. Picture her, at the peak of her frantic posturing, turning blushcheeked, jellykneed and girlish when the magnetic stranger, who has been'clevouring her with his eyes all during the wedding reception, steals over to her and huskily whispers, I want you to know I've fallen in love with you.

title: East Coast Longshoremen Say Talks With Shippers Have Reached an Impasse
description: The International Longshoremen's Association bogged down in what the union called an impasse in contract negotiations yesterday.

title: Knicks Lose in a Farewell By Bradley and Holzman
description: Red Holzman, the Knick coach, and Bill Bradley deserved better than to be making the final New York appearances of their careers last night with the kind of game their team played against the Indiana pacers.

title: Broadus Erie Dies at 59; Concertmaster a Leader In Contemporary Music
description: Broadus Erle, violinist and teacher at the Yale School of Music, died at his home in Guilford, Conn., on Wednesday night. He had been ill for some time from cancer. He was 59 years old.

title: April in Paris: Gloom and Despondency About the Future of France
description: PARIS, April 6A wave of depression about the future has swept this city in the last few weeks.

title: Money Supply Down $1.2 Billion In Week, Federal Reserve Says
description: The nation's money supply, narrowly defined, declined $1.2 billion in the week ended March 30, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

title: DOBRYNIN CONSULTS WITH VANCE TO SEEK ANEW ARMS PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance conferred today with Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union in an effort to resume discussions on a treaty limiting strategic arms.

title: 11YearOld Boy Seized While Dealing in Heroin On a Street in Harlem
description: An 11yearold boy who the police say was dealing in heroin on West 115th Street in Harlem was arrested yesterday afternoon with a teenage accomplice. The police also siezed more than 2 pounds of heroin and $1.400 in cash.

title: Issues and Debate
description: An important issue affecting many New York State apartment tenants and ownersand also the soundness of many neighborhoods and the fiscal health of some cities, a number of housing specialists say  will soon come before the State Legislature when it takes up the issue of converting rental apartments to cooperatives or condominiums.

title: Wynn, Jackson Star at Bat as Hunter Stops Brewers
description: Let there be on allstar team in New York, George Steinbrenner said two years ago, and yesterday there was an allstar team in New York and George Steinbrenner saw that it was good.

title: MONDALE IS BEATING DRUMS FOR HIS PARTY
description: Like the circus worker who puts up the billboards before the big parade, Vice President Mondale visited New York yesterday to help drum up interest in a major Democratic Party fundraising effort in the city by President Carter.

title: EFFORT MADE TO BAR ATOMIC POWER PLANT
description: TRENTON. April 7The Public Advocate appealed today Federal approval for construction of a huge nuclear power plant on the Delaware River south of Salem.

title: ExF.B.I. Man Indicted by U.S. In Mail Opening
description: WASHINGTON, April 7A Federal grand jury in New York today indicted John J. Kearney, a former supervisor in the Federal Bureau of Investigation, on charges that agents working under his direction had illegally opened mail and tapped telephones in their search for Weather Underground fugitives.

title: Music: After Satie
description: THE CONCERT AT Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night was billed as the, last of the 197677 season of the Evenings for New Music presented by the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts of the State University of New York at Buffalo.

title: Julius Watkins, 55, Played Jazz on the French Horn And Was Music Teacher
description: Julius Watkins, a French horn jazz instrumentalist and music teacher, died Monday at St. Barnabas Hospital, Short Hills, N.J. He was 55 years old and a resident of Montclair. N.J.

title: Dow Adds 4.15; Bally, Off by 4, Is Biggest Loser
description: Shrugging off adverse inflation news, the stock market advanced moderately yesterday in continued slow trading.

title: U.S. PLANNING A BANK TO AID LARGE CITIES
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal said today that the Carter Administration was drafting plans to set up an urban reconstruction bank to make borrowing easier for New York and other large cities with financial problems.

title: Stage: Ladies at the Alamo
description: Politicswhether they be political politics, office politics, or even theatrical politicsundeniably exert a fascination. Watching bloodless stabbing has always been a firstrate spectator sport, and fair food for commentary. It is politicstheatrical that provides the basis for Paul Zindel's fullhearted, overblooded melodrama, Ladies at the Alamo, which opened at the Martin Beck Theater last night.

title: PLAY BALL Catfish Hunter of the Yankees pitching
description: PLAY BALL! Catfish Hunter of the Yankees pitching against the Brewers in the first inning of season opener in Yankee Stadium yesterday. Below: Reggie Jackson, in his first regular season game with the Bronx Bombers, connecting for a single in the fourth inning. The Yanks won, 30, behind the pitching of Hunter and Sparky Lyle. In Chicago, the Mets beat the Cubs, 53, as Tom Seaver won his sixth season opener in 10 tries. Details, page A17.

title: NADJARI SUBPOENAED BY ASSEMBLY PANEL
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the former special state prosecutor, has been subpoenaed to testify next week before a State Assembly subcommittee that is looking into grand jury and prosecutors practices.

title: Crime: No Change and No Answers
description: As even the most cloistered citizen knows by now, rising crime has been one of the melancholy givens of American society. Except for one year between 1960 and 1975, the crime rate rose steadily by amounts ranging up to 18 percent a year. Indeed, since 1960, the national serious crime rate has nearly tripled. But now, in its preliminary 1976 report, the F.B.I. finds the rate essentially unchanged from 1975; the final report might even show a slight decrease.

title: U.S. Delegation Leaves for China
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (Reuters)A bipartisan 10member Congressional dele gation left here today for Shanghai as part of the U.S. China exchange program begun five years ago during the Nixon administration. President Carter's 24yearold son, Chip, was accompanying the group on its 10day visit.

title: Curbing the Gumshoes
description: Representative Herman Badillo of New York and others have introduced sweeping legislation to reform and control the intelligence agenciesso sweeping that there probably is little chance for these measures to be approved in their entirety. They nevertheless raise crucial questions for debate and offer some needed protections fnr the citizens of a democracy.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: BRONX

title: An Innovative Leader for Vassar
description: Virginia Beatrice Smith, director of the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare's Fund for the Improvement of Post secondary Education, is a lawyerturnedeconomistturnedadministrator who ponders questions long and hard until she's been asked just the one: why was she chosen as the new president of Vassar College? Because I was the best qualified, says Miss Smith evenly, without pause.

title: PLAY BALL Catfish Hunter of the Yankees pitching
description: PLAY BALL Catfish Hunter of the Yankees pitching against the Brewers in the first inning of season opener in Yankee Stadium yesterday. Below: Reggie Jackson, in his first regular season game with the Broni Bombers, The New York Times/Robert Walker connecting for a single in the fourth inning. The Yanks won, 30, behind the pitching of Hunter and Sparky Lyle. In Chicago, the Mets beat the Cubs, 53, as Tom Seaver won his sixth season opener in 10 tries. Details, page A17.

title: Throngs of Youthful JobSeekers Turned Away After 2d Day's Vigil
description: Thousands of teenagers, including many who had waited all night in near freezing weatherlined up at community employment centers throughout New York City yesterday for the second day of registration for summer jobs. And for the second day many were turned away because of confusion and overcrowding.

title: Antiques
description: WHEN THE BRITISH departed from Massachusetts 200 years ago, they left behind far more than a bounty of English decorative arts. There was also, for example, a legacy of love for the splendid sterling silver wares that English craftsmen had been producing under kings and queens, and even under Cromwell, since the late Middle Ages.

title: Taiwan Ministry Reported to Deny It Purchased Missiles From Israel
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 7 (Reuters)Taiwan's Ministry of National Defense today denied a report that it had purchased Gabriel surfacetoair missiles from Israel, the Central news agency said.

title: HOUSE ETHICS PANEL BARS PLEA FOR PERSONAL FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)The House ethics committee ruled yesterday that Representative George Hansen, Republican of Idaho, may not solicit funds for his personal use.

title: Rail TonMileage Gains 11%
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.7 billion tonmiles, 11 percent above the corresponding week year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 473, 500 cars, 5.0 percent above last year. The American Trucking Associaiton Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 46.2 percent above last year. The extremely large increase was primarilly because of the work stoppage by the Teamsters last year.

title: Panamanian Leader Begins Tour
description: PANAMA, April 7 (Reuters)Panama's head of government, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos, left here today for an overseas tour that was expected to last about two weeks. Officials said that General Torrijos would first visit Canada and that his tour would include a fiveday stay in Libya beginning April 12.

title: Giants Get a HomeTeam Edge for Jet Game
description: The Giants announced yesterday they would be the home team in Giants Stadium for their preseason game against the Jets and that they would be the visiting team next week in Mexico City.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES ROSE 1.1% IN MARCH, MOST IN 17 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, April 7  Wholesale prices jumped 1.1 percent in March, the sharpest increase since October 1975, the Labor Department said today. The announcement came even as President Carter was exhorting Congress to pass his program of economic stimulus.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: Federal Reserve Statement

title: Edelstein Works His Political Savvy Into His City U. Post
description: There is a 30yearold story told about a much younger Julius C. C. Edelstein, vice chancellor for urban affairs of the City University of New York, when he was political adviser to the first President of the Republic of the Philippines, the late Manuel Roxas.

title: Met Star Owes It To Verdi
description: Although he has won particular acclaim for his role as Otello in Verdi's opera, James McCracken, the Metropolitan Opera tenor, traces his career to the part he will sing tomorrow in the Met production of Verdi's II Trovatore, which also will be broadcast at 2 P.M. on WQXRFM and WORAM.

title: Soviet Georgian Dissident Who Seeks Independence Is Arrested, Wife Reports
description: MOSCOW, April 7The wife of a Georgian nationalist said today that her husband and two others had been arrested in Tbilisi, capital of the Soviet Union's Georgian republic.

title: Cauthen Has Six Winners For 2d Time
description: Steve Cauthen won the first five races at Aqueduct yesterday and, after recovering from dropping his whip early in the seventh race, became the first jockey to win six races twice in a day at a New York track.

title: Zaire Says Morocco Is Sending Troops to Help Out
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 7 (Reuters)Morocco is sending troops and China military equipment to help Zaire repel the invasion of western Shaba Province, a Zaire Government spokesman announced today.

title: News Summary
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, who is in charge of Israel's caretaker Government, withdrew as the Labor Party's candidate for the prime ministership in the May 17 elections. His withdrawal was announced following Israeli newspaper reports that Mr. Rabin had lied about the amounts he kept in bank accounts in Washington. Such deposits are illegal under Israeli currency laws. [Page 1, Column 6.1

title: U.S. PLANNING A BANK TO AID LARGE CITIES
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal said today that the Carter Administration was drafting plans to set up an urban reconstruction bank to make borrowing easier for New York and other large cities with financial problems.

title: CLOTHING COMPANY OPENS NEW PLANT
description: A men's clothing company opened a $2 million plant on West 18th Street yesterday that could point the way toward a revival of the depressed men's apparel industry in New York City.

title: Spring on the Potomac
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The big news in Washington these days is the arrival of springsomething reassuring and maybe even more important than the arrival and departure of Portillo, Trudeau, Rabin, Callaghan, Sadat, and all our latest visitors. Jimmy Carter cannot possibly have understood what it meant to capture the White House until he saw Washington in the spring.

title: In the City, a Weekend for Strolling, Egg Rolling and Flowers
description: EASTER WEEKEND in New York has its own special flavor, a blend of the most solemn and of the earthiness that the city never seems to shake. This means that the holiday weekend schedule is studded with things to do, from attending church and finding surcease in the majestic music of Easter, to running off to a museum or the circus, enjoying the spring flowers or watching the kids roll eggs across spacious lawns.

title: Antipornography Rally Planned for Times Sq. Area
description: The casts of 25 Broadway shows will join businessmen, trade unionists, neighborhood residents and clergymen here next week in three days of antipornography demonstrations in Times Square that are being called S.O.S., or Stamp Out Smut.

title: Events and Openings
description: DEMON SEED, directed by Donaid Cammell starring Julie Christie and Fritz Weaver, at the Criterion, Trans Lux 85th Street, Greenwich, Loews 83d Street and showcase theaters.

title: Topics
description: An art treasure was restored to full public view when the Postal Service decided to remove some phone booths and a bulletin board hiding parts of the Ben Shahn mural in its General Post Office in the Bronx. It was the mural's second rescue from obscurity. The first threat was a writein campaign that challenged its very completion in the late 1930's. Writers claimed that an inscription, included by Shahn, suggested that religion is krdlevant in the modern world. AntiChristian, said the protesters. Artistic freedom, said the thenPostmaster, Albert Goldman.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, April 7The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that a criminal could not be found guilty of murder if an accomplice in a felony was killed by one of their intended victims.

title: C.I.A. Study Says Soviet Owes $10 Billion in Debts to the West
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI)The Soviet Union owed nearly $10 billion in debts to the United States and other Western nations by the end of 1976 and was paying nearly $500 million in annual interest, according to a study released by the Central Intelligence Agency today.

title: GOOD FRIDAY
description: Today is Good Friday. Stock and commodity exchanges and public and parochial schools are closed. Federal and most city offices, including post offices and libraries, and most department stores are open. Banks are open in New York but closed in New Jersey and Connecticut. There will be regular refuse collections. Only alternatesideofthestreet no parking regulations are suspended.

title: City Phasing Out Contracts With Bronx Drug Project
description: New York City officials said yesterday that they would phase out $115, 000 in contracts with a controversial Bronx drugrehabilitation program.

title: Schlitz Planning to Fight S.E.C.'s Suit on Payments
description: WASHINGTON, April 7  The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company made at least $3 million in undisclosed and illegal payments to induce customers to buy its products, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged in a suit filed today in the Federal District Court here.

title: West German Prosecutor Is Slain; Led Fight Against Urban Guerrillas
description: KARLSRUHE, West Germany, April 7Assassins riding a motorcycle pulled alongside a limousine carrying West Germany's chief prosecutor today and sprayed it with submachinegun fire, killing him and his driver and critically wounding another official.

title: Palestinians and Lebanese Leftists Recapture Moslem Town in South
description: BEIRUT, April 7Palestinian and leftistMoslem forces pressing their offensive against rightwing Christian militiamen in southern Lebanon today captured the Shiite Moslem town of Khiam which had been under Christian control for more than two months.

title: Station Must Counter Biased Ad
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission has ruled that a Texaco television advertisement was politically biased and has ordered a station the aired it to present opposing viewpoints to comply with the socalled fairness doctrine.

title: Surge of Lebanese Border Fighting Imperils Israeli GoodFence Policy
description: METULLA, Israel, April 7Early this morning, residents of this community in northern Israel that peers over a barbedwire fence into Lebanon awoke to the sound of notsodistant shelling.

title: Peabody Institute Names Chief
description: BALTIMORE, April 9 (AP)The trustees of the Peabody Institute, one of the nation's oldest conservatories of music, have announced the appointment of Elliott W. Galkin as the new director of the 109yearold school. Mr. Galkin, a professor and chairman of the Department of Music at Goucher College here, will succeed Richard Franko Goldman, who is retiring in June.

title: Big Retail Chains Report Robust March Sales Gains
description: Consumer buying in March, spurred by warmer weather and the onset of an earlier Easter this year, continued strong across the nation, even exceeding the robust tempo of the two prior months, reports from leading chain stores showed yesterday.

title: Big Board and Amex Tell How Merger Would Work
description: The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange told their members yesterday what to expect if a merger of the nation's two largest securi. ties exchanges were consummated.

title: Unser After 3d Indy Victory
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 7 (AP)Bob Unser, a twotime winner, entered his 15th consecutive Indianapolis 500mile auto race today. Unser, winner in 1968 and 1975, will be the No. I driver for the threecar Fletcher Racing Team of Phoenix, Ariz. The other two drivers for the team haven't been selected.

title: DroughtAid Bill Signed
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)President Carter signed legislation that authorizes $100 million in drought assistance and sets up Government subsidies to allow farmers to exchange water rights among themselves.

title: RABIN STUNS ISRAEL BY CANCELING HIS CANDIDACY FOR SECOND TERM UNDER FIRE ABOUT DEPOSITS IN U.S.
description: JERUSALEM, Friday, April 8Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin submitted his resignation early this morning as the ruling Labor Party's candidate for a second term as head of the Israeli Government.

title: Management
description: Against a backdrop of all the recent adverse publicity about business activity, the corporate rite of spring, the annual meeting, promises to produce numerous probing questions from stockholders.

title: Art: Age of Rubens At Metropolitan
description: THERE ARE TIMESand very good times they arewhen the small Prints and Drawings Gallery on the second floor of the Metropolitan Museum of Art strikes one as being more like a fine library than a conventional exhibition space. We are offered no chairs and tables, to be sure, for the kind of relaxed, leisurely study that the objects on display invite us to pursue, but the objects themselves are often of a kind that both require and reward the sustained attention we bring to a precious literary text. We may come to look, but we are tempted to stay on and read.

title: Congress Recesses Without Acting on Stimulus Bills
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Congress left town today, bound for China, Australia or even for home, feeling a bit embarrassed at having enacted no part of President Carter's economic stimulus program.

title: Brubeck & Sons Top a Jazz Festival in the Lofts (Page C4)The World of Dubuffet (page C10) and the Age of Rubens (Page C18) A Tristate Baedeker for an Easter Outdoors; Drawing by Arnle Ten
description: For suggestions and details of events, see pages C22 and C23.

title: Panel of Historians Calls for a Shift in Research to Emphasize Central Role of Women in History
description: ATLANTA, April 7A panel of historians, members of the Organization of American Historians, called today for a massive but temporary shift of emphasis in historical research to place the woman at center of history.

title: How to Deflate Inflation Fears
description: The fact that wholesale prices jumped 1.1 percent in March was announced just yesterday but is already being widely cited as confirmation that the economy has begun to overheat. Critics of the Carter Administration offer the fact as new evidence that the proposed stimulus to the economy would now be senseless. Are they right?

title: NEV AIETHOD OBTAINS WHITE BLOOD CELLS
description: SARASOTA, Fla., April 7A simple, inexpensive new technique for collecting white blood cells from blood donors may help to prevent lifethreatening infections in many thousands of patients who are treated with anticancer drugs, a hematologist reported here today.

title: Concert Sunday At Sarah Lawrence
description: Under the direction of Harold. Alts, the 45piece Community Orchestra at Sarah Lawrence College will present a free concert Sunday at 8 P.M. at Rei singer Concert Hall in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: SPREAD OF REDLINING IN NU YORK CHARGED
description: Decisions about where or whether to invest in home mortgages can no longer be left to banks alone, Eleanor Holmes Norton, New York City's Commissioner of Human Rights, declared yesterday.

title: CHRYSLER LIFTING PRICES ON CAR, TRUCK OPTIONALS
description: DETROIT, April 7  The Chrysler Corporation said it would raise optionalequipment prices by $13, or 0.2 percent on the average equipped car effective Monday. It also announced a $45, or 0.7 percent price increase in truck optionalequipment at the same time.

title: Fluorocarbons In Aerosols Face Government Ban
description: Two Federal agencies, in a move designed to preserve the earth's protective ozone, are drafting regulations that would ban nonessential uses of fluorocarbons as spraycan propellants. They will be issued by the Food and Drug Administration and the Environmental Protection Agency by April 26 unless unforeseen obstacles arise, according to officials in Washington.

title: Ford and Chrysler To Cut Production
description: DETROIT, Aptil 7The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation are scheduling shutdowns of four small car assembly plants next week. The closings will idle 14, 300 workers. Subcompact and compact cars have lost about 6 percentage points of their market share this year to the intermediate and fullsize cars.

title: Major League Scores
description: Tennis

title: John Marriott, Actor, Dead at 83; Appeared on Stage, Film and TV
description: John Marriott, an actor whose theater, film and television credits were both extensive and impressive, died on Tuesday at his home, 11115 174th Street, Jamaica, Queens. He was 83 years old. He was last seen on the New York stage last September, as Ramsey Eyes, the caretaker of the clubhouse, in The Last Meeting of the Knights of the White Magnolia, one of the plays in Preston Jones's A Texas Trilogy, which ran for 62 performances.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: NATIVE AMERICANA

title: A.S.P.C.A. Eliminates Pickup Of Stray Dogs in New York City
description: The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to AnimalsNew York City's official dog catchersaid yesterday that it had quit picking up strays and that this was part of its plan to go out of the animalcontrol business altogether on July 1 unless the city came up with a $2.1 million subsidy.

title: JANE ELIZABETH KENWORTHY
description: BALTIMORE, April 7Jane Elizabeth Kenworthy of Washington, a writer and editor with Health and Education Resources Inc., which prepares teaching materials, died of cancer today at the Johns Hopkins University Hospital. She was 63 years old.

title: Help Is Offered Remarried Parents
description: A new organization has been formed to give stepparents a hand. It's the Step Family Foundation, which offers information, group counseling and its own newsletter.

title: Hearing Set on Offshore Oil Ban
description: NEW YORK, April 7 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals here has agreed to hear arguments on April 25 by the United States Interior Department, which is seeking to overturn a lower court's ban on the department's graning of oil leases offshore Long Island and New Jersey.

title: Roosevelt
description: RESULTS

title: Islanders Complete 2  Game Sweep
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 7Despite becoming the visitors in their own rink, despite losing J.P. Parise to a knee injury and despite a sensational performance by Tony Esposito in the Chicago net, the Islanders scored a 21 victory over the Black Hawks tonight and advanced to the quarterfinal round of the National. Hockey League playoffs.

title: BOND PRICES FINISH WITH OVERALL GAIN
description: The credit markets, depressed by sharp climb of the Wholesale Price Index and encouraged by a reported decrease in the money supply, declined in the morning and recovered in late afternoon to close with a moderate overall gain. TradCredit markets ing was unusually lignt, nowCredit ever, as the market tended to postpone activity prior to a threeday weekend. Markets Many bond traders and investment managers had expected the wholesale prices to show sizable upward move for March, but few said they expected them to jump 1.2 percent. But even though the increase exceeded the consensus, bond prices were not particularly hard hit in the trading that followed the Labor Department announcement of the disappointing statistic.

title: Young Gives an Apology to Britain For Calling It Chicken on Racism
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 7Andrew Young, the outspoken United States delegate, apologized to the British Government today for saying in a broadcast interview that Britain was a little chicken on racial questions and had institutionalized racism more than anyone else in the history of the earth.

title: Brubecks Top Weekend of Loft Jazz
description: The jazz lofts of lower Manhattan will be celebrating Easter weekend with a parade of musicians and special events. Dave Brubeck, who has taken an interest in loft jazz because of his musician sons, will be performing with them as Two Generations of Brubeck on Saturday afternoon at Environ, 476 Broadway. The Ladies Fort at 2 Bond Street and Studio Rivbea at 24 Bond are in the midst of April festivals and will be presenting topflight groups throughout the weekend. Nobody seems to have planned it this way, but the listener who is so inclined will be able to celebrate Easter weekend as an almost continuous loft jazz festival.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: American Standard Inc., a major producer of plumbing products, announced yesterday that it would purchase 700, 000 shares of its $4.75 cumulative convertible preferred stock at $90 a share for a total of $63 million. The company said the offer was not conditioned on any minimum number of shares being tendered.

title: British to Revive City Centers
description: LONDON, April 6 (Reuters)The British Government is to spend more than $1.7 billion over the next 10 years in a program to revive inner London and other city centers affected by years of decay.

title: Let's at Least Spend What There Is
description: You would think that the one thing an impoverished city could do with dispatch is to spend available money. notably money to rehabilitate its neglected housing and physical plant. Not so with the funds that have been assigned for that task by the Federal Government's Housing and Community Development Act. New York City has obtained $200 million over two years and due to get $150 million more. Although the city is spending the funds slightly faster than the average community around the country, so far only about $100 million has been committed and only about $50 million has actually been spent. All this while housing deteriorates and people cry for help.

title: 478Ton Generator Part Is Safely Loaded on a Vessel
description: One of the heaviest pieces of cargo to he handled at Port Newark in yearsa 478ton piece of electrical generating machinerywas safely loaded aboard a vessel yesterday.

title: Montgomery, Furniss Break U.S. Records in A.A.U. Swim
description: CANTON, Ohio, April 7 (AP)Jim Montgomery and Bruce Furniss, teammates on the United States goldmedal winning 800  meter freestyle relay team, cracked American records tonight in the national Amateur Athletic Union indoor swimming meet.

title: Art People
description: CHRIS BURDEN is waging a oneman war against Detroit. Disturbed because you can't buy the most basic economy car for less than $4, 000, he went ahead and made one himselfa tiny bug of a machine that he calls a B [for bicycle]Car. Powered by a motorcycle engine, the oneman machine steps up to 50 miles per hour and gets 150 miles to the gallon. It cost him about $4, 000 to make, and you can buy it for $12, 000, but never mind. It's the thought that counts.

title: Continental Group Wins Approval To Build Rowayton Headquarters
description: NORWALK, Conn., April 7The Planning and Zoning Commission last night approved a change to permit the giant Manhattanbased Continental Group Inc. to build its headquarters in Rowayton, despite a vote against the move by residents of the middleclass residential neighborhood, which thinks of itself as more of a suburb than as part of the city.

title: Single TeenAgers Found Using Better Contraceptives
description: More unmarried American teenagers are sexually active now than in 1971, but they are relying more heartily on effective contraceptive practices, according to the results of a national survey released yesterday.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES ROSE 1.1% IN MARCH, MOST IN 17 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, April 7  Wholesale prices jumped 1.1 percent in March, the sharpest increase since October 1975, the Labor Department said today. The announcement came even as President Carter was exhorting Congress to pass his program of economic stimulus.

title: Retail Store Sales Climb 11%
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The Department of Commerce reported today that total retail store sales last week were an estimated $13.79 billion, up 11 percent from last year's $12.41 billion. Department store sales last week were about 1.29 billion, also up 11 percent from the year earlier $1.15 billion.

title: FROST REAFFIRMS CONTROL OVER NIXON INTERVIEWS
description: David Frost reasserted last night that he and his company had sole control over the content and editing of his forthcoming television interviews with former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: CUNARD PRINCESS (Cunard), Left Bermuda April 7; due B A.M. at W. 55th St.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Letters
description: Recent articles dealing with waterborne disease, irrigation and industrial pollution of the Rhine provided an excellent introduction to some of the issues considered at the U.N. Water Conference at Mar del Plata, Argentina. However, it remains simply and unavoidably true that the most urgent problem which faced the U.N. Water Conference, and faces governments in the years ahead, is the unavailability of clean water in many parts of the world.

title: DOBRYNIN CONSULTS WITH VANCE TO SEEK A NEW ARMS PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance conferred today with Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union in an effort to resume discussions on a treaty limiting strategic arms.

title: India Planning Court to Investigate All Charges Against Ousted Regime
description: NEW DELHI, April 7The new Gov ernment announced today that it was set ting up a judicial court of inquiry to in vestigate ail complaints of excesses malpractices and abuse of authority dur ing Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's 19 month period of rigorous emergency rule.

title: Tradition Plays a Role in First Yank Victory
description: It surrounded Sal Bondo; wearing an enemy uniform. It swirled around Reggie Jackson, wearing pinstripes for the first time. It even shook up Vincent Palitto, a New Jersey hairdresser, who stood on the mound briefly.

title: Marine Corps Foundation to Give Total of $60, 000 in Scholarships
description: The National Marine Corps Scholarship Foundation said yesterday that it would award 177 scholarships totaling $60, 000 this year to sons and daughters of present and former marines.

title: Soybean Futures Add 15 Cents For 3Day Gain of 56c a Bushel
description: CHICAGO, April 7 (AP)Soybean futures advanced 15 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade today for a threeday total gain of 56 cents for oldcrop beans.

title: Carter's Cousin Hugh Brings Thrifty Ways to White House
description: WASHINGTON April 7  Those Washington bigwigs deprived of their limousines may not know it, but their troubles are probably rooted in the hardscrabble soil of southern Georgia and the price of apples there some vearc ago.

title: Vorster Seems to Resist Compromise Plan by U.S. On SouthWest Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 7A United Statesled effort to work out a compromise on the future of SouthWest Africa, the territory that. South Africa has governed since World War I, appeared to have run into resistance from Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa at a meeting in Cane Town today.

title: Black Label Offering Scholarship Prizes
description: If you are a fan of Johnnie Walker Black Label Scotch advertising  and thats nothing to be ashamed of since it's been pretty snazzy stuff  you are well aware that the drinkers of this premium brand are a bunch of affluent cats.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: LAST Sunday about 23 million American homes watched the first threehoursplus portion of Jesus of Nazareth, putting its director, Franco Zeffirelli, in the television blockbuster class. The second half of the sumptuous production will be presented on NBC this Sunday at 8.

title: After 12 Years, God's in His Heaven
description: New York's baseball season opened in Yankee Stadium yesterday before a crowd of 43, 785 that includedaccording to the Rev. William Kalaidjian God. We pray this year, Chaplain Kalaidjian said in his invocation, that from your great heaven we receive the world chamoionship.

title: Advertising
description: Lois, Holland, Callaway has changed its name to Holland & Callaway.

title: Pon Music: Minimal Miles
description: John Miles, the English singer, guitarist and songwriter who performed at the Bottom Line on Wednesday evening, has attracted a cultfollowing in New York with a brand of music one might as well label minimalist poprock.

title: CARTER ASKS SENATE TO BACK TAX REBATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 7  President Carter publicly and privately exhorted the Senate today to approve his income tax rebate program but said he was not inclined to bargain with the senators on water projects to get his way.

title: Mrs. Harris Tackling Urban Problems Cautiously
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Patricia Roberts Harris, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has brought with her strong commitments to help revitalize the nation's older cities and provide decent shelter for the poor.

title: Young Gives an Apology to Britain For Calling It Chicken on Racism
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 7Andrew Young, the outspoken United States delegate, apologized to the British Government today for saying in a broadcast interview that Britain was a little chicken on racial questions and had institutionalized racism more than anyone else in the history of the earth.

title: Carter Bids Other Nations Join U.S. in Curbing Plutonium
description: WASHINGTON, April 7  President Carter, announcing as expected that the United States would not use plutonium to fuel nuclear reactors that produce electricity, appealed today to other countries to make maximum efforts to combat the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Official Fined Under Election Law
description: TRENTON, April 7 (AP)Ralph DeRose, New Jersey's commissioner on the hesitate Waterfront Commission of Now York Harbor, has been fined $100 for violating state campaignspending laws during his unsuccessful 1973 Campaign for Governor Lewis Thurston director of the State Election Law Enforcement Cornmission, said yesterday that Mr. DeRose had improperly paid a $1, 300 campaign debt out of personal funds, bypassing his campaign treasurer.

title: Outfield Collision by Cubs Helps Seaver Win
description: CHICAGO, April 7The other team in New York, the formerly amazin Mets, neither signed nor traded Dave Kingman today but did manage to open the National League season with Tom Seaver pitching them past the Chicago Cubs, 53, before a standingroom crowd of 39, 937 in old Wrigley Field.

title: What Johnson Dancers Do
description: The Raymond Johnson Dance Company is appearing in its Manhattan debut this weekend at Pace University's Schimmel Center. And what is it doing there? Dancing. Not demonstrating how to make Grandmother's 7Up Cake or teaching football players to pirouette. Just dancing.

title: 2 Choreographers Share Bill at Riverside
description: The choreographers Claudia Gitelman and Alice Teirstein will present a variety of their works tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 4:30 as part of the Riverside Dance Festival at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: Broadway
description: AFTER HE WON the Oscar, Jason Robards said that soon he would be unemployed. Now, however, Mr. }tabards has found job. He will be in Eugene O'Neill's A Touch of the Poet, which Elliott Martin will produce and Jose Quintero will direct on Broadway next season.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Bernard Bergman, a former nursing home operator convicted of fraud, has lost an effort in the State Court of Appeals in Albany to block the state takeover of his property to recover $2.5 million defrauded from the Medicaid system. Mr. Bergman, 65 years old, who has served a fourmonth Federal prison sentence and is appealing a oneyear state prison sentence, had sought to block the appointment of Ramsey Clark, a former United States Attorney General, as a receiver to manage and dispose of his property.

title: Oil and Gas Reserves Again Drop, Continuing Trend of Severaly ears
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The nation's oil and gas reserves declined again last year, continuing a trend of several years, the industry reported today.

title: Broadway Show Is a Hit as It Goes Behind Walls of jail
description: NEWARK, April 7Inmates at the maximumsecurity Essex County Jail demonstrated noisily today, but prison officials did not mind a bit.

title: San Francisco Publisher Named
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 (UPI) Richard T. Thieriot was elected president of the Chronicle Publishing Company and publisher of The San Francisco Chronicle today. He succeeds his father, the late Charles de Young Thieriot, who died last month after 22 years as head of the publishing company.

title: People in Sports
description: Mike Marshall of the Atlanta Braves said yesterday he was quitting baseball temporarily because of a monthslong dispute with officials of Michigan State University. Marshall charges the university with disturbine his family.

title: Letters
description: Art That Sings To WEEKEND:

title: No. 1 Topic in Little Havana: Possibility of Visiting Cuba
description: MIAMI, April 7Three years ago when one of the 500, 000 Cuban refugees living here suggested rapprochement with Fidel Castro, the proposal was greeted with a fusillade of bullets. The refugee died.

title: Police Officer Is Indicted In the Shooting of Friend Whom He Had Arrested
description: A Brooklyn police officer was indicted yesterday on charges of attempted murder and assault in the shooting of a boyhood friend last March 13.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Outer Space Legal Subcommittee10:30 A.M.

title: Books of The Times
description: IMAGINE A WORLD in which there are no animals but men, women and children. Imagine them staring at one another, wondering where all the various species have gone and what they were like. Picture man as driven up against some final biological wall, awaiting his turn for extinction. This is the image, not immediate, but ultimate, with which some highly reputable conservationists are threatening us. If animals can survive in the world.

title: Television
description: TOP WEEKEND FILMS

title: Restaurants
description: IF EVER THERE WAS a restaurant that had a decor and tone that belied its food, it is La Folie, newly opened in the Carlton House on Madison Avenue and 61st Street. A discotheque after 10:30 P.M., its decor is far more suitable to that function than to a restaurant that rates the extraordinary and impressive talents of Bernard Nourget, who previously served as a chef at the Connaught in London. All is a glitter of mirrors, and there are so many types of inlaid marble that it makes the place look like the sample showroom of the Marble Institute.

title: FED RAISES RATE CEILING ON SOME KEOGHS AND IRA'S
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI)  The Federal Reserve Board took action today to enable persons to gain higher interest and other benefits from their own retirement plans at Federally insured commercial banks.

title: SIDES IN STEEL TALKS PRESS FOR CONTRACT
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Steel union and industry negotiators continued to meet late tonight seeking to work out a threeyear wage and benefit settlement.

title: RABIN STUNS ISRAEL BY CANCELING HIS CANDIDACY FOR SECOND TERM UNDER FIRE ABOUT DEPOSITS IN U.S.
description: JERUSALEM, Friday, April 8Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin submitted his resignation early this morning as the ruling Labor Party's candidate for a second term as head of the Israeli Government.

title: Foreign Investors Note Contrasts With U.S.
description: The adage that the grass is always greener on the other side of the fence has certainly colored the view of many important industrial and financial sources abroad in the last decade regarding the American investment scene. The positive assessment seems particularly ironic now since the United States own investors are lukewarm to the stock market and more skeptical about the domestic economy. Furthermore, the nation's businessmen are reluctant to embark on any exuberant capitalspending programs.

title: U.S. Bans a Flame Retardant Used in Children's Sleepwear
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission voted yesterday to ban the use of Tris, a chemical that makes textiles flameretardant, from all children's apparel because it has been found to provoke cancer in laboratory animals.

title: BONN TO SEND BRAZIL NUCLEAR EQUIPMENT, THOUGH U.S. OBJECTS
description: BONN, April 8Over the strong objec tions of the Carter Adminstration, West Germany has approved export licenses for the controversial nuclear equipment it has agreed to provide to Brazil, according to a Foreign Ministry spokesman.

title: LOCKHEED WARNS HOLDERS OF NEW BRIBERY SCANDALS
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation warned its stockholders yesterday that Federal grand jury investigation may reveal more bribery scandals that could hurt its foreign aircraft sales and possibly severely affect its financial condition.

title: Moroccans Arrive in Zaire
description: RABAT, Morocco, Saturday, April 9 (UPI)The Moroccan Foreign Ministry said today that the first contingent of Moroccan troops had arrived in Zaire. An official statement said King Hassan I had sent in troops to comply with a equest by President Mobutu Sese Seko following grave event affecting the wire republic in the recent years.

title: SICK PAY RULE CHANGE UPSETTING TAXPAYERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)The delay in Congress over putting off for a year the effective date of a change in sick pay rules for income taxes has left taxpayers with two options as the April 15 filing deadline approaches.

title: Life in Inawi, Papua New Guinea, Is a World Apart From That in New York
description: A couple of times a week, the entire New York City population of Papuans goes off to a movie. His wife goes too.

title: A's Blue Ends Walkout Without Comment
description: OAKLAND, Calif. (AP)  Vida Blue returned to the Oakland A's, as promised, for a workout today but declined to discuss the incident in which he left the team's springtraining camp in Arizona on Tuesday. The A's owner, Charles O. Finley, had placed him on the disqualified list and said Blue would be fined $500 a day until he returned and would be suspended if he didn't show up by today.

title: VETERANS SWAMPING ES, AGENCY TO OBTAIN BETTER DISCHARGES
description: OVERLAND, Mo., April 8Veterans of the Vietnam years who received lessthanhonorable discharges, including deserters, are swamping the Government's Joint Liaison Office here with more than 3,000 telephone calls a day seeking to have discharges upgraded to honorable status.

title: Lottery Drawings Omitted
description: No drawings were held in the New Jersey and Connecticut lotteries yesterday because of the good Friday holiday.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: State Weighs Using a Nearby Fuel Source: Hard Coal
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 8Energy officials from New Jersey and New York, along with utility executives, are studying the potential for conserving oil and controlling air pollution by capitalizing on a nearby fuel resourcethe moribund anthracite coal fields of northeastern Pennsylvania.

title: Hunter's Foot Badly Bruised
description: Dock Ellis, selfstyled baseball revolutionary, reported for duty at Yankee Stadium yesterday, while Catfish Hunter and Ron Blomberg reported to Lenox Bill Hospital.

description: The New York Times/Bob Glass

title: Helen Corlett, 74; Wrote About Society For Herald Tribune
description: Helen Edwards Corlett, who was known professionally as Helen Ames during the half century she wrote for the society department of The New York Herald Tribune, died Thursday in her home in Ormond Beach, Fla., after a long illness. She was 74 years old.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week.

title: Naber, Two Girls, 14, Slash U. S. Records in Swimming
description: CANTON, Ohio, April 8 (AP)John Naber captured his 15th national Amateur Athletic Union swimming title and 14yearold Tracy Caulkins picked up her second victory of the week, both in Americanrecord times tonight in the A.A.U. shortcourse championships in Branin Natatorium.

title: France Reacts Cautiously
description: PARIS, April 8French officials reacted cautiously today to President Carter's announcement yesterday that the United States would halt further production of plutonium and of the breeder reactors that produce it.

title: Banks and Unions Agree to Discuss Mutual Concerns
description: The city's major commercial banks and the leaders of the city's municipal unions have called a tru???e.

title: Ultimate AntiRoach Weapon: The Lizard
description: Like thousands of New Yorkers, Wendy Fuller, Marlene Matarese and Lawrence Goldstein had to share their tworoom Greenwich Village apartment with battalions of cockroaches. All kinds of chemical sprays seemed to have little effect, except on the roommates.

title: General Motors Plant Struck
description: SAGINAW, Mich., April 8 (AP)A General Motors foundry plant was struck last night by some 2,500 workers. The walkout came as bargainers for G.M. and the United Automobile Workers Local 455 failed to reach agreement on a new threeyear local contract.

title: Chiang's Son Has Tightened Hold on Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, TaiwanIn the two years since the death of his father, Chiang Kaishek, Prime Minister Chiang Chingkuo has moved with a combination of toughness and subtlety to achieve even tighter control over this island's 16 million people than his father enjoyed and to preserve Taiwan's record as the most stable country in Asia.

title: Sport in Cuba Is Not a Game
description: HAVANA, April 8  Soon after he took power following the Cuban Revolution in 1959, President Fidel Castro put out the maxim that Sport is a right of the people. In the intervening years, the state has expended a consistent portion of its meager resources on developing the physical side of what the Government calls el hombre nuevothe new man.

title: Lucey's Acceptance of Mexico Post Surprises Both Wisconsin Partieg
description: MADISON, Wis., April 8Gov. Patrick J. Lucey has surprised political leaders of both parties in Wisconsin by announcing that he would resign to accept President Carter's nomination as Ambassador to Mexico.

title: The Standings
description: American League

title: Concert: Baltimore Symphony Is Gaining in Stature
description: If the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra continues to improve the way it has in recent years, its neighbors in Washington and Philadelphia will have to look to their laurels. This is hyperbole, of course. Yet the playing of the Baltimore ensemble in Carnegie Hall Thursday night was exceptionally fine, colorful and virtuosic, worthy of a firstclass orchestra. If its tone erred on the side of lean brilliance and lacked mellow fullness, that is the way with most American symphonic ensembles.

title: DOCTOR IS ACCUSED OF KILLING HIS WIFE
description: A 29yearold Filipino doctor who works at Harlem Hospital was arrested yesterday on a charge of murdering his wife at the hospital on Feb. 9 with a deadly drug.

title: Founder of the Saints
description: Four major religious groups that owe their character to the American experience were established in the 19th century and are still with us, on the whole remarkably unchanged in their original concepts. They are Mormonism, Christian Science, Seventh Day Adventism and Jehovah's Witnesses. Adventism and Christian Science were established largely through the exertions of womenEllen White in one instance and Mary Biker Eddy in the other. Patriarchal and authoritarian, the Mormons and the Witnesses were founded by men  Joseph Smith and Charles Taze Russell, respectively.

title: AGENTS BEWILDERED BY F.B.I. INDICTMENT
description: WASHINGTON, April 8Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here and in New York expressed anger, bewilderment, hurt and concern today over the first felony indictment issued against an agent in the 53year history of the bureau.
