title: Sun Valley Ski Resort Sold to Businessman
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, April 8The oldest ski resort in the United States was sold today for an undisclosed sum when a Wyoming businessman, R. Earle Holding, closed negotiations for Sun Valley with the owner, William Janss.

title: Talks on Jets' Move Fail
description: Efforts to settle the dispute over where the Jets play their home football games next fall failed to produce an agreement yesterday despite a daylong series of closeddoor discussions in United States District Court.

title: Southern Managers Hired to Lilt Roosevelt Hospital Out of the Red
description: A Southernbased company has taken over the management of Roosevelt Hospital in an effort to bring it out of a period of serious budget deficits, loss of endowments, acrimony among some professional staff members, administrators and trustees, and intermittent fears of bankruptcy.

title: Reds Win as Morgan Drives in
description: CINCINNATI, April 8 (AP)Joe Morgan drove in four runs with a threerun homer and a sacrifice fly, propelling the Cincinnati Reds to a 63 victory over the San Dieeo Padres tonieht.

title: A Personal View of Lebanon and Its War
description: PARISHis eyes were dark and enormous. They were not sad, but strong. He spoke slowly as he sat, calmly, in the bulletpocked old Presidential Palace. Elias Sarkis, the new Lebanese President, knows a lot but, when I interviewed him in Beirut in November, he did not like to speak about the past. He knew that if he did not succeed, no one would after him.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Although some employes of Warner Bros. Jungle Habitat in West Milford may have been careless, they did not violate the law in their handling of 40 animals found dead at the amusement park, New Jersey officials say. The state's Agricultural Department inspected the drivethrough park following reports that the carcasses of an elephant, zebras and a number of other species had been cut up and left to decay.

title: Emmy Leaders Set to Give Prizes Despite Cancellation of Telecast
description: Two principal officers of the conflicttorn National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences said yesterday that this year's Emmy awards would be presented to the winners whether it is done on or off television.

title: WEATHER IN MARCH AIDS CROP OUTLOOK
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)Although dry areas still persist, the rain and snow that fell over much of the nation last month improved prospects for the 1977 crop in some of the country's most productive grain areas, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Castro sets Terms for Better Ties
description: GANDER, Newfoundland, April 8 (AP) President Fidel Castro, on his way home from Moscow, said today that Cuba would like to improve relations with the United States but that any change depended on Washington.

title: Out at the New Ball Game
description: I guess you seen in the papers where I'm playing out my option with the Mudvilles. It's the reporters here Al. All they want to do is cut me. I struck out with men on base in the bottom of the ninth yesterday and one of them writes Mighty Casey can't see the ball no more because his eyes is wore out studying the small print in the stock market quotations. I got a mind to bust.

title: Deaths
description: APTERRalph. Age 76 Of 18 Timbertake Drive, Greenville, S.C. Died Thursday, Surviving are his wife, Ethel Lindenberg Apic, daughter Mrs. Joan Winkler of Greenville, a son Robert Apter of Detrol, Michigan, sister Mrs. Bertha Moss of Staten Island, N.Y. Cremation took vine Friday in Hendersonville, N.C.

title: Catholic Church Revises Its Style In Fighting Sao Paulo'surban Ills
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 7The progressive Roman Catholic clergy of this industrial metropolis has changed the style of Easter worship here to serve the religious needs of the poor and promote a more communitarian church.

title: AGENTS BEWILDERED BY F.B.I. INDICTMENT
description: WASHINGTON, April 8Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here and in New York expressed anger, bewilderment, hurt and concern today over the first felony indictment, issued against an agent in the 53year history of the bureau.

title: Irrigation Overflow Is Drowning a Lake in California
description: ELCENTRO, Calif.Most of California is suffering from its worst drought on record, with agricultural losses reckoned at $3 billion, but prospering farmers here in the sunbaked Imperial Valley would be delighted if they never saw another drop of rain.

title: Soviet Union and Cuba Promise More Aid for Guerrilla Groups
description: MOSCOW, April 8The Soviet Union and Cuba today pledged further Communist support for guerrilla movements abroad as President Fidel Castro concluded a fourday visit to Moscow.

title: JAPAN AND U.S. HALT TALKS ON TV SALES
description: TOKYO, April 8Japanese and American negotiators failed to reach agreement here today on restraints of massive Japanese color television exports to the United States, and the talks were temporarily adjourned amid indications they had encountered sudden serious difficulties.

title: People and Business
description: Harold Williams, new chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said yesterday that he believed the S.E.C. should move slowly in expanding stock options trading.

title: CONGRESS IS BRIEFED BY PRESIDENT'S AIDES ON ENERGY MESSAGE
description: WASHINGTON, April 8Apparently determined to minimize political friction, Carter Administration energy aides have mounted an extensive campaign to painstakingly explain to members of Congress the Administration's upcoming energy message, scheduled for delivery on April 20.

title: Peterson Stays Unbeaten, Campbell Loses on Mat
description: AMES, Iowa, April 8 (AP)  Ben Peterson, an Olympian, remained unbeaten today in the national amateur Athletic Union freestyle wrestling championships, but Chris Campbell, a twotime National Collegiate champion, suffered his first defeat in two years.

title: Frazier Threatening To Bench Kingman
description: CHICAGO, April 8Manager Joe Frazier joined the New York Mets war with the unsigned Dave Kingman today, threatened to bench the Powerhitting outfielder and said: I think it's time for him to shut up.

title: Astros 3, Braves 2
description: HOUSTON, April 8 (AP)Joe Ferguson, one of four newcomers in Honston's starting lineup, blasted a leadoff home run in the 11th inning tonight to give the Astros a 32 seasonopening victory over the Atlanta Braves. Ferguson connected off Bob Johnson, whorelieved Andy Messersmith in the 10th.

title: COSTOFLIVING PAY GRANTED TO POLICE
description: An arbitrator directed New York City yesterday to pay a costofliving allowance totaling $441 to each of its 18,000 police officers. At the same time, he ordered the partial deferral of annuity contributions by the city and other savings that a spokesman estimated would be more than 810 million.

title: Article 2 No Title
description: Assoclated Press Bob McAdoo of the Knicks getting two of the 41 points he scored last night against the Braves in Buffalo. New York won the game 104102.

title: Watson and Funseth Gain Masters Lead
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8Tom Watson, who has developed a semantic adroitness in dealing with questions about his choking in the clutch, and Rod Funseth, a grizzled 17year veteran who, has a way of surfacing now and then in major golf tournaments, shared the lead today after the second round of the 41st Masters tournament.

title: Angels, 2
description: SEATTLE, April 8 (AP)Nolan Ryan limited Seattle to three hits and Bobby Grich belted a firstinning homer last night in leading the California Angels to a 20 victory over the Mariners.

description: Scientists working on artificial sweeteners in laboratories around the country, driven by the vast commercial potential that would be opened up by the Food and Drug Administration's planned ban on saccharin, are accelerating their efforts to find, develop and win approval for alternative sweeteners.

New Yorkers will recall the singer and guitarist from the early 40's, when she was hailed for her folk songs and ballads at Cafe Society, the downtown nightclub. After a long absence, Miss Reed appeared briefly several years ago at the Cookery.

description: ROME, April 8Pope Paul VI, in a Good Friday enactment of the Passion and Crucifixion of Jesus, carried a large cross in an outdoor rite near the Colosseum late tonight.

title: News Summary
description: West Germany approved export licenses for the controversial nuclear equipment it agreed to provide Brazil despite strong objections of the Carter Administration that were relayed to the Bonn Government in January by Vice President Mondale. Chancellor Helmut Schmidt apparently did not agree with the Administration's contention that the West German agreement with Brazil would contribute to nuclear proliferation. The agreement with Brazil provides for supervision by the International Atomic Energy Organization in Vienna. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Amid Confusion, A Primer On Nuclear Energy Policy
description: This week, the Carter Administration unveiled its plans for nuclear power, a significant part of its forthcoming energy policy package. The preview of a redirection in atomic energy came in a statement about how to avoid spreading the ability to make nuclear bombs throughout the world. The statement left many people confused about the complex issues involved and what the Carter proposals mean.

description: Alexander L. Guterma, the controversial financier who was killed Tuesday With five members of his family in the crash of a private plane in the Bronx, conducted his affairs as mysteriously at the time of his death as he did when he controlled a large fortune.

description: Bonn, April 8Once again, West Germany's political and legal institutions have been strained by terrorist violenceThe assassination of the federal prosecutor, Siegfried Buback, and his driver in Karlsruhe yesterday.

Tom Watson, a man in the gallery muttered, even finds a way to blow a 36hole lead.. Two years ago Tom Watson won the British Open, and early this year he won both the Crosby and the San Diego open in successive weeks. But three weeks ago he was leading the Tournament Players Championship by two shots with nine holes remaining, shot 77 and lost by four.

Miss Austin, the 14yearold phenom who was topseeded in the 18's, was unable to handle Miss Stoll's topspin Lobs, Miss Austin evened the match afte Hosing the first set and then came from 14 to 4all in the third set. Miss Stoll broke service in the ninth game and held in the 10th to advance.

Nevil, who won this event in 1973 and 1974, is tied at 135 with Don Pooley, Mike McCullough and Gary Groh. Their lead is one stroke.

title: Islanders Hope Form Holds For Next Test With Sabres
description: Form has held up perfectly thus far in the National Hockey League's playoffs, much to the Islanders satisfaction. A 106point team In the regularseason standing, they were not expected to lose to a 63point team such as the Chicago Black Hawks, and they didn't. The Islanders swept the preliminary series in two games. Their next opponent, starting Monday night, will be the Buffalo Sabres, who eliminated the Minnesota North Stars in the first round just as the point comparison indicated (104 to 64).

title: Mr. Young on the Run, Mr. Ford at Large
description: Ambassador Andrew Young's continuing clarifications, amendments and apologies for statements made on the run are becoming harmful as well as tedious. It being impractical for the country's chief United Nations delegate to cease making statements, we suggest an end to the running. Some say the compulsion to make headlines betrays a desire to run for higher office. We think, on the contrary, that Mr. Young values his job and is chasing an idea, a worthy idea, at that. His willingness on occasion to look foolish or illinformed is widely admired as a part of his charm, but Mr. Young himself should now consider slowing down, to protectand finally definehis animating idea.

title: CARROLL C. PENDLETON
description: Carroll Chester Pendleton, who retired in 1957 as executive vice president of the Seas Shipping Company, in Manhattan, died Thursday in Saybrook Convalescent Hospital in Old Saybrook, Conn. Mr. Pendleton who was 88 years old, lived at Shore Acre Road, South Lyme, Conn. He is survived by a son, James, and two grandchildren.

title: Oil and Gas Earnings Affected Erratically by Winter
description: The capricious winter weather, which put the Eastern half of the country in a deep freeze while parching the Western states, has had an erratic effect on oil and eas earnines as well.

title: Damned, British PunkRock Group
description: What may have been the first foray of a new British invasion took place Thursday night at CBGB's. The occasion was the first New York appearance of any of the newwave British punkrock bands. The opener was called the Damned, and the group will be there through tomorrow night.

title: BROOKLYN COVERUP IN SHOOTING IS DENIED
description: A Brooklyn police sergeant yesterday strenuously denied allegations by District Attorney Eugene Gold that there had been mishandling or a coverup in the police investigation of an attempted murder involving a fellow policeman last month.

The N.H.L. will televise one playoff game every week until the final series, when it will show all of the games.

title: StateFinanced Mining Group In Italy Will Be Dissolved
description: ROME, April 8 (UPI)The Government has announced that it was dissolving statefinanced mining, steel and textile group that piled up a $464 million loss in 19 years.

title: Fresh pasta: Plain (Just Butter or Fancy With Truffles)
description: It is possible to find (if not entirely to, understand) people who dislike lobsters or caviar, asparagus or raspberries, brie or hot roasted almonds, but it is virtually impossible to find anyone, of any age, who does not love pasta.

title: Computer Suitor in 'Demon Seed'
description: "Demon Seed," which opened yesterday at the Criterion and other theaters, is gadget-happy American moviemaking at its most ponderously silly.A group of scientists in Southern California works eight years to build an artificial intelligence system that contains all the knowledge of the world and that thinks for itself. They call it "Proteus Four" and intend to use it as "the ultimate instrument of financial power," but Proteus Four has other ideas.One day, after finding a cure for leukemia, Proteus Four falls in love. Aware that he is in something approximating mortal danger (that the scientists will pull his plug when they realize how independent he is), he desires to have a child to carry on his knowledge and his work. Among other things, he tells us in his gravelly voice that he is "interested in the uncertain future of seashores, deserts and children." Proteus Four isn't all bad but he gets his priorities mixed up."Demon Seed" is virtually a one-woman, one-computer movie. It's about Proteus Four's courtship and rape of Susan Harris a pretty, suitably bewildered psychiatrist played by Julie Christie. All this happens after Susan and her husband. Alex (Fritz Weaver), Proteus Four's chief designer, have split and Alex has made the mistake of leaving Susan alone in their house with an open computer terminal connected to Proteus Four.Miss Christie is too sensible an actress to be able to look frightened under the circumstances of her imprisonment. Most of the time she just looks bloody impatient, as the computer, with the help of an automated wheelchair and electric eyes that open and close doors, keeps her prisoner, makes medical tests on her and busies himself with creaing his ownare you ready?demon seed.Donald Cammell, a painter who was the co-director (with Nicholas Roeg) of "Performance," directed "Demon Seed" with more apparent interest in the machinery of the movie than in its sense. Some of this machinery is quite impressive, including the large metal tetrahedron that becomes the material manifestation of Proteus Four.Yet most of these effects are more mind-depressing than mind-expanding. At best, they are unintentionally funny, as in a sequence in which the movie attempts to find video-image equivalents to a woman's feelings as she reaches the peak of pleasure with a computer. For those of us who've seen "2001," it looks as if she were landing on Jupiter.The screenplay was written by Robert Jaffe and Roger O. Hirson with no humor and a great deal of self-consciousness of the sort that seeks to separate the writers from what they've written. "This is ridiculous," someone says desperately at one point, or, says another. "At the risk of sounding simplistic. . . ." before he goes on to sound simplistic. Miss Christie and Mr. Weaver are bearable and two actors were used to play the computer-baby. Both look like brass-dipped Mickey Rooneys.

description: CALHOUN, Ga., April 8President Carter said today he had received private assurances from Leonid I. Brezhnev that the Soviet Union was as serious abaut an eventual agreement on the limitation of strategic arms as the United States.

description: Remember when people used to talk about doing things in Macy's window? That was just talk. They never really did those things, whatever they were. At least, not that anyone ever noticed.

description: It was Nietzsche who advised people to live dangerously by building their cities under volcanos. For longshot betting New York horseplayers, the volcano is Steve Cauthen. Just when it seems the 16yearold apprentice jockey has quieted down, he erupts with another surge of winners. On Thursday, Cauthen brought home six winners at Aqueduct for the second time this season. Yesterday, he rode four more. Three of them were favored, two at oddson, and the fourth was a strong second choice.

title: Shoes, Sugar and TV Sets
description: President Carter has demonstrated fidelity to principle in refusing to increase tariffs on foreignmade shoes. This is probably the toughest political decision he will have to make in foreign trade because of the strong support the domestic shoe industry has mustered in Congress. Onehalf of the Senate and onethird of the House had gone on record urging him to raise shoe tariffs. The caustic attack on the Carter decision by Lane Kirkland, secretarytreasurer of the A.F.L.C.I.O., shows that the President is already beginning to pay a political price. The plan of the two leading clothing workers unions to stage a brief symbolic strike next week to affirm their solidarity with the shoe workers indicates that the pressure is going to continue.

title: Notes on People
description: Princess Anne is expecting her first baby, Queen Elizabeth II's first grandchild, in November, Buckingham Palace announced yesterday. It said that Anne, who is 27 years old, will be able to carry out public engagements already arranged between now and july [including a trip to the United States in midJune], but she will not be competing in further equestrian events. The Princess, a member of Britain's equestrian team in the 1976 Olympics, and her husband, Capt. Mark Phillips, are spending the Easter weekend at the Bristock Horse Trials in Northamptonshire, but Anne did not plan to compete. The Queen and her husband, Prince Philip, were told of their daughter's pregnancy on their recent tour of, the Pacific to mark Elizabeth's 25th year on the throne.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: QUARTERFINAL ROUND

title: Reserve Mining Wins Court Battle Over Disposal Site for Ore Wastes
description: ST. PAUL, April 8The Minnesota Supreme Court today unanimously affirmed the decision of a lower court and ordered state environmental agencies to issue permits for the Reserve Mining Company to dump ore wastes at a disposal4 site in northeastern Minnesota that the company prefers.

title: Eubie Blake in Ellington Tribute
description: The musical tribute that was held at the Whitney Museum of American Art on Thursday evening was in honor of Duke Ellington and the programimprovisations by three pianists and selections from Ellington's Sacred Concertswas devoted to the Duke's music. Yet it was the irrepressible Eubie Blake, still bubbling with high spirits at 94 years of age, who gave the concert its warmest, most appealing moments.

title: THOUSANDS ARE FACED WITH RENT INCREASES
description: The rents of thousands of tenants of rentcontrolled Apartments in New York City are expected to go up by as much as 7.5 percent soons to compensatn tkeir landlords for higher labor costs resulting largely from the settlement of a building employees strike last year.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Vidi or Cogliendo rose, Demophon; Fauna Canzone Senza note nere, Vecchi; Engtr music of the Late Renaissance.

title: Friday Night at Suburban Disco An Outward Coolness Amid the Hustle
description: No moon shone on Westchester County Friday night a week ago, but off Route 22 in Scarsdale you could see headlights climbing the steep driveway to the Milky Way, one of the many fancy, loud and jammed discotheques that have become the main center of night life for young people in the New York Ctiy area.

title: People in Sports
description: Whether the United States Tennis Association will accept the findings of a sex test in Arkansas qualifying Dr. Renee Richards as a genetic female will be discussed at a U.S.T.A. meeting on Monday. Acceptance could allow the 42yearold transsexual, the former Richard Raskind, to participate as & woman in the United States Open next fall.

title: Religious Brainwashing Dispute
description: During Passover and Holy Week, when Jews and Christians celebrate the theme of freedom, the watchdogs of America's religious liberty are measuring the potential impact of two highly charged court cases involving allegations of brainwashing  one highly praised by civil libertarians and the other labeled appalling. The first was the March 17 decision in Queens by State Supreme Court Justice John J. Leahy to throw out two indictments against the Hare Krishna movement for allegedly holding two members captive illegally and attempting to extort funds from the father of one of the two.

title: Front Page 1 No Title
description: The New York Times/Robert Walker

title: CRIME LABORATORIES SCORED IN U.S. STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, April 8(AP)Crime laboratories often do poor work and sometimes are wrong snout the evidence used against defendants in criminal trials, a Government study says.

title: Sadat Said to See Full Relations With Israel 5 Years After a Pact
description: WASHINGTON, April 8Carter Administration officials said today that President Anwar elSadat of Egypt had told them he envisaged full normalization of relations with Israel within about five years after a Geneva agreement had been signed, and that some interim steps toward normal relations could take place even earlier.

title: New Study by Concorde Operators Calls Noise Comparable to a 707's
description: Concorde operators have given New York City and Federal authorities new data purporting to prove that, with revamped flight procedures, there would be very little difference between the supersonic airliner's noise and that of longrange Boeine 707's.

title: Personal Investing
description: For most Wall Streeters, ideology and investments are like oil and waterthey just do not mix. That is one of the reasons Kenneth J. Oberman, president of the Dreyfus Third Century Fund, says, with evident regret, that everybody has been very negative on us.

title: KLM Pilot in Collision Reportedly Didn't Hear Controller's Stand By
description: The pilot of the KLM Royal Dutch Airlines jet in the collision in the Canary Ishnds with 8. Pan American World Airways jet last month apparently never heard the tower's instructions to stand by for takeoff, sources close to the investigation revealed yesterday.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: Los Angeles 124 Nets 100. Knicks 104, Buffalo 102. Milwaukee 118, Atlanta 107. Chicago 113, Houston 109. Seattle 112, Kansas City 105. Boston 120, New Orleans 109. Detroit 116, Philadelphia 112. Portland 122, Phoenix 111.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 8 (AP)Two policemen were killed today and a third seriously wounded in a machine gun ambush north of here, security authorities said.

title: Scientists Seek New Sweetener
description: Scientists working on artificial sweeteners in laboratories around the country, driven by the vast commercial potential that would be opened up by the Food and Drug Administration's planned ban on saccharin, are accelerating their efforts to find, develop and win approval for alternative sweeteners.

title: Indians in Johannesburg Evicted From Area Earmarked for Whites
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 8At sunset, a muezzin's cry filters down the narrow colonnaded road. Women in saris appear on the stoops, watching their men folk gather for disconsolate conversation. Occasionally one of the men steps forward to poke at a pile of smoldering ashes, sending charred scraps flittering in the still evening air.

title: Palmieri Leads Band At Smucker's
description: Smucker's is a spacious new club across the street from the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and in this, its first month of operation, it's been offering a nice assortment of firstclass talent, most of it based here.

title: Peres and Allan Top Contenders As Party's Replacement for Rabin.
description: JERUSALEM, April 8Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin's unexpected resignation as the governing Labor Party's candidate for reelection today stirred the political ambitions of two leading party figuresForeign Minister Yigal Allon and Defense Minister Shimon Peres.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: VISITOR TO CHINA: Margaret Thatcher, leader Britain's Conservative Party, meeting in Peking with Teng Yingchao, widow of Prime Minister Chou Enlai.

title: Caramoor to Welcome the Public
description: C A RAMOOR,the 56room Florentine villa built by the lawyer and investment banker Walter Tower Rasen to house an extensive collection of European and Chinese works of art dating from the Middle Ages through the 18th century, will open to the public without appointment for the first time April 23. Guided tours will be conducted without prior reservations by a staff of 65 trained docents on Wednesdays and Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. throughout the spring, summer and fall.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Yankees conclude their home stand today with a 2 P.M. game against the Milwaukee Brewers in Yankee Stadium, then take off Kansas City. The Mets home opener is at 2:05 Tuesday against the. St. Louis Cardinals. The Cards also have 2:05 games against the Mets in Shea on Wednesday and Thursday. The Chicago Cubs come in for a weekend series Friday, Saturday and Sunday, all at 2:05. Sunday is Photo Album Day at Shea.

title: STAMPS
description: The translation of complex scientific developments, all Nobel Prizewinning achievements, to the minute dimensions of postage stamps has been undertaken by Great Britain with a quartet of unusual issues that mark the centenary of the Royal Institute of Chemistry, while paying tribute to British scientists.

title: Equity Elusive in Bloc Grants
description: ONE of the trickiest jobs in Washington is putting together those complicated formulas to check blight and spur community development in older communities.

title: GARDENING
description: ALTHOUGH the beauty of purewhite trumpet lilies dominates New Jersey living rooms on this Easter Sunday, there is a dearth of ??? in New Jersey gardens. Why is that?

title: 10 Defendants Freed for Easter
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 (UPI)Noting that Pontius Pilate freed Barabbas in the first Easter weekend, a judge yesterday released 10 criminal defendants; without bail. It was Good Friday and they were stuck in jail for the weekend, explained Municipal Court Judge John A. O'Kane. All the released prisoners had been accused of nonviolent crimes.

title: Home Guide to Choosing And Using Batteries
description: In recent years more and more portable appliances, toys, small power tools, radios, clocks, cameras, calculators and other household accessories have been introduced which are pow ered by compact replaceable batteries.

title: New Governor of Minnesota Throws His Door Open
description: ST. PAULIn a small conference room, Gov. Rudolph G. Perpich listened attentively as he sat with a dozen men representing opposing sides in a dispute over landfill operations in St. Louis County.

title: A Costlier April 15th
description: For the millions of American taxpayers who can't face the job of completing tax returns, it may cost as much as 10 to 20 percent more to get help this year.

title: DayCare Comes of Age
description: DAYCARE, created to fill the needs of families in the inner city, has raised its tousled head in the suburbs, where working parents no longer want to pay up to $200 a week for a housekeeper. Community programs have opened in such communities as Larchmont, Dobbs Ferry, Katonah and Harrison, in part because of a dramatic increase in the singleparent home, but also because of the need to give a child beyond the age of 2 something more than a baby sitter and the tedium of television.

title: Seoul's Critics Appear Stronger
description: SEOUL, South KoreaThe recent South Korean Supreme Court decision upholdiag the conviction of 18 critics of President Park Chung Hee, designed to discourage opposition activities, appears instead to have strengthened the determination of the protestors and to have ignited a rash of new demonstrations against Government repression here.

title: Engagements
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. O'Connell of Manhasset have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Ann, to Stephen Philip Hanson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald N. Hanson, of Glen Head. Miss O'Connell attended Graham Junior College in Boston and Is employed by Irving Trust Co. Mr. Hanson Is a graduate of Brown University and is emProved by American Electric Power Service Corp as an engineer.

title: Miss Chamberlin, John A. Earle Are Married
description: Carolyn Chamberlin, associate editor of Magnum Photos Inc., the international photographic agency in New York, was married in Darien, Conn., yesterday afternoon to John Agnew Earle of New York, a freelance photographer. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Noroton Presbyterian Church.

title: Tracie Balliett, An Artist, Plans August Nuptials
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Fargo Balliett Jr. of East Norwich, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Trade Lyon Balliett, to Peter Brooks Saltonstall, son of Mrs. Leverett Saltonstall Jr. of Ithaca, N.Y., and the late Mr. Saltonstall. The wedding is planned for Aug. 13.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The controversy continues. Anyone even mildly interested in dance knows who Maurice Mart is. The only doubt in anyone's mind is what Maurice Br jart isgenius or charlatan, man of the theater or choreographer, poet or fake, jaded Pop artist or avantgarde leader. Or any or all of the above.

title: Cotrubas  A Mimi to Make The Heart Beat Faster
description: Inject the phrase Rumanian soprano into a casual conversation and you will very likely conjure up for your hearers the vision of a powerful, oversized female with matching voice and plenty of wobble: such is the stereotype. But this will prepare you in no way for the experience of seeing, hearing or meeting Ileana Cotrubas, who this week concludes a string of six performances as Mimi in La Bohme, her debut role at the Metropolitan Opera. The lady from Bucharest has none of the expected attributes. Her figure is petite, her personality unassertive, her voice has lyric (not dramatic) dimensions and there is no trace of transDanubian tremolo in the true and evenly matched tones of her gamut. Even her laughterand she laughs readilycomes in neat, musical clusters of chromatic eighthnotes.

title: Some Arthur, Some Tolkien
description: WHEN a new mythmaking talent comes along and it's coupled to a freerolling ability to tell a grand story, delight at this occurrence tends to override any shortcomings you may observe in the initial work. That was my. Frank Herbert is the author of numerous science fiction novels, among them Dune, Dune Messiah and Children of Dune. first reaction to this first novelthat plus the fact that I was sorry when Ole story ended and I was forced to leave the peregrinations of Flick and Shea Ohmsford, who finally caught me. The operative word there is finally.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area

title: STEEL UNION ACCEPTS CONTRACT GRANTING JOB SECURITY GAINS
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The local leaders of the United Steelworkers of America grudgingly approved today new threeyear contract that the union's presidentelect said was a start toward lifetime security for all workers in the industry.

title: Martha Roberts West, D. F. Lyman to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph O'Neal West of Wellesley, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Roberts West, to Daniel Franklin Lyman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Franklin Lyman of St. Louis and Annisquam, Mass. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Yanks' Unbeaten Season Ended, 32; Mets Down Cubs, 86, With Two in 9th
description: With a batting order in which every player had seen AllStar Game action, the Yankees still made their move too late yesterday and were halted by the Milwaukee Brewers, 32.

title: Judge Overrules New York's Ban On City's Use of Nonunion Printing
description: A longstanding policy that bars nonunion printing shops from obtaining contracts to print material for New York City has been declared unconstitutional by a judge in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: WEIRD, bizarre, hilarious, pathetic, were some of the strongly negative comments aroused by the nominations for National Book Awards announced recently. There were 35 nominations in seven categories; the winners will be announced tomorrow. Disagreements are nothing new in connection with the awards, but this year's protests seemed more disaffected than usual. Knopf's Robert Gottlieb, two of whose big books were passed over, went so far as to say that the list was so bad, it signaled the end of the N.B.A., adding that three people had told him the same thing.

title: Downfall of a Florida Empire
description: MIAMIThe future could not have looked brighter for Jose Fend and his son Maurice A. Ferre and for their small but growing collection of Floridabased companies. It was 1973 and the construction business in the Sunshine State was booming.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street the Bronx, 2 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 11, 2 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, 1:55 P.M.)

title: Concert
description: Billy Paul, Jean Cam and Dexter Wansel, who were at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening, represent the jazz and poporiented side of Philadelphia International records. The company is best known for its soulPhiladelphia International's O'Jays are a kind of contemporary apotheosis of the genre but a slicker sound has always been an important factor in its success. In fact, Mr. Paul's Me and Mrs. Jones, a song about an extramarital affair sung in a lush, middleoftheroad style, was one of the label's alltime biggest hits.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: April 15Wheel and rash Sports Car Club map rally. Information: phone John, (201)3645640 or Chet (201)7538556.

title: Some Loopholes for the Overtaxed Sports Fan
description: In this week of tribute to the tax collector, the average fan in the average sportsfoaming city deserves a tax break. The fan who spends his days of rest at work, emotionally supporting his team; the fan who celebrates every weekend gazing through endzone blnoculars; the fan who looks down a kaleidoscopic television tube at the possible pieces of his marriageeach fan is more than ready to have his emotional expenditure quantified in ferms of money and put into the Internal Revenue Service form under the occupation of fan.

title: 4 Children Killed in House Fire
description: LANSDALE, Pa., April 9 (AP)Four children were killed when a fire of undetermined origin swept through a row house in this Montgomery County community early today, the police said. They were found in a bedroom where they had apparently been trapped. Their father, William Mack, escaped uninjured, the police said, amt their mother, Diane, arrived home after the fire had started.

title: Miss Hooker, Hackett Win Swim Titles
description: CANTON, Ohio, April 9 (AP)Jennifer Hooker and Bobby Hackett, a pair of durable high school stars, became the champion American distance swimmers tonight after winning the 1,650yard freestyle titles in the national Amateur Athletic Union indoor meet.

title: A Day in the Life of the Pope
description: ROME. The first rays of a rising sun reach across the city, passing above the stilldark Tiber to touch the high cross atop St. Peter's Basilica. As the sun climbs higher, its light moves onto the vaulted dome of the greatest church in Christendom. Finally, It reaches the top windows of the Apostolic Palace which stands like an indomitable old duchess above the Bernini columns embracing St. Peter's Sauare.

title: Miss Austin a Champion Even in Loss As Juniors Put On Easter Bowl Show
description: Even when she takes a beating, Tracy Austin comes out like a champion.

title: POLITICS
description: THE New Jersey gubernatorial campaign hasn't started officially, but it seems to have been with us so long that it's possible to make up trivia games about the more than a dozen candidates who claim to have what the people want or need in the way of leadership.

title: Parents Seek Bargaining Power In Interest of Students in Palo Alto
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., April 9In the three years since it began, an organization developed here to represent students interests in school policy decisions has made itself felt but has not yet gained its ultimate goala third seat at the bargaining table with representatives of the school board and the teachers union.

title: Trashman Turns In Box of Securities
description: NOBLESVILLE, Ind., April 9 (UPI)Thanks to a trash collector, a box of stocks and bonds valued at $150,000 was returned to J. M. Schugart yesterday. The securities, half of which were negotiable, had been stolen in a burglary Tuesday. Carl Taylor, a trash collector, turned the securities in to police, telling them he had found the metal box against an alley fence Tuesday afternoon.

title: Resting in Style at Ferncliff
description: CHARLES REVSON reserved a private room, custom furnished. Liza Minnelli chose the airy new unit for her mother, Judy Garland. Malcolm X is outside, on a hill to the east. Whitney Young's grave looks west, to the Palisades. The place is Ferncliff Cemetery an Hartsdale, where traditional burial plots surround the largest mausoleum on the Eastern Seaboard.

title: As the Bills Roll In, Consumer Debt Piles Up
description: People were given voices to disguise their thoughts, an old adage goes, and statistics to hide facts.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor Robert Ornstein, in his review of our book MindReach (Mar. 13), implies that our experiments in Remote Viewing, the main concern of the book, lack solidity and cannot be repeated by anyone. This is simply not true.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: YOU don't have to be a member the Small Business Committee to love small business. So says Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of West Islip, who thinks the district that sent him to Congress is better served by his membership on the House Science and Technology Committee, which he joined early in this session of Congress when he failed to win a subcommittee chairmanship on the Small Business Committee and so quit it.

title: From La Rochelle, Mostly With Love
description: THE band of French Huguenots who settled New Rochelle in the 17th century may have thought they had left behind their mother city of La Rochelle. But 300 years later, 16 French school students from La Rochelle have shown up on Main Street, and after 11 days of a threeweek exchange program, they have concluded that Americans put too much sauce on their hamburgers, that the size of American pizzas is a wonder almost beyond words, and that we are a fortunate tribe to inhabit this land of purple mountain majesty and cheap records.

title: Put Yourself in the Pilot's Seat
description: Teterboro Airport is already dark at 6 P.M. on a winter Friday as I fire up the engine on N4681 J, a singleengine, fourseat private airplane off on a week's vacation to Florida.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Monday to FridayManhattan Savings Bank's 17th exhibition, bank lounge, Madison Avenue and 47th Street; 23 breeds including Westminster winners; noon to 1:30 P.M.

title: Leafs Oust Penguins As McDonald Stars
description: PITTSBURGH, April 9 (AP)Lanny McDonald scored three goals and assisted on two to lead the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 5.2 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight in the final game of their National Hockey League playoff series.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: ANNA CHRISTIE Liv Ullmann in a revival of Eugene O'Neill's drama, directed by Jose Quintero. With John Lithgow, Mary McCarty and Robert Donley. Imperial, 249 W. 45th St. (CO 52412) Opens Thur. (previews Tiles: Wed.)

title: New Products
description: The Prestolock is an unusual combination padlock that permits the owner to not only set his own combination (usually by selecting numbers that are easily remembered, such as birthday, address, etc.), it also permits him to change it any time in the future in just a few seconds without need for tools of any kind. Made with a case hardened steel shackle, and chrome plated to resist corrosion even when used outdoors, the lock has four dials on the front, instead of the usual knob. It sells for $6.75 in hardware stores, locksmith shops and department stores, and is made by the Presto Lock Company, Div. of Walter Kidde and Company, 35 Market Street, Elmwood, N.J. 07407.

title: THREE NOVELS
description: WILLIAM BURROUGH'S earliest novel, Junky, has just been published in the first complete and unexpurgated edition. Until now, Junky had been issued only in an Ace paperback in 1953, and the author was given as one William Lee. That edition was a peculiar tandem. volumeif you turned it over and read back to front, it also contained another work on drugs by a former narcotics agentand it is doubtful whether many readers ever saw the debut of the man who is now a grand panjandrum of the drug culture and the experimental prose novel, as Allen Ginsberg calls it in his characteristically ineffable introduction,

title: Life, Renewal and the Bomb
description: This year, with the dawn of another Easter, another celebration of life and renewal, public thoughts mingle easily with private reverence. Three days ago, the United States took a step which could, if other nations join, reduce danger, allay fear and promote peace. That step is to renounce plutonium.

title: Premier of Laos Makes His First Appearance in Public
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 9The Prime Alinister of Laos, Kaysone Phomvihane, made his first public appearance here today since taking office 16 months ago.

title: Picture Credits
description: 15:819BERT MILLER; THE NEW YORK TIMES/TERESA ZABALA

title: Charity Groups in the Winner's Circle
description: SEVEN charitable groups are the big winners at Roosevelt Raceway, thanks to a singular contractual agreement between union members and the management of the trotting track.

title: Mr. Rabin Had Many Rough Days At the Office
description: It was a sorely troubled stewardship from the start. Conceived in the aftermath of a frightful war, nurtured in the midst of tough diplomatic bargaining, wracked by internal dissension, shaken by scandal and suicide, Yitzhak Rabin's premiership was brought down in the end by an inpropriety that was almost routine by Israeli standards.(Although it is illegal for an Israeli to maintain a bank account abroad, it is far from rare, and usually results in little more than a fine and temporary embarrassment.)

title: Mapping Out a National Energy Policy
description: WASHINGTONOn the second floor of the Executive Office Building, next door to the White House, 15 economists, public administrators and lawyers are shaping the much heralded National Energy Plan that President Carter is scheduled to propose to Congress on April 20.

title: Sipping and Nibbling in Closter
description: M ORE than 200 people turned out for a recent winetasting session by Les Amis du Vin. The groupmost from North Jersey, a handful from as far afield as Connecticut, Long Island and Pennsylvania  took over Danny's steakhouse in Closter for the occasion.

title: J. M. Muldoon to Wed Lauren D. Fritzinger
description: Noel C. Fritzinger, State Education Department assistant commissioner for the State Museum in Albany, and Mrs. Fritzinger have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Dwight Fritzinger, to Joseph Michael Muldoon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Muldoon of Philadelphia.

title: LilyAn Opera That Took 18 Years To Flower
description: Lyndon B. Johnson, the paradox of the Pedernales, might not strike everyone as a symbol of Western civilization. But to Leon Kirchner, whose longawaned Lily will have its premiere at the New York City Opera on Thursday night, there is a mythic fascination about about LBJ that makes that huge, cruel, kindly, crafty, bumbling, sentimental social idealist a blood brother to the central male character of his work, which is based on Saul Bellow's novel, Henderson the Rain King.

title: Karen Hirshberg Is Engaged to Gary Hediger
description: Dr. and Mrs. Irwin Hirshberg of Tenafly, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Linda Hirshberg, to Gary Paul Hediger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Hediger of Woodridge, N.J.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: AMAN fixed his eye on Richard N. Lander, Westchester County's jury commissioner, at a party recently. Don't I know you from somewhere? he asked.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The New York Times/Jack Manning THE YALE CENTER FOR BRITISH ART, which opens April 19th, is the finest collection of British art ever

title: Protestant Churches Are Reviving Evangelism in Membership Drive
description: America's mainstream Protestant churches, spurred by recent declines in membership are showing a renewed interest in evangelism, which they have long neglected and even shunned.

title: As Lobbies Go, Education Is a Powerful One
description: Traditionally, education has received special attention from lawmakers because of its basic importance to large numbers of the electorate. It is a microcosm of politics. Tradition alone, however, does not sustain education budgets. At city, state and Federal levels there exist powerful education lobbiesconsisting of teachers, school and college officials, parents and studentsthat probably match or exceed in strength the lobbies for any other purpose.

title: Anna Christie Has Benefits
description: One of the hottest theater party tickets this spring is the revival of O'Neill's Anna Christie starring Liv Ullmann. The Henry Street Settlement has reserved seats for the evening performance at the Imperial Theater on April 20, Roosevelt Hospital has hooked for the April 26 performance, the Lincoln Square Neighborhood Center has chosen May 5 for its theater party and the Experiment in International Living May 10. Tickets for all four benefits can be obtained from Mrs. Gillette Boland, 40 East 68th Street. Prices range from $25 to $100.

title: PRIVATE UNIVERSITIES MD COST EFFICIENT
description: A study by the New York State De partment of Education has found that disadvantaged students in educational opportunity programs at private universities are graduated at much lower cost to state, city and Federal governments than students in similar programs at the City and State Universities.

title: Sunset in Augusta
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9The man was older than most of the other golfers, and he did not have a Masters badge pinned to his shirt. When the Pinkerton guard in the blue uniform didn't see a badge, he thrust his hands against the man's chest to prevent him from entering the door. But the man was.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Newspaperman. You'll find his kind in every city roomthe reporter who dreams of putting on his hat and coat some fine day and striding forth to win fame and fortune writing books, doing his own stories in his own way. Every year a few make it all come true, usually as writers of nonfiction. Among the very, very few who've made it of late as fiction write's is Gregory Mcdonald.

title: Perry, 38, Still Admirable As He Stops Orioles, 51
description: Gaylord Perry, who at age 38 ought to be thinking about retirement, began his 16th major league season yesterday by beating the Baltimore Orioles, 51, with a fivehit effort. The victory was the Tcxas Rangers second straight over Baltimore in Memorial Stadium.

title: UGANDA REFUGEES SAY ATROCITIES CONTINUE
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 9Since 1971, when stories of systematic murders by the Government of President Idl Amin began filtering out of Uganda, the numbers of those who have disappeared or been killed have largely been guesswork.

title: PREVIEW WHAT'S COMING IN FASHION
description: Saint Laurent Yves's witty evening look moire taffeta pantaloons with featherbordered shawl shot with glitter.

title: A Shunpike Tour: Finding Faults and Other Things
description: Don't go back tomorrow, said my friend. Stay over till Sunday. The work that had taken me west had been finished a day ahead of schedule.

title: The Region
description: Because it has fashioned a truly balanced budget, with little legislative dissension, New York State has performed its annual rite of spring borrowing with surprising ease.

title: FIREBOMBS START BLAZES AT 3 DEPARTMENT STORES
description: Firebombs exploded and touched off Iminor blazes in three Manhattan department stores last night, the police said. No trnuries were reported.

title: Radio
description: Today: Leading Eventbs

title: $45,000 Paid in Consumer Case
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 9 (AP)American Consumer Inc., a large mail order company, has agreed to pay $45,000 in damages for allegedly deceiving buyers of plants. The agreement settled a suit by the state's Bureau of Consumer Protection, which accused the company of allegedly violating a court order prohibiting it from making false and misleading product claims. The suit said that the concern misrepresented five plants in its advertisements, including a yearround tomato that supposedly required no care and produced tomatoes by the ton.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: For 10 years, Augustus J. Simmons had tried to prove that six acres of Bradley International Airport at Windsor Locks, Conn., really belonged to him. Last Jan. 13. Louis Shapiro, the state referee hearing the case in Superior Court, agreed that the disputed land was indeed part of the Simmons family's old farm.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Because 35 percent or more of American children under age 15 have not been vaccinated against preventable childhood diseases, the Federal Government has announced a new immunization drive. Its goal is to reach 20 million unprotected children by the fall of 1979 and to set up a reliable system for vaccinating the three million children born each year.

title: Boxing's Fight For a Comeback
description: HUFFING and puffing as they flailed away at one another with powderpuff punches that hurt only their reputations, Marian Tiger Trimtar and Gwen Gemini engaged in a fourround exercise in pugilistic futility while boos reverberated through the Waterbury Armory.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor Linda Charlton's and David Binder's April 4 reports on The Committee on the Present Danger may make us more complacent rather than alert us in indicating that some people are concerned about the burgeoning Soviet military threat. But in fact, groups often ignore the debates of individuals and decide to actor not to actaccording to irrational reasons fundamental to the group minds. Democracies, unfortunately, tend not to act until it is dangerously late.

title: Tennis Clinic
description: Is your backhand as reliable as a politician's promise? Does your second serve float over the net like a dewdrop?

title: Reaping Big Harvests from Small Spaces
description: Asurprising number of gardeners are getting the plantincontainer habit, especially for vegetable crops. Tubs, pots, barrels, window boxesyou name itare being turned into productive minifarms on city terraces and penthouses, in condominium yards and even in suburban gardens where sunny space is limited.

title: ART
description: THE architectural photogaphs of Philip Trager are pictures without people. There are houses where people might live, municipal buildings where people work, railroad stations, firehouses, row houses, town halls and greenhouses and apartment houses and stores, but no one is in them or around them. Even main streets, where people must walk sometimes, are uninhabited. Mr. Trager has totally depopulated his imagery.

title: ART
description: ROSLYN IN these postFreudian days, virtually nothing escapes analysis; since the Viennese doctor put Da Vinci to the test in a famous essay, artistsand sometimes even collectors have had the psychological motives of their work described relentlessly.

title: 5 in Family, From 3 Generations, Killed in a House Fire in Queens
description: It began as an Easter celebration, but it ended tragically for a grandfather, his daughter and three of his grandchildren, who were killed early yesterday morning in a fire that swept through a twostory Queens home.

title: A Bundle From Britain
description: WHEN the Yale Center for British Art opens officially on April 19, the public will find that it is as welcome to visit as the university community. The center was a gift to the university from Paul Mellon, a 29 Yale graduate, and officials emphasize that anyonescholar, layman, tov.'n or gown affiliate can make use of the center, which will make Yale the leading institution outside England for the study of British art and culture.

title: CLIFFORD C. GOES, 84; WAS NOTED COXSWAIN
description: Clifford C. (Tip) Goes, chairman of the United States Olympic Rowing Committee for many years and an allAmerican coxswain at Syracuse University, died Friday at his home in Hackettstown, N.J. He was 84 years old.

title: Eine Kleine Strassenmusik
description: As an authentic churl, I hug to myself a morbid distaste for uplift. Nevertheless, on a recent splendid sunny Sunday afternoon on Sheridan Square in Greenwich Village, I was completely bamboozled by spring.

title: Young Fun in Northern Ireland
description: That is the way it is in Belfast and Londonderry.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN'a door's bell or chime fails to ring each time the button on the outside is pushed, the first thing the homeowner should suspect is a faulty push button. On most houses, this button is exposed to the weather, and so dampness eventually causes contacts to corrode; sometimes, it even causes connections to loosen or break off.

title: Columbia Eight Beaten by Navy
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., April 9Navy's heavyweight crew made a clean sweep of their regatta with Columbia, and retained the Maxwell Stevenson Cup today.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Animals have always been popular subjects for photographers, and good animal pictures are often among the prize winners at shows and contests. Photographs of animals are also widely used commerciallyon calendars and greeting cards, as well as in illustrated advertisements of all kinds.

title: Jullie B. Ferris, Andrew B. Sillin To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Ferris of Geneseo, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jullie Barbara Ferris, to Andrew Borden Sillin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lelan F. Sillin Jr. of Lyme, Conn. A wedding next month in Milibrook, N.Y. is planned.

title: Carol Flaxman Is Betrothed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Seymour. L. Flaxman of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Thalia Flaxman, to Louis Michael Richter, son of Jean F. Richter of Chicago and the late Dr. Irving B. Richter. A summer wedding is planned.

title: MUSIC
description: WHOEVER said that light music is music everybody likes except the critics had a point. Nothing is likely to make an esthete turn up his nose faster than an invitation to a pops concert or an operetta performance, yet some of the most delectable music in the world is likely to show up in just such outings.

title: Open on Wednesday Public Golf Courses
description: AT 7:08 next Wednesday morning, weather permitting, at each of five Westchester County courses, a golfer will swing at a dimpled white ball, and the 1977 public links season will be under way. Before it ends late in November, more than 200,000 rounds of golf will have been played at Dunwoodie and Sprain Lake golf courses in Yonkers, at Saxon Woods in Scarsdale, at Maplemoor in White Plains and at Mohansic in York town Heights.

title: Wedding in August For Nancy Haggerty And Gerard J. Eaton
description: The engagement of Nancy Haggerty to Gerard J. Eaton has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Haggerty of Plandome, L.I., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Eaton of Jamaica Plain, Mass. An August wedding Is planned.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Lawsuits are not uncommon in the movie industry. Like telephones in Rolls Royces, they are status symbols as well as an accepted means of communication between wheelerdealers. When friend sues friend, it's often as much for emphasis as for anything else. It's tone of voicea point of view italicized. Every now.

title: 3 Turbo Trains, Out of Service, Offered for Sale by Amtrak
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)Amtrak has forsale signs on three TurboTrains that generated maintenance headaches When they were operated until last year on the run from New York to New Haven and Boston. The trains were taken from service last September and now are idle tit a maintenance yard near Providence, R.I.

title: GARDENING
description: PROBABLY the most famous cherry blossoms in America are those that rim the Tidal Basin around the Jefferson Memorial in Washington. They are visited by thousands of people every spring.

title: The World
description: The Government of Taiwan, upset by what it sees as an insufficient and laggardly supply of weapons from the United States, has apparently found an alternative source in Israel. The sale of Gabriel missiles reported last week also suits Israel's purposes; greater arms exports help support its military development.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: REMEMBERING BATAAN: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, center, leading U.S. Ambassador William H. Sullivan and Japanese Charg d'Affaires Makoto Taniguchi during ceremony in the Philippines commemorating 35th anniversary of battle of Batain. Veterans from all three countries attended.

title: DINING OUT
description: UNLIKE most of the seafood restaurants in Freeport, Moorings is not on the water it is a couple of blocks from the boat canals, but manages to compensate for this distance with a nautical atmosphere inside. Netting, rope, cork, running lights, figureheads, diving bells and wheels clutter every available inch of wall space. The various sections of the lowceilinged, candlelit restaurant are rather cozy.

title: We Did Overcome
description: When I was invited to deliver this year's commencement speech at my old high school in Okemos, Mick, my pleasure was somewhat tempered by intimations of mortality. It seems that most members of the Class of 1977 were born in 1959the year in which I entered the school.

title: Frank Milan, Actor, 71, Dead; Made. Broadway Debut in 1935
description: Frank Milan, who made his debut on Brodaway in 1935 as the football player in The Petrified Forest, starring the late Leslie Howard and the late Humphrey Bogart, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 400 East 57th Street. He was 71 years old.

title: The Cinematic Search for the Japanese Spirit
description: The Japanese film returns to New York today with the Regency theater's opening of a festival of 51 movies ranging from masterpieces by Kurosawa, Ozu and Mizoguchi to potboilers featuring the superhuman exploits of a blind samurai named Zatoichi. Japanese movies nearly always involve a search for identitywhat it means to be a Japanese and how the Japaitse spirit may be recovered after a century of westernization and industrial development. Often violent, sensual and intensely passionate, Japanese films are about people struggling within alien circumstances to remain true to an authentically Japanese style of life always in danger of being lost and submerged beneath the frantic pace of commercial life in contemporary Japan.

title: Food
description: If there is any doubt that American cookery took a lightningbolt leap forward in sophistication these past few years, one has only to consider the past and current status of fresh mushrooms and their availability. Twenty years ago they were practically unknown in most of the country's smaller metropolises, and the total annual production was a mere 75 million pounds in the entire nation. Today that figure is well over 309 million pounds and is increasing annually. The phrase lightning bolt is not used loosely here. Legend has it that the ancients believed mushrooms, one of the most delectable and versatile of foods, were created by lightning bolts. An inadequately small display of the lowly mushroom's versatilityand delectabilityis recorded on this.

title: Lebanon's Christians Are Building Own Large Airport
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 9About 30 miles north of Beirut, near the town of Batrun bulldozers working on a plateau overlooking the sea have gouged a milelong gash through olive groves.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: ON EASTER Sunday mornings, different people do different things. Some get up before dawn to get to sunrise services. Some make sure that the Easter bunny has not been stingy with the baskets left overnight for their children. Some cook and color, then roll and hide eggs. Some just sleep late.

title: POLITICS
description: WELFARE is a slippery, fastmoving treadmill, easier to get on to than to leave. In the mindless sort of momentum it is gathering in Connecticut, the treadmill has become a force not only of rescue but also of destruction, wiping out the incentive of some men and women to work, and sometimes breaking apart their impoverished families.

title: INTERVIEW
description: ANN KLEIN might, be forgiven if she has a gloomy view of the world. She is the state's Commissioner of Human Services, dealing in welfare and other miseries, and her working days are filled with litanies of one human disaster after another.

title: Clifford Hack Slavin Plans To Marry Lori J. Forman
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Milton L. Forman of Stamford, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Lori J. Forman, to Clifford Hack Slavin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Murray Slavin of Lake Success, L.I. The wedding is planned for next August.

title: Dance: Raymond Johnson Company at Pace Center
description: Dance companies are coming out of the ground like dragon's teethif that simile makes any sense at all. What I mean is, that just as the dance audience is expanding like inflation, so too is the amount, and even the variety, of dance available to it.

title: SELECTION
description: GLASSES. Once upon time, they were the mark of the vulnerable. At least to me. Not the pincenez of Woodrow Wilson; his was the emblem of the Sunday schoolmaster, the wrinkled prune, the bloodless. Nor the pincenez of FDR, which, in its offagain, onagain behavior, became as insouciant a sign as his tilted cigarette holder. Nor the pincenez of my mother, which, considering her tough credo, became as antic and outrageous a symbol as Bobby Clark's paintedon glasses. No.

title: MAYOR WILLIAM O'NEIL OF TROY N.Y., DEAD AT 62
description: TROY, N.Y., April 9 (AP)  Mayor William O'Neil of Troy, whose recent party switch shifted the balance of the Troy City Council, died today. He was 62 years old. Mr. O'Neill had been hospitalized for several weeks with heart trouble, the apparent cause of his death.

title: The Migrants Come Back
description: The geese have come back, and most of the lesser birds. You see them and you hear them and you know, you sense, that certain fundamentals persist. If a flight of robins still can arrive and scatter over a park slope or a suburban village green, full of strut and eager satisfaction, you know that the supersonic jets do not yet command the air.

title: John Davenport Remembered
description: LARGER than life: How he would have honked at that phrase, which loomed throughout his British obituariesalong with outsize personality and teacher of genius and one of our greatest literary figuresterms which he, with his horror of clichs, would have stricken from anyone's copy. Yet John Davenport, 19081966, critic, aesthete, editor and heavyweight boxer, didn't discourage the legends that mounted in his wake: He seemed both amused and nourished by them. It was said that T. S. Eliot had pronounced his poetry most promising when he was a student at Cambridge in the late 20's. It was repeatedwith some awethat he had been expelled from the Savage Club for putting a smell bishop on the mantelpiece: Nettled by some minor discord in their theologies, Davenport had lifted the little prelate into the air and deposited him above the fireplace, declaring, You talk like a bloody clock and that's where you belong. Others recall that he hurled tureens of tomato soup over the snowy shirtfronts of clubmen whose perceptions of Proust displeased him. He did take literature into his fists: It was a measure of his passion.

title: Conflict on the Half Shell
description: RELEASED from its burden of ice, Great South Bay shimmers with spring. This lagoon is the heart of Suffolk County's marine economy, pulsing with the hidden life of mollusks, crustaceans, eels and finfish. Ranging from 9 feet 1 inch to the 1toot shallows, in the bay has an average depth of 4 feet 6 inches that is ideal for hardshell clams and vital to Babylon, Islip and Brookhaven.

title: Posner's Pyramid
description: It took one of two skills to ride the gogo years of the Sixties to fortune and notoriety on Wall Street. One skill was picking winning stocks by throwing darts at stock tables. The other was building conglomerates with other people's money.

title: What's Doing in the VAUCLUSE, FRANCE
description: THE SETTINGFrenchmen and foreigners have for centuries seen southern Provence as a region oz benign skies, warm days and cool evenings, old stones and old ways. Indeed, the Vaucluse may be Provence at its best, scenically and culturally a delight and, in its reasonablypriced hotels and restaurants, a good buy. The Vaucluse is a French department, or territorial subdivision, put together at the time of the French Revolution from the papal states of Avignon and Comtat Venaissin, as well as from the principality of Orange (where the Netherlands royal dynasty originated) and smaller territories. It is a region of high hills with snow on top, parched plains, but also green valleys dotted with orchards, chalky, pebbly soil tamed by vineyards. Nights are enhanced by odors of lavender and of jasmine, but also of the myriad herbs which go into Provencal cooking, basil, thyme, rosemary. The wines are some of the richest of the Rhone River valley (Cates du Rhone), a map and guide to which is available at 41 Cours Jeanin Avignon.

title: DurrWade Gain Final Of Doubles
description: TOKYO, April 9 (AP)Francoise Durr of France and Virginia Wade of Britain scored a 63, 63 victory over Mima Jausovec of Yugoslavia and Virginia Ruzici of Rumania today in the semifinals of the $100,000 Bridgestone women's doubles tennis tournament.

title: Favored On The Sly Scores at Garden State
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., April 9On The Sly, a Floridabred 4yearold, won the $32,070 Whirlaway Handicap today at Garden State Park:

title: Ulster's Deepest Troubles May Be in the Hearts of the Children
description: BELFAST, Northern IrelandAs Northern Ireland goes Into its eighth year of violence, behavioral experts are becoming ever more concerned about the damaging effects of the religious war on the mental health of Ulster's childrem Their concern grows with each new episode, such as the restaurant bombing that injured 33 adults and children last week.

title: Goodbye To All That
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel, a man never quite at peace with the job or with the rough and tumble of his nation's politics, walked away from both last week in the midst of sensational news accounts of currency law violations involving the premier and his wife, Leah.

title: Unexpected Legacies
description: WHEN Mary and Elizabeth Fitch, sisters who had lived together in Bridgeport all their lives, died within six months of each other in 1925, they left about $800,000 of their approximately $1 million estate for the establishment of a free rest for white, Protestant female teachers living in Fairfield County.

title: The New American Information Revolution
description: WASHINGTONMark Lynch praised the Pentagon last week as by far the best, most responsive part of the Government. Because Mr. Lynch is a lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union, an unlikely source of kind words for the Defense Department, his remark had the effect certifying that an information revolution is taking place in the capital.

title: POLICE MAINTAIN VIGIL AT THE HOME OF DALEY
description: CHICAGO, April 9 (UPI)The shrine of Bridgeport is a onestory, red brick bungalow behind a flag pole and a lawn not much bigger than a large beach towel.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I.At age 9 William J. Catacosinos began his working career by sweeping and mopping floors in his Greekborn father's grocery store in Harlem. Although that was in 1939, the training was to come in handy some 32 years later, in 1972, at Applied Digital Data Systems Inc. here on Long Island.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: In reference to the article by Matthew C. Cordaro, Why Lilco Prefers Nuclear Power [Opinion Page, March 13] issue: Since Mr. Cordaro is employed by Lilco, it is not surprising that he is promoting nuclear power over the use of coal. He states that there would be (or could be) a much greater loss of life in mining coal rather than in producing nuclear energy.

title: Judicious Reluctance
description: WHEN Republican politicians talk about a possible competitor to Perry B. Duryea, the Assembly Minority Leader, for the Republican gubernatorial nomination next year, they invariably mention another Long Islander, Judge Sol M. Wachtler of the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court.

title: Joining Past and Future
description: JAMESPORT A CITIZENS group is busy restoring a part of the past on the stillundeveloped site here where the Long Island Lighting Company hopes to construct the latest in nuclear power plants to meet the energy needs of the future.

title: Group Matches Feat Of French Explorers
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 9 (AP)A group of canoeists, recreating the expedition that claimed the Mississippi Valley for the King of France, ended a 3,800mile journey here today.

title: Questions /Answers
description: I, too, was having problems with clivia blossoms shriveling before opening. Here is my solution. Last year summered both pots of clivia outdoors where they received five to six hours of sunlight. In the fall one was returned to the greenhouse and another to den kept between 5060 degrees. Watering was reduced. Early in March, I noticed a flower head appearing on the one in the den and I increased watering. It has since bloomed. The one in the greenhouse shows no sign of flowering. D. L. Foglia, South Huntington, N.Y.

title: Moroccans Arrive To Fight in Zaire Against Katangans
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 9 (Reuters)A first detachment of 1,500 Moroccan troops arrived today to help repel an invasion from Angola, the official press agency reported.

title: State of the Union Jack
description: FOR those who specialize in economic brinkmanship and political crisis, there can be few countries more interesting than modern Britain. Its finances are in disarray, its creditors ever more numerous. Its vaunted Welfare State can no longer deliver the goods. And while there is still much to be proud of, the British themselves have grown increasingly critical of their own political and economic institutions. It is now quite respectable to wonder openly whether the hallowed paraphernalia of 10 Downing Street and the Cabinet, with all its welleducated ministers, and the House of Commons, with all its tradition, is genuinely responsive to the wishes of ordinary British citizens, or whether the machinery has simply become a handmaiden of larger forces.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor Walt Rostow's thoughts about A Regional Sense of Purpose (March 20) are imaginative but don't go far enough. The divergent trends of the Sunbelt and the Snowbelt, which he indicates but quickly reconciles are in fact cutting a deep national division. The North is suffering many elements of absolute declinenot just relatively slower growth. Sunbelt growth is not mere replications of Northern plants but many actual substitutions, aided by migration of capital and skills from older areas.

title: The Star You Love to Hate
description: Philadelphia was having its face slapped by a bully of a winter, and Jimmy was coming from practice, where he had attempted murder on a few dozen tennis balls. He had a sealskin coat over his shoulders and the former Miss World on his arm. As he walked past a group of fans, one of them called out in a fatherly way, Button up, Jimmy. It's cold outside.

title: A Village Tinged With Old Russia
description: THE VICTORIAN houses of Sea Cliff with their gingerbread trim have the flavor of other times; its walkable streets are, in their narrow unexpectedness, reminiscent of mountain villages. And from the sloping streets that lead to Hempstead Harbor rise two Russian Orthodox churches in 15thcentury Novgorod style, bringing to the othercentury charm of this village evidence of another culture as wella community of Russian emigres that since the 30's has grown to include some 600 people.

title: Barbara J. Weiss to Be Wed To Anthony A. Waits in July
description: Barbara Jane Weiss and Anthony A. Waits, 1976 graduates of Rollins College, plan to be married next July. Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Weiss of Massapequa, L. I., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Waits of Prospect, Ky.

title: Budget Unit Outlines to Congress 3 Options on Nuclear Strategies
description: WASHINGTON, April 9Congressional options involving United States nuclear strategy could reduce next year's defense budget by as much as $2.9 billion or increase it by $580 million, according to a report by the Congressional Budget Office.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN a door's bell or chime fails to ring each time the button on the outside is pushed, the first thing the homeowner should suspect is a faulty push button. On most houses, this button is exposed to the weather, and so dampness eventually causes contacts to corrode; sometimes, it even causes connections to loosen or break off.

title: Paperbacks New and Noteworthy
description: AGENT IN PLACE, by Helen Macinnes. (Fawcett, $1.95.) Vintage. Macinnes thriller., about a Soviet agent pitted against an American reporter for possession of a NATO document: a best seller in hardcover.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE war room in my house on the second floor. It is always the scene of cluttered activity, of deployments, of massed concentrationsall this whether there is someone in it or not. We don't call it the war room; it is called my son's room. The war, which has been going on for years, is between us and him. If we win, it will be cleaned up. If he wins, it will remain as it is.

title: Lobbying for the Land
description: INSIDE the Oyster Bay Town Hall, just a twominute walk from the Long Island Rail Road station, the crowd oveflowed into the hall way. John Franchina had to stand under an exit sign, but the Plainview homeowner was determined to wait indefinitely for his chance to speak out.

title: Taiwan Still Expects the U.S. to Be Supportive
description: TAIPEI, TaiwanAn inconspicuous building on the edge of Taipei, close to an elevated expressway under construction, is headquarters for a small staff of Americans known locally by their initials as the T.D.C. Whether the United States needs to keep them there, or ought for reasons of global policy to remove them, is one of the more difficult questions that President Carter will face. Certainly his decision, either way, will profoundly affect Taiwan's 16 million people.

title: Ethnic FoodWhere to Go, What to Buy
description: DO YOU plan to feast on freshkilled roast baby lamb this Easter? To gorge yourself with paskha after the lenten fast? Or to sit down to a Sunday dinner of pancit wrapped in banana leaves and charcoal broiled?

title: Poll Shows Interest In Origins Growing
description: In the wake of Alex Haley's bestselling novel, Roots, its serialization on television and the nation's Bicentennial celebrations, Americanswhite and blackare increasingly interested in their own genealogical roots, according to a Gallup poll.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This analysis is based on reports from representative wholesalers and chains with more than 10,000 outlets in the United States.

title: Pregnant Woman, One of 3 Slain, Was Attacked Before Her Murder
description: An autopsy completed yesterday disclosed that a woman eight months pregnantone of the three found stabbed to death Friday night in a Brooklyn apartmenthad been sexually attacked just before the murder.

title: The Bottom Line for Greenwich Teachers
description: APPROVAL of the longdisputed Greenwich teachers contract is widely expected when the 230  member Representative Town Meeting votes on it tomorrow night. Preliminary meetings held by three standing committees last week endorsed the $6.5 million package overwhelmingly.

title: From Hollywood to Westport
description: IF JOBS for teachers of film were plentiful, nights in and around Westport these last couple of winters might not have been so eventful.

title: MUSIC
description: WHOEVER said that light music is music everybody likes except the critics had a point. Nothing is likely to maze an esthete turn up rus nose faster than an invitation to a pops concert or an operetta performance, yet some of the most delectable music in the world is likely to show up in just such outings.

title: Romance With Baseball rings Patty Cox a Job
