description: Patty Cox fondly remembers the summers of her childhood that she spent visiting with her grandmother in Kansas City. They were seasons passed listening to broadcasts of the games of the Kansas City Blues, then a New York. Yankee tarm team. Mrs. Cox's grandmother was an avid fan of anything and everything that represented her beloved hometown, and the Blues were no exception. That old radio was on for every game, every summer, Mrs. Cox, now 48 years old, recalls.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: THE literary defense of the 1960's is hard upon us these days, and already one of its most distinctive featuresthe conviction, it sometimes seems, upon which the whole case may be expected to restis becoming all too clear. This is the impulse, amounting at times to a mania, to portray the 1950's as a period of unparalleled wickedness, repression and fear. A concerted historical myopia about the 50's is currently the rule, in literary criticism no less than in writing about politics, and a picture has now emergedutterly false, of course, but nonetheless widely acceptedof that decade as a time when an entire culture collapsed in a state of academic torpor and moral retreat, and an entire generation of writers and intellectuals succumbed to an atmosphere of blandness and sterility, guided solely by motives cowardice and venality.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)President Carter today declared a major disaster for Alabama, permitting the use of Federal funds in relief efforts in designated areas of the state. The declaration came as a result of severe storms, tornadoes and flooding beginning last Monday.

title: Reverse Tactics on the Zoning Issue
description: IT is a rare day indeed when the news reports do not add something to the suburban zoning scenario. The latest rulings of the United States Supreme Court and state tribunals are interspersed with threats by lowincome housing proponents topursue one course of action, while lowincome housing opponents and voteconscious public official threaten other measuresincluding sometimes the sacrifice of Federal funds earmarked or available for such housing.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: GARDEN CITYWilliam Blake: The Painter as Poet, exhibition of engravings and rare books; now through May 29; Mondays through Thursdays 9 A.M. to 10 P.M., Fridays, Saturdays 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., Sundays 1 to 5 P.M.; closed today; Swirbul Library Gallery, Adelphi University.

title: Trudeau Will Not Say If Separation Is Near
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 (UPI)Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau refused to comment today on a report that he and his wife had agreed to 90day trial separation.

title: BRIDGE
description: Afeature of bridge that makes it unfortunately unique among all games and sports is the fact that the mere act of thinking can create problems and arguments. Thinking is of course inseparable from the game, but it can create an ethical difficulty: If a player hesitates about what to bid, his partner may not draw any inference therefrom.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: LIVING beside northern New Jersey's highways is like having a table near the kitchen in a busy restaurant. An awful lot of traffic passes by, but very little of it concerns you.

title: Taking a Flier in Energy Stocks
description: Trying to anticipate President Carter's energy program, due for unveiling on April 20, Wall Streeters have been busily trying to pick the stocks that will win in the new policy. But it all adds up these days to a massive guessing game.

title: Music in Review
description: Robert Fountain established himself as one of the bestperhaps the best at the timeof college choral conductors in the years he was at Oberlin College. Since then, he has been associated with other schools and is now at the University of WisconsinMadison. On Wednesday, he brought its Concert Choir to Alice Tully Hall for the first time.

title: When the G. O. P. Was Boss
description: WILLIAM LUKENS WARD died nearly 44 years ago, but the Westchester Republicans (a dwindling number) who knew him still talk of Mr. Ward with a touch of awe. And his name arouses strong feelings of political nostalgia among them and fellow Republicans who know their party's history.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: issuing reports and recommendations for changes. The N.T.S.B. members are political appointees, in the past often appointed without technical expertise. They approve, before issuance, all accident investigation findings of their staff of professional aviationaccident investigators, who are among the finest in the world.

title: Deaths
description: ARMSTRONGMervyn V., M.D. The Brooklyn Gynecological Society records with deep regret the passing of Mervyn V. Armstrong, M.D., longtime member and Life Fellow of this Society, on April 2, 1977. Our heartfelt sympathy Is extended to the family. RICHARD J. CALAME, M.D., Pres. JAMES R. JONES, M.D., Secty.

title: Are Urban Counties Ignored By HUD.?
description: WESTCHESTER COUNTY officials have become disturbed in recent weeks by what they consider to be a tendency of the Carter Administration to ignore the role of the urban county in the rehabilitation of the nation's aging cities.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: We are told by the publisher that Frank Cormier is the dean of White House correspondents, and therefore has the honor of shouting, Thank you, Mr. President at the end of all press conferences. We are also told that he has flown more than one and a half million miles on Presidential trips, many thousands of them aboard Air Force One.

Chromed trames. Ever popular for today's life style. In natural, walnut or black stained finish. Side chair shown sells regularly for $69, on sale for $39. Matching armchair not shown, regularly $89, on sale for $59.

title: Westchester/ThisWeek
description: MAMARONECKPerformances at the Emelin, Theater for the Performing Arts, 126 Library Lane are: In Praise of Falling, an original production performed by the Painters Theatre of Sarah Lawrence College. Tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. Sponsored by the Mamaroneck Arts Council. $3, students and the elderly $2. A Streetcar Namei, Desire. Friday and Saturday at 8:30 P.M., next Sunday at 2 P.M. $3.50, students and the elderly $2.50. 6980098.

title: Yamanin, $14.20, Scores in the Widener
description: HIALEAH, Fla., April 9Yamanin, a 5yearold son of Herbager who had not been campaigning against rivals of the highest quality, today joined such present and past stars as Forego, Nashua, Coaltown, Bull Lea and War Admiral, all former winners of the Widener Handicap.

title: Amy Stone to Be Bride Of Michael Walker Glenn
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Stone of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Isabel Stone, to Michael Walker Glenn, an electronics specialist with the Wiltron Electronics Company in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: A Cool Reading on the Celsius Scale
description: In the United States, manufacturers have begun to prepare for this probable step in the introduction of metric measure by responding to a slowly growing demand for Celsius devices and by providing consumerproducts with both scales.

title: World News Briefs
description: Castro Contrasts Idealism Of Carter and U.S. Reality

title: The Sunshine Laws Do Not Uniformly Let Sunshine In
description: It is illegal for a town board In New York State to vote, say, on a highway contract in closed session. But what if the board members merely discuss the contract behind closed doors, then vote on it in public? Is that legal or illegal?

title: How to Follow Federal Orders
description: The indictment of a former Federal Bureau of Investigation official for illegal interception of mail, illegal were taps and conspiracy surely represented a hard decision for Attorney General Bell. There must have been enormous pressure from the F.B.I. and from its formidable alumni association to save one of their own. Their views were probably best expressed by a lawyer for a prospective defendant who said that trials flowing from the ongoing investigation into illegal F.B.I. activities could be a very bad scene  You'll have agents testifying against their bosses, agents being accused of crimes and the whole thing is just going to be tragic.

title: Ethnic Diversity a Problem in N.A.S.L.
description: In the North American Soccer League a team can have as many as 10 nationalities represented, so the problem of unfamiliarity with what the opposition has and can do is a blg one for the coaches. They are the ones who have to devise formulas to face opponents, upgrade the quality of their players, and subsequently play different and more complicated systems.

title: Seeds of Capitalism Are Sprouting in Poland
description: WARSAWWe're not exactly going to become wealthy under the new rules, but for the first time since the war, it's clear now that private enterprise in Poland is here to stay.

title: The Judge Judged
description: FIVE years after his death at age 85, Hugo La Fayette Black, who stood near the center our national life for nearly half a century, remains an enigma. Gerald Dunne's ambitious biography seeks to unravel the mystery of the Klansupported Alabama Senator who became one of the most influential Supreme Court Justices in history.

title: Sandra Joan Clyman Plans May Nuptials
description: Sandra Joan Clyman, a member of the community health faculty at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, and Jonathan Merrill, an urban planner with the New York City Planning Commission, plan to be married May 29.

title: Headliners
description: Los Angeles Mayor Tom Bradley has demonstrated his ability, as a black politician, to gain broad support from white voters by winning a second fouryear term with a large majority. Although only 20 percent of the city's population is black, the Democratic Mayor gained 59 percent of the votes against a field of 11 white challengers. The Mayor's leading opponent, State Senator Alan Robbins made race an explicit issue by using television advertising that dramatined his opposition to courtordered busing for school intogration. The election results are considered to have brightened Mr. Bradley's prospects of running for Governor or Senator in California. In another election in which race was at least a submerged issue, Wyche Fowler, who is white, defeated a black, John Lewis, for the Georgia Congressional seat vacated by Andrew Young when he became United States representative at the United Nations. Voting_ in the district, which includes part of Atlanta and its suburbs, divided along racial lines, and Mr. Fowler, who was president of the Atlanta City Council, gained 62 percent of the ballots. In his last two campaigns, in 1974 and 1976, Mr. Young, who was the first black representative from the South since 1899, managed to capture much of the.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: I t's a small fraternity. Ralph Gomberg in Boston. John Mack in Cleveland. Ray Still in Chicago. Two or three others. These are the best oboe players currently active in American symphony orchestras. Of these, the most legendary is Harold Gomberg, brother of the abovementioned Ralph, who is leaving the New York Philharmonic at the end of this season after 34 years with the orchestra. And, before that, four years as first oboist of the St. Louis Symphony, one year with the Toronto Symphony and four years with the National Symphony in Washington. For 49 of his 60 years, Harold Gomberg has been tootling the oboe.

title: Rising Popularity of Eating Out Puts a Pinch on Supermarkets
description: ATLANTA, April 9Eating out has become so popular in the United States that one of the great American merchandising institutions, the supermarket,' is in economic trouble.

title: Mary Grant Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Mary Elizabeth Grant to David Dennis Burrows has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James B. Grant of Greenwich, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fianc Is the son of Mr and Mrs. Robert H. Burrows of Santa Barbara, Calif. A June wedding is planned.

title: Half the $100 Billion Budget Is Payroll
description: WASHINGTONThe nation's largest employer, the Defense Department, has a manpower problem. It is that military manpower costs are running so high that the Pentagon may have trouble finding the funds to buy the weapons to arm the wellpaid workers who man the ramparts.

title: Price of Orange Juice Expected to Increase
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)Consumers can expect less orange juice and higher prices despite a record orange crop this season, the Agriculture Department reported yesterday. The reason is that the juice yield of Florida oranges is down.

title: Carol Biays Is Fiancee of James K. Johnson
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Sheridan Biays of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., formerly of Manliassei, L.I. and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Ann Biays, to James King Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin E. Johnson of Gilbert, Minn.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE CARTER ADMINISTRATION Is raising Government price supports for 1977 livestock feed grains and will pay farmers to set up a United States wheat reserve of 300 million bushels from last year's harvest, according to Bob Bergland, Secretary of Agriculture.

title: John Updike on Poetry
description: On the occasion, next month, of the publication of John Updike's new collection of verse, Tossing and Turning, Helen Vendler asked Mr. Updike some questions about poetry. A selection of Mr. Updike's poems appears on page 28.

title: Tax Help by Youth for Aged
description: DENISE KAHOUD slipped her hand into Uncle Sam's pocket a couple of weeks ago, pulled out $217 and handed it to an old man at the East Meadow Public Library.

title: Cormorant Captures Gotham Stakes.
description: Maybe it's time to start taking Cormorant seriously as a legitimate Triple Crown threat to Seattle Slew. He's beginning to look the part.

title: Frankenheimer Rides a Blimp To a Big, Fat Comeback
description: LOS ANGELES AGoodyear blimp armed with thousands of lethal darts glides into the Super Bowl chased by an Israeli agent dangling at the end of a helicopter's rope. It is the climax of Black Sunday. In three minutes, the $7.8 million picture will be over.

title: Television This Week
description: 10 A.M. (2) REJOICE: AN EASTER IN GREECE. An hourlong look at the Greek Orthodox religious festivities in Athens and in small villages and churches throughout the Greek Isles.

title: CBS After Paley Filling a Gianat's Shoes
description: Almost from the time television became a business, the superlatives have collected around CBS  richest of the networks, classiest, most glamorous, most popular, most powerful, most uptight.

title: In the Way of the Floodwaters
description: Every time Upper Westchester County is hit with heavy rainstorms, Abe Stromer, owner of Greely's County Store in Chappaqua, starts wondering how much water is going to be pouring through his front door.

title: ART
description: THE architectural photogaphs of Philip Trager are pictures without people. There are houses where people might live, municipal buildings where people work, railroad stations, firehouses, row houses, town halls and greenhouses and apartment houses and stores, but no one is in them or around them. Even main streets, where people must walk sometimes, are uninhabited. Mr. Trager has totally depopulated his imagery.

title: ART VIEW
description: As of April 19 we can all seefor nothing, and whenever we likethe finest collection of British art that ever was formed by a private individual. The collection begins around 1550 and pulls up not long after the death of J. M. W. Turner in 1851. Preindustrial England is its main subject, therefore. It includes paintings, sculptures, watercolors, drawings, prints of all kinds and illustrated books. It is housed in a building by the late Louis Kahn which is of outstanding quality even in a country which has many beautiful modern museumbuildings. Its curatorial staff is young, informed and ideally enthusiastic. It is integrated into one of the world's great teaching institutions, and one which is already very strong in English studies. If you think that British art is a matter of being glared at by fulllength portraits of other people's ancestors, this is the place to undeceive yourself.

title: CHILD POPULATION DROPS IN NEW YORK
description: An accelerating decline in New York State's numbers of younger children has been disclosed in new Federal Census estimates, while the state's prime workingage population has gone up.

title: Tanker to Be Fined for Spill
description: BOSTON, April 9 (UPI)The 570foot tanker Gulf Tiger, which leaked about 8,000 gallons of gasoline and No. 2 oil after running aground in the Cape Cod Canal this week, will be fined an as yet undetermined amount, the Coast Guard said yesterday. Crew members labored last night with highcapacity pumps to empty three port tanks that were damaged in the accident. The ship is owned by the Gulf Oil Company.

title: A Wall St. Merger?
description: Wall Streeters no longer ask whether, but how, the New York and American stock exchanges will merge. Last week, the boards of both exchanges provided many answers.

title: Nina Barbaresi Betrothed to Jonathan Jones
description: Nina Barbaresi, an illustrator, and Jonathan C. Jones, an assistant treasurer at the EuropeanAmerican Bank, both of New York, plan to be married next month.

title: Ousted Police Aide in Boise Sues In Dispute on Alleged Lesbianism
description: BOISE, Idaho, April 9The first of several expected lawsuits has been filed in connection with the dismissal of seven women employees as a result of an investigation involving alleged lesbianism within the Police Department.

title: Marilyn Chanin Fiancee Of Kenneth J. Platzer
description: Marilyn Chanin, a marketing representative with the New York manufacturing office of International Business Machines dataprocessing division, and Kenneth Jeffrey Platzer, a lawyer with Bower & Gardner in New York, will be married next June.

title: New Satellite to Scan Universe For Answers About Its Nature
description: A new type of window will be opened on the universe if all goes well with the launching about April 29 of the largest unmanned satellite yet sent into orbit by the United States.

title: Democratic Voters Showed Increases In Albany Report
description: ALBANY, April 9 (UPI)Tallies by the State Board of Elections show that Democrats made large gains in enrollment last year, although the greatest increase in voter affiliation was among independents.

title: How the Figures Help the G.O.P.
description: THE WIDELY publicized split in he Nassau County Republican Party has given rise to speculation that Nassau, like neighboring Suffolk and Westchester Counties, will eventually go Democratic. This rationale does not take into account the political realities of Nassau's unique governmental structure, which has made possible Republican domination of the county and its three towns for more than 50 years. Every other suburban county in the state elects a representative county legislature from equal population districts of up to 60,000 people. There is no such responsive, representative government body in Nassau, on either town or county level.

title: Industry's Views on the Critical Choices
description: A new national energy policyat least as it relates to automobilesshould have two principal objectives to moderate the rate of growth of energy consumption without denying individual freedom of choice, and to reduce our vulnerability to energy shortages without damaging the environment or imposing unnecessary costs on the public.

title: Albany Panels Give Hearings Schedule
description: The following public hearings will be held in New York City this week by state legislative committees:

title: Nevada Chooses a State Fossil
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., April 9 (UPI)Nevada now has an official state fossilthe ichthyosaur. Gov. Mike O'Callaghan yesterday signed into law a bill giving the title to the prehistoric fish. The remains of an ichthyosaur are in a state park in central Nevada.

title: ShieldsNassau Benefit
description: Bob Hope will be the headline attraction at a May 13 concert sponsored by the ShieldsNassau County Inc., a fraternal association of policemen and policewomen, mostly Nassau County residents. Proceeds from the event at the Nassau County Veterans Memorial Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I., will go toward such projects as a scholarship program for members children. Tickets at $10, $12.50 and $15 can be obtained from the ShieldsNassau County, 170 Old Country Road, Mineola, L.I.

title: Maureen Sullivan Plans To Be Married on July 9
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roger J. Sullivan of Tupper Lake, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maureen Sullivan, to Dr. William J. Kennelly 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kennelly Jr. of Westfield, N.J.

title: Lewisboro Story: Ordeal by Press
description: LEWISBORO is on the map now, in a way that none of us would have chosen. As the whole metropolitan area no doubt knows, two of our neighbors were viciously murdered, apparently during the commission of a robbery in one of their homes. To make the tragedy worse, it is possible, the four small children of the women were present in the house at the time. Thanks to quick work by the New York State Police, two of the suspects in the case were arrested within 24 hours of the crime, and the other suspect was in custody before the week was over.

title: Ruth Gordon I've Come a Long Way for Tonight
description: Anything better than to be honored by your own people?

title: What They Are Saying
description: Joe Lis, Seattle Mariner first baseman, comments on the gray cell big in the Kingdome that makes it difficult to follow fly balls: There' no more saying, I got it! When somebody pops up, it'll be: I think got it.

title: NAY R. BEZIO, AN OFFICIAL OF UNITY RELIGIOUS GROUP
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 9 (AP)May Rowland Bezio, an official of Unity, nondenominational religious organization, died today at her home.

title: Morris County Plans Bikeway
description: CONSTRUCTION of a countywide bikeway system, probably the first of its kind in the nation, is being proposed jointly by the Morris County Planning Board and Park Commission as part of a Master Plan that will be presented to the public on April 21.

title: Indian Ocean, ArmsRace Focal Point
description: DIEGO GARCIAFrom the peaceful coral lagoon facing west across the Indian Ocean and the narrow paved airstrip with three cargo planes sitting idly along the apron that fades off into the coconut palms, it's hard to visualize the intense SovietAmerica air and naval competition that's shaping up with this tiny atoil and its United States base as the focus.

title: Soviet Ship Held By Coast Guard On Fishing Rule
description: BOSTON, April 9The United States Coast Guard seized for the first time tonight a foreign fishing ship for violating the new 200mile fishing zone.

title: Illegal Renters The Open Secret
description: SOME of Westchester's aging and outwardly elegant communities have a dirty little secret. But like an aging and penniless dowager clutching at the remains of her dignity and respectability, these communities attract a certain amount of official sympathy, and the indiscretion is being dealt with mercifully by most.

title: Why Some C.P.A.'s Write Poetry
description: From the Internal Revenue Code as of July 1, 1971 SECTION 1037 (B) (b) Application to Section 1232.

title: Three Persons Slain, One Wounded In a Bank Robbery in Tennessee
description: KODAK, Tenn., April 9 (AP)Two bank employees and a customer were shot to death today and a third employee was critically wounded in a robbery here, the authorities said.

title: Shelby Doggett Plans To Marry in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert K. Doggett of Far Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Shelby Kreh Doggett, to Roger Drew Mellick 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mellick, also of Far Hills.

title: Two Aides in Business at the Capitol
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)Two clerks for the House of Representatives are drawing salaries paid by the taxpayers while running profitable printing businesses on the Capitol grounds, using space and utilities provided at public expense.

title: Alcohol Abuse State's Policy
description: A HOUSEWIFE on a limited budget goes to the liquor department of a supermarket, buys two $9 bottles of Scotch, then goes to the meat department, where she Is arrested for stealing a $12 roast.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, April 11 ROYAL VIKING SEA (Royal Viking Line). Left Portugal March 30; oue 8 A.M. at W. 55th St.

title: Angola Warns of Consequences
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 19 (UPI)Angola warned today that grave consequences could result from foreign military help for Zaire against the invaders whom President Mobutu of Zaire says include Cubans and Ratsians.

title: How to Be a Legitimate Junkie
description: TO the growing ranks of Westchester's scavengers, spring has great meaning. Spring cleaning! New pickin's If you are already part of this social subculture, or thinking about coming out of that particular closet (a Fibber McGee closet if there ever was one) it also means making room in the garage attic or cellar by having a spring cleaning of your own.

title: PILOTS TALK ABOUT AIR CRASHES
description: The KLM pilot taxied his Royal Dutch Airline 747 slowly to the end of the runway, and turned it around. He shoved the throttle levers full forward and the huge jet roared down the runway through dense fog to take off from the Canary Island of Tenerife. But at that exact moment, a Pan American World Airways 747 was rolling slowly down the same runwayin the opposite direction. As the KLM 747 loomed out of the fog, the Pan Am pilot screamed: What's he doing? He'll kill us all! The resulting collision, on March 27, killed more than 570 people. It was the worst accident in civilaviation history.

title: A Fed O.K.
description: Unlike those who lend them money, nations rarely go bankrupt. Instead the poorer countries simply borrow more each year to pay off old debts. And the bankers lend the money so that that can close the books on old loans.

title: Cary Bangser to Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Bangser of Scarsdale, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cary Susan Bangser, to Steven Mark Goldberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burtin Goldberg of Brooklyn.

title: The Pilgrims Hair Turned White
description: ALTHOUGH not yet as well known as he de serves to be, Italo Calvino is one of the world's best living fabulists, a writer in a class with Kobo Abe, Jorge Luis Borges and Gabriel Garcia Marquez. He is most famous for his dazzling, astonishingly intelligent fantasiesThe Nonexistent Knight, The Cloven Viscount, Invisible Cities, The Baron in the Treesbut his mastery is equally evident in what might be called, loosely, his whimsical science fictions on the history of the universeCosmicomics and t zeroand in his moreorless realistic fictions, for instance, The Watcher and Other Stories. In the realistic stories and in The Baron in the Trees, Calvino creates substantial, moving characters and fully elaborated, thoroughly convincing fictional worlds. In all his books, but especially in Invisible Cities, he has moments where the prose turns into pure, firm lyric poetry. In the science fictions he brilliantly translates modern scientific and mathematical theory into fictional emotion; and everywhere his final pursuit is metaphysical. His strange new production, The Castle of Crossed Destinies, uses all these talents, rises directly from the world view he has been developing all these years, yet is like nothing Calvino has done before.

title: Won't Play in S. Africa, Ashe Declares After Visit
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 9The boy's name was Simon, and he was knocking a tennis ball against the wall of one of the tiny brick homes in Soweto, a black ghetto. A mile away, smoke was rising from a burnedout beer hall, a casualty of last year's antigovernment riots that ended with more than 400 blacks dead.

title: Births
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stephen M. Bernstein (nee Linda Hyman), Joyfully announce the birth of their daughter, Lauren Jill, on March 31, 1977. Fcstatic grandparents are Mr. and Mrs. Warren G. Hyman of Manhasset, New York. Proud greatgrandmothers are Mrs. Edith Lewis of Hempstead, N.Y. and Mrs. Dorothy Hyman of Sante Clara, Calif.

title: INTERVIEW
description: AMONG the women and men named last month by President Carter to the National Commission on International Women's Year was Mildred E. Persinger of Dobbs Ferry. The appointment is a nonpaying one, but then Mrs. Persinger has had 20 years of experience as a volunteer in the world of international and United Nationsrelated politics.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: After a great deal of whispering about the photographs of George Platt Lynesespecially about his erotic photographs, which have never, or hardly ever, been seen by the publicsome 60 of his pictures have finally surfaced in a oneman show at the Sonnabend Gallery (420 West Broadway, through April 16). Lynes was known in the 1930's and 40's as a fashion, portrait and dance pnotographer, and examples of all are included in the show, along with a group of seminude mythological scenes, and nudes pure and simple.

title: INTERVIEW
description: NUTMEGGERS,like other New Englanders, tend to regard anything that smacks of too much government with a kind of hostility once reserved for taxation without representation. Consequently.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Prayer to a baleful god O mighty Internal Revenue, who turneth the labor of man to ashes, we thank thee for the multitude of thy forms which thou halt set before us and for the infinite confusion of thy commandments which multiplieth the fortunes of lawyer and accountant alike.

title: Sympathy Versus Artistic Control
description: Whether a playwright is asking us to devote an evening to the desperate plight of the terminally ill (Michael Cristofer's The Shadow Box) or to share his deep concern over the unhappy days and nights of disturbed youngsters (Ernest Joselovitz's Hagar's Children), he's faced with two problems that must be taken care of, quickly. Obviously he must find a means of making a distressing situation dramatic rather than downhill the whole way. Less obviously, though just as importantly, he must hold his personal compassion quite fiercely in check. A dramatist wouldn't tackle materials of this kind if he weren't in some way touched by them. But he's got to be rigorously careful not to feel so sorry for his characters that they're all drowned in his tears before the rest of us can get near them.

title: IN AMERICA
description: PHILADELPHIA, Miss. The headstone marks no grave, stands in no cemetery. II is found instead in the dusty front yard of a small Baptist church, across the tracks in the black part of town. Embedded in the stone are three crudely retouched portraits, corresponding to three names and dates of birth. Only one date of death was necessary, but that dateJune 21, 1904has been repeated three times once each for Andrew Goodman, James Chaney and Michael Schwerner, the young civilrights workers whose murders here marked the beginning of the end of violent white resistance to black rights in Mississippi.

title: DINING OUT
description: LIKE many other human institutions, restaurants have life cycles. Some wither soon after birth, others develop quickly into flamboyant youth and then disappear; still others grow each year, like fine wine, into beautiful maturity.

title: Pact Reached at AllisChalmers
description: MILWAUKEE, April 9 (UPI)  The United Automobile Workers has reached an agreement with the AllisChalmers Corporation on a new national contract, but the strike by some 4,500 production workers in five states will continue until local issues are resolved. The union struck AllisChalmers March 3. The agreement yesterday was on a new threeyear national pact that also must be ratified by workers. The new pact includes about a $2 pay increase and other beenefits.

title: YUGOSLAVS FEAR ADS UNDERMINE IDEOLOGY
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 9This country's leaders are worried that newspaper advertisements and television commercials are infiltrating bourgeois and alien standards into the country, and they mean to halt the trend.

title: Loretta Otte Betrothed
description: William N. Otte of New York and June C. Otte of Port Washington, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Loretta Jean Otte, to James J. Mullin, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Mullin of Port Washington. A September wedding is planned. Miss Otte attended Marymount College in Tarrytown, N.Y., and graduated from Boston College. Her fianc attended the New York Institute of Technology.

title: JetSet Golfers at the Masters Tournament Sweep Into Georgia Aboard Private Planes
description: AUGUSTA, April 9They began roaring in Thursday, sleek twinjet Citations, fierce  looking Lear jets, stately Convairs, trim Falcons and the Cadillac of the airthe patrician Gulfstream.

title: DINING OUT
description: LIKE many other human institutions, restaurants have life cycles. Some wither soon after birth, others develop quickly into flamboyant youth and then disappear; still others grow each year, like fine wine, into beautiful maturity. Emily Shaw's Inn, now well into its fourth decade, shows few signs of its age. Indeed, the restaurant has changed with the times, and some of its present offerings might well surprise those who have not dined there in some time. Though the emphasis still on steaks, chops and other foods in the American tradition, there is now a sprinkling of such Continental items as osso buco, scampi and frog's legs.

title: Pamela Wick Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Arms Wick of Boston and Manchester, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Wick, to Edmond L. Lincoln, son of Mrs. Edmond E. Lincoln of Wilmington, Del. and the late Mr. Lincoln, who was chief economist of E. I. Du Pont de Nemours & Company.

title: Why Not a Homeland or a State for the Palestinian Refugees?
description: BEIRUTWhen President Carter declared last month that there has to be a homeland provided for the Palestinian refugees who have suffered for many, many years he startled both the Israelis and the Palestinians by using a phrase that goes to the heart of the Middle East conflict but has opposite connotations for the two sides.

title: A New Style for a Diocese in Transition
description: WHEN John Raymond McGann was a young priest at St. Anne's parish in Brentwood in the early 1950's, he and his pastor, the late Rev. Thomas I. Conerty, confronted a serious problem. The period was a time or building and growth in Brentwood. During the 50's, the community's population would grow from about 2,800 to more than 15,000. (It has doubled since then.) This furious growth was typical of what was happening elsewhere on the Island, but for the young priest and his superior, who later became a monsignor, the difficulty was to find out who was moving into the parish, how to meet the, newcomers, how to serve them, and how to get them into the church.

title: L.P.G.A. Shifts a Site
description: NOBLESVILLE, Ind., April 9 (AP)The Ladies Professional Golf Association has sanctioned a 54hole tournament to be played here in June at the Harbour Trees Golf Course. The tournament, scheduled for June 1719, will replace the L.P.G.A. tour stop at Lake Monroe in Bloomington, Ind., and will offer $50,000 to the winner.

title: 12,562 in Oakland See A's Win Opener
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 9  With Billy Carter, the President's brother, throwing out the first ball and Charley Finley, the owner, nursing a bad back, the Oakland A's opened their 10th and possibly last season here in perfect weather today.

title: Emily Shaw's Inn
description: Route 137, Pound Ridge, N.Y. (914) 7645779

title: 25 Temperature Snaps 1950 Record for Cold
description: New Yorkers awoke to recordbreaking cold yesterday morning, with the mercury sinking to 25 degrees.

title: For Maria at 16, a Birthday Gift of Hope
description: SAYVILLE MARIA MURPHY of Sayville will soon'be celebrating her 16th birthday, but her parents have not planned the traditional sweet 16 celebration for her. Instead, Dorothy and Thomas Murphy have consented to highly advancea, expenmental brain surgery for their youngest daughter with the hope that it will alleviate her brain damage and enable her to live a more normal life.

title: Jady Cohen Plans To Become Bride Of Peter Robbins
description: Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Cohen of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jody Cohen, to Peter Robbins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Robbins of Armonk, N.Y.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: The state's Division of Fish, Game and Shellfisheries apparently has no representative in Morris County, according to an article on Jan. 24.

title: Watson, Crenshaw Share Masters Lead
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9The third round of the 41st Masters, the aristocrat of golf tournaments, posed today an equivalent of the ancient philosophical question: How many angels can dance on the head of a pin?

title: Peter Quennell to 33
description: THE marble foot of Peter Quennell's title stands on the Via Pie di Marino in Rome. The sole surviving fragment of an ancient colossal statue (Statues are always likely to assume importance in humanistic poetryG. Wilson Knight), it is anomalously planted upon the pavement of a busy modern street, among scraps of vegetable refuse, discarded lottery tickets and the crumpled sheets of old newspapers. By illuminating and then wryly interpreting scores of such memorable visual symbols, Peter Quennell, the British critic and biographer, has fashioned a thoroughly artful and satisfying memoir.

title: Education/ Psychology
description: The old math lasted for centuries, the new math for something more than a decade. Now enter the new new math. A growing number of educators are awakening the realization that while students trained under the new Math that has dominated math education in the United States since the early 1960's may know why two and two equal four, they don't necessarily know that they do equal four.

title: City Council Units Set Hearings for the Week
description: The following public hearings will he held by. New York City Council committees this week:

title: Churches in a Time of Challenge
description: THIS EASTER weekend in Connecticut, more than two million Christianstwo out of every three citizens of the statewill flock to 2,000 houses of worship to proclaim their belief in Christ's resurrection.

title: The Expensive Way to Keep Your Teeth
description: Harry L., a 46yearold Manhattan lawyer, noticed a while ago that his gums bled when he brushed his teeth or bit into something hard, such as an apple. He discussed the problem with his dentist, who assured him that although the gums were inflamed, the problem could be handled by cleaning and scaling. Little did he know he was soon to embark on an often painful treatment program that would ultimately cost more than $1,500 and mean the loss of three teeth in the hope of saving the other 29. To add insult to injury, Harry now knows that it all probably could have been prevented if he had simply learned to clean his teeth in a different, more thorough way when he was a youngster.

title: Genovese Murderer Gets College Degree
description: ALBANY (UPI)  Winston Moseley, convicted of murder in the widely publicized Kitty Genovese case, has received a college degree while in prison with the help of a state tuition grant.

title: Home Style
description: The perfect house. The dream house. Does such an animal exist? Yes, of course. It is a dollhouse.

title: Some Historians Dismiss Report Of Factual Mistakes in Roots
description: A number of American historians did not seem upset when they were told of a report in The Sunday Times of London that there were factual errors in Alex Haley's book Roots. Most said that regardless of errors the historical essence of the book was truthful.

title: GARDENING
description: THE kids know that spring is herethey have been picking dandelions. The old couple harvesting dandelion greens with basket and knife along Old Westbury Road know it as well. So do the young couple buying weed killer for their lawn in the garden center. Each of these reactions reveals a different aspect or reaction to the life of this humble, yet spunky, little plant.

title: SIR ROBERT TREDGOLD
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 9 (Agence FrancePresse)Sir Robert Tredgold, former chief justice of Southern Rhodesia and of the old federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, died yesterday in Marandellas, near here, it was announced today. He was 78 years old.

title: Dance Quintet In U.S. Debut At Riverside
description: The New York Dance Quintet made its American debut at the Theater of Riverside Church on Friday evening with a program of three blandly undemanding dances, two of which were first shown in the Soviet Union. These performances occurred during a tour last year that Greg Reynolds organized for his company under an AmericanSoviet Youth Forum program.

title: The Economic Mess
description: By Tom Wicker The Wholesale Price Index rose 1.1 percent in March, with its important industrial commodities component registering the fourth straight month of increase. Together with some other economic indicators, these rises have caused many legislators, businessmen and economists to conclude that inflation once again is a major threat, and that President Carter's $31 billion stimulus program is therefore the wrong economic medicine.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: We sympathize with Evan Darcy Litty's feelings of frustration as she tries to navigate Westchester in a wheelchair, but simply feeling irritated and wondering why her community doesn't drop curbs will accomplish nothing. We therefore invite her to join the Westchester Easter Seals (Committee to Eliminate Architectural Barriers). This group, which includes both the disabled and ablebodied, is headed by Leo Zamory, engineer and city planner, and has been working for the last seven years to eliminate the blocks that keep the handicapped from joining the mainstream of community life.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The theme of National Coin Week, which starts on April 17, is Coins Are History, so this would seem an appropriate time to take a close look at the two historically interesting old English coins pictured here. Both are groats, a term that was a household word in England a century or two before Columbus. It was a hammered silver coin equivalent to four pence. Groat means great, in contrast to the everyday coin of the time which was a onepenny piece. (In milling grain, cracked fragments of wheat larger than grits are called groats).

title: A Touch of Paris in the Land of the Vikings
description: MINNEAPOLISHere in the land of the Minnesota Vikings and other reminders of a Scandinavian heritage the aggressive Parisbased SofitelJacques Borel hotel chain has successfully established its first American outpost.

title: Nanuet High Captures Honors in Its Relays
description: NANUET, N.Y., April 9Kevin Byrne had no excuses. It was a cold, blustery day in this Rockland County community and the 18yearold Paramus Catholic senior had just been upset on the anchorleg of the twomile relay at the 10th annual Nanuet Relays on the high school's allweather track today.

title: Letters
description: As recent graduates of Sarah Lawrence College, as well as alumnae / i and parents, we are outraged at Anne Roiphe's article (The trouble at Sarah Lawrence, March 20).

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Paul E. Erdman.
description: Thirteen rules of the game of writing a best selling novel called The Crash of 79 if your name is Paul E. Erdman:

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: FOR those who view government as a necessary evil, it may come as something of a surprise to to learn that government is now the third biggest industry in New Jersey. It may be even the biggest, all things considered, dwarfing such commercial enterprises as the state's $2billionayear chemical industry.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Apply fertilizer to lawns, perennials, evergreens, trees, shrubs and roses Do not overzealously rake out all natural mulch under shrubs during cleanup. Plant whatever where ever the ground is dry and workable. Finish cleaning up around perennials.

title: The Games Children Play
description: ERIK H. ERIKSON'S new book is his most readable since Childhood and Society. Toys and Reasons is concerned with the relation of play with reality; with man's ability to conceptualize and the process of creation; with ritualization and with the influence of our inner world of images upon our varying ways of life and our political assumptions. He draws heavily upon J. Huizinga, the Dutch historian who wrote Homo Ludens; upon the ethologists who have studied animal play; and upon psychologists like Jean Piaget and J. S. Bruner, who have devoted themselves to elucidating the early cognitive development of young children.

title: 15YearOld Disciple of Harry Hopman Gets Lessons in Tennis, Independence
description: LARGO, Fla.John Van Nostrand learned to cook for himself this spring, learned to do his own laundry, learned to clean his own apartment. These are not bad lessons for a 15yearold living away from home for the first time.

title: PREVIEW WHAT'S COMING IN FASHION
description: In the fashion business, autumn happens in April. That's whenin Paris, New York and wherever fashion is cooked up  everything new for next fall and winter is being planned and presented. Last week, some 2,000 American store buyers were in Paris for the hiver 7778 pretaporter collections. Starting next week, more than 24,000 of them will stampede New York's Seventh Avenue garment center to choose the clothes you can buy next September. Here's a look at what's going on in the workrooms of some of America's top designers in the throes of finishing up their allimportant fall collections.

title: Miss Lozier Engaged To John C. Chapin Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. William S. Walcott 3d of Middlebury, Conn., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Walcott's daughter, Elizabeth W. Lozier, to John C. Chapin Jr., son of Mr. Chapin of Manchester, Vt., and Mrs. Arthur Smith Jr. of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. The wedding is planned for July 9.

title: They Sing Honest Songs of Love
description: Their music is delicate and subtle, so vulnerable and private that you sometimes want to turn your head away. The two voices intertwine with wonderfully crystalline harmonies, trading the top part back and forth. The instrumental support is homespun and unpredictable: strong, folky piano, gently rocking banjo and fiddle, softly wailing harmonica, sighing accordion.

title: For HenryParks More Than Sausages
description: BALTIMOREEager as he may have been to fill the demand for More Parks Sausages, Mom, Henry G. Parks Jr., City Councilman and civil rights advocate, as well as entrepreneur, went public himself long before his meat products company became H.G. Parks Inc. in 1969.

title: GARDENING
description: P ROBABLY the most famous cherry blossoms in America are those that rim the Tidal Basin around the Jefferson Memorial in Washington. They are visited by thousands of people every spring.

title: Jewish Soul in Westport
description: THERE WILL BEthere's not yet a weekend of Yiddishkeit due out in Westport beginning this Friday.

title: Teaching Old Folks an Old Art
description: IN a letter to a young admirer, William Carlos Williams once had this to sa I hear lines of poetry every day from my patients. They sometimes say what they see and feel in interesting ways. In my car, later in the day, I hear their words. Kenneth Koch has had the same willingness to pay close heed to the lyrical possibilities that many ordinary human beings possess, and even demonstrate rather impressively, given any encouragement at all.

title: Haley Is Hoping to Debate Reporter
description: He was not sweating, but his face and forehead were shiny. For three hours yesterday Alex Haley had been signing his autograph on books, records and even a dollar bill in the basement level of a record store. And afterward, he said, he felt like a wrungout dish rag.

title: City Employees to Forgo Pay
description: PARLIER, Calif., April 9 (UPI)This community southeast of Fresno is facing a financial crisis and its city employees are coming to the rescue. Dan Ayala, the city administrator, said Wednesday that more than half the city's employees had volunteered to give up a month's pay to help prevent the city from having a $26,000 deficit for the fiscal year ending June 30. Mr. Ayala said that he hoped the volunteers would be able to find temporary employment in the month they will not be paid by the city.

title: SHARP RISE REPORTED FOR SERIOUS CRIMES IN ALL FIVE BOROUGHS
description: Every neighborhood in New York City experienced sharp increases in reported crimes last year except for the normally highrisk sections of Harlem and the South Bronx, where the crime index dropped.

title: Victoria Towns Fiancee Of Alan H. Kupferberg
description: Victoria Erin Towns, a staff writer with House Beautiful magazine, plans to be married June 19 to Alan Harris Kupferberg, a student at Brooklyn Law School.

title: Miss Okamoto Leads by
description: TOKYO, April 9 (AP)Ayako Okamoto of Japan shot a fouroverpar 78 in heavy rain today and widened her lead to two strokes after the second round of the 54hole, $53,000 World women's golf tournament. Miss Okamoto had a tworound total of 149 on the 6,490yard, Yomiuri Country Club course. Jan Blaclock of the United States, the defender, carded a 13overpar 87 and shared 11th place with six Japanese pros at 161.

title: A Hale at Large In a Fat Farm
description: It is 6:37 A.M. and a brilliant sun is just beginning to burn its way through the early morning haze that drifts around the mountains and through the valleys outside Tecate, Mexico. That I can appreciate this glorious sight at all is something of a surprise, since I am in the process of painfully panting, grunting, coughing and wheezing my way up the side of one of those mountains.

title: EDITH KANE BAKER, ACTIVE IN CHARITIES
description: Edith Kane Baker, for more than 30 years a board member of the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, and widow of the late George F. Baker, New York financier, died Friday at Community Hospital, Glen Cove, L. I. She was 93 years old and lived in Locust Valley.

title: Notes: Travel Clubs At Savings Banks
description: For a decade or more a number of financial institutions in the United States have been offering their depositors membership in various types of travel clubs, often to the chagrin of travel agents, who charge that the institutions compete with them unfairly.

title: Kissinger Columbia Post Fought
description: Columbia University officials, who began negotiations with Dr. Henry A. Kissinger five months ago about a teaching post for the former Secretary of State, are meeting growing opposition to the proposed appointment from students and faculty members.

title: Best Sellers
description: Best Sellers

title: Women Athletes: Legacy of Infinite Possibilities
description: A series of eight intimate profiles of women athletes by a sportswriter, Pat Jordan's new book, Broken Patterns, is a rare glimpse into the lives of women whose successes as well as hardships usually eo ignored.

title: INTERVIEW
description: Ar the age of 68, Dr. Allyn P. Robinson thinks it's about time that I took a little less pressure.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Inflation continued to be the major market concern last week as stock prices closed lower in slow trading.

title: New York A.C. Wins Title At A.A.U. T4'restlin4 Meet
description: AMES, Iowa, April 9 (AP)Bill Rosado, Stan Dziedic and Ben Peterson, all former Olympians, captured titles tonight, and the New York Athletic Club repeated as the team champion in the Amateur Athletic Union's national freestyle wrestling championships.

title: Despite Losses, City Officials Hope To Keep Corporations in New York
description: Last Easter Sunday morning, in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Bishop Paul Moore of New York, accused corporations leaving New York City of betrayal and compared them to rats leaving the sinking ship.

title: N.Y. Budgets May Feature Retrenchment Permanently
description: People in public life have a tendency to announce a decisive turning point at every jog and wiggle in the course of public affairs. The detection of real turning points best left to historians armed with hindsight.

title: Burglary, to the Victim, Is a Kind of Rape of the Home
description: When New Yorkers go apartment hunting nowadays, security is sure to be high on their list of priorities.

title: Denise J. Di Chiara Fiancee Of Thomas Vincent Grieco
description: Denise Joan Di Chiara and Thomas Vincent Grieco plan to be married in August. Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Di Chiara of Greenvale, L.I., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas V. Grieco of New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: TV VIEW
description: Defenders of the TV news documentary are slipping further into confusion and despair. In a business geared to audience ratings and maximum profits, the traditional documentary has become an object of tough questioning. Faced with rising production costs, poor audience ratings, new technologies and increasing divisions within its own ranks, the form has reached a point where perhaps only significant change can assure its survival. The wellmade structures of the pastthe CBS Reports and NBC White Paper essays, drenched in facts and cosmic frignificanceare, by themselves, no longer enough. In most cases, their impact does not justify the time and effort spent in production. They probably won't, and shouldn't, disappear entirely, but they are likely to become a minor part of the news and documentary schedule. Even in Britain, news producers are currently phasing out the hourlong documentary. One observes: They're just too damned expensive, and most of the customers prefer light entertainment anyway.

title: G.E. Ducks Out on a Debate
description: General Electric shareholders will vote soon on a resolution to end G.E.'s South African operations until that nation ends its policy of apartheid. But before the vote is taken, the New York State Council of Churches had hoped to hold a debate on the proposal between a representative of the coalition of church groups that sponsored the resolution and a spokesman for G.E.'s management.

title: DINING OUT
description: PALISADIUM DRIVE is not going to help you very much. It is really a driveway cutting off Palisade Avenue, the Collins Avenue of Bergen County. Palisade Avenue is the site of all those soaring highrise apartment houses that went up along the rim of the Palisades in the 1960's, to the consternation of the conservationsts who wanted to preserve the skyline for people who lived on Riverside Drive.

title: Strudels, Step by Step
description: MAKING strudel is more craft than cooking. As Rosalie Steinetz prepared to instruct a class in working, stretching, filling and rolling strudel dough, she explained that it was her husband's mother's recipe. Her motherinlaw, who is Czech, showed her how to do it and Mrs. Steinetz has in turn taught her daughter. Now the fascinating and exacting technique of producing the flaky, tissuelayered pastry can be learned at Mrs. Steinetz's shop, Kitchen Time, in Plainview. The craft will be kept alive in many Long Island kitchens.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN a door's bell or chime fails to ring each time the button on the outside is pushed, the first thing the homeowner should suspect is a faulty push button. On most houses, this butboth wires and touch them together. If the bell or chime now works, you know that the button is defective. To correct the problem, buy a new button and install it in place of the old one.

title: Built With Their Own Hands
description: w E HAVE a very active parish here, said the Rev. James M. Connolly, pastor of Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Hartsdale, as he led a visitor down the steps from the upper sacristy, where he and five other people in the parish had labored for more than a year to create a new cross for the church. I wanted them to share in the making of the major artifact. They were very enthusiastic.

title: Are Students Employees?
description: ARE students employees under the law? No, says the United States Labor Department, because the legal definition of employee makes exception for students employed by educational Institutions. As a result, students are employed at rates below the minimum wage of $2.30 an hour.

title: Town on Reunion Is Evacuated
description: SAINTDENIS, Reunion, April 9 (UPI) Authorities ordered the evacuation today of another town on this Frenchowned island in the Indian Ocean because it was threatened by lava from La Fournaise volcano. Several hundred persons fled to safety from Piton SaintRose, the third community to be evacuated since La Fournaise erupted earlier this week. About 800 persons were evacuated earlier from the two other villages, officials said.

title: An Insolent Abundance
description: ST. TROPEZ, FranceThe population problem is not exactly new. In the fifth century B.C. Euripides, in his great play Orestes, explained the Trojan War accordingly: The beauty of Helen was a pretext for the gods to send the Greeks against the Phrygians and to kill many men so as to purge the earth of an insolent abundance of people.

title: New York State Is Celebrating Its 200th Birthday, but You Would Hardly Know It
description: ALBANYOne of the bestkept secrets of the year, in this normally gossipy capital city is that New York State is cele brating its 200th birthday.

title: McCarter Gets a Ford Grant
description: THE McCarter Theater Company in Princeton, one of New Jersey's foremost playhouses and among the leading nonprofit regional theaters in the country, has received a Ford Foundation challenge grant of $85,548 for the purpose of establishing a cash reserve fund.

title: California Experts Say New Wells May Slash Expected Drought Loss
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 9Crops in California, the nation's leading foodproducing state, may not be in such bad shape from the drought after all.

title: Trudy Bennett Plans Wedding Next Fall With Cooper Stuart
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Edgar Bennett of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Trudy Bennett, to Cooper Stuart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Spencer R. Stuart of Darien, Conn. A wedding next fall is planned.

title: 4 Libraries Plan Computer Link
description: An Innovative and potentially controversial plan to link their libraries through centralcomputer cataloguing and coordinated purchasing is expected to be announced shortly by four colleges in the Greenwich Village area. They are New York University, Cooper Union, the New School for Social Research and its affiliate, the Parsons School of Design.

title: Reporter's Notebook
description: PARISPutting aside for the moment the question of the clothes themselves, American retailers agreed that the fall readytowear openings were the most wearisome they had ever attended. The shows were long and crowded, admission to them was difficult, even with the proper credentials. But what made them physically debilitating was the fact that they were scattered all over town. Getting around any big city swiftly is not easy; Paris is often impossible.

title: Design
description: When Mr. and Mrs. Volney Righter started planning a new house in suburhan New York they knew they wanted it to have a look that Mrs. Righter calls classic modern.

title: BRUCE GRANT, 83, NEWSMAN AND AUTHOR OF 50 BOOKS
description: CHICAGO, April 9 (UPI)Bruce Grant, a former newspaperman who wrote more than 50 novels, informative volumes and historical books, died yesterday of what the police said was a selfinflicted gunshot wound. He was 83 years old.

title: The Nation
description: Wholesale prices in March rose 1.1 percent and while economists are not sure if the increase, the third substantial raise this year, is a signal of a serious acceleration in the rate of inflation, many think that there may now be justifiable cause for concern.

title: Billiards Title to Ceulemans
description: TOKYO, April 9 (AP)  Raymond Ceulemans of Belgium, the defender, scored his 10th victory against no defeats today and captured his 14th World threecushion billiard championship. The 40yearold Ceulemans clinched the title by beating Yoshio Hoshihara of Japan, 6049, in 49 innings in the 10th round.

title: Realty News
description: The Meredith Corporal ion, which publishes Better Homes and Gardens and other magazines and books, has leased 32,000 square feet of office space at 750 Third Avenue for 15 years at an aggregate rent of more than $3 million.

title: Ecumenism: Just Lip Service?
description: DESPITE decades of effort and substantial progress in reducing tensions between religious groups, serious barriers and significant differences still plague interfaith understanding among New Jersey's Roman Catholics, Protestants and Jews. This is the conclusion of a recent study of the attitudes of New Jersey's clergy. The state's religious leaders agree almost unanimously that they have gained new appreciation from other religious traditions, but they show little evidence of actually acting upon this interfaith understanding. They also contend that the laity is much less knowledgeable and sympathetic to other religious faiths than the clergy.

title: Ch. Chuca Gives fitters First Lakeland Success
description: Ch. Terra Copper Chuca has taken off tm the circuits like a Texas tornado and is sweeping almost everything in her bath. The 15pound red Lakeland terrier funneled through Texas last month with three bests and five groups. in seven snows, won an other Raisin on the California circuit April 1 and today has descended on a Sunflower show in Wichita, Kan. The word Chuca in Argentina stands for the name of the topwinning side of a foursided game played by the gauchos or cowboys, explained Mrs. Robert Jordan of Malibu, Calif., the wife of the Lakeland's handler. Bred by Carlos and Nydia de la Sota of Northern California and Argentina, Chuca is owned by Dr. Richard Etter, a Houston allergist, and his wife, Elizabeth.

title: A Hike to the Source Of the Hudson River
description: For all those millions of us who live along its banks,. the Hudson is a Presence, not considered or perhaps even seen for weeks at a time, but therehuge, gleaming, flowingwhen we do look.

title: Spring a Welcome. Relief For Horse Show World
description: The wretched winter weather in the metropolitan area hurt the equestrian set where it hurts the mostin the pocketbook. Yet to some of the officials of the horse shows, the weather was not the main culprit. Rather, the villain was the weatnerman, At the moment, the coaches and exhibitors are looking ahead to the spring season after a winter of mild discontent. The threeday Boulder Brook show in Scarsdale, N. Y., ends today. The show opens the springsummer season in the New YorkNew JerseyConnecticut area.

title: New Life for a Parish
description: AT THE turn of the century, St. John's parish in Newark numbered more than 1,000 families, had its own parochial school and maintained a business school for the children of immigrants. Today, the schools are long gone and there are but two families left in the parish.

title: CHESS
description: One way to get caught with egg on your face is to make a positional sacrifice of a pawn and then find there is no propitious moment to recover the lost material, while your opponentnot in the least fazed by the supposed difficultiesblithely develops a decisive attack against your king. That is what befell the Swedish grandmaster Ulf Andersson in his firstround game against the West German grandmaster Ludek Pachman in the Geneva International Tournament in the Hotel la Mditerrane.

title: D'Acquisto Out 21 Days
description: PITTSBURGH, April 9 (AP)John D'Acquisto, St. Louis Cardinal pitcher, strained a leg muscle running in pregame sprints today and will be placed on the 21day disabled list.

title: TOO HOT HANDLE
description: We are, said Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, launching a unique operation here today which I regard with pride as a symbol of imagination and foresight. The day was June.

title: NEW YORK SCHOOLS FRET MOST ON TESTS
description: The anxiety over standardized reading tests that has reached such high proportions in New York is apparently not felt to the same degree by many other bigcity school systems, which view the Jests more casually.

title: Meditation: Is It Based on Need?
description: ON Feb. 16, by a vote of 62 to 5, the New Jersey Assembly passed a bill introduced by Thomas Deverin, Democrat of Carteret, that requires:

title: ART
description: MUCH has been written about the formal qualities of the art of Milton Avery, whose paintings and drawings are on view at the Summit Art Center, and much of the writing has brought us closer to a stronger understanding of his work. But the writings through energetic, sometimes excessive, analyses of Avery's pictorial structurehave also diminished the fresh experience of the art and our reaction to its particular magical beauty.

title: April 20 Florida Launching Set For European Scientific Satellite
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)A scientific satellite developed by 10 European nations will be launched April 20 from Cape Canaveral, Fla., by a United States rocket, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said yesterday.

title: For the Knicks, the End of an Era
description: They started together and they are leaving together.

title: DeDe Beasley Plans Nuptials
description: The engagement of Mary Bedelia Beasley to Robert Hunter Frierson Armistead has been announced by Catherine Farris Beasley and John Coode Beasley of Natchez, Miss., parents of the bridetobe.

title: CHILDREN'S ROOKS
description: THE BIG CHEESE

title: Courtier Poet in the Classroom
description: IHAVE MODELS of good manners that I get from Shelley, said William Meredith, a poet who teaches in the English department of Connecticut College.

title: Peyser to Shift to Democratic Party
description: Charging that the Republican leadership in Westchester County had knuckled under to the manipulations of the Conservative Party, former Representative Peter A. Peyser yesterday confirmed reports that he would soon switch his affiliation to the Democratic Party.

title: Soviet Sees Carter Administration In Awkward Position on Arms Issue
description: MOSCOW, April 9 (Reuters)A Soviet commentator, Georgi Ratiani of the newspaper Pravda, said today that the Carter Administration had been placed in an awkward position following last week's abortive talks on a new strategic arms agreement.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: State Acts To Shift Family Doctors
description: AMEASURE designed to Increase the number of family physicians in New Jersey is expected to receive final legislative approval later this month.

title: Leaderless Israel
description: One of the glories of Israel is that despite all peril, its people strain for normality. No matter how menaced their borders, how tense their diplomacy, how strained their economy, the Israelis persist at indulging democracy, vanity, partisan fratricide and petty peculationall the passions of the comfortable and secure. But that exhausts the admiration that can be mustered for Prime Minister Rabin's recent management of the affairs of his state, party and household. He has betrayed the trust of his people and of millions of Americans for whom the health of Israel is a matter of deep concern.

title: I Would Love to Create Earthquakes Onstage
description: When the Louis Falco Dance Company was last seen at Alice Tully Hall, Mr. Falco and his thenpartner, Jennifer Muller, were nibbling away at each other in a pessimistic Falco work called Storeroom before deciding that cannibalism was no answer to mankind's problems. That was three years ago.

title: Title Bridge Event Begins in McAfee
description: DURING the coming week, some 900 bridge players, nearly all of them black, will gather at the Playboy Resort and Country Club in McAfee to compete in the Spring National Championships of the American Bridge Association.

title: New One Design Offers YachtRacing Alternative
description: In a further effort to develop an alternative to grand prix yacht racing, the New York Yacht Club has announced the formation of a second One Design Class called the New York 40. The first One Design, the New York 48. was approved last fall and marked the first N.Y.Y.C. class since the famed New York 32's sailed Long Island Sound 40 years ago.

title: Pollutants Pose Problems for Plants
description: In the area stretching northeast from Richmond, Va., including parts of Maryland, Delaware and Pennsylvania, across New Jersey, New York, Connecticut and up to Boston, episodes of air pollution injury to vegetation have become increasingly evident. This should not be surprising in view of the high population, the omnipresent motor vehicles, the conglomeration of industries, refineries and powergenerating plants that are concentrated in this area. They are either the direct source of many pollutants, or they supply the precursors that are converted into air pollutants.

title: TeacherStrike Mess
description: WE THINK we are reasonable people, don't we? And most of us would probably agree that our school situation is in a mess when we have two teachers strikes within one school year. Then let us ask ourselves, Who is responsible for this mess?

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East Orange'Kennedy's Children. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. 53.9055.50; students and the elderly, 52.5053.90; group rates. (201) 6751881.

title: Valedictory: A Sharing of Moments
description: Standing at micicourt in Madison Square Garden, two fists raised, I realized on May 8, 1970 that we, the New York Knicks, had won the championship. I existed apart from the 20,000 people who roared their approval.

title: Letters: Selecting That Airplane Seat
description: To the Editor David C. Berliner in his article on the varied needs of airline travelers, How to Choose the Seat That's Right for You (Travel Section, March 27), has in my opinion omitted one important factor in selecting a seat. It has to do with whether one is lefthanded or righthanded.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A fire termed suspicious by the local police heavily damaged an unoccupied 30room mansion known as Halsey's Castle in the village of Irvington in Westchester County. The mansion and 37acre tract on which it was built were given to the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Irvington about a year ago by Mrs. Benjamin Halsey. A local developer had introduced a controversial plan to build condominium and singlefamily housing on the land, but a request for a zoning variance was rejected. There were no injuries reported in the blaze.

title: Old Rail Depots Manifest New Destinies
description: Down at the little depot, all is frenzied activity. Sunlight falls through Gothic artglass windows upon the thronged waitingroom benches. Luggage dollies are heavyladen. The storage room is up to its skyblue eaves in cartons.

title: The Houses of History
description: PROSPECT HALL in Jersey City is vacant land today. Frenchman's Place in Newark was demolished years ago. Cincinnati Hall in Freehold was mostly destroyed by fire  no one knows its site today. Lake Villa in Bordentown is nothing but ruins.

title: Mr. Simon Returns to Wall Street
description: Former Treasury Secretary William E. Simon came home to Wall Street last week. It wasn't to the same house he left in 1973 to join the Nixon Administration, but it was a house where his name was first placed on the door.

title: Kozlov Sets WeightLift Mark
description: MOSCOW, April 9 (AP)Alexander Kozlov snatched 374 pounds at the Russian federation weightlifting championships today, the Soviet agency Tass reported. This broke the world record of 369 pounds for the upto220pound weight class set by another Russian, Sergei Arakelov.

title: Potent Drug Focus of Nurses Trial
description: DETROIT. April 9It looks innocent enough: a colorless medication in a tiny glass vial. But Pavulon is the paralyzing drug in the spotlight at the trial here of two Filipino nurses charged with using it to poison nine patients, two of them fatally, at the Ann Arbor, Mich., Veterans Hospital. Testimony here this week has centered on some of the drug's little known and frightening aspects.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Budget Cuts and Water
description: Conservationists who worked long and dilgiently to help secure last year's New York State legislation which provided for enlightened management, through water releases, of the rivers that supply New York City apparently feel that the program stands a good chance of being eviscerated.

title: Syrian Leader to Visit Soviet
description: MOSCOW, April 9 (UPI)President Hafez alAssad of Syria will visit Moscow later this month, the Soviet daily Pravda announced today. The visit, following this week's visit by the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, was viewed by Western diplomats as Soviet preparation for Geneva, talks with the United States in May.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BETHELRobert Andrew Parker, watercolors. monoprints and constructions. Bethel Gallery, 186 Greenwood Ave. 7436644. Until April 27, 11 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Wednesdays through Sundays.

title: A French Howard Johnson
description: Sofitel's acceptance in this country may result in part from America's flocking to Europe In the last 15 years on lowcost group flights. There Jacques Bore), a 49yearold gogo businessman of deceptively mild appearance, is the largest restaurateur with more than 900 fastrood restaurants. He has been called a French Howard Johnson in a land that prefers to be known from its haute cuisine.

title: PALESTINIANS POISED FOR LEBANON ATTACK
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 9Palestinian forces were reported poised today to attack Merj Uyun, one of the largest Christianheld military towns in south Lebanon; Lebanese rightwing Christian leaders in Beirut sought Syrian intervention to restrain the guerrillas.

title: Rome's Hospitals Beset by Crowding and Hardships
description: ROME, April 9 The head physician at one of Rome's major hospitals said the other day that he had 500 beds and 550 patients.

title: Mary Ann Alford Sets Aug. 13 Bridal
description: Mary Ann Alford and Thomas Wells White, students at the Columbia Law School, plan to be married Aug. 13 in Vienna, Va.

title: Liv Ullmann's Love Affair With Eugene O'Neill
description: Wearing a faded lavender dress, a drab jacket and a hat with frayed, drooping plumes, and clutching a scuffed cardboard suitcase, she edges into JohnnythePriest's New York waterfront saloon, sizes up the place and then says to the bartender in a coarse, urgent voice, Gimme a whisky  ginger ale on the side. And dont be stingy, baby.

title: Dr. Arthur C. Ingerman Marries Rosalie Hoffman
description: Rosalie Hoffman, assistant chairman of the social studies department of Brooklyn Technical High School, was married yesterday evening to Dr. Arthur C. Ingerman, a dentist in New York. Rabbi Edward Klein of the Stephen Wise Synagogue performed the ceremony at the New York home of the bridegroom's uncle and aunt, Dr. and Mrs. Irving I. Crown.

title: Whitey and Mickey
description: When Billy Martin was the Yankees second baseman, he and six teammates took their wives to the Copacabana to celebrate his 29th birthday. An altercation with a delicatessen owner from the Bronx caused a brouhaha that got in the papers and led to a grand jury inquiry. Martin's employers decided he.

title: Wise Synagogue Marks 70th Year
description: A member of the congregation once described the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue as one of God's settlement houses. Its founder and first rabbi, the late Stephen Wise, defined it as a place where worship was translated into collective and organized human service.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN a door's bell or chime fails to ring each time the button on the outside is pushed, the first thing the homeowner should suspect is a faulty push button. On most houses, this button is exposed to the weather, and so dampness eventually causes contacts to corrode; sometimes, it even causes connections to loosen or break off.

title: CRIME
description: The classic British mystery novel lives and flourishes, as witness STEP IN THE DARK by Elizabeth Lemarchand (Walker, $6.95) and THE AFFAIR OF THE BLOODSTAINED EGG COSY by James Anderson (McKay, $6.95). Both books are prefaced by a list of characters and a map of the house in which the crime is committed. Both take their time establishing character and backgrounds before the dirty work begins.

title: An Outbreak of Measles Is Reported in Nassau County
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 9The Nassau County Health Department said this week that there had been a significant increase in cases of measles and rubella in the county since January, and warned that a potential danger of an epidemic exists unless precautions are taken.

title: Sadat Returns to Cairo
description: CAIRO, April 9 (UPI)President Anwar elSadat arrived home today from a 10day tour of Europe and the United States. He met with President Carter in Washington on ways of promoting ArabIsraeli peace negotiations and also visited West Germany and France.

title: Emily Shaw's Inn
description: Route 137, Pound Ridge, N.Y. (914) 7645779

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SEATTLE, April 9 (AP)Paul Givens, a lefthanded pitcher selected first by the Seattle Mariners in the winter freeagent draft, has been assigned by the American League team to Fort Lauderdale of the Class A Florida State League.

title: Torre's Hit Breaks Tie After Murcer's Homer
description: CHICAGO, April 9Still battling themselves, their owners and everybody else in sight, the New York Mets wasted a 60 lead today before rallying with two runs in the ninth inning for their second straight victory of the new season over the Chicago Cubs.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: I should like to answer the recent oomments by Ina Bradley about the American Shakespeare Theater which appeared in your Connecticut section on Feb. 17.

title: Carter's First 80 Days
description: WASHINGTON, April 9In these 80 days from Inauguration through Easter, President. Carter has irritated big business, big labor and the Russians. This probably helps explain why, having acquired such prominent and popular enemies, his personal and political standing with the American people has increased so much in less than three months. Nobody seems to be going for him but the people.

title: Events Today
