description: SPRING BULB DISPLAY: Tullos, hyac'nths, azaleas, ???ps and other flowers In bloom; 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue.

title: PERES IS UNOPPOSED AS ALLON BOWS OUT
description: JERUSALEM, April 9Defense Minister Shimon Peres was virtually assured of the Labor Party's nomination for Prime Minister of Israel today when Foreign Minister Yigal Allon said that he would not seek to replace Prime Minister YitZhalc Rabin, who resigned as a candidate two days ago.

title: News Summary
description: Defense Minister Shimon Peres of Israel was virtually assured of the Labor Party's nomination for Prime Minister when Foreign Minister Ylgal Allon announced, that he would not seek the nomination. Each was considered a potential successor to Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, who withdrew his candidacy Thursday. The party's Central Committee will meet today to select its nominee. [Page 1, Column 3.]

title: Hyrn Sets Meet Record In State Archery Event
description: The New York indoor archery championships have been held in Angola, N. Y., in conjunction with the junior Olympic archery development tournament. The state record for men was broken by David Hyrn of West Seneca, who turned in scores of 568 and 569 for a total of 1,137.

title: U.S. STUDY QUESTIONS PACIFIC BASE'S VALUE
description: WASHINGTON, April 9A Senate staff study released today questions the value of keeping Clark Air Base in the Philippinesa mainstay of American air power in the Pacificunless the United States intends to maintain the ability to launch further Vietnamlike military operations on the Southeast Asian mainland.

title: City Opera Revives a Double Bill
description: The New York City Opera's double bill of Stravinsky's Oedipus Rex and Orff's Carmina Burana, which returned to the repertory for the first time in four years Friday night, makes a logical pairing. Stravinsky's operaoratorio of 1927 is an archetype of the epic drama that was popular 50 years agoan art form in which grand, violent passions are frozen into neoClassical immobility.

title: Track Writers to Begin Spring Season Tomorrow
description: The Track Writers Association will open its spring season of weekly luncheon meetings at noon tomorrow at Mamma Leone's, 239 West 48th Street.

title: Some Points of Roots Questioned; Haley Stands By Book as a Symbol
description: The Sunday Times of London asserts today that the factual basis of Roots, Alex Haley's acclaimed book about his ancestors journey from freedom in Africa to slavery in America, was more tenuous than anyone had thought.

title: A Higgledy Piggledy Life
description: LOUIS TERKEL, known as Studs, is of course the great listener, folk historian, troubadour, lover of life, goodhumor man and maker of mischief he is also, and not incidentally, citizen Chicago, disk jockey, actor, activist and author (Division Street, Hard Times, Working). In the course of what he modestly calls a higgledypiggledy uneventful life, he has managed to enchant thousands of peoople into telling him who they are.

title: 33 Deaths Reported In Pakistani Rioting At Assembly's Start
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, April 9 (Reuters)Riots erupted today in the populous and politically volatile Punjab Province, and dozens of people were reported dead as protests continued against Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto's Government.

title: Mirror, Mirror on the Wall
description: BOSS TWEED knew what he was saying when he remarked I don't care who does the electing, as long as I do the nominating. In Connecticut, the tremendous power involved in nominating public officials Is much appreciated by the politicians who exercise it, but too little understood by the public, which is excluded from it. The politicians know that the power to nominate brings with it not only the usual personal pleasures of power, but also a substantial measure of control over the public official once he is elected.

title: COMPLAINTS ON CARE HELD POORLY HEEDED
description: New York State's system of dealing with complaints by nursinghome residents was sharply criticized yesterday by the American Jewish Congress and Community Action and Resources for the Elderly.

title: Seville's Somber Holy Week Mixed With Revelry
description: SEVILLE, Spain, April 9The song floats down from the thirdstory balcony and silences a thousand people pressing against each other in the darkened street. Oh, dear Virgin, when I see your smiling face

title: County Government: A Yes Vote
description: IN NEW JERSEY, county government is very much alive and kicking. In an age when people want government to be accessible and yet able to cope with problems that cross municipal boundaries, the 21 counties in New Jersey are a natural bridge between the 567 municipalities and the state. For the most part, counties are logical geographic units. Unlike legislative districts, county boundaries do not change constantly. If counties did not exist in this diverse state, they would have to be invented.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: REPRESENTATIVE Joseph G. Minish has a tiger by the tail. Again. It just may be that this time he can succeed in throwing the ornery critter back into the jungle.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: AN islanda quiet beach, blue sky, sea water, the sound of gulls, awesome sunsets, and in the hazy distance the magnificent skyline of a wondrous and powerful city. A fantasy? There are about 100 families living right in the middle of this fantasy. It's called East Island.

title: Young CoLeaders Unfazed by Nicklaus
description: AUGUSTA Ga., April 9In other years, the younger pros on the golf tour always played and sounded as if they were looking over their shoulders if they were leading a major tournamentlooking over their shoulders at Jack Nicklaus lurking behind.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ONE of the two major uncertainties that have been overhanging the financial markets all year may be dissolved in the coming week when President Carter unveils his promised antiInflation program. There is the chance, of course. that it might not produce that effect at all if contains some big surprises or includes elements that disturb labor, business and the markets.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox Patchwork Diplomacy
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Article 5  No Title
description: 3 WOMENSissy Spacek gets set to swill down a stein of beer as Shelley Duvall,

title: American Dream Of an Aussie City
description: The Australian capital of Canberra suffers from a bad press. This planned city of 200.000, between Sydney and Melbourne, has won such Aussie epithets as a sheep station overrun with people and a cemetery with lights. It is to Australian sophisticates what Philadelphia is to New Yorkers. Yet last year more than 1.3 million tourists visitea Lanoerra (meeting place in aboriginal), and not a few of them were American. Appropriate, since Canberra is the fulfillment of an American dream.

title: Kenneth Koch: I Like Writing
description: UNLIKE some writers, Kenneth Koch has always enjoyed writing. We talked in his spacious Claremont Avenue apartment, a minute's walk away from Columbia College, where Koch (pronounced coke) has taught for the last 15 years. He remembered that as a child he kept a little orange book named the Scribblein Book, which he filled with drawings and poems. It's natural to like writing, Koch said, just as it's natural to like drawing or singing, unless of course someone Interferes with the process. He admits to a lack of sympathy for a gloomy attitude about writing that I've found in writers whose work I don't much like. I always think there's something just perhaps a little insincere, or at least that I don't understand, in a person's spending the best part of his life doing something that causes him pain.

title: The World's Most Exclusive Hotel
description: WASHINGTON, April 9  The world's most exclusive hotel is far from opulent.

title: Speedboat Pilot Killed
description: STUART, Ha., April 9 (AP)A Jensen Beach speedboat pilot was killed last night when his boat flipped in the Okeechobee Waterway, officials said. Ransom Tilton Jr. was announced dead on arrival at Martin Memorial Hospital. Witnesses say Tilton, the brother of Ren Tilton, a race car driver, was practicing for an uncoming regatta when his hydroplane flipped over. The Florida Marine Patrol is investigating the accident.

title: Miss Lovell Takes First In 40Mile Bicycle Race
description: HAMILTON, Ontario, April 9 (AP)Jocelyn Lovell, a Canadian Olympic cydlist from Toronto outsprinted five riders at the finish today and won the 27th annual Good Friday road race.

title: Ellen Cohalan Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Conway Cohalan of Loch Arbour, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Teresa Cohalan, to Michael Thomas Foley, son of Mrs. Clifford J. Foley of Atlanta and the late Mr. Foley. Miss Cohalan is a granddaughter of the late Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan of New York.

title: GUGGENHEIM PRIZES ARE AWARDED TO 313
description: Fellowships Totaling $4.6 Million Given to Scholars, Scientists and Artists in, Competition

title: Cyclists Head for the Roads
description: WITH the opening of the Bike Sunday season a week away, bicycle riders are in full bloom in Westchester from slow pedalers on oversize tricycles to lean, 10speed tourers who think nothing of 30 miles of hard riding in a few hours.

title: Condemned Pigeons of Siena Are Given a New Lease on Life
description: SIENA, Italy, April 9 (UPI)An avalanche of protest letters has persuaded Mayor Canzio Vannini to commute the death penalty he pronounced on 4,000 pigeons.

title: For Rent: An Office, A Staff, an Image
description: When Michael Downs left his job with an advertising agency recently to start up a new magazine for women, he and his partner had hundreds of major decisions to make, not the least of which being where they should set up an office.

title: Albert G. Moore Jr. Weds Denise Caffrey, Lawyer
description: Denise Caffrey and Albert G. Moore Jr. were married yesterday at the United Church in Chapel Hill, N. C., by the Rev. Phillip S. Washburn.

title: For Turkophiles
description: WHEN Lord Kinross died last year, aged 71, he left a great many friends and admirers in the Middle East as well as in Britainand especially in Turkey. There, his biography of Kemal Ataturk was regarded as a masterly and sympathetic presentation of Turkey's greatest modern hero. The affection for Kinross was all the warmer, in that gifted interpreters of Turkish culture and civilization are comparauveiy rare in the West; they tend to be elbowed aside by their natural rivals, the more fervent and numerous philhellenes and Arabophiles. So it was altogether fitting that Kinross should leave for publication this splendid legacy: a onevolume history, in over 620 pages, of the Ottoman Empire.

title: Frank E. Linde, Builder, Fiance of Amy S. Chatsky
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Chatsky of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Sue Chatsky, to Frank E. Linde, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Linde of Newtonville. Mass.

title: Mr. Keenan Talks About. His Office, PostNadjari
description: In his first nine months as New York State special anticorruption prosecutor, John F. Keenan has cleaned up old investigations and brought indictments against more than two dozen individuals, including three judges and a top police official. His style contrasts with that of his predecessor, Maurice H. Nadjari, who was a frequent center of controversy. Mr. Nadjari's methods were often condemned, and his most important indictments were dismissed. In an implied attach on his predecessor, Mr. Keenan says these dismissals are an important way of judging the office's performance. In an interview with Tom Goldstein, who writes on legal affairs for The New York Times, he said he had nothing against some of Mr. Nadjari's more controversial techniques, but he suggested ways to curb overzealous prosecutors.

title: A Plea for Tax Equity
description: PICK YOURSELF UP by your bootstraps, suburban communities tell the cities. You created your own problems, suburbanites tell us, through mismanagement and fiscal irresponsibility. Don't expect us to bail out the cities.

title: Sardinero Debut in Met Boheme
description: Marcello in La Boheme may not exactly be an attentiongetter, but by the same token it is a role in which a singer can rarely go wrong. Vicente Sardinero made his Metropolitan Opera debut in the part Friday night and he was, not surprisingly, wholly in command of all situations.

title: Spain Ends Communist Ban
description: The Spanish Government legalized the Communist Party after a ban of four decades, the chief of staff of the Interior Ministry said in Madrid. Page 3.

title: Special Surgery to Gain
description: Supporters of the Hospital for Special Surgery have arranged a theater party at the Metropolitan Opera for April 25, when Mikkail Baryshnikov will perform in two of the three ballets on the program, including Pillar of Fire. Tickets at $125, $100 and $75 are available from Mary Ryan at the hospital at 5355500, extension 320.

title: Hope Schieffelin Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Schleffelin 3d of Mount Kisco, N. Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Hope Williams Schieffelin, to Jon Dale Dooley of Hobart, Okla., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wendall Earl Dooley of Childress, Tex. A June wedding is planned.

title: Catherine Josi Is Bride of Dr. Arthur Langer
description: Catherine Chilcott Josi, an epidemiologist with the Mount Sinai School of Medicine's department of community medicine, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Arthur Mark Langer of Hartsdale, N. Y., a widower and an associate professor of minerology and a senior investigator in the environmentalsciences laboratory at Mount Sinai. The Rev. Albert Ahlstrom, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

title: Federal Job Training, a Project Nearly Impossible to Evaluate
description: Although a significant part of President Carter's plan for stimulating the economy, now under consideration in Congress, calls for continuing Federal job training programs, there is surprisingly little evidence that such programs have been effective in the past. For that reason there are many in Congress and elsewhere who urge that less be spent on training people for future jobs and that more be spent on putting the unemployed to work immediately.

title: United Press International
description: BARGE BURNS IN PHILADELPHIA: Fireboats pouring water into an oil barge that exploded yesterday at a Gulf Oil Company refinery on the Schuylkill. Two persons were believed injured in the sixalarm blaze, that was brought under control beefore it could spread to a nearby empty tanker that was filled with ignitable fumes. The barge burned down to the water line.

title: Spain Legalizes Communist Party, Ending Long Ban
description: MADRID, April 9The Spanish Government tonight legalized the Communist Party, which the late Generalissimo Francisco Franco for four decades had castigated as the nation's supreme enemy.

title: Jonathan Livingston Shimoda
description: THERE was a Messiah once who was born Indiana and earned his living by barnstorming in an old Travel Air 4000 biplane. He pretty much limited his ministry to Middle Western middle America and worked such miracles as never having to refuel his plane, bringing bugs back to life and effortlessly repairing holes in the 4000's fabric. His name was nonald Shimoda and he got tired of the.

title: Editors Choice
description: A BOOK OF COMMON PRAYER, by Joan Didion. (Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) Empty woman's search and chilling descent into madness,

title: The Korean Probes Are Still Very Much Alive
description: WASHINGTONOn the day it was learned that Tongsun Park had fled the United States for England, there was, some cynics said, a sigh of relief on Capitol Hill that could be heard 30 miles away in the Baltimore suburbs. The Justice Department seemed to have lost the critical potential witness in its Korean influencebuying inquiry, and with him the possibility of obtaining indictments of members of Congress for bribery, extortion, tax exasion, mail fraud, conspiracy and other violations.

title: BELL ORGANIZING REVIEW OF ENFORCEMENT AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI)Attorney General Griffin B. Bell is setting up a committee to review the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, spokesman said today.

title: Princeton Oarsmen Sweep Seven Races
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 10The Princeton heavyweight rowing team defeated Rutgers for the fourth consecutive year today on Lake Carnegie today, pulling away with 700 meters to go to win by a length. Victories also were fashioned by Princeton crews in two other heavyweight races and four lightweight events, completing a sweep.

title: Right Turns on Red Lights: Many in New York and New Jersey Finding System
description: WHITE PLAINSA young man made a right turn through a red light recently in the Westchester County town of Greenburgh and suddenly found himself being waved over to the curb by a police officer. But instead of getting a ticket he received a compliment.

title: Blumenthal on Jobs, Inflation, Cities
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  The tape recorders were whirring, the food waft plentiful and the topics ranged from energy to the stock market. The occasion was a twohour luncheon interview last week with reporters and editors of The New York Times and W. Michael Blumenthal, Secretary of the Treasury.

title: In Honor of Fighting Frank Farley
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 10Just a few months ago, few people thought that former State Senator Frank S. Farley would survive complications from a heart attack he suffered 18 years ago.

description: WASHINGTONFormer Louisiana Congressman Otto Passman is one of the prime suspects in the investigation into illegal payoffs by the Korean C.I.A. to members of the Houseof Representatives.

description: We are sometimes taken to task by readers who admonish us that the indicated yield on various recipes is often low. To wit, this letter from a reader in DeWitt, N.Y., about a veal recipe:

title: INTERIM COUNSEL NAMED TO ASSASSINATION PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Alvin B. Lewis Jr., a 43yearold lawyer on the staff.. of the House Select Committee on As sassinations, was appointed today to a 30day term as interim chief counsel and staff director while the committee seeks a replacement for Richard A. Sprague, the chief counsel who resigned two weeks ago.

title: Closing Arguments Today in Boston Racial Assault
description: BOSTON, April 10Closing arguments will be heard tomorrow in the trial of three young black men charged with pullmg a white man from his car and beating him at the height of racial conflict here last April.

title: Life for N.B.A. Referees: A Lonely Band on the Run
description: They are never the home team.

title: Mobster on Furlough From Prison Is Slain
description: BRIDGEWATER, N. J., April 10 (AP) A reputed underworld lieutenant, !reed from prison on a 26hour courtordered Easter furlough, was shot and killed at a motel here early this morning.

title: Commodities
description: Now that timely rains of the last two weeks have washed away fears of drought east of the Rockies, farmers are looking less at the sky and more intensely at market prices for spring crops.

title: CARTER WILL SUBMIT MODEST PLANTO SLOW WAGE AND PRICE RISES
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  The Carter Administration plans to publish in a few days an antiinflation program with modest goals for gradually slowing the rate of price and wage increases that will play down visible Government intervention in wage and price decisions. No grandstanding, one official said in describing the program. We're going

title: CONTRACTS DISPARITY FOR NORTHEAST CITED
description: WASHINGTON, April 10New Jersey, New York, Connecticut and other industrial states of the Northeast and the Middle West have been deprived of military contracts amounting to hundreds of million of dollars in a violation of Federal policy, according to an independent analysis.

title: COURT WILL RESUME DEPROGRAMMING CASE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 10When the legal custody fight between the Unification Church and the parents of five young adults is resumed here tomorrow, the murky question of coercive persuasion may be added to the issue of religious freedom.

title: Quinlan Family Still Keeps Vigil After Two Years
description: ROXBURY TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 10The mail still arrives each day from across the country and abroad, and the daily hospital visits continue, but for the famlly of Karen Anne Quinlan, life has become more settled.

title: Brazil Dismisses Mayor Who Told Of City Problems
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 10The Mayor of Salvador, Jorge Hage, has been removed from his post partly because of an interview he gave to The New York runes recounting the urban problems he faced as political leader of Brazil's fifth largest city.

title: TruthinLabeling Laws Affecting Farmers and Nurserymen in State
description: HAMMONTON, April 10New Jersey's farmers and lawn nursery owners are becoming more involved in consumer protection as a result of increased Aressure by the state's Department of Agriculture for care in processing and packaging.

title: Watson Takes Masters Golf by 2 Shots on 276 With Nicklaus
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10Tom Watson got that monkey off his back. today, and he won the 41st Masters golf tournament by two strokes.

title: Welfare Reform Again
description: The Aid for Dependent Children rolls have moved up to more than 3.5 million families. Swollen budgets at the state and local levels are thus provoking demands for welfare reform, and President Carter is convening task forces to put the matter before the Congress again. But this period of debate is just as likely as earlier ones to avoid the underlying problem: Persisting unemployment, the main cause of high welfare case loads.

title: Suns Rout Nets, 128104; New York's 611th Loss
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., April 10 (AP)Ron Lee, with 21 points, led the Phoenix Suns to a 128104 rout of the New York Nets tonight as the National. Basketball Association season ended.

title: Referees Strike N.B.A But Substitutes Step In
description: Twentyfour of the 26 referees in the National Basketball Association carried out their strike threat yesterday, the last day of the regular season. All eight games were played as scheduled, staffed by Eastern League referees and by those the N.B.A. considered hiring when it discussed the possibility of expanding to three referees a game, instead of the current two.

title: For the Baron of Rikers Island, Empire Means City Behind Bars
description: Remember all those old prison movies in which James Cagney played a convict of such improbable force of personality that the whole institution, revolved around him? If Cagney had ever played the warden instead of the convict, you'd have some idea of the nature of Francis R. Buono, supervising warden of Rikers Island.

title: Music: Davies
description: Dennis Russell Davies is bestknown as a conductor these daysof the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra and the New and Newer Music series here, among others. But Saturday night at the Kitchen, Mr. Davies appeared as a solo pianist. His program was a challenging one, full of interest. But it wasn't entirely successful, which was partly the fault of the music and even more of Mr. Davies.

title: Born Captures Second Tourney in a Row
description: MONTE CARLO, April 10 (AP)Bjorn Borg won the $120,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tennis tournament today, beating Italy's Corrado Barazzutti, 63, 75, 60, in the final.

title: MAYNE SEGUINE MASON, ELECTRICAL ENGINEER, 86
description: Mayne Seguine Mason, electrical engineer and retired vice president and secretary of the board of Giaphite Metallizing Corporation of Yonkers, died Saturday at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 86 years old.

title: Courts to Use Computers in 78
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI)Criminal courts in 58 cities will use computers by the end of next year to control trial schedules, spot repeat offenders and even warn of likely bail jumpers, the Institute for Law and Social Research said today. The socalled Prosecution Management Information Systems already are being used in 12 jurisdictions. It will be added in nine more cities by December, the institute said, and 58 are expected to have the system installed by the end of 1978.

title: Pilot in Fatal Crash Is Identified
description: READING, Pa., April 10 (AP)Investigators late today identified the pilot of a small plane that collided in the air with a commuter jet and killed four people near here. He was Robert Pollock, 56 years old, of Abbottstown, N. Y., they said. The investigators said they still did not know what had caused the collision,

title: Home Runs Set Back Yankees, 21, and Mets, 52
description: And the Yankee season is only three games old.

title: Jack Augenblick, 80, Chairman Of 2 Refrigeration Companies
description: Jack Augenblick, chairman of the Hudson Refrigerating Cdmpany in Jersey City and the Atlantic Refrigerating Company in Newark, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital in Newark of which he was an honorary vice president and past director and finance committee chairman. He was 80 years old and lived in East Orange, N.J.

title: Bridge:
description: Two of the most popular women players on the tournament trail are Ida Bennett of New York and Ethel Keohane of Wellesley, Mass. They form a tough partnership, and consistently get good results in all types of events and at every level. Mrs. Keohane, indeed, owns more master points than any other player, man or women, in New England.

title: Pravda Says U.S. Arms Makers. And Jackson Sabotaged Parley
description: MOSCOW, April 10 (UPI)The Soviet Union charged today that the Pentagon and American arms manufacturers, with the aid of Senator Henry M. Jackson had sabbtaged the talks on limitation of strategic arms.

title: Suburban Child Abuse: Its Subtle Forms Hinder Identification
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 10David C. Honings took his young son to a Westchester County . hospital recently for treatment of a broken finger. It was set properly, but the father noticed an omission: Nobody asked how it happened.

title: Varied Songs by Bobby Cole
description: Most of those who nowadays practice the art that was once known as saloon singingsingers such as Hugh Shannon, Bobby Short, Ronny. Whyte or Blossom Dearie, who play their own piano accompanimentshave developed specialized repertories built around obscure old tunes, unheralded new songs or, as in the case of Miss Dearie, original material. Bobby Cole, who sings and plays at Soave, :33 East 60th Street, also mixes the old and the new, but most of it is relatively recognizable and the only thing likely to surprise a listener about his material is the way he does it.

title: N.H.L. Ouarterfinals Have Familiar Look
description: The four dramas of last year's quarterfinal series in the National Hockey League return to local playhouses tonight as the Philadelphia Flyers renew their bloody feud with the Toronto Maple Leafs, the New York Islanders once again face the Buffalo Sabres, the Boston Bruins play host to the Los Angeles Kings, and the Montreal Canadiens, who last season swept Chicago in four games, again face the weak Smythe Division winner, this time the St. Louis Blues.

title: Topics
description: A middleaged theatergoer and his teenaged daughter were heading home the other night when they spotted a man bent over, clutching his stomach, at the bottom of a flight of subway stairs in Times Square. As the couple descended, they saw a white travel bag slung over the man's shoulder. Coming closer, they noticed it held a wallet containing several bills, conspicuously displayed.

title: Bradley, Holzman Exit Laughing As Knicks Crush Pistons, 144126
description: DETROIT, April 10The Knicks ended their season today with a 144126 victory over the Detroit Pistons. And Bill Bradley ended his career, having made the first and last shots he took during his 10 seasons in the National Basketball Association.

title: Price of a PrimeTime TV Minute May Cost $125,000 Next Autumn
description: The cost of a television commercial broadcast during prime time next fall will reach and sometimes exceed $125,000 a minute, according to network and advertising agency officials.

title: 5,000 SPANISH POLICEMEN FOIL BASQUE RALLY PLAN
description: VITORIA, Spain, April 10 (Reuters)Some 5,000 riot policemen fought running street battles with Basques marking their national holiday in this northern Spanish town today, but heavy snow and the exi ceptional security measures thwarted a plan to stage, a huge nationalist rally.

title: PERES IS NOMINATED TO HEAD LABOR SLATE
description: JERUSALEM, April 10Shimon Peres, Israel's Defense Minister, was nominated today by the country's governing Labor Party as its candidate for Prime Minister in the general election May 17.

title: Nixon, on'72 Trip, Promised Chinese To Normalize Ties
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Carter Administration officials report that former President Richard M. Nixon told Chinese leaders in 1972 that he strongly desired to normalize relations with Peking and intended to do so in his second term if I he was reelected that November.

title: Caldwell Production of Ariadne Returns to City Opera Repertory
description: Sarah Caldwell's inventive production of Ariadne auf Naxos returned to the City Opera repertory Saturday night, a conception of the delicious StraussHofmannstha! conceit that is always fascinating in its visual details, even if many of them are maddeningly at odds with the specifics of the opera. When the production was rew several years ago the cast seemed markedly uncomfortable if not downright confused by it all, but Saturday's performance, rehearsed by Richard Getke, was a smooth and confident ensemble effort.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture printed with the patents column in Saturday's Times, identified as Arthur D. Hall 3d, actually showed Representative Bruce F. Caputo, Republican of New York. Mr. Hall's picture appears on page 42,

title: Red Smith
description: Now that Bowie Kuhn has appointed himself supreme arbiter of all player transactions, with the wisdom to foretell which deals will be good for baseball and which bad. the question is whether he would sanction a trade that would separate Dave Kinsman from the Mets.

title: Business Leaders Offer Proposals To Improve Sanitation Department
description: In a municipal government noted for its bureaucratic bottlenecks, New York City's Department of Sanitation has frequently been Cited by critics for being particularly resistant to good management.

title: Alert Is Declared in Capital of Laos As Tension Mounts With Thailand
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 10The Laotian Government declared a state of alert in the capital tonight as tension mounted with neighboring Thailand. According to unofficial sources, however, Government leaders believe that the situation is not yet serious and that if no incidents take place between the two countries in the next few days, the emergency measures will be lifted.

title: Dean of the Law School at Hofstra Resigns in Dispute on Salary Raise
description: Charging breach of salary agreement and partisan politics, Monroe H. Freedman has resigned as dean of the Hofstra University Law School in Hempstead, L.I.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FUN AND BIDS Tonight, from 5:30 to 9 o'clock, the promenade of the New York State Theater will be the scene of a festive auctionentertainment, as star singers mingle with and perform for public guests, who can also acquire picturesque opera memorabilia. The gala event, presented by the New York City Opera Guild, celebrates the City Opera, spotlighting the 21 productions staged by Frank Corsaro. the director's wellknown, witty caricatures of nnera folk will also be up for bidding.

title: An Island Chief Talks of Old Ways and Moon Trips
description: ENEWETAK, Marshall IslandsVisits with Pacific islanders always seem to make a deep impression on the socalled modern mind.

title: Getting Serious at the Gas Pump
description: Americans burn gasoline like there is no tomorrow and at current rates they may be right. A third of all oil consumed in the United States each year365 gallons for each man, woman and childis used in cars. To meet this demand last year, we used more than $20 billion worth of imported oil. To keep meeting it, we will have to increase our fragile dependence on foreign oiland continue to deplete domestic reserves. Small wonder that Federal energy policymakers, concerned with conservation, are staring hard at the automobile.

title: Maloney, Umpire, in Hospital
description: DETROIT, April 10 (AP)George Maloney, an American League umpire, was listed in stable condition in a Detroit hospital today after suffering chest pains during yesterday's Kansas CityDetroit baseball game. Maloney experienced a rapid and irregular heartbeat, according to the Tigers team physician and is in the coronary care unit.

title: U.S. Resettles 75 on Pacific Atoll Evacuated for Bomb Tests in 40's
description: ENEWETAK, Marshall Islands  The people of Enewetak were shipped away 30 years ago, made homeless by American fiat so that nuclear weapons could be tested on their atoll in the Western Pacific.

title: Hua's Hair Style Latest Sign Of China's Political Troubles
description: HONG KONG, April 10Hua Kuofeng, the chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, has changed his hair style, letting his crew cut grow longer and combing his hair back from his forehead in a fashion that bears an uncanny resemblance to the late Mao Tsetung.

title: Colbert Beats Mosley (Junior); Stopped Mosley (Senior) in 75
description: MIAMI BEACH, April 10 (AP)Mike Colbert, an undefeated middleweight, won a split decision today in the semifinals of the United States boxing championships by defeating the son of a man he knocked out two years ago.

title: Books of The Times
description: It was five days after Christmas 1973, in an apartment two blocks away from the Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago. Outside, the wind off the lake was knocking people down. Inside, a motley mixture of malcontentsjournalists, of course, who complain more than baseball playershad finished a late breakfast and an inordinate amount of a compound of Curacao and lemon juice. We were arguing about whether A. J. Liebling had been everything he was cracked up to be. Then Studs Terkel, who had brought along a bottle of brandy for the ride, began to talk.

title: Fallibility of Statistics on Crime Is Illustrated in a Queens Precinct
description: Fannie Cohen, whitehaired and sprightly, sitting with other elderly people in the lobby of the Sanford Hotel, in the Flushing section of Queens, was amazed by the question.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 (AP)Handicapped demonstrators won several concessions from Government officials yesterday as their occupation of the regional office of the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare passed its fifth day.

title: LAWSUITS MULTIPLY IN Gilt ENGINE CASE
description: DETROIT, April 10Despite its arguments that it has not misled or cheated its customers, the General Motors Corporation is being hit by a series of legal actions over the discovery that it has allowed engines made by various G. M. divisions to be installed in cars bearing the brand names of other divisions without the knowledge of the buyer.

title: Critics Say Curbs Formation of'Trucking Concerns
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Over the last four years, a small number of the nation's truck companies have paid more than $80 million for Federal licenses that, in theory at least, they could have obtained for less than $150,000 in license fees.

title: Quinlan Family Still Keeps Vigil After Two Years
description: ROXBURY TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 10The mail still arrives each day from across the country and abroad, and the daily hospital visits continue, but for the family of Karen Anne Quinlan, life has become more settled.

title: BeltTightening on the London Run
description: While Congress talks of deregulating domestic airlines, the White House is fending off demands for still greater regulation of international air travel. The British are no longer satisfied with the basic agreement that governs air service between Britain and the United States, and they wish to reduce the number of flights and raise the fares. They want compassion to bring them what they have lost in competition. If they succeed, other countries, notably Japan and Italy, will seek the same.

title: Around the Nation
description: TORONTO, April 10 (UPI)  Dwight Alan Armstrong, wanted in the United States for the fatal bombing in 1970 at the University of Wisconsin, was arrested in his Toronto apartment and faces extradition later this week, the police said today.

Some time this spring the Supreme Court is expected to decide the legality of a complex and controversial plan by the du Ponts of Delaware to dissolve a familyowned company called Christiana Securities. Its principal asset is a 28 percent controlling interest in the nation's largest chemical enterprise, E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company.

title: Amphetamine Curb Backed

Farley Jr., head of the Rhode Island Medical Society's committee on drug abuse, said today. The Utah State Medical Association is the only other statewide group to formally oppose amphetamines, in the treatment of obesity, Dr. Farley said.

description: John G. Hutchinson, professor of management at Columbia University's Graduate School of Business, died Friday at his home, apparently of a heart attack. He was 48 years old and lived a 19 Sycamore Street, Bronxville. N.Y.

title: Ramsey Clark Assails.Death Penalty
description: ATLANTA, April 10Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, speaking to a crowd of more than 3,000 opponents of the death penalty yesterday, called on lovers of life from all over the United States to reject capital punishment because death as a problem solver is unacceptable to a humane people.

title: Police Say Libyan Office in Egypt Is Set on Fire by Demonstrators
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, April 10 (Reuters)Police sources said today that demonstrators set fire to a Libyan Government office here in apparent retaliation for the seizure of an Egyptian office building in Benghazi.

title: Altman's '3 Women' a Moving Film; Shelley Duvall in Memorable Role
description: Millie Lammoreaux is a joke. Her conversation is a confusion of clichs, brand names and affectations. "I'm famous for my dinner parties," she might say, or, "This is my parking space. It's the best one," as if today's Cosmopolitan Girls were graded on their parking spaces as well as on their grooming. Millie is nothing if not perfectly groomed, though when she hops into her car to go cruising for men she never quite succeeds in pulling all of her skirt inside. A bit always hangs out the door, like a distress pennant.Millie Lammoreaux is the central figure in Robert Altman's funny, moving new film, "3 Women," and, as played as well as largely created by Shelley Duvall, she's one of the most memorable characterizations Mr. Altman has ever given us. Miss Duvall's large, round dark eyes are windows through which a tiny creature inside looks out upon a world whose complete disinterest Millie Lammoreaux refuses to accept.Mr. Altman says that "3 Women," which he wrote, directed and produced, had its origins in a dream he had in which he saw two young women in a desert setting. Ordinarily, I'm not sure that we should ever know too much about the particular inspiration for any work of fiction. Such knowledge has a way of sidetracking us from the work itself, or of prompting us to read into it things that are no longer there.It's apropriate in this case, though, since "3 Women" is still a dreamMr. Altman'sand, like a dream, it is most mysterious and allusive when it appears to be most precise and direct, when its images are of the recognizable world unretouched (as happens in the film from time to time) by camera filters or lab technicians.It's been a moviemaker's convention for a long time to smear Vaseline around the edges of an image, or to blur it in some other way, to indicate a dream, even though an image of blinding clarity more accurately reflects the condensed nature of the dream experience, when, for example, without the slightest hesitation, we may accept one person as being two different people at the same time. Logic is beside the point in dreams.Because "3 Women" is a dream, one must know what happens before one attempts to find out what it's about. What happens, briefly, is this:Millie Lammoreaux, a physical therapist in a Palm Springs spa for old folks with fat incomes, finds herself the adored object of another young therapist who calls herself Pinky Rose (Sissy Spacek). Pinky seems to have no past of her own, not even a Social Security number. At first, it seems that Pinky might be retarded but then it's apparent she's simply a blank, possessing nothing but her worshipful appreciation of Millie.Millie accepts Pinky's praise and affection as if she'd always been a prom queen instead of the figure of ridicule she really is, both at work and at the Purple Sage Apartments, the singles complex where she lives and that Pinky comes to share with her. Pinky doesn't notice the snubs given to Millie. She doesn't envy Millie. Because she loves Millie  idolizes her  she comes to be her, to take over her life being both herself and Millie.The third woman in the composition is a reclusive painter named Willie Hart (Janice Rule), the wife of a philandering, middle-aged, ex-stunt man (Robert Fortier) and the owner, with her husband, of the seedy desert recreation area where Millie likes to hang out and look for men.In the course of the film, in sequences that sometimes seem absolutely natural and at other times absurdist, these three women merge into one person, who is mother, daughter and granddaughter, isolated but serenely self-sufficient.Now, I suppose, someone is bound to ask what it really is about. I'm not sure, but there are a number of possibilities. Since it is the moviemaker's dream more than that of the characters within, it seems to be a consideration of today's women. It's not a narrative in any strict sense but a contemplation of three stages of a woman's life by a man who appreciates women and may not be without a bit of guilt. It's also about youth and age and (as are all Altman films) about the quality of American life. Let it go at that and don't worry too much.Having no easily discernible surface logic, "3 Women" must depend on internal logic, and this only falters when Mr. Altman loads his dream with more or less conventional dreams within, when we are given superimposed images, standard nightmare visions and images seen through water. This fanciness is unnecessary. "3 Women" is most strange and poetic when it's played straight, as when poor Millie one night comes upon an elderly couple making love, or when someone says cheerily of a character in a deep coma, "I'm sure she'll wake up when she sees you."Logic has nothing to do with films' effeciveness, though it does with all of the performances, beginning with Miss Duvall's. In this film Miss Spacek adds a new dimension of eeriness to the waif she played so effectively in "Carrie." Also noteworthy are Miss Rule, Mr. Fortier and veteran actor-director John Cromwell and his real-life wife, Ruth Nelson, who play Pinky's possible parents."3 Women," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some nudity and one scene of discreetly photographed sexual intercourse.

title: People of Moscow Respond to Call of Easter Bells
description: MOSCOW, April 10Anticipation hung in the clear midnight air. Well over 1,000 Moscovites, many of them young, strained against the steel harriers that had been erected to keep them away from St. NicholasattheWeavers Church on Komsomolsky Prospekt.

title: Leonard Silk; Defining InflationNo Easier Than Controlling
description: Historians of the 1920's have amused their readers with Calvin Coolidge's classic explanation of unemployment. When more and more people are thrown out of work, the President said, unemployment results. In the 1970's, a eonfused nation is searching for an equally clear but less tautological explanation of inflation. The old dictum that inflation caused by too much money chasing too few goods no longer seems to apply. The money supply has been growing moderately. During the threemonth period from November to February, M1 (demand deposits and currency in circulation) grew at an annual rate of 4.9 percent.

title: As to Meaning of Words
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  From Shakespeare in The Merchant of Venice to Agatha Christie in A Witness for the Prosecution, playwrights of all shapes and sizes have recognized the value of a courtroom drama. The law court is indeed a species of dramasometimes tragedy, sometimes farce and usually predictable. Even the advocates, and sometimes the judge, to say nothing of assorted witnesses, have some of the qualities of actors. They preen, attitudinize, strutall in an attempt to catch the attention of that alltoocaotive audience, the jury.

title: A Tale Twice Told

One is an argument of abstract ideas: our political system and theirs, national interests, internal affairs. The other is personal and concrete: about bodies and minds, suffering and death.

title: Acting Is an 18 Year Detour for Luckinbill
description: Brian in Michael Cristofer's The Shadow Box is a whirlwind. As played by Laurence Luckinbill, he is man desperately trying to make up for lost time. Dying, Brian comes alive writing as incessantly as he speaks, philosophizing, functioningall of his fierce hyperactivity masking his own helplessness. In the role that playgoers can see him in at the Morosco, Mr. Luckinbill gives a remarkably gallant and touching portrait of a man bravely grasping for survival.

title: Robert Munoz: From Bankruptcy to Multimillion Drug Project to Figure in Investigations
description: At the age of 35, Robert Munoz walked away from a bankrupt bar with $4,000 in debts and started looking for a new career. Fifteen years later, he had mastered the new career so well that he was directing a corporation fighting drug abuse in the South Bronx with a $3.2 million annual budget.

But he said that there was no role for him to play in a party where dissension and hostility were growing.

description: ARCADIA, Calif., April 10 (UPI)Blocked most of the way, Properantes closed with a rush on the outside and captured the $150,000 San Juan Capistrano Handicap today. It was the closing feature of the Santa Anita meeting.

title: Connors Bows To Nastase in $100,000 Duel
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 10Through three and a half hours of oftenbrilliant but inconsistent tennis, Tile Nastase ended Jimmy Connors's unbeaten streak at the Caesars Palace Sports Pavilion and took the $100,000 winnertakeall final match of the World Championship Tennis Challenge Cup series which began in December. The scores were 36, 76, 64, 75.

title: LOUIS BERG
description: Louis Berg, a freelance writer and former movie editor of This Week magazine, died Friday at his home, 333 West 86th Street. He was 77 years old.

title: KnoxPhipps Duo Triumphs
description: AIKEN, S.C., April 10  Northrup Knox of Buffalo and Dennis M. Phipps of New York defeated Peter. Clement and William Shettle of Philadelphia, 63, 65, 64, today in the final of the United States amateur court tennis doubles championship at the Aiken Tennis club.

title: Sponsors of Bill to Curb Lobbies Are Encouraged by Ethics Votes
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Encouraged by the willingness of the new Congress to impose a strict code of ethics on its members, backers of a tough new bill to regulate lobbying believe that they have the best opportunity yet to get enacted this year.

title: TAXEXEMPT ISSUES DISPLAY STRENGTH; STATE SALE IS CALM
description: The taxexempt securities market last week handled $3.6 billion of New York State notes yielding 4 percent or less. The big financing was done with a minimum of fuss, in marked contrast to last year's patchedtogether $4 billion sale of 7 percent notes. The taxexempt market also handled $700 million of state and city bonds that carried the lowest interest rates offered to investors since early January, and yet most of the bonds sold quickly.

title: Gunman Kills 3 Yemenis, Including Former Premier, Outside a Hotel in London
description: LONDON, April 10 (Reuters)A former Prime Minister of Yemen, his wife and a Yemeni diplomat were shot dead by an assassin outside a luxury hotel here today.

title: Miss Stoll Wins Easter Bowl Tennis, 62,60
description: She's so hard to play, and it's damn frustrating.

title: Journey, a Smooth Rock Quartet
description: Journey, a rock quartet that headlined a triple bill at the Palladium on Saturday, came together when Neal Schon and Gregg Rolie, a guitarist and keyboard player from Santana, joined with Ross Vallory, a bass player who had worked with Steve Miller, and Aynsley Dunbar, a British drummer transplanted to Los Angeles, who had played with Jeff Beck, John Maya11, Frank Zappa, David Bowie and many others. Their first album came out two years ago, and although they haven't yet broken out into massive commercial success, they have won a steadily growing following.

title: 2 SCHOOL JOBS HELD BY SOME CUSTODIANS
description: The New York City Board of Education's continuing investigation into improprieties and deficiencies in the school custodialoperation has found that 86 psi todians held Parttime jobs as helpers to other custodians in addition to their culltime jobs.

description: JERUSALEM, April 10  A few months ago, in the heat of a political battle to become the Labor Party's nominee for Prime Minister, Shimon Peres portrayed himself as the new face. needed to reinvigorate the party and to inaugurate cnange at a time when Labor's fortunes were ebbing.

title: Nixon, on 72 Trip, Promised Chinese To Normalize Ties
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Carter Administration officials report that former; President Richard M. Nixon told Chinese leaders in 1972 that he strongly desired to normalize relations with Peking and intended to do so in his second term if he was reelected that November.

title: Consumer Liberation
description: This is the era of liberation. I hope we will soon add to the growing list of liberation movements one to liberate consumers from their selfappointed protectors in and out of government.

title: Padres
description: Pitching against the imposing Cincinnati Reds, Bob Shirley could have been forgiven, on Easter Sunday, for laying an egg. I'd have been glad to pitch one inning, said the San Diego Padres rocade. Instead, he went 8 2/3, allowed fo:.r hits and struck out 11 as the Padres won, 124.

He is a longtime friend of Andrew Young, the former Georgia Representative who is now United States delegate to the United Nations. And he is a decorated veteran of the military with a continuing commitment to amnesty.

title: Lester Ratcliff Marries Marcia Diane Goldstein
description: Marcia Diane Goldstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer D. Goldstein of Merrick, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Lester B. Ratcliff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Ratcliff of Middletown, Pa.

description: ATLANTA, April 10There is something of the fantastic about hotair ballooning, like wandering into the Sunday daydreams of Jules .Verne.

description: GENEVA, April 6Bent Larsen of Denmark, Roman Dzindzikashvili of Israel and Ulf Andersson of Sweden topped the field after nine rounds of the Geneva International Tournament here in the Hotel la Mediterrande. In this closefought, lowscoring event, each has five points.

title: U.S. HUNTING PLANES BEARING MARIJUANA
description: EL PASO, Tex., April 8His helicopters are bulletriddled, rebuilt Vietnam war models. His radar was scrounged from World War II surplus junkyards, His electronic sensors are leftovers from the Ho Chi Mirth Trail. And his pilots are barely able to coax 170 miles an hour out of their fastest airplanes.

description: To those who wonder at the exasperation of the democratic world with the racial policies of South Africa, and to those who insist that the desegregation of a few sports teams and cafeterias can postpone that nation'nation bloody day of reckoning, we commend a quiet but powerful dispatch from Johannesburg by The Times'Times John Burns.

description: HOLLYWOODRide it in Sensurround, the advertisements will say: 'Rollercoaster, a film to ride SENSURROUND.

title: Nursing Home Acts to Bar Fund Attachment by Union
description: A Bronx nursing homeowner has asked a Federal Court to block a labor union from attaching Medicaid payments to the nursing home and using them to pay off the home'home debts to the union.

title: Dave Anderson
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11  In the hours after Tom Watson put on a green coat as the Masters champion, he was reflecting on his answer last Friday when, sharing the 36hole lead, he was asked which golfer he feared the most over the final two rounds. Myself, he had said. I think everybody out her feels that way, he was saying now. In golf, you do everything yourself. That'That what makes it the greatest game titan. And that'that what makes golfers the sports millionaires that nobody resents. If they win

title: Mabel Gray, 87
description: Mabel Wiley Gray, the director of admissions at Centenary College for Women in Hackettstown, N.J., from 1935 until 1965, died Sunday in Hackettstown Community Hospital. She was 87 years old and lived in Hackettstown.

title: U.S. Calls Situation Serious
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (Reuters)France'France decision to provide transport planes to help contain an incursion in Zaire shows how serious that situation has become, the State Department said today.

title: Drat1111

Rodney Adams of Passaic, and Miss Louise Adams of Clifton. Service at I the Burroughs & Kohn Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Ave., Summit, N.J. on Wednesday, April 13, at 11 A.M. In, lieu of flowers contributions in his I memory to the Class of 1926, Prince1 ton University, Princeton, N.J. would be appreciated.

title: Jays Win 3d and Defy Those Expansion Blues
description: It'It still a little early in the season, but the major league record for expansionteam futility set by the 1962 Mets seems safe from the Toronto Blue Jays. The Jays won yesterday for the third time in four games, defeating the Detroit Tigers, 53, and seemed to be pointing toward the California Angels record for expansion success.

title: Leafs Beat Flyers, 3 to 2, In Opener at the Spectrum
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 11  The matchup that last playoff season brought violence, bloodshed and criminal charges resumed quietly tonight but with a surprise as the elusive Toronto Maple Leafs slipped out of the Philadelphia Spectrum with a 3.2 victory over the Flyers.

title: LEE FOSTER,54,EDITOR AT THE TIMES, DEAD
description: Lee Foster, assistant editor of the New. York Times Travel section, who became a popular lecturer on hemodialysis after his kidneys failed, died yesterday at New York Hospital of complications stemming from the replacement of a hip joint. He was 54 years old and lived on East 63d Street.

title: Mets Back Home Today As Other
description: With the rich Yankees out of town, the poor people of baseball take over the stage today when the Mets ring up the curtain at Shea Stadium for the first time since last Sept. 29.

title: Royals
description: KANSAS CITY, April 11In a game that was unusually tense and dramafilled for the first week of the season, the Kansas City Royals edged the Yankees, 54, tonight on John Mayberry'Mayberry runscoring single in the 13th inning.

title: Young Feels U.S. Is Paranoid On Communist Activities in Africa
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Andrew Young, the United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that the United States got into difficulty in Africa because it made cold war assessments of developments there, based on a paranoia about Communism.

title: In New York, When It Rains It Pours Along the East River Drive
description: It rained last Tuesday and sections of the East River Drive flooded. It flooded when it rained the time before. And the time before that. The drive started flooding soon after it was opened in 1942. And if it rains tomorrow it will probably flood again.

title: PANELS FINISH WORK ON SPENDING TARGETS
description: WASHINGTON, April 11The Congressional budget process is making liberals sound like conservatives, and even making some conservatives defend $60 billion Federal deficits.

description: Should the owners of professional sports teams have the right to sell their players at will, and is the commissioner'er right to bar such sales a violation of free enterprise?

title: BEAM HOPES TO END PUBLIC LIBRARY CUTE
description: Mayor Beame'Beame office, said yesterday that it intended to use Federal public service job fundsnot yet approved by Congress, but being considered as part of President Carter'Carter economic stimulug programto restore personnel in  the city'city library systems to their 1975 levels.

description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 11Dr. Renee Richards was the center of attraction in the final $20,000 Lionel Cup women'women circuit tennis tournament, which began today with day and night programs.

title: Trouble in OverFished Waters
description: In the nononsense world of Soviet commerce, no fishing vessel sent 10,000 miles into the overfished coastal waters of the United States will lightly return home lightly loaded. So there was probably a touch of truth in the contention of Soviet diplomats that their fishermen at first underrated the risks of getting caught by the Coast Guard with forbidden hauls in the vast waters now regulated by the United States to a distance of 200 miles from its shores.

title: One of Three Dissidents in Tbilisi Is Released by the Security Police
description: MOSCOW, April 11 (Reuters)The security police has released one of the three dissidents detained On Thursday in Tbilisi, Soviet Georgia, dissident sources said today.

description: International

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: As certain as the blossoming of crocuses in sheltered sunwashed places at this time of year in the Northeast, comes the announcement of various fly fishing schools for those who wish to learn more about this delightful pastime.

title: Four Men Captured
description: DODGE CITY, Kan., April 11(AP)Four men were taken into custody today after their DC6 aircraft, loaded with marijuana, landed on U.S. 233 west of Jetmore, Kan.

title: TWO IN NASHVILLE ACQUIRE MUCH OF GENESCO'GENESCO STOCK
description: NASHVILLE, April 11 (AP)A Nashville financier, Jack C. Massey, said today he and a retired banker, Sam M. Fleming, had acquired a substantial number of shares of Genesco Inc., making them among the largest individual shareholders in the company.

description: VIENTIANE, LAOS, April 11Laotian Government forces today reoccupied an island in the Mekong River seized by rebels late last month.

title: SEARS IS CONSIDERING A NEW PENSION PLAN
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company outlined yesterday a new employee retirement program that would cost the big retailing chain about 43 cents a share before taxes in the first year of operation. The company earned a record $4.37 a share in the fiscal year ended last Jan. 31.

title: KLM Jet'Jet Tape Said to Contain Question on Pan Am Plane'Plane Position
description: One of the KLM Royal Dutch Airlines pilots in the March 27 collision in the Canary Islands raised the question with a colleague in the cockpit just before the accident whether Pan Am has cleared the runway, sources close to the investigation said yesterday.

description: MIAMI, April 11 (UPI)  The Howard Hughes Medical Institute, established 22 years ago by the late industrialist and endowed with profits from the Hughes Aircraft Corporation, has announced plans to build a $6 million headquarters adjacent to the University of Miami Medical School.

title: Advertising
description: Airlincs and most other advertisers generally concentrate their advertising in areas of greatest potential. They fish where the fish are biting.

description: Cuba and the United States are making plans to continue their round of sports diplomacy, including the visit of a major league allstar team to Havana after the end of the baseball season.

description: There'There a little factory in St. Paul that may be unique in the annals of manufacturing.

title: Soviet Trawler Arrives in Boston; Catch of Second Ship Also Seized
description: BOSTON, April 11Her Russian crew glumly lining the rails, her gray and white hull splotched with rust, the Taras Shevchenko, the first foreign ship seized for violating the United States new 200mile fishing zone, arrived in custody here today.

title: DENIAL ISSUED BY BOEING ON ALL NIPPON PAYMENTS
description: SEATTLE, April 11 (AP)The Boeing Company has denied any wrongdoing in payments it made to All Nippon Airways, which the aerospace giant says covered routine advertising and promotion costs. Boeing refused today to disclose the size of payments it said it made for advertising and promoting its jets sold to All Nippon.

title: Many Animals in Chicago'Chicago Zoo Have Human Parents
description: BROOKFIELD, III., April IIThere is a forlorn white rhinoceros here at the Brookfield Zoo that is probably aching to be adopted by some human being, preferably one with money. More than half the zoo'zoo 2,065 animals have acquired human foster parents in the past month, and the rhinoceros may be wondering what is wrong with him.

title: Heater Blamed in Child'Child Death
description: CAMDEN, N.J. April 11 (UPI)A defective electric heater apparently started a fire that left a child dead and four members of her family injured this weekend, authorities said today. The child, 2yearold Keesha Russ, was found:dead in a rear bedroom after firemen extinguished the flames late yesterday.

title: Otto Gold, a Skating Instructor Who Was Coach of Some Stars
description: Otto Gold, a professional skating instructor who coached such stars as Sonia l'l, Barbara Ann Scott and Dorothy Hamill, died Thursday in a Canadian hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Willowdale. Ontario.

title: Boyer Will Revise Office of Education To Remove Clutter
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)Ernest L. Boyer, the Federal Commissioner of Education, said today that he would reor. ganize his office to emphasize three broad priorities of Federal aid to education.

title: Prosecutor'Prosecutor Remarks Lead to Reversal of Mugging Conviction
description: The Appellate Division of New York State Supreme Court in Brooklyn has overturned a mugging conviction despite overwhelming evidence of guilt because remarks by the prosecutor were believed to have deprived the defendant of a fair trial.

title: Miss Farrer Leads Golf by 2
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S. C., April 11 (AP)Kathy Farrer of Decatur, Ala., shot a oneunderpart 72 and took the lead by two strokes today after the opening round of a 36hole, $5,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association satellite tournament at Bay Tree Golf Plantation. The event has 21 L.P.G.A. members and 16 amateurs. Tied for second at 74 were Beth Solomon of Middletown, Ind., and Beverly Klass of Tarzana, Calif.

title: U .S ., in Policy Shift On Virgin Islands, Invites U.N . Mission
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April IIFor the first time, the United States hasinvited the United Nations colonialism committee to send a mission to the Virgin islands in a policy shift seen here as reflecting the more open style of government promised by President Carter.

description: Abraham D. Beame was speaking in remembrance of crises past. Once, hanging around outside the poolroom on Stanton Street, young Abe Beame stuck up for his childhood friend, Nervo, when an interloper from a neighboring gang gave insult. I kicked him in the behind. Mr. Beame said.

title: Earthquake Player Hurt
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 11 (AP)John Rowlands, starting center defender for the San Jose Earthquakes of the North American Soccer League, will be lost for the rest of the month with a broken left foot.

description: A Brooklyn Criminal Court judge ordered the Police Department and the state'state Division of Criminal Justice Sery ices yesterday to return the fingerprints, photos and other identification made of a man who had pleaded guilty to three motor vehicle law infractions.

description: It was in 1925, when he was just 16, only months after he had come to the United States from Milan with his family, that Luigi Barzini discovered vanilla, American vanilla, unwavering perfect vanilla, created by American technicians in their laboratories so that it would always please, never vary, never surprise.

title: New Head of Anticorruption Unit
description: Alan R. Kaufman, a Federal prosecutor, was named chief of the official corruption unit in the office of United States Attorney Robert B. Fiske Jr. in Manhattan. Mr. Kaufman, who is 31 years old, is a graduate of Lehigh University and the New York University School of Law. He succeeds Bart M. Schwartz, who resigned to join a law firm.

description: BOULDER, Colo.Here, where young people come from all over America to catch the fleeting spirit of the 70's to mediate at the foot of the Rocky Mountains as mendicants before a shrine, to crash through the forests like Paul Bunyanshere in the mountainhigh mecca of the new age, it'it murder looking for a job.

title: Rep. Tonry Says That He Expects To Be Charged With Vote Fraud
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 11Representative Richard A. Tonry said today that he expected to be indicted soon by a Federal grand jury for alleged vote fraud and violations of Federal campaign fund raising laws.

title: MURIEL F. SIEBERT EXPECTED TO HEAD STATE BANKING DEPT.
description: Muriel F. Siebert is soon to be nominated by Governor Carey as Superintendent of Banks of New York State, banking industry sources said yesterday.

title: G,E. POSTS 25% RISE IN QUARTER'QUARTER PROFIT ON A 17% SALES GAIN
description: The General Electric Company, the nation'tion largest electrical and electronic equipment maker, reported yesterday a 25 percent jump in firstquarter earnings on a 17 percent sales gain. All areas of the company'company business were well ahead of last year, G.E. said.

title: Dance. Falco Buoys With Cheer
description: The Roundabout Stage One, locked for some time in legal battles with its landlord, has now had its electrical :equipment restored by order of the United States District Court, and, as a .result, the Louis Falco Dance Company was able to open as scheduled last night. It will present two programs during a week'week season.

title: Islanders Triumph Over Sabres, 42
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 11In game between teams using diverse styles, the hardhat New York Islanders, forever digging for the puck in the corners, defeated the flashierskating Buffalo Sabres, 42, tonight at Nassau Coliseum in the opening of their National Hockey League quarterfinal playoff series. The second game will be played at the Coliseum on Wednesday night, and then the series moves to Buffalo for two games.
