title: Sprague Urges Carter to Set Up Inquiry Into the Murders of Kennedy and Dr. King
description: WASHINGTON, April 11Richard A. Sprague, who resigned two weeks ago as chief counsel to the House Select Committee on Assassinations, urged today that President Carter appoint a special prosecutor to reexamine the murders of President Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: WORLD BANK SEEKS $600 MILLION LOAN
description: The World Bank is expected to announce today plans to borrow $600 million in the United States capital markets later this month by selling three $200 million issues of debt securitiesto mature in 5, 10 and 25 yearsthrough an

title: Yen Gains Sharply Against the Dollar; Gold Futures Firm
description: TOKYO, April 11 (Reuters)The Japa nese yen rose to its highest level for three years against the dollar on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today and the Bank of Japan bought an estimated $70 million to support the American currency, dealers said.

title: 903d Cosmos Satellite Launched
description: MOSCOW, April 11 (UPI)  The Soviet Union launched into orbit today a new earth satellite, the 903d in the Cosmos series. Tass, the. Soviet press agency, said that Cosmos 903 was orbiting the earth once every 12 hours 6 minutes at a distance ranging from 391.4 miles to 24,960.5 miles.

title: Bruins Rout Kings, Lead Series
description: BOSTON, April I 1 (AP)Bobby Schmautz scored three times in a fivegoal first period and the Boston Bruins rolled to an 83 victory over the Los Angeles Kings tonight in the first game of their fourofsevengame National Hockey League quarterfinal playoff.

title: Patricia Hearst Quits Nob Hill for a Suburb
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 (AP)Patricia Hearst left her Nob Hill apartment more than a week ago to return with her parents to Hillsborough.

title: DOROTHEA ENGLISH MURPHY
description: Dorothea English Murphy, founder and first dean of Pace University'University New Directions Program, died Sunday in Riverside, Conn. She was in her mid50's.

title: Notes on People
description: He could have become chairman of the President'President Council on Wage and Price Stability; the job was offered to him last week. But John R. Coleman, who is leaving the presidency of Haverford College, instead is coming to New York to be chairman of the Edna McConnell Clark Foundation. Mr. Coleman, an economist, quit the Quaker college in Pennsylvania because it refused to admit women as freshmen. In his new job, he'he succeed Robert F. Goheen, who did heed a White House call and is becoming Ambassador to India. The McConnell Foundation helps homeless children, the elderly and the mentally ill. A former chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank in Philadelphia, Mr. Coleman has on occasion dropped out to work anonymously in blue collar jobs and experience the lives of ditch diggers, garbage collectors and others. In New York he plans to be host of a weekly public television program on economic affairs.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The United Technologies Corporation announced yesterday that it had received a request for information from the New York office of the antitrust division of the Justice Department concerning its proposed offer to purchase any and all shares of the common stock of the Babcock & Wilcox Company at $42 a share.

title: Oerter Alters His Regimen In Bid to Return to Olympics
description: He has expanded from a size 46 jacket to size 52 in less than a year. The traditional dinner of steak and 12 pounds of potatoes has been replaced by bran, yogurt, meal bread and a magic potion of raw eggs, honey and a cup of raw protein. He has altered his training program despite the success of four Olympic gold medals.

title: Carter and the Arms Talks
description: WASHINGTONPresident Carter'Carter comprehensive strategic arms limitation proposal has broken much of the bureaucratic deadlock besetting the arms talks. The contents of the proposal demonstrate that Mr. Carter supports freezing development of new weapons, moving to insure the survivability of fixed landbased intercontinental ballistic missiles, controlling technological improvements, and reducing strategic nuclear weapons. If accepted by the Soviet Union, these principles could lead to an important reduction in the threat of nuclear war.

title: F.A,LEN, TAKES BLAME FOR BOMBS IN STORES
description: The Puerto Rican proindependence group that calls itself Fuerzas Armadas de Liberacion NacionalF.A.L.N.has claimed responsibility for eight incendiary devices that started small fires late Saturday evening in three Manhattan department stores.

title: Howe Gets History Book Award
description: With one exception, the twain of critical and popular acclaim did not meet at this year's National Book Awards, which were announced yesterday by the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters.

title: Pullman Kellogg Tries 4Day Week in Texas, Adds Jersey Workers
description: HOUSTON, April 11Pullman Kellogg, the large petrochemical engineering company, announced today that it had placed its 3,900 headquarters employees here on an abbreviated fourandahalfday work week with the hope of improving productivity and saving on energy costs.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 11 (UPI)  The United States Government asked the Federal courts today to halt the start of the next class of potential police officers for Philadelphia because it had no women.

title: Louisville Asks for Federal Funds To Clean Poison Out of Its Sewers
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 11 (AP)Mayor Harvey Sloane said today that he had asked President Carter for Federal money to help remove more than 25,000 tons of toxic sludge from the city'city sewer system.

title: Injunction Adds to Time Pressure On Giving New York School Tests
description: A State Supreme Court justice granted a preliminary injunction yesterday to bar \the Board of Education from giving citywide reading and mathematics tests that the board suddenly postponed late last month on evidence that copies had been used improperly in some schools to coach pupils.

title: Sudan Promises to Send Help
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 11 (AP)President Gafaar alNimeiry of the Sudan said today that he was ready to give Zaire any help it needed, but did not indicate if the help would include troops or weapons.

title: Carter Will Announce AntiInflation Plans
description: WASHINGTON, April 11President Carter will hold a news conference Friday morning to present a series of antiinflation proposals, Jody Powell, the White House press secretary said.

title: Retail Sales Rise Continued In March, With 2.4% Gain
description: WASHINGTON, April 11Retail sales continued to surge last month, providing fresh evidence of an economy more robust than when the Carter Administration began developing its economic stimulation package.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Gthduation Rate Unaltered by City U. SEEK Program
description: A study by the City University of New York has reported that students who took part in the system'system SEEK program of intensive remedial work graduated'graduated no better rate than other disadvantaged students who were eligible for the program but who could not be admitted.

title: U, S SEEMS TO STRESS CONTACTS WITH CHINA
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 1Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance discussed his recent mission to Moscow with China'China ranking diplomat in Washington today. Earlier, Mr. Vance affirmed the desire of the Carter Administration for normal relations with Peking and an increase in ChineseAmerican trade.

title: CAREY GIVEN A PROPOSAL FOR STATE NUMBERS GAME
description: Plans for a New York State numbers game have been submitted to Governor Carey by John D. Quinn, director of the New York lottery, officials said last night.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Attorneys for Joanne Chesimard have filed a suit, seeking to have her transferred from the Youth Correction and Reception Center in Yardville, where she is serving a life sentence for the 1973 murder of a state trooper. The suit filed in United States District Court in Trenton said Mrs. Chesimard, the 29yearold reputed leader of the Black Liberation Army, was the only woman in the prison. It complained that her cell was extremely small and that her solitary confinement there constituted cruel punishment in violation of her rights. The suit seeks to have Mrs. Chesimard moved to the State Correctional Institution for Women in Clinton, where she was briefly held before Yardville.

title: The Standings
description: American League

title: Du Pont Expects 14% Drop in Net; View on Arab Boycott is Defended
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 11E. I. du Pont'Pont firstquarter earnings are expected to fall about 14 percent short of the $2.80 per share of a year ago, but about 28 percent above earnings for the final quarter or 1976, Irving S. Shapiro, the company'company chairman, told some 1,200 stockholders at the annual meeting here today.

title: New York Is Joining In G .M. Engine Suit
description: The New York Attorney General'General office yesterday jumped on the bandwagon, obtaining a court order requiring the General Motors Corporation to explain why should not be barred from equipping Oldsmobile, Buick and Pontiac cars with Chevrolet engines and be forced to make unspecified restitution to unknowing consumers who bought cars with switched engines.

title: Rabin Fined $ 1 ,500 For Bank Accounts; Wife to Stand Trial
description: JERUSALEM, April 11Israel'Israel Finance Ministry today fined Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin the equivalent of $1,500 for his part in maintaining illegal bank accounts in Washington.

title: U.S. WARNS RUSSIANS VIOLATIONS IN FISHING MAY HURT RELATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, April IIThe United States warned the Soviet Union today that further violations of its new fishing regulations could lead to a worsening of our bilateral relations.

title: Market Place
description: The termination of discussions between the Sonesta International Hotels Corporation and the Loews Corporation yesterday rocked the shares of Sonesta and reminded investors of the heavy risks of buying into takeover situations.

title: Couple Married Over Mountain
description: GILFORD, N. H. (AP)The marriage of Frederick Nialetz and Holly Smith got off to a bumpy start, if only because they chose to marry 3,300 feet above Gunstock Mountain in a rented fourseater aircraft. A witness at the local airport said that the bride, who had never flown before, said on landing, It was bumpy and we had a hard time hearing the justice of the peace.

title: Byrne Proposes 126 Hours a Week For Atlantic City Casino Gambling
description: TRENTON, April 11Governor Byrne recommended today that Atlantic City gambling casinos be open 126 hours a week, including Sundays. Legislators who have visited casinos have recommended roundtheclock, sevendayaweek gambling.

title: 34 STATES TO WITHHOLD TAXES FROM SERVICEMEN
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)Military personnel in 34 states, including New York, will have state income taxes withheld from their paychecks beginning July I, according to a spokesman for the Defense Department.

title: Peyser Joins Ranks Of Democratic Party
description: IRVINGTON, N.Y., April 11 (UPI)Peter Peyser, the former Westchester Republican member of Congress, joined the Democratic Party today, complaining that the Republican Party was being manipulated by the Conservative Party.

title: INQUIRY INTO DEATHS OF 3 VETERANS BEGUN
description: An investigation has been started by the New York City Health Department to ascertain what caused the deaths of three disabled war veterans who had been staying at a foster home in Yonkers.

title: Young Feels U.S. Is Paranoid On Communist Activities in Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Aoril 11  Andrew Young, the United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that the United States got into difficulty in Africa because it made cold war assessments of developments there, based on a paranoia about Communism.

title: Smith Expects Little Progress
description: CAPE TOWN, April 11 (AP)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia said today that little progress should be expected from his scheduled talks here Wednesday with Foreign Secretary Owen.

title: Stage: Jockey Falls for Ballerina
description: What happened to oldtime romance? What happened to boys meeting girls and liking it? What happened to Hollywood Bfeatures? Perhaps the answer to all or some of the questions above can be elicited from a curious little play called Jockeys, which opened last night at the Promenade Theater.

title: FIVE IN MOON CHURCH WIN CUSTODY RULING
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 11A State Court of Appeals panel here today freed five young adult followers of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon'Moon Unification Church from the custody of their parents.

title: FIVE IN UN CHURCH WIN CUSTODY RULING
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 11A State Court of Appeals panel here today freed five young adult followers of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon'Moon Unification Church from the custody of their parents.

title: Jack Augenblick, 80, Chairman Of 2 Refrigeration Companies
description: Jack Augenblick, chairman of the Hudson Refrigerating Company in Jersey City and the Atlantic Refrigerating Company in Newark, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital in Newark of which he was an honorary vice president and past director and finance committee chairman. He was 80 years old and lived in East Orange, N.J.

title: F.B.I. Caps Agents To Parley to Study Mysterious Killings
description: WASHINGTON, April 11The Federal Bureau of Investigation has summoned a group of agents and officials from around the country to attend a meeting Wednesday in San Diego aimed at coordinating efforts to solve a series of mysterious killings that have puzzled and concerned bureau investigators.

title: Luce Foundation Aide Is Big Board Nominee
description: Martha Redfield Wallace, executive director of the Henry Luce Foundation Inc., has been nominated for election as a public member of the New York Stock Exchange'Exchange board of directors. If elected at the May 9 meeting she will succeed Juanita M. Kreps who resigned to become Secretary of Commerce.

title: Vadnais Gets 3 Assists AS Team Canada Wins, 51
description: HELSINKI, Finland, April 11 (AP)Carol Vadnais of the New York Rangers assisted on three goals today as Team Canada registereo a 51 victory over Finland in an exhibition hockey game.

title: Taxes &
description: Writing accounting rules for the nation'tion businesses should remain a job for the private sector, according to a highlevel review panel, but the current standardsetting apparatusthe Financial Accounting Standards Board and its supporting organizationsshould be revamped in several important ways:

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, April 11Reports persisted today here and in Washington that Democrats close to Governor Byrne are trying to persuade the Carter Administration to find a job for him.

title: Israeli Athletes Assured of Fair Deal at Moscow
description: TEL AVIV, April 11 (Reuters)Israel has been assured by the Soviet Union that its competitors will be treated properly at the 1080 Moscow Olympics, according to a leading sports official. Haim Glovinsky, the secretary of the Israeli National Olympic Committee, has reported that he enjoyed cordial relations with Soviet representatives in Abidjan, Ivory Coast. last week at a meeting of national Olympic committee delegates.

title: TV: Timely Documentary Is a Lucid Hour Exploring Many Conservation Possibilities
description: Demonstrating that the major networks do not have a monopoly on solid documentaries aimed at a national audience, Capital Cities Communications is presenting one of the more lucid and practical hours television has devoted to the subject of energy. We Will Freeze in the Dark can be seen tonight at.8 on WNEWTV.

title: Growing PartTime Work Force Has Major Impact on Economy
description: There'There a little factory in St. Paul that may be unique in the annals of manufac. turing.

title: Glomar Explorer Conversion Backed
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)It is economically feasible to convert the Glomar Explorer into a scientific deep sea drilling ship, a study released today says.

title: Commontverdth Oil'Oil Funds Frozen
description: The problems of the financially troubled Commonwealth Oil Refining Company intensified over the weekend as its nine banks froze major deposits because of a $9 million claim by the Gulf Oil Corporation.

title: Cincinnati Milacron Discloses Payments
description: CINCINNATI, April 11 (UPI)Cincinnati Milacron Inc. announced today it had voluntarily reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that an audit disclosed the company made $3.9 million in improper payments over the last five years in connection with foreign operations.

title: Ford Scores Limit on War Powers
description: LEXINGTON. Ky., April 11 (UPI)Gerald R. Ford said today that it was literally impossible in six major crises of his Presidency to consult with Congress in a meaningful way during the heat of military emergency.

title: U. S. SEEMS TO STRESS CONTACTS WITH CHINA
description: WASHINGTON, April 11Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance discussed his recent mission to Moscow with China'China ranking diplomat in Washington today. Earlier, Mr. Vance affirmed the desire of the Carter Administration for normal relations with Peking and an increase in ChineseAmerican trade.

title: Music Fest Has Its Moments, but Is a Group Short
description: The first of two shows presented at the Felt Forum on Sunday as an Easter Music Festival turned out to be somewhat longer on delays and shorter on music than many patrons had anticipated. Brick, one of lour black pop groups scheduled to appear, did not. It was announced that the group had been involved in an accident on the way to the concert, but a number of audience members did not accept this explanation. There were demands for refunds, and the grumbling did not entirely subside during the 45minute performance by the Moments that capped the show.

title: Miss Krantzcke'Krantzcke Death Is Laid to Enlarged Heart
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 11 (AP)Karen Krantzcke, the 30yearold Australian who collapsed yesterday after having won a professional doubles tournament, apparently died of an enlarged heart, C. W. Ketchum, Leon County medical examiner, said today.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: LENDLEASH A local bank has gone to the dogsor perhaps vice versa. Twentyfour aristocratic animal breeds are on view from noon to 1:30 P.M. through Friday in the lounge of the Manhattan Savings Bank'Bank main office at 47th Street and Madison Avenue. The canirie cast also has stars, headed by America'America No. 1 dog, Ch. Dersade Bobby'Bobby Girl, the Sealyham terrier from Pennsylvania that won first prize in the recent Westminster competition. Two specimens of the Chinese SharPei, the rarest of all dog breeds, have been flown up from North Carolina for the occasion.

title: The Glamorous Life Seldom Enters Day Of Junior Diplomat
description: Ahmed Aboul Gheit is a diplomat, a title that conjures up pictures of being whisked by limousine from sites of momentous decisions to elegant parties and then home on Park Avenue. It is a true image for some, but for Mr. Aboul Gheit and other junior diplomats, a recent evening he spent might be a more accurate picture.

title: Paul Taylor Dancers Set City Center Run
description: The Paul Taylor Dance Company will make its only New York City appearance this season at the City Center, West 55th Street, from May 31 through June 5. It will offer two world premieres and one New York premiere. The world premieres are Images, set to several piano pieces by Debussy, and an asyetuntitled work with music by Poulenc. Polaris, first performed at the American Dance Festival in Newport, R.I., with a scare by Don York, will be presented here for the first time.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A squad of eight detectives was assigned yesterday to an aroundtheclock investigation in an effort to solve the murder of four Rastafarian men on Sunday in their apartment in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. Two bodies were found on the floor of a bedroom, a third on the floor of a second bedroom and the fourth on a livingroom sofa of the apartment at 351 Martense Street. All had been bound hand and foot and shot in the head.

title: Dutch Journalist in Kennedy Case Is Half Showman,
description: WASHINGTON, April 11When Willem Oltmans created a flurry of publicity recently with oblique, hearsay charges that Texas oilmen and antiCastro Cubans had conspired with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Central Intelligence Agency and Lee Harvey Oswald to kill President Kennedy, he was identified only as a Dutch journalist.

title: JUDGE GRANTS NEW TRIAL FOR DEEP THROAT
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., April II (UPI)Harry Reems, the star of Deep Throat, who was the first actor convicted on Federal obscenity charges, was granted a new trial today.

title: Jacques Prevert, Poet, 77; Collaborated With Carne On Major French Films
description: PARIS, April 11  Jacques Prdvert, popular poet and screen writer, died today after a long illness at his home of OmonvilleLaPetite near the English Channel. He was 77 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: An unknown Scotsman who produced an outstanding book on defensive play a decade ago has since become one of the world'world most prolific writers. His name is Hugh Kelsey, and his eighth book, now available here, fully maintains the high standards hr has set himself. It is Test Your Match Play, available at 38 from The Bridge World magazine, 39 West 94th Street, New York. N.Y., 10025.

title: U.S. WARNS RUSSIANS VIOLATIONS IN FISHING MAY HURT RELATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, April 11The United States warned the Soviet Union today that further violations of its new fishing regulations could lead to a worsening, of our bilateral relations.

title: In New York, When It Rains It Pours Along the East River Drive
description: It rained last Tuesday and sections of the East River Drive flooded. It flooded when it rained the time before. And the time before that. The drive started flooding soon after it was opened in 1942. And if it rains tomorrow, it will probably flood again.

title: News Summary
description: France'France Defense Ministry disclosed that French military instructors were stationed in Zaire, whose army is fighting an invasion by former Katangan rebels in the province of Shaba, formerly Katanga. A Government spokesman said that instructors were in Zaire only to teach the Zairian armed forces how to use French military equipment, mainly planes and tanks under a May ]974 contract for arms deliveries. The instructors had been sent to Zaire several months ago, the spokesman said. LPage 1, Column 2.]

title: Holm Dance Is Presented By 2 Women
description: One had a strangely anticlimactic feeling after the concert by Claudia Gitelman and Alice Teirstein Sunday afternoon at the Theater of Riverside Church. Perhaps too much had been expected from the New York premiere of a work by the legendary Hanya Holm.

title: MENTAL HEALTH UNIT IS FOCUS OF DISPUTE
description: MORRIS PLAINS, April 11A proposal that the Morris County Guidance Center be replaced by a private, nonprofit agen. cy has stirred a controversy here.

title: Graduations Rate Unaltered by City U. SEEK Program
description: A study by the City University of New York has reported that students who took part in the system'system SEEK program of intensive remedial work graduated at no better rate than other disadvantaged students who were eligible for the program but who could not be admitted.

title: CHARLES K. PAPON
description: Charles K. Papon, a retired editor in New York City for the Reuters news agency and past president of the New York Financial Writers Association, died Fiiday while visiting in Chatham, N.Y. He was 65 years old and lived at 213 Bennington Lane, Crestwood Village, Whiting, N.J.

title: Drug Project Chief Wants Job Back
description: Robert Munoz, who said he had suspended himself last week as head of a controversial drug rehabilitation program in the Bronx, said yesterday that he had decided to rescind the suspension and ask the program'program directors to reinstate him.

title: No Spring List From the C. I. A.
description: The report that the Central Intelligence Agency no longer secretly underwriting Englishlanguage hooks seems reliable, even though it comes at secondhand from Representative Don Edwards of California. The agency'agency policy in such matters is neither to confirm nor deny, but a spokesman acknowledges as public information the fact that the C.I.A. has over the years secretly produced, subsidized or collaborated on hundreds of books and periodicals, many of which Wound up in the United States. He is not able to say exactly what it is doing at present along these lines or what it will be doing in the future.

title: Rally Against Death
description: ATLANTAIn brilliant Southern sunshine on the Saturday before Easter, 17yearold Junior Jackson, resplendent in a vivid green suit, stood under a statue of Tom Watson on the steps of the Georgia state Capitolthe very steps where six years ago Gov. Jimmy Carter declared in his Inaugural that the time for segregation is over.

title: A Rally Opens Antismut Drive In Times Square
description: Celebrities, union officials, sports stars, civic leaders and clergymen gathered in Times Square yesterday for the opening of a threeday campaign against pornography, called Stamp Out Smut.

title: New Rhodesia Plan Set Back as Black Expresses Doubts
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 11 (AP)A new British and American peace initiative on Rhodesia received an early setback today when the black nationalist leader Robert Mugabe said that Foreign Secretary David Owen had failed to convince him that Britain was capable of achieving a solution.

title: Pop: Jacksons Run Into Interference at. Coliseum
description: UNIONDALE, LI., April 11By the end of the Jacksons set last night at the Nassau Coliseum the crowd was streaming out the exits. Part of that could be attributed to the fact that the audience was full of parents with children who needed to get to bed, and the concert ended at 11 P.M., some five hours after the scheduled beginning.

title: B1 Foes Will Demonstrate Friday
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP1)0pponents of the B1 bomber said today that they would demonstrate on tax day Friday in an effort to dissuade President Carter from going ahead with the new generation of strategic planes.

title: Beame Plan for Use of Community Funds Scored

It was recommended by some of the most prestigious designers, but except at Valentino where it constituted the major theme, it got lost in the outsized clothes.

title: Dow Up 5.22 in a broad Advance Led by Du Pont, Which Climbs 2
description: Firmness in bluechip issues sent the stock market higher yesterday along a fairly broad front. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by an 8to5 ratio.

description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 11The feasibil ity of using solar energy for the heating of buildings was demonstrated today tc bank officials responsible for granting mortgage or home improvement loans.

description: Ben Fried doesn'doesn excite easily. In his 42 years as a hardware merchant in Bayside, Queens, he has viewed with equanimity the young woman who wanted a lefthanded monkey wrench and the teenager who sought a pail of steam for her frozen car.

description: TRENTON, April 11Governor Byrne recommended today that Atlantic City gambling casinos be open 126 hours a week, including Sundays. Legislators who have visited casinos have recommended roundtheclock, sevendayaweek gambling.

title: Peking Editorial, Calling For Stability, Envisages Success Within 3 Years
description: HONG KONG, April 11A Peking editorial today called for hard work to restore order following last year'year factional conflict and said it might take three years to achieve complete success.

title: Shanker Is Reelected
description: Albert Shanker has been reelected president of the United Federation of Teachers, a post he has held since 1964, the union announced yesterday. Mr. Shanker, 48 years old, received 72 percent of the votes cast in last week'week election, the union said, in turning back challenges from Marc Pessin and Anne Filardo. His new term, which begins July 1, will run for two years.

title: Justice Is Speeded For
description: NEWARK, April 11Under a new, federally supported program, justice is being meted out swiftly these days in Essex County in socalled strangertostranger crimes such as armed robbery, muggings and rapes, and officials are eratified with the results.

title: How You'You Valued On Direct Mail List
description: Finding out just how much you'you worth to the direct mail advertising industry can be a little disconcerting. Company presidents, abattoir operators, newspaper editors and behavioral scientists are all worth the same, which is somewhat less than lefthanded persons.

description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April IIRobert R. Wheeler was coming back to Kansas City, back to the only place he knew au home and to a job he had coveted is Superintendent of Schools.

description: WASHINGTON, April II  Senator George McGovern said today that as result of his fourhour discussion with President Fidel Castro in Havana on Saturday he intended to push for the lifting of the United States embargo on trade with Cuba.

title: PARIS SAYS ITS AIDES INSTRUCT ZAIRE ARMY IN USE OF EQUIPMENT
description: PARIS, April 11The Defense Ministry disclosed today that a number of French military instructors are stationed in Zaire, whose army is fighting an invasion by former Katangan rebels in the southeastern province of Shaba.

title: May Is Older Americans Month
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI)President Carter today designated the month of May as Older Americans Month and said, We must find ways to assure that older citizens will continnue to lead useful and productive lives.

description: MOSCOW, April 11 (UPI)The Soviet press today criticized President Carter'Carter budget request for Radio Liberty and Radio Free Europe as strange, to say the least.

title: Immunization: 99.99 Percent Right
description: The call by Secretary Califano of Health, Education and Welfare for a national effort to raise the immunization levels of the nation'nation children ought to be heeded. Polio, measles, rubella (German measles), diphtheria, mumps, whooping cough and tetanus are all serious ailments against which complete or substantial protection can be given by vaccination. Yet more than a third of children 14 and under have not been adequately immunized against polio; about a quarter have not been protected against measles, about half have not been immunized against mumps. These millions of youngsters come from all economic and racial groups, andit will require maximum cooperation of both the private and public sectors of the nation'nation health system to give them the protection they should have.

title: Deborah Remson, 45, Singer Played In Musicals on Broadway
description: Deborah Remson, who appeared in Broadway musicals, died suddenly Saturday in San Francisco, where she lived. She was 45 years old.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs Open Tonight; Strike Still On
description: The National Basketball Association playoffs start tonight with only two of the 26 regular referees not on strike. There was no change yesterday in the status of the strike, which began Sunday, the final day of the regular season, after the National Labor Relations Board delayed a decision on the unfair labor practice charges the referees had filed against the N.B.A.

description: Manhattan

title: Offbeat Piano Recital
description: ROBERT SCHRADE gave his first New York recital since 1963 on Monday night in Tully Hall. The pianist, who made his debut here in 1949, has been out of concert commission because of finger surgery, but since 1968 he, his wife and five musical children have overseen a thriving annual music festival, Sevenars Concerts, in Worthington, Mass., in the Berkshires.

description: Morning

title: New Security Chiefs in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 12New chiefs of security have been appointed here in a shuffle of some of the main posts in the country's civil service as a means of strengthenint President Elias Sarkis's hold on the country.

title: Consumer Unit Scores British Cars
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)A consumer group has asked the Government to investigate more than two dozen alleged defects in cars imported from Britain. The organization said the defects warrant recalling the cars.

title: 4 LEFTISTS IN CHINA FACE NEW CHARGES
description: HONG KONG, April 12The Chinese leadership has circulated a dossier of purported evidence against four purged leftist members of the party's Politburo, including charges that Chiang Ching be1 otrayed fellow Communists to the Nationalists in the 1930's and Chang Chunchiao had been a Nationalist secret agent.

title: Personal Health
description: PRESIDENT Kennedy got it from shaking hands, a champion dart: thrower got it throwmg darts, a woman got it shootmg craps in Las Vegas, and a housewife got it by hanging into a door jamb in toe dark. For one man it was caused by screwing in a doityourself shelf, another was lifting heavy metal casings on his job, and a third was playing golf.

title: Carter Reduces Liddy Sentence, Citing Fairness
description: WASHINGTON, April 12President Carter commuted today the 20year prison term of G. Gordon Liddy to eight years, thus making the last of the original Watergateburglary defendants still in jail eligible for parole in July.

title: Church's TaxFree Status Is in Peril;
description: A majority on the City Tax Commission has recommended rejection of an application for exemptions on more than $2.6 million worth of property owned by the Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, according to sources close to the commission.

title: Alleged Spy for Soviet Linked to C.I.A. Contractor
description: LOS ANGELES, April 12A Federal agent said today that a 21yearold Californian had admitted passing the contents of thousands of documents to the Soviet Union over a twoyear period. The documents were reportedly from his former employer, TRW Systems Inc., one of the Central Intelligence Agency's principal sources of clandestine reconnaissance satellites.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: FLORA LEWIS IS HONORED BY OVERSEAS PRESS CLUB
description: Flora Lewis, European diplomatic correspondent and chief of the Paris bureau of The New York Times, has won an Overseas Press Club award for best daily newspaper or wire service interpretation of foreign affairs and for her ability to see the continent as a whole, and report its shifting patterns In comprehensible terms to an American audience.

title: Picketed Celtics Win
description: The Boston Celtics continued their supremacy over the San Antonio Spurs last night in their opening game of a National Basketball Association twoofthreegame playoff series. The Celtics, the defending champions, triumphed, 10494, while four striking N.B.A. referees picketed outside Boston Garden.

description: WASHINGTON, April 11For the first time in modern political history, a President has undertaken a personal campaign to eliminate the historic stateoriented electoral vote system that officially put him in the White House and substitute a national plural.. ity of the popular vote.

title: BELL SYSTEM BONDS SET TO YIELD 8.17%
description: A new issue of Bell System bonds was priced yesterday to give investors a yield of 8.17 percent, a rate well below the 8.33 percent rate of return offered on similar securities marketed March 29. The decrease was considered notable in

title: DISTRICT POLICE METHODS BACKED BY FEDERAL COURT
description: WASHINGTON, April 12(AP)  A Federal appeals court ruled today that the District of Columbia police acted properly in their handling of several major antiwar demonstrations in the late 1960's and early 1970 s.

title: Ray Gunter, Former Minister In British Labor Government
description: LONDON, April 12 (AP)Ray Gunter, a former Labor Cabinet minister, was found dead today in his retirement cottage at St. Mary's in the Scilly Isles, the police said. He was 67.

title: Rene Brion, Retired Executive Of Oil Company, Dies in France
description: Rene Brion, a retired Compagnie Frangaise des Petroles executive of one of the largest oil companies in Western Europe, died in Paris Monday night after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: McAFEE, N.J. April 12The top spot in the American Bridge Association's masterpoint standings changed hands here this afternoon when Bob Price of Chicago led his team to victory in their semifinal of the knockout team championship.

title: Corporate Mergers Fall to 490, According to W. T. Grimm Survey
description: Corporate merger announcements dropped to 490 in the first quarter from 557 a year ago, according to a survey by W. T. Grimm & Company, a brokerage firm specializing in mergers.

title: Soybeans Are Highest Since 73, Spurred by Talk of Export Curb
description: Oldcrop soybean and meal futures prices soared by their daily permisible limits yesterday to close at their highest levels since midAugust 1973. Bean oil closed a touch below its upward limit.

title: U.S. Open Won't Recognize Test Taken by Dr. Richards
description: United States Open tennis officials have decided not to recognize the sexchromosone test that Dr. Renee Richards said she passed last week in Little Rock, Ark.

title: Dock Strike Planned Tomorrow On Contract and Container Rules
description: The International Longshoremen's Association said yesterday that its members would strike seven major ship lines at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow in a dispute over contract demands and the handling of containerized shipments.

title: Ethiopia Said to Charge The Sudan With Invasion
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 12 (Reuters)Ethiopia's military rulers have charged that invading Sudanese troops are locked in battle with defense forces deep inside Ethiopian territory, informed sources reported today.

title: Spanish Navy Minister Said to Quit
description: MADRID, April 12At least one of the four military men in the Spanish Cabinet was reported tonight to have announced his decision to resign in protest against the decision last Saturday to legalize the Communist Party.

title: Wine Talk
description: FROST seriously damaged grapes in the Bordeaux region of France 10 days ago. Some properties lost 50 percent or more of the 1977 crop. And every time a natural disaster strikes a major wine region, wine enthusiasts begin to reassess their buying patterns.

description: Truite en Gel..

title: Lord Moran, Churchill's Doctor for 25 Years
description: LONDON, April 12 (AP)Lord Moran, the physician who spent 25 years looking after Sir Winston Churchill and related the years and experiences in his diaries, died today at the age of 94.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 13, 1977 Zaire will receive from the United States $13 million in nonlethal military equipment to help it combat an invasion by Katangan exiles from Angola, the State Department announced. A request by Zaire for additional aid has been denied, a spokesman said. He denied that Washington was coordinating the aid with other countries. [Page Al, Column 6.]

title: In Memoriam
description: LEVYSaul K.; Warm loving memories, dear brother.

title: Papp Plans New Look for Beaumont
description: JOSEPH PAPP is planning a massive $6.5 million renovation of the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center. Yesterday, Mr. Papp, producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, presented his plan to the board of directors of Lincoln Center Inc., which has to approve before the reconstruction can take place.

title: Marshall Asserts a $50 Tax Rebate Is Needed to Reassure Consumers
description: WASHINGTON, April 12Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall, saying that there is a danger of focusing exclusively on business confidence and forgetting consumer confidence, strongly urged today the enactment of President Carter's $50 tax rebate plan.

title: Technology
description: A fundamental dispute over government regulation of new technology that may have cancer risks and involving tests of plastic bottles, is leaving one purveyor of soft drinks, Pepsico Inc., sitting pretty, and another, the CocaCola Company, with a problem.

title: Croatian Testifies On Buying Dynami For Making a Bomb
description: Zvonko Busic, on trial in Brooklyn with his wife and two other Croatian nationalists for sky piracy leading to a death, told yesterday how he purchased dynamite for a bomb left in a locker in Grand Central Terminal. A member of the Police Department's bomb section, Brian Murray, was killed trying to defuse the device.

title: MABEL BOGARDUS
description: Mabel Bogardus, who retired in 1935 as a reference librarian in charge of various New York Public Library branches in Manhattan, died Monday night in Candlewood Valley Nursing Home, New Milford, Conn., after a long illness. She lived at Hat Shop Hill, Bridgewater, Conn., and was 94 years old. Miss Bogardus, a descendant of a Dutch family that settled in Manhattan in the 17th century, had started with the public library system in 1913. She is survived by two nephews, E. Hal Bogardus of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., and Sidney Bogardus of New York City.

title: Careers
description: Corporations have been quietly building up their inhouse, or staff, legal departments so much so that there is considerable demand for young lawyers with some experience

title: They Can't Put HumptyDumpty Together Again
description: Thanks to food technologists, it's no longer true that to make an omelet you have to break eggs. Excepting only poached or fried eggs, it is now possible for restaurant cooks to serve eggs in any form without having any on the premises in a natural, fragile and per. ishable state.

title: Rivers of Cheap Hydroelectric Power Are Not Bottomless, Northwest Finds
description: PORTLAND, Ore.When the folk singer Woody Guthrie composed those lines back in 1941, the Bonneville Power Authority was in its infancy and the benefits of a Federal dambuilding program to provide cheap hydroelectric power were largely ignored in the still agricultural, timberladen region.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The New York Times/Rill Alter

title: Thefts by Youths in Queens Lead Dozen Plants to Say They'll Move
description: Two gangs of youngsters, directed by adult criminals and using preteenagers as lookouts, have been pillaging factories in parts of Long Island City, Queens, with such frequency that businessmen there are getting ready to leave the city.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Accepts Full Blame For Her Party's Disastrous Defeat
description: NEW DELHI, April 12Former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi formally accepted the blame today for her party's defeat in last month's parliamentary elections.

title: Morale in Kolwezi Reported Higher
description: PARIS, April 12French and Belgian correspondents report that morale in Kolwezi, the coppermining center of Zaire's Shaba province, has risen because of the presence of a French military mission and the arrival of a Moroccan expeditionary force.

title: Dressings: Let a Miser Pour the Vinegar
description: The old rule for salad dressing still stands. Four persons are wanted to make a salad. A spendthrift for oil, a miser for vinegar, a counselor for salt and a madman to stir it all up.

title: Zaire Made Clear
description: A peculiar international game is now being played out in Central Africa. The playing field is Zaire, once the Congo, an extremely poor country torn by tribal rivalry. Secessionists bent on reclaiming their copperrich province of Shaba (formerly Katanga), from the central Government headed by General Mobutu, moved into the country from Angola a few weeks ago, stimulating alien interventions that require the genius of Evelyn Waugh to do them justice. Since weighty geopolitical and ideological considerations are being imposed on this pathetic conflict, it is worth a few moments to sort out the participants:

title: Dollar Declines in Europe To 3Month Low vs. Mark; Gold Prices Advance $1
description: LONDON, April 12 (AP)The dollar dropped on all major European money markets today, hitting a threemonth low against the \Vest German mark in the first day of trading since the Easter holiday. Gold bullion prices rose by more than SI an ounce over Thursday's close.

title: Talks Ordered in Strike At Kansas City Schools
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 12 (AP)A judge ordered striking teachers and Kansas City's school board back to the bargaining table today in an attempt to end a threeweekold walkout.

title: Settlement Agreement On Conrail Is Reached
description: TRENTON, April 12 (AP)  New Jersey's Department of Transportation and the Consolidated Rail Corporation have agreed to settle a contract dispute, ending a threat by Conrail to terminate rail commuter service, a state transportation official said today.

title: P. K. Wrigley, 82, Owner of Cubs And Chewing Gum Company Head
description: Philip K. Wrigley, the chairman of the company that sold billions of sticks of chewing gum a year and the owner of the Chicago Cubs baseball team, died yesterday in an Elkhorn, Wis., hospital. He was 82 years old and was stricken by a gastrointestinal hemorrhage on Monday night while watching his baseball team on television.

title: A. H. Raskin
description: When several hundred thousand workers in men's and women's apparel factories across the country stop work today in a symbolic strike for import curbs, they will be vanguard elements in what is almost certain to

title: Mount Vernon Policeman Cleared
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 12A Westchester County grand jury today cleared a white Mount Vernon policeman of any wrongdoing in the fatal shooting of a black man, but returned perjury indictments against several persons who said they had been eyewitnesses. One of those indicted was arrested.

title: Closed End Funds
description: Tuesday, April 12, 1977

title: Pillow Talk (and Heads Win)
description: WHEN IT COMES to pillows, there's no need to be a featherbrain. Once upon a time, pillows were a simple matter. They seemed, in those faraway days, to come In one size on lne filling. But even though things have changed, when it comes to pillows, it really isn't too difficult to keep your head on straight.

title: U.S. Jury Is Investigating NursingHome Union Chief
description: A Federal grand jury is investigating criminal charges against Peter Ottley, president of Local 144 of the Hotel, Hospital, Nursing Home and Allied Health Services Union.

title: New Fizz for the Old RattlePlop
description: THAT rattlerattle, plopplop that's being heard in living rooms and clubs so much these days is the sound of the dice in backgammon, a game that may date back to 3,000 B.C. and is increasingly popular in the 1,970's.

title: U.S. Space Program Lags Because of Lack of Interest and Money
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The bustling activity at the new National Air and Space Museum, whose 10 acres of satellites and planes have become the most popular tourist attraction in town, contrasts sharply with the almost melancholy atmosphere at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration across the street on Independence Avenue.

title: SOVIET CARGO OF FISH BROUGHT INTO BOSTON
description: BOSTON, April 12The huge, 503footlong Soviet refrigerator ship Antanas Snechkus, which was brought here today with her cargo of illegal fish under seizure, is a symbol of the size and technology of the big foreign fleets that have swept the fish from the seas off New England, leading to the imposition of the heW 200mile fishing zone.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The New York Times/Teresa Zabala

title: Carter and Mondale Lobbying for E.R.A.
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)President Carter and Vice President Mondale are waging a fight from the White House for the equal rights amendment, which will be voted on tomorrow in the Florida Senate.

title: Defense Scores a Point In Michigan Nurses
description: DETROIT, April l2Defense arguments that two Filipino nurses did not poison patients at the Ann Arbor, Mich., Veterans Hospital two summers ago were bolstered today when Federal Judge Philip Pratt refused to admit into evidence two intravenous bags the Government says had been used for two of the victims.

title: New British Effort on Rhodesia Begins, but Its Prospects Appear Slim
description: CAPE TOWN, April 12After a threemonth lull, another major effort to get a Rhodesian settlement is under way. Foreign Secretary David Owen of Britain, who is to meet Prime Minister Ian D. Smith here tomorrow, brings with him yet another new approach to the issue. But his proposals, jointly developed with the Carter Administration, appear to have only the remotest chance of bringing about a peaceful transition to majority rule.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 13, 1977

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported in The Times yesterday that Edward M. Carey tormerly controlled the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company. Mr. Carey had no such connection.

title: CARTER AND DOBRYNIN MEET ON ARMS ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, April 12President Carter met today with the Soviet Ambassador, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, to discuss ways of ending the impasse in the negotiations toward a new treaty limiting strategic bombers and missiles.

title: RESULTS
description: By The Associated Press

title: G.M. Rules Out Plans For Rotary Engine Use; Drops Work on Research
description: DETROIT, April 12  The General Motors Corporation today made it official: Barring unforeseen developments, the rotary engine has no place in the future plans of the world's biggest auto maker. G.M. announced that it had discontinued research and development work on the rotary, or Wankel, engine, that began seven years ago.

title: Accounting Board Deadlock Ends Effort on Prior Period Adjustment
description: For the first time, the fouryearold Financial Accounting Standards Board, the private sector's top authority on accounting rules, yesterday abandoned a project because of a deadlock among its seven members.

title: HERMANN F. FRANKEL
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., April 12 (UPI)Hermann F. Frankel, an authority on early Greek philosophy and literature, has died in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 88 years old.

title: Carter's Intervention Is Sought In Case of a Dissident in Poland
description: WARSAW, April 12 (Reuters)President Carter's intervention is being sought by the father of a Polish worker jailed for his part in last June's food price riots, the dissident Workers Defense Committee said here today.

title: Child's World
description: THE books are piled on the desk now, like so much compost. Normally that wouldn't be a very flattering simile, but this time it's meant to be. Those books glory in telling children about leaves, insects, growth and decay.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Bergland to Resume Big GrainSale Listing
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland has reversed his decision to keep some big sales by private grain exporters confidential for up to a week, an aide disclosed today.

title: End of Curbs Sought In OffBoard Trade
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The National Market Advisory Board, a securities industrydominated group advising the Securities and Exchange Commission on the national market system, is expected to recommend next week that all offboard trading restrictions be removed by a fixed date.

title: Ulu Grosbard Pays a Price for Being a Perfectionist
description: THIS SEASON a number of prominent directors  Arthur Penn, Mike Nichols, Frank Perry and Ulu Grosbardhave gone from Hollywood to Broadway. What brought them back to the legitimate theater are new plays.

title: Military in Argentina Seizes Food Centers
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 12 (AP)Troops took over 23 of the capital's major fruit and vegetable distribution centers during the night in what Government officials said was a new step in the fight against inflation, which last year was 347.5 percent. No violence or arrests were reported.

title: N. B. A. Playoffs
description: PRELIMINARY ROUND Boston vs. San Antonio April 12Boston 104, San Antonio 94. April 19Af San Anteno, 8:30 P.M. April 17At Boston, 1:30 P.M, Chicago vs. Portland April 12Portrand 96, Chlean 83. Aor'i 15Af Diceoo, 8:30 P.M.

title: Seaver Subdues Cards, 40, in Shea Opener
description: It was not said Tom Seaver, a work of art.

title: Tennessee Adopts Death Penalty As Legislature Overrides Veto
description: NASHVILLE, April 12 (AP)The Ten, nessee legislature overrode Gov. Ray Blanton's veto last night, thereby enact: ing a state'death penalty law.

title: AvantGarde Performers In Concert at the Diplomat
description: Performing Artservices, Inc., which provides management and administrative services to avantgarde performers, will present a series of music and dance performances from April 25 through May 9 In the Grand Ballroom of the Diplomat Hotel, 108 West 43d Street. The series is entitled In Performance at the Diplomat.

title: St. Clair Meets on Indian Claims
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)James St. Clair, the lawyer who worked for President Richard M. Nixon on Watergate problems, returned to the White House today for a meeting on land claims of the Mashpee Indians of Massachusetts. Mr. St. Clair, who met with the Indians attorneys, is representing the Selectmen of the town of Mashpee. An announcement after the session said that Mr. Carter had chosen Judge William Gunter to help all parties try to resolve the dispute. Judge Gunter serves in a similar capacity in an Indian lands claim case in Maine.

title: REFUSE BALING SITE DEDICATED BY BYRNE
description: NORTH ARLINGTON, April 12Amid the growl of garbage trucks in low gear and derisive shouts from demonstrators nearby, Governor Byrne led state, county and local officials today in a groundbreaking ceremony for construction of New Jersey's first, and the nation's largest, refuse baling system 10 miles southwest of Giants Stadium in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: People in Sports
description: The Detroit Tigers have traded Willie Horton, their 33yearold former AllStar left fielder, to the Texas Rangers. Details of the deal were held up since Horton, with more than 10 years in the major leagues and five years with the same club, had the power to nullify the agreement. But Horton said yesterday that he wouldn't veto the deal.

title: About Real Estate
description: The United States Postal Service has wanted to build on the block bounded by.28th and 29th Streets and Ninth and Tenth Avenues for about 15 years. With the passing of time, its plans for thesite have changed and the complexities of construction planning have grown.

title: Carey Signs Bill Setting Elections
description: Governor Carey has signed a bill setting primary elections on Thursday. Sept. 8, this year, with a runoff for citywide offices in New York City on Monday, Sept. 19, if needed, a spokesman for the Governor said yesterday.

title: Ordinary
description: He seems like just an ordinary guy with an ordinary name, and if you saw him on the street, you would probably never think he was a professional athlete. Much less a National Hockey League star.

title: YUGOSLAVS AGAIN ASSAIL DJILAS AS PROVOCATEUR
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 12Friends of Milovan Djilas, Yugoslavia's leading dissident, said today that the Government of President Tito was apparently preparing a new campaign against the critic.

title: Best Buys
description: THIS BEING the week when the taxman cometh and the dollar goeth, many citizens made all too aware by April 15 that in the midst of life there is debt have probably taken fresh vows of frugality.

title: Nonprofit Group to Start Prison Print Shop
description: TRENTON, April 12  A nonprofit, churchbacked group seeking to set up today it hoped to be in operation at the Clinton Corrections Institute for Women industries in New Jersey prisons said by July 1.

title: US. and Africa: An Aloof Policy
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 12 The United States appears to be signaling a new policy of disengagement and reserve toward Africa by maintaining an aloofness toward Zaire's appeal for

title: Red Smith
description: Boycott all future Met games, urged a dodger handed out yesterday at the Shea Stadium gates, which might have been the wrong place because fewer than 24,000 of New York's millions were there to get the message. The dodger was the work of a group called the Bronx Mets Fan Club, whose home team is the Yankees but whose masochistic members prefer the city's No. 2 club. Chances are they rent their cars from Avis. If the Met management doesn't care about you, the fan, why should you support

title: New York Withers Under Earliest 90
description: After the coldest winter in 41 years, six months of vertiginous ups and downs that even the circumspect National Weather Sevice will concede were quirky, and a weekend so unseasonable that the IndiansRed Sox baseball game was canceled Saturday because of cold, New Yorkers faced the earliest 90degree day in weather records yesterday with neither shock, amazement, nor surprise.

title: F.D.A. SAYS COSMETICS MUST LIST CONTENTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 12Following a twoyear legal battle, the Food and Drug Administration will begin Friday requiring the nation's cosmetics manufacturers to list the ingredients of their beauty and cleansing products.

title: Lulu
description: IT WOULD BE HARD to imagine a more difficult role for an opera substitute to be handed than the title part in Lulu. Berg's 12tone idiom, while often remarkably expressive and evocative in the orchestra, puts all the voices through a wringer, but no singer is squeezed more cruelly than the soprano who is the draMatic focus of this perverse and claustrophobic work.

title: Self Defense for Welfare Workers
description: SAN DIEGO, April 12 (UPI)  County welfare workers are taking dirty street fighting courses to help them defend themselves from welfare applicants who attack them. People who come to us are in a desperate situation, said Marcia Saweatzky, who led the group that requested training in sel defense. We're their last hope. If we can't help sometimes they'll strike out, just because we're the closest target.

title: Mollie
description: The world premiere of Mollie, by Simon Gray, the noted. English playwright now represented on Bioadway by Otherwise Engaged, will take place May 26 at the first Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C. Mr. Gray was also the author of Butley, in which Alan Bates scored a triumph in London and New York several seasons ago.

title: Sea Lion Death Held Unrelated To Vandalism
description: Bonnie, an 8yearold sea lion who had been one of the Central Park Zoo's bestloved attractions, died yesterday afternoon in the pool she had lived in since 1971.

title: Hussein to Visit Carter For Talks on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)  King Hussein of Jordan will visit President Carter in two weeks in a continuation of Mr. Carter's consultations with Middle East leaders, the White House announced today.

title: Chicago Segregation Figures
description: CHICAGO, April 11Of 669 public schools in Chicago, only 83 meet the integration requirements of the Illinois Board of Education, according to a report issued last week by Joseph P. Hannon, Chiacgo School Superintendent.

title: Pornography's Victims
description: It was Victims Day in Times Square yesterday, the day when neighborhood residents who suffer from th socalled victimless crimes of prostitution and pornography got a chance to tell their stories and vent their anger.

title: Men Give Scarves A Spring Fling
description: It's a crisp spring Saturday with just a hint of chill lingering in the air, the kind of day that, years ago, would cause women to reach for their new suit or the hat with a flower on it.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Internal Revenue Service has proposed that the Rockwell International Corporation pay an additional $8.6 million in Federal income taxes for fiscal 1969. Rockwell is contesting the I.R.S. proposal in the United States Tax Court.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Elderly Go to Court To Observe Justice
description: While 15 elderly men and women watched and listened attentively in State Supreme Court in the Bronx yesterday, Justice Joel J. Tyler sentenced two 17yearolds to long prison terms for assaulting and robbing an aged couple of S6.

title: A Trout Feast n the Catskills
description: SHANDAKEN, N.Y. UP HERE, a twoandaonehalfhour drive from Manhattan, there is a territory known as the Catskills. To some of the citizens and visitors hereabouts, it is also known as a transplant of the French Pyrenees, which was once home for many of those who have settled here. And American citizens of French background, who visit here by the score, agree that this area reminds them of the French mountain range.

title: Strife Engulfs Mexican Campuses
description: MEXICO CITY, April 12  Mexico's state universities, their budgets inadequate, their classrooms crowded, are becoming the focus of a struggle between political conservatives and leftists.

title: Reserve Member Banks Required To Give Mortgage RateRise Data
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)The Federal Reserve Board adopted regulations today requiring member banks to notify customers that interest costs may rise under variablerate mortgages.

title: Private Lives
description: IT WILL happen by accident. No one will have warned you. Why should they? They have their own erotic depths and nasal passages to worry about. You will leave the safety of your typewriter the sanctuary of your homeand perhaps a provocative book, only halfread, on genetic engineering cr how to process cannabis in a Cuisinart. Goingout is a way of not watching Scenes from a Marriage on public television. What you expect is an unlacing of the mind among loose friends: Off with the hoots cf duty! Let us talk small, gnaw chicken and risk a giggle.

title: Pornography's Victims
description: It was Victims Day in Times Square yesterday, the day When neighborhood residents who suffer from the socalled victimless crimes of prostitution and pornography got a chance to tell their stories and vent their anger.

title: Zeffirelli to Film Champ
description: Franco Zeffireili, who directed the sixhour film, Jesus of Nazareth, which was presented on television by NEC during the Easter holiday, has been signed by MetroGoldwynMayer to make a modernized movie version of the studio's 1931 hit, The Champ. It will be Mr. Zeffirelli's first American film under the auspices of MGM.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The New York Times/Frank C. Dougherty

title: JUDGE VOICES DORT ON COAST BUSING PLAN
description: LOS ANGELES, April 12 (AP)A hearing on a plan to integrate city schools next fall has been halted by a judge who said that his research had shown that similar plans in other cities had been. ruled unconstitutional.

title: U.S. WILL SEND ZAIRE $13 MILLION PACKAGE OF NONLETHAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The United States has decided to send $13 million worth of nonlethal military equipment to help Zaire resist an invasion by Katangan exiles from Angola, the State Department said today.

title: Carter Reduces Liddy Sentence, Citing Fairness
description: WASHINGTON, April 12President Carter commuted today the 20year prison term of G. Gordon Liddy to eight years, thus making the last of the original Watergate burglary defendants still in jail eligible for parole in July.

title: Israeli Cautions P.L.O. on Lebanon
description: JERUSALEM, April 12Foreign Minister Yigal Allon said tonight that Israel could not tolerate attacks by Palestinian !guerrillas in southern Lebanon against !mainly Christian villages adjacent to Israel's northern borderenclaves that the Israelis have been assisting for months.

title: JOHN C. M'CLINTOCK DIES; LATIN AMERICAN EXPERT
description: John Chamberlain McClintock, a specialist in Latin American economic affairs and a principal economic adviser to Nelson A. Rockefeller when he was Assistant Secretary of Sate in the mid1940's, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 67 years old.

title: Prisoners at Large
description: The New York State Commission of Correction has announced an investigation and special hearing to determine if the city's House of Detention for Men on Rikers Island should Le closed because of unsatisfactory conditions. Without another place to put them, the city would have to release 1,500 inmates who are awaiting trial or sentencing. While those not yet tried must be presumed to be innocent, their records indicate that many have committed violent deeds in the past.

title: Nearly 5,000 Concorde Opponents Stage Rallies, but Differ on Tactics
description: Nearly 5.000 opponents to the landing of the Concorde at Kennedy International Airport crowded inside two high schools in Queens and Nassau County in separate rallies last night.

title: New York Justices Said to Hold Trials Only Half the Day
description: State Supreme Court justices in Manhattan and Brooklyn have been greatly underused and have spent too much of their day merely waiting for cases, according to a study released yesterday by the Economic Development Council.

title: COURT OEDERS DUTIES ON ELECTRONIC GOODS COMING FROM JAPAN
description: Casting aside United States Government warnings of disastrous political and economic consequences, a three1 judge panel of the United States Customs Court yesterday ordered Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal to impose countervailing duties on Japanese electronic eauinment.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Former State Senator Frank S. Farley, who spent a record 35 years in the Legislature, was honored yesterday when the Atlantic City Expressway Authority dedicated its service plaza near Hammonton in his name. On hand were a gathering of present and former officeholders and political figures. Still erect and voluble despite a serious illness, the 75yearold former political power was lauded by Attorney General William S. Hyland as an architect for progress. Senator Farley was a moving force behind the construction of the 44milelong expressway and the Garden State Parkway among a number of other projects during his legislative career.

title: JOHN ANTONIADES
description: John Antoniades, an arcniteq long active in Athens, died Monday in a hospital in the Greek capital. He was 87 years old. Active until recently, he specialized in the design of public buildings and was part of the design team for the United Nations headquarters building in New York.

title: The Standings
description: Wednesday, April 13, 1977

title: U.S. WILL SEND ZAIRE $13 MILLION PACKAGE OF NONLETHAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The United States has decided to send $13 million worth of nonlethal military equipment to help Zaire resist an invasion by Katangan exiles from Angola, the State Department said today.

title: Costa del Sol's Tourism Hopes Are Riding on Legcdizod Gambling
description: MARBELLA, SpainAfter a half century of banishment, gambling has been legalized in Spain. When the roulette wheels start turning and the dice begin to tumble, one of the main beneficiaries could be the fabled Costa del Sol, which is just recovering from a fiveyear tourist slump.

title: Death of 3 Veterans Of Yonkers Facility Tied to Pneumonia
description: The deaths last weekend of three disabled war veterans who lived at a foster home in Yonkers were tentatively attributed yesterday to pneumonia; apparently caused by a flulike virus.

title: Marcos Says Insurgents Accept Peace Plan
description: MANILA, April 12 (UP)  President Ferdinand F. Marcos today said Moslem rebel leaders, in agreeing to end their fouryear rebellion in the southern Philippines, had expressed willingness to participate in a provisional government.

title: $17.50 Buys Fireplug at Pier Garage Sale
description: The city held its first garage sale yesterday, auctioning off what the municipal Service Administration called choice items of memorabilia, including one fire hydrant, two barber's chairs, four dentist's chairs, 14 traffic signs, 15 traffic signal heads and 31 firealarm boxes.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: HE most famous lines ever written about the rich, aside from the line about the camel passing through the eye of the needle, are these: Let me tell you about the very rich. They are different from you and me. The riposte. equally famous, is Yeah, they have mote money. Now whatever the truth about the rich, it is absolutely unassailable to say that they love bargains as much as anyone else, and that they have nothing against saving a buck. We at not talking here about William Randolph Hearst using paper napkins at San Simeon, H. L. Hunt carrying his lunch in a brown paper bag, or J. Paul Getty having pay phones in his house ill London: these were only eccentricities. We are talking about shopping. Sometimes the rich do this very well.

title: Marian Heiskell Named Woman Of Year by Scholarship Group
description: Marian S. Heiskell, director of special activities of The New York Times Company, was awarded the Woman of the Year award of the New York chapter of the Achievement Rewards for College Scientists Foundation Inc., at a benefit luncheon yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Lifts Quarterly Earnings 88.2% On a 25.2% Sales Gain
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, the nation's third largest aluminum producer, reported yesterday an 88.2 percent rise in firstquarter net earnings on a 25.2 percent sales gains.

title: One of Civilized London's Pleasures
description: LONDON

title: Racers Go Up, 20, With 72 Triumph
description: CINCINNATI, April 12 (AP)Reg Thomas got two goals and had two assists as the Indianapolis Racers took a 20 lead in the World Hockey Association's Eastern Division playoffs tonight by beating the Cincinnati Stingers. 72.

title: Brewers Get 55,120 Fans But Palmer Wins 2Hitter
description: The biggest crowd in the history of Milwaukee's County Stadium, 55,120, primed by the Brewers two victories in Yankee Stadium, wound up cheering an opposing pitcher yesterday.

title: WASTE FOUND IN A SURVEY OF U.S. EMPLOYEE TRAVEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)A survey of travel by employees of three Government agencies shows that 15 percent of the trips violated standards for approved Federal travel, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: Remember the good old days, when cops used to find lost children? Well, if a correspondent from Richmond Hill is correct, any day now a child is likely to find a lost cop. Yes, it seems that the men in blue are beginning to join the cabbies who manage to misplace the city.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Tuesday, April 12, 1977

title: International Paper Off 24% for Quarter
description: The International Paper Company said yesterday that firstquarter earnings fell 24 percent from last year's comparable quarter.

title: CARTER TO ASK RISE ON U.S.PRODUCED OIL TO THE IMPORT PRICE
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  President Carter will propose to Congress next week that American consumers pay for domestic oil at least the same high price set by an international cartel for imported oil, Congressional and Administration sources said today. A rise in the price of domestic natural gas is also to be sought, perhaps through a parity formula that would link gas prices to world oil prices.

title: Living Abroad: Along the Bosporus
description: ISTANBUL

title: Music: The Endymion
description: The Endymion Ensemble is a pool of players from which almost any kind of performance group can be drawn. Its great value is its ability to handle some of the more unusual instrumental combinations used by composers. On Monday night, in Cami Hall, the ensemble presented Stravinsky's Wind Octet (flute, clarinet, two bassoons, two trombones, two trumpets), Hindemith's Concert music for Piano, Brass (four horns, three trumpets, two trombones, bass tuba) and (two) Harps, and Dvorak's Serenade in D minor (two oboes, two clarinets, two bassoons, three horns, cello and double bass).

title: Peres, Now Vying for Israeli Leadership, Seeks to Shed Image as Hawk
description: JERUSALEM, April 12Israel's new Labor Party candidate for Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, has been attempting to divest himself of the label hawkishone he regards as a misnomer and one that has been troubling officials in foreign capitals interested in ArabIsraeli peace talks

title: Market Place
description: During the bear market of the early 1970's, a visitor asked managers of a mutuel fund that had lost 25 percent of shareholders capital in the prior year why they remained fully invested, since stock market prospects clearly continued to be bleak.

title: Transit Authority Pay Increases Found Unjustified by Productivity
description: The New York City Transit Authority has not achieved enough savings through increased productivity to pay for wage increases already given to its workers, according to Sidney Schwartz, the special deputy state comptroller.

title: Advertising
description: I got to the point where I can say that I really know this market better than anyone on the face of the earth, said James B. Bradbeer, adding, mostly because nobody else cares.

title: All About: Fluorescent Lights
description: THE MAIN TROUBLE with fluorescent lights is that nobody well, virtually nobody  can love them. One of the most magical and romantic moments in any 24.hour stretch is when the lamps come onbut, lamps with ordinary incandescent bulbs.

title: It Was Stolen. No, Lost. No, Taken by a Frog.
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y.Warren is a teacher at Syracuse University. He spends some of his time meeting students in a slightly esoteric vocational subject they have expressed interest in by enrollment.

title: Seattle Slew to Sample Sights, Sounds of Big A
description: When Seattle Slew runs in the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct a week from Saturday, his handlers want the undefeated 3yearold colt to feel right at home.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: The New York Times/Neal Boenzl

title: Tennis
description: AT BUENOS AIRES RIO DE LA PLATA TOURNEY

title: Shift of Open Would Sadden Fans, But Need for Better Facilities Seen
description: Most tennis fans in the New York area would be saddened to see the United States Open move from its traditional home in Forest Hills to Flushing Meadow Park, but felt that a change was necessary because of the growth of the sport.

title: School Desegregation: A Sense of Deja Vu
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.I was saddened when I read, in The New York Times, remarks on school desegregation by Assistant Attorney General Drew S. Days, who heads the Justice Department's civil rights division. But it took me a while to figure out why.

title: Putting It All Together
description: Spinach, redveined beet tops and tart sorrel, as well as mildflavored nasturtium leaves if any grow in your garden, are all legitimate candidates for the mixed salad and add iron and other valuable minerals.

title: CHARLES 0. TANC
description: Charles O. Tanc, who retired in 1964 as a vice president of International Flavers and Fragrances Inc., New York, died yesterday in Muhlenberg Hospital, Plainfield, N. J., after a short illness. He lived in Green Brook, N. J.:and was 84 years old.

title: Giscard Explains Action
description: PARIS, April 12President Valery Giscard d'Estaing asserted today that France had flown Moroccan troops to Zaire to combat the subversion and invasion of a friendly African nation.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported In The Times yesterday that Erl, v7.rd M. Carey formerly controlled the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company. Mr. Carey had no such connection.

title: Vinaigrette Variations
description: Vinaigrette dressing is the only type dealt with here, because it is really the only fitting one for green salads. Save mayonnaise and sour cream dressings for other vegetable, meat and seafood salads. These delicate greens cannot withstand the assault of heavy dressings on either their flavor or texture.

title: Koreans in U.S. Suffer Effects Of Bribe Affair
description: ARLINGTON, Va., April 12Just before Christmas last year, several Korean children living here made little gifts for their school teachers, in the custom of their homeland. But the teachers, so the story goes, politely refused the gifts because they feared the taint of accepting anything from a Korean.

title: A New Medical Science Unit Opens
description: NEWARK, April 12  The Medical Science Building became today the fifth new structure to open on the 5200 million campus of the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey.
