title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 12, 1977

title: Salads: A Spring Tossup
description: CONSIDERING the overwhelming popularity of green salad, it is surprising how difficult it is to find one that is properly made whether in homes or in some of the city's best restaurants. A perfect green saladfresh, crisp lettuces, wellwashed and thoroughly dried, carefully glossed with a soothing, light and oily dressing with just the slightest sting of vinegar or lemon juiceis as hard to come by as such other culinary simplicities as a properly boiled potato, really good egg salad, honesttoGod hot chocolate, or even a glass of decent iced tea.

title: Carey Seeks to Give Wage Rise To 8,000 Employees Not in Union
description: ALBANY, April 12 (AP)Governor Carey wants to give the state government's management and confidential employees the tame wage and fringe benefits offered to and rejected by the Civil Service Employees Association.

title: Prosecutors Are Put on Defensive By a Plan to Curb Their Influence
description: New York City prosecutors were put on the defensive yesterday, and they, did norlike it.

title: January Aluminum Shipments Fell 1.7% From YearAgo Level
description: Aluminum shipments in January fell L7 percent from the yearago level, the Aluminum Association reported yesterday. The trade association placed January shipments of ingot and mill products at 905,644 pounds against 921,392 a year earlier.

title: CARTER TO ASK RISE ON U.S.PRODUCED OIL TO THE IMPORT PRICE
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 President Carter will propose to Congress next week that American consumers pay for domestic oil at least the same high price set by an international cartel for imported oil, Congressional and Administration sources said today. A rise in the price of domestic natural gas is also to be sought, perhaps through a parity formula that would link gas prices to world oil prices.

title: JOEL HARNETT ENTERS RACE FOR MAYORALTY
description: Joel Harnett said yesterday that he would enter the Democratic primary for Mayor of New York, but would not abide by the results if he lost in the voting in September.

title: The Political Playoffs
description: WASHINGTON, April 12About this time of year, at the changing of the seasons, you can look west in the evening from the Potomac and see the struggle of nature over the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia: Spring trying to banish a savage winter; spectacular sunsetsclear and pink light streaming through the vast gray clouds.

title: HARRY ABT
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 12 (AP)Harry Abt, a leading figure in Jewish cultural and religious life in South Africa, died yesterday in Johannesburg. He was 76.

title: Alaska Land Battle to Open in Congress
description: A legislative battle over Alaska's vast wilderness areas, some of which are rich in minerals and timber as well as scenery and wildlife, is taking shape as a major. confrontation between those who want to protect this country's last great tracts of truly wild land and others who want Alaska to profit from the extraction o its natural resources.

title: JOSEPH L. SABO
description: Joseph L. Sabo, a cartoonist and illustrator for newspapers and popular magazines and for Walt Disney, died yesterday in Riverview Hospital, Red Bank, N.J., after a long illness. He lived at John Street, West Keansburg, and was 81 years old. He retired 15 years ago. He is survived by his wife, the former Helen Stewart, and two sisters.

title: Alleged Spy for Soviet Linked to C.I.A. Contractor
description: LOS ANGELES, April 12A Federal agent said today that a 2Iyearold Californian had admitted passing the contents of thousands of documents to the Soviet Union over a twoyear period. The documents were reportedly from his former employer, TRW Systems Inc., one of the Central Intelligence Agency's principal sources of clandestine reccrna'.,:sance satellites.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two small privately owned planes collided in midair shortly after 11 o'clock last night near the Sikorsky Memorial Airport in Stratford, Conn., but tboth planes landed safely at the airport and none of the 15 persons aboard the two aircraft were injured, officials said.

title: Net for Merrill Slumped 80.5% In 1st Quarter
description: Merrill Lynch & Co. Inc., holding company for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., reported an 80.5 percent drop in firstquarter earnings with revenues down 25 percent, indicating the profit pattern for the industry so far this year.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: If you're a business man or woman, or spouse of same, and if occasionally, you have a group of visiting firemen, women or spouses on your hands, what can you do that's a little unusual? Well, there's a service in Westchester called Carriage Trade Tours Inc., that might be of interest. Its run by two women, and they arrange tours to historical houses and sites in the Tarrytown, White Plains, Hyde Park area. There are three, six and eighthour tourssome with lunchand among the choices are Boscobel in Garrison, Lyndhurst in Tarrytown, Union Church in Pocantico Hills, the Franklin D. Roosevelt home in Hyde Park and the John Jay homestead at Katonah. One can leave from Westchester or New York City and the minimum number of participants is usually four. Prices vary depending on the location of the limousine pickup, the length of the tour and whether or not lunch is included. However, a six or sevenhour trip, starting ana returning to Manhattan and including lunch, Would likely run around $55 a person for four people. A brochure and further information can be had by writing Carriage Trade Tours at Box 211, Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. 10510, or by calling 914.941350G or 91.40413871.

title: Letelier's Murder Still Baffles U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 12Although nearly a dozen antiCastro Cuban exiles have recently been called before a Federal grand jury here, the Government still has no solid evidence linking anyone to the murder of Orlando Letelier, the former Chilean diplomat, Justice Department sources said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHEN the talk comes around to women writersthe group portraitI am on my guard. Though the intent these days is praise. I recoil at a collective image in which faces are blurred and the individual talent is merged into one big blob of Female Creativity. I have read and ,profited from the writings of Carolyn Heilbrun, Patricia Meyer Specks, Ellen Moers and others, but however strong their case for a polarity of the sexes in literature. I always end up more impressed by a polarity of styles separating one group of women writers from another the literary distance one must travel, for instance, between Charlotte Bronte and Virginia Woolf.

title: Securities Automation Names Head
description: The Securities Industry Automation Corporation, owned by the New York and American stock exchanges, yesterday named Leland H. Amaya, executive vice president, as its new president. He succeeds Robert C. Hall who becomes an executive vice president at the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Yankees Again Planning To Switch Their Hitters
description: KANSAS CITY, April 12The panic button is as close as the nearest telephone. The telephone George Steinbrenner usesoften.

title: Dr. George A. Trowbridge, Episcopalian Rector, 79; AidedflungarianRefugees
description: The Rev: Dr. George Augustus Trowbridge, who headed large Episcopal congregations here and in Philadelphia during almost half a century of clerical service, died monday at his home at 333 East 68th Street. He was 79 years old.

title: 38 Pakistani Police Hurt By Grenades in Lahore
description: ISLAMBAD, Pakistan, April 12 (UPI) Grenades allegedly thrown by antiGovernment demonstrators exploded today in the midst of two security patrols and injured 38 policemen in Lahore, the Government said..

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS.

title: Performing Arts High Plans Gala
description: The High School of Performing Arts, in urgent need of funds to continue in operation, will hold a benefit evening, Spring Celebrity Gala, at 9 P.M. on May 5 at the Burger King Restaurant, 1165 Avenue of the Americas, between 45th and 46th Streets.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: BROILED foods, fish in particular, are ideally suited to good but hasty cookery. And yet home cooks seem more perplexed by broiling techniques than almost any other. It's true that broiling may embrace the simplest yet most confusing of cooking procedures. Consider the making of a white sauce, for example. You take a certain amount of butter, stir in a certain amount of flour and add a given quantity of milk. You can predict in advance what the volume and consistency will be.

title: Young Will Accept Criticism to Achieve Full Policy Debate
description: LANSING, Mich., April 12Andrew Young carried the Carter Administration's campaign for a more open government to this state capital today, pledging that at the risk of incurring attack on hithself he would continue to speak his mind before foreign policy decisions were Made which can cost the taxpayer money and lose precious American lives.

title: Bombs Damage 2 Soviet Offices In Paris After Moscow Protest
description: PARIS, April 12 (UPI)Bombs damaged the FranceU.S.S.R. Friendship Association and a Soviet bookstore in Paris today, less than 24 hours after Moscow protested earlier attacks on Soviet offices in France.

title: Chess:
description: GENEVA. April 9Sent Larsen of Denmark, squeezing oul a victory in his adjourned queenandrook ending with Werner Hug of Switzerland, took the lead after 12 rounds of the Geneva International Tournament here in the Hotel la Mediterrande. Larsen's 8 points put him a halfpoint ahead of Ulf Andersson of Sweden.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 13, 1977

title: 2 Subway Riders Hurt as Car Goes Off Track in Rush Hcur
description: Two subway riders were slightly injured during the evening rush period yesterday when a subway car of the BMT N line derailed between the Manhattan Bridge and the DeKalb Avenue station in Brooklyn, transit officials reported.

title: How to Make Trout in CourtBouillon
description: Truites au Bleu

title: Penn to Buy Divinity School Sought by Moon Church
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 12 (AP)The University of Pennsylvania has agreed to buy a divinity school sought by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church, according to a university spokesman.

title: ENTRIES
description: Horses listed In order of poet Positions

title: What's Tom O'Horgan Doing Directing an Opera?
description: MOST Americans attend opera for the singing, and most American opera productions reflect that bias. At rehearsals, directors confine themselves to explaining rudimentary motivations and to position the singers in a way that makes decent dramaturgy but still gives them a clear view of the conductor.

title: Thorium Backed as Plutonium Alternative
description: A future worldwide nuclear power industry could avoid heavy trading in plutonium suitable for nuclear weapons by relying instead on fuels containing the element thorium, two Princeton University disarmament specialists proposed yesterday.

title: DiningOut At the Inn
description: Although we dined at Pierre Larre's streamside cookout one midday, we also shared two excellent meals with him at the Auberge des Quatre Saisons, or the Inn of the Four Seasons, on Route 42 in Shandaken, N.Y. Each meal began with troutfished and provided by Larre and songenerally sauteed meunierestyle, sometimes with a touch of garlic and parsley (Pierre's personal favorite) or with capers Grenoblestyle.

title: Music From Academe
description: RUTGERS UNIVERSITY is presenting a series of faculty composer concerts at Carnegie Recital Hall this season, and the two who were featured on Monday night were Larry Ridley and Noel Da Costa.

title: Protesting Cabbies Snarl Traffic At La Guardia and Win Concession
description: Nearly 1,000 radiodispatched taxi drivers, angered over airport restrictions on them, blocked roadways at La Guardia Airport for two and a half hours yesterday morning, tying up traffic for miles and inconveniencing thousands of travelers.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Upstairs, Downstairs
description: Upstairs, Downstairs actually ends with a sort of whimper, but the Public Broadcasting Service means to conclude the popular fouryear British series May I with a bang.

title: Jews Protest Met Show
description: Coinciding with a major exhibition of Russian art lent by the Soviet Union to the. Metropolitan Museum, the American Jewish Congress is holding a counterexhibition featuring the work of four Jewish migr artists from the Soviet Union.

title: Pop: Magical McGarrigles
description: KATE AND ANNA McGarrigle's first formal New York performances Monday and last night at the Bottom Line confirmed their status as the most charming and original songwriters and singers in a folk idiom to emerge in many years. Their shows weren't perfect, but at their best they came disturbingly close to that standard.

title: Books: Rise Of Carter In Homespun
description: JOURNALISM is history written to a six o'clock deadline. Kandy Stroud's account of the rise of Jimmy Carter and his, winning campaign is a book of her firsthand journalism written also to a deadline (being an early entry in the 1976 campaign book sweepstakes)an assemblage of swatches of her reportage on Mr. Carter during two years of covering him. The result is a patchwork, which, like any good quilt, is satisfactory as coverage, though lacking in finer workmanship.

title: News Executive Urges Businesses in New York To Stay at Least 5 Years
description: Tex James, president and publisher of The Daily News, urged the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry yes4 terday to get pledges from its 1,700 member companies to stay in New York City for the next five years.

title: Thomson Vetoes Free Speech Bill
description: CONCORD, N.H., April 12 (AP)Gov. 1VIeldrim Thomson has vetoed a bill that would have guaranteed freedom of speech for all state workers. He said the bill was unnecessary and obviously proposed for political embarrassment. The measure's sponsor, Representative Eugene S. Daniell Jr., a Democrat from Franklin, said he was not surprised by the veto and accused Governor Thomson of being a dictator.

title: Letters
description: A Matzoh Question

title: Holland &
description: Harold A. Pearson, 35yearold senior vice president, has been promoted to executive vice president and named chief operating officer of Holland & Callaway, until last week Lois, Holland, Callaway.

title: Stage: G. R. Point, Death Vietnam Style
description: T.S. ELIOT once suggested that the playwright Webster was much obsessed with MI death. At the moment, so is the New York theater. For the fifth play of the Phoenix Theater's season at, the Marymount Manhattan Theater, which opened last night, we had death, Vietnam style. It was G.R. Point, a new play by David Berry.

title: 3 Candidates for Mayor Agree: Fiscally, the Worst Is Yet to Come
description: Three candidates for the Democratic nomination for Mayor agreed yesterday that the worst of the fiscal crisis was Atilt ahead for New York City.

title: Dow Average Rises 13.06; Biggest Gain in 6 Months
description: Staging a powerful rally that caught Wall Street by surprise, the stock market sprinted ahead yesterday to its best advance in six months as the Dow Jones industrials gained more than 13 points.

title: RICHMOND APPROVES CONTINENTAL OFFER
description: Directors of the Richmond Corporation decided yesterday, by a vote of 6 to 5, to merge with the Continental Group Inc. in a new cash and securities deal valued by Wall Street analysts at roughly $27 a shareor about $356 million.

title: Indian Atoms for U. S. Peace
description: PARISThe International implications of India's recent change of government could conceivably be almost endless. Mrs. Gandhi's Congress Party dictatorship was ousted the moment she opened the door to democracy. The subsequent Desai regime has made it plain that foreign policy will take a decisive veer.

title: Miss Klass Wins by Shot In Golf at Myrtle Beach
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C., April 12 (AP) Beverly Klass of Tarzana, Cailf., won the Ladies International satellite golf tournament today by shooting a twoday total of 150 in the 36hole, $5,000 event.

title: Book Awards: Are the Judges Too Old?
description: THE USUAL GRUMBLING was heardbut not in the publishing houses of the prize winners about the National Book Awards that were announced Monday and will be formally conferred early this eveningby the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters.

title: About Education
description: Ara Zerounian was working as a substitute, teaching mathematics to seventhgraders in Detroit, on the day recently when he learned that he had been chosen 1977's music teacher of the year by the American String Teachers Association.

title: Muddling Through a Dull Night Out
description: The longest day is nothing to the longest night, which is the night one is invited to dinner at the home of friends who are dear but boring whose other friends, save for present comps. ny, arc worthwhile but longwinded, and whose idea of company food is beef liver al dente and strawberry shortcake made with aerosol whipped cream.

title: Ticket Sales Up 44%, Soccer League Says

title: Notes on People
description: HE'S 73 years old, but physically and mentally ready for another sixyear term in the Senate. and so, said Strom Thurmond, he's seeking reelection. The Republican from South Carolina, the Senate's 11th ranking member, said that those back home who suggest he step aside to let Gov. James B. Edwards be the Republican nominee were misguided. Mr. Edwards has denied he seeks the office, but Charles D. Ravelie!, expected to be the Democratic nominee, said he still believed Mr. Thurmond would step aside in Mr. Edwards's favor.

title: New York Justices Said to Hold Trials Only Half the Day
description: State Supreme Court justices in Manhattan and Brooklyn have been greatly underused and have spent too much of their day merely waiting for cases, according to a study released yesterday by the Economic Development Council.

title: Fort Hood Confirms Loss Of $1.5 Million in Supplies
description: FORT HOOD, Tex., April 12 (UPI)The Fort Hood public relations office confirmed today that $1.5 million in equipment and supplies disappeared in late 1975 and 1976 and that the Army had begun an investigation.

title: U.S. and Africa: An Aloof Policy
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 12  The United States appears to be signaling a new policy of disengagement and reserve toward Africa by maintaining an. aloofness toward Zaire's appeal for

title: How to Battle Cancer Is Debated
description: NEWARK, April 12Government officials today differed sharply with members of the medical profession and a spokesman for the chemical industry over what immediate steps should be taken in New Jersey to reduce the incidence of cancer, which experts estimate will strike more than 26,000 persons in the state this year.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Park Says South Korea Will End Partying for U.S. Congressmen;
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 12  A group of American Congressmen was told by President Park Chung Hee yesterday that there would be no more wining and dining at South Korean Government expense for United States legislators who visit here in the future.

title: Byrne Keeps Options Open as Petitions Are Filed
description: TRENTON, April 12The fact that Governor Byrne allowed his nominating petitions for a second term to be filed quietly last evening without making a formal announcement was viewed today as an indication that he wanted to keep

title: Burns Calls for Decisive
description: Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve System, warned last night that failure to adopt new rules for the world financial system would risk making it especially vulnerable to another recession.

title: Budget for Quebec Shows Discipline; New Aims Cited
description: QUEBEC, April 12Quebec, a frequent bidder for funds in New York and other financial markets in recent years, will be seen much less this year under the $11.5 billion budget unveiled tonight by the new government, which seeks to make this largely Frenchspeaking province independent.

title: Vietnam Statement Says Six Million More in South Must Quit City for Farm
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 12 (UPI)Vietnam said today that the biggest problem facing Saigon on the second anniversary of the city's takeove by the Communists was how to get city dwellers back to the countryside.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SLICES The Big Apple, Midtown, is like this or a Wednesday at lunchtime. Take a break and your pickeither a jazz session in a convenient auditorium, or a knowledgeably guided walking tour through one of the world's great railroad terminals. The diversions, both at 12:30 P.M., last about an hour. They cost nothing.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: ST. LOUIS, April 13David S. Lewis, chairman of the General Dynamics Corporation, told the annual meeting here today that the company was reluctant to pay a cash dividend because of cash drain from the company's Electric Boat division's attack submarine program.

title: COFFEE SPILL: Policemen standing watch over bags of coffee after tractortrailer overturned in Memphis yesterday. The 38,000pound shipment, valued at more
Television
description: Morning

title: Books: Lap of Luxury
description: They lived lives of constant luxury in a world where their slightest wish was a command. They had only to snap their fingers and vast armies of servants would appear, bejeweled elephants would parade, colorfully clad soldiers would present arms, huge cars would arrive. Gayatri Devi was born into this world of India's fabled maharajas. A Princess Remembers is her story of that world.

title: CURBS RECOMMENDED ON CASINOS IN JERSEY; Panel Urges Rules on Operations Being Planned in Atlantic City
description: TRENTON, April 13The New Jersey State Commission of Investigation recommended today a number of stringent regulations for casino gambling in Atlantic City, including a prohibition on & edit and restrictions on hours, that it said were necessary to prevent the infiltration of organized crime.

title: Deaths
description: ABBOTTAlice. Greatly beloved wife of Wainwright Abbott. Suddenly on April 9 at Dublin, Ireland.

title: Kunta Kinte's Village in Gambia Takes Roots
description: JUFFURE. Gambia, April 13It may well be that Alex Haley is not a descendant of Kunta Kinte after all. But that scarcely matters to the hundred or so people of Juffure who scratch a meager living out of the soil near the Kamby Bolongo, the Gambian River. Clearly, the villagers of Juffure have taken the black American author of Roots, Is one of their own. And just as clearly, they expect him to adopt themin the way of any African son who leaves the family compound to make it big in the distant city and returns one day as a benefactor.

title: Personal Beauty
description: HELP! A broken fingernail is just about annoying as a sore thumb. It catches everything, rips stockings and makes woman feel thoroughly awkward. Fortunately, recue is at hand from a number of nail specialists around town whose new techniques go beyond the usual paperpatch method.

title: Bullets Top Cays in Picketed Opener
description: The National Basketball Association playoffs continued last night with striking referees picketing the start of the WashingtonCleveland series and the Bullets striking early enough to fashion a 109100 victory over the Cavaliers at, Landover, Md.

title: The Alternatives in South Africa
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y.Thirty years ago almost exactly, Marie and I were talking. We sat under tall umbrella pines while flannelclad young men played cricket on an oval field..Our subject was The Native Question in South Africa. We knew, with all the clarity of youth, that the privilege we were part of could not last.

title: Spy Trial Defense: Mexican Trip Was to Buy Drugs, Not Sell Data
description: LOS ANGELES, April 13Part of the! defense strategy in the espionage trial! of Christopher J. Boyce emerged today! when his lawyer sought to depict a trip; to Mexico as a drug smuggling mission rather than an effort to transmit American secrets to the Soviet Union, as the prosecutors contend.

title: No Room for Dr. Kissinger?
description: Columbia University has been discussing with Henry Kissinger the possibility of his joining its faculty, probably to occupy a wellendowed chair. Dr. Kissinger is no novice in Academe, having been a professor government at Harvard for a decade before moving Washington in 1969. Since then, he has busied himself with other matters around the globe; by ordinary criteria he would be an adornment to any university.

title: Flight Controllers in Yugoslavia Dispute Circumstances of Collision
description: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, April 13 (Reuters) Three flight controllers, alleged with five others to have caused the world's worst midair collision, today disputed statements by the main accused man that he was overloaded with work at the time.

title: Tree Houses Just for Fun
description: AMY CARTER, who has a perfectly nice White House to sleep in, recently shinnied five feet up a cedar on the South Lawn and spent the night in her new tree house.

title: Plan to End 500 Jobs In Bayonne Is Fought
description: BAYONNE, April 13 (UPDSenator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Representative Joseph A. LeFante and Hudson County officials called on the Navy Department to reconsider its proposal to move 500 jobs from the Navy International Logistics Office here.

title: A WellKept Secret: Federal Theft Insurance
description: THE BURGLARS who ripped off Judy and Richard Forrest's apartment a couple of years ago were professional and highly selective. They bypassed the silver and other bulky items in favor of such easily concealed valuables as the jewelry, a collection of gold coins, and a small portable TV set that was probably spirited out to the street in the folds of trench coat that Richard Forrest had bought only a few days before.

title: Home Beat
description: GOODBYE SAUDI ARABIA. Hello Atlantic City. That's where the action is for designers and architects since it's soon going to be legal to gamble in saltwater taffyland.

title: Car Sales Dropped in Early April; End of Selling Contests Is a Factor
description: DETROIT, April 13American newcar sales slumped to a 7.5 million annual rate in early April from a robust 10.2 million level in March, according to auto analysts.

title: New York City Denies Moon's Church Exemptions on Real Estate Taxes
description: The City Tax Commission in a 4to3 vote formally denied tax exemptions yesterday for three pieces of property, valued at $2.6 million, owned by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church.

title: 146,618 Were `Bumped From Airlines in 1976
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)The number of passengers with confirmed reservations who were bumped from airline flights last year totaled 146,618, an increase of more than 15,000 over the 1975 figure, the Civil Aeronautics Board announced today.

title: Body of Capt. James B. Cosgrave, Crash Victim, Reaches New York
description: The body of Capt. James B. Cosgrave, a Vietnam War veteran killed April when his B52 bomber crashed while trying to land in a storm at K. I. Sawyer Air Force Base, Mich., arrived in New York yesterday. He lived at 14720 Tenth Avenue, Whitestone, Queens. He was 31 years old.

title: Thronesand Stools
description: Each of Paul Tabou's six wives excels at beadwork and helps the Cameroon carver to execute the stunning coverings for his anthropomorphic thrones.

title: Bridge:
description: McAFEE. N.J., April 13It was Chicago against Chicago in the final of the American Bridge Association's knockout teams here last night, and the winner was, of course, Chicago.

title: Text of Deposition on Kunta Kinte
description: My name is Kebba Kangye Fofana, son of Jalang Kinte. I am the first son of Jalang Kinte. I come from Juffure in Niomi, I am 76 years of age. Our ancestors came from Mending. They came to Niomi. They found the Kassenkas in Niomi.

title: GARDENING: IN AND OUT
description: IS IT erb or herb? On this side of the Atlantic, the silent h is preferred. The British pronounce it. But that debate aside, virtually no one disputes the delights of growing herbs. Everyone can try at least one. A windowsill has space for a small pot of chives or parsley, while a penthouse gardener can expand to include basil, marjoram and thyme.

description: Paul Goldberger

title: The New York Times/Frank C. Dougherty
description: A MUCH TRAVELED BOAT AND ITS SKIPPER: Tristam Jones standing by his boat, Sea Dart, at the Elizabeth terminal of Atlantic Container Line yesterday. Mr. Jones has sailed the boat in Lake Titicaca, three miles high In the Andes, and in the Dead Sea, the lowest body of water. Mr. Jones, who has sailed the boat 48,000 miles over a period of six years, will be honored by the Explorers Club at the Plaza Hotel this weekend.

title: ISRAEL S. FLAX
description: Israel S. Flax, who retired in 1971 as principal of Junior High School 80, the Bronx, died in Montefiore Hospital Tugsday after a long illness. He lived at 28 Highview Terrace, Yonkers, and was 73 years old.

description: Buffalo Sabres .......... 2 0 02

title: Israel Honors Nazis
description: TEL AVIV, April 13, (Reuters)Movie theaters, cafes and places of entertainment throughout Israel were closed this evening as the country began Memorial Day observances in honor of the 6 million Jews killed by the Nazis during World War II. Sirens will wail throughout the country at 8 A.M. tomorrow and two minutes of silence will be observed.

title: SOUTH KOREANS CONTRACT $100 MILLION PURCHASE
description: A South Korean purchasing mission has signed contracts to buy American products worth nearly $100 million, the Korean Commerce and Industry Minister, Yieioon Chane. announced yesterday.

title: Washington &
description: WASHINGTONOne of the 28,000 letters that has arrived at the White House energy office in the last five weeks bears this salutation: To Whom Energy May Concern. And one conclusion the happy energy staff has drawn from the writein is that a lot of ordinary Americans are themselves very concerned.

title: New Government in India Plans To End Control of Radio and TV
description: NEW DELHI, April 13 (UP)Moving to enhance freedom of the press in India, the new Government said today that it would give up its radio and television stations and might allow the return of foreign journalists expelled by former Prime I Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: By the Associated Press

title: ROBERT SIDNEY BOWEN
description: HONOLULU, April 13 (UPI)Robert Sidney Bowen, a World War I air ace and former newspaperman and author, died of cancer here Monday. He was 76 years old.

title: CARTER HEARS LABOR ON TEXTILE IMPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 13While thousands of workers staged protest marches and sitdowns around the country, a delegation of labor leaders called on President Carter today to ask that he restrict clothing and textile imports to save American jobs.

title: Americans Define Possible Role
description: WASHLNGTON. April 13Administration officials confirmed tonight that the United States was prepared to play more direct part in a new conference on Rhodesia than in the past, but they rejected a role of cochairman or coconvener with Britain.

title: Defense Chief Vows A Flexible Stance For Soviet on Arms
description: ROCHESTER, April 13Secretary of Defense Harold Brown said tonight that the Carter Administration was prepared to revamp its strategic arms prOnosals to the Soviet Union but would block any attempt by Moscow to bully us to sign an acord to control nuclear_ weapons.

title: Carey Vetoes Part of Bill on Budget
description: ALBANY, April 13Governor Uarey announced today that he had vetoed section of the New York State budget that would have limited the amount the Metropolitan Transportaion Authority could assess localities for station maintenance.

title: Judge Delays Gov. Mandel's Trial After Doctors Testify on His Illness
description: BALTIMORE, April 13The political corruption trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel and five associates was postponed today to May 11. after five neurologists testified in Federal District Court here that Mr. Mandel was suffering from a circulatory nroblem in his brain.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: In a Hungry World, Brazil Emerges as Agricultural Giant
description: PATROCINIO, Brazil, April 8After 20 profitable years as an economist and engineering consultant, Wando Borges decided to invest his savings in the oncebleak scrublands of central Brazil, known as the Cerrados.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: The Whistle That's Finally Blowing
description: Dave Anderson

title: About New York
description: A Frenchman would have judged the antiConcorde rally under the flight paths of Queens throatier than the one under the flight paths of Nassau. Queens had a finer peasant's bite: the Nassau rally aimed for a smoother tone from a larger and richer crop of partisans.

title: East Coast Dockers Co on Strike Against 7 Major Shipping Lines
description: East Coast longshoremen went on strike against seven major shipping lines this morning despite lastminuteefforts by Labor Department officials to avert the walkout.

title: The Standings
description: Thursday, April 14, 1977

title: Beating Time
description: THE GREAT MACDADDY by Paul Carter Harrison. Directed by Douglas Turner Ward; choreography by Dianne McIntyre; music he Coleriage.Tayler Perkinson; setting oy William Ritrnan: costu rns by Mary Mease Warren; righting by Sandra L. Ross, stage manager, Horazena J. Taylor. Presented to the Negro Ensemble Company. At Le Theater &Lis, 121 Christeener Street.

title: Democrats to Debate
description: The Democratic State Committee has agreed to organize a debate of all party candidates for Governor at a convention of state and county committee members. Barbara McConnell of Hunterdon County, a member of the state committee, was appointed by James P. Dugan, the Democratic chairman, to arrange the debate.

title: Grand Jury in Las Vegas Indicts Powerful Sheriff On Income Tax Evasion
description: LAS VEGAS, April 13Sheriff Ralph Lamb of Clark County, considered one of the most powerful men in Nevada, was indicted today on three counts of Federal income tax evasion.

title: Soybeans Buffeted
description: The soybean futures complex was buffeted yesterday by limit gains and declines as traders responded to a bewildering array of facts and rumors. By the close, oldcrop soybeans were down the limit of 30 cents a bushel, while the newcrop deliveries were off as much as 24 cents. Page D1 1.

title: Diego Garcia Base Backed
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 13 (AP)Australia's Foreign Minister, Andrew S. Peacock, says the United States base on Diego Garcia island in the Indian Ocean should be maintained until the Soviet Union agrees to a mutual reduction of its base at Berbera, Somalia. You can talk about disarmament or a zone of peace, but before you can have a zone of peace, you have got to have a zone of balance, he said in an interview with, the newspaper The Australian.

title: RALPH HALLENSTEIN
description: CHICAGO, April 13 (UPI)Ralph Hallenstein, day news editor of The Chicago Tribune, died last night in his home in suburban Wheaton. He was 56 years old.

title: 2D HELD AS PERJURER IN MT. VERNON INQUIRY
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 13District Attorney Carl A. Vergari of Westchester County today announced the indictment and arrest of a second person on a perjury charge on a grand jury's investigation of the fatal shooting of a black man by a white Mount Vernon policeman.

title: PRESIDENT REPORTED READY TO DROP PLAN FOR $50 TAX REBATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 13President Carter has decided to withdraw his request to Congress for a $50 rebate for most American taxpayers, sources in the Administration said tonight.

title: Carter Considers Plan to Continue Portions of Some Water Projects
description: WASHINGTON, April 13President Carter, whose effort to curtail water projects has stirred widespread anger in Congress, is considering proposals to continue construction on portions, but not all, of some of the endangered projects, according to Administration officials.

title: Carey Cites Room for Bargaining To Avert State Strike on Monday
description: ALBANY, April 13Governor Carey said today that there was still room for bargaining to avert a strike called for Monday against the state by its largest public employees union, and he urged the employees not to walk off their jobs while negotiations were continuing.

title: The Gangster SuitHas Gone Legit
description: THE PINSTRIPED suit has undergone quite a metamorphosis. In the past 40 years or so, it has changed from the fashion symbol of the bigcity gangster to that of the earnest, industrious member of the executive suite. A classic case of upward mobility.

title: Who Lost Africa?
description: WASHINGTON, April 13In the presence of a reporter for Time magazine last week, Jimmy Carter displayed his irritation with Secretary of State Cy Vance. Speaking about policy toward certain African countries, the President complained to Vice President Mondale: We're just sitting around, and added ominously, I've told Cy that before.

title: Hers
description: THE trouble must have started when I first heard the saying Woman's Work Is Never Done. Maybe I saw it crossstitched on sampler, with sweetheart roses couchant, or carved in a knotty pine decorative accessory.

title: Cuomo May Seek Mayoralty
description: Mario M. Cuomo will run for the Democratic mayoral nomination with the behindthescenes encouragement of Governor Carey, high state sources reported yesterday.

title: No Appeal in Reserve Case
description: ST. PAUL, April 13 (AP)Attorney, General Warren Spannaus of Minnesota said today that he would not appeal a State Supreme Court decision that cleared the way for the Reserve Mining Company to request state permits for a waste disposal basin near its Silvef Bay plant. The court ruled last Friday that the permits should be granted, subject to certain conditions to safeguard public health and safety.

title: A Set Designer At Home: It's An Empty Stage
description: FOR SANTO LOQUASTOa man accustomed to contemplating space, or spacesquestions like What color should the walls be? Where should the sofa go? are seldom insoluble. Mr. Loquasto has after all, constructed whole houses for Joseph Papp's Shakepeare in the Park. He has assembled roughly a ton of junk at the Barrymore Theatre for the set of American Buffalo. He has created a cherry orchard at Lincoln Center. And he is one of the most successful and soughtafter set designers in New York, precisely because producers and directors seem to think he solves these problems so well:

title: Gold Advances by $2.50 in Europe
description: LONDON, April 13 (AP)The price of gold jumped more than $2.50 an ounce in major European centers today. The dollar continued to sag on foreign exchanges.

title: Carter Adds $1.5 Million to S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI)President Carter signed today a measure increasing the authorization of the Securities and Exchange Commission by $1.5 million for fiscal 1977 from $55 million, the White House announced.

title: Magazine to Send Photos by Satellite To Ease Deadline
description: WASHINGTON Earl next month, U. S. News & World Report will begin transmitting pictures by way of satellite from its editorial offices here to its three printing plants in Los Angeles, Chicago and Old Saybrook, Conn.

title: DoItYourself Q &
description: Q: Our home has cedar shingles on the outside that have never been stained or oiled, just allowed to weather naturally. We are now thinking of applying linseed oil Would this be beneficialor is there something else we should apply?Mrs. J. P., Monsey, N.Y.

title: EGYPTIAN SEES NO PLACE FOR HAWKS
description: CHICAGO. April 13 (Reuters)Ambassador Ashraf Ghorbal of Egypt said today that there was no place for hawks in the Middle Eastan apparent allusion to Defense Minister Shimon Peres of Israel.

title: Islanders Take 20 Series Lead, Overcoming Sabres Again, 42
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 13Get in there and hit somebody!. Coach Al Arbour ordered his Islanders tonight after they had fallen behind by two goals and were hardly able to get a shot off against the Buffalo Sabres during the first period.

title: 2 U.S. Agencies Clash on Voltage For Rails in New York City Area
description: WASHINGTON, April 13Conflicting plans by two Department of Transportation agencies threaten confusion in the modernization of the rail system in the New York City area, according to officials here.

title: DR. ANDREW M. DOYLE
description: Dr. Andrew M. Doyle, an assistant pro. lessor of neurology at Albert Einstein Col. lege of Medicine, died Tuesday at Albert Einstein College Hospital, the Bronx, of Hodgkins disease. He was 37 years old and a resident of Yonkers.

title: Textile Association Gets Government Assurances Of Some Relief on Imports
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., April 13The Government is intent on renewing the MultiFibre Agreement, due to expire at the end of 1977, but the textile industry has been given assurance that it will get some relief in terms of imports from the five countries that supply the bulk of textile apparel shipments to the United States.

title: MARKET GAINS 1.02 TO CLOSE AT 93818
description: The stock market absorbed an earnings disappointment yesterday for its most popular issuethe International Business Machines Corporationand then recovered sufficiently to make a token gain.

title: Deadlock on Arms Talks Persists As Dobrynin and Brzezinski Meet
description: WASHINGTON, April 13Despite highlevel contacts and optimisticsounding comments since the unsuccessful talks Moscow last month, the Soviet Union and the United Stales remain deadlocked in an effort to renew serious negotiations on strategic arms.

title: ADA L. RICE
description: CHICAGO, April 13 (UPI)  A mass will be held tomorrow for Ada L. Rice, 78 years old, a prominent horsewoman whose Lucky Debonair won the 1965 Kentucky Derby. Mrs. Rice, a resident of suburban Wheaton, died Monday in RushPresbyterianSt. Luke's Medical Center. Services are scheduled for 10 A.M. tomorrow a Holy Name Cathedal.

title: Jazz and Clacsical
description: The crossfertilization of jazz with contemporary music in the EuropeanAmerican tradition had tentative beginnings in the 1940's and 50's, with Igor Stravinsky's Ebony Concerto for Woody Herman and, somewhat later, the aleatory or improvisational pieces of younger American composers. But jazzmen and classically trained musicians did not really begin to find common ground until the 60's, and one of the leading groups in the vanguard of this fusion was Musica Elettronica Viva. Founded in Rome in 1966 by Alvin Curran, Frederic Rzewski and Richard Teitelbaum, the group has worked with several important jazz musicians, including Steve Lacy and Anthony Braxton.

title: Singing the New York Blues
description: New York City has never been thought of as a blues center, but over the years quite a few bluesmen have settled here, enough to establish New York blues style. Most of them came from the Southeast, particularly from the Carolinas, Virginia and Alabama, and as a result New York blues never had the stark, raw, aggressive qualities associated with blues from the Mississippi Delta and Chicago. It was and is a gentler, more lyrical style, touched by ragtime, if it is older, and by country gospel singing, if it is

title: Gun Group Offers a $200 Reward To Victims Who Kill Assailants
description: A federation of 135 pistol and rifle clubs in New York with 5,000 members is offering S200 to any victime of a robbery or assault who shoots and kills his attacker, the president of the organization said last night.

title: ANIMALS ARE TESTED ON QUAKE FORECASTS
description: Why did the chickens suddenly fly into the trees? What made the pigs start biting each other? Why did the deer jump up and down, and the snakes slither out of their dens in the middle of winter? And what caused the dogs to bark madly and refuse to go into their pens at night?

title: Kunta Kinte's Village in Gambia Takes Roots
description: JUFFURE, Gambia, April 13It may well be that Alex Haley is not a descendant of Kunta Xinte after all. But that scarcely matters to the hundred or so, people of Juffure who scratch a meager living out of the soil near the Kamby Bolongo, the Gambian River. Clearly, the villagers of Juffure have taken the black American author of Roots, Es one of their own. And just as cleatly, they expect him to adopt themin the way of any African son who leaves the family compound to make it big in the distant city and returns one day as a benefactor.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 14, 1977

title: Phone Call by Juror Causes Texas Judge To Order a Mistrial
description: FORT WORTH, April 13A call allegedly made by a juror in which she told an employer she was ready to issue a verdict caused a State District Court judge here today to order a mistrial in the murder trial of T. Cullen Davis, Fort Worth millionaire.

title: W. and M. Coach Quits
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., April 13 (AP) George Balanis, who just completed his third full season as basketball coach at William and Mary, resigned today to go into business as a sales representative for athletic equipment.

title: Prompt Export Reports For Grain and Soybeans Reinstituted by Bergland
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI)The Agriculture Department formally announced today that Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland has ordered a new system of daily reports on all major export sales of seven designated grain and soybean productsreversing an earlier decision.

title: Rights Group Accuses Greece
description: LONDON, April 13 (AP)Amnesty International accused the Greek Government today of failing to enact special laws against torture and of not, bringing to trial all those guilty of torture under the former military dictatorship. The complaints were made in a report on the 1975 trial of 32 military police officers and soldiers arrested after the overthrow of the sevenyear dictatorship in 1974.

title: Nadjari, a Witness, Parries Jabs At His Record by Assembly Panel
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, called ostensibly to testify about legislation affecting grand juries, spent three hours on the witness stand yesterday as a State Assembly subcommittee went into the minutest details of his actions as special prosecutor in charge of rooting out corruption in New York City's criminaliustice system.

title: Nets Get Pacers
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 13 (AP)The New York Nets have acquired a centerforward, Darnell Hillman, from the Indiana Pacers to complete a midseason deal for a guard, John Williamson.

title: Stringent CasinoGambling Rules Urged by lnvestigation Commission
description: Continued From Page A1

title: F. D. A. TO ALLOW SALE OF SACCHARIN ASDRUG, BUT NOT IN BEVERAGES
description: WASHINGTON, April 13The Food and Drug Administration plans to announce tomorrow that it will continue to permit bulk sales of saccharin in tablet or powder form but will stand by its proposal to ban the use of the artificial sweetener in prepared foods and beverages.

title: The Santores own four dozen Windsor chairs, How collectors live with their collections, page C6.

title: FineTuning the Boycott Bill
description: Commerce and diplomacy have nibbled away at the antiboycott law that President Carter promised to provide. Both the pending Senate and House bills show, their complexity, the pressures exerted on Congress by Mr. Carter's State and Commerce Departments. State wanted to avoid upsetting the Arabs on the way sensitive Middle East negotiations. Commerce sought soften the bill lest American business lose its share Middle East trade. These concerns are understandable. But even though principle must be bent to the realities of oil and power, clarity must not.

title: I.M.F. Raising Interest Charges On Members
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)The International Monetary Fund said today that it would increase interest charges on loans to member countries by 0.375 percent.

title: N. B. A. Playoffs
description: PRELIMINARY ROUND

title: Spanish Generals Reportedly Accept Reds
description: MADRID, April 13  The Supreme Council of the Army was reported today to have adopted a resolution that grudgingly accepted the Government's decision to legalize the Spanish Communist Party.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 13, 1977

title: Letter  From Home
description: THE FIRST factory that I see from the window when I take the train to New Yorkthe train on which Connecticut dwellers spend, so much of their lifeis one that makes ecclesiastical brasses. That happens, to be a product that I have never thought much about. It isn't that I'm not a churchgoer; I know a chasuble from a versicle. But I just can't picture an ecclesiastical brass.

title: Collector's Mania: If You Love It, You Live With It
description: WHAT MAKES the collector collect? Is it the excitement of the hunt or the lure of the catch? Greed, competition or the instinct to hoard?

title: Florida Senate Rejects Equal Rights Proposal, 2119
description: WASHINGTON, April 13The Florida Senate defeated the equal rights amendment today, and disappointed proponents said that unless there was a major change in the makeup of Southern legislatures next year, the amendment had almost no chance of becoming law.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: MASS EFFORT: In a scene reminiscent of China's massivescale community projects, Laotian civilians dig an irrigation canal near Vientiane without me

title: MOROCCANS IN ZAIRE MAY PLAN OFFENSIVE
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 13Moroccan troops are reported taking positions around the southern coppermining center of Koiwezi in apparent preparation for an offensive against Katangan invaders from Angola.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Briton Asking Direct U.S. Role in the Rhodesia Talks
description: CAPE TOWN, April 13Direct United States participation in a new constitutional conference on Rhodesia, possibly involving a role as coconvenor with Britain, is being proposed by the British Foreign Secretary, David Owen, during his current tour of South Africa.

title: Drug Trafficker Admits Bribing Guard in Escape Of 7 From Federal Jail
description: Ernest Malizia, a convicted narcotics dealer, has pleaded guilty to bribing prison guard and using a prison chaplain to obtain keys for a major escape from the Federal House of Detention in lower Manhattan in 1974.

title: Failure of An Engine Forces Concorde to Land in Canada
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, April 13 (Reuters)An Air France Concorde with 71 passengers aboard landed here today with one engine not working, an airport spokesman said.

title: A Designer's Secret Sources
description: Mere are some of Loquasto's favorite shopping spots

title: Dance: Louis Falco on Relationships
description: THE LOUIS FALCO Dance Company is usually concerned with human relationships, which, in cidentally, are not at all the prime concern of many other dance companies. On Tuesday night, for the second program of its current season at the roundabout Theater, these subjects were treated in three works: BMine by Juan Antonio. the company's associate director, and Mr. Falco's Two Penny Portrait and Caviar.

title: Morgan's Operating Net Is Up 10.4%
description: J. P. Morgan & Company, the first major moneymarket bank to report firstquarter earnings, posted a 10.4 percent gain in operating earnings to $49.5 million from $44.9 million in the 1976 quarter. Among other factors, the gain reflected a general improvement in loan quality at the nation's banks that has accompanied the continuing economic recovery, analysts said.

title: Protesters Break Up An M.T.A. Meeting
description: Protestors demonstrating against the shutdown of certain subway entrances during offpeak hours yesterday forced an early adjournment of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's monthly meeting by shouting down the thembers of the authority.

title: Florida Keys Water Pipe Cut
description: KEY LARGO, Fla., April 13 (UPI)The vital Florida Keys water pipe was ruptured when a car slammed into this morning, and about 250 families in this island chain southwest of Miami were without water for nearly 12 hours. The 18inch pipe, which rests on pilings about three feet off the ground, provides. the only water link with the mainland. Ralph Tudela of Miami apparently fell asleep at the wheel. He was only slightly injured.

title: New England Fishermen Reflect a New Optimism
description: NEW BEDFORD.. Mass.. April 13Mickey Swain remembers a night out on the Georges Bank fishing ground in 1972 when he climbed into the rigging of his fishing boat to look at the catch of one of the 22 big Russian trawlers around him.

title: Killanin, Ill, Is Unable To Join Talks in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, April 13 (AP)As meetings opened on planning the 1980 Summer Olympics here, Lord Killanin, 62yearold president of the International Olympic Committee, was reported resting comfortably in a hospital in his native Ireland after a minor heart attack. Juan Samaranch, 58yearold Spaniard, his most likely successor, was on his way here.

title: British Outrace Americans And Russians to Produce Plastic MiniSubmarine
description: LONDON, April 13 (UPI)British en gineers have beaten the Americans and Russians in the race to build the world's first plastic minisubmarine.

title: Cities Urged to Fight Cuts in Carter's Housing Plan
description: HOBOKEN, April 13Representatives of more than 40 cities were warned today that unless Congressional action was reversed, President Carter's housing plan fordistressed inner cities would be severely restricted. The Senate Budget Committee recently cut $500 million from the President's $400 billion housing package.

title: Soviet Bloc Steps Up Ideology Drivel
description: VIENNA, April 13East European newspapers and broadcasts are stepping up a campaign to depict Western societies, and especially the United States, as mercilessly exploitative.

title: Beame Promises More Protection For Looted Long Island City Plants
description: Mayor Beame promised yesterday to beef up police protection for a Long Island City sector in Queens where plants have been pillaged so frequently by youth gangs that business leaders said they were planning to move from the city.

title: Curbs on Imports Urged At Apparel Union Rally
description: Herald Square, the center of New York's garment industry, resounded yesterday with militant calls for tougher import quotas on clothing and textiles at a union rally against lowwage foreign competition.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Energy Bank Is Urged

title: Henry Ford Expected To Name a Successor
description: DETROIT, April 13  Speculation mounted here today that Henry Ford 2d would announce his suc(lessor as chief executive officer of the Ford Motor Company when the company board of directors holds its regular monthly meeting tomorrow.

title: Westinghouse Net for Quarter Up 12.7% to a Record $53.2 Million
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, entangled in legal disputes over its uranium supply contracts, reported yesterday a firstquarter profit increase of 12.7 percent.

title: DR. FRANCIS STEVENS
description: Dr. Francis Stevens, director of obstetrics and gynecology at Unity Hospital, Brooklyn, died at his Queens home yesterday. He was 52 years old and lived at 139 Beach 141st Street, Belle Harbor.

title: Bond Prices Continue to Advance; Southern Bell Issue Sales Pick Up
description: Bond prices rose yesterday, continuing a trend that got under way late Tuesday when the Treasury disclosed it would pay off in cash some $6.5 billion of shortterm securities that come due next week. The S275 million of Southern Bell Telephone bonds that sold slowly at first on Tuesday picked up Credit some speed yesterday, and Markets underwriters reported the issue twothirds sold.

title: Spain, in Midst of Nuclear Power Buildup, Worries About U.S. Curbs
description: MADRID, April 13The Spanish Government is studying with concern the implications for its own program of President Carter's new restrictive nuclear policy.

title: Schmidt  Warns Germans to Avoid An Excessive Reaction to Slaying
description: BONN April 13West Germany's Chancellor. Helmut Schmidt, speaking at a state funeral in Karlsruhe for the assassinated federal prosecutor called upon his countrymen today not to overre et to terrorist acts.

title: Financing Is Set in New Brunswick To Build $6 Million Office Building
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 13City and business leaders announced today the completion of private financing for a $6 million downtown office building known as Plaza II that they hailed as a first step in this Middlesex County conununity's revitalization.

title: Music: Puccini's Fascinating Edgar
description: GIACOMO PUCCINI'S first two operas, Le Villi and Edgar, are but names in the history books. But last night in Carnegie Hall, Eve Queler and her Opera Orchestra of New York gave us a chance to hear Edgar, which had its premiere in 1889 and has not been heard very often since then.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Connecticut House of Representatives voted 77 to 65 yesterday for a bill to require deposits on all beverage containers and to ban fliptop cans. However, the bottle bill, debated for four consecutive years in the General Assembly, is still stalled in the Senate's Environmental Committee.

title: Hirer at Rap Studio Guilty of Prostitution
description: A State Supreme Court jury in Manhattan yesterday convicted Joe Costello of promoting prostitution at a rap studio called the Intimate Room, at 701 Seventh Avenue. Mr. Costello, who is 36 years old, was arrested last June in one of several raids on midtown massage parlors conducted by the Manhattan District Attorney.

title: Two Seized as Peddlers Of Walking
description: Two brothers who allegedly offered to sell to an undercover Federal agent bornbs that walked, pens that fired 25caliber bullet and other esoteric weapons were arraigned in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday and ordered held in $100,000 bail each.

title: An Ohio Congressman Finds A Gas
description: TOLEDO, April 13To judge by a 12hour day in the hectic life of Thomas Ludlow Ashley, the national issue that most seriously concerns the voters of Ohio's Ninth Congressional District is the prospect of an increase in the Federal gasoline tax and its impact on the economy, both personal and general.

title: Margolis to Conduct Own Defense
description: PALO ALTO., Calif., April 13In a major development, Harry Margolis, a Bay Area tax lawyer, on trial in Federal Court here for conspiracy to defraud the Government out of $1.4 million in fictitious tax deductions, has removed his chief defense attorney and become his own attorney of record.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EASY DOES IT At a time of so much violence, the revival of a beloved old stage romp spoofing murder (offstage) seems apt. Hence Arsensic and Old Lace, to be shown tonight through April 24 at the Equity Library Theater, 103d Street and Riverside Drive. The Howard LindsayRussel Crouse comedy opened on Broadway in 1941 and played here and in London throughout the war. It also became a Cary Grant movie that scuttled one of the stage's brightest endings.

title: I.B.M. EARNINGS RISE ONLY 5.3% IN QUARTER AND STOCK TUMBLES
description: GAIN IN GROSS REVENUE 7.2%

title: G. M. Plans 50% Rise in Chevette Production
description: DETROIT, April 13The General Motors Corporation, expressing belief that sales of small cars would soon turn upward, announced today that it planned to increase production of the Chevette, Chevrolet's minicar, by more than 50 percent on June 27.

title: TV: A Full Day At the White House
description: ON APRIL 4, 1977, John Chancellor and an NBC News production staff put in a full day at the White House monitoring President Carter, from 6 A.M. wakeup phone call with weather report to final goodnights at 11:25 P.M., following dinner for Egypt's President Anwar elSadat. With a small transmitter hooked on his belt, President Carter had wireless microphone clipped to his tie. An onoff switch gave him complete control over his conversations. And unlike another President confronted with tape recorders, Mr. Carter chose to do some selective editing.

title: Books of The Times
description: IGUESS IT WAS the squid that got methe squid that surrounded Lyall Watson's wooden prau in the Banda Sea, east of Bali, and blinked their phosphorescent messages until some larger luminescence rose from the depths to disperse them. The squid  and the gobies, which are little torpedoshaped fish with the ability to leap from one lowtide pool to another like guided skipping stones. And also the legend of the weeping sea turtle that bunt mr. Watson's pseudonymous island of Nus Tarian, as well as all the other Indonesia islands, for want of a place to lay her eggs. Something, at any rate, drew me into and on through Gifts of Unknown Things, an attempt to reconcile the physical and the mystical by an English ethologist who once worked under Desmond Morris at the London Zoo. I anticipated, perhaps, a book like Annie Dillard's Pilgrim at Tinker Creek, or Lewis Thomas's The Lives of a Cell, or Loren Eiseley's The Immense Journey, all of which Mr. Watson invokes in his list of sourcebooks at the end of Gifts.

title: Simmons and Hernandez Connect for CardinalsSwan Absorbs Defeat
description: They caught Lou Brock stealing second base and Joe Torre pinch hit a home run but apart from that, the New York Mets lapsed through an afternoon of negatives yesterday as they dropped a 73 decision to the rousing St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Simplified Disclosures Asked by S. E. C. Advisory Unit
description: WASHINGTON, April 13An advisOry group to the Securities and Exchange Commission is preparing to recommend to the commission that it move quickly to eliminate or simplify n any 01 the documents it requires from public corporations.

title: California Defense Industry Receives Highest Total in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)California industries received 53.2 billion in prime defense contract awards in the last three months of 1976, the highest total of any state, a Pentagon report showed today.

title: Israelis Increasing Pressure to Force Rabin Out Quickly
description: JERUSALEM, April 13Pressure is increasing here for the immediate revision of an Israeli law that has barred until the elections May 17 the resignation of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin because he is presiding over a caretaker administration.

title: Hear America
description: EIGHTEEN SONGS by five composers and an extended work combining song and speech by yet another composer were given first performances by five singers and a pianist in the Hear America First concert in the chapel of Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church on Tuesday night.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended March 31 unless otherWISe Indicated. (N) indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Ex. change, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: ALFALFA TREATMENT RAISES PLANT YIELDS
description: Scientists at Michigan State University have found a way to increase the growth of many kinds of food plants by 10 to 40 percent by treating the soil or the plant with trace amounts of a highly potent substance isolated from alfalfa hay.

title: At Your Service: Caring for Rugs and Floors
description: GIVE A floor a new finish or wash out years of dust from an old rug and an entire room can take on new life.

title: Deaths
description: ABBOTTAlice. Greatly beloved wife of Wainwright Abbott. Suddenly on April 9 at Dublin, Ireland.

title: ERA, TO ALLOW SALE OF SACCHARIN AS DRUG
description: WASHINGTON, April 13The Food and Drug Administration plans to announce tomorrow that it will continue to permit bulk sales of saccharin in tablet or powder form but will stand by its proposal to ban the use of the artificial sweetener in prepared foods and beverages.

title: CLARENCE M. WOODBURY
description: Clarence M. Woodbury, a freelance magazine writer, died Tuesday at the Northport, N. Y., Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 78 years old and a resident of Centerport, N. Y.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Como Study Seeks Way to Predict Recoveries
description: An international team of experts on coma is completing a critical phase in a study that began seven years ago and is expected to change the way braindamaged patients such as Karen Anne Quinlan are treated in the early course of hospitalization.

title: NEW YORK G.O.P. FILLS TWO COMMITTEE JOBS
description: GUILDERLAND, N.Y., April 13Bereft of the guidance of Nelson A. Rockefeller for the first time in almost two decades, New York Republicans filled the state's male slot on the National Committee today, then squabbled long but decorously over a female counterpart.

title: LEROY GORE, EDITOR, IS DEAD IN WISCONSIN
description: Leroy Gore, the Middle Western newspaper editor who started the Joe Must Goe, campaign to recall the late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, died yesterday at the Countryside Home, a nursing facility in Jefferson, Wis.

title: A Correction: Lunda, Not Luba
description: In seeking yesterday to make everything clear about the fighting and assorted interventions in Zaire, we managed to compound the confusion by mixing up two tribal groups of the secessionminded province Shaba, formerly Katanga. Both groups, the Luba and the Lunda, resent the central Government of General Mobutu and would prefer an independent existence, based on their copper wealth, to union with the large but poor country of Zaire. The militants who spearhead the fighting, however, and who recently invaded Shaba with a force of about 5,000 from neighboring Angola, are Lunda, not Luba, people. In further clarification, be it noted that their adversaries, the Kongo, are divided into related groupings living in Zaire and Angola; the Angola branch is closely allied with General Mobutu, but his tribe is the Ngbandi.

title: Coma Study Seeks Ways to Predict Recoveries
description: An international team of experts on coma is completing a critical phase in a study that began seven years ago and is expected to change the way braindamaged patients such as Karen Anne Quinlan are treated in the early course of hospitalization.

title: The New York Times/Norman Peagam
description: MASS EFFORT: In a scene reminiscent of China's massivescale community projects, Laotian civilians dig an irrigation canal near Vientiane without mechanized help. Even the nation's Prime Minister, Kaysone Phomvihan, wielded a shovel to help the workers, described as volunteers from the capital.

title: Bridgeport Fronton Gets 4 Extra Days in Season
description: BRIDGEPORT, April 13The Connecticut Gaming Commission granted the Bridgeport JaiAlai Fronton four extra dates today, extending the season to May 3. The dates will be used for matinees on April 28 and May 2 and evenings on May 2 and 3.

description: A settlement in the longcontested multimilliondollar estate of J. J. Shubert, a founder of a nationwide theater and realestate empire, was announced yesterday.

title: A Diplomatic Cover
description: WASHINGTON, April 13If Gerald Ford were President now, and he picked for a vital ambassadorship man who had directed secret bombing in Indochina and said Richard Nixon had the right to make war without authority from Congress, would Democratic Senators silently accept, the choice? If he picked a man who played a key role in sending U.S. Marines into the Dominican Republic in 1965, would the press murmur approval?

title: World News Briefs
description: PARIS, April 13 (AP)Paul Goma, the Rumanian dissident writer, has been arrested in Bucharest and eight other dissidents have been sent to work camps for a year, the French Committee for the Defense of Freedom in Rumania said today.

title: Beyond Bebop; ANA CHRONIC JAZZ BAND. Open (0P02).
description: Ever since the vindictive battles between the Moldy Figs and the beboppers erupted in the mid1940's, the jazz world has been split into two irreconcilable camps. On one side are the followers of preWorld War II jazz styles, primarily traditional New Orleans and Chicago jazz, although in recent years the swing bands have also been included. On the other side are the bebop revolutionaries of the 40's and everything else that has followed jazz since then.

title: Stage: Great MacDaddy
description: THREE years agoor just about the Negro Ensemble Company produced a most interesting black musical called The Great MacDaddy. It was written by Paul Carter Harrison and had music by ColeridgeTaylor Perkinson. Last night, at its new home at the Theater de Lys, the N.E.C. staged what it said was a revised version. Possiblyit looked pretty similar to me, However, it had, with one exception, a completely different cast, and it is a show important enough to justify any amount of restaging.

description: Yes, Virginia, there is a Santa Clausand Aqueduct does have a 1mile main track on which horses can run. They'll start doing it today at 5:30 A.M., when the troublesome main racing surface is opened to equine trattic for the first time in four months. It was supposed to be ready for us more than three weeks ago, on March 21. But soft spots in the base of the straightaway chute that leads into the backstretch kept the big track closed. title: Cubs to Wear Armbands
description: CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) The Chicago Cubs will wear black armhands this season in memory of Philip K. Wrigley, the man whose family name adorns their field. Wrigley, 82 years old, who owned the Cubs and was also owner of the world's largest chewing gum company, died of a gastrointestinal hemorrhage yesterday at Lakeland Hospital in Elkhorn, Wis.

Behind them are gleaming vases, some over four feet high, carved from black or dark red solid lacquer and brilliantly decorated with flowers and birds, or subtly painted with red or orange dragons.

description: WASHINGTON, April 13The State Department said today that the United States was seeking, through intense diplomatic activity, to stabilize the situation along the IsraeliLebanese border so that southern Lebanon could be brought under the effective authority of the Government of President Elias Sarkis.

title: Giselle Wins With Tracks
description: For over a century the hapless Giselle has been the perpetual victim in the ballet of the same name, but she startingly turned the tables Tuesday evening and won. What she was never able to achieve at the Paris Opera Ballet, starting in 1841, she managed at the Palace Theater with the choreographic assistance of Les Ballets Trock. adero de Monte Carlo &11 travestie. It was a triumph of special sensibilities over sense.

title: Wild Strawberries Return
description: AS A youngster, I used to wander the summer meadows of Sweden in search of wild strawberries. Now Ingmar Bergman aside, wild strawberries do have an underlying symbolic significance in the Scandinavian north country, being psychological harbingers of the summer season's relaxed and dreamlike tranquillity. In my particular case, the symbolism invoked mild fright along with palatine joy, for the biggest collection of berry plants I knew grew along the sunny side of an old sand pit, a spot also frequented by some rather fearsomesized vipers with less than benevolent qualities.

title: Piano Bar's Choirboy
description: The innocenteyed choirboy face of Steve Ross peering over the piano that he plays at Backstage, 3IS West 45th Street, is a deceptive but provocative setting for the songs that he sings. In his songs, Mr. Ross walks a fine line between a subtle hint of mockery and a serious involvement in the lyrics, between complete acceptance of a sunny, sentimental song and a forthright comic eruption.

title: The Promise and Price of Coal
description: It is by now an axiom that a sound energy policy must start with conservation. That is the essential first step. But if dependence on foreign oil is to be minimized and if the United States is to maintain even a moderate growth rate, conservation will not be nearly enough; there will have to be an expanded production of domestic fuels.

title: The Payoff

Deductibles aside, payment is generally made on a depreciated basis, A TV set, for example, might be arbitrarily assigned a life of seven years. If the set is two years old, the householder can expect to recover only fivesevenths of its cost.

description: NOBODY PLAYS LISZT'S Harmonies Poetiques et Religieuses complete at one recital. Or almost nobody, for David Bean did it Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. The 10section piano work represents Liszt in.: his most religious mood, if not always his most poetic, which explains why the only piece from the cycle that is at all_ wellknown is Funerallles.

You did not come to this university to become a welfare recipient or freeloader, Mr. Benson said. When you accept food stamps, you accept an unearned handout that other people are navine for.

description: KANSAS CITY, April 13Manager Billy Martin devised his third batting order 4n the season's fifth game tonight, but it thethree players who have remained in fixed spots who produced the Yankees 53 victory over Kansas City.

title: It's Not just Because the Man
description: A GREAT MANY people are expressing their astonishment, and their gratitude, that director Frank Dunlop should have been able to reach out and pull together so many fine actors on such very short. notice for two productionsand the beginnings of a repertory arrangement at the Brookyn Academy of Music. So many oddities. Where did he find the actors? How did he persuade them to take time off from films, television and other profitable pursuits to devote themselves to doing one unknown American play, The New York Idea, and one difficult Chekhov, The Three Sisters'? How did he know they'd work so well togather without an extended period of training that would help them to become acquainted with one another's habits, mannerisms, rhythms?

title: Syrian Aide COming to U.S.

Vance, it was officially announced here today. He will also meet President Carter during his twoday visit. The visit will follow a trip by President Hafez alAssad to the Soviet Union.

title: Aide Says Liquor Was Smuggled Into TRW Center

Students in the production are 7 to 18 years old. Admission is $3 for adults, $1 for students.

It is Sally Little's explosion shot from a greenside bunker on the 72d hole of the 1976 Women's International. The ball rolled into the hole, 75 feet away, for a birdie 3 and a onestroke victory.

Things of this world offer glimpses of another, and that other, often hallucinatory, surreal, nightmarish, even angelic, invades this one. The universe, he writes, is broken into minds. There is a kind of pantheism in these poems. Every

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Does it matter if, as seems to be the case, Roots is filled with inaccuracies? For the tens of millions who were moved by the book and by the unprecedentedly popular television version, probably none of the recent criticisms of Alex Haley's work count for much. Americans, white and black, responded to the appeal of the saga of Kunta Kinte's journey from his home in Africa to slavery in America, and they found inspiration in a black author's search for his ancestors and the heritage of his people.

title: Crafts Demonstration At Rizzoli Festival

title: CORRECTIONS

title: Out of Doors
description: CLOCKS, perhaps more than any other machines, have molded our world and shaped our minds. We rise when the clock says we should, eat when the clock says we should, and retire when the clock says we should. We believe that the clock reflects some integral part of the universe called time, which exists independently of our measuring it. This prepares us for the idea that the world is measurable. Lewis Mumford calls the clock the key machine of the modern industrial age.
