description: The Now York Times/Edward Hausner

title: BEAME AND GOVERNOR SPLIT ON CANDIDACY OF CUOMO FOR MAYOR
description: Mayor Beanie broke openly yesterday with Governor Carey and charged that Mr. Carey's support of Mario M. Cuomo in the race for the Democratic mayoral nomination represented an effort to control City Hall.

title: Daddy Bluegrass Comes to the City
description: Erect and austere, Bill Monroe is to bluegrass what Charles de Gaulle was to the Fifth Republic: he wrote the script, and it would sometimes seem that the entire system would disintegrate five minutes after he is gone. But after nearly 40 years as the recognized premier bluegrass musician, Mr. Monroe is probably entitled.

title: F.A.A. Prohibits Airlines
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)Airlines will no longer be allowed to deny seats to handicapped persons by arguing that the handicapped might get in the way during an evacuation, the Federal Aviation Administration says.

title: Music: Guitar Fluency From Barrueco
description: MANUEL BARRUECO, a Cuban who is now on the faculty of the Manhattan School of Music, exemplifies a new generation of classical guitarists. His playing at Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night was that of scrupulous musician and a sensitive one.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: There have been several analyses recently by international agencies and private sources that conveyed a sense of disappointment and concern over the state of the Western world's economic situation. They focused on the pace of the recovery abroad, the further rise of unemployment in some Economic countries, the renewed inScene flationary pressure in others, the slowing of world trade and the growth of protectionist sentiment.

title: Subsidized New Canaan Housing Gains Approval of Town Council
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 14The New Canaan Town Council gave final approval last night to plans for this affluent community's first federally subsidized housing project for lowand middleincome residents.

title: ZAIRE BLAMES SOVIET FOR RAID ON ZAMBIA
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 14President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire today accused the Soviet Union of bombing a mission hospital in Zambia, an attack that reportedly took place three days ago and for which Zaire has been blamed.

title: Management
description: Why is there such a high turnover in the computer programming department? a spokesman for Pitney Bowes Inc. was asked this week.

title: A New Life for the Bowery
description: THE BOWERY between Houston Stret and Cooper Square was as warm with people last Sunday at midnight, an hour when you might assume the shabby old thoroughfare would be deserted and wrapped in memories of its yesteryears as New York's show business center. But this is the new Bowery. A crowd of young people, as many as 1,000 of them, were milling about the front of a nightclub at 315 Bowery off Bleeker Street called CBGB and Omfug (the full nameCountry Iiiiue Grass Blues and Other Music for Uplifting Gourmandisershas been as forgotten by its rock partisans as the policy that gave birth to it).

title: Wesley L. Fishel, a Professor, Dies; Leading Advocate of Vietnam War
description: Wesley L. Fishel, a Michigan State political science professor who became a leading academic advocate of American involvement in Vietnam, died yesterday at the Sparrow Hospital in Lansing. He was 57 years old and had entered the hospital last week.

title: L I. DOCTOR WHO LOST LICENSE GOT BACKING
description: Had Admitted Misconduct, but Was Recommended by Colleagues for Practice in Michigan

title: Tass Hits Easing of Liddy Term
description: MOSCOW, April 14 (AP)The Soviet press agency Tass criticized President Carter today for reducing the prison term of G. Gordon Liddy, convicted for burglary in the Watergate affair, from 20 years to eight years. American prisons are filled with political prisoners and no one intends to free them in the interests of justice, Tass said. Mr. Liddy has served more than four years for planning the 1972 Watergate breakin. The Carter decision will make him eligible for parole in July.

title: Diamond Shamrock Raising Price. Of Several Plastic Items May
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation's plastic division announced yesterday an acrossthebroad price increase of 1 cent a pound for polyvinyl chloride, suspension resins and multiscrew powder pipe compounds, effective May 1. Singlescrew powder pipe compounds will increase by 11/4 cents a pound the same date.

title: Communist Leadership Meets Legally in Madrid After 4 Decades
description: MADRID, April 14The Central Committee of the newly legalized Communist Party today held its first meeting in Spain since the Civil War as rightwing politicians maneuvered to oppose its legality.

title: Fed Money Supply Is Up Sharply, With Mix of Elation and Caution
description: The nation's money supply expanded sharply in the week ended April 6, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: MAMARONECK  named by Indians, planted by Britans, home to Italian immigrant masons and American blacks ore the Civil Warremains something of an island in a sea of Westchester suburbs.

title: YONKERS CONTROL BOARD APPROVES BOND ISSUING
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 14The Yonkers Emergency Financial Control Board today approved the city's first attempt since its narrow brush with default last year to return to the normal borrowing market.

title: Miss Beene Named as Coach
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 14 (AP)Catherine Beene, tennis pro at the University Club in Houston, was named today as women's tennis coach at the University of Texas.

title: Missile Fired From B.52
description: CAPE CANAVERAL. Fla., April 14 (UPI)  A shortrange attack missile carying a dummy warhead was fired successfully today from a B52 bomber. the Air Force said. A spokesman said that the missile had performed perfectly and the dummy warhead hit a target area in the Atlantic Ocean. The bomber was flying near Grand Turk Island, about 70 miles south of. Cape Canaveral, when it launched the airto surface missile.

title: ExBrunswick Head Held Genesco Choice
description: John L. Hanigan, the retired chairman and chief executive officer of the Brunswick Corporation, is expected to be named president and chief executive officer of Genesco Inc. at that company's board meeting on April 27, informed sources said yesterday.

title: Carter Energy Plan Outlined to Officials
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)President Carter and his chief energy adviser outlined the Administration's forthcoming energy plan today to several governors, local officials and state legislators. The meeting was designed to give the officials their last chance to object to the energy plan before it goes to Capitol Hill next Wednesday.

title: IMPORTS OF CRUDE OIL CLIMB SLIGHTLY IN WEEK
description: The American Petroleum Institute was down slightly from the week before, reported yesterday that daily crude oil but remained at a higher letel than in the well ahead of last year's levels.

title: McKee Gets Soviet Job
description: Arthur G. McKee & Company said it received a $25 million contract from the Ross Laboratories division of Abbott Laboratories to provide engineering services for an infantformula plant to be built in the Soviet Union. McKee said the project was expected to be completed by 1981.

title: Bell Considers Antitrust Weapons
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today that the Justice Department's experience in trying to bring antitrust suits under Section 2 of the Sherman Act suggested that such cases might simply be too large and too lengthy for courts to handle, and that legislative remedies might be needed instead.

title: All Divisions of the Continental Group Contribute to Record 32% Profit Gain on 8% Rise in Sales in Quarter
description: The Continental Group Inc., the nation's leading producer of metal cans, reported yesterday firstquarter earnings increased 32 percent on an 8 percent sales gain.

title: Checkez les Brakes? A Tough Job Ahead For Quebec Schools
description: MONTREAL, April 14If Johnny can't read and has trouble writing, Tie, his teachers and his parents may be consoled by the knowledge that here in Quebec, Jean is not doing much better. In fact, Jean has some special, problems in speaking. The linguistic difficulties of Quebec children are complicated in ways that their American counterparts have never experienced. Language in Quebec is a political and emotional issue and his aspect has just been highlighted by publication of a new policy asserting esssentially that French is the province's only language.

title: A Toast to the First Printer in English
description: The 20thcentury's information explosion, in English at least, owes much to William Caxton, the 15thcentury publisher, printer, translator, advertiser and seller of books. Just 500 years ago the first pages printed on English soil came clattering off his wooden press at the sign of the Red Pale in Westminster. The anniversary will be enthusiastically observed all day tomorrow, beginning at 9:30 A.M., in A Caxton Celebration at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 120th Street.

title: At the Movies
description: Guy Flatley

title: Probate Court Told That Hughes's Mental Faculties Were Unimpaired
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 14Attorney General John Hill of Texas reported today to a Probate Court judge in Houston that Howard Hughes's mental faculties were not impaired by neurological disease when he died on April 5, 1976.

title: About Real Estate
description: The Beame administration is moving toward loosening the vise on taxdelinquent property.

title: Northrop Says Affiliate Made Dubious Payments
description: The Northrop Corporation said yesterday a subsidiary corporation paid $1.56 million in fees and commissions that may have gone to foreign government officials.

title: Babcock &
description: The Babcock & Wilcox Company said that the Ohio Division of Securities had concluded that the United Technologies Corporation's proposed tender offer for Babcock & Wilcox constituted a takeover bid and that the division had granted the request of Babcock for hearing under the Ohio takeover statute.

title: Suspended Lieutenant And Police Department Achieve a Settlement
description: A settlement has been reached in dispute between the Police Department and a suspended lieutenant who had been accused of failing to act on his knowledge that prostitution was going on in a bar.

title: Carter News Parley On at 10 A.M. Today
description: The three television networks and their local stations  WCBS, WNBC and WABC  are scheduled to televise live today President Carter's news conference starting at 10 A.M. There will be live coverage on radio stations WCBSAM, WINS, WMCA, WNBC and WNYCAM.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 15, 1977

title: One China, Still Divisible
description: The disclosure that President Nixon told the Chinese in 1972 of his intention to normalize relations with Peking during his second term opens a small window on history. But it changes nothing in the ChineseAmerican relationship. The question was and remains how the two Governments can navigate diplomatically around their rival concerns for Taiwan.

title: Arson Suspected in Jersey Fire
description: WESTWOOD, N.J., April 14 (AP)A warehouse fire that claimed the life of a volunteer fireman in this Bergen County community was caused by arson, the police said. The Comfort Coal and Lumber Company building, abandoned since 1974, was destroyed Tuesday afternoon by blaze in which more than 20 people were overcome by heat and smoke, authorities said.

title: A Giant Baseball Bat Sculpture Dedicated in Chicago Ceremony
description: CHICAGO, April 14Sculptor Claes Oldenburg's Batcolurnn, Chicago's retort to the Eiffel Tower, was dedicated by Joan Mondale today in ceremonies in front of the new Social Security Building.

title: Credit Suisse Loses $100 Million In Unauthorized Deals at Branch
description: ZURICH, April 14 (AP)Credit Suisse, Switzerland's third largest commercial bank, announced today that it had lost as much as 250 million francs, or $100 million, in unauthorized dealings between one of its branches and a major foreign client.

title: Recovery and Inflation Killed Plan for Rebate
description: WASHINGTON, April 14The Administration's decision to abandon the $50 tax rebatealthough there perhaps were political considerasions as wellcame after a steady parade of statistics showing unmistakably

title: Sales of OldCrop Soybeans Send Futures Prices Down Daily Limit
description: Active selling of oldcrop (1976) soybeans again drove futures prices down to the daily limit of 30 cents a bushel yesterday in an abbreviated session on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Argentina Announces 15 Arrests In Economic Crime
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 14 (UPI)The Argentine Army today announced the arrest of 15 personsincluding three members of the family of financier David Graiverfor an investigation of economic crimes.

title: Fashion or FundRaising, There's Just One Blass
description: Too bad Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr. missed the fashion show at Bergdorf's the other night. There, on the runway, was something that the State Department's former chief of protocol doesn't see every night: His wife in a sevenyearold dress.

title: Reports of Carter Energy Plan Arouse Strong Criticism From Affected Industries
description: The reaction from three industries to reports of President Carter's energy proposals has been swift and strongly worded. Detroit is said to be in a state of something close to fear. The coal industry has called the plan policy that is not going to work. And the oil industry has expressed shock and outrage.

title: Manufacturers Hanover Earnings Up 24.8%
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation reported a 24.8 percent gain in firstquarter operating earnings yesterday.

title: New Face
description: Robert Fortier is not your usual Hollywoodactorontherise. For one thing, he has spent most of the last 15 years working, as a commercial fisherman in Hawaii. For another, he's 50 years old.

title: Sylvester, Cellist, Joins Cleveland Quartet Concert
description: Robert Sylvester, cellist, will be guest artist with the Cleveland Quartet in a concert tomorrow at 8:30 P.M., repeated Sunday at 2 P.M., in the Lepercq Space at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue. Tickets, $5, may be bought at the box office.

title: U.S. Says It Is Willing to CoSponsor a4 New Conference on Rhodesia
description: WASHINGTON, April 14The Carter Administration, in a significant policy move, announced today that it was willing to serve as cosponsor with Britain of a new Geneva conference on Rhodesia.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Spring's Model Rooms Furnish Fantasy for the Buyers and the Browsers
description: The painter made up with the carpenter. The fabric manufacturer made up with his partner. The last flowers got arranged. The thresholds got painted, The rhinorceroses reared their heads on carpeted walls. That annual rite of spring was celebrated the other nightthe opening of Bloomingdale's model rooms.

title: Election in West Bengal Reflects Widespread Desire for a Change
description: BARRACKPORE, India Sudhir Kumar Ghose, who is 28 years old and has been unemployed for seven years, has voted twice in the last five years, each time for a different party.

title: Britain for Open Olympics
description: LONDON, April 14  Britain, through its Sports Council, called today for an open Olympics and an end to the distinction between amateurs and professionals in all major interatioal sports.

title: Money
description: Thursday. Anril 14. 1977

title: CHUCK COLLINS, 73, FOOTBALL END, DEAD
description: Charles C. Collins, one of the Seven Mules on the famous Notre Dame football team of 1924, a former president of the National Carloading Corporation, and village attorney in Ridgewood, N.J., died yesterday at the Valley Hospital in Ric gewood after a brief illness. He was 73 years old.

title: Art: NewWorks by Jack Tworkov
description: JACK TWORKOV has been one of the best painters around for a very long time. His is a quiet and reflective nature, and the idea of making a career would never enter his head. So it should be said that without ever in any way seeking to put himself forward he has indeed had a very distinguished career  and one that is furthered and enriched by his show of new paintings at the Nancy Hoffman Gallery, 429 West Broadway.

title: Come Dancing in the Balkans
description: The drone of Spanish bagpipes and the whirl of Yugloslav couple dancers will fill the Hunter College Assembly Hall tomorrow night in one of the highlights of a heady weekend for fans of ethnic music and dance. Two events are scheduled.

title: On Crass Overemphasis of Money
description: A letter from a reader who may or may not be a baseball fan deplores the recent crass overemphasis on the purely commercial aspects of the sports. The reader adds: Maybe professional sport [particularly baseball] as some us remember it, has outlived its usefulness. Not even television may rescue it for long, once the ratings begin decline.

title: Say It Ain't So, Pat
description: WASHINGTON, April 14Ever since the beginnings of democratic government, the representatives of the people in Parliament or Congress have puzzled over a fundamental philosophical question: whether to vote for the special interests of the people who elected them, or for the larger interests of the nation.

title: Letters
description: In Nearby Woods

title: Notes on People
description: If he can get away Governor Carey hopes to fly to Dublin on April 22 to deliver a lecture on subjects close to his heart. It's the Harry O'Flanagan Lecture at the Royal College of Surgeons in Dublin, the Governor said. It's a high honor which no American has yet received, and I would plan to speak to the conditions in Northern Ireland on human rights and the politics of death that prevails unfortunately in that country. On his mother's side the Governor's family comes from County Tyrone, on his father's side from County Galway.

title: Blue Jays Tame Tigers
description: Those new kids on the block just don't have any respect for their betters.

title: Cambodians Mark 2d Year of Victory
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Friday April 15 (Agence FrancePresse)The Cambodian radio reported today that the population assembled from 7 A.M. on public squares throughout the country to celebrate the second anniversary of the Khmer Rouge victory of April 1975.

title: Howatt Takes Thrust Out of Sabres
description: Football has its monster men. Baseball has its designated hitter. Basketball has its sixth man. What the Islanders have is Garry Howatt.

title: Ruland Is Recruiting Coup for Ions
description: When Wayne McKoy announces today that he will attend school and play basketball at St. John's University, metropolitan college basketball will take a giant step forward. But St. John's will not be alone. Tiny Iona College in New Rochelle is on the path toward being a national power, too.

title: Kingston Trio at Caldwell
description: The Kingston Trio will perform tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. in the Campus Center Auditorium at Caldwell College in Caldwell, N.J. Tickets$12.50 for reserved seats, $10 for general admission  may he bought at the door. The college is on Ryerson Avenue, just otf Bloomfield Avenue. For information or reservations: (201) 2284424.

title: Charities
description: John S. Burke Jr., chairman of the board of B. Altman and Company, has been appointed chairman of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity, fundrasing arm for Catholic Charities of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. He succeeds the late John A. Coleman, chairman from 1944 until his death Feb. 23. The committee, with a membership of 500, solicits special gifts from individuals to help support the service programs of Catholic Charities.

title: Broadway
description: IT HAS SCARCELY been a secret that Philip Langner, the president of The Theatre Guild, has yearned to produce a play about Golda Meir, or that he wooed her for years to get the rights to her autobiography. The news that William Gibson has written the script for the play, Golda, or that Arthur Penn is to direct it, has not been hidden under a bushel, either. What is news, however, is that now Mr. Langner has signed Anne Bancroft to star in Golda. If this makes you think of a couple of old triumphs, then your memory is absolutely correct.

title: Coal Spokesman Says President Is Meeting His Show Business
description: WASHINGTON, April 14The chief spokesman for the coal industry complained today that from what was known of President Carter's new energy policy the plan failed to make any important environmental concessions on the use of. coal and mainly meets the show business needs of the Administration to look like it is doing something.

title: SOME OIL MEN FEAR A SHARP RECESSION
description: HOUSTON, April 14Oil industry officials today expressed apprehension, dismay and even shock over the apparent direction of the Carter Administration's energy policies.

title: 1.4% MARCH INCREASE IN INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT BIGGEST IN 19 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)The nation's industrial output rose 1.4 percent in March, the biggest gain in 19 months, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney reports that economists at Citibank, in their latest analysis, maintain that the picture abroad is not so clouded as some recent discussions have indicated. Page D9.

title: Almaden Sets Price on Stock
description: Almaden Vineyards Inc. announced that its board of directors, including a special committee of outside directors, had agreed with National Distillers and Chemical Corporation on a price of $12.25 a share for shars in the hands of public stockholders. The payment would be made upon consummation of a proposed statutory merger whereby Almaden would become a wholly owned subsidiary of National Distillers. National Distillers now owns 80.4 percent of Almaden's stock.

title: Retail Store Sales Gain 9%
description: WASHINGTON, April 14The Department of Commerce reported today that total retail sales iast week were an estimated $13.79 billion, up 9 percent from last year's $12.63 billion. Department store sales were about $1.48 billion, up 20 percent from the year earlier $1.23 billion.

title: Puccini Western
description: Ogden Nash and Kurt Weill once wrote a song called Way Out West in Jersey. so what could be more natural than that Puccini's The Girl of the Golden West should turn up in Newark tomorrow night at 8 o'clock. The opera is being staged in Symphony Hall by the New Jersey State Opera.

title: Art: Gunter Grass, Portraitist
description: THERE ARE talents that overflow conventional boundaries separating one realm of the arts from another, and Giinter Gruos's is apparently one of them. Mr. Grass is widely regarded as the leading German novelist of his generationthe generation that came to maturity in the aftermath of World IIand several of his books, especially The Tin Drum and Dog Years, have enjoyed an international readership and acclaim. As an articulate Social Democrat, he has also been active in West German politics, at once a critic and spokesman of liberal values. Few who have followed his literary and political exploits are probably aware that he originally set out to become a sculptor, and that he has in fact continued to pursue an ardent interest in the visual

title: Ford Revamps Top Management But Leaves Succession in Doubt
description: DEARBORN, Mich., April 14Directors of the Ford Motor Company, the nation's second largest automobile producer after the General Motors Corporation, approved a topmanagement reorganization plan today that considerably clouds the debate over who will eventually succeed Henry Ford 2d as chairman and chief executive officer when he retires five years from now.

title: INFLATION IS FEARED
description: WASHINGTON, April 14President Carter announced today that he was abandoning his proposal for a $50  tax rebate for individuals because he feared it would fuel inflation and because he felt that it was no longer necessary to stimulate the economy.

title: Everett, Escalera in Rematch
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 14 (AP)Tyrone Everett of Philadelphia will fight Alfredo Escalera of Puerto Rico May 16 in a rematch for the World Boxing Cbuncil's juniorlightweight championship. The 15round bout is planned as part of a closedcircuit doubleheader, including the heavyweight title fight in Landover, Md., between Muhammad All and Alfrdo Evangelista of Spain. Escalera defeatd Everett Nov. 30 for the title in a split decision.

title: WALL ST. DELIGHTED
description: The nation's financial markets gave President Carter a resounding vote of approval yesterday for deciding to withdraw the $50 tax rebate. Stock prices rose sharply in the heaviest trading of the year.

title: 15 WASHINGTON PRESSMEN ACCEPT REDUCED CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)In exchange for guilty pleas to serious misdemeanor charges, Federal prosecutors dropped felony counts today against 15 former Washington Post pressmen, United States Attorney's spokesman said.

title: Dance: The True Pearl Lang
description: PEARL LANG and Dance Company opened Wednesday night at Kaufmann Concert Hall for an engagement that will pick up again tomorrow at 8 P.M. and on Sunday with performances at 2 P.M. and 630.

title: Alan Wood's Creditors To Postpone Payments
description: The Alan Wood Steel Company announced that holders of its major long term debt had agreed to postpone all principal and interest payments due on May 31 through Oct. 1. The company said the postponed payments would be on a demand basis until Nov. 30, when they are due and Payable.

title: The Standings
description: Friday, April 15, 1977

title: Army Says Part of Its Tank Ammunition, Including Some Sold to Israel and 12 Other Countries, Is Defective
description: WASHINGTON, April 14The Army has found that some of its stockpiles of 105 millimeter tank ammunition are defective, as well as portions of supplies it sold to Israel and 12 other foreign nations the Defense Department said today.

title: Margolis Will Resign as Member Of State Financial Control Board
description: David I. Margolis, the president of Colt Industries, said yesterday that he would resign in the next few months as a member of the State Emergency Financial Control Boardcreating the, third expected vacancy for Governor Carey to fill at a time of increasing political tension between Mr. Carey and Mayor Beame.

title: NursingHorne Talks Continue As Strike Deadline Approaches
description: Negotiations to avert a strike at 67 private nursing homes in New York City continued early today. The strike had been called for 6 o'clock this morning.

title: Head of Labor Board Appointed by Carter
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)President Carter today designated John H. Fanning to take over the chairmanship of the National Labor Relations Board from the present chairman, Betty Southard Murphy. Mr. Fanning has been a member of the board since 1957.

title: People in Sports
description: In case you were in Boston Wednesday night and took Boston Independent Taxi Owners Association cab No. 352 and thought you recognized the driver, you did. Yes, that was Dave Cowens, the Celtics 6foot9inch star center. He was relieving some tension between National Basketball Association playoff games.

title: Singapore Detention Described
description: SINGAPORE, April 14 (Reuters)Arun Senkuttuvan, Singapore correspondent of The Financial Times and The Economist, both of London, said today that he was kept in solitary confinement for five weeks in a Singapore detention center. He was released yesterday after two months with nine other political detainees accused of proCommunist activities.

title: Bridge:
description: McAFEE, N.J., April 14Winning two major titles in two clays was the achievement of three experts at the American Bridge Association's Spring Nationals here this week.

title: INFLATION IS FEARED
description: WASHINGTON, April 14President Carter announced today that he was abandoning his proposal, for a $50 tax rebate for individuals because he feared it would fuel Inflation and because he felt that it was no longer necessary to stimulate the economy.

title: Church's Chicken Splits Stock:
description: Church's Fried Chicken, the fastfood chain, has split the common stock 3for2 and also declared a 15 cents quarterly dividend on the new shares, payable June 10 to holders of record May 27. The new rate amounts to a 50 percent increase from the presplit shares on which the company had been paying 15 cents quarterly.

title: JetsMetsCity. Battle Returned to State
description: In what was described by lawyers as a procedural matter rather than a victory for anybody, a Federal judge yesterday ordered the battle royal among the Jets, Mets and New York City returned to State Supreme Court.

title: Rhodesia Signing Up Men Over 38
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 14 (AP)Thousands of Rhodesian men aged 38 to 50 were ordered to register for national service today in an effort to strengthen the armed forces in the fouryearold war against black nationalist guerrillas. The order is the forerunner of a new drive to absorb older white men, men of mixed race and Asians into the security forces. Blacks are not included.

title: Bryant Park for the People
description: Just as the New York public library building on Fifth Avenue itself does, most New Yorkers have long since turned their backs on Bryant Park. A few people from surrounding office buildings still walk through the park, but their enjoyment of it is diminished by the inevitable derelicts draped over benches and by toughs who drink from brown paperwrapped bottles and glare menacingly at them.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: The phrase is don't bellyache"don't complain unnecessarily. It's a reflection of how parents sometimes view their children's stomach and intestinal problems. They suspect that the ailments aren't real, just some kind of cleverly manipulative way of getting out of doing something unpleasant, such as going to school.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Services for Steven Derounian To Be Held in Garden City Today
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 14Sere ices will be held here tomorrow at the Cathedral of the Incarnation for Steven Blake Derounianthe son of Supreme Court Justice Steven Derounianwhq was fatally injured in an accident in Florida on March 30.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Council Would Extend State Income Tax

title: RABIN TO GIVE POWERS TO FIERE NEXT WEEK
description: TEL AVIV, April 14Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, barred by law from resigning as head of the caretaker government, has decided to go on vacation and delegate his functions and powers to Defense Minister Shimon Peres.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: Brazilian Army Tightening Its Grip
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 14The rightwing military Government of Brazil took a giant step away from political liberalization today as President Ernesto Geisel decreed a series of measures to prevent the civilian opposition from reaching power in the foreseeable future.

title: Talks Resumed in Albany to Avert Monday Strike by State Employees
description: ALBANY, April 14Representatives of New York State and its largest publicemployees union, the Civil Service Employees Association, resumed facetoface negotiations today after a threemonth hiatus in an effort to avert a strike threatened for Monday.

title: 2 Weather Underground Members Give Up After 7 Years as Fugitives
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)  Two fugitives from the Weather Underground have surrendered in Cook County Court in Chicago in a move that might signal shift away from political bombings and sabotage by members of the radical group.

title: 300 Agents of F.B.I. Demonstrate In Support of Indicted Supervisor
description: Three hundred agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation went public yesterday, but only briefly, to demonstrate on the steps of the United States Court House for John J. Kearney, a former F.B.I. supervisor indicted on charges of tampering with private citizens mail and of tapping their telephones in a hunt for terrorists of the Weather Underground.

title: Massage Is the Medium
description: When a pedestrian receives a flyer for a massage parlor, chances are good it will end up on the street. The Sanitation Department is trying to fight such litter by cleaning up its source.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEL AVIV, April 14 (AP)Two Israelis who said they were angered by what they saw as world apathy over unpunished Nazi war criminals seized part of the West German, Embassy here today, but surrendered peacefully five hours later.

title: Strike at Pimlico Settled
description: BALTIMORE, April 14 (UPI)  A strike by Maryland racetrack employees ended today when union members overwhelmingly ratified a threeyear agreement with the state's three major tracks  Pimlico, Laurel and Bowie. The vote assured that Pimlico Race Course would play host to the 102d running of the Preakness Stakes May 21.

title: Decrease in Farm Population Accelerates; Figures Show a 14% Decline From 197076
description: WASHINtTON, April 14The Federal Government reported today that the exodus of Americans from farms appeared to be accelerating sharply despite a heavy increase in agricultural output in recent years.

title: Theater: Liv Ullmann's Anna Christie
description: Quintero's O'Neill

title: A Polish Baby Doll Opens at Yale
description: White Marriage, opening tonight at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven, is a sexual comedy, which makes it an unconventional undertaking, for Yale, for the playwright, the Polish poet Tadeusz Rosewicz and for the play's director, the acclaimed Polish film maker, Andrzej Wajda.

title: Gruen Industries Files A Bankruptcy Petition
description: Gruen Industries, which makes electronic solidstate and  mechanized watches, has filed a Chapter XI bankruptcy petition. Last month the cornpany announced it planned to file the petition following disclosure that it had a net loss of $3.8 million for its fiscal third quarter ended Dec. 31, compared with net income in the yearbefore period of $350,000, or 21 cents a share.

title: Rioting in Pakistan Is Said to Endanger Bhutto Government
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 14Only month after what appeared to be a major, election victory for Prime Minister Zulf kar All Bhutto, angry mobs are rioting regularly in most of the major cities of Pakistan demanding his resignation be?; cause of what they say was wholesale fraud in the parliamentary election.

title: Art People
description: RICHARD NONAS'S massive but minimal steel bars, architecturally placed on the floor in the elegant new exhibition space of P.S. 1 in Long Island City, Queens, seem remote from tribe of Indians in a Mexican desert village. The connection in a minute, but first, a description.

title: The New York Times/Heal Boend
description: F.B.I. AGENTS SUPPORT FORMER COMRADE: Agents the Federal Bureau of Investigation applauding as John Kearney, left, and his wife, Jane, arrived at the U.S. Court House at Foley Square yesterday for Mr. Kearney's arraignment on mailtampering and wiretapping charges. Mr. Kearney pleaded not guilty and was released by Federal Judge Morris Lasker in his own recognizance. About 300 agents were on hand. Article is on page D14.

title: F.A.A. BACKS A STUDY FAVORING CONCORDE
description: The Federal Aviation Administration gave a qualified endorsement yesterday to a BritishFrench analysis contending that proposed new flight procedures for the Concorde would mean much less noise around Kennedy International Airport than previously calculated.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: TOMORROW AFTERNOON at 1, CBS News unveils Razzmatazz, a magazine designed for young viewers. Assorted features are introduced and linked together by Barry Bostwick, the studio host and occasional participant in the films. With Joel Heller as executive producerdirector, the premiere has pieces on the Keane brothers, just barely teenagers, who write, perform and record their own songs; a young woman with her pet lion; two boys training for a tripeze act done by their parents, and a traffic reporter who covers San Francisco in an airplane.

title: The Pop Life
description: LAST YEAR, Brian Wilson's return to the Beach Boys was heralded by a bigger blitz in the printed and electronic press than Bruce Springsteen's return. And, as it turned out, it was a less deserving blitz. Mr. Springsteen, let it not be forgotten, was worth all the hype. Mr. Wilson showed up vestigially at some Beach Boys concerts and produced an oldies record, 15 Big Ones, which was disappointing even in the eyes, of Beach Boys fanatics.

title: Wax Model
description: LOS ANGELES, April 14 (Reuters)The wax model at a local amusement park that turned out to be a mummified corpse was identified yesterday as the body of a turnofthecentury Oklahoma bandit, Elmer McCurdy.

title: Camden Boy, 7, Drowns
description: CAMDEN, N.J., April 14 (AP)Sevenyearold Harry Land fell into Newton Creek here yesterday and drowned. The police said the boy had been playing with friends at the time of the accident.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Five youths who pleaded guilty to the gangrape of a 17yearold girl last Oct. 28 have been sentenced to prison terms ranging up to 10 years. Two of the five approached the girl, who was standing with her 11yearold sister on De Kalb Avenue in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn waiting for a bus. They placed a pistol to the head of the older girl, sent her sister away, and then marched their victim 12 blocks to an apartment, where they held her for six hours, repeatedly raping and sodomizing her.

title: FRANCIS CONNELLY
description: Francis Connelly, New England theatrical producer, died of cancer Wednesday at the Norwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 46 years old and a resident of Plainfield, Conn.

title: F.C.C. to Fight Cable Ruling Of U.S. Court
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  The Federal Communications Commission has voted to appeal a court decision that the commission's regulation of paycable television was unconstitututional and improper.

description: WASHINGTON, April 14The Food and Drug Administration eased its proposed ban on saccharin today but in seeking to calm the controversy surrounding the sugar substitute, the agency seemed only to rekindle the furor.

title: Brazilian Army Tightening Its Grip
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 14The rightwing military Government of Brazil took a giant step away from political liberalization today as President Ernesto Geisel decreed a series of measures to prevent the civilian opposition from reaching power in the foreseeable future.

description: Union Oil of California and Molycorp Inc. of White Plains, N.Y., said yesterday that they had agreed in principle on the acquisition of Molycorp by Union in a taxfree reorganization.

title: New I.B.M. Data System
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has introduced a lowcost data processing system with work stations. Called I.B.M. System/34, it brings daily operating information and computer processing to as many as eight locations in a business through tabletop work stations. The lowest priced model of System/34 will lease for $950 a month with a three year lease. Purchase price for the base system is $34,700. First deliveries will begin in January.

title: Decision on Rebate Sparks Gains Despite Expanded Money Supply
description: Substantial price gains were registered throughout the credit markets yesterday. Traders and specialists said the strong showing was a direct and affirmative response to the Administration's decision not to seek personal tax rebates at this time.

title: Film: A Festival of the Unrecognized
description: FILM FESTIVALS are the worst possible circumstances in which to see movies that are of somewhat less than spellbinding interest. The competition for our attention at a festival, as well as the expectations created by the nature of a festival (which, I always assume, should be a celebration), guarantees a certain number of disappointments. Truly good movies are no problem. They are as tough as they are rare. They hold up no matter what goes on around them while lesser, even quite decent movies suffer dearly. They are vulnerable. It's as if mediocrity were a contagious disease.These thoughts are prompted by the sixth annual New Directors/New Films series starting today at the Museum of Modern Art. At this writing I've seen six of the 12 films that will be shown in the minifestival, sponsored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the museum's film department, but I haven't yet seen one that could be said to make the entire occasion worth the time, effort and funding that have gone into it.It's unfortunate that film festivals are as locked into annual models as Detroit. Some years it might be better to pass  to admit that the festival material simply wasn't there.Because the films in this series have no common denominator other than hat each is the work of as yet unrecognized film makers, I deal with them separately in the chronological order in which they'll be screened at the museum."When Joseph Returns" (today at 6 P.M., Sunday at 8:30 P.M.) is an unsentimental Hungarian film about the edgy relationship between a middle-aged woman and her young, restless daughter-in-law when the son/husband goes to sea for six months. The film, directed and written by Zsolt Kesdi Kovacs, is beautifully acted by Lili Monori as the younger woman and Eva Ruttkai as the mother-in-law, and though the outcome is never in doubt, the manner in which the two women arrive at mutual understanding is surprisingly harrowing in its close-up details.The girl, whose life had previously been more or less determined by equal doses of television and sex, is a slob, though an extremely pretty one, a person who never stands unsupported if there's a wall to lean against. At first she misses her husband, then resents his absence and eventually she tears loose to enjoy herself, which, of course, she doesn't. "When Joseph Returns" is the sober sort of movie that one can admire without really liking it a lot."The First Swallow" (today at 8:30 P.M., Sunday at 6 P.M.) has the determined jollity of a political operetta. The Russian (Georgian) film, directed by Nana Mchedlidze, is about the efforts of some ferociously quaint Georgian men to organize themselves into a respectable soccer team at the turn of the century, but if you think that's all it's about, you are wrong. The fellow who pulls the team together and keeps their spirits up is a dead-ringer for Uncle Joe Stalin. The acting and often epic-looking photography are terrible."11x14" (Saturday at 8:30 P.M. and Monday at 6 P.M.) is an independent American film, "conceived and executed" (say the credits) by James Benning. The objective of the film, according to Mr. Benning, is "to formulate a number of ideas using methods that are conventionally thought to be contradictory to the ideas themselves. The contradictions are used to develop a continual feeling of paradox." For paradox read impatience.Mr. Benning's way of creating a new narrative form is to dispense with narrative completely. The film is composed of fragmentary scenes sometimes shot with a stationary camera, of landscape, viaducts, highways, fields, people getting in and out of automobiles, two women making love, a number of golfers teeing off, each in his/her turn.Though Mr. Benning claims to have conceived and then executed his movie, I suspect it was made the other way around. "11 x 14" looks to have been assembled from available fragments, some not very well photographed, and then justified by program notes on the order of "'11 x 14' is also an attempt to create spherical time-space. The editing structure emphasizes the inherent linear quality of film. . . .""Anatomy of A Relationship" (Tuesday at 6 P.M. and next Friday at 8:30 P.M.) is a funny French film, jointly directed by Antonietta Pizzorno and Luc Moullet, in which a liberated young woman (Christine Herbert) and her cheerfully chauvinist lover (Mr. Moullet) try to reach some accord on her demands that she too receive sexual satisfaction. He calls himself "natural." She sniffs that he is only "traditional."Mr. Moullet is especially comic as he attempts to deal with a girl who is completely normal except for saying things like "I feel I'm in touch with my body again." He vows to give up sex for bicycling, that being a relationship he can "dominate," but it's not really the same thing. As he rides around Paris he finds himself envying all nonintellectuals who, in his fantasies, never have sex hang-ups. The movie goes a bit self-conscious at the end when the actors discuss their roles with the director, but until then it's true comedy."Coming of Age" (Tuesday at 8:30 P.M. and next Friday at 6 P.M.) is an East German film directed by a young Iranian, Sohrab Shahid Saless, with the sort of obsessive concern for literal detail that, with repetition, is meant to become a kind of poetry. The movie never quite succeedsone is never unaware of its compositionthough it is nicely acted by 9-year-old Mike Henning, who, in the course of things, comes to realize that his mother (Eva Manhardt) is a whore."Local Color" (Wednesday at 8:30 P.M. and Saturday, April 23 at 6 P.M.) is a failed attempt to make a camp melodrama in the style of the Kuchar brothers. It's the work of Mark Rappaport, a fellow who all too often means to be facetious, as if he believed consciously heavy-handed parodies of soap opera could somehow find layers of truth behind the jokes. They don't. The purposely dense plot concerns, among others, a set of incestuous twins, an amorous barber and the barber's dissatisfied wife.One actressJane Campbellalmost makes the film sit-throughable, though. Looking like a young Alice Ghostley in her "Boston Beguine" days, her mouth always turned down, she wears an expression of earnest reproach that, for reasons that I don't understand, seems very funny under the circumstances. The rest of the film, however, is more than a teeny tiny bit precious.

title: Music: Berlin Octet
description: THE BERLIN Philharmonic Octet, founded in 1935 and consisting of wind and string players from the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, gave the first of two New York concerts Wednesday night at the Kitchen, as part of the continuing Berlin Now series. The octet will present a program of music by Schubert and Mozart on Tuesday at Cameale Hall.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: MANHATTAN

title: Woodcock Leaves Governor Race And Supports Kean in the Primary
description: Joseph C. Woodcock Jr., the former New Jersey State Senator who recently ly resigned as Bergen County Prosecutor to seek the Republican nomination for Governor, dropped out of the race yesterday and announced his support in the primary for Assemblyman Thomas H. Kean of Livingston. Mr. Woodcock said he was leaving the race because of his inability to win the endorsement of party leaders in his home county of Bergen and because of difficulties in raising money. He said he has become convinced that he could not win the Republican primary election on June 7 and rather than take on the role of the socalled spoiler, have decided that the most responsible action I can take is to withdraw from the field. In announcing his support for Mr. Kean, who sat beside him at news conference in the State Assembly, Mr. Woodcock said: Tom Kean is an honest, decent, competent man who has the ability and background to do the job. He is most qualified to provide the leadership that New Jersey needs.

title: Follovvers in Jersey City Hail the Coptic Pope on His Arrival in the U.S.
description: JERSEY CITY, April 14More than 500 Egyptian immigrants crowded into the Coptic Orthodox Church of St. Mark today in prayerful thanksgiving for the first visit to the North American continent of a reigning Coptic pope, His HolineSs Pope Shenouda III.

description: An article in The Times on Tuesday incorrectly identified Robin Newbold, an appraiser for the Roslyn Savings Bank on Long Island, as the president of the bank. The president and chief executive officer of the bank is Floyd N. York.

title: AIDE ASSERTS PRESIDENT STILL PRESSES FOR E.R.A.
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)President Carter will continue to speak out for the equal rights amendment, and there is hope that it will be ratified right at the wire in 1979, an aide said today.

title: THREE LOSERS IN 1976 MAY POOL THEIR DEBT
description: WASHINGTON, April 14Acting on the widely accepted principle that misery loves company, three of the unsuccessful Democratic Presidential candidates of 1976 are exploring the possibility of pooling their campaign debts and conducting joint fundraising activities to retire them.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: The Bill Monroe bluegrass program will be held in the Loeb Auditorium of New York University, 566 LaGuardia Place in Greenwich Village. Shows are at 7 P.M. and 10 P.M. on Sunday. Tickets are $5.50 ($4 for N.Y.U. students). The box office will be open until 7 P.M. today and reopen at 4 P.M. on Sunday. For further information, call 4271488.

title: Loggers Assail Redwood Park Plan
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 (UPI)A truck caravan of angry loggers rolled across the Golden Gate Bridge into San Francisco today to register their protest at a Congressional hearing on whether to expand the Redwood National Park by 74,000 acres.

title: 30.6% RISE IS FORECAST IN WEEK'S AUTO OUTPUT
description: DETROIT, April 14The domestic auto industry is scheduled to build 203,166 cars this week, an increase of 30.6 percent from the 155,522 cars produced last week when most plants were closed early because of the Easter weekend, according to Ward's Automotive Renorts.

title: Cosmos Beat Hawaii, 21 Home Opener Is Sunday
description: The Cosmos will open their home sea.: son against Rochester on Sunday with a record of one victory and one loss. Having lost to Las Vegas in their sea; son's opener, 10, the Cosmos defeated Hawaii, 21, at Aloha Stadium late Wednesday night before 13,000 fartS, who ignored a driving rain.

title: Requiem for the Rebate
description: The $50 tax rebate plan was laid to rest yesterday by President Carter with neither the flair nor the logic that attended its birth last winter. The story of its brief and troubled life is a sobering commentary on the difficulty of economic policymaking.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.. April 14The Security Council approved a resolution tonight condemning an attack by mercenaries on the small westcentral African country of Benin. The action ended a debate that brought out into the open feuding between political moderates and radicals among the Frenchspeaking Africans here.

title: Rioting in Pakistan Is Said to Endanger Bhutto Government
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan. April 14One month after what appeared to be a maior election victory for Prime Minister Zulf kar Ali Bhutto, angry mobs are rioting regularly in most of the major cities of Pakistan demanding his resignation because of what they say was wholesale fraud in the parliamentary election.

description: LONDONIt should have been obvious to anyone who had studied human behavior that the downward trend to pornography would be followed by an upsurge to romance. Yet the Romantic Age which began two years ago took writers, composers, publishers, theatrical and film producers by surprise.

Salant, president of CBS News, has issued a set of guidelines for the network's journalists to follow in covering such stories.

description: BankAmericnrd, a leading bank card company, announced that its affiliated cards around the world had started to Interchange card billings electronically. Data processing computers linking member banks are programmed to give cardholders the currency exchange rates that banks use among themselves for milliondollar transactions.

description: Caroline Fearey Hover, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lawrence Fearey of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Stuart Barr Schimmel of New York. The bride is executive secretary of the Bibliographical Society of America, of which her husband is president.

title: Hysteria on Zaire
description: Much hysteria is now being heard from newspaper columnists, politicians and others about Communist invaders of Shaba province in Zaire, about the possibility of a colossal Soviet beachhead in the heart of black Africa, and even asking a paraphrased question resurrected from the McCarthyite Fifties: Who lost Africa? And of course it's being glibly suggested that the United States would and should be springing to the military aid of Zaire were it not paralyzed by its experience in Vietnam.

title: Chemical Bank to Pay $222,500 Fine
description: The Chemical Bank was fined $222,500 yesterday after it pleaded guilty to having violated the Federal Bank Secrecy Act by failing to report 445 large cash transactions amounting to $7 million.

title: N.B.A. Coin Flip Is Today For First Choice in Draft
description: The Milwaukee Bucks and the Kansas City Kings will learn today who gets first shot at the cream of the college crop in the National Basketball Association's draft June 10.

title: Amman and Peking Plan Ties
description: AMMAN, Jordan, April 14 (Reuters)Jordan and mainland China plan to establish diplomatic relations, Minister of State Hassan Ibrahim said today, adding that the countries would establish embassies in the near future. The Amman daily newspaper Al Destour, which generally reflects official thinking on foreign affairs, said Jordan agreed to end its relations with Nationalist China.

title: Casino Gambling Saves the Seashore Line
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 14South Jersey's only passenger railroad, marked for extinction last year, is getting a facelifting and added service instead because of the arrival soon of gambling casinos here.

title: S.C.I. Members to Urge Byrne to Veto Any Bill Weakening Casino Regulations
description: TRENTON, April 14Members of the State Commission of Investigation said today they would urge Governor Byrne to veto any legislation for regulating Atlantic City's casino gambling that they considered too weak to curb infiltration by organized crime.

And by it, Mr. Stern meant buying professional restaurant utensils and equipment for home kitchensin the case of the wealthy, to be used by private chefs who catered large parties at home.

title: Quijano Retains Title
description: MANILA, April 15 (AP)The Orient junior featherweight champion, Ric Quijano of the Philippines, retained his title with a decision over Soon Hyun Chung of South Korea in a championship fight tonight. There were no knockdowns in the 12round bout before a crowd of 6,000 in the Rizal Coliseum Arena. The victory was Quijano's 43d against two losses and two draws. Chung's defeat was his first in 20 fights.

title: Flyers Win, 4 to 3, on MacLeish's Overtime Goal
description: TORONTO, April 15 Nonchalant Rick MacLeish dropped his mask of indifference tonight and leaped with fist raised after he scored a goal at 2 minutes 55 seconds of overtime and gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 43 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Around the Nation

title: Blast Cuts Off Oakland Power
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 15 (UPI)A transformer blew up outside of a Pacific Gas and Electric substation late yesterday, knocking out power for more than 5,000 central Oakland homes for up to two hours. The terrorist New World Liberation Front later claimed responsibility for the blast.

description: CARLSBAD, Calif., April 15Bob Wynn, who has won only one tournament in his sevenyear career on the pro golf tour, shot a 67 today at La Costa Country Club and became the halfway leader in the $225,000 MONY Tournament of Champions.

title: France Plugs An African Hole
description: PARISSubSaharan Africa's twin curses are racism and tribalism. Racism, developed enormously under colonialism, disfavored nonwhites but it has since, during decolonialism, favored blacks over some whites and almost all Asians. Tribalism remains universal and contributes to the region's disunity, corrupt government and feeble development.

title: WetCombustion Process Uses Wastes as Fuel
description: A professor at the Polytechnic Institute of New York has invented a wet combustion process that he says will permit Amelicans to burn valueless and objectionable wastes in water. In this way, he says, sewage and sewage sludges, garbage and rubbish can be destroyed without creating any nuisance.

title: Mexico and Canada Remain Spiralling Inflation Victims
description: MEXICO CITY, April I5The economic recovery program of Mexico's new Government is being threatened by growing complaints from the labor movement that inflation here is still out of control.

title: St. John's Five Gets A Real (Big) McKoy

title: ]Islanders Beat Sabres, 43, For a 30 Margin in Playoffs
description: BUFFALO, April 15The New York Islanders are in another rut. For the second straight playoff game, they spotted the Buffalo Sabres two goals and then scrambled back to overtake them. Tonight's victory, by a score of 43 at Memorial Auditorium, gave the Islanders a 30 lead in their National Hockey League four  of  seven  game quarterfinal serves. They need to win only one more game to advance to the Stanley Cup semifinals for the third consecutive year.

description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)The United States and Vietnam will open discussions in Paris on May 3 on the possibility of normalizing diplomatic relations, the State Department announced today.

title: Women Gamblers Are Starting to Seek Help for Their LongHidden Problem
description: When Betty B. was a child, her father would take her to poker games. The men would have her cut the cards for luck and give her coins. She learned to play by watching. By the time she was a teenager, she was gambling with her lunch money.

It's the one place where you can see actual results of your efforts. For almost every dollar the state puts in we get back a dollar for the consumer.

description: MOSCOW, April 15The Foreign Ministry has protested to the United States Embassy over private showings of the films Dr. Zhivago and The Girl From Petrovka in the apartments of American diplomats here.

title: 'Beast,' X Film, Unfit for Man
description: A flabby-fleshed, perverted priest plants a soggy kiss on the lips of a passive, doleful-eyed adolescent, pops a sweet into the boy's mouth and greedily kisses him again. Later the good father will accept a bribe and agree to lie to his religious superior, to say that he has baptized a certain notorious heathen, thus paving the way for his marriage to a wealthy young woman. It could be a scene from Luis Buuel at his most scathingly sacrilegious, but the passion and wit are missing, the vigor and the venom.Sunlight floods the branches of a forest as a tense maiden with silvery tresses picks her way gingerly along a leaf-strewn path. It could be a scene from Bo Widerberg in prettily pastoral mood, but the pulsating music on the soundtrack is Scarlatti, not Mozart, and the presumably pure wanderer is soon to shed her powdered wig and fragile frock and tumble into an illicit, bittersweet liaison with a lover far more forceful, and furry, than any man ever to stir the dreams of Elvira Madigan, or even Jessica Lange in "King Kong."The syrupy, hypocritical prelate and the lascivious lass with the deceptively delicate air represent flip sides of a tarnished coin in "The Beast," a sleazy blend of fairy tale, Freudian foolishness and Eighth Avenue peep show. Written and directed by Walerian Borowczyka Polish migr to Paris who has been praised for such bizarrely erotic works as "Immoral Tales" and "Story of Sin"this unsavory descent into black comedy focuses on the scheme of a decadent marquis to marry off his only sonan imbecilic oat who is obessessed with the mating habits of horsesto a stunning, sexually repressed heiress, a blond nitwit given to elaborate masturbatory fantasies, one of which centers on a rumored relationship between an ancestor of her prospective husband and a rapacious creature of the forest.There are occasional flashes of humor in "The Beast." For the most part, however, Mr. Borowczyk's handling of his actors and his themes is sledgehammer-heavy, painfully in keeping with his evident contempt for humanity. If there is a message in "The Beast," it is to be found in the leeringly prolonged scenes of copulation and oral sex between the wanton woman and the panting animal. And that message is unfit for man or beast.
