title: 'Jabberwocky' Monster Film With Heart
description: The time is the mythic long-ago, a period after the eclipse of Camelot, but not yet the time of recorded history. The place is the kingdom of Bruno The Questionable, who is not a bad tyrant under the circumstances. Bruno's realm is being ravaged by a monster so terrible that the sight of it once turned an old peasant's teeth snow-white over night.Who will slay the monster to restore law and disorder, thus to win half of the Princess's hand and all of the kingdom (or perhaps it's the other way around)? From the opening sequence of "Jabberwocky," there's no doubt but that it must be Dennis-the-cooper's-son. Dennis (Michael Palin), disowned by his father in an embarrassing deathbed speech (his father was out of sorts), is the quintessential naif. Being profoundly and cheerfully stupid, slavishly faithful to the obese Griselda, polite in all situations, and ever optimistic, Dennis is fate's triumphant plaything.He is also the hero of "Jabberwocky," the most marvelously demented British comedy to come along since "Monty Python and The Holy Grail," to which "Jabberwocky" is a sort of stepson. The film, which opened yesterday at the Cinema 1, was directed by Terry Gilliam, who co-directed "The Holy Grail" and is, like Mr. Palin, a member of the group that calls itself Monty Python's Flying Circus.Taking as their inspiration some lines from Lewis Carroll's "Through The Looking-Glass," ("Beware the Jabberwock (my son!/The jaws that bite, the claws that catch. . . ."), Mr. Gilliam and Charles Alverson, with whom he collaborated on the screenplay, have written a wickedly literate spoof of everything from "Jaws" through "Ivanhoe" to "The Faerie Queen."It's a monster film with heart, a movie romance with bite, a costume picture without zippers, and a comedy with more blood and gore than Sam Peckinpah would dare use to dramatize the decline and fall of the entire West.The world through which Dennis stumbles ever upward is an unending landscape of misery, torture, filth, slop buckets, sudden death, and all-round decay"Jabberwocky's" comment on movie makers' comparatively recent obsession with showing us the past as it supposedly really was.Mr. Palin's Dennis is a fully realized comic character as much because he seems a mite old to be so innocent as because of his sturdy faith in his own small goals. All Dennis wants to do is to make his way enough to be able to claim the hand of the grouchy, overfed Griselda, but fortune keeps smiling on him. By chance he finds himself squire to the knight chosen to slay the monster, and eventually the sole survivor of the battle with a creature that looks like something out of a medieval Sesame Street.The movie's gags are nonstop, both verbal and visual, with lots of cross-references. "At last," proclaim the movie's ads, "a movie for the squeamish!" though some audiences may find the blood and scatology difficult to take. If there's anything unpleasant to be walked under or stepped into, Dennis will find it.Supporting Mr. Palin are a number of excellent character actors, many of whom are unknown to me. They include Max Wall as King Bruno, Warren Mitchell as Dennis's would-be father-in-law, and Harry H. Corbett as a squire who's fallen upon bad times. The performances are fine, but even more remarkable for a comedy of this sort are Roy Smith's stylish production design and the camera work of Terry Bedford."Jabberwocky" is very funny, yet it looks like an epic.

title: Carter Granted Delay In Filing Tax Return
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)President Carter has joined thousands of fellow citizens in getting an extension of today's deadline for filing his Federal income tax return.

title: Carter CitesC.I.A.ReportShowing World Oil Reserve Is Overstated
description: WASHINGTON, April 15President Carter said today that a new analysis by the Central Intelligence Agency showed that the world's reserves of oil and natural gas are not as great as we thought they were.

title: Unemployment Increases in France
description: RAMBOUILLET, France, April 15(Reuters)President Valery Giscard d'Estaing and his new Cabinet worked today on ideas for a yearlong Government action plan amidst news that France's unem. ployment reached a postwar record last month of 1,002,500 up from 972,400 in February.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: United Press International

title: Bucks Win Coin Toss and Plan To Make Benson No. 1 Choice
description: Kent Benson, the massive Indiana University center, will be the first choice in the National Basketball Association's college draft, and he will be playing for the Milwaukee Bucks next season. The college draft will be held June 10, but the Bucks hope to sign the 6foot11inch, 245pound Benson before then if he passes an examination of the back injury he suffered late in the season.

title: Some Call Him the Schweitzer of Guatemala
description: CAPITOLA, Calif.The devastating earthquake in Guatemala on Feb. 4, 1976 threw a spotlight on a remarkable Midwestern doctor, Carroll Behrhorst, who for 15 years has headed a farranging communityhealth experiment that is quietly revolutionizing the Guatemalan highlands, and is being proposed as a model for underdeveloped countries in Africa and the Far East.

title: TN BHUTTO ENVOYS ASSAIL HIS ACTIONS
description: MADRID, April 15As Prime Minister Zultikar All Bhutto's hold on power seemed to grow ever more uncertain today, two military men who were helpful in bringing him to power in Pakistan in 1971 warned that the man they had once hoped would bring democracy to Pakistan was leading it toward civil war.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An associate professor of economics at Ithaca College was charged with possession of an estimated seven pounds of marijuana contained in two garbage cans found inside a horse barn at his home.

title: World News Briefs
description: MADRID, April 15The Government tonight announced that Spain's first free parliamentary elections.in 41 years would be held on June 15.

title: Television
description: Afternoon

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Following is a transcript of President Carter's news conference yesterday morning, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: Antipoverty Groups March Against Cuts
description: Chanting They say cutback, we say fight back, about 750 people representing a coalition of poor peoples groups marched from East Harlem to midtown Manhattan yesterday to protest budget cuts for hospitals, daycare centers, schools and other services.

title: Young Says Reply On South Africans Was Not in Context
description: Andrew Young said last night that his affirmative reply to a question asking whether he considered the Government of South Africa to be illegitimate was really in the context of a discussion of the process of majority rulethe whole subject of majority rule.

title: Saccharin Industry Revamps Plans
description: The nation's only saccharin producer, the SherwinWilliams Company, intends to continue producing the sugar substitute but expects its cost will rise as a result of the Government's easing the ban on its use.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New Jersey leaders met with President Carter in Washington yesterday to oppose a shift in the Army's electronics command facilities from Fort Monmouth. The President was encouraging, said Governor Byrne. Mr. Byrne said the group had presented facts about which the President said he was not aware.

title: Clergymen Join Beame in Fight Against Pornography
description: New York City's major religious leaders agreed yesterday after a breakfast meeting with Mayor Beame to help him rally public support for his fight against pornography and street crime.

title: Saccharin: When Desire Becomes a Need
description: Now the saccharin problem is getting interesting. When the Food and Drug Administration proposed a month ago to ban all saccharin from the market, we shared in the general indignation even while recognizing that the agency had no choice. On the strength of a single round of experiments in Canada, which showed some rats developing bladder tumors when fed diets with 5 percent saccharin, the F.D.A. felt compelled to invoke the socalled Delaney clause in its basic statute. That clause bans any food additive that is found to induce cancer when ingested by man or animal. Since no human had ever been shown to suffer cancer from saccharin and since at least some humans with diabetes and severe obesity problems felt a need for artificial sweeteners, the clause was exposed as foolishly rigid. It must be altered.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The rimes in the last week.

title: BHUTTO IS REBUFFED IN GESTURES TO FOES
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, April 15Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto,met urgently with his Cabinet Ministers today and negotiated with the political opposition in an attempt to end Pakistan's deepening Government crisis.

title: Mrs. Rabin's Trial Begins Sunday
description: TEL AVIV, April 15 (Reuters)Lea Rabin, the wife of Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, will go on trial here Sunday on charges of illegal possession of foreign currency. The trial, which led Mr. Rabin to announce his resignation as leader of the ruling Labor Party, stems from two bank accounts maintained by the Rabins in Washington. Israelis are not allowed to hold foreign currency accounts abroad. Mr. Rabin begins a leave of absence Thursday, with Defense Minister Shimon Peres taking over as acting rime Minister.

title: Brock Hopeful on British Talks But Says Air Links Could Be Cut
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 Brock Adams, Secretary of Transportation, said today that, in the unlikely event of breakdown in bilateral negotiations between the United States and Britain over a new transAtlantic air transport agreement, there was a realistic possibility that flights between the two countries would be suspended.

title: China Publishes Volume by Mao Promoting Moderate Socialism
description: HONG KONG, April 15China published today the longdelayed and evidently controversial fifth volume of Mao Tsetung's Selected Works in a move that appeared likely to bolster Peking's tendency to view the late Chairman as a moderate socialist devoted to economic growth.

title: LAW STUDENTS WARN HOFSTRA'S PRESIDENT
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI., April 15 Hofstra Law School students today threatened to take legal action and to place their tuition in escrow in the controversy that has shaken this young school since the resignation of Dean Monroe Freedman last week.

title: More Flexible Replacement Knee Joint'',
description: WASHINGTONAn orthopedic surgeon and a mechanical engineer have teamed up to patent a replacement knee joint that closely mimics the natural version. The recipient can not only walk and run but also bend, swivel about and make other normal movements.

title: SOLAR POWER PLANT GETS FEDERAL FUNDS.,
description: ATLANTA, April 15 (AP)The Federal Government has awarded a grant to the Georgia Power. Company to build the country's first major commercial solar energy plant, the company said today.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Trying to Be Fair to City Workers
description: Inflation accounts for New York City's biggest headaches in dealing with public employees. As the consumer price index continues to rise, the city's workers, having accepted a deferral of wage increases, find that their takehome pay is not merely frozen but actually declining. That is why their unions and the city agreed last June on a program of costofliving adjustments, C.O.L.A., provided that they did not add to total spending or reduce services.

title: STRAUSS BACKS CURB ON TEXTILE IMPORTS; BARS PROTECTIONISM
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., April 15President Carter's chief trade negotiator, Robert S. Strauss, told textile manufacturers today that the United States could not turn toward protectionism but he added that. something must be done to stem the surge of textile and apparel imports.

title: Arthur King Peters to Head FrenchAmerican Foundation
description: Dr. Arthur King Peters, an international trade executive and scholar in French literature, has been named president of the FrenchAmerican Foundation. In his new post, Dr. Peters succeeds Prof. Nicholas Wahl, a founder of the organization, who will continue as chairman of the board.

title: Police Say Adding Harlem Officers Cuts Crime Sharply in 2 Precincts
description: Saturation police work and heightened public concern have brought about dramatic decline in crime in Harlem at at time when it is on the rise everywhere else in the city, the Police Department said yesterday.

title: Menu for a BlackTie Dinner: Roast Lion and Marinated Boar
description: The blacktie dinner was already under waysomewhere between the roast lion and the marinated boarwhen a man turned to the stranger seated next to him and casually introduced himself.

title: Funding Status of Water Projects
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)Following is a partial list of water projects the Carter Administration placed on its ndangered list, and President Carter's plans now for them, as reported tonight by state and Congressional officials or in published accounts. The status of oher projects could not be determined immediately.

title: Canal in South Wins Funds With Capitol Trump
description: COLUMBUS, Miss., April 15For at least 150 years men have dreamed of having a canal through the northeast corner of Mississippi that would link the Tennessee River to the Tombigbee River and provide a short cut to the Gulf of Mexico. For about that many years the dreams have been cluttered and complicated with considerations of politics. Now, it seems those same considerations will help the dream become reality.

title: Futures Prices Up Allowable Limits For Soybean Group
description: CHICAGO, April 15 (AP)All three commodities in the soybean complex advanced the allowable daily limits on the Chicago Board of Trade today. Soybean futures gained 30 cents a bushel, soybean meal $10 a ton and soybean oil 100 points, or I cent a pound.

title: FIGHTING IS REPORTED AFTER LULL IN ZEE
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 15After lull of nearly three weeks, some ground fighting appears to have resumed today in the south where Katangan exiles returning from Angola are challenging the rule of President Mobutu Sese Seko.

title: Rose Calamari, Wardrobe Chief At Metropolitan Opera Since 1962
description: Rose Calamari, wardrobe mistress of The Metropolitan Opera, died yesterday morning at St. Clare's Hospital. She was 78 years old and had suffered a heart attack Monday.

title: Inventories Rose 0.6% in February Despite Brisk Sales, U.S. Reports
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPD)Inventories gained 0.6 percent in February despite brisk sales, the Commerce Department said today. Although the $1.8 billion increase for inventory accumulation slowed from a $2.8 billion rise in January, circumstances were significantly different.,,Inventories gained in January largely because of a 1.3 percent decline in sales. The Commerce Department said sales increased 2.6 percent last month.

title: Pittsburgh,Revamped and Revitalized,Sheds Its Steel Town Image
description: PITTSBURGH, April 15In all urban America there may be no more dramatic spectacle than the wonderland tbat bursts suddenly into view as one emerges from the Fort Pitt Tunnel and sees downtown Pittsburgh, the Golden Triangle, glittering across the Monongahela River.

title: Music: Late Stravinsky Works
description: Stravinsky's early ballet scoresThe Firebird, Petrushka and The Rite of Springare played incessantly, but concert audiences are not so familiar with his later dance works. Pulcinella and The Fairy's Kiss, perhaps because they borrow their material from recognized composersPergolesi and Tchaikovsky, respectivelystrike Western ears as too derivative to be important Stravinsky. In fact, however, the early ballets also are based on borrowed stuff, but because it is Russian folk music, we fail to recognize it.

title: MISCHA HARRY FAYER
description: Mischa Harry Fayer, a retired professor who had headed the University of Kentucky's department of Slavic and Oriental languages, died in his home in Lexington, Ky., Thursday after a long 1 illness, He was 74 years old.

title: PRESIDENT, IN SHIFT, FAVORS SOME FUNDS FOR WATER PROJECTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 15President Carter approved today full or substantial funding for a number of the biggest water projects on a Presidential review list that had inspired intense Congressional criticism and pressure.

title: About New York
description: Even as he was hoisted aloft into his mayoral campaign, Mario Cuomo had to joke that he was in danger of being done in by a favorable press.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 15, 1977

title: Clergymen Join Beame in Fight Against Pornography
description: New York City's major religious leaders agreed yesterday after a breakfast meeting with Mayor Beame to help him rally public support for his fight against pornography and street crime.

title: Ministers Ordained By Mail Challenged On Tax Exemptions
description: ALBANY, April 15New York State advised local tax assessors today to deny religious taxexempt status to members of the Universal Life Church, an organization that mails credentials of ministry free to anyone on request and that sells doctorates of divinity for $20.

title: Magnetic Field Aims Satellites
description: The RCA Corporation has found a way to keep power flowing steadily', from the sun to the company's satellites. The large panels of solar cells, attached to the crafts were subject to a turning or twisting force, or torque, but a countertorque has been harnessed to keep the panels aimed at,the sun.

title: Bridge:
description: McAFEE, N.J., April 15New York players had their first success at the American Bridge Association's Spring Nationals here last night when Charles Agard, Ruth Giambrone, Dan Arrindell and Ethel Foreman took the mixedteam title.

title: German's Collection of Old Jewish Documents Travels to the New World
description: The directors of the Leo Baeck Institute, who have just purchased what they call the Bodenheimer Collection, knew little more about the man for whom they named it than that his address is the Jewish Cemetery, Frankfurt, West Germany.

title: The Second Time Around for Renee
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 14On her second time around the tournament circuit, the most important word in Dr. Renee Richards's life continued to be chromosomes, but the 42yearold transsexual now is being looked upon more as a human being and as a tennis player rather than a wierdo from another planet. Once you spend some time with her, you discover she's really a nice person, says a companion on the Lionel Cup tour. But sometimes she can be a prima donna. Being referred to as a prima donna might be the nicest possible compliment now for the former Richard Raskind, part transsexual, part tennis player, part ophthalmologist and all controversy. Even on a tour whose dramatis personae includes Billie Jean King, once the Joan d'Arc of Women's Lob, Renee Richards is at least a costar. And she has been known to act the part. Not long ago she phoned an airline for a reservation.

title: London on $42.50 a Night
description: LONDON, April 15 (UPI) A onenight stay in an average London hotel with rollandcoffee breakfast and an ordinary chnner with half a bottle of wine now costs $42.50, a survey showed today. Outside London the cost averages $34, the survey, by a private consulting firm, said.

title: U.S. Five in Final
description: MANNHEIM, West Germany, April 15 (AP)Led by Jeff Lamp's 19 points, the United States high school allstars trounced West Germany, 14647, tonight and reached the final of the Albert Schweitzer basketball tournament. Spain upset previously undefeated Turkey, 8169, and will meet the Americans tomorrow. Lamp is from Louisville.

title: KneeJoint Replacement
description: A surgical implant to replace damaged knee joints that allows a wide range of natural movements was patented this week by an orthopedic surgeon and mechanical engineer. Page 30,

title: Radio
description: Music

title: 2 Missing After Race Track Fire. In Jersey and Are Feared Dead
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J. April 15Two Garden State Park race track employees were missing today and feared dead in the aftermath of a fire yesterday that destroyed the clubhouse, and grandstand.

title: Today I'm a Man Who Wants to Be an Asset
description: ATTICA, N.Y.More than a decade ago, I committed a crime I genuinely regret. No one should murder or can justify it. Society was rightly outraged. One of its members had been murdered. The murderer should have been speedily apprehended and punished. I've been imprisoned many years now, and I've wished so many times that could bring Kitty Genovese back to life, back to her family and friends.

title: U.S. Six Loses, 61, in Prague
description: PRAGUE, April 15 (UPI)The United States hockey team, which will play next week in the World Hockey Championship at Vienna, was defeated, 6I, by a Czechoslovak junior team today. Bobby Sheehan scored the goal for the United States. Yesterday, the Americans were defeated, 71, by Czechoslovakia, the world champion.

title: Alberta Town Is Flooded
description: FORT McMURRAY, Alberta, April 15 (AP)Floodwaters spilled into a 60square block area of this town in northeastern Alberta and nearly 1,000 people were reported evacuated today. The water was said to have backed up into the town after winter ice broke up yesterday on the Athabasca River and then jammed, creating a natural dam.

title: The Now York Times/Chester Proles Jr.
description: COPTIC POPE WELCOMED IN NEW YORK: Pope Shenouda III of the Orthodox Coptic Church being greeted by Terence Cardinal Cooke on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. After conferring, they expressed mutual interest in church unity. The Pontiff later met with other religious leaders in the city. Details, page 23.

title: Music and Magic Highlight Food Day Festival in Park
description: Songs by Pete Seeger, a magic show by an educator who uses magic to teach nutrition to children, and a variety of nutritional foods from restaurants will be featured tomorrow at a Central Park festival designed to initiate a week of activities surrounding Food Daya national day of education for action on foot issues to be celebrated next Thursday.

title: Cost of Living Up I% in March, or 12% at Annual Rate, Despite Wage and Price Controls
description: MONTREAL, April 15Inflation has returned with a vengeance in Canada increasing social and political tensions prevalent in the country since the Federal Government instituted wage and price controls 18 months ago.

title: Miss Crocker, at 139, Maintains Lead
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., April 15Nancy Lopez is the kind of golfer who is good enough to keep breaking out of her assigned world.

title: VITO PELLETTIERI, STAGED GRAND OLE OPRY SINCE 1934
description: NASHVILLE, April 15 (AP)Vito Pellettieri, stage manager for the Grand Ole Opry here since 1934, died yesterday, six days after suffering what doctors diagnosed as a stroke. He was. 87 years old.

title: Jersey Racing, Halted by Fire, Hoping to Get Back on the Track Soon
description: New Jersey's expanded thoroughbred racing operation remained at a costly standstill yesterday after the fire that destroyed Garden State Park Thursday afternoon. While firemen searched the smoldering rubble of the 35yearold structure in Cherry Hill, members of the State Racing Commission spent the day conferring with officials of other New Jersey tracks about a revised schedule. Charles T. Carella, chairman of the commission said he was hopeful Garden State's remaining 41 racing dates could be assigned very soon to another track.

title: Watson, Kelly of Flyers Fined
description: TORONTO, April 15Exactly one year after the explosive quarterfinal N.H.L. playoff game here that resulted in the arrest of three members of the Philadelphia Flyers, Joe Watson pleaded guilty today to a reduced charge of common assault and was

title: Philippines to Hold Poll Despite Moro Boycott
description: MANILA, April 16The Philippine Government is going ahead with a referendum tomorrow on proposals for autonomy for its southern region despite a boycott by the rebel Moro National Liberation Front, which is insisting on negotiated change.

title: U.S. Schoolboys Win Tourney
description: MANNHEIM, West Germany, April 16 (AP)A team of United States high school allstars, led by Tom Baker and Tracy Jackson, defeated Spain, 137110, today and won the International Albert SchWeitzer basketball tournament for the third straight time. Baker of Jeffersonville, Ind., and Jackson of Burtonsville, Md., each scored 26 points. Baker was named the most valuable player.

title: A Shield for the Home
description: APOPULAR feature of many homes that border on or over look the North or South Shores of Long Island Sound is a raised outdoor wood deckor, in some eases, a waterfront dock on pilings that is also used as a sun deck and outdoor lounging area.

title: Miss Flack Bride Of Thomas E. Young
description: Suzanne Margaret Flack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Monroe Flack of Tryon, N. C., was married yesterday at noon to Thomas Elliott Smith Young, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Young 2d of Boulder, Colo.

title: As Much a Part of Life as Books
description: ON RAINY days, the smell of sea meeting land hangs over the campus like a dense, damp, sa??ty cloud. A foghorn with the vocal quality of a very lonesome dinosaur moans mournfully throughout the long gray afternoons and evenings. It is the monsoon season at the College of New Rochelle.

title: Dr. David Plimpton Weds Susan Batchelder
description: Susan Blaine Batchelder, a product manager with the Green Giant Company in Minneapolis, was married in Minnetonka Beach, Minn., yesterday to Dr. David Blair Plimpton, a Minneapolis physician. The Rev. Edwin J. Ellertsen performed the ceremony in St. Martin'sbytheLake Episcopal Church.

title: TV MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: The Game Of House Renting
description: NO DOGS. No children. No heterosexual singles. No homosexual singles  No parties

title: For Racers, the Fun Is Competition
description: IN THE CROWDED waters of the Sound one breed of sailor stands out. Unlike the other sail and powerboaters who are escaping for an interval of casual relaxation afloat to savor whatever adventure or fun the day may offer, members of this species invade the Sound with a game plan.

title: What Kind of America
description: WASHINGTONWe are coming into a time that will do much more than test the leadership of President Carter and the Congress. The forthcoming battle over energy policy will also test the character of the American people and the coherence of the American nation.

title: New York Is Attracting Foreign Businesses
description: A French banker who eats hamburger lunches at his desk and likes both the hamburgers and the time saved....

title: The Broadway Limited Chugs
description: BY DAY, John Heinemann of Ridgefield Park works in the composing room of The Passaic HeraldNews, Nights and weekends, he runs a railroad.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, APRIL 17, 1977

title: HopefullyAn Energy Plan
description: President Carter, searching for ways to conserve the country's energy, may have overlooked an opportunity right under his nose. A White House draft of his energy program has been making the rounds of Government offices. To it was clipped this memo: Attached is (hopefully) the final specifications for proposals under the National Energy Plan. One way to save untold energy would be to kill that sentence.

title: An Emerald Isle Bonanza
description: NAVAN, Ireland  Heavy mining operations have traditionally taken place in such wild and remote parts of the world that it came as a surprise when one of the biggest ore discoveries occurred in Ireland's green and civilized County Meath, scarcely 30 miles from the heart of Dublin.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: LEAVES have blown in under the door, which has never fitted more than approximately. The beach has put in another season on its hibernal task of reclaiming the three steps up to the porch. An agreeable mustiness from saltsoaked walls, a sense that there are cobwebs out there in the shuttered dimness, a hint that someone may have left a corner of a fried cheese sandwich to ossify on the kitchen counterthese combine to create a cry as primal as a mating call: Spring on the Sound and time to open up the beach cottage.

title: Realty News
description: Three banks have leased prime space in Chinatown for new branch facilities. At the same time, a Chinese restaurant described as the largest in the city has opened in the same area.

title: A Getaway to a Rustic
description: GEORGE WASHINGTON didn't sleep here. But Ulysses S. Grant paid a visit. So did Giovanni da Verrazano, who compared the place to the Isle of Rhodes, and Captain Kidd, who may have left something behind. French privateers sacked the place. And people say a flaming ghost ship, immortalized by John Greenleaf Whit ??er, still looms offshore.

title: Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: POLITICS
description: LAST November, after President Ford narrowly won New Jersey, the Democrats went looking for reasons. They eventually blamed Governor Byrne's lack of popularity, his poor relations with James P. Dugan, the state Democratic. Chairman, and Mr. Dugan's refusal to work with the New Jersey Carter campaign staff, which he considered woefully amateurish and out of tune with the state.

title: 3 Shells Swamped in Sound During Hughes Regatta
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., April 16Possible tragedy was averted today when 36 thoroughly soaked oarsmen and five coxswains observed the crewracing maxim of stay with the boat. The occasion was the 20th Hughes Cup regatta on Long Island Sound.

title: Diana Levy to Be Wed
description: Diana Levy, who expects to receive a bachelor's degree in political science from New York University in June, plans to be married in August to Andrew B. Melnick, who expects to receive his law degree from N.Y.U. in June. An alumnus of Syracuse University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, Mr. Melnick is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Melnick of Liberty, N. Y. Miss Levy, who spent her junior year at the City of London Polytechnic in England, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Levy of Peekskill, N. Y., who have announced the engagement.

title: On Making Little Orphan Annie Sing And Dance
description: On Thursday evening, when the curtain rises at the Alvin Theater on Annie, a new musical that is being presented by Mike Nichols and for which I wrote the book, the openingnight audience may be a trifle surprised to discover that the redheaded title character, none other than Little Orphan Annie, has straight rather than curly hair and isn't wearing the red dress that was her most familiar trademark in Harold Gray's classic American comic strip. Moreover, again unlike Gray's Annie, she has pupils in her eyes the bluegray eyes of Andrea McArdle, a 13yearold Philadelphia school girl who is making her New York theatrical debut the show's star.

title: For Racers, the Fun Is Competition
description: IN THE CROWDED waters of the Sound one breed of sailor stands out. Unlike the other sail and powerboaters who are escaping for an interval of casual relaxation afloat to savor whatever adventure or fun the day may offer, members of this species invade the Sound with a game plan.

title: Carol Eileen Covely Is Wed
description: Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Allentown, Pa., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Carol Eileen Covely, daughter of Anthony V. Covely of Allentown and the late Mrs. Covely, to William Michael Hirschman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hirschman, also of Allentown. The Rev. James Reichert performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: I WAS hopscotching through the headlines of my local weekly paper, The Montclair Times, the other day when I came across an article that had a vaguely familiar look about it. The annual school budget, it seemed, had come up for consideration, and a vote on whether or not it was to be approved had been deferred.

title: LISBON COMMUNIST SEEKS A NEW IMAGE
description: LISBONEven Portugal's stalwart Communist leader, Alvaro Cunhal, whose followers have been called Europe's last Stalinists because of their unswerving loyalty to Moscow, is now seeking a new, more flexible image.

title: Mayor Appears to Have Crushed Strike by Atlanta Sanitationmen
description: ATLANTA, April 16Despite assertions from the union that we're not going to give in, Atlanta's black Mayor, Maynard Jackson, appears to have crushed an 18day strike by the city's sanitationmen, most of whom are black.

title: Roots in the Ironbound
description: RECENTLY, on impulse, I went back to the neighborhood I grew up in, Newark's Ironbound section. Strange, about the Ironbound. When I was a boy there, it was a lowermiddleincome area rated just a notch above a slum by those who lived On the Hill, the betteroff gentry of Clinton Hill and Weequahic, the families of city commissioners and police captains in Vailsburg, the aristocrats of Forest Hill.

title: Celtics  76ers Series in the Playoffs Evokes a Big Rivalry of Yesteryear
description: The National Basketball Association was a 14team league in 196869. Wilt Chamberlain played his first season with Los Angeles after the Philadelphia 76ers had traded him to the Lakers and Bill Russell was in the final season as the Boston Celtic player coach.

title: A Golden, Silvery Animal Kingdom
description: The Aaron Faber Gallery on the mezzanine at 578 Fifth Avenue (at 47th Street) was recently turned into a zoo: The animals are not cages, however, but on jewelry.

title: Resident Fish and Visitors
description: SPORT fishing is one of the most important activities on Long Island Sound and its rapid growth in recent years is expected to continue according to the Sound study by the New Engiana River Basin Commission. The study estimates that more than one million persons fish the Sound's waters each year.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In late editions of last Sunday's Times the pictures of Victoria Towns and Lauren Fritzinger were transposed.

title: Gorki's World In All Its Abundance
description: WASHINGTON Maxim Gorki's The Lower Depths is a tragic city of a play. It is set in a slum rooming house, crawling with the wretched and the abused of a society about to collapse. A dozen characters are on stage at any one time. They come and go, lie around, theorize, gamble, quarrel, make love, survive or die.

title: The Nation
description: President Carter has announced the details of his antiinflation package, and the package is modest. He has also abandoned two tax measures the Administration had presented to Congress in January, and defended since then as integral parts of its economic stimulus program.

title: Premier Skippers From Yale
description: STANLEY Honey took a year off from Yale to navigate a sloop to Honlulu and back in the TransPacific Race. Steve Benjamin took a year off from Yale, perfected a new style of sailing and won a world championship with it. Peter Isler took a year off from Yale to race on yachts in the Caribbean and West Indies.

title: Health Care Begins With the I's
description: ALBANY We Americans are health worshipers. We have invested, and continue to invest, billions in our temples of health: our hospitals, medical schools and nursing homes. As no other society, we indulge physicians and surgeons, not only monetarily but technologically.

title: A Coast Off Limits to the Poor
description: WESTCHESTER COUNTY has an area of about 450 square miles of beautiful, varied terrain. The Long Island Sound borders the county on the southeast. Westchester is primarily a county of homes, balanced by successful stores, executive offices, research laboratories and light manufacturing units. It has become, over the years, a national symbol of good living and sound economy.

title: Susan L. Kraus Becomes Bride of Takuji Nakamura
description: The Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest was the setting yesterday afternoon for the wedding of Susan Lillian Kraus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Peter Kraus of Ridgefield, Conn., and Takuji Nakamura, son of Mr. and Mrs. Shohei Nakamura of Kazo, Japan.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Theater

title: FollowUp on the News
description: It was reported to be the first successful hijacking of a Soviet airliner in flight. In October 1970, Pranas Brazinskas, a 46yearold Lithuanian, and his son, Algirdas, 19, brandished a sawedoff shotgun and hand grenades aboard an Antonov 24 bound from Batumi to Sukhumi. Turkey! Turkey! the hijackers shouted to the crew.

title: Jazz Lofts: A Walk Through the Wild Sounds
description: It was a long way from Berlin, but there was George Gruntz, director of the prestigious Berlin Jazz Festival, lounging in the hallway of a loft at 24 Bond Street. He was on the track of the newest artists on the jazz scenethe innovators of loft jazzand he tilted his head as music suddenly erupted inside the loft. A rehearsal was under way in Studio Rivbea. Reed master Sam Rivers, who founded the studio with his wife Bea, was leading the woodwind section of his big hand. It sounded like the blues reinvented. Gruntz was exuberant. The music Sam is makingit is so beautiful! There is nothing like it in the old clubs, or in Europe. Only here in the lofts is there such exciting musicso many new ideas, such enthusiasm, such control of the instruments. It's the most exciting jazz in town.

title: Firefighter Safe in Copter Crash
description: STROUDSBURG, Pa., April 16 (AP)A helicopter fighting a forest fire crashed near Stroudsburg yesterday, but the pilot, Robert Dennis of Vivien, La., was unhurt. He was carrying water to drop on the flames, according to the state police, when the back rotor broke about 1 P.M.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: THE State Casino Control Act, which may come up for a vote this week, is being designed by a committee, but it is not known yet whether it will more nearly represent a camel or a giraffe, two animals frequently mentioned as example of committee design.

title: Harvard and M.I.T. Eights Shut Out Syracuse, Lions
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 16Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology were the hosts today to the heavyweight crews of Syracuse and Columbia and it was an auspicious opening day of rowing for the Cambridge eights on the cooperatively calm Charles River course.

title: An Import Uproar
description: The uproar over mounting Asian exports to the United States increased a few decibels last week, as the United States Customs Court ordered Secretary of the Treasury W. Michael Blumenthal to impose countervailing duties on Japanese electronic equipment, including television sets, radios, tape recorders and record players.

title: CONVICTED MURDERER ESCAPES FROM PRISON
description: FISHKILL, N.Y., April 16 (AP)A convicted murderer known as the Capeinan because of his attire as a teenage member of a 1950's street gang called the Vampiresdidnot return to the Fishkill Correctional Facility from an educational release program at New Paltz State College, authorities said today.

title: Here It Comes Again
description: ASSEMBLYMAN ROBERT C. WERTZ, in his introduction to his recent bill to resurrect the RyeOyster Bay Bridge project, estimates that 225,000 heavy commercial vehicles would travel the bridge annually. This figures out to 616 tractortrailers on average a day, 25 on average an hour, or one tractortrailer on average every two minutes. This is Mr. Wertz's idea of landuse planning for residential Southern Westchester and the Island's North Shore.

title: Deaths
description: ADAMSPlerpont, age 74, of Redding Ridge, Conn. and Saranac Inn, N.Y., April 13 aboard the cruise ship Fagafgiord. Husband of Caroline (Christy Adams). father of Samuel A. Adams, Judith Smith, Mary Coombe and Caroiine Jones. The funeral service will be held in The Christ Episcopal Church, Redding Ridge, Conn. on Tuesday, 11 A.M. Private interment In KensIco Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y. Please omit flowers.

title: SOVIET UNION FACING MANPOWER DECLINE
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The Soviet Army is quietly facing a major problem familiar to the United States armed forces: a looming drop in the number of Youths of military age.

title: Where to Learn More
description: For the consumer seeking guidance on solar systems, the Solar Energy Industries Association has published a 400page catalogue listing by geographical area the engineers and solar authorities that can be consulted for information. The catalogue costs $8. The association is at 1001 Connecticut Avenue N.W., Suite 632, Washington D.C. 20036.

title: Light From Darkness
description: HOW we come to know the world in which we liveinanimate objects, other persons, ourselveshas long perplexed and fascinated thoughtful individuals. From those professionally charged with pondering these issues in the West, two traditions have emerged. Nativists, in the tradition of Descartes, see knowledge as built into the nervous system (at most a smidgen of experience is needed to arouse our innate ideas). Empiricists, on the other hand, view knowledge as painstakingly constructed from our sensory experiences in the world. In reaching this conclusion, such empiricists as Locke, Berkeley and Hume relied primarily on reason, but they were keenly aware that scientific or natural experiments could invalidate their point of view. And so each speculated about the world of the individual deprived of sensory experience. Not surprisingly, most of their comments centered on a mythical blind Individual, who, they agreed would conceive the world quite differently from sighted persons.

title: Keith Ingber Fiance Of Barbara Strauss
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Strauss of Wantagh, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Jo Strauss, to Keith Geoffrey Ingber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Ingber of South Fallsburg, N.Y.

title: Crime May Not Be the Best of All Issues
description: The Democratic mayoral primary in New York City is months away and the field is not complete, but one thing about the race is clear: Crime will be an important if not the dominant issue.

title: Soviet Writers Help Clean Up Zoo On Annual Day for Unpaid Labor
description: MOSCOW, April 16 (Reuters)Soviet poets, novelists and critics exchanged their pens for spades today and helped clean up the Moscow Zoo in the country's annual day of unpaid labor.

title: A COOLHEADED COP WHO
description: The 5yearold girl reached for the plate of bacon and eggs that Detective Lieutenant Frank Bolz held out to her through the partly open door, and Bolz tried to measure the risk. It was 6 A.M. and he had managed to get a few hours of sleep be fore resuming negotiations, but the man sitting erect on a straightbacked chair in the bedroom had been without sleep for at least 30 hours, and it was hard to believe he could be alert. Yet the revolver he pointed at the little girl's head was steady. He claimed he loved her, and for hours he had held her on his lap. But all during the night and the previous day, he had threatened to kill her if anyone tried anything.

title: 44 Japanese Win Large Settlements In Suits on DC10
description: The 44 remaining Japanese plaintiffs in damage suits resulting from the Turkish Airlines DC10 crash outside Paris in 1974 have won substantial outofcourt settlements.

title: Are You Better Off at Harvard?
description: For this year's college applicants, the suspense is finally over. Last week they received their letters of acceptance or rejection. Once again, the arduous process of selective college admissions had run its unreal course.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox : JetAge Tennis
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Canticum Novum Eager and Fresh
description: There was an infectious atmosphere of spontaneity and immediacy about the Canticum Novum's concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on. Friday night, the kind of Musical freshness that a small chamber chorusin this case 20 voices can generate far more successfully than a large one.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: LESS emphasis on the rehabilitation of criminals, stiffer sentences for those convicted repeatedly of violent or serious economic crimes and compensation to crime victims to pay for their medical expenses and time lost from work.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Everyone knows how sacred the word tends to become when written down. Print sanctifies, for reasons that are probably lost civilized humanity's dim past. Print on paper is intimidating, and if you can manage to have the word chiseled onto stone tablets, so much the better. Even opera librettos, which do not always represent the highest level of printed communication, become sacrosanct once audiences have come to terms with their frequent absurdities, inconsistencies and non sequiturs. They become to us like old friends: we no longer know if they are clever or dumb, good or badand we are comfortable with them, and that is that.

title: Authors' Queries
description: For a biography of poet Conrad Aiken I would appreciate any information or correspondence relating to his life. Edward Butscher 8401 Main Street Briarwood, N. Y. 11435

title: Cosmos, Home Today, Have Yet to Hit Stride
description: If Pele doesn't display his fancy tricks or move with the ball as often as usual in today's home opener for the Cosmos, bear with him for another few days until a minor injury goes away. And if Giorgio Chinaglia goes scoreless again, bear with him, too. Last year, remember, Chinaglia went scoreless for seven games and missed five others, but still led the North American Soccer League in scoring. Similarly, the Cosmos led the league in scoring with 65 goals in 24 games, although they have only two goals in two games this season.

title: Different Kinds of Love
description: ELIZABETH CULLINAN'S short stories began appearing in The New Yorker in 1960. Flawlessly crafted, the dozen stories in Yellow Roses, her second collection, explore the same sorts of lives that engaged the author in her previous work. Her cast of characters typically includes middleclass Irish Catholics suffering the unremarkable trials and tribulations of their lot with reasonable fortitude, victims, as the narrator puts it at one point, of life and the way it punishes people who are weak as well as innocent. Yet despite their narrow horizons, disappointments and discontents, these people get by. The portraits of their survival, articulated with both irony and compassion, delineate the extraordinary psychological drama entailed in these ordinary experiences of life.

title: Pair Seized As Net Play Is Disrupted
description: NEWPORT BEACH, April 16As more than 400 protesters shouted, South Africa, go home, two black spectators jumped over a small gate and allegedly slammed a milk carton filled with motor oil on the tennis court during the Davis Cup North American Zone final today.

title: Soviet Dissident Reported Freed
description: MOSCOW, April 15 (UPI)A Ukrainian writer seized in Kiev and taken to another town for two days of questioning as part of an apparent Soviet crackdown on the human rights movement has been freed, a leading dissident said today. Former Maj. Gen. Pyotru Grigorenko, a founding member of a group monitoring Soviet compliance with the human rights provisions of the Helsinki accords, told Western correspondents that Oles Berdnik had telephoned him to report he was released yesterday and had returned home.

title: BIRTH CONTROL DRIVE EXTENDED IN BRAZIL
description: RECIFE, Brazil, April 12Brazil's private familyplanning organization is extending birthcontrol methods into impoverished rural areas of this populous northeast region through a community program based on local women as promoters.

title: Design
description: In the midst of the popularity for spare modern and traditional elegance in decorating, a handful of young designers are not afraid ot express their wit in fantasy environments. These personal statements, created for themselves or for their clients, explode in humor and imagination. Living in fantasy, they say, is like taking a trip each time they open the front door.

title: Susan Bergesch Bride of E. B. Shanks Jr
description: Susan V. Bergesch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis William Bergesch of Mamaroneck, N. Y., was married yesterday to Eugene B. Shanks Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. E. Baylis Shanks of Nashville.

title: France Is Again Strengthening Ties With Zaire
description: The African nation of Zaire gained independence from Belgium in 1960, but because of its mineral wealth, size, strategic location and chronic political instability, outside countries have been unable to keep their hands off. And in time of trouble, the Zairians have often welcomed foreign help. The latest trouble is an apparent invasion by exiles who have been living in neighboring Angola. A number of outsiders respondedBelgium sent weapons and is believed to be advising Zairian Government troopsbut the Western nation rushing most openly to the defense of President Mobutu Sese Seko's regime was France.

title: 3 Classical Indian Dance Styles Shown in Ritha Devi's Gallery
description: More than once, Ritha Devi, a classical dancer from India who now lives in New York, has cited the following phrase as her motto: Dance alone is my religion, my wealth and my desire.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Best Advance in 14 Months
description: The stock market made a sharp advance last week as prices were propelled upward mainly by President Carter's move to abandon his proposal for a $50 tax rebate for individuals.

title: White Sox Option Nyman
description: CHICAGO, April 16 (UPI)The Chicago White Sox optioned Nyls Nyman, an outfielder, to their Iowa Oaks farm team at Des Moines and recalled Wayne Nordhagen, a catcher and infielder, from the same club.

title: A NEW TRIAL IS ORDERED IN CASE AGAINST KINGSTON
description: ALBANY (UPI)The New York Court of Appeals has ruled in favor of a man who sued the city of Kingston because policemen left him at a deserted golf course to dry out.

title: A World Made Just for Running
description: Like most distance runners, I am still a child. And never more so than when I run, I take that play more seriously than anything else I do. And in that play I retire into the fantasyland of my imagination any time I please.

title: Shad Count Begins
description: ACENSUS of the shad population in the Delaware River has just begun, the joint Federalstate program being aided by the volunte??r efforts of about 200 fishermen.

title: Louisville Fears Further Ill Effects From Toxic Chemicals in the Ohio
description: LOUISVILLE, April 15Normally, rising temperatures and a receding river at this time of year would be enthusiastically welcomed along the Ohio River, especially after the extremely harsh weather this winter.

title: Diane Stone Fiancee Of Samuel Cardonsky
description: Mr. and Mrs. Elliot J. Stone of Newton, Mass., and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Fay Stone, to Samuel Jay Cardonsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Cardonsky of Hillside, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Davids Island Still a Battleground
description: DAVIDS ISLAND, an 80acre spot in Long Island Sound about 4,000 feet off New Rochelle, has figured in a modest way in the military history of the United States and in a more raucous fashion in the recent political history of the city.

title: Diane Keaton: From Mr. Allen to Mr. Goodbar
description: Diane Keaton slumped on a a couch in her East 68th Street apartment, wearing a bizarre baggy black granny dress and $4 clear plastic sandals. Eclectic, she said with a smile, when asked about her wellknown casual manner of dressing. Her light brown hair streamed past her shoulders in an uncombed, frizzy washandwear style, and she was wearing no makeup She seemed more like a strugglingycungactressfromtheVillage than a star who has two potentially blockbust er movies coming up, with roles that could help make Woody Allen's onetime prediction about her come true: Keaton could be the biggest female star in the country.

title: A Walk on the Wildlife Side: Nature Preserves
description: There are no fewer than 41 public nature centers within a 50mile radius of midManhattan. Each is dedicated to heightening our awareness of the natural world and preserving what's left of it. And each offers, in addition to naturalist trips and guided walks, special programs in the arts and natural sciences. Listed below are some of my favorites from among the more than three dozen I have visited. Admission to the pre serves and participation in various programs is free unless otherwise stated. A list of other centers appears on Page 23.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Thanks to the proliferation of summer workshops in many parts of the country, more and more photographers now have the opportunity to improve their techniques by studying for awhile with one of the masters of the art. They can study color with Ernest Haas, the zone system with Ansel Adams, landscape photography with Eliot Porter, or portraiture with Yousuf Karsh.

title: Can the Yankees Survive a SteinbrennerMartin Battle?
description: MILWAUKEE, April 16It would be the ultimate in irony in the wacky world of the Yankees if the goose that laid the golden egg stepped on the egg and splattered it.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: ART
