description: From left to right: Brickcolored jacket of polished nylon, cotton and polyester has snap closures, safaristyle pockets, an elasticized waist. By Zero King. $6.5 at Waltachs. Slacks by Majer. Shirt by Robert Schafer for Burma Bibas. . . . Glossy jacket is made of gunmetalblue cotton coated with polyurethane vinyl. It has a zip front, upper envelope pockets and lower zip pockets. By Europa Sport Inc. $33 at Abraham & Straus. Jeans by Bristol.... Glazed red Dacron and cotton jacket has a button front, navyandredstriped knit collar, cuffs and waistband. By Lakeland. $70 at Dolph's. Jeans by Faded Glory.

title: Pollution Control Has Become a Large American Business
description: Last year, American industry and government spent as much as $16 billion to clean waste water, control emissions into the air and provide for environmentally sound disposal of solid refuse. Of the total, about $1.8 billion is calculated to have gone for equipmenteverything from particulate precipitators to sewage treatment centers.

title: The Carter Retreat
description: IN a reluctant but pragmatic retreat last week from two key elements of its proposed and highly controversial economicstimulus programthe $50 rebates for most Americans and the $2 billion increase in business investmenttax creditsthe Carter Administration finally recognized the realities of an untenable position.

title: THE CRACKER FACTORY
description: Her priest wants a perfect Catholic mother; her husband a perfect wife. Her mother surveys her already immaculate house and offers, Now why not wash down the walls? Cassie Barrett, young mother of three, wants to check out.

title: On the Merits Of the Mints
description: According to Greek mythology, there was a beautiful nymph named Minthe who was loved by Pluto, the god of the underworld. In a fit of jealously, Pluto's mate, Persephone, changed Minthe into a fragrant plant. So goes the story on the origin of mints.

title: BANNED CANCER DRUG GAINS IN SOME STATES
description: A small but steadily growing number of states are moving to allow limited use of Laetrile, a substance promoted by some as a cancer cure but considered worthless as a treatment by the Food and Drug Administration, which has banned it from interstate commerce.

title: Bhutto Steps Up Peace Efforts but Foes Won't Yield
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, April 16Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto stepped up his efforts today to persuade opposition leaders to negotiate a settlement to the current political crisis. But the opposition, which is insisting that he resign, refused to yield an inch, and tumultuous antiGovernment demonstrations continued in Lahore and other cities, though they were considerably less violent than yesterday's.

title: Memoirs of a NotSoDutiful Daughter
description: During the early years of our marriage we saw little of Bob's mother and, of course, nothing at all of my family. I had looked forward to meeting Aranka, to being clasped to the warm and loving bosom of a Jewish family, as I inferred from Jewish literature would be my good fortune. Bob was far from sanguine about this prospecta shiksa of radical persuasion with a 2yearold child, he suggested, was arguably not the ideal bride for the apple of Aranka's eye.

title: Gen. Aleksandr Rodimtsev, 72, Soviet Commander and Author
description: MOSCOW, April 16 (AP)Col. Gen. Aleksandr I. Rodimtsev, who fought in the Spanish Civil War and at the defense of Stalingrad in World War II, has died at the age of 72, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

title: Notes: Palm Springs Not for Tycoons Only
description: Publicity surrounding the elegant life styles of celebrities who have settled in Palm Springs, Calif. (former President Ford, Bob Hope and former Ambassador to Britain Walter H. Annenberg) has created a false image of the resort, its officials complain. The town's Visitors Bureau is fighting the problem with a program called Small Discoveries, emphasizing hotels with no more than 50 rooms. When inquirers write to the town for vacation information, a postagepaid Small Discoveries postcard is sent to them. It asks for details on planned arrival, budget, whether the visitor is bringing children or pets and if a kitchen is desired. When the information comes back it is circulated to 185 participating hotels which are then free to send brochures or other required information to the inquirers.

title: Dental Plans Face State Senate Vote
description: UNDER intense and conflicting pressure from labor and New Jersey's organized dentists, the State Senate is scheduled to vote tomorrow on a controversial measure that would permit the continued operation of prepaid group dental plans in the state.

title: Radio
description: 89 A.M., WKTU: Mellow Child. Children's songs and stories.

title: Deaths
description: ROTHMarian. At Miami Heart Institute. Beloved wife of the late Emanuel S. Roth, cherished mother of Joan Williams and Kate Silver. Loving sister of Herbert Span, adored grandmother and greatgrandmother. Funeral services were held April 15, 1977 at The Riverside? North Miami Beach, Fla.

title: Coal Emissions in New Mexico Reduced at High Cost to Consumer
description: FRUITLAND, N.M.On one side of the road in this corner of the Navajo Indian Reservation, two plumes of yellowish smoke signal what is perhaps the most controversial coalfired electric generating plant in the country: Four Corners.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Luring Trout From Tidal Waters of the Nissequogue
description: SMITHTOWN, L.L.The Nissequogue Riverlike several other Long Island streamshas searun trout in its tidal portion, and a short while ago it seemed to be a good idea to try for them.

title: Turn and Count Scores In Excelsior at Aqueduct
description: X marked (he spot for Steve Cauthen, Sigmund Sommer and Frank (Pancho) Martin at Aqueduct yesterday as Turn and Count won the $80,250 Excelsior Handicap with one of his typical whirlwind finishes.

title: What's Doing in the ARIZONA SUNBELT
description: SETTINGArizona, like Caesar's Gaul, is divided into three parts: desert, mountains and some of the most valuable water in the world, the Colorado River. Winter sportsmen who think of Arizona as sandy waste should try the ski slopes near Flagstaff. Fishermen who think of Arizona's wildlife in terms of lizards and roadrunners can stalk the canny largemouth bass, the behemoth striper (now coming in at 50 poundsplus at Lake Havasu) and oversize rainbow trout in the Colorado's huge dammedlake reservoirs. But the pervading element is sunshine, which at this time of year warms the spirits of chilled Eastern and Northern visitors. Winter and fall are also good times to visit; summers are hot. The state is a cornerstone of that vast geographical entity that is changing the migration patterns, economy, sociology and, in some conspicuous cases. the politics of Americathe Sunbelt. In Arizona the Sunbelt is focused on the snowfree northwestern and central parts of the state, an area bounded by Phoenix, Lake Mead and the Colorado River. Among its showplaces is Scottsdale, a glossy city with elegant resorts, fancy malls and stylish architecture that began as a little desert town. Others are Wickenburg, an old gold mining town that is sometimes called the Dude Ranch Capital of the World, and Lake Havasu City, which prospers in the shadow of London Bridge.

title: Westchester
description: ALMOST within an anchor's cast of Mamaroneck's busy harbor are several restaurants offering diverse fare for visitors arriving by wateror, for that matter, for Westchester neighbors. You don't have to be a seafood fancier to sample their wares, but since our focus today was to be life around the Sound we took a special look at what each restaurant presented in the way of edibles from the sea. The following rundown, please note is, in geographical, not quality, order.

title: Fashion
description: Just when everyone was thinking that belowknee lengths had finally made it, designers in Paris decided to shake things up and hike skirts again. It started when Kenzo, the enfant terrible of French readytowear, showed tuniclength sweaters and smocks over leggings or tights in his fall 76 collection. Soon other French designers and a few Americans had short skirts in the summer collections that are in the stores now. When the fall 77 prtporter was shown recently in Paris, there were short skirts in just about every collection (two examples are shown below), proving that they're a fashion to be reckoned with.

title: Nora T. Nelson Plans to Marry
description: The engagement of Nora Thrse Nelson to Peter Nelson Tiffany has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. William James Nelson of Pelham Manor, N. Y., and Litchfield, Me., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Tiffany, also of Pelham Manor.

title: ART VIEW
description: For almost as long as anyone can remember, the English art movement known as Vorticism, which came into existence on the eve of the First World War, has been a subject of greater importance to writers and literary scholars than to painters or art historians or connoisseurs of the visual arts. The reasons for this are not mysterious. The central animating figure of Vorticism was Wyndham Lewis, who has proved to be of far greater interest to posterity as a writer than as a painter. Lewis's most energetic collaborator in promoting Vorticism was Ezra Pound, an even more commanding and influential writer than Lewis himself. As an avantgarde movement, moreover, Vorticism suffered the further handicapa handicap, at least, when it came to impressing itself upon the consciousness of later generations of artists and art historiansof failing to win the support of the greatest English art critic of the Vorticist period, Roger Fry. For Roger Fry, the modern movement in painting was largely FrenchCzanne was the great hero, of courseand there existed, in any case, differences in taste and temperament between Lewis and himself that could never be reconciled. Simply stated, the literary world has tended to accept Pound's view of the importance of Vorticism, whereas the art world has tended to endorse Fry's less favorable judgment.

title: Floatable Feasts
description: EATING, for many people whose lives or leisure involve the Sound, means moist, pearly fish, patentleather mussels, briny clams and succulent lobsters. It is the joy of seafood at its freshest along with the agony, for those with boats, of preparing it in a pocketsized galley with a twoburner stove. There are a number of new books intended to enhance the pleasure and relieve the problems.

title: And on the Shore, Attractions Galore
description: THERE'S more to cruising the Sound than meets the radar screen. Throughout spring and summer, its shores are alive with enough easily accessible sounds of music and theaterand sights of art and historical museumsto keep intrepid boatmen at anchor.

title: Hot Horseplayers
description: George Strawbridge of Philadelphia was sitting at an outside table near the clubhouse turn at Garden State waiting to see his filly run. The

title: At Seawanhaka, Tradition's Lure
description: CENTRE ISLAND AHALFCENTURY has drifted by since Jay Gatsby and the Jazz Age roared through F. Scott Fitzgerald's North Shore, but for many people the more refined aspects of that era still endure at the stately and secluded Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

title: For Racers, the Fun Is Competition
description: IN THE CROWDED waters of the Sound one breed of sailor stands out. Unlike the other sail and power boaters who are escaping for an interval of casual relaxation afloat to savor whatever adventure or fun the day may offer, members of this species invade the Sound with a game plan.

title: ART
description: THE RECONSTRUCTED village of Mystic Seaport on Long Island Sound would make an ideal set for an Eastern, if movie moguls were looking for a convincing New England backdrop, Eastern Seaboard counterpart to Westerns.

title: A Baedeker for Ship Passengers Sailing From New York Harbor
description: The advent of spring along the waterfront means a seasonal upturn in the port's cruise business. Yesterday five liners carrying almost 4,000 passengers left here. And for the benefits of some of these passengers on their return and for the hundreds of thousands who will follow them between now and the fall, herewith a bit of a port Baedeker to enhance the pleasure of standing at the rall and watching the harbor scenery pass by.

title: OVERBOARD
description: Mark Twain once observed that Even popularity can be overdone. In Rome, along at first, you are full of regrets that Michelangelo died, but by and by you only regret that you did not see him do it. Ditto suspense. When Lindy Gordon falls off a 40foot ketch some 70 miles from Tahiti, you rather hope that her amateur seadog husband, Mitch, will find her. Later, the reader faces with blissful equanimity the possibility that sharks will beat Mitch to his wife.

title: Other Sites
description: In addition to the group of nature preserves discussed in the accompanying article, there are at least 30 othersnot counting botanical gardens and natural history museums open to the public within a 50mile radius of midManhattan. Admission, unless otherwise noted, is free.

title: ART
description: THE TITLE of an exhibition at New York's Knoedler Galleries of 18th and 19thcentury American paintings from the Newark Museum is Aspects of a Collection. The title is at once appropriate and somewhat inappropriate. It is appropriate insofar as the 65 works represent only a small selection from the museum's vast holdings.

title: Ambulance Service Turns Private Company Profit Into Oklahoma City Loss
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, April 16 (AP)The private ambulance companies that served this city at a profit have been replaced by a citysponsored service that remains alive only because of a $200,000 emergency loan from the taxpayers.

title: Events Today
description: FOOD DAY FESTIVAL: Booths with nutrition information, food and entertainment; 11 A.M. to 4 P.M.; Central Park bandshell, Fifth Avenue and 72d Sheet.

title: The Prodigy and the Man
description: YEHUDI MENUHIN is a stately, dignified man, and he has written a stately, dignified autobiography. In many respects he has been one of the lucky ones, and that has nothing to do with his violin playing. For in addition to his genius with bow and finger, he was born with charismasomething that cannot be learned or purchased. Handsome, sensitivelooking, wellbred, he is the public's dream of what a great violinist should look like. He has a physical and psychic domination over his audiences; his personality arcs right over the stage into the auditorium, and he conquers even before he starts playing.

title: Thomas Cutler Jr to Wed Beverly Haskins
description: The engagement of Beverly Ivins Haskins to Thomas Pollard Cutler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cutler of Brookline, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Chandler Haskins of Concord and Wianno, Mass.

title: Iron Derby Wins Stakes at Pimlico Opener
description: BALTIMORE, April 16 (AP)Iron Derby defeated Jeff's Try by a neck to win the $27,500 Hirsch Jacobs Stakes today at Pimlico Race Course.

title: Boys High Wins 3 Relays, Title In New Jersey
description: KEARNY, N.J., April I6Boys and Girls High of Brooklyn continued on the comeback trail today as it won three open events and just missed taking one more in the West New York Memorial Relays on Kearny High School's lightningfast allweather track.

title: U.S. Clinches Davis Cup Series With South Africa, 30
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., April 16Bob Lutz and Stan Smith won from Byron Bertram and Frew McMillan, 75, 61, 36, 63, today for an insurmountable 30 lead over South Africa that assured the United States Davis Cup team a trip to Buenos Aires for the American Zone tennis final in two weeks.

title: Manhattan Groups Attend Workshops On Neighborhoods
description: While many New Yorkers were out enjoying the balmy weather yesterday, Jane O'Connor sat in the foyer of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association at 331 Fast 70th Street, listening to a discussion of sanitation problems in the city.

title: Baseball's Rare Birds
description: The designated hitter is older than the general manager. The first baseman was a roughneck on a North Sea oil rig off the Scottish coast. The second baseman is getting a second chance. The shortstop batted 1.000 in the World Series last year. The third baseman is a Canadian. Two of the outfielders have the same name but not the same color. The other outfielder has the name of another sport. The catcher's claim to fame is having seen two of Sandy Koufax's nohittersas a teenage spectator. The lefthanded starter kicks high in his windup the way Juan Marichal did as a righthander. The pitching coach had a 112 wonlost record with the original New York Mets. And the manager played second base in eight cities that are in the major leagues now but were in the minors then.

title: Albany Is Requiring the Conservation of Soil and Water by Landowners
description: ALBANY, April 12New York state is losing groundabout 45 milion tons of soil year, washed out of farm fields and stream banks by rain and rushing rivers.

title: Copano Wins on Hialeah Turf
description: HIALEAH, Fla., April 16 (AP)Copano scored an impressive turf victory over Imogene II today in Hialeah Park's $66,000 Black Helen Handicap despite carrying 11 to 17 pounds more than each of the 12 other fillies and mares in the field.

title: Mary Brennan Married To Winthrop Newcomb
description: Mary Ann Brennan and Winthrop Holbrook Newcomb were married yesterday at noon in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Winchester, Mass., by the Rev. Bernard Hoy.

title: The shape of a blazer
description: Left, waistshaped blazer of cranberrycolored polyester and linen has metal buttons, side vents. By Stanley Blacker. $125 at Barney's. Slacks: Trousers by Barry. Shirt by Aetna. Tie by Cappuccino.

title: City Council Units Set Hearings for the Week
description: The following public meetings will be held by New York City Council committees this week:

title: DISEASE UNIT PLANS BIG REEVALUATION
description: Dr. William H. Foege, the new director of the Center for Disease Control, has begun a major reevaluation of the center's objectives and daily operations in an effort to determine what, if any, changes should be made in the Federal agency.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1LANGDON CLAY; MAGNUM/ ALEX WEBB

title: Food
description: As we have noted on numerous occasions, thoughts on foods seem to go in cycles; this looks like another of our years for chocolate desserts. There is a twofold reason for the chocolate pie listed here: it has one of the most Incredibly delicate and luscious chow late fillings, and it is made with what might be called an almostfailsafe pastry (to make it totally failsafe, it should be made in a food processor). To further illustrate the versatility of this pastry, we are also offering a fullbodied and traditional French apple tart.

title: GARDEMING
description: THE North Shore provides an exceptional environment for plants, and for a good reason. The planthardiness map for the United States published by the United Sates Department or Agriculture shows that the major outdoor production areas for horticultural crops in the Northeast are all adjacent to sizable bodies of water.

title: A Lighthouse With a Legend
description: IN the days when great wooden ships sailed Long Island Sound under taut canvas clouds, men and lighthouses stood watch over the rocks and shoals that dotted the waters, lying in wait for the unwary.

title: Murmuring Over a Brook
description: MY HUSBAND and I, having succumbed to the beauty and prestige of a home by a babbling brook, now find that our equity, which was considered to be the best hedge against inflation, may now be destroyed by the bureaucratic malevolence of floodways, flood fringes and floodplains. The ramifications of the Federal and state regulations, which differ, are ambiguous, unconstitutional and, ultimately will worsen the problems they set out to correct.

title: FILM VIEW
description: So far it has not been a good year. To be a bit more blunt about it, these last three and a half months have been about as bleak a period for commercial films as any recent time I can remember. We've been overloaded with suspense melodramas to the point where our ruses tre giving out. It's next to impossible to tell the difference between those that are wellmade (Black Sunday, The Eagle Has Landed) from those that are especially mindless (The Domino Principle, The Cassandra Crossing,) and one that is both wellmade and mindless (Twilight's Last Gleaming). And does anyone really care? I suspect not since the movies aren't about anything at all.

title: Weddings
description: EngelmanShapiro

title: Fishing Truce Faces A Test
description: AN UNEASY PEACE has lasted through the three summers since lines were drawn around the edges of Long Island Sound to keep commercial fishing vessels from intruding too close to the shore into the areas that are now the preserve of sport fishermen. The test of this peace should come next month with the arrival of great numbers of menhaden, known also as bunkersthe oily, inconsequentiallooking fish that, even though much soughtafter, never seem to find a place on restaurant menus and are not much fun to catch.

title: A Stroll in London With Pip, Fagin and Oliver
description: Charles Dickens is commemorated in London by a small museum, at 48 Doughty Street, where he set up house after his marriage and wrote Oliver Twist. But there is more to the city of Dickens than that: A number of places he used as the settings of his novels are still to be seen, tucked away in the byways of central London. Those settings are often thought to be fictional, but many of them existed, and still existin spite of time, the World War II blitz and urban renewaland invite visitors to step into the pages of his stories.

title: Assembly Vote Due On ScenicRiver Bill
description: IS THERE any New Jersey river worth saving as a recreation area? A bill creating the state's first wild and scenic river system may come up for a vote in the Assembly tomorrow.

title: Dean Skylar to Wed Christine Ledbetter
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Lee Ledbetter of Downingtown, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christine Louise Ledbetter, to Dean Miller Skylar, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Skylar of Shaker Heights, Ohio. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Sheryl Pomerance Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Pomerance of Southfield, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheryl Ann Pomerance, to Charles Seigerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Seigerman of Monsey, N. Y. The future bridegroom's mother is Victoria K. Seigerman, clerk to the Rockland County Legislature in New City, N. Y. Miss Pomerance attends the School of Dentistry at the University of Michigan. Mr. Seigerman, who graduated from the University of Michigan, is with the National Institute for Behavior Change in Birmingham, Mich.

title: Israel Gives Bernstein a 30Year Retrospective
description: TRL AVIV An important tact to remember about Israel is that it had an orchestra before it was a nation. This, better than words. speaks of how firmly implanted music has been in the development of the land and the lives of the people. The year the Israel Philharmonic is 40 years old. It marked the birthday by celebrating another anniversarythe 20th of Leonard Berastein's IPO debut, which took place when the Philharmonic was still the Palestine Orchestra.

title: A Life Cycle for All
description: PRECISELY on schedule, on March 21, a pair of ospreys settled down onto a tall nesting pole along the shore of the Sound in the town where I work. These powerful and stately fish hawks had just completed another roundtrip journey from their wintering grounds in South America.

title: Yale's Students Ask For a Greater Voice On Budget Priorities
description: NEW HAVEN, April 16The rising cost of a Yale education, coupled with cutbacks in faculty positions, the elimination of entire academic departments and overcrowding in classes, has provoked widespread student clamor on campus for a greater voice in determining budgetary priorities.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Gilliland, A. D. Soussloff Plan Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Gilliland of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Seeley Gilliland, to Andrew Dimitri Soussloff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dimitri G. Soussloff of Wyomissing, Pa. An August wedding is planned.

title: Trade Board Sets Up Crime Project
description: The New York Board of Trade has begun to set up a demonstration project that relies heavily on local business leaders to fight crime in the 17th precinct, which covers the middle East Side.

title: Even in His New Job, Mr. Strauss Is Caught in the Middle
description: WASHINGTONRobert S. Strauss, President Carter's new special trade representative, is caught right in the middle of an angry debate among powerful, competing interests who have taken irreconcilable positions on issues involving enormous stakes. As a former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, he feels right at home.

title: Dwindling Jews of East Berlin Struggling to Retain Their Heritage
description: EAST BERLIN  The old woman clapped her hands and softly hummed to the tune of a Yiddish folksong. She and the others in the oldfashioned meeting hall had come to attend a Sunday matinee at the Jewish community center. I always enjoy coming here, the springtly whitehaired woman told another visitor. It is good to keep in contact.

title: Vorster Says All Groups Will Share in Growth
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 16 (Reuters)Prime Minister John Vorster said today that his Government was committed to giving all population groups an increasing share in South Africa's economic development.

title: Hail Hilarious Triumphs At Hollywood Park
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 16 (AP)Hail Hilarious, with Don Pierce in the irons, outran five other fillies and mares today to capture the Gamely Handicap, with a purse of $53,750, at Hollywood Park.

title: Long Island
description: SEAFOOD restaurants dot Long Island's North Shore harbors and beachfronts, as if being directly at the water's edge guaranteed the freshness of their fare. Through plate glass windows they welcome in the waterfront, and their docks stretch into the bays. The best of the seafood is often freshly caught from local waters, the splendor of fish that was swimming that very morning.

title: The First Taste of Summer
description: LEAVES have blown in under the door, which has never fitted more than approximately. The beach has put in another season on its hibernal task of reclaiming the three steps up to the porch. An agree able mustiness from saltsoaked walls, a sense that there are cobwebs out there in the shuttered dimness, a hint that someone may have left a corner of a fried cheese sandwich to ossify on the kitchen counterthese combine to create a cry as primal as a mating call: Spring on the Sound and time to open the beach cottage.

title: Pulitzer Poet at Kean
description: GARY SNYDER, who will read his poetry in a Townsend Lecture Series program at Kean College tomorrow evening. shatters the stereotype of the obscure modern poet. Each selection of poems he publishes seems more transparent to its objects, less effortful in its meansand thus more accessible to the readerthan the one before. It is as if, increasingly, he has been living the advice he gives to the young in his Pulitzer Prizewinning book Turtle Island on their difficult climb toward the 21st century: stay together learn the flowers go light

title: ONE CRITIC'S FICTION
description: ARE contemporary writers bored with people and their predicaments? About half the stories in this anthology give that impression. There is in them only the remotest hint of characters, and these are often no more than keys to unlock what turns out to be only a literary puzzle. Everybody is all metaphor: Real life has been flushed away like waste. Such stories are one continuous climaxor anticlimax. There are few transitions, nothing so plodding as development. Situations are instantaneous and arbitrary. It is as if these authors are trying to establish an alternative theory of human nature.

title: Deaths
description: HOROWITZMorton, of of Lauderhill, Fla., on April 16, survived by wife Ray, daughters Mrs. Elaine Wasserman and Laurie, son Steven and a sister Mrs. Irene frame. Member of the Cosmopolitan Sam Harris Lodge, K. of P.

title: The In Places
description: Buddy Korsh is a devoted fisherman. He also is selfemployed, which makes it possible for him to be part of the closely knit clan known as Long Island Sound's hardcore fishermen.

title: CONCORDE FOES URGE SUPPORT FOR PROTEST
description: Ignoring a court order, opponents of the supersonic Concorde jetliner used sound trucks and distributed leaflets in sections of Queens, Brooklyn and Nassau Counties yesterday in an effort to marshal support for today's planned protest and motorcade of thousands of cars at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Lyle Is the Victim of Rally by Brewers
description: MILWAUKEE. April 16Billy Martin discovered a miracle cure for Reggie Jackson, but he still hasn't found the wonder drug that will cure the Yankees' general ailment.

title: Opera: Clamma Dale as Nedda
description: There were two debuts in Friday night's New York City Opera presentation of Cavalleria Rusticana, but Pagliacci worked better, as overall performance, and the most exciting portrayal of the night was Clamma Dale's Nedda.

title: Velikovsky Lives Again
description: IT is often difficult to explain to nonscientists why the name of Immanuel Velikovsky or any of his followers makes scientists go purple in the face. The books seem intelligent and scholarly. They are full of undoubtedly real names, dates and facts. Booklength treatises have been written in refutation. This review has not the space to summarize them, but the short answer is that science is not done by adopting a parti pris and then marshaling facts, speculations and downright imagination in support of it.

title: The Sunny Sea at Our Back Door
description: MYSTIQUES hover like fog over bodies of water. The mystique derives not so much from the water itself as from man's struggle with it. Water has been both bridge and barrier, and our constant efforts to make it do what we want have challenged and harassed literary people since the days of Homer. Implacable. Storm toss'd. Raging. Towering. Painted. Cruel. Romantic. These are the words that futilely try to capture the sea while it runs through our fingers or inundates us.

title: Announcer Finishes First In Golden Gate Handicap
description: ALBANY, Calif., April 16 (AP)Elmendorf Farms' Announcer ruined the West Coast debut of a pair of Eastern invaders, Effervescing and Angel Cordero Jr., and stalled the comeback bid of Telly's Pop in the $116,000 Golden Gate Handicap today at Golden Gate Fields.

title: What the Doctors Order: Condo Office Buildings
description: A major new real estate specialtythe medial office buildingis emerging from the changing nature of health care.

title: French Policy Today
description: PARIS  The only significant change in the French foreign policy inherited by President Giscard d'Estaing has been normalization of relations with Israel, marked this month by Foreign Minister Guiringaud's visit to Jerusalem and symbolized by his award to Walter Eytan, chairman of the Israeli Broadcasting Authority, of the coveted Legion of Honor.

title: Floatable Feasts
description: EATING, for many people whose lives or leisure involve the Sound, means moist, pearly fish, patentleather mussels, briny clams and succulent lobsters. It is the joy of seafood at its freshest along with the agony, for those with boats, of preparing it in a pocketsized galley with a twoburner stove. There are a number of new books intended to enhance the pleasure and relieve the problems.

title: KingABC Fights Are Suspended Pending an Inquiry
description: MIAMI BEACH, April 16. (UPI)The United States Boxing Championships, promoted by Don King and funded by ABC Television, have been suspended pending an investigation into boxers' rankings by Ring Magazine, which was also involved in the project.

title: Goodbye, Doldrums
description: The warm breezes of spring have apparently coaxed the economy out of its winter doldrums, for the economic indicators in recent days have been as cheering as the first flowers of the season.

title: The Confidence Man
description: Maybe the combination will do it. Maybe President Carter's decision to drop his proposed $50perperson tax rebate as well as the announcement of his antiinflation plans will at last create the business confidence he and his advisers seem to seek above all else.

title: Carey vs. Beame: the Undeclared War
description: So the Democratic Governor of New York has set out to retire the Democratic Mayor of New York City. Why? Because Hugh Carey has concluded, first, that the wrong Mayor would gravely damage his own administration and career, and second, that without his intervention Abe Beame stood to win reelection, or lose to someone worse.

title: The Gap Too Wide to Bridge
description: ASSEMBLYMAN Robert C. Weitz, in his introduction to his recent bill to resurrect the RyeOyster Bay Bridge project, estimates that 225,000 heavy commercial vehicles would travel the bridge annually. This figures out to 616 trac tortrailers on average a day, 25 on average an hour, or one tractortrailer on average every two minutes. This is Mr. Wertz's idea of landuse planning for residential Southern Westchester and the North Shore of Long Island.

title: Suffolk County's Population Rise Exceeds Nassau's for the 19th Year
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 16For the 19th consecutive year, Suffolk County's population has grown at a faster rate than the population of neighboring Nassau County, the Long Island Lighting Cotitpany reported this week.

title: Headliners
description: Muriel F. Siebert, who became the first woman member of the New York Stock Exchange a decade ago, has been nominated by Governor Carey to be superintendent of banks. Miss Siebert won a reputation on Wall Street as a specialist in aerospace stocks, and once had several of New York City's larger banks as her clients. But lately her firm has switched to a discount commission business designed to attract individual investors. Among the questions she faces in her new post are redlining and the financing of urban housing, and the oversight of foreign and multinational bank branches and agencies.

title: U.S. Worries Over Pakistani Drugs
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan  American narcotics agents are worried that Pakistan may some day become a major source of heroin for the American market.

title: HONE CLINIC
description: APOPULAR feature of many homes that border on or over look the North or South Shores of Long Island Sound is a raised outdoor wood deckor, in some cases, a waterfront dock on pilings that is also used as a sun deck and outdoor lounging area.

title: Clifford Jordan Plays Jazz at the Tin Palace
description: Clifford Jordan, who appeared at the Tin Palace on Friday and yesterday and will be there again next weekend, began his jazz career in the mid50's. He was a hardblowing tenor saxophonist with fine technique and a hybrid style that was fairly typical of the period. Like many musicians of his generation, he was taken aback at first by the developments of the early 60's, particularly by Ornette Coleman's concept of free jazz.

title: B. M. Baker 3d Plans to Wed Laura Kautz
description: The engagement of Laura Livingston Kautz to Benjamin M. Baker 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Baker of Baltimore, has been announced by Rudolph L. Kautz Jr. of Branford, Conn., father of the future bride.

title: Clambake At the Shore
description: THE SEASON is fast approaching for that most dramatic, ceremonious andin its own waygratifying of American feasts, the jolly institution known as a clambake on the shore.

title: Sanctuary: Long Island Sound
description: Detached at last from our accustomed moorings we set our skiff and weary selves adrift and let the waters work their wonders, curing woes of the world until our spirits lift. Beyond those rocky straits with breakers rolling, we steer past narrows of anxiety; the Sound is Sundaycalm, buoys gently tolling their exhortation toward a promised sea.

title: A Solitary Sentinel
description: IN the days when great wooden ships sailed Long Island Sound under taut canvas clouds, men and lighthouses stood watch over the rocks and shoals that dotted the waters, lying in wait for the unwary. Today, the wooden ships are only beautiful and romant?? curiosities and the weathered lighthouses are for the most part victims of an advancing technology, no longer needing the hand of man.

title: Graduate Buys His
description: AVARIATION of the scenario about an alumnus returning to school as the principal or football coach is being acted out in Ridgewood. In the case of the Union Street School, however, an alumnus is returning as the owner of the school, which the borough disposed of in a sealedbid auction in June 1975.

title: Cradle for Yachting's Contenders
description: SOME time next month, the 12meter yacht Enterprise will be trucked across the country from San Diego to the Minneford Yacht Yard on City Island in the Bronx for modification and a final outfitting in preparation for the America's Cup challenge in Newport, R. I.. on Sept. 13.

title: CHESS
description: When it comes to upsetting an opponent, maneuvering him into unfamiliar terrain, the Danish grandmaster Bent Larsen is hard to top. Consider his fifthround game with the Icelandic grandmaster Gudmunur Sigurjonsson from the Geneva International Tournament.

title: U.S. Urged to Seek More Secure Route For Mideast Airlift
description: A Congressional study has proposed that Congress consider the development of a selfsufficient United States airlift to supply and support American and other forces, including those of Israel, in the event of another war in the Middle East. It also raises questions about the value of bases in the region over the longer term in relation to their costs and other factors.

title: Steven Ard Mojo Marries Jean Noonan in Bay State
description: At St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in Wellesley Hill, Mass., yesterday afternoon Jean Marie Noonan, an assistant account manager with Compton Advertising in New York, was married to Steven Ard Mojo, an assistant product manager at the WarnerLambert Company in Morris Plains, N.J. The Rev. John Philbin performed the ceremony.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The fifth game in the Islanders' quarterfinal round of the Stanley Cup playoffs with the Buffalo Sabres is scheduled for Tuesday night at 8 o'clock in the Nassau Coliseum. The series moves to Buffalo for game 6 on Thursday and returns to the Coliseum Saturday night at 8 o'clock.

title: Sears, Roebuck: Nation's Banker?
description: LOS ANGELESIn a dispute that probably foreshadows similar clashes in the future as the nation shifts into the uncertain era of electronic banking, major .opposition is developing to a plan by Sears, Roebuck and Company to move heavily into the savings and loan industry.

title: Jay Ring, Accountant, And Lisa Brodsky To Wed in August
description: Dr. and Mrs. William A. Brodsky of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Brodsky, to Jay Michael Ring, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney B. Ring of St. Louis. An August wedding is planned.

title: Some Saccharin, Not All Saccharin
description: By modifying a proposed ban on saccharin to permit it to be sold as an overthecounter drug, the Food and Drug Administration has put the burden of a conscious choice to use saccharin on the consumer. The agency is convinced that saccharin can cause cancer, and will require a warning to be carried on saccharin packages. Because saccharin would still be prohibited in commercially prepared foods and beverages, the agency expects that inadvertent use of saccharin will be eliminated, and total consumption much reduced.

title: Miss Burchenal Sets June Bridal
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Holland Burchenal of Noroton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Payne Burchenal, to Walter DeMiller Wilson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson of Mobile, Ala.

title: Something for Everyone by the Shore
description: ONE raw day recently when a chill wind was whipping up whitecaps on Long Island Sound and sweeping across the boardwalk at Playland, gardeners were carefully clearing patches for the flowers that will soon decorate its handsome mall.

title: Alexa Stirling Fraser, Golfer, 79
description: OTTAWA, April 16 (AP)Alexa Stirling Fraser, one of the biggest names in women's golf more than half a century ago, died yesterday after a long illness. She was 79 years old.

title: Baseball in Jersey City: A Faint Echo of the Past
description: Organized baseball returned to Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City Friday night after an absence of 16 years as the Cleveland Indians shifted their Eastern League franchise from Williamsport, Pa.

title: Protection for The Sound's Kitchen
description: IN a few weeks, if all goes better than it has so far, New York's long overdue inventory of tidal wetlands will be ready. When the maps are published and registered, the final stage will be set for an effort whose main goal is seen as no less than the salvation of the Sound from extinction.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: CITY REQUESTS A WRIT IN STEEPLECHASE CASE
description: The city has asked a State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn to bar the operator of the Steeplechase Park at Coney Island train the amusement site, which is city property.

title: Why Was April the Cruellest Month?
description: THE most discussed modern poem in English since 1922, The Waste Land, broke into the news again in 1968, three years after Eliot's death, with the announcement that its lost manuscript had been discovered among John Quinn's papers at the New York Public Library. The 1971 facsimile edition of the manuscript is edited by Eliot's second wife, Valerie, who sums up in her introduction what is at this point known about the poem's biographical backgroundthat Eliot's first marriage with Vivienne HaighWood in 1915 was unhappy, that husband and wife were psychologically disturbed, Vivienne especially so, and that The Waste Land was mainly written just before and during the six weeks of 1921, when Eliot underwent psychiatric treatment at Lausanne. She quotes Eliot's statement that his illness made much of the writing automatic, and therefore, we can infer, unwittingly confessional.

title: Thousands March in Dublin To Back Hunger Strikers
description: DUBLIN, April 16 (UPI)Thousands of demonstrators marched through the city center today, shouting their support for 18 prisoners on a hunger strike in the Curragh Military Hospital.

title: SELECTION
description: ONE night the cast and crew of a film shooting in the nearby desert came into Las Vegas for a night on the town. The Director was a degenerate gambler with unlimited credit and a faulty understanding of the percentages. The Casino Manager welcomed him with open arms. Unfortunately the. Director was accompanied by the Leading Lady of the film who had a profound belief in the powers of the zodiac.

title: Letters
description: C. P. Gilmore's article (Taking exercise to heart, March 27), was a fair and accurate account of the current status of exercise as a potential benefit to the heart and cardiovascular system. I feel it should be strongly emphasized, however, that periodic, careful exercise testing (with EKG monitoring) is essential for all persons over 35 years of age before they are encouraged to engage in vigorous exercise.

title: Arabs and Mexicans Seeking to Buy Boats Idled in Tuna Protest
description: SAN DIEGO, April 16Saudi Arabian oil interests and the Mexican Government are competing to take over a large part of the American tuna fleet, which is immobilized at dockside here in a dispute over Federal restrictions on its operations.

title: Indy 500 Field Grows By Five Entries to 58
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 16 (AP)The field for the 61st Indianapolis 500 jumped to 58 today as five more cars were entered in the May 29 auto race.

title: IN AMERICA
description: PALM BEACH, Fla. Fred Schiafly should be given his due as the man who made possible the movement that for two years now has battled the Equal Rights Amendment to a virtual standstill III. E.R.A. would have been ratified months ago if only he had kept his wife and the mother of his six children at home in Alton, Ill., in her place.

title: Los Angeles Will Allow Private Taxis to Operate
description: LOS ANGELES, April 16In this city or freeways and threecar families, just about anyone will soon be able to turn his car into a taxi.

title: Twins Stop A's and Blue Behind Zahn
description: Geoff Zahn outpitching Vida Blue? This unlikely scenario developed yesterday when Blue made his first start of the season for the Oakland A's and was defeated by Zahn and the Minnesota Twins, 31.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: MASS MARKET

title: What's in a Name? Apples and Anxiety
description: If you're the marketing director of the champion New York Sets of World Team Tennis and looking for a new name with the primary purpose of selling more tickets, I guess the only name that really makes sense is the New York Apples. In fact, in the recent contest to rename the Sets there were 5,000 entries, 48 of them Apples.

title: Suzanne Donahue Is Wed on L.I.
description: St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in Great Neck, L. I., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Suzanne Marie Donahue, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Francis Donahue of Manhasset, L. I., to George Bernard Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard, also of Manhasset.

title: Between Guilt and Gratification:
description: Enter a typical New York abortion clinic and you will see a sight never witnessed beforewaiting rooms filled with hundreds of young women, all of whom will ter minate their pregnancies that day. Most of them sit silent and alone. A few talk quietly with a male companion, perhaps the father of the soontobeaborted fetus. Almost no one bothers to look through the magazines on the table. No one stares inquisitively at her neighbors. It is a wretched time of waiting, when even the woman who is absolutely certain she does not want her child is emotionally torn. But for these women the wait is short, and the abortion itself, at least when the fetus is less than three months old, takes only a few minutes. After several hours' rest and a checkup, the women can leave.

title: Journalist in Argentina Is Reported Abducted
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 16 (Reuters)An Argentine journalist, Enrique Raab, was taken from his home today by armed men dressed in army uniforms, a colleague and neighbor of his reported.

title: TV VIEW
description: The willingness of the average citizen to perform on television can sometimes defy comprehension. People sit on panel shows casually discussing the most intimate details of their lives. They throw open their homes to camera crews for closeup portraits of themselves and their families, In a seeming frenzy of look, Ma, I'm dancing innocence, they put their lives on public display. Six American Families, the publicTV series currently being shown on Mondays at 8 P.M., is one of the more prominent of recent example. Calculated for maximum diversity, its portraits are in the style established by An American Family, the publicTV project that, a few years ago, ended in bitter recriminations between the filmed family and the producers.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East OrangeKennedy's Children. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through May 14). $2.90$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$3.90; group rates. (201) 6751881.

title: New President Sworn At Brown University
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 16 Howard R. Swearer was sworn in today as Brown University's 15th president, and in an address at the ceremony called on universities to participate vigorously in shaping the emerging new environment in which we operate.

title: Elderly Become A Political Force
description: THE elderly and retired have found their political voice this election year, and are fast becoming a most effective lobbying force. Instead of talking over their problems in local seniorcitizen or golden age clubs, usually amid growing feelings of frustration, the aged have learned that there is strength in numbers.

title: ENVIRONMENT GROUPS BACK CARTER EFFORT'S TO CURB DAM BUILDING
description: WASHINGTON, April 16Environmentalist groups rallied today to the support of President Carter's water projects policy even though the President evidently plans to restore partial or complete funding to nearly half the 30 projects he had reviewed for possible cancellation.

title: Floatable Feasts
description: EATING, for many people whose lives or leisure involve the Sound, means moist, pearly fish, patentleather mussels, briny clams and succulent lobsters. It is the joy of seafood at its freshest along with the agony, for those with boats, of preparing it in a pocketsized galley with a twoburner stove. There are a number of new books intended to enhance the pleasure and relieve the problems.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: YOU could call this caper Roots Traduced or maybe The Revenge of the Confederacy. It seems that in two widely separate locales, copies of Roots have turned up with the text of Gone With the Wind bound inside. That is, the books had Roots jackets and binding, but the words on the pages were all about Scarlett O'Hara and Rhett Butler and the War Between the States, suh.

title: Haiti Proclaims 200Mile Limit
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, April 16 (UPI)Haiti joined the United States and several other Latin American countries today by proclaiming a 200mile offshore limit.

title: A Cartoonist's Romance With Filmmaking
description: SYDNEY, Australia Who is this Bruce Petty anyhow? Well, along with his fellow Australian, the late Peter Finch, he won an Oscar a couple of weeks ago. In Petty's case, the award was for an animated short called Leisure. To Australians, the award came as no surprise. Petty has long been their outstanding political cartoonist; in tact he is probably better known as a newspaper cartoonist than as a filmmaker. His work is widely admired internationally, and he has been praised by such fellow artists as Ronald Searle, who talks about his electric line, and he has drawn for the New Yorker, Punch and various cartoon anthologies.

title: Miss Evert Defeats Miss Wade, 63, 64
description: TUCSON, Ariz., April 16 (AP)Chris Evert recovered from 34 in the second set and beat Virginia Wade, 63, 64, at the start of the fourplayer $100,000 World Series of women's tennis today. The top prize is $50,000.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Miss Stoll, 16, Topples Dr. Richards in Semifinal
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 16The Billie Jean King posters came down from Caroline Stoll's room tonight: the 16yearold high school junior from Livingston, N.J., will play Mrs. King, one of her idols, tomorrow at 1 P.M. in the final of the $20,000 Lionel Cup tennis tournament

title: Almost Everything Went Wrong For Bhutto
description: ISLAMABAD, PakistanThree months ago when Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto called what he described as his country's first completely democratic civilian election, it was generally regarded as a walkaway for him and few people doubted that, once reendorsed, he would stay on the scene for a good many years to come. But now, as chanting crowds race through the streets of Pakistan's cities demanding his resignation, the urbane Prime Minister is fighting for his political life. As a demonstrator in Lahore said, peering through a line of battleready guards outside the ornate Government residence where Mr. Bhutto was closeted in urgent consultations: He must be wondering what went wrong.

title: BillionDollar Bank Heist With Government Help
description: This is not the story of a bank robbery. Neither the great Willie Sutton nor any gang of desperadoes ever relieved a bank of billions. It is the story of robbery by banks that has been under way for more than 40 years. Moreover, the banks are not in this alone; their chief accomplice is the Federal Government.

title: The Sunny Sea at Our Back Door
description: MYSTIQUES hover like fog over bodies of water. The mystique derives not so much from the water itself as from man's struggle with it. Water has been both bridge and barrier, and our constant efforts to make it do what we want have challenged and harassed literary people since the days of Homer. Implacable. Storm toss'd. Raging Towering. Painted. Cruel. Romantic. These are the words that futilely try to capture the sea while it runs through our fingers or inundates us.

title: Albany Study Cites Vested Interest In Makeup of Blue Shield Boards
description: The New York State Consumer Protection Board charged yesterday that the leadership of Blue Shield plans in upstate New York, which insure subscribers for the costs of doctors' fees, was dominated by doctors and others who had a vested interest in increasing the income of physicians, rather than in controlling the costs of medical services.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: issued their joint management proposal for Long Island Soundon whether or not to open the dump site to disposal of the 33,700 cubic yards of dredge material anticipated by the 10 applicants on hand, as well as the 1.8 million cubic yards from other projects that the corps expects will be considered for openwater disposal in the next three years.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Those Murky Waters
description: FIFTEEN years ago, a Long Islander could clam off Glen Cove or swim in relatively clear water at Sunken Meadow State Park near Kings Park. But not any more.

title: BRIDGE
description: Bridge literature is full of littleoldlady, or L.O.L., stories. An expert finds himself opposing a whitehaired grandmother, often with a bag of knitting, and feels totally confident of the result. But a few minutes later he is a broken man, devastated by some fortuitcus stroke of brilliance.

title: Salming of Leafs Forges a Reputation As Mr. Clean Amid Hockey Onslaughts
description: TORONTO, April 16The sound of the puck striking his helmet and the side of his face cracked the air in the Philadelphia Spectrum. The crowd cheered as Bone Salming crumpled to the ice. The Toronto players circled around the tallen Swedish detenseman who has been holding up the Maple Leafs and steadying them. They have won 2 games and lost 1 in a fourofsevengame quarterfinal playoff series with the Philadelphia Flyers, The series' fourth game is tomorrow night in Maple Leaf Gardens.

title: A Correction
description: In photographs of the team that is planning the Carter Administration's energy policy, the names of S. David Freeman and Robert R. Nordhaus were inadvertently transposed, on the front page of last Sunday's Business and Finance Section. The two men are correctly identified below.

title: GARDENING
description: Beginning with the practical side of the new gardening bookshelf, there's Newcomb's Wildflower Guide, which as a guidebook has one remarkable feature: it works. Book in hand, I stood ankledeep in the snow at the cage or our marsh in the first week of spring, staring at what was obviously a skunk cabbage  wildflowers being hard to find at that date. Following the key system of the guide, I arrived at the number 111, which in turn led me to page 16, on which was duly pictured and describedthe skunk cabbage. My testing proceeded indoors where I identified such common local flora as trillium, bloodroot and jackinthepulpit from memory. Ah, if only all the illustrations were in color.

title: Deaths
description: YASGOUREmma, widow of late Louis, beloved mother of Abraham, David, Paula Rica and Helen Novak, grandmother of Vivian Margulies and Louise Yastrow, Roy and Edward Novak, William and Michael Rice. greatgrandmother of Ted and Dahlia Margulies, sister of Abraham and Ora. Services private.

title: DoItYourself Sprinkler System and Other New Products for the Home
description: Using a doityourself prepackaged sprinkling kit that comes complete with instructions, any homeowner can now put in his own underground lawn sprinkling system in less than one day, thus permanently eliminating the need for dragging wet garden hoses and sprinklers over his lawn several times a week.

title: More Lonely Than Evil
description: JAMES JOYCE once said that he could have written two conventional novels a year, but that it would not have been worth it. And it has been said by Anthony Burgess that the writer who refuses to acknowledge Joyce is like a person who, living near the foot of a mountain, pulls down his blinds and stubbornly refuses to look out. Nevertheless, it has been the case for decades that English novelists continue to work in a realistic and conventional tradition that looks back not to the great

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: WE live in a decadent era, replaying our tragedies as if they were farce. The moral anxiety of the fifties and apocalyptic dreams of the sixties have given way to the cautious greed and temporizing of the seventies. We've exchanged radicals and wits for Jesus and grits. The high technology of the moon shot years also gave us napalm, bugging devices and bionic man and woman dolls. The civil rights and black power movements have shriveled to Roots. We're big on body building, divorce, gourmet food and celebrity gossip. We're sexually eclectic and spiritually fatigued, prone to violent fantasies, sordid entertainments and sudden religious conversions. Beyond ideology, we're antiintellectual and proud of it. Our novelists proclaim the end is near. Slouching toward Zabar's, we reflect: the seventies are the fifties in drag.

title: On City Island,
description: SOME time next month, the 12meter yacht Enterprise will be rucked across the country from San Diego to the Minneford Yacht Yard on City Island in the Bronx for modification and a final outfitting in preparation for the America's Cup challenge in Newport, R. I., on Sept. 13.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayRhode Island K.C. 72d show and obedience trial, Meehan Auditorium, Brown University, Providence; limit 1,200 dogs; 8 A.M. to 8 P.M.

title: Supermarkets: New Sales Pitch
description: CUSTOMER service, which has enabled many department and specialty stores to keep their clientele happy and acquire new accounts, has been extended to, of all things, the supermarket.

title: Sneed, at 206, Leads by Shot At Tallahassee
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 16 (AP)Ed Sneed shot a 68 today for a 10underpar total of 206 and a onestroke lead after 54 holes of the Tallahassee open golf tournament. Sneed, a twotime winner of the PGA Tour, had been tied for third place at the start of the round.

title: The art of elegance
description: I feel that to be well dressed is to be badly dressed, declares Ivan Chermayeff, the industrial designer, which is by way of saying that he doesn't want his clothes to look as if he really pays attention to them.

title: Playing the Ratings Game at NBC
description: A visitor to the plush, whitecarpeted executive offices of the National Broadcasting Company in Rockefeller Center could well expect the mood there to be gloomy.

title: President Backs Young on Angola
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI)President Carter, rising again to the defense of Andrew Young, the chief United States delegate at the United Nations, says that he, too, believes the presence of Cuban troops stabilized the situation in Angola.

title: Births
description: Charno

title: I .L. A. Unit to Study New Terms Offered To End Dock Strike
description: New proposals advanced by management and the Federal Government will be considered tomorrow by the: wagescale committee of the International Longshoremen's Association in an effort to end the threedayold strike by 35,000 dock workers.

title: What's Good for the Oil Companies...
description: The energy crisis is really a gas and oil crisis. Twenty years ago the United States was virtually selfsufficient in these two fuels; last year, with steadily growing demand and slowly declining domestic output, we were forced to import a third of our total oil and gas requirements. Conservation, combined with increased reliance on coal, can slow the growth of gas and oil consumption. Since we wish to reduce our dependence on foreign energy, however, we will have to start producing more of our own gas and oil.

title: One Garden, Undivided, With Liberty and Leisure for All
description: After a long, tedious and frigid winter, everyone is thinking spring. But thinking spring for some serious gardeners also means hard work. So many favorite perennials require lifting, dividing and replanting.

title: Radicals in Berkeley Face a Test at Polls on Tuesday
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 17Although this university town of about 115,000 persons has long been associated with liberal and radical causes, the political left has not held power in the city. That could change, however, in the nonpartisan City Council election Tuesday, in which a strong leftwing coalition has its best chance ever to win a Council, majority.

title: H.E.W. USING CONSULTANT IN CHICAGO SCHOOLS CASE
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI)An outside consultant is helping the Carter Administration negotiate a settlement in the politically touchy Chicago school desegregation case.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Why is dance so popular nowadays? It a question I am often asked. Well, it not as if it were as popular as baseball, or even movies, or theater. Undoubtedly its popularity is growingindeed, in the arts, it is the biggest growth industry in the United States, and probably in the entire Western world. It is just possible that its popularity is slowly leveling off now more about that possibility laterbut, unquestionably, the rise of interest in dance over, say, the past 10 years has been spectacular. Nor, clearly, is it merely a passing phase, for while the expansion of interest in dance is clearly not limitless, even if its rate of growth is slowing down, there is no abatement in the present degree of interest. Also, it revealingly seems to make its greatest appeal to the young. Dance audiences, from simple observation, appear to be markedly younger on the whole than the audiences for theater, opera or serious music.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Disabled in San Francisco Vow to Continue SitIn
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 16The occupation of the local offices of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare by more than 100 handicapped demonstrators entered its 12th day today and continues to generate widespread community support.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Potential child abusers sometimes develop funtinal or psychosomatic ailments to signal their need for help, doctors at Colorado General Hospital and the University of Colorado Medical Center report. If emergency room personnel recognize such signals, the doctors say in the Journal of the American Medical Association, some child abuse cases can be prevented.

title: Andretti's Great Goal: World Formula 1 Title
description: Mario Andretti may be off Cloud 9 in time for next Sunday's United States Auto Club championship race in Trenton, and then again he may not be. The Nazareth, Pa., driver has been in a happy state since April 3 when he won the Formula 1 championship race through the streets of Long Beach, Calif.

title: Alaska Pipeline... What Happens When the Oil Flows
description: LONG BEACH, Calif.These days the rubblestrewn finger of landfill jutting out into San Pedro Bay holds shiny new Toyotas just off the boat from Japan. But the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) is betting millions of dollars that, within two years, the land can be turned into a terminal and pipeline connection to receive Alaskan oil.

title: Future Events
description: Live Mannequins

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: The tale of the lovely young princess put to sleep for a hundred years by a vengeful fairy retains its shimmering sense of fate and romance, with David Walker's misty, dreamlike, watercolor paintings helping to cast the perfect magic spell.

title: Helen Spoor King Married
description: Helen Spoor King, widow of Richard H. King, and an administrative aide to Grayson Kirk, president emeritus of Columbia University, was married yesterday afternoon to Stuart Murdock Ensinger of Madison, N. J., a retired vice president of the Bankers Trust Company of New York. The Rev. Eugene Laubach, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony in Christ Chapel of Riverside Church. Mr. Ensinger's first wife, the former Beulah Crane, died last year.

title: Hospital Benefit Tomorrow
description: The New York City Friends of the Southampton Hospital will give a cocktail party and fashion show tomorrow at the Club El Morocco. Charlotte Ford will present her 1977 fall clothing for women. Tickets are $25 and are available from Serge Obolensky Associates at 30 East 60th Street.

title: Engagements
description: KahnMouallem

title: Education Alternative: Return to the Basics
description: EDUCATION is one of those sensitive areas in which the entire field of public policymaking is inextricably and immediately connected to public welfare. The issues confronting public education in New Jersey over the next few months and years are of such weight that state officials cannot afford to assign them anything less than top priority. The decisions made by these elected and appointed officials on the conduct of education in this state will affectwith force and immediacythe lives of every person within its borders.

title: WOMEN'S G.O.P. CLUB HONORS FOE OF ERA.
description: The Women's National Republican Club yesterday honored Phyllis Schlafly, leader of the opposition to the proposed Equal Rights Amendment, at a WaldorfAstoria Hotel luncheon, and the event prompted picketing and a piethrowing incident.

title: Challenge Awaits Mr. Blandings
description: IF A PLOY being planned by the state's Division of Community Affairs is successful, the cost of singlefamily homes in New Jersey may be cut by as much as $20,000 each

title: Gore Vidal, Essayist
description: YOU only have to read a few sentences of an essay by Gore Vidal and he's right there with you in the room, sitting in the chair opposite. There are times when you are wholly delighted with this presence, times when you fall out of your chair fromlaughing. At other times you feel he's a clever, earnest student who doesn't like the academy and isn't liked by quite all the teachers nor by quite all the other students, but who's, trying to impress on you that he's cleverer in class and out of class than the whole bunch of them, put together. There are moments when he seems'to be an unelected President who insists on reading to you his undelivered acceptanceofthePresidency address. He hams this up a bit by doing, at the same time, a takeoff of the way in which he read the same address at Sarah Lawrence College. You try to conceal from him the fact that whatever his subject, for you it is nearly always he who is the subject you find the most interesting.

title: Bilingual Classes Are Said to Lag
description: NEW JERSEY'S twoyearold bilingual education law, which was hailed as a step toward bringing the state's Spanishspeaking children into language parity with their public school classmates, has fallen far short of its goals, according to leading members of the Puerto Rican community.

title: American Classic
description: Spring and summer clothes are cool and comfortable. They're classically styled, and most are made of natural fabrics. Suit jackets have a minimum of shoulder padding and waist suppression, the trousers only a slight flare. Sport coats are back in solidcolor and plaid cotton madras, and in linen blends patterned in traditional checks and plaids in soft colors. Blazers, mostly doublebreasted, are back, too.

title: The Heights Remain A Place of Refuge
description: From below no one expects a touch of Tudor England to rise out of Pinehurst Avenue. But that is what Hudson View Gardens, one of New York's earliest experiments in cooperative living, looks like.

title: Suspect Arrested In Beating Death Of Optometrist, 67
description: A 27yearold Bowery drifter was charged yesterday with the murder of a 67yearold optometrist whose body was found by some of his patients Friday in his office at 34 Third Avenue.
