title: The Standings
description: Monday, April 18, 1977

title: Lester Johnson, 69, Commissioner Of Customs Service From '64 to '69
description: MIAMI, April 17 (AP)Lester D. Johnson, Commissioner of Customs from 1964 to 1969, died today in a Miami hospital after a long illness. He was 69 years old. Mr. Johnson retired in 1972 and moved to Miami from Washington after 36 years in the Federal Government. He served as Treasury attach in Tokyo from 1955 to 1958 and in Rome from 1959 to 1962.

title: Chart of Hollywood Derby
description: C 1877 by Triangle Publications Inc. The Daily Racing Form.

title: CARTER WILL PRESENT ENERGY VIEW TONIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, April 17President Carier will attempt tomorrow night to persuade the nation that the energy shortage is real and that the continued was of fuels could have disastrous consequences, White House officials said today.

title: Sri Lanka Greets Chou Widow
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, April 17 (Reuters)Teng Yingchao, widow of Prime Minister Chou Enlai of China, was given a welcome of the sort accorded a visiting head of state today. Miss Teng, on a goodwill visit to China's biggest trading partner, was met by President William Gopallawa and Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike and drummers beat out a rhythmic welcome at the airport.

title: Auto Racing
description: 1Cale Yarborough, Chevrolet, 500, $22,950.

title: Floundering Against Crime
description: Ten years ago, the Federal Government launched a major effort against rising crime. Since then, the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration has spent more than $6 billion trying to improve criminal justice systems across the country and helping them curtail crime. L.E.A.A. has done some useful workbut mainly it has floundered. What might have been a strong Federal stimulus to a national anticrime effort became the victim of too many different missions and different hopes. Now the Carter Administration has decided to step back and reevaluate the agency and its aims.

title: TRADING IN FUTURES FOR MARCH SOARED BY A RECORD 67.5%
description: A dramatic 67.5 percent increase in futures trading was recorded on the nation's 10 commodity exchanges last month. The record gain in business brought total volume for the first quarter 37 percent above the 1976 level.

title: Deaths
description: AKSMANLester, (P.E.), 61 years old, beloved husband of Cyrene, devoted father of Jason and Stacey, loving son of Lillian Axman, cherished brother of Milton, Martin and Sol. Services Monday, 1 P.M.,. Jeffer Funeral Homes, 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, N. Y.

title: ALBANY PACT TO GIVE STATE WORKERS RAISE OF 14% OVER 2 YEARS
description: ALBANY, April 17New York State and its largest publicemployee union agreed to a new contract today, granting more than $215 million in increased wages and fringe benefits over the next two years.

title: Flag of Convenience Ships Evade Fiscal Curbs, U.N. Study Shows
description: GENEVA, April 17Some $10 billion in annual freight revenues earned by ships flying socalled flags of convenience escapes the fiscal and monetary controls of the countries providing such flags as well as those of the vessels' effective owners, according to a United Nations study.

title: Islanders in Sweep, Gain Cup Semifinals
description: BUFFALO, April 17The improbable happened tonight. The New York Islanders defeated the Buffalo Sabres, 43, and swept their National Hockey League Stanley Cup quarterfinal series in four straight games.

title: China Says Bone Find Is New Link to Man
description: TOKYO, April 18 (AP)Chinese scientists have found the jawbone of an ape that lived eight million years ago and consider it evidence that south China was an important area for the development of the earliest humans, acording to a Peking broadcast.

title: News Summary
description: Legal and social changes directed to the more conservative Moslem elements among the coalition that is opposing him were offered by Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan. I am taking new initiatives to normalize the situation, to tranquilize the situation, the embattled Prime Minister said. He declared an immediate prohibition of alcoholic beverages, banned gambling, proposed more strict censorship regulations in conformity with the moral standards of Islam and promised to move the country closer to the civil and criminal codes of the Koran. [Page 1, Column 2.]

title: In Memoriam
description: KATZMathilde Beller, April 18, 1976. Lovingly remembered by all who knew her.

title: Dognappers Win Their Ransom By Preying on Owners' Emotions
description: When Marilyn Farmer went into her local delicatessen a few weeks ago, she left her dog, as usual, waiting outside. A few minutes later the dog had vanished.

title: $100 Million City Budget Deficit Projected by Beanie for 197879
description: The Beanie administration, which will introduce a balanced budget this week for the year starting July 1, is also projecting a deficit of $100 million for the subsequent fiscal year with the possibility that the deficit could grow to more than $300 million if the city were to award 6 percent wage increases to its work force in 1978.

title: 1906 Quake to Be Recalled
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 (UPI)San Francisco tomorrow will mark the, 71st anniversary of its earthquake of 1906 with films, parties and reunions. Earthquake Day commemorates the historic temblor and fire that leveled then. city, killing 452 persons, destroying 28,000 buildings and virtually wiping out the boom town that had grown after the gold rush in the Sierra Nevada. The observances will begin at 5:13 A.M., the time the quake struck.

title: 10 Arrested in Another Protest at Davis Cup Match
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., April 17The hex still holds. Ray Moore, whom the South Africans had prayed would draw Roscoe Tanner in the opening Davis Cup tennis match, beat him today for the third time in their last four meetings 97, 64, 57, 62, over 2 hours 47 minutes. Then the unflappable Brian Gottfried played textbook tennis in beating Byron Bertram, 64. 63. 64. serving out at love to end the series with a flourish.

title: Humane Society to Award Prizes For Kindness to Animals Posters
description: More than 1,500 posters on Kindness to Animals have been submitted by public school students to the Humane Society of New York, and next Saturday at 1 P.M. prizes will be given to the outstanding artists during a ceremony in the Union Dime Savings Bank at 1065 Avenue of the Americas at 40th Street.

title: Advertisers Support Challenged Claims
description: The softest bathroom tissue on earth, And it [Ban Basic] keeps you dryer than Arrid Extra Dry, Right Guard and Sure, and I had my Fresh Cornish Game Hen tested against all the frozen competition. And found my Cornish is at least 40 percent more tender than any of them.

title: Angel Quintet Depends on Flash
description: Rock groups that are almost wholly lacking in musical qualities and rely entirely on flash are rare, despite the claims of rock music's detractors. But Angel, which performed at the Palladium Saturday night, seems to be such a group.

title: Lebanon Is Refusing Entry to Palestinians
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 17Palestinians carrying passports issued by Arab countries have been refused entry to Lebanon under stricter travel regulations laid down by the authorities here.

title: The Semantics of It
description: Is he kidding when he describes how he and the President's political consultants, Doug Bailey and John Deardourff, sat around writing Mr. Ford's program for the next four years and fell to debating whether to call it A New Dimension of Freedom or A New Generation of Freedom? (I thought about it. Generation, I said finally. It will be easier for schoolchildren to remember. ... One small question, I said, opening my Pentab and getting read to go to work. Does he actually have any programs for the future? As a matter of fact, he does, said Doug.)

title: Yacht Racing
description: AT LARCHMONT Y.C.

title: Clinic on Incest Grants Exclusive, Stirring Controversy in NBC News
description: Weekend, NBC's monthly news magazine, whose episodes normally consist of several short pieces, will give over the entire 90minute telecast on May 7 to a single topic, the family rehabilitation program of a California clinic specializing in the problem of fatherdaughter incest

title: Chinese Show Wins Paris With Its Politics
description: PARISThe Shanghai Ballet has come to Paris and is winning, as it does in China, more applause for its political high point than for technical dazzle in its mixture of classical ballet, Chinese dance and socialist realism.

title: Nicklaus Takes Coast Playoff, Beating Lietzke
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., April 17Jack Nicklaus sank a birdie putt on the third extra hole today and defeated Bruce Lietzke in a playoff for the $45,000 first prize in the 25th annual Tournament of Champions, thus reaching two major golf milestones.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: Recital Given By Leonhardt
description: Recital Given By LeonhardtGustav Leonhardt owes his distinguished reputation among presentday Baroque specialists as much to the adventuresomeness and scrupulousness of his musicianship as to his sheer ability as a keyboard player and conductor. For his only harpsichord recital of the season Saturday night at the Metropolitan Museum of An, Mr. Leonhardt turned to relatively obscure pieces from 17th and 18thcentury France, and as might be expected he made a most persuasive case for them.

title: Canadiens Top Blues, 4 to 1, For a Sweep
description: ST. LOUIS, April 17 (UPI)Guy Lafleur scored in the third period at the St. Louis Arena tonight to put the Montreal. Canadiens into the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup semifinals with a 41 victory over the St. Louis Blues.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: (Caree shi?? sallings su?? to deck stri??)

title: Ontiveros Singles in 5th in 60 Game
description: It takes 27 outs to win, Casey Stengel used to reason. And Tom Seaver got his 27 outs yesterday in almost flawless fashion as he pitched the New York Mets to a 60 victory over the Chicago Cubs: allowing one hit, four walks and nothing else.

title: Haley Visit Captivates Village Where Roots Began
description: JUFFURE, Gambia, April 16Alex Haley returned home today.

title: Zaire Army Attacks Katangan Positions With Moroccan Aid
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 17 (UPI)Zairian troops backed by air strikes and Moroccan reinforcements have attacked Katangan insurgent positions west of Kolwezi in Shaba Province, according to an official communiqu. President Mobutu Sese Seko was reported to be confident of a decisive victory.

title: Stage: Tuneful I Love My Wife
description: They were bound to happen. The first was a respectable musical to enliven a Broadway season that had hitherto been tonedeaf, even stonedeaf. Second, a musical about wifeswapping, or about near wifeswapping. After all, Hollywood did it years ago.

title: Lance Is Playing Influential Role In Setting Administration's Policy
description: WASHINGTON, April 17Bert Lance disarmed one of the capital's most cynical audiences the other day by inviting career budget officials to create some graffiti.

title: Bless the Blitz
description: WASHINGTONThis week, Jimmy Carter will make the most extensive use of the television medium of any President in our history. If he goes through with it, he will become the first oneman miniseries.

title: LEROY L. WILLIAMS
description: Leroy L. Williams, the president of the J. A. Williams Company of Pittsburgh, distributor of hardware, housewares and major appliances, died Friday at his winter home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 71 years old and lived in Pittsburgh.

title: WellTrained Moroccan Troops Said to Enforce Zaire Stalemate
description: About 1,500 Moroccan troops, soon to be joined by 1,500 to 2,000 more, are enforcing a stalemate in Zaire, according to United States and European analysts specializing in the area.

title: Steinbrenner Colt Is Victor
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 17 (AP)California, which has yet to produce an outstanding colt this year among 3yearolds racing here, came up with a $70.80 surprise today when Steve's Friend captured the $227,500 Hollywood Derby. The winner is owned by George Steinbrenner, principal owner of the New York Yankees.

title: JACK LAST
description: Jack Last, a labor lawyer Who represented many locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in contract negotiations and arbitration settlements, died Saturday of cancer at his home, 511 West 232d Street in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 66 years old and maintained offices at 11 East 44th Street.

title: Stage: White Marriage Dreams
description: NEW HAVENIn Tadeusz Rozewicz's White Marriage, the subject is sexuality, seen from the point of view of the adolescent female. Two young women, Bianca and Pauline, exchange secrets, dreams, fantasies and misinformation.

title: Topics
description: The Equal Rights Amendment was narrowly defeated in Florida last week, leaving its ultimate fate in doubt. But supporters of sensible policies for the sexes could find some comfort In another development. An extreme example of the bureaucratic mind has been reversed at last; the Wethersfield boys' choir is legal again.

title: City's Storefront Service Center Lending An Ear and a Hand to Residents in Queens
description: A backyard rooster had become an annoying daybreak alarm clock in middle  class southwestern Queens. In another part of the area, one person had been killed and many injured in accidents where a road curved and dipped beneath an overpass.

title: Horse Shows
description: AT STATEN ISLAND WEST SHORE STABLES The Chief Awards

title: A Fire in Union City Destroys Five Buildings on Bergenline Avenue
description: UNION CITY, April 17 (AP)Half a city blockincluding a plumbingsupply company and at least four apartment houseswas destroyed by a fire today before the blaze was brought under control by firemen from 11 communities.

title: Pilgrimage to BurnedOut Shrine
description: About a mile below Bushkill Falls in Pennsylvania a dozen or more men and boys were clustered beside a tank truck parked on the shoulder of a narrow woods road. On top of the truck a man with a longhandled dipnet filled yellow plastic pails with wriggling fish and passed them down workers who carried them to a nearby stream and emptied them into the water. The men were stocking the Little Bushkill with trout, mostly brookies, one said, but with a few rainbow and browns among them. The fish were all of legal size and some appeared to be 11 or 12 inches, big enough to be fun on light tackle. They ran eight inches and up, the man said, mostly up. He said they were putting about 1,250 fish in at this spot and would stock the same number at another point a mile or so away. Here, you can see em close up, he said, setting a bucket down for an instant before fitting a cover on and carrying it to the water.

title: Seattle Slew in Drill
description: Very much in hand, according to Mrs. Karen Taylor, Seattle Slew sped around Belmont Park's main track yesterday in a sixfurlong workout that took only 1:11 35.

title: Protest Against Kennedy Landings By the Concorde Attracts 600 Cars
description: Foes of the Concorde supersonic transport mustered about 600 cars to drive around Kennedy International Airport for nearly three hours yesterday, vowing to shut its operations if the BritishFrench airliner was introduced there.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, April 17After years of considering dogs and other beasts as the state symbol, the State Senate votes tomorrow on giving the honor to the horse, which it describes as a large, stately herbivorous animal.

title: Owen and Smith Say Outlook Has Improved For Rhodesian Parley
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 17 (Reuters)Foreign Secretary David Owen of Britain ended his tour of southern Africa today, expressing optimism that at sides would agree to another conference on Rhodesia under BritishAmerican auspices.

title: Electric Company Using Electric Car
description: ROSLYN, L.I.Usually, Robert Gabris attracts only dogs as be makes his rounds as an electricmeter reader. But lately he has been attracting adult human beings, who keep asking him what kind of car he is driving.

title: French End Airlift
description: PARIS, April 17 (Reuters)All French planes used to ferry Moroccan military men to Zaire have now left there, the French Government said today.

title: Carter Plan Would Give Amnesty To Illegal Aliens Already in U.S.
description: HOUSTON, April 17The Carter Administration is shaping new immigration policies that would include amnesty for hundreds of thousands, perhaps millions, of foreigners, mostly Mexicans, who are living in the United States illegally.

title: Woodlands Burn in Pennsylvania
description: LEBANON, Pa., April 17 (AP)A fire set off by military smoke grenades and fed by gusty winds raced through 2.000 acres of woodland yesterday at the Fort Indiantown Gap Army base in northern Lebanon County, a military spokesman said. The spokesman said that two servicemen had been injured fighting the fire:

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: State officials are planning to lift a rate freeze imposed on insurance companies, opening the way for increasing premiums for more than a million motorists. Philipp K. Stern, a chief adviser to Insurance Commissioner James J. Sheeran, said that at least one company, State Farm Mutual, would receive a rate increase in the near future. The company insures 300,000 drivers in the state.

title: Soccer
description: NATIONAL AMATEUR CUP

title: N. B. A. Playoffs
description: QUARTERFINAL ROUND Boston vs. Philadelphia

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: 26 BY 6 Office workers and visitors who sample the new lunchtime fare (bring your own) at the midtown Quaigh Theater might be seeing themselves. The oneact comedy by Elyse Nass and James Struthers is a 35minute officelife spoof titled Until Further Notice, Tomorrow Is Canceled! The sixmember cast will be portraying a gallery of 26 workers in broad, burlesque style.

title: 2 Audits of Albany Tuition Grants Lead to Debate on Aid and Credits
description: Two critical audits of a New York Institute of Technology program for police officers have led to a widening, fractious dispute over the powers and duties of state education agencies, academic freedom, nontraditional schooling and accountability in the expenditure of public funds.

title: Brazil's Chief Political Loner
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 17It may be a clich to describe a head of state as suffering from the loneliness of power. Yet this has been the hallmark of Gen. Ernesto Geisel's three years as President of Brazil. It has been his inclination to act decisively, largely keeping his own counselassuming the responsibilities incumbent upon me, as he has often saidthat has occasionally earned him plaudits, and, more recently, intense criticism from virtually all sectors of Brazilian political opinion.

title: CAREY DENIES CUOMO HAS HIS SPONSORSHIP
description: Governor Carey insisted yesterday that, no matter what virtually every other politician in New York believed to be so, he had not sponsored Mario M. Cuomo's mayoral candidacy.

title: Kate Thoresen Is Bride
description: Kate Thoresen and Dr. Lawrence Goldstone were married yesterday in the Tillman Chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations by Cantor Albert Sturmer. The bride, a fashion model, is a daughter of Marie A. Thoresen of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and the late David M. Thoresen. Dr. Goldstone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Goldstone of New York, is in the metaltrading division of J. Aron & Company in New York.

title: Sue Casey Schrank Married To Edwin Olsen in Georgia
description: Sue Casey Schrank, widow of Leonard David Schrank, was married yesterday afternoon to Edwin Robert Olsen of New York.

title: Southern India Concerned Over Political Isolation
description: HYDERABAD, IndiaHere in the deep south of India, politicians are concerned about the new sense of isolation brought on by the recent parliamentary election, in which this region became the remaining stronghold of the defeated Congress Party.

title: St. Cecilia Ensemble Offers Fine Concert
description: There was some wonderful music to be heard at the St. Cecilia Chorus and Orchestra concert Saturday night in Carnegie Hall. Pergolesi's Magnificat, Bach's Cantata No. 4 and Schubert's Mass No. 6 are not encountered very often, and David Randolph, the group's director, made an enterprising choice in programming the works.

title: MRS. RABIN IS FINED $27,000 IN BANK CASE
description: JERUSALEM, April 17Lea Rabin, wife of Israel's Prime Minister, vas fined about $27,000 today for her role in maintaining bank accounts in Washington in violation of Israeli currency regulations.

title: Market Place
description: When the new management team joined United Realty Trust in Beverly Hills, Calif., in mid1975, the banks were pressing the trust to repay borrowings while an inordinate amount of the trust's investments were in trouble.

title: Vilgelm P. Letsis, 79, Leader Of Communist Party in Latvia
description: MOSCOW, April 17 (UPI)  Soviet newspapers have reported the death of Vilgelm P. Letsis, 79 years old, a retired leader of the Latvian Communist party.

title: CORRECTION
description: Cold Storage, a new play by Ronald Ribman, continues through next Sunday at the American Place Theater, 111 West 46th Street. It did not close yesterday, as listed in Sunday's Arts and Leisure Guide.

title: Katherine Armstrong, Nutritionist
description: Katherine Martin LeBoutillier Armstrong of 200 East 66th Street, a nutritionist, former New York Hospital dietition, and former restaurant manager, died yesterday in New Milford, Conn. She was 90 years old.

title: Memorial Seruices
description: ARMSTRONGMollie Bangs Services will be held Wednesday. April 20th, at 11:00. St. Thomas More Church 65 E. 89th St., N. Y. C.

title: High Price of Silver Revives Mining at Idaho Ghost Town
description: DELAMAR, Idaho  A century ago silver was king in Idaho's Owyhee Mountains. The ghost town of DeLamar is a mute witness to those days.

title: TRIAL FOR ESPIONAGE HAS UNUSUAL QUIRKS
description: LOS ANGELES, April 17Sitting in the back of the courtroom, his chin resting most of the time on the pewlike seat in front of him, a man with reddish hair and a ruddy complexion has been intently observing the espionage trial of Christopher J. Boyce, who is accused of selling state secrets to the Soviet Union.

title: Fourth Woman Slain by Same Gun
description: A young woman was shot to death and her male companion was critically wounded early yesterday as they sat in a parked car in the Bronx. The police said the killing was similar to the slaying of three other women in the city over the last nine months.

title: Rhodesia Reports Attack by Zambia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 17 (AP)Rhodesia reported that Zambian troops opened tire today with machine guns and mortars on a Rhodesian post about 400 yards across the Zambezi River from Zambia.

title: Jane Berger Is Married To Charles K. Tallents
description: Jane Berger, daughter of Judith Derish Berger of West Orange, N.J., and Louis Berger of Verona, N.J., was married yesterday in the Tillman Chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations to Charles Kercheval Tallents. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. T. W. Tallents of Banbury, Oxfordshire, England. The nondenominational ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne.

title: The Absent Father, Too, Can Wind Up Broke  Or Inside a Prison
description: LEVITTOWN. L.I.Nobody goes to jail any more for not paying alimony. That's what Robert Hetner kept telling himself every month as he missed his payment to his former wife.

title: Celtics Set Back 76ers On White's Shot at End
description: PHILADELPHIA,. April 17Jo Jo White is the Boston Celtics' leading scorer, top playmaker, best dresser and most softspoken player. His way is to share in the blame for a Boston loss and to call victory a team effort.

title: Yarborough Triumphs In Southeastern 500
description: BRISTOL, Tenn., April 17 (AP)Cale Yarborough led all but two laps as he made a runaway of the final 500lap Grand National stockcar race at Bristol International Speedway with an easy victory today in the Southeastern 500.

title: Dakota Jury to Resume Today at Trial of Indian In Killing of F.B.I. Agents
description: FARGO, N.D., April 17 (AP)The trial of Leonard Peltier, charged in the 1975 slayings of two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has gone to the jury, which failed to reach a verdict yesterday and is to resume its deliberations tomorrow.

title: The Selling of Gerald Ford
description: The 1968 Presidential campaign gave us Joe McGinniss's The Selling of the President 1968, about how Richard M. Nixon put into practice his belated discovery that beauty is a thing in the eye of the television audience. Now the 1976 campaign has given us Malcolm D. MacDougall's We Almost Made It, which, if anything, presents an even more appalling and absurd picture of the art of packaging Presidential candidates. Except, where Mr. McGinniss was aware of what he was doing. Mr. MacDougall, who was creative director of Gerald R. Ford's advertising campaign, seems ludicrously innocent.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Yale Center for British Art, Costing $10 Million, to Open
description: The Yale Center for British Art, housing what is believed to be the largest concentration outside of England of British paintings, drawings, prints and rare books from the Elizabethan period to the mid19th century, opens to the public tomorrow.

title: The U.N. Today
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: The Sense Of Limits
description: On the pond, this is the season of alewives, the herring that come in from the sea every spring to spawn in the backwaters of the Northeast. Dropped fresh in the pan, they make wonderfully delicate eating; but they are really prized for their roe.

title: Haley Visit Captivates Village Where Roots Began
description: JUFFURE, Gambia, April 16Alex Haley returned home today.

title: RICHARD M. HAYWOOD, 71; FORMER N.Y.U. PROFESSOR
description: Richard Mansfield Haywood, professor emeritus of classics at New York University, died March 31 at the University of Virginia Hospital in Charlottesville, it was reported yesterday. He was 71 years old and had lived in Charlottesville since 1973.

title: Kahn's Legacy to Yale Center: His Love of Silence and Light
description: Louis Kahn spoke often of his love for the elements of silence and light, and there is a room in the new Yale Center for British Art that explains this love more clearly, perhaps, than anything else the architect ever made. The room is a great interior court, three stories high, with walls of oak set as panels within the building's exposed concrete frame. Skylights admit diffused light, which tumbles down softly through the space, like a gentle snow. The walls are hung with just a few large paintings, and to one side of the room sits a massive concrete cylinder within which is contained a stair, it sits silently, not an intruder but a form that plays off gently against the other elements of the room and brings just the right amount of movement and power to the

title: Nearly Half of All Fatherless Families Said to Live in Poverty
description: Because of soaring divorce rates and a rise in illegitimacy, more and more American children  one of every seven, to be exactnow live apart from their fathers. And according to a group of women economists, the vast majority of those children have to survive without much help from their absent parent.

title: 17 STATE COLLEGES FACE TOUGH TIMES
description: EAST WINDSOR, April 17  Trustees of New Jersey's 17 community colleges will face tough decisions in coming years because of tighter budgets, declining enrollment and increasing offcampus pressures, such as political efforts to control the academic environment.

title: TRIAL OPENING TODAY IN JACKSON H.S. CASE
description: The long and bitter case involving the New York City Board of Education's effortsor lack of effortsto integrate a virtually allminority high school in Queens is scheduled to go to trial today in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: WILLIAM T. RUSSELL
description: William T. Russell, assistant general counsel of the International Business Machines Corporation, died Friday at Stamford Hospital in Connecticut after a short illness. He was 60 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: 26,752 See Home Opener As Cosmos Triumph, 20
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J, April 17The reason the Cosmos won only by 20 from the Rochester Lancers in their home opener at Giants Stadium today was perhaps described best by Giorgio Chinaglia, the outspoken striker of the Cosmos.

title: ROSE A. O'NEILL
description: Rose A. O'Neill, a retired New York City civil servant who was secretary to Mayor Beanie When he was assistant budget director, Budget Director and Comptroller, died Saturday in Alexian Brothers Hospital in Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: C.I.A. Denies Aiding Recruitment Of Mercenaries to Fight in Zaire
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The Central Intelligence Agency categorically denied today that it was involved in recruiting mercenary soldiers to help Zaire resist an invasion by Katangan exiles from Angola.

title: If the Kremlin...and We...If...If...
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.It was on the eve of the 1948 elections that Harry S. Truman proposed to send Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson as a special envoy to negotiate with Stalin. It is unlikely that Truman saw this move as merely a means of improving his chances visvis Gov. Thomas E. Dewey.

title: Chess:
description: Bent Larsen of Denmark scoring 8 4, won the Geneva International Tournament at the Hotel la Mediterranee, the first in a projected series of annual competitions sponsored by the hotel and by Blanshut and Bertrand Engineering.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL OUTLINES CARTER'S AFRICA POLICY
description: RABAT, Morocco, April 17The State Department's senior political officer said today that the United States wanted Africans to solve their own problems and did not wish to interfere in the internal affairs of the African continent.

title: BERGLAND IS HOPEFUL ON DROUGHT'S IMPACT
description: MONTEREY, Calif., April 17Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland says that he sees no need for retail food prices to rise this year because of the twoyearold drought in this state. However, in an interview as he prepared to return to Washington, Secretary Bergland said that a third year of drought would bring a real crunch in food supplies and prices.

title: Indiana Judge Rules Out Use of Biology Textbook Promoting Biblical View
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April. 17 (AP)A judge has ruled that it was unconstitutional for public schools to use a ninthgrade biology textbook that promoted the biblical theory of creation and contained the sentence There is no way to support the doctrine of evolution.

title: Bridge:
description: Honors in the American Bridge Association's Spring Nationals Championships that ended a week of play here yesterday were equally shared between Midwest and East Coast players. Successes by Chicago players early in the week were balanced when Bill Williams of New York and Lee Pennington of Yonkers captured the open pairs Friday, following a New York victory in the mixed teams.

title: Carey' s Big Gamble in Mayoral Sweepstakes
description: In his dramatic and open rejection of an incumbent Mayor who is also a fellow Democrat and a longtime associate in Brooklyn Democratic politics. Governor Carey could well be putting his own political future on the line as he touches off a classic struggle between New York's City Hall and Albany.He's throwing the dice, said a high state official of the move by the Governor against Mayor Beame, his supposed friend. Other Governors have tried to intervene in New York Cityit's almost a perquisite of the officebut rarely has a Governor so openly tried to defeat an incumbent Mayor. Nobody thought he would have the guts to do it, said a top Bronx Democrat.

title: President's Plan to Reduce Outlays on Water Projects Could Save $120 Million
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)President Carter's cuts in recommended funding for water projects could save taxpayers $120 million in the fiscal year 1978.

title: Mrs. King Routs Miss Stoll In Lionel Cup Final, 61, 61
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 17Displaying her old magic and skill, Billie Jean King defeated 16yearold Caroline Stoll of Livingston, N.J., 61 61, today in the final of the Lionel Cup. $20,000 women's tennis tournament at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Yale Center for British Art, Costing $10 Million, to Open
description: The Yale Center for British Art, housing what is believed to be the largest concentration outside of England of British paintings, drawings, prints and rare books from the Elizabethan period to the mid19th century, opens to the public tomorrow.

title: Hundreds Try to Trace Old Claims to Texas Land In Hope Mexico Will Pay Reparations Under Treaty
description: SAN ANTONIO, April 17Clutching tattered receipts and typewritten deeds, several hundred wouldbe millionaires gathered here this weekend to try to establish claims to vast tracts of land taken from their ancestors more than a century ago when the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo suddenly transformed parts of northern Mexico into southern Texas.

title: CARDINAL CONWAY, IRISH PRIMATE, DIES
description: William Cardinal Conway, Archibishop of Armagh, Northern Ireland, and the Roman Catholic Primate of All Ireland, died yesterday at his residence behind St. Patrick's Cathedral in Armagh. He was 64 years old and had been recuperating from gall bladder surgery.

title: Team Spirit Gains, but Brewers Win
description: MILWAUKEE, April 17On the surface, this was another of the many bad days the Yankees already had endured this season. But a month from now, two months, six months, this could be remembered as the day the Yankees turned themselves around.

title: On Defending the Ku Klux Klan
description: Civil libertarians in Southern California find themselves in disarray. The difficulty began in February when the American Civil Liberties Union's San Diego chapter filed suit on behalf of a group of white marines, Ku Klux Klan members who were summarily transferred from Camp Pendleton because they had allegedly terrorized black enlisted men. Meanwhile, the Southern California branch of the A.C.L.U. came to the defense of some black marines who attacked a barracks room in which they mistakenly believed the Klan was meeting. In both cases, the civil liberties lawyers are charging bias, intimidation, harrassment and denial of due process.

title: Boston Marathon Today; Runners Won't Be Lonely
description: BOSTON, April 17Whatever happened to the image of the lonely longdistance runner?

title: Late Registration and More Outlay Advised to Increase Voter Turnout
description: WASHINGTON, April 17An analysis of the 1976 Presidential race, published by a politically conservative research group, indicates that neither a national Presidential primary nor primaries in additional states would be likely to raise the level of voter participation in the selection of the two majorparty Presidential candidates.

title: Rats on Atoll Seared by Nuclear Tests Are Providing Valuable Data for Scientists
description: ENEWETAK, Marshall IslandsAbout once a year Bill Jackson travels a third of the way around the world to go hunting. He hunts rats.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A forest fire closed off an eightmile stretch of the Garden State Parkway in Ocean County and three major blazes burned out of control in the Pinelands yesterday in one of the worst forest fire seasons on record in New Jersey, authorities said. Civil defense officials in Bricktown said a fire started in Lakewood shortly after 1 P.M. and spread toward the parkway, the main artery leading to the shore resorts.

title: A Summary of Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
description: The Court declined to hear an appeal raising the argument that it was unconstitutional for states to bar aliens from voting in local school elections. The Court said that the appeal, from a decision by the Colorado Supreme Court upholding state laws barring aliens from such elections, raised no substantial Federal question. (Skafte v. Rorex. No. 76951.)

title: Rockets Are a Franchise Reborn
description: There have been a lot of empty seats at the playoff games in Boston, Washington, Philadelphia and Oakland, Calif., thus far. But as Ray Patterson, the president and general manager of the Houston Rockets, tallied the 2,000 tickets sold yesterday for tonight's Eastern Conference semifinal opener against the Washington Bullets, in addition to the 6,000 tickets sold previously, he was looking at numbers bigger than many he had seen before.

title: Stage: Kay Carney's Off Off Broadway Reprise
description: There's a good idea at the heart of the onewoman show that Kay Carney is presenting at the Interart Theater, 549 West 52d Street, Thursdays, through Sundays until May 1. Herself a participant in at least a dozen Off Off Broadway shows in the 1960's, it occurred to her to take pieces from her favorite plays, splice them together with verbal introductions and shape them into an evening's entertainment. Thus she would preserve the flavor of those heady times, transmit some of its quality and do on stage the things she likes to do.

title: Panatta Defeats Gerulaitis in Final
description: HOUSTON, April 18 (UPI)Adriano Panatta capped a brilliant week of tennis today by beating Vitas Gerulaitis, 76, 67, 61, in the final of the $100,000 River Oaks tennis tournament, a World Championship Tennis event.

title: BREDINEV CAUTIONS NATIONS MEDDLING IN ZAIRIAN CONFLICT
description: MOSCOW, April 18Leonid I. Brezhnev said today that countries seeking to meddle in the fighting in Zaire would bear full responsibility for whatever consequences followed.

title: YOUNG SEES HIMSELF AS TOO MODERATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Andrew Young said today that he had always been a moderate with regard to southern Africa, working for peaceful solutions that would enable the white populations to remain in the area after the coming of majority rule.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Catholics in Korea Demand Park Put End to Repression
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 18 (AP)The Roman Catholic Church in South Korea has demanded the repeal of President Park Chung Hee's 1972 Constitution and 1975 emergency decree, the measures that gave him authoritarian power and banned any political dissent.

title: Decisions on Water Projects
description: No Funding: Cache Basin, Ark.; Fruitland Mesa, Colo.; Savery  Pot Hook, Colo.Wyo.; Richard B. Russell Project, Ga.; Grove Lake, Kan.; Hillsdale Lake, Kan.; Yatesville Lake, Ky.; Atchafalaya River and Bayous Chene, Boeuf and Black, La.; Bayou Bodcau, La.; Tallahala Creek Inlet, Miss.; Meramec Park Lake, Mo.; Lukfata Lake, Okla.; Applegate Lake, Ore.; Columbia Dam, Tenn., and LaFarge Lake, Wis.

title: The Cast
description: SIDE BY SIDE a musical entertainment, music and lyrics by Stephen Sondheim. Directed by Ned Sherrin; musical director, Ray Cook; musical staging by Bob Howe; writing by Peter Docherty; costumes by Florence Klotz; lighting by Ken Billington; scenery supervision, Jay Moore; musical supervision, Paul Gemignani; stage manager, John Gri??. Presented by Harold Prince In association with Ruth Mitchell, by arrangement with the ?? Company. At the Mucis Box, 239 West 45th Street. WITH: Millicent Martin, Julie N. McKenzie, David Kernan and Ned Sherrin.

title: Anxieties of Business Over the President's Energy Plans
description: Business confidence, at a low ebb in 1976's second half, began to blossom moderately in this year's first quarter as evidence accumulated that the American economic recovery had mawsfully weathered the worst winter in a century and was gathering strength toward the approach of its second anniversary at the end of March. Then, late last week, the mood of business was further bolstered when President Carter first backed away from his unpopular, potentially inflationary, taxrebate plan and subsequently embraced a voluntary, mild program for holding down increases in prices and wages.

title: TV NETWORKS WARY ON CARTER COVERAGE
description: WASHINGTON, April 18When President Carter's speech on energy tonight was made available for live coverage a couple of weeks ago, CBS declined before the other two commercial networks could respond to the offer.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Monday, April 18, 1977

title: Market Place
description: Anderson, Clayton & Company, one of the nation's most conservative and littleknown major companies, is taking a friendly tack to corporate acquisitions, hoping to persuade one of the nation's most widely known companies Gerber Products Inc.to support Anderson's proposed tender of $40 in cash for each Gerber share.

title: Miss Lear Sings of 3 Singers
description: Evelyn Lear was in a celebratory mood at her Tully Hall concert Sunday night. The occasion marked the 22d anniversary, to the day, of the soprano's first New York recital, as well as the 10th anniversary of her Metropolitan Opera debut.

title: Savings Units Net Gain in March
description: A net savings gain of $164 million in March by New York State's 136 savings and loan institutions, exclusive of interest credited to accounts, was announced yesterday by the Savings Association League of New York State. Including in terest, net savings were $409 million for the month. At the same time the savings and loan institutions made new mortgage loans of $365 million and additional commitments of $493 million, the association reported.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney reports that while business confidence is rising, questions are being raised on the effects the President's tough recommendations for a national energy policy may have on business attitudes. Page 61.

title: Mrs. Carter Plans White House Conference on Aging
description: WASHINGTON, April 18Rosalynn Carter said today she would be the host at a White House conference on aging next month to help personally spotlight the problems of old people in America.

title: Confident 7th Army Faces Bigger Red Force
description: RASDORF, West GermanyStaff Sgt. James Cooney, who has been assigned to the watchtower at Observation Post Alfa here on the East German border for three years, will never forget the last week of January 1977.

title: $325.3 Million  Tender for Gerber Announced by Anderson, Clayton
description: A cash tender offer of $325.3 million for the Gerber Products Company, one of the bestknown baby food makers, was announced yesterday by Anderson Clayton & Company, which deals in food products and agricultural commodities.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ABOY Downtown visitors and office workers with boating in mind have a warmweather dividend today in the weekly Lunch & Learn series drawing capacity audiences to Pace University (one block east of City Hall). The speaker is Ens. Curtis L. Gunn, boating safety officer at the Coast Guard. His text How to Get Started in Boating: Anchors Aweigh!

title: Who Will Pay to Stay Inflation?
description: President Carter's antiinflation program, outlined a few days ago, is a grab bag of regulatory and tax reform, antitrust enforcement, free trade and informal businesslabor consultations. Mr. Carter hopes thereby to cut the inflation rate to 4 percent by 1979. Can he do it?

title: Music: Unfamiliar of the Familiar
description: Sunday's program of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Alice Tully Hallwhich will be repeated there tonight at 7:30was devoted to unfamiliar works by familiar composers. This has been a consistent Chamber Music Society policy, and a laudable one, and it can rarely have worked out better than it did on this occasion.

title: Carter Says New Water Projects Will Face Even Stiffer Standards
description: WASHINGTON, April 18While Congressmen began working on alliances to vote money for 18 water projects that President Carter wanted to kill on economic, safety and environmental grounds, the President announced he would judge future projects by even stiffer standards.

title: Belmonte Wins at Big A, Then Collapses
description: Eddie Belmonte was bobbing happily under his bright orange cap yesterday when he suddenly collapsed and fell off his horse after winning at Aqueduct the victim of a toosudden weight loss.

title: Wife Testifies She Tried to Dissuade Croatian From Hijacking Jetliner
description: The wife of the man accused of leading a group of Croatian plane hijackers told a Federal Court jury in Brooklyn yesterday how she had tried to dissuade her husband from going through with the seizure of the jet.

title: Ward Allan Howe, a Travel Writer
description: Ward Allan Howe, who retired in 1956 as a New York Times newsman but continued for many years to contribute articles about rail travel, the great enthusiasm of his life, died Saturday in University Hospital in New York. He was 77 years old and lived at 310 Riverside Drive.

title: ROBERT DUNN, EXECUTIVE OF AVIATION UNDERWRITERS
description: Robert W. Dunn, vice president and chief financial officer of the Associated Aviation Underwriters of New York, died at the age of 30 last Saturday following an automobile accident in Clayton County, near Atlanta. Mr. Dunn, who was on a business trip, lived in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: State U. at Old Westbury Boycotted In Dispute on Minority Admissions
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., April 18Students at the State University Center here boycotted classes today in a dispute with the administration over the admission of minoritygroup and women students to the institution.

title: C.I.A. Sees Oil Price Increases Unless Conservation Cuts Demand
description: WASHINGTON, April 18The White House made public today a report by the Central Intelligence Agency that predicted sizable price increases for oil, and by implication for all forms of energy, by 198283 unless largescale conservation measures cut demand sharply.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The General Foods Corporation, the nation's largest coffee roaster, yesterday again raised wholesale prices on ground coffee by 25 cents to a record of $4.46 a pound. The increase should be reflected on supermarket shelves in Late June.

title: Bridge:
description: The Westchester CountyNew Jersey area continued the process of finding a district grand national team champion at White Plains during the weekend.

title: News Summary
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev warned that other countries seeking to meddle in the fighting in Zaire would hear full responsibility for the consequences. The Soviet leader avoided naming specific countries, but he spoke of attempts undertaken by the imperialist forces and their henchmen to interfere in the domestic military conflict of Zaire. He did not say what the consequences of involvement might be. [Page. 1, Col. 3.]

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Brooklyn's Dewey H.S. Is More Like a College
description: There is something strange going on at John Dewey High School in Brooklyn.

title: Seventh Avenue Softens Up
description: Now it's New York's turn. A couple of weeks after readytowear designers in Paris presented their versions of what women will wear when the 1977 swimsuit season fades into history, Seventh Avenue began presenting its fall fashion story.

title: Yields on Treasury Bills Decline
description: Yields declined on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Iceberg Aground After 10 Years at Sea
description: A rogue iceberg, almost the size of Rhode Island that has been banging around Antarctic waters for 10 years is safely aground after its collisions gave birth to at least one other giant berg.

title: British Study Finds Concorde Is Noisier Than Other Planes
description: LONDON, April 18 (AP)The BritishFrench Concorde supersonic jetliner is noisier than other aircraft and it appears unlikely a significant noise reduction can be achieved, according to a British Government study made public today.

title: Dollar Edges Lower In Trading Abroad; Price of Gold Gains
description: LONDON, April 18 (AP)The dollar lost ground slightly against every major Western European currency on foreign exchange markets today.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Major League Scores
description: E Rose, DPLos Angeles 1 1 OBLosAngeles. Cicinnati 5 2BSmith 2, Gar??, Driessen, Lum, Morgan 3BLoges, HRGarvey (3), Rose (1), Dressen (1) SBGarvey SBillingham, Rhogen SF Sir.H

title: Young Becoming SelfConscious
description: ATLANTA, April 18 (UPI)  Andrew Young, conceding that he is selfconscious about his recent statements on world affairs, backtracked a little yesterday on his terminology for describing the South African Government.

title: Books of The Times
description: His brother and sister, his son, his widow, an official biographer, a sixpack of friends, at least three professional psychologizers and more critics than you can shake a shillelagh at have written books on Ernest Hemingway. Norman Mailer keeps threatening to do so. Morley Callaghan, John Dos Passos, Donald Ogden Stuart, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Malcom Cowley, Stephen Spender, Archibald MacLeish, Gertrude Stein, Edmund Wilson, Wright Morris and John O'Hara, among many others, have remembered him in passing. Letters abound. We know more of his Michigan days, his Toronto days, his Paris days, his Spanish days, his Key West days, his African days and his Cuban days than we need to.

title: Belgian Premier Seems Assured Of Backing in Hunt for a Coalition
description: BRUSSELS, April 18 (UPI)Prime Minister Leo Tindemans handed in his formal resignation today, but he was apparently assured of enough support in the wake of the general elections yesterday to allow him to pick his coalition partners.

title: PARLEY ON FLOW OF NEWS FROM THIRD WORLD OPENS
description: FLORENCE, Italy, April 18 (UPI)The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization opened a threeday debate today on accusations that the West holds a monopoly on the flow of news between developed and developing countries.

title: City Charter Copies Won't Be Available Until This Summer
description: Seventeen months after the voters approved the new City Charter, a copy of the Charter is still not available in printed form to the general public.

title: United Technologies Net a Record
description: EAST HARTFORD, Conn. April 18The United Technologies Corporation set firstquarter records in sales, earnings and order backlogs. Harry J. Gray, chairman and president told 1.519 stockholders at the annual meeting here today.

title: Group Says 9 Planned Communities Tend to Hurt Florida Environment
description: A study of nine of Florida's largest planned communities indicates that the huge housing developments generally tend to have a deleterious impact on the state's environment.

title: Carter's Plan to Raise Gas Tax Runs Into Opposition
description: WASHINGTON, April 18President Carter's expected request for an increased gasoline tax as part of his energy package ran into opposition from a Republican leader and a labor leader today, while Democrats predicted that the measure faced strong though not necessarily insuperable opposition.

title: Senegal to Send Art Abroad
description: DAKAR, Senegal, April 18 (Agence FrancePresse)  Exhibitions of Senegalese paintings are to be held in New York, Mexico and Montreal next year, President Leopold S. Senghor has announced.

title: March Housing Starts Up To Highest Rate Since '73
description: WASHINGTON, April 18New homes were being built last month at the highest rate in nearly four years, giving further evidence that the economic recovery is gaining speed, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Memorial Services
description: COHUKathryn Kimball. A memorial service will be held at The Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue ,at 90th St., N.Y.C., on Thursday, April 21st at 5:00 P.M. Please omit flowers.

title: Note Believed Left by Bronx Killer: Is Called Rambling, Incoherent
description: A note written by the gunman who is believed to have killed five young people in the Bronx and Queens was a rambling, incoherent message, a high police official disclosed yesterday.

title: Woman Speaks Up: Men Control Conversation
description: James Thurber, whose cartoons depicted huge women browbeating tiny men, would have disagreed. But men do dominate women, according to Pamela Fishman, a doctoral student in sociology at the University of California at Santa Barbara, at least when they're alone together and talking.

title: Trudeau, in Speech in Winnipeg, Campaigns for Canadian Unity
description: OTTAWA, April 18Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau campaigned for Canadian unity today in the disaffected western part of Canada, promising to help redress grievances in that region in return for support in combating separatism in Quebec.

title: family/style
description: Ruth Nivola works with gold and silver and shimmering jewels, but not of the usual kind. Mrs. Nivola is a jeweler in thread.

title: Dr. Charles LeRoy Lowman Dies; Was a Leading Orthopedic Surgeon
description: LOS ANGELES, April 18Dr. Charles LeRoy Lowman, a leader in orthopedic surgery for the last 70 years, died yesterday after a brief illness. He was 97 years old.

title: New York's Boxers Top Chicagoans
description: New York's Golden Glovers easily swept to victory in the Intercity championships against Chicago at Madison Square Garden last night, winning six of the first seven bouts on the 11bout card.

title: Notes on People
description: The Prime Minister of Portugal, Mario Soares, arrived in New York yesterday for three days of private meetings before going on to Washington for an official visit. Among the highlights here will be a reception at the home of Mrs. Carol Haussamen tonight, where Mr. Soares will receive the Human Rights Prize from the International League for Human Rights. The inscription on the award, which is to be presented by Andrew Young, the chief United Stites delegate 63 the United Nations, reads: By his unremitting devotion to democracy and freedom, Mario Soares inspired his people to redeem their country to the cause of liberty. Mr. Soares, who was imprisoned 12 times by the Salazar dictatorship before being forced into exile in 1968, became, in 19976, the first democratically elected Prime Minister of his country in almost 50 years.

title: Muddying the CleanWater Law
description: The Federal Water Pollution Control Act of 1972 was a major turning point in the long struggle to clean up the nation's rivers and protect its water resources. For the first time, Congress adequately responded to two grim facts: Every major river system in America is seriously polluted, and the nation's ponds, marshes and other wetlands have been systematically diminished to a dangerous extent. As a result of recent actions by the House of Representatives, that act is now in jeopardy.

title: Dow Drops by 5 as Trading Falls; G.M., Ford and Chrysler Decline
description: The stock market declined moderately yesterday as investors generally took to the sidelines to await President Carter's energy message last night.

title: The NonIndifference Policy in Europe
description: The political gains of the Communist parties of Italy, France and Spain pose a difficult problem not only for those countries but for the Carter Administration. Democrats throughout the Western community must learn how to gauge the democratic slogans uttered by the Eurocommunists as they seek respectability followed by responsibility. Beyond that, the United States must determine how best to protect its vital security and economic interests in Europe without acts of crude interference that would only abet antiAmericanism.

title: Streaking Dodgers Rout Reds, 73
description: The Cincinnati Reds, the champions of major league baseball the last two seasons, may face a formidable challenge from the Los Angeles Dodgers as the Reds bid for their third straight Western Division crown, National League pennant and World Series triumph.

title: Idaho State Hires Coach
description: POCATELLO, Idaho, April 18 (UPI)Lynn Archibald, an assistant coach at Southern California, was appointed today as Idaho State's new head basketball coach. Archibald replaces Jim Killingsworth, who moved to Oklahoma State.

title: Chemical Producers'Profits Lag
description: Earnings of chemical companies generally continued to lag in the first quarter this year, while the physical volume of sales has been on a plateau since the first half of last year, according to reports out yesterday.

title: 1,700 L. & M. Workers Strike
description: DURHAM, N.C., April 18 (AP)About 1,700 employees of the Liggett & Myers Tobacco Company went on strike last midnight and began picketing the concern's cigarette plant here when their work contract expired. J. T. Carthen, president of Local 176 of the Tobacco Workers International, said that the members had voted to strike if agreement on a new contract had not been reached at the expiration date. The two unresolved issues in negotiations were a costofliving clause and a provision for wage adjustments, he added.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: The American's Price
description: The $50 tax rebate for lowerbracket Americans may have been bad economics, as its business opponents argued, but the simpler fact behind its defeat was that nobody who matters to the Congress wanted it.

title: Usery to Head Panel for Labor Study on Arts
description: Former Labor Secretary W. J. Usery Jr. has accepted an invitation from leaders of labor and management in the performing arts to explore creation of a continuing forum for cooperation in a field long scarred by discord and deficits.

title: People and Business
description: Donald H. Rumsfeld. former Secretary of Defense, has been elected president and chief executive officer of G. D. Searle & Company, effective June 1. The Skokie, Ill., company, whose sales last year exceeded $761 million, is a worldwide supplier of healthcare products and services.

title: TV: Ben I. Wattenberg Series Sticks Up for the Real America and Twits the Naysayers
description: Public television is actually giving a monthly halfhour of air time to a political analyst who questions popular perceptions. In the tightly circumscribed world of television, where just about all opinions are processed through safely centrist mentalities, where the possibly controversial is defused through the nonthreatening persona of a Walter Cronkite, In Search of the Real America might look positively audacious.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 9.5300: NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487761.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a report on proposed Electoral College changes that appeared in The Times last Wednesday, it was incorrectly stated that Senator Birch Bayh's current proposal for direct popular election of the President provided for a vote by a joint session of Congress in the event that no Presidential candidate received 40 percent of the national vote. The Bayh plan, in its present form, calls for a runoff election in such a situation.

title: Going Too Far In Africa
description: Ambassador Andrew Young has been bearing up pretty well under the storm of controversy he's been arousing with his undiplomatic candor, but even he must have been glad to hear himself roundly praised the other day for being a refreshing voice in world affairs.

title: Beame's Budget Will Revive Plans To Build Convention Center in City
description: The Beame administration, whose proposal for a city convention center has been in a kind of suspended animation since 1975, now intends to revive plans for the $170 million project in the next fiscal year with financing to be provided from the sale of city bondsan approach that had been previously ruled out because of the fiscal crisis.

title: Zaire Optimistic on Fighting
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 18A Government spokesman displayed optimism today as he reported that a weekend offensive by Zairian units had pushed back the insurgents some 16 miles and had resulted in the capture of weapons and incriminating documents.

title: 2 Scientists Tell of Gains in Mapping Genes in Human Chromosomes in Fight on Cancer and Birth Defects
description: WASHINGTON, April 18Scientists have made so much progress recently in genetic mapping that they know the location of at least one gene on each of the human chromosomes.

title: NaturalGas Policy
description: WASHINGTON  Natural gas is overpriced. Raising prices paid to producers even higher should not be the centerpiece of a national strategy designed to generate greater supplies and encourage conservation. The key to a sensible naturalgas policy is controlling the end use of this finite commodity.

title: Governor Starts Boxing Tourney Inquiry
description: ALBANY, April 18 (AP)Governor Carey said today that he had ordered an in house investigation on the relationship between the chairman of the State Athletic Commission and a commercial boxing venture.

title: Miss McBride and Schaufuss In Eglevsky Sleeping Beauty
description: The chance to see two of the New York City Ballet's popular principal dancers make their local debuts in The Sleeping Beauty was a highly persuasive reason for dropping in on the Eglevsky Ballet's production of the 19thcentury classic in Hempstead, L.I.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, APRIL 18, 1977

title: STEEL PRODUCTION SHOWS RISE OF 0.2% FOR WEEK
description: Steel production for the week ended April 16 was 2,588,000 tons, 0.2 percent above the preceding week's total of 2,584,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Dollar Falls Further Against Yen
description: TOKYO, April 18 (AP)The dollar fell further against the yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today, but rose in later trading with overseas banks.

title: New York Brokerage Is Among 6 New Defendants In $3.5 Million Stock Suit
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 18A local businessman has charged in Federal Court that Thomson & McKinnon Auchincloss Kohimeyer Inc. participated in a scheme to get him to purchase $3.5 million of stock in the International City Bank and Trust Company here last April, seven months before the bank failed.

title: Carter Asks Delay on Auto Fumes
description: WASHINGTON, April 18The Carter Administration today recommended delay in enforcing automobile emission standards but generally called for tough regulation of air polluters, including economic penalties on those who fail to comply with clean air laws.

title: Howard Hunt Questioned in a Hughes Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 18A small confrontation of figures from the Watergate years occurred today in a law office here.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Federal authorities have issued a license to Columbia University permitting the fueling and operation of a controversial small atomic reactor on the school's Morningside Heights campus. However, university plans to use the reactor must still await the issuance of a second similar operating license now being considered by New York City's Bureau for Radiation Control. The reactor has never been activated since its completion in 1969 because of environmental criticisms from neighbors in the densely populated neighborhood.

title: Drayton Wins Boston Marathon, but Isn't Overjoyed
description: BOSTON, April 18It should have been one of his more satisfying hours. erasing the bitter memories of the fast starts and four frustrating failures in the past.

title: ExSchool Aide Tells of Collecting $400,000 as CoAuthor of Tests
description: A retired assistant superintendent of schools testified yesterday that while in charge of testing for the Board of Education he had received an average of $25,000 a year as coauthor of the Harcourt, Brace & Company reading test used in New York City and elsewherecollecting about $400,000 from 1958 until the present.

title: H. R. H. and Starrett Resume Discussions
description: Two of the city's largest building companiesthe H. R. H. Construction Company and the Starrett Housing Corporationhave reopened the merger discussions they had initiated several years ago.

title: Passports of Mrs. Gandhi's Son And ExDefense Chief Are Lifted
description: NEW DELHI, April 18 (AP)India's new Government announced today that it had impounded the passports of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's son and her Defense Minister, preventing them from leaving the country while their financial dealings are investigated.

title: Supreme Court Will Hear U.S. Appeal of Ruling That Curbs Right to Search for Job Safety Violations
description: WASHINGTON, April 18The Supreme Court agreed today to hear the Government's appeal from a lower court's decision that struck down as unconstitutional a key portion of the Federal job safety legislation permitting Federal inspectors to go into factories and other workplaces without search warrants.

title: Dock Union Orders End of Strike As Ship Lines Move on Job Issue
description: The leader of the striking longshoremen directed them yesterday to return to work today and day following moves by the shipping lines and the Government aimed at improving job opportunities on the docks.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: The buoyant optimism in some quarters a few years ago that the cure for cancer might be just around some corner has largely vanished. That is the strongest impression left by the 1977 American Cancer Society seminar for journalists held earlier this month in Sarasota, Fla., with some of the nation's leading cancer researchers in attendance. The society itself published a selfexamination noting that a fair number of ideas propounded at a similar seminar five years ago have run into blind alleys. The disillusionment could be measured also by the fact that some of the nation's most important newspapers chose to skip the meeting after years of eager attendance.

title: ExDetective Sentenced to Prison
description: Frank E. King, a retired New York City narcotics detective whose name has been linked to the theft of the French Connection heroin from the police property clerk in 1972, was sentenced yesterday to five years in prison and fined $30,000 fort incometax evasion.

title: MISS HEARST PLEADS T0 2 STATE CHARGES
description: LOS ANGELES April 18  Patricia Hearst pleaded no contest today to state charges of armed robbery and assault with a deadly weapon. Nine other chargs, including kidnapping, were dropped.

title: Loss of Nastase Seen
description: KANSAS CITY, April 18 (UPI)The World Championship Tennis doubles finals received a blow today when it was learned that Ilie Nastase and Jan Kodes probably would not compete in the May 4to8 tournament here because of a conflict with the Davis Cup.

title: DEMARCO TESTIFIES TO SELFINJECTIONS
description: NEWARK, April 18Dr. Peter T. DeMarco testified today that he had used himself as a human guinea pig to prove the efficacy of his patented socalled wonder drug before trying it on patients. The state, in its attempt to revoke Dr. DeMarco's license, says the drug is worthless.

title: FiveDayaWeek Postal Deliveries And Increased Subsidies Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, April 18A Government study commission recommended today that the United States Postal Service receive increased subsidies and that postal deliveries he cut to five days a week to reduce operating costs.

title: Haley Gets Special Pulitzer Prize; Lufkin, Tex., News Takes a Medal
description: A special Pulitzer Prize was awarded yesterday to Alex Haley for his controversial best seller, Roots. which traces his family origins back to a slave who came from a small village in Africa.

title: Venezuela to Spend $700 Million To Develop Oil Industry in 1977
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 18 (Reutars) Venezuela will spend about $700 million to develop its oil industry this year, Venezuela's Minister of Energy and Mines, Valentin Hernandez said.

title: Violence Destroys a Boom In Kansas City's Old Section
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 13Night finds the streets of the River Quay section all but deserted. A lone patron sipping a screwdriver at the bar of Poor Freddie's feels the solitude inside to be almost as eerie as that outside.

title: Oaks
description: IOWA CITYSince my father's funeral last September, I've been pondering my family's response to death. By my family I mean my mother's extended family, this matriarchy that claims me, these Norwegians who keep their secrets in the oldcountry language, yea even unto the fourth generation in America.

title: World News Briefs
description: ZAMBOANGA, the Philippines, April 18 (AP)Early official returns from voting in 13 southern provinces today indicated an overwhelming rejection of Moslem rebels' demands that they be given control of the region.

title: Cards Edge Mets by 32 On Homer
description: ST. LOUIS, April 18Al Hrabosky of the Cardinals, who is equally adept at throwing rising fast balls and soaring paradoxes, said a crunching homer by Dave Kingman tonight had won a game for St. Louis.

title: Now the Islanders Take a Rest, Their Next Opponent in Question
description: Are the Islanders really that good? Coach Floyd Smith of the Buffalo Sabres, who were swept by New York, four games to none, in the National Hockey League quarterfinals, says no. Ask the Islanders, who have won all six of their playoff games, and the answer will be yes.

title: Exxon Scientist Gets Award
description: PITTSBURGH, April 18The $10,000 Dickson Prize, given annually by the CarnegieMellon University for outstanding work in science or engineering in the United States, has been awarded to Dr. John Sinfelt, a research scientist at Exxon Research and Engineering Company. Dr.

title: In Memoriam
description: SULLIVANGrace Brinkley. An anniversary Mass will be offered at the Chapel of St. Faith Hope & Charity at 9:00 A.M. on Tuesday April 19. In memory of Grace Brinkley Sullivan who died April 19, 1910.

title: Blue Jays Beat Yanks; Hunter on Disabled List
description: Which one was the expansion team?

title: 2 Who Survived Collision of Jets On the Canary Islands Die in Texas
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 18 (UPI)Two persons who survived the Canary Islands jumbo jet collision on March 27 died today at Brooke Army Medical Center.

title: Monticello Raceway to Put New Focus on Hospitality
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., April 18Leo Doobin, the new genera! manager at Monticello Raceway, said today imagination was to be the theme this year as this upstate harness horse racing facility opened a 165program meeting tonight on its halfmile track.

title: Theater: Side by Side by Sondheim Is a Dream
description: The British have a proverb about taking coals to Newcastle. As newcastle has coals in plenty, this is generally regarded as a somewhat futile effest. Something of the same pessimism could have been turned upon side by side by Sondheim. Which most gorg??ousty opened at the Music Box Theater last night and is a kind of Broadway from London. How wrong such pessimism would have beenfor here is a tiny, manyfaceted gem that lights up Broadway

title: Cambodian Leader Cites Progress
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 18 (AP)In the two years since the Communist victory in Cambodia, children have joined workers and buffalo in transforming the nation into a vast work site, President Khieu Samphan said in an anniversary address.

title: Indian Is Found Guilty Of FirstDegree Murder In Death of 2 F.B.I. Men
description: FARGO, N.D., April 18 (AP)Leonard Peltier, an American Indian Movement leader, was found guilty today on firstdegree murder charges in the killing of two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on South Dakota's Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in 1975.

title: Connecticut Ruling Latest in Drive To Equalize Education in All States
description: The ruling by the Connecticut Supreme Court yesterday that found the states existing system of financing public schools Inequitable represents the latest success in a series of legal efforts to achieve educational equality for school pupils in poor communities.

title: Assembly Gets a Bill Controlling Casino Gambling
description: TRENTON, April 18A bill setting guidelines for casino gambling in Atlantic City was reported out of committee today and sent to the full Assembly, where its first test is expected to come on Thursday.

title: Haley, Assailing Critic, Says Roots Is Sound
description: BANJUL, Gambia, April 18Alex Haley today strongly defended his genealogical research in Roots, saying that a British reporter who has challenged the factual basis of the bestselling book was out headline grabbing.

title: RALPH M. CARSON, 80, CORPORATE LAWYER
description: Ralph M. Carson, a lawyer who specialized in complicated corporate litigation for the firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell here, died on Saturday in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he had maintained A winter home for many years. He was 80 years old and had lived in Pawling, N.Y., since retiring from active practice six years ago.

title: A Comfortable Pair Sing at Bottom Line
description: Ralph McTell and Paul Siebel, who were at the Bottom Line on Sunday for one night only, made a nice pairing, and not just in their music. Both are folkoriented in one way or another, and neither has made the sort of impact on the American market that his talents might deserve.

title: News Conference Friday
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI)President Carter will hold a nationally televised news conference Friday morning, the White House said today. The news conference is part of Mr. Carter's campaign to inform the public about his energy program.

title: In Kinshasa, Where PalmGreasing Is a Way of Life, War Seems Far Away
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 18Except for the now frequent checkpoints at which soldiers ask for drivers' credentials, cigarettes and beer money, there is very little sign that this is the capital of a country at war. The Katangan insurgents are 1,500 miles away and so are the Moroccan troops who have arrived to shore up the reportedly atrophying forces of President Mobutu Sese Seko.

title: Wilder Recalled With Humanism
description: Thornton Wilder, the playwright and novelist who died in 1975, came to life, theatrically speaking, (as he so successfully did), last night in a celebration of what would have been his 80th birthday.

title: Banned Jockey's Lawyer Tries To Get Hearing Officer to Testify
description: The defense attorney for Sandino Hernandez tried to call the judge to the stand yesterday in the hearing involving the alleged use of a battery by the jockey.

title: CARTER ASKS STRICT FUEL SAVING; URGES MORAL EQUIVALENT OF WAR TO BAR A NATIONAL CATASTROPHE
description: WASHINGTON, April 18President Carter warned tonight that the United States faced a possible national catastrophe unless it responded with the moral equivalent of war to dwindling energy supplies by accepting a program based on stringent conservation of fuels, higher energy prices and penalties for waste.

title: Byrne Slated to Announce Today That He Will Run for a 2d Term
description: TRENTON, April 18Governor Byrne is scheduled to announce tomorrow his candidacy for a second term, but this time, the man who won the State House less than four years ago by more than 700,000 votes, the largest plurality in New Jersey's history, will enter the races as a decided underdog.

title: Czechoslovak Six Tops Canada in Exhibition, 41
description: PRAGUE, April 18 (AP)Czechoslovakia scored in all three periods in skating to a 41 victory over Team Canada today before a crowd of 14,500. It was a warmup game for the forthcoming World Ice Hockey Championships in Vienna.

title: Transcript of Carter's Address to the Nation About Energy Problems
description: Good evening. Tonight I want to have an unpleasant talk with you about a problem unprecedented in our history. With the exception of preventing war, this is the greatest challenge that our country will face during our lifetimes. The energy crisis has not yet overwhelmed us, but it will if we do not act quickly.

title: The Athlete in the Wheelchair
description: BOSTON, April 18After about 16 miles of the Boston Marathon today, a man on a Wellesley Hills street corner called, Who's leading? From inside a beige van, a voice replied, Drayton, but Bobby Hall is leading the whole thing. Bobby Hall was in a wheelchair. And soon Bobby Hall appeared, his arms pumping his wheels along, a white visor over his blond hair, a white track shirt with Greater Boston Track Club in red over his muscular torso, his poliocrippled legs inside blue sweatpants, his feet in blue sneakers, the right crossed over the left. With the 15minute jump he and six other wheelchair athletes had received to avert the crush at the starting line in Hopkinton, he would stay ahead of the runners through nearly 18 miles of the 26mile385 yard course along the blacktop roads and streets. Jerome Drayton, the event winner, finally caught him, but rolling down a Commonwealth Avenue hill Bobby Hall regained the lead briefly until the Canadian passed him again. From there about 30 other runners passed him through the corridor of spectators leading to the downtown finish line. But some of the loudest applause surrounded Bobby Hall, the wheelchair athlete.

title: GOVERNOR SIDESTEPS MAYORAL QUESTIONS
description: ALBANY, April 18  Governor, who said: He who ventures into the primaries sometimes scars himself so badly he has to go to the blood bank.?

title: Carter Asks Delay on Auto Fumes
description: WASHINGTON, April 18The Carter Administration today recommended a delay in enforcing automobile emission standards but generally called for tough regulation of air polluters, including economic penalties on those who fail to comply with clean air laws.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Board Adjourns Without Acting on Staff Employees' Strike
description: About 170 clerical and professional staff members of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People continued their walkout yesterday after failing to win support from the civil rights organization's executive board, which ended a quarterly meeting here.

title: WORLD BANK ISSUES TO GO ON SALE TODAY
description: In three disparate but significant credit market developments yesterday, the World Bank priced $600 million of notes and bonds for sale today, the Exxon Corporation announced plans to sell $250 million of taxexempt bonds May 3 in a socalled Dutch auction. and Treasury securities dealers refined their ideas on for to bid this afternoon for $1.47 billion of twoyear notes.
