Fixedincome securities declined slightly in price yesterday as the momentum from President Carter's decision to drop the 350 rebate dissipated and dealers and traders waited

title: Advertising
description: Jackie DaCosta, vice presidentdirector of media information and analysis at Ted Bates & Company, is a woman with a missionto get the two major TV audience rating services to change their method of information collection.

title: A Rare Call for Sacrifices
description: WASHINGTON, April 18At the core of President Carter's televised address to the nation tonight was the unmistakable message that the time had come for some elemental transformations in the American way of life. To some, it may have seemed almost heresy that, less than a year after the American Bicentennial celebration, the new President was not repeating historic refrains about manifest destiny or making new promises about the limitless potential of this nation of plenty.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: As the first intensive Congressional scrutiny of the public accounting profession opens with hearings this morning, in Washington, there are sharp disputes backstage over whether the proceedings, as planned, will prove biased stacked and closeminded.

title: Women United Back on the Scene, Unified
description: The idea seemed so logical when it was first proposed: To bring together women of vastly divergent origins and concerns in a mutual effort to help stem the decline of the city and boost hopes for its future.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: The Standings
description: Tuesday. April 19, 1977

title: California Power Station Blasted
description: SONOMA, Calif., April 18 (UPI) A series of explosions set off by an underground terrorist group last night wrecked three transfomers in a Pacific Gas and Electric Company substation. No injuries were reported. The Fedeal Bureau of Investigation said that the blasts were sabotage, for which the Eugene Kuhn unit of the New World Liberation Front took responsibility in a telephone call to the Associated Press. Power was cut off to about 8,000 customers. The unit is named for a man who allegedly died of cold after his electricity was cut off for failure to pay his bill.

title: U.S REVEALS PAPERS ON '49 KOREA PULLOUT
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (Reuters)Amid South Korean concern over Carter Administration plans to withdraw American troops from the Korean peninsula, the State Department has made public diplomatic papers detailing a far stronger reaction to similar plans in 1949, the year before the start of the Korean War.

title: MARJORIE GATESON, ACTRESS, 86, DIES
description: Marjorie Gateson, an actress for nearly six decades, died on Sunday of pneumonia at the Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home, 1339 York Avenue. She was 86 years old.

title: RCA Earnings Rise By 41.4% in Quarter
description: Firstquarter net profit of the RCA Corporation climbed 41.4 percent to $48.5 million, or 63 cents a share, from $34.3 million, or 44 cents a share, in the first three months last year. This year's results marked the best first quarter in the company's 58year history. Sales were $1.4 billion, up 9 percent from $1.3 billion a year ago, the report disclosed yesterday.

title: Indy 500 Entries at 85
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 18 (AP)Seventeen late entries, including cars for Janet Guthrie and Al Unser, a twotime winner, swelled the field for the 61st Indianapolis 500mile race to 85the race's secondlargest entry. The largest number of cars entered for the auto racing classic was 90 in 1967.

title: BANK HOLDING UNITS SHOW PROFIT RISES
description: Six of the nation's major bank holding companies reported higher firstquarter profits yesterday, as the banking industry continued its recovery from the large loan losses and other recessionrelated problems. Analysts said the increases were in line with expectations.

title: Connecticut High Court Invalidates Property Tax for School Financing
description: HARTFORD, April 18The Connecticut Supreme Court ruled today that the state's system of financing public schools largely from local property taxes was unconstitutional because it denied equal educational opportunities to children from poorer districts.

title: Diamonds Estimated at $1 Million Stolen on W. 47th St.
description: Two welldressed men, one armed with a handgun, took a safeful of cut and uncut diamonds worth perhaps $1 million from a merchant in West 47th Street's diamond center yesterday morning. The police estimated the loss at $1 million, but called it a shaky estimate.

title: Roosevelt
description: (C) Conventional sulky. *Also ellgible.

title: Black Asserts Geneva Demands
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 18A leader of the Rhodesian black nationalist alliance representing the guerrillas said last night that settlement in Rhodesia will come through a bazooka.

title: Report of Soybean Inventory Drop Brings Rise of 30 Cents a Bushel
description: Prices of oldcrop soybean futures once again advanced by the daily limit of 30 cents a bushel, or $1,500 a contract, yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The newcrop deliveries were up as much as 15 cents.

title: Strike Halts Geneva Newspapers
description: GENEVA, April 18 (AP)Typesetters started what they called a threeday warning strike today, shutting down all of Geneva's newspapers for the first time in 27 years. The strikers are demanding a 40hour work week and the month's bonus wage traditionally paid by most Swiss companies each year.

title: Scientists Find Hot Springs on Pacific Ocean Floor Teeming With Life
description: The first manned exploration of active hot springs on the deep ocean floor has found that some of them are focal points of teeming life in an otherwise largely sterile environment.

title: Venezia Tossed at Start
description: Mike Venezia was tossed and stepped on by Runs Harder at the start of the first race, but the jockey suffered only a bad sprained left ankle. His boot was torn off by the horse's hoof. . . .Seattle Slew's Sunday morning workout, very much in hand, according to Karen Taylor, the horse's owner, still was 1 2/5 seconds faster than any other Belmont Park workout that morning. The colt sped six furlongs in 1:11 3/5.

title: Ladany Wins Walk
description: OLD BRIDGE, N. J.,(AP) April 18Dr. Shaul Ladany of Israel won the national Amateur Athletic Union 50mile walking championship yesterday for the second year in a row, posting a record time of 7 hours 4 minutes 47 seconds. Ladany circled the Madison Central High School track 186 times to erase the former American record of 7:13.46 he set last year.

title: The Cast
description: NEW ROOTS: An Anthology of Off Off Broadway Directed by Margot Lewitin; ??cal director Patricia Moeser; lighting by Rebecca Binks; muscial director, Natalia Gilbert; costumes by Irene Fer?? stage manager, James West. Presented by the Women's Interart Comer. At the Interart Theater, 549 West 52d Street.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a report on proposed Electoral College changes that appeared in The Times last Wednesday, it was incorrectly stated that Senator Birch Bayh's current proposal for direct popular election of the President provided for a vote by a joint session of Congress in the event that no Presidential candidate received 40 percent of the national vote. The Bayh plan, in its present form, calls for a runoff election in such a situation.

title: High Court to Scan TripleDamage Plea Of Foreign Nations
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)  The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether freign nations can sue for triple damages when alleging they were the victims of antitrust law violations by American companis.

title: RHODESIA CHIEF WINS FREER HAND AT TALKS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 18 (AP)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith won a free hand from his political party today to negotiate a Constitutional settlement leading to black majority rule.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 19, 1977

title: BHUTTO'S OPPONENTS REJECT PEACE OFFER
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, April 8The political forces demanding the resignation of Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto have rejected overtures made to them yesterday and have declared that their campaign of street demonstrations against him will continue.

title: Confident 7th Army Faces Bigger Red Force
description: RASDORF, West GermanyStaff Sgt. James Cooney, who has been assigned to the watchtower at Observation Post Alfa here on the East German border for three years, will never forget the last week of January 1977.

title: Reaction to Carter Talk Favorable
description: WASHINGTON, April 18First reaction from Congressmen, environmentalists and industry officials to President Carter's energy address tonight was largely favorable. The President's diagnosis is essentially correct, said Senator Russell B. Long Democrat of Louisiana, chairman of the Finance Committee: He's right about our need for conservation. I wish he had placed more stress on production.

title: Americans Judo Victors
description: ST. LOUIS, April 18 (UPI)Corrine Kenison of Menlo Park, Calif., won the heavyweight class in women's judo yesterday in the Pan American Games. Maureen Braziel of New York won the open division as Americans took first place in all eight categories.

title: Business Records
description: Monday, April 18, 1977

title: Around the Nation
description: Pine Ridge Indians Vote Not to Build Model Town

title: How Union Became AllAmerican City for 197677
description: UNION, April 18When the streets of Newar kand Plainfield erupted with riots in 1967, this Union County community, which sits between them, seethed with tension and members of the clergy walked the streets to maintain calm.

title: Gold
description: Selected world gold prices Monday. London: morning fixing $151.00.?? up $0.35; afternoon fixing $151.00, up $0.35

title: Letters
description: To the Editor.

title: Brooklyn's Dewey H. S. Is More Like a College
description: There is something strange going on at John Dewey High School in Brooklyn.

title: A Rare Call for Sacrifices
description: WASHINGTON, April 18At the cure of President Carter's televised address to the nation tonight was the unmistakable message that the time had come for some elemental transformations in the American way of life. To some, it may

title: About New York
description: The rotary rubber stamp of Myrtle Bradford puts love on the public record in threequarter time. Chagung, chagung, chagung she goes across the official document, numbering another license to marry, perchance to love.

title: Companies List Their Sales and Earnings Figures
description: For periods ended March 31 unless otherwise indicated. (N) Indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange, and (O) overthecounter

title: FERRY RUNS DISPLAY COMMUTER TROUBLES
description: State Assemblyman John C. Dearie Democrat of the Bronx, learned firsthand yesterday about two of the chronic woes of Staten Islandersuncertain ferry service and expensive telephone calls.

title: Businessmen Visiting Cuba Urge Trade
description: HAVANA, April 18  A delegation of 52 Minnesota businessmen, accompanied by two dozen reporters, arrived in Cuba this afternoon, the largest American group to visit Cuba since the break in relations a decade and a half ago.

title: U.S. BUSINESS OPENS CAMPAIGN TO AMEND ANTIBOYCOTT BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, April 18American businessmen have decided that antiboycott legislation already passed by House and Senate committees threatens a disruption of trade with the Middle East and have begun a massive drive to ruption of trade with the Middle East amend it.

title: BREZHNEV CAUTIONS NATIONS MEDDLING IN ZAIRIAN CONFLICT
description: MOSCOW. April 18Leonid I. Brezhnev said today that countries seeking to meddle in the fighting in Zaire would bear full responsibility for whatever consequences followed.

title: Deaths
description: ALLENMarlory, E. M. Of 3 Red Oak Dr., Rye, N.Y. On April 17, 1977. (Retired Ilngerie buyer of W. T. Grant Co.) Beloved wife of the late John Edward Allen, and devoted sister of Mrs. Francis A. (Elizabeth M.) Squires. Services 8:30 P.M. Wednesday, April 20, at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, N.Y., followed by interment on Thursday at the family plot, Roslyn Cemetery, Roslyn, L.I., N.Y. (Friends may call at the William H. Graham Funeral Home on Tuesday and Wednesday from 25 and from 7.9 p.m.)

title: Pakistani Chief In Eye of Storm
description: LAHORE, Pakistan. April 18  Five years ago, when Zulfikar Ali Bhutto took over a humiliated and defeated country in the dark days right after it had been split in two by the Bangladesh war of independence, one of his first tasks was to rebuild the morale of his dispirited the countrymen with a series of encouraging speeches. We have to pick up the pieces, very small pieces, he said then in a characteristically long and rambling address to his broken nation. But if Allah wills it we will make a new Pakistan, a prosperous and progressive Pakistan.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 19, 1977

title: Jazz: Strange Double Piano Bill
description: There was an air of excited anticipation about the jazz concert at Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening. Not only were. Mary Lou Williams and Cecil Taylor going to play an unusual evening of improvised piano duets, but also their meeting would bring together two of the strongest representatives of styles of jazz that had, previously, been completely at oddsthe swinging, rhythmic tradition of jazz from blues through, bebop (Miss Williams) and the free form, avantgarde (Mr. Taylor). So the concert was called Mary Lou Williams and Cecil Taylor, Embraced.

title: CHRISTIAN TELLS ISRAEL BEIRUT BLOCKS RED CROSS
description: TEL AVIV, April 18A Lebanese Christian militia commander charged today in a message to Israel that his Government in Beirut was making it difficult for the International Red Cross to reach the scene of what he denounced as Palestinian atrocities in the southern part of Lebanon.

title: FrontLine Leaders Discuss Strategy
description: LUANDA, Angola, April 18 (Reuters)The leaders of five black African states held strategy tally here today and afterward affirmed publicly their commitment to oust southern Africa's white governments, if necessary by force.

title: MISS HEARST PLEADS T0 2 STATE CHARGES
description: LOS ANGELES April 18  Patricia Hearst pleaded no contest today to state charges of armed robbery and assault with a deadly weapon. Nine other chargs, including kidnapping, were dropped.

title: CAREY PROPOSES AID FOR GRAPE GROWERS
description: ALBANY, April 18The Carey administration, seeking to aid the state's sling grapegrowing industry, proposed today a sevenpoint legislative program to facilitate the marketing of New York State's wines and other grape products.

title: They Almost Threw in the Towel...Until
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass. LESTER HELLER and his wife, Adele, were sitting in the living room of their winter home in Silver Swing, Md., on a recent Friday night discussing the plays to present in their Provincetown Playhouse this summer when the phone rang about midnight. It was bad news, Mr. Heller recalls. The playhouse was on fire ...

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Mime Full of Symbolism
description: ANDREA DARRLAU'S skill as a mime is little in question when she chooses to show it, but there is some doubt as to whether she has fully formed suitable vehicles for that skill. She represented five works Monday evening at the Dance Gallery that were, on the whole, inconclusively structured. The parts were more interesting than the whole.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Jimmy Carter did not begin it, although in a way he legitimatized it, and certainly he made it known to us all. Mr. Carter, who is also great for blue jeans, spoke to the nation on television while wearing a cardigan sweater. In the past, he and his family and friends have been accused of sponsoring something called redneck chic, but a cardigan sweater is different from that. A President wearing a cardigan sweater while he addresses the nation is not redneck, but reverse, chic. It is symbolic, something you do when you can easily afford to do something else. Hardly anyone thinks the President is just one of the boys; therefore he can easily afford to look like one. Hardly anyone thinks David Merrick would have trouble getting a good table at Sardi's; therefore he frequently goes to the back of the restaurant and sits with the tourists. That is reverse chic.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, April 19State officials heard pleas today from industry spokesmen for more stringent fuel conservation requirements in new building codes.

title: Energy Plan Said to Lack A Public Transport Aspect
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The Carter Administration, on the eve of announcing a proposal for saving energy, has not yet linked its conservation program with a policy to enhance public transportation, Administration sources said today.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: A Priest Is Stirring the Melting Pot To Revitalize Ethnic Neighborhoods
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  When Msgr. Geno Baroni was growing up in western Pennsylvania, his teachers urged him to blend into the American melting pot and forget the language of his Italian immigrant parents. He has since tried valiantly and vainly to learn it, even taking a lastditch fling at Berlitz, but to this day he can scarcely say good morning in Italian.

title: Senate Committee Backs President On Aid to Nations Observing Rights
description: WASHINGTON, April 19President Carter won an important Senate test today for his ideas on how the United States can best advance human rights through international financial institutions.

title: Advertising
description: For the promotionminded entrepreneur the supermarkets of America are an alluring but dangerous challenge. Most attempts at finding an effective way of delivering all those consumers at the momentofpurchase decision to advertisers have failed.

title: U.S.Soviet Relations: A Period of Testing and Testiness
description: MOSCOW, April 18Despite Soviet and American pledges to further dtente, relations in the first three months of the Carter Administration have been marked by one confrontation after another, producing little more than friction, annoyance and public posturing. By the most optimistic assessment, it has been a period of mutual testing, natural when a new President takes office.

title: VENEZUELA SEEKING TO STRENGTHEN OPEC
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 19President Carlos Andree Perez, on the eve of a trip to the Middle East, said today he would be seeking to strengthen the Or ganization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, which has been upset by a split in crudeoil pricing.

title: Carter Urged to Intervene in Seoul
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  Twelve Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders have asked President Carter to intervene on behalf of Christian dissidents arrested recently in South Korea.

title: Koosman Wins First as Mets Top Cards, 52
description: ST. LOUIS, April 19Jerry Koosman looked back on his 52 victory over the Cardinals tonight with mixed emotion.

title: CONFEREES IN ACCORD ON JOBS BILL DETAILS
description: WASHINGTON. April 19House and Senate conferees agreed today on all the details of a $4 billion public works jobs bill except the critical one: how to vote it out and get it passed.

title: Revival of L.I. Press Ruled Out by Mobil
description: The Mobil Oil Company said yesterday that it was no longer interested in the possibility of reviving the defunct Long Island Press.

title: Reluctance to Follow Steel on Arbitration
description: The most ambitious effort in any major industry to date to substitute reason for muscle in resolving contract disputes has been assured of another threeyear lease on life, though it picked up a few bruises in running the gantlet of union ratification. Local leaders in the United Steelworkers of America did a doubletake early this month before approving a new basic steel contract that combines increases of more than 10 percent a year in labor costs with a pledge to arbitrate any impasse that may arise in 1980 negotiations with 10 large producers.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in The Times yesterday on President Carter's use of television, William Small was erroneously identified as president of CBS News. Mr. Small is senior vice president. Richard Salant is president

title: A Toast to Ethnic Bakeries, And Noble Loaves of Splendor
description: Of all the foods that have suffered from mass production, none has fared more abysmally than bread. Made of overrefined flour that is treated with dough conditioners to ensure insipid softness, sweetened with sugar to ensnare infantile palates, and dosed with chemical preservatives toward the goal of an eternal shelf life, the resultant loaves, short on both flavor and nutritive values, remain limp in their waxen enclosures.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 20, 1977

title: 2 Officers Are Critically Wounded As Suspect Seizes a Police Pistol
description: Two plainclothes policemen were shot and critically wounded outside a Brooklyn bar yesterday when a man they were trying to arrest grabbed one of the officers' guns and opened fire. A suspect was arrested late last night.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: AFROIMSKYAaron. Beloved husband of Pauline. Devoted father of Herbert and Rita Kahan and loving grandfather. Services 1 P.M. today, at Sherman's Flaibush Memorial, 1283 Cones Island Ave. (Ave. J).

title: Flyers Win, 20, on Leach's Goals And Take a 32 Lead Over Leafs
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 19Reggie Leach, who they say can shoot from anywhere, shot while on his stomach and halfleaning on his elbows tonight, lifted the puck over Mike Palmateer in the Toronto net and sealed a 20 victory for the Philadelphia Flyers over the Maple Leafs.

title: Letters
description: Exchange Buffets

title: Bullets Down Rockets With Rally, 111101
description: HOUSTON, April 19 (UPI)Mitch Kupchak scored a careerhigh 32 points tonight to lead the Washington Bullets to a 111101 victory over the Houston Rockets in the opener of their National Basketball Association quarterfinal playoff series.

title: U.S. LOWERS ITS ESTIMATE ON '76 CORPORATE PROFITS
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)The Commerce Department lowered today by $300 million its estimate of corporate profits in the last quarter of 1976, when the nation's economy was in a lull.

title: CARTER PLANS REBATE OF NEW ENERGY LEVIES THROUGH INCOME TAX
description: WASHINGTON, April 19President Carter decided today that income tax rebates would be the best way to return to the public billions of dollars of new energy taxes that he will propose to Congress tomorrow as part of a comprehensive, and already controversial, national energy plan.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SMILEAGE This is the 20th anniversary year of the founding of the ensemble called We Are Hereknown as Anachnu Kan in Hebrewin Lithuania. The company of 105 singers, dancers, musicians and actorsall Soviet Jewish emigrants now living in Israelis making its second annual United States tour. There are two local performances, tonight at 8 at Avery Fisher Hall and Saturday at 9 at Carnegie Hall. General admission is $5.50 to $12.50.

title: Some in Pakistan Rally for Bhutto
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, April 19 (Reuters)Supporters of Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto took to the streets today in the first proGovernment demonstration here since the opposition started a drive to force him to resign.

title: Bullets'Box Score
description: RefereesRichie Powers, Houston Vaughn and Donald Durr.

title: Personal Health
description: MR. AND MRS. S. are in their late 30's and although they share a deep love, affection, respect and consideration, they have had sexual intercourse fewer than 10 times in the more than 10 years they have been married, and this is fine with both of them.

title: Bullock Is Signed by Spurs
description: SAN ANTONIO, April 19 (UPI)Rick Bullock, a former San Antonio high school star and Texas Tech's leading career scorer, signed a freeagent contract today to play for the San Antonio Spurs in the 197778 National Basketball Association season. Bullock was an AllSouthwest Conference player four years at Texas Tech before being drafted in the fourth round by the New York Knicks in 1976. The Knicks waived him the day before the season began last fall.

title: Meyer Is Named Coach of 49ers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 (AP)Ken Meyer, a Los Angeles Ram offensive assistant since 1973, was named today head coach of the San Francisco 49ers. He succeeded Monte Clark, who was dismissed earlier this month in a dispute with General Manager Joe Thomas over responsibilities.

title: SIX MAGAZINES HONORED IN NATIONAL COMPETITION
description: The winners of the 1977 National Magazine Awards have been announced. They are Architectural Record Audubon. Harper's, Mother Jones, Philadelphia and Rolling Stone.

title: BYRNE STRESSES TAX AS ISSUE OF ELECTION
description: TRENTON, April 19Pledging to stand up and take the heat. Governor Byrne declared his candidacy for a second term today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 20, 1977

title: Beame Seeks to Tie Pay Raises To WorkRule Changes in Budget
description: In a shift of approach to increase the productivity of New York City workers, the Beame administration is putting aside $40 million to $60 million in its budget next year to pay for costofliving wage increases for employees who agree to workrule changes that save the city money.

title: MOROCCAN KING SAYS CUBANS ARE IN AIRE
description: RABAT, Morocco, April 19King Hassan 11 said in an interview made public today that Cuban elements were among the forces facing his expeditionary troops in Zaire's Shaba Province and that he had both direct and circumstantial evidence to prove it.

title: RICHARD L. KENNEDY
description: Richard L. Kennedy, a retired stockbroker, died Sunday at Lake Forest (Ill.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and a resident of Lake Forest.

title: District Attorney Aide Indicted
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 19 (AP)An aide to District Attorney F. Emmett Fitzpatrick was indicted today on three counts of perjury by a Federal grand jury investigating underworld loansharking operations. The indictment accuses Stanley Apfelbaum of lying three times to the panel, which for 18 months has been investigating a nowdefunct auto dealership in suburban Chestnut Hill.

title: Israel Releases 47 Arabs in an Exchange for 9 Dead Soldiers and 2 Spies
description: EL HIRBEH, IsraeliOccupied Sinai, April 19A group of Arab prisoners and members of their families were exchanged today for the bodies of 11 Jews two spies and nine soldiersat this remote windy oasis in the northern Sinai Desert.

title: Odor Leads Inquiry to Factory Area
description: The foul odor that has bothered midtown Manhattan residents in recent nights probably is coming from two factories, one in Long Island City. Queens, and the other in Brooklyn, the city's Environmental Protection Agency said yesterday.

title: Bridge
description: The lower the level of the contract, the greater the likelihood of complex play. In a part score, the lead tends to swing back and forth, and both sides have more choices.

title: CAREY URGES BANKS TO INVEST IN HOUSING
description: Governor Carey called on the state's savings banks yesterday to help the state's economy by investing more heavily in residential mortgages. He warned that if they did not, he would try next year to rescind a mortgage rate increase the banks hope to get this year.

title: Winnipeg Coach Is Fined
description: TORONTO, April 19 (AP)Bill MacFarland, president of the World Hockey Association, announced today that Bobby Kromm, coach of the Winnipeg Jets, and defenseman Bryan Maxwell of the Cincinnati Stingers had been fined for actions during the W.H.A. playoffs. Kromm was fined for his behavior in game at San Diego Sunday and Maxwell was tagged for his actions in game against Indianapolis April 14. The fines were reportedly $500 apiece.

title: The Four Seasons Go It Alone  Almost
description: ANYONE WHO MANAGED to get a ticket for either of the Four Seasons shows Monday night at the Bottom Line must have expected that this was to be a chance to see Frank Valli and his group perform their show in a congenial, intimate setting. No matter that the advertisements stressed the Four Seasons or even that a nervous note by the Bottom Line box office cautioned that this was to be a special Warner Brothers promotional event, unlike a regular show.

title: Activist Priest in H. U. D. Post Seeks To Revitalize Ethnic Neighborhoods
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  When Msgr. Geno Baroni was growing up in western Pennsylvania, his teachers urged him to blend into the American melting pot and forget the language of his Italian immigrant parents. He has since tried valiantly and vainly to learn it, even taking a lastditch fling at Berlitz, but to this day he can scarcely say good morning in Italian.

title: More BigTime Tennis in New York As Garden Gets Grand Prix Masters
description: Madison Square Garden, home of the Knicks, the Rangers, the circus, the horse show and the like; Madison Square Garden, of all places, has suddenly turned New York City into the tennis capital of the world.

title: TV: For Serious Viewers
description: THAT intrepid block of viewers professing to loathe entertainment programming can spend all three hours of tonight's prime time in the alternate worlds of news and documentaries. At 8, CBS has Mysteries of the Great Pyramid and public television's Nova series examines The Business of Extinction, referring to the international trade in animals. At 9, all networks will be carrying President Carter's energy address. And at 10, back on CBS, a militaryassessment essay is entitled: Who's Ahead: The Debate Over Defense.

title: TV and Radio to Carry Carter Speech Tonight
description: President Carter's energy message to a joint session of Congress at 9 o'clock tonight will be televised live by Channels 2, 4, 7, 13 and 50.

title: CARTER WILL DOUBLE SUPPORT FOR FARMS
description: WASHINGTON, April 19President Carter, in a move to generate more backing for his Administration's agricultural program, has agreed to double Federal spending for farmincome supports, Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland said today.

title: Rubber Capital of Akron No Longer Revolves Around Tires
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 19This time a year ago, this midsize northeastern Ohio city, commonly known as the rubber capital of the world, was hours away from plunging into the longest strike by rubber workers in the history of the industry. It lasted 4  months.

title: CARTER PLANS REBATE OF NEW ENERGY LEVIES THROUGH INCOME TAX
description: WASHINGTON, April 19President Carter decided today that income tax rebates would be the best way to return to the public billions of dollars of new energy taxes that he will propose to Congress tomorrow as part of a comprehensive, and already controversial, national energy plan.

title: ChildAbuse And Snooping
description: Child abuse is one of this year's causes. We are told that it is as widespread and common in wealthy suburbs as in city slums. Indignant citizens groups are forming to combat the epidemic. Maternityward staffs are encouraged to screen new mothers for signs of the childabuse profile.

title: Head of Navy Requesting Delay in Changes in Pay And Retirement Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. James L. Holloway, worried about possible unionization of the military forces, said today that the Navy had asked the Defense Department to delay changes in military pay and retirement benefits for another year to work out a clearly defined policy on military compensation.

title: MARTIN M. GOLDBERG
description: Martin M. Goldberg, an insurance industry executive. died of a heart attack Monday at bellevue Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 25 Central Park West.

title: HORTENSE LOWENTHAL GANS
description: Funeral services for Hortense Lowenthal Gans, who died Saturday in her 88th year, were held yesterday at her residence in the Hotel Surrey, 20 East 76th Street.

title: British Government's Advisers Find Concorde Noisy
description: LONDON, April 19The British Government's advisers on aircraft noise, in a report made public today, found that the supersonic Concorde airliner exceeded the statutory noise limit on 72 percent of its takeoffs from London's Heathrow Airport. They said it was regrettable that Concorde had been exempted from noise regulations.

title: U.S. Asks Sugar Accord That Holds Price Shifts Within Reasonable Levels
description: GENEVA, April 19The United States urged leading sugarproducing and consuming countries today to conclude an international agreement that would hold price movements within reasonable levels.

title: GENERAL TELEPHONE REPORTS NET UP 53%
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, the nation's largest independent telephone system, reported yesterday increases of 53.8 percent in net income for the first quarter and 12.8 percent for sales and revenues.

title: JACK MAXWELL
description: ALBANY, April 19 (UPI)Funeral services will be held Thursday for Jack Maxwell, 71 years old, former president of the Northeastern Professional Golf Association and head professional for 20 years at the Stamford Country Club in Delaware County. Mr. Maxwell, a native of Scotland, died yesterday at St. Peter's Hospital after a long illness.

title: The Annual Threat to the Adirondacks
description: The New York State Senate will soon confront a piece of legislation that crops up annually and seems to get worse each year. With a persistence that could serve a better purpose, Senator Ronald Stafford and Assemblyman Glenn H. Harris have been trying to scuttle the Adirondack Park Agency ever since its creation in 1973.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: Giacomo Puccini seems to have gotten himself a medium who's forgotten a message.

title: Conference on Soviet Jewry Stages Demonstration on Steps of Library
description: On the steps of the Main Library at 42d Street and Fifth Avenue yesterday, Rabbi Haskel Lookstein of the Greater New York Conference on Soviet Jewry and Bella S. Abzug, former United States Representative, heaved together and placed in an empty chair a symbolic carton of petitions demanding an end to oppression of Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: Outlook Held Bleak
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Although the Postal Service's books were in balance in the 12 months ending in March, observers agree that the success is unlikely to continue. The outlook for the rest of this year has been made bleak by the prospect of more than $700 million in scheduled or costofliving salary increases and an unspecified amount of general inflation in other costs.

title: Woody Allen Fights Anhedonia
description: MALKING ALONG the streets of New York, Woody Allen, Diane Keaton and Tony Roberts run into the Devilrobust, bearded and wearing a red tiewho invites them to accompany him on a guided tour of hell. The four enter an elevator, which goes down. At each level, some of Mr. Allen's favorite enemies get on: C.I.A. assassins, F.B.I. informers, fastrood servers. At the sixth level, the door opens andwith flames leaping at their highestRichard Nixon enters.

title: Council Approves a Liberalized Proposal on Delinquent Realty Taxes
description: In deliberate haste, the New York City Council passed a bill yesterday to permit delinquent payers of the realestate tax to liquidate their debts in a oneshot program expected to bring an immediate infusion of cash to the city. The vote was 39 to 3.

title: Brush Fires Destroy 1,000 Acres Of Woodlands in Suffolk County
description: MIDDLE ISLAND, L.I., April 19A spectacular forest and brush fire billowed through a thousand acres of pine and scrub oak in this central Suffolk County village today, requiring five hours of work and 50 volunteer fire units from across the county to contain it.

title: Brooklyn Drug Facility's Outlay Is Put at $45,000 a Year a Patient
description: A state legislator charged yesterday that a cityaided drugtreatment facility in Brooklyn was caring for 17 addicts with a staff of 36 at an estimated cost of $45,000 a year a patient.

title: General Signal Agrees To Acquire Sola Basic For Over $100 Million
description: The General Signal Corporation of Stamford announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Sola Basic Industries of Milwaukee through An exchange of stock valued at more than $100 million.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Like most marriages, partnerships between a city and its sports franchises generally begin as if they were made in heaven.

title: Dollar Rises in Tokyo
description: TOKYO. April 19 (AP)The dollar rose to its highest level against the Japanese yen since April 1 today as businessmen bought large amounts of United States currency to pay for imports.

title: Search for the Killer of Five Put Under a Unified Command
description: A deputy inspector was assigned yesterday to coordinate the works of at least 30 detectives who are seeking a deranged gunman who has killed five people and wounded three others during the last nine months.

title: Moynihan Lecture Engagements Brought Him $152,000 Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Daniel Patrick Moynihan made $152,000 from speeches and lectures last year, bunching most of his appearances on the lecture circuit in the months just before and just after his successful race for the United States Senate from New York.

title: London Office for Morgan Stanley
description: Morgan Stanley International Inc., an affiliate of the New York investment banking firm, announced the opening of a fullservice office in London under the name of Morgan Stanley International.

title: Subject: Bobo Rockefeller
description: To: The Living Section Edition

title: An OldTimer Impressed by Meadowlands
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J, April 19 If only my father had been around to see this spread, said 72yearold Frank Ervin this afternoon as he scuffed the track with his heel near the Meadowlands' finish line. Looka here, my heel hardly made a dent. Ervin, the famous sulky driver who retired two years ago after scoring 1.211 victories, was one of 10 members of harness racing's Hall of Fame on hand at the onemile harness racing oval.

title: School. Results
description: BASEBALL

title: Technology
description: A major role in supplying fuel for United States and foreign nuclear plants is to be given to a largely secret technology for enriching uranium by use of gas centrifuges. Page D5.

title: Offer for Irvine Company By Taubman Seen as Best
description: The James Irvine Foundation, principal shareholder of Irvine Company, said that it believes that the $302.9 million cash bid for the California land company made by the TaubmanAllenIrvine group is the best which it has received.

title: Two Face Kidnapping Sentence
description: LOS ANGELES, April 19 (AP)A female model and a machinist face sentencing May 18 in the kidnapping of a record company president, Lou Adler, and business associate. Veronica Franovich, 28 years old, and Zoltan Laslow Kakash, 39, both of Torrance, were convicted in Superior Court yesterday of kidnapping, robbery and conspiracy. They were acquitted on a second kidnapping charge involving Mr. Adler's aide, Neil Silver.

title: Companies List Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For ?? 3?? unless ?? (M) Indicates stock ?? the Now York Stock Ex?? (A) American Stock Exchange, and (O) overthecou??

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Paul W. Douglas, president and chief executive of the Freeport Minerals Company, said at the annual meeting in Wilmington, DeL, yesterday that a longterm contract for sale by its wholly owned subsidiary, the Freeport Uranium Recovery Company, of 50 percent of the output of its new uranium recovery project in Louisiana had been virtually completed.

title: Three to Get Awards From Dance Magazine
description: Murray Louis, Natalia Makarova and Peter Martins will receive the 22nd annual Dance Magazine Awards at a presentation Monday, at the Regency Hotel.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A suspect wanted in connection with the shooting of a patient in Booth Memorial Hospital in Flushing two months ago was arrested yesterday by the police and immigration officials. The suspect was identified as Frank Giovanny Arbelaez Naranjo, 27 years old, a Colombian citizen living at 9008 208th Street, Queens Village, Queens.

title: SENATE PANEL KEEPS CREDITS FOR BUSINESS IN NEW TAX MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON. April 19The Senate Finance Committee, while going along readily with President Carter's surprise request to strip the unpopular $50 rebate from his economic. stimulus package, presented a tax bill to the Senate floor today retaining the credits for business that the President also said he wanted scrapped.

title: Young Is SilencedBut Only for a While
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 19Andrew Young, the United States delegate, was silenced today for a while.

title: DISCOVERY OF BLIGHT MAY AID CHESTNUTS
description: The alertness of a treelover while skiing crosscountry through Michigan woods has, for the first time, disclosed the presence in this country of a native strain of chestnut blight that nullifies the effects of the lethal strain.

title: CARTER WILL NOT BLOCK MOVE TO EASE CUBA TRADE
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)President Carter will not interfere with any Congressional move to loosen the trade embargo against Cuba, Senators George McGovern and James Abourezk said today.

title: Around the Nation
description: MIAMI April 19The Dade County Commission today rejected efforts by mostly conservative groups to repeal an ordinance that outlaws discrimination against homosexuals in housing, public accommodation and employment.

title: Carter Supports Arms for Turks In Policy Review
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The Carter Administration, after a threemonth review of policy in the eastern Mediterranean, has decided to endorse a controversial bases agreement with Turkey that was signed last year by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and was not approved by Congress.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL. 20, 1977

title: Closed End Funds
description: Tuesday, April 19, 1977

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Mobutu Wants Cokes To Go With His Plane
description: WASHINGTON, April 19President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, who expects shortly to receive a C130 transport plane that he purchased from the United States, apparently wants the plane to be delivered full of CocaCola.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 19, 1977

title: Yankees'Box Score
description: TORONTO (A.)

title: Private Lives
description: WHEN A FRIEND called to arrange a softball game, Dmitri was listening to WBAI. (Alfred Kazin asks in a letter, Dmitri, Dmitri, why always Dmitri? Why not Alyosha or Smerdyakov? These are good questions.) WBAI, for those of you who have been off on a crusade to recover the Holy Land, is the listenersupported, noncommercial, Pacifica radio station in New York City. There are also Pacifica stations in Washington. Texas, Los Angeles and Berkeley, Calif.

title: MERCENARIES'RECRUITER DENIES LINK WITH C.I.A.
description: FRESNO, Calif., April 19 (AP)David Bufkin, a crop duster who has confirmed that he was recruiting mercenaries to fight in Zaire, denies in a report published here that his activities are being financed by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Moral Equivalent of War
description: WASHINGTON, April 19President Carter is touching on some of the deepest questions of American history, and even on some of the deepest puzzles of human conduct, in his crusade for a more austere energy policy.

title: Soybeans Futures Prices Advance and Then Slump Daily Limit of 30 Cents
description: CHICAGO, April 19 (AP)Soybean futures advanced 30 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade today and then closed with a limit decline of 30 cents after 15 minutes of wild trading at the close.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: O NE of the best, tastiest and fastest ground meat dishes in the French repertory is known as veal cutlets Pojarski. Like biftoks, it is a kind hamburger. The story of the origin of the name is well kown. There was a tavern in a Russian town called Torjok, and the proprietor of the inn was named Pojarski. Legend has it that he created one or more of the ground beef dishes that bear his name, and these he served to passengers who passed his way in their carriages.

title: Phosphate Detergent Ban Signed
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., April 19Gov. Richard A. Snelling today signed into law a bill banning the sale of phosphate detergents in Vermont. The measure goes into effect next year. The law is aimed at curbing water pollution by stemming the growth of algae.

title: 2 Deserters Return to Leave Army
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 19 (AP)Nils F. Swenson and Phillip L. Gower returned to the United States today just long enough officially to get outof the Army that they deserted during the Vietnam War. Their slates with the Government cleared, they headed back to Canada.

title: Bypass for a Segregation Impasse
description: School desegregation has been so long polarizedor paralyzedthat it is worth taking note of even a small new step with potential for progress that has been made, in the heated setting of Chicago, by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. After 12 years of fruitless wrangling with school officials over alleged discrimination, the department is bringing in an outside negotiator to devise a detailed remedy.

title: Books: A Man Smitten by Art
description: BY USUAL STANDARDS of measurement, the Julien Levy .Gallery was not a blazing success. And Julien Levy, who opened it in 1931 and closed it in 1948, admits it. More than once in this memoir, he mentions shows that did not sell and the names of artists he exhibited who went to other galleries when they became better known. He tells how he was outmaneuvered by others when it came to economic matters and how some of his ideas were taken and exploited by cannier promoters. He found, too, that people were beginning to take credit for shifting movements that he had done more than anyone else to call to the attention of art buyers and the general public.

title: Talks Open in Beirut On Enforcing Curbs Over P.L.O. Activity
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 19With controversy continuing to surround the 1969 agreement on the status of the Palestine Liberation Organization in Lebanon, the Government of President Elias Sarkis has resumed negotiations with a special fournation Arab commission on enforcing the accord.

title: Carter's Raiders: The Outsiders Are In
description: WASHINGTON REPRESENTATIVE John W. Jenrette was looking over the witnesses at a House Agriculture Committee hearing on food stamps when his eyes fixed on a lanky, bushyhaired mustachioed man. He stared.

title: Geneva Newspapers Are Struck
description: GENEVA, April 19None of this city's five daily newspapers appeared today because of a threeday strike by printers in support of demands for a 40hour week and a yearend bonus equivalent to a month's pay. This is the first time in 29 years that a strike has deprived the city of its newspapers.

title: Young Says Criticism Will Not Deter Him
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 19Andrew Young, the controversial United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that he did not mind being called naive because he had dared to dream impossible dreams, whether pursuing the civil rights struggle in the South or promoting peace in South Africa.

title: Wine Talk
description: RESTAURANTS catering to the wine enthusiast are becoming more numerousnot just places with adequate wine lists, but places that try to do something special. Here are reports on some recent discoveries.

title: Accusatory Tone in Carter Talk Is Deplored by Oilmen in Houston
description: HOUSTON, April 19Frank Melchor, the maitre d'htel at the Houston Petroleum Club, is probably as good as anyone at sensing the mood of the oil industry. Today he looked over his all male luncheon crowd, listened for a few seconds and said: It's quietvery quiet.

title: Books of The Times
description: WE ARE impressionable out here in bookchat land, which is what Gore Vidal likes to call the place where we clerks of literature scratch away. We are impressionable, and so one gets seduced rather too quickly into Mr. Vidal's way of thinking in his fourth and latest collection of essays, Matters of Fact and of Fiction, which is too often characterized by an affinity for the Single Explanation. According to Mr. Vidal, bookchatters don't appreciate the fiction of Louis Auchinclass sufficiently because bookchatters don't recognize the class that actually rules them (The Great World and Louis Auchincloss). Or: Fiction writers whom Donald Barthelme admires are inept because theyand heare too much under the influence of the French New Novel, which is close to forty years old . . . young for an American presidential candidate or a Chinese buried egg . . . [but] very old indeed for a literary movement, particularly a French literary movement (American Plastic: The Matter of Fiction).

title: Percy, at Big 8 Hearings, Chides Accountants for Fiscal Reports
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Senate overseers and accountants took conciliatory stances today as hearings began on charges that the Big Eight accounting firms exercise undue influence over the profession's rulemaking machinery.

title: Zairian Force, Including a Company of Pygmies, Is Said to Have Encircled Key Town Held by Katangans
description: KINSHASA. Zaire. April 19A Government spokesman said tonight that Zairian troops had encircled a rebelheld railroad junction town in the south and that a company of pygmies armed with bows and arrows was with them.

title: Dollar Mixed in Trading On European Markets; Gold Price Off in London
description: LONDON, April 19 (AP)The dollar was mixed today against European currencies, strengthening in the Netherlands, West Germany and Switzerland, showing no change in Britain and sagging in France and Italy.

title: PROPOSED FOR DOWNTOWN NEWARK: An aerial view with an artist's conception of a 26story office building superimposed in the center of the picture. Public
description: Service Electric and Gas Company would be the major tenant of a complex that would be constructed on the block at the rear of present headquarters at Park Place.

title: Accounting Unit Proposes FinancialReporting Rules For Pension Statements
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, the privatesector rulemaking body, yesterday proposed the first authoritative financialreporting rules for pension plans.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: A 30's Revival

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in The Times yesterday on President Carter's use of television, William Small was erroneously identified as president of CBS News. Mr. Small is senior vice president. Richard Salant is president.

title: Once Again, French Bread
description: In some editions of The Living Section on March 30 the recipe of French bread dough was difficult to read because of poor reproduction. Because of the large number of requests, the recipe is reprinted in full.

title: Dance: Following In Spirit of Limon
description: IT IS 30 years since the late Jos Limn formed his companya company that was to make international dance history. Now at The Roundabout Theater, the company bereft of its master, but still imbued with his spiritis giving an anniversary season, which opened last night

title: Justice for Juvenile Offenders
description: The New York State Legislature has again provided a public arena for the sport of how best to get tough with juveniles. Careful marksmanship is not required and nothing seems to have been learned from the failure of the harsh narcotic laws. This year, the target chosen is violent juveniles, especially those who have hurt elderly people, although younger children are more often injured by youths than older people.

title: Child's World
description: THE toy industry, like the stock market, is sensitive to what the country is thinking. America's preoccupations show up as Evel Knievel daredevils, McDonald's toy restaurants and anatomically correct dolls.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Dr. Dorothy S. Brady, 73, Is Dead; A Professor at Wharton School
description: Dr. Dorothy S. Brady, professor emeritus of economics at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania died in her home in Pine Hill, N.Y. Sunday after a short illness. She was 73 years old.

title: Best Buys
description: WITH SALES on pork, chuck and chickens dominant in the markets, and with anjou pears still singing their siren songs from the produce racks, this is one of those weeks when the auguries are more exciting than the actuality.

title: Andrus Urges Expanded Redwood Park
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Secretary of the Interior Cecil D. Andrus proposed today that Congress expand the Redwood National Park in northern California by acquiring, over the vehement protests of loggers and lumber companies, 48,000 acres on the park's periphery.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: ExFrench Envoy Takes Own Life; Killed Wife, 2 Children in February
description: PARIS, April 19 (UPI)Gerard Amanrich, a former French ambassador who killed his wife and two children in February then lost the nerve to commit suicide, hanged himself today in a hospital psychiatric ward, the police said. He was 56 years old.

title: Chess:
description: Heikki Westerinen, the only grandmaster in Finland's history, finished last in the recent Geneva International tournament but nevertheless won the prize for the best attacking play.

title: ENVIRONMENT GROUPS PRESS BRIDGE TOLLS
description: Environmental groups asked a Federal judge yesterday to compel Governor Carey to follow a courtordered timetable for imposing tolls on the East River and Harlem River bridges as part of a transportation control plan to reduce air pollution in New York City.

title: Aria Caps Senate Testimony for Arts
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Capping her appearance with an aria from Turandot, Carmen Balthrop of the Metropolitan Opera testified today before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee in support of President Carter's proposed budget for the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Strike Shuts Westinghouse Plant
description: TAMPA. Fla., April 19 (UPI)Operations at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation plant here were shut down today by a strike of more than 300 members of the United Electrical Workers Union that began yesterday.

title: About Education
description: Amid the furor over postponement of the annual citywide reading tests in New York, a long time suspicion has been fanned to a passionate conviction in some circles. This is, in brief, that such questions as How many eyes saw the supposedly secure test in advance and is it fair to go ahead with the nowcompromised test are among many wrong ones being asked.

title: Designed for the Practical Professional
description: Given an average New York apartment kitchen, 8 feet wide by 14 feet long, is it possible to fit into its long and narrow confines eight gas burners, three ovens, a freezer that holds 338 pounds of food, a 19cubicfoot refrigerator, twin sinks, a dishwasher, a nine  foot  long cutting  board work counter with a bank of cabinets underneath, hanging cabinets to hold tableware, and enough wall and ceiling racks to keep all pots and pans within easy reach?

title: Met Gets A David As a Gift
description: THE METROPOLITAN Museum of Air has acquired a JacquesLouis David portrait; sold by Rockefeller University for several minion dollars. The work, painted in 1788, is of the French chemist AntoineLaurent Lavoisier and his wife.

title: House Panel Approves a StripMine Control Bill
description: WASHINGTON. April 19The House Interior Committee cleared again today a strong Federal strip mine regulatory bill that the mining industry calls a straight jacket.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Nyquist Defends the Segregation Of High School in Queens Section
description: New York State's Commissioner of Education, Ewald B. Nyquist, yesterday defended segregation of Andrew Jackson High School in Cambria Heights. Queens, as necessary to retain integration in other high schools in the borough.

title: Richard D. Brauer Dies at Age 76; A Pioneer in Modern Algebra
description: Richard Dagobert Brauer, widely regarded by mathematicians as one of the century's leading pioneers in the development of modern algebra, died on Sunday after a short illness. He was 76 years old and his home was in Belmont, Mass.

title: Market Place
description: Citicorp, one of the premier bankholding companies, surprised Wall Street yesterday by reporting flat earnings for the first quarter of 1977.

title: Carter Supports Arms for Turks In Policy Review
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The Carter Administration, after a threemonth review of policy in the eastern Mediterranean, has decided to endorse a controversial bases agreement with Turkey that was signed last year by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and was not approved by Congress.

title: Vote Results Cast Shadow Over Philippine Accord
description: MANILA, April 19Results tabulated so far on Sunday's referendum on autonomy for the Moslem regions of the southern Philippines show an overwhelming rejection of the Moro National Liberation Front and cast serious doubt on the likelihood of a peaceful settlement of the front's rebellion against the Government in Manila.

title: Columbia Gets Lipchitz Sculpture
description: A 23ton bronze sculpture that was the last and largest work by Jacques Lipchitz before his death in 1973 was delivered yesterday to the Columbia University campus, where it will stand as one of the city's largest and most commanding sculptures.

title: Doctor Calls Woman Companion Good Influence on Groucho Marx
description: LOS ANGELES, April 19Groucho Marx, recovering from recent hip surgery, was confined to his Beverly Hills home today while miles away a courtroom battle continued over the naming of a conservator to manage his estate.

title: Topics
description: The noise level of the debate about the noise level of the Concorde has become deafening, and certain overbearing and supersonic advocates should be denied landing rights in the controversy. We have in mind the zealots who think that noisy traffic jams on the roads to Kennedy Airport are the way to demonstrate that Concorde takeoff noise violates the posted limits for all aircraft. We also have in mind French officials like JeanMichel Fourtanier, vice chairman of a proConcorde committee, who responded to criticism of the supersonic AngloFrench plane by charging poor sportsmanship. We did not say anything when American jets at the beginning were losing their motors on the runway and cabin doors were getting loose and falling all over France, he said. At least we had the elegance to pretend to ignore it. So what shall we do with the news that the British Noise Advisory Council found the Concorde considerably noisier than subsonic commercial aircraft? It found the noise spread over a much wider area and said it caused deterioration of the noise climate around London's Heathrow Airport. Having advocated a true test for the Concorde at Kennedy, of brief duration and against the same standards held forth for other planes, and in the spirit of Lafayette, we choose to be elegant on this round and will pretend to ignore it.

title: Murders by Strangers Drop in New York
description: The number of people murdered by strangers declined in New York City last year for the first time in three years, a Police Department study has found.

title: Gregory In Swan Lake
description: TWO OF AMERICA'S greatest institutions in the performing arts got together on Monday night in what may not be precisely a shotgun wedding, but certainly hopes to be a marriage of convenience. The institutions are the Metropolitan Opera House and American Ballet Theater.

title: Chemical Companies' Sales Up
description: Chemical companies reporting firstquarter results yesterday all showed sales gains, but while the Dow Chemical Company posted a 7.4 percent profit increase and the Inmont Corporation had record preshare earnings, the Monsanto Company reported a 5.7 percent decline.

title: Bhutto's Choice: Resign or Resist
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, April 18  At a news conference here yesterday, Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto was asked, as he has been asked so often lately, whether he would consider resigning from office, as the political opposition is demanding. Why should I consider to resign? he shot back in exasperation. I am legally, politically, morally Prime Minister of Pakistan. The people are with me. If the hardpressed people of this impoverished land are indeed with him, then why have thousands of them taken to the streets during the last six weeks in violent clashes that have claimed 150 lives?

title: Ralph Nardella Sr., 80, Founder Of Foreign Language Station WOV
description: Ralph Nardella Sr., founder of radio station WOV, which pioneered in Italianlanguage broadcasting in New York City in the early 1930's. died Monday while visiting in Hallandale, Fla. He lived in Yonkers and was 80 years old.

title: West German Star Is Slated To Join Cosmos Next Month
description: Franz Beckenbauer, the heralded captain of the West German national team that won the World Cup in 1974, has agreed to play for the Cosmos, according to reliable sources.

title: Music: Empire Quintet Brass With Gusto
description: IT TARES REAL BRASS to put on a chambermusic concert without strings, percussion or wood winds and expect a wide public to be interested in it. But the Empire Brass Quintet, one of the youngest and best groups of this brazen type, did just that at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night. The quintet, which is in residence at Boston University, gave the concert as cowinner of last year's Naumburg Chamber Music Award. You have not often heard an ensemble that played with more gusto than this one.

title: The Standings
description: Wednesday, April 20, 1977

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: ABC Sports Names Ring Inquiry Head
description: Scrutiny of the suspended United States Boxing Championships intensified yesterday as ABC Sports appointed the former chief counsel of the Knapp Commission to direct its investigation into the tournament.

title: Press Role Disputed at Meeting
description: FLORENCE, Italy, April 19 (UPI)Delegates to a United Nations press colloquium agreed today that an information gap existed between thirdworld and industrialized nations but they differed, in sometimes heated debate, on how to close that gap.

title: ALFRED ELLER
description: Alfred Eller, a retired textile industry executive, died yesterday at John F. Kennedy Hospital, Atlantis, Fla. He was 81 years old, and lived in retirement in Atlantis for 14 sears.

title: Ruthven of Braves Wins Third in Row
description: Dick Ruthven, a righthander for the Atlanta Braves who turned in a 1417 record a year ago, gained his third straight victory of the season last night, beating the San Diego Padres, 41, with a fivehit performance in Atlanta Stadium.

title: Get Immunized Campaign Is Off to Audible Start
description: Sixyearold Theresa Bernard had no idea what the word immunization meant, but she knew perfectly well what a clown was, and that there was going to be one yesterday morning in the auditorium at the Lower Manhattan Health Center. The clown, said Theresa, was the reason she was there.

title: CONSTITUTION NO BAR TO SCHOOL SPANKING, HIGH COURT RULES
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that the spanking of schoolchildren, no matter how severe, by teachers or other school officials does not violate the Constitution's Eighth Amendment ban against cruel and unusual punishment.

title: Carter Signs Earthquake Aid Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (Reuters)President Carter today signed legislation authorizing $20 million in relief assistance for victims of a devastating earthquake in Rumania in March. The actual funds are to be appropriated in separate legislation.

title: World News Briefs
description: STRASBOURG, France, April 19 (AP)The Attorney General of Ireland, Declan Costello, urged the European Court of Human Rights today to compel the British Government to institute legal proceedings against members of British security forces accused of brutality in Northern Ireland.

title: 85YearOld ExLongshoreman Apparently Strangled in Bronx
description: An 85yearold retired longshoreman who had apparently been strangled was found bound and gagged yesterday in closet in his apartment at 2090 Walton Avenue in the Bronx.

title: Theater: 24 Weill Melodies
description: KNICKERBOCKER Holiday, the Kurt WeillMaxwell Anderson musical that was revived last night as the second installment in Broadway in Concert at Town Hall, is, of course, the September Song show. That song, with its poignant words and music, its dusky refrain about incipient loneliness, deserves its eminence.

title: DALEY PROTEGE WINS PRIMARY FOR MAYOR
description: CHICAGO, April 19Acting Mayor Michael A. Bilandic, the choice of this city's, Democratic organization, won today his party's nomination for Mayor, beating five independent challengers.

title: Mondale and O'Neill Rebuke Ford For His Early Criticism of Carter
description: WASHINGTON, April 19With President Carter looking on, Vice President Mondale said today that former President Gerald R. Ford had departed from traditional behavior with his early criticism of the Carter Administration.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Allegro and Minuet for 2 Flutes, Beethoven; Nuages, Debussy; Ah! vous diraije maman, Adam; The Noonday Witch, Dvorak; Nocturne, Scriabin; Rumanian Dances, Bartok.

title: Los Angeles Reply on Energy: Usual Congestion and Delays
description: LOS ANGELES, April 19It was just another day on this city's freeways. By 6:45 AM., the Santa Monica, the Santa Ana, the San Diego, the Ventura and the other freeways had become as congealed as a clotted artery. And the spotters in radiostation helicopters were warning drivers to expect the usual congestion and delays.

title: About Real Estate
description: Fastfood chains are beginning to cater to urban neighborhoods by varying their architectural fare.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Fortyone persons were indicted in conncetion with an operation importing $3 million to $4 million worth of heroin a year from Mexico for sale in Ocean and Monmouth Countiesn United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein ainnounced yesterday. Nineteen persons were arrested in raids before dawn yesterday by state and Federal agents, Mr. Goldstein said.

title: Oil Fleet Captains Shape Up for Alaskan Waters
description: VALDEZ, Alaska, April 19  Top United States sea captains from eight major oil and shipping companies, some of them sailors for more than 40 years, are bunking four to a cabin on the supertanker Arco Fairbanks in waters off southern Alaska cramming for exams.

title: Citicorp, Chase Operating Nets Increase Modestly in the Quarter
description: New York's two largest banking organizations, Citicorp and the Chase Manhattan Corporation, reported at their annual meetings yesterday that firstquarter results were little changed from the cornparable 1976 period.

title: 69 OF 79 CONVICTED IN BUILDINGS INQUIRY
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan reported yesterday that 69 of 79 persons indicted in the borough in 1975 following an investigation of corruption in the city's Department of Buildings had been convicted.

title: Living Abroad: Singaporethe Clack of Chopsticks
description: SINGAPORE SINGAPORE has always suffered from one form or another of an identity crisis that only seems oe be growing more acute with the passing years and its rising wealth.

title: That WonTon Soup Headache
description: The chest tightens. A numbness creeps up the back. A headache, and sometimes vomiting, follows. And maybe upper abdominal discomfort as well.

title: Arts Endowment Issues Booklet
description: The National Endowment for the Arts has published its latest edition of Creative America: Arts & the Pursuit of Happiness, a 32page booklet written for the general public interested in the arts.

title: Social Notes From the Backstretch
description: Jack Gayer came up from the South with nine of Greentree Stable's horses yesterday morning, so Seattle Slew, who had been a house guest in the Greentree barn at Belmont, moved to more permanent quarters across the stable area. An hour later, the unbeaten favorite for Saturday's Wood Memorial, and for the Kentucky Derby two weeks later, was on the walking ring getting accustomed to his new surroundings. He seemed entirely at home in a threehorse parade plodding along a sandy path, stopping politely when one of the others stopped, resuming his walk when the others did. As usual, the full Cast was presentKaren and Mickey Taylor, who own the colt; Billy Turner, who trains him; Dr. Jim Hill, the veterinarian who recommended his purchase; Chester Taylor, who watches him; Mike Kennedy, who gallops him; John Polston, who grooms him.

title: Havana Wants Tourists, but Is in No Mood to Rhumba
description: HAVANA  On the Malecn the American Embassy still stands, a sunbleached fortress shuttered against the inshore wind. Farther down the seaside boulevard is the tarnished monument to the 298 sailors of the Maine, facing the Straits of Florida and the azure passage of the Gulf Stream.

title: Nixon Offer to Brief Carter Is Reported
description: WASHINGTON. April 19 (Reuters)Former President Richard M. Nixon has offered to brief President Carter personally on matters of foreign policy but Mr. Carter has no plans to accept. the White House said today.

title: Careers
description: Some of the most widely held assumptions about the relationship between college education and job satisfaction have been brought into question by a new national study completed by the College Placement Council.

title: France Plans $2.4 Billion in Aid To Ease Crisis in Steel Industry
description: PARIS, April 19The French Government moved today to soften the economic and political effects of the growing crisis in the country's steel industry.

title: Postal Service Has Surplus for Year
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 19 (AP)The Postal service has finished a full year with a financial surplus for the first time in recent history, Postmaster General Benjamin F. Bailar announced today.

title: CoalCarrying Railroads Advance As Dow Drops for 2d Day by 3.99
description: The coalcarrying railroads, regarded as major beneficiaries of President Carter's energy program, stood out as the stock market's strongest sector yesterday as most other issues continued to retreat.

title: Pizza Pizazz In the Kitchen
description: Today's housewares market is almost absurdly flooded with gimmicky items of highly questionable value except for people with limited taste and energy.

title: Street Theater's Appeal as Big as All Outdoors
description: New Yorkers looking for a lingering sign of spring have only to wander through the Central Park Zoo on a balmy Saturday or to sit on the steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where mimes, clowns, a stray magician or two and countless jugglers and musicians do their turns.

title: Havana Wants Tourists, but Is in No Mood to Rhumba
description: HAVANA  On the Malecn the American Embassy still stands, a sunbleached fortress shuttered against the inshore wind. Farther down the seaside boulevard is the tarnished monument to the 298 sailors of the Maine, facing the Straits of Florida and the azure passage of the Gulf Stream.

title: Lynne Stuart's Sunshine
description: You've got to make your own sunshine wasp the song that Lyme Stuart used as the theme of her program at the Ballroom on Monday evening. She opened with it and she dosed with it. And in between she spread sunshine with a kind of determination that was reminiscent of Shirley Temple, arms akimbo, delivering her perpetual chinup lectures.

title: Carter's First Big Crunch
description: PARISPresident Carter has addressed himself admirably to the greatest longrange problem of the United States and the rest of the industrialized world. If hi succeeds in gaining national and international support for his energy program he will have shown himself able to act in the grandly effective manner of another Democratic leader, Franklin D. Roosevelt. But the road remains long, twisting and studded with pitfalls.

title: Home for Battered Women Facing Uncertain Future in Hackensack
description: HACKENSACK, April 19The future of a temporary shelter for women who have left their husbands because of beatings was thrown into doubt today when the city obtained a temporary restraining order against the refuge and issued three summonses to the owner.

title: Carter's Selling of His Energy Plan Expected to Accentuate the Positive
description: WASHINGTON, April 19President Carter, in trying to sell the sweeping energy program he will present to Congress tomorrow, will probably emphasize that the measures he Is proposing will not seriously harm the bank accounts or the life styles of most private citizens, White House sources said today.

title: Carter Studies Environment Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 19A program to deal with nuclear wastes, a moratorium on strip mining of prime farmland and a Government office to regulate development of the outer continental shelf are among the proposals suggested to President Carter for his forthcoming environmental message.

title: Notes on People
description: WEARING only a nightgown in the 44degree night air, Sophia Loren huddled with her two sons and neighbors for more than two hours early yesterday on the roof of her duplex penthouse in Paris before being rescued by firemen. Awakened by smoke from a fire that broke out in the lower apartment of Jacques Dorfman, a French producer, Miss Loren grabbed her sleeping sons, Carlo Ponti Jr., 8 years old and Eduardo, 4, and ran to the roof. Miss Loren's husband, Carlo Ponti, was out of town. After the smoke had cleared. Miss Loren returned to her apartment, which includes a swimming pool, and found it undamaged.

title: Foreman Rehires Sadler As Pilot, Drops Clancy
description: HAYWARD, Calif., April 19 (UPI)George Foreman, the former champion who lost a shot at the heavyweight title last month when he was beaten by Jimmy Young, rehired Dick Sadler as his manager today in his quest to move back into the heavyweight picture.

title: Dr. DeMarco, at a License Hearing, Disputes F.D.A. Study on His Drug
description: NEWARK, April 19Dr. Peter T. DeMarco testified today at a hearing by the State Board of Medical Examiners on whether his license should be revoked that years of his own experimentation prove his patented drug did not cause cancer.

title: Seoul Rounding Up Political Foes In Wake of Visit by U.S. Officials
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 19The Government of President Park Chung Hee has begun a nationwide police roundup of political opponents in recent days as South Korea experiences one of the most politically active periods in recent years.

title: CONSTITUTIONNOBAR TO SCHOOL SPANKING, HIGH COURT RULES
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that the spanking of schoolchildren, no matter how severe, by teachers or other school officials does not violate the Constitution's Eighth Amendment ban against cruel and unusual punishment.

title: BIGGEST RISE POSTED IN PERSONAL INCOMES IN NEARLY TWO YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP)Americans' personal income in March registered the sharpest monthly rise in nearly two years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What is an omelet norvegienne, which I have seen on menus in France?

title: Murders by Strangers Drop in New York
description: The number of people murdered by stranger declined in New York City last year for the first time in three years, a Police Department study has found.

title: Byrne, Announcing His Candidacy, Stresses Tax as the EIection Issue
description: TRENTON, April 19Pledging to stand up and take the heat, Governor Byrne declared his candidacy for a second term today.

title: Salvador Minister Reported Kidnapped
description: SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, April 19 (AP)Foreign Minister Mauricio Borgonovo Pohl was kidnaped today by a leftist group that threatened to kill him unless the Government freed 36 political prisoners, sources said.

title: PRICES IN RETREAT FROM RECENT RALLY
description: The credit markets yesterday had second thoughts about last week's celebration of the death of the tax rebate. Bond prices declined as traders wondered whether the rally had not been overdone, and money market analysts once again began to emphasize the general view that interest rates are headed higher this year. Some bond men asserted that President Carter's energy conservation program calling for higher taxes and higher prices was inflationary and bad for fixedincome investments.

title: Photo Sale for Veterans
description: An auction of photographs that includes the work of some of the most famous contemporary photographersHenri CartierBresson. Robert Capa, Alfred Eisenstaedt, Elliott Erwitt, Ernst Haas, Andre Kertesz and Barbara Morgan, among otherswill be held tomorrow evening as a benefit for Volunteer Service Photographers Inc., a nonprofit organization that sponsors rehabilitation projects in veterans' hospitals, homes for the elderly and other institutions.

title: Tennis
description: AT CHARLOTTE, N.C. $100,000 W.C.T.

title: PrisonRelease Escapes Are Decried
description: Several hundred inmates are escaping each year from state penal institutions simply by walking away from the prisonrelease program, according to the New York State Parole Officers Association.

title: Business Records
description: Tuesday, April 19, 1977

title: Mr. Carter's Certain Trumpet
description: That havoc, described in Paul Erdman's bestselling novel of petrodollar intrigue, is, of course, imaginary. But something approaching it is imaginable. The muscle and comfort of the United States depend on energyand, increasingly, on foreign oil. Yet, the world's oil supply is getting scarcer all the time. The perils may not cause a crash by 1979 but they are already alarmingly evident.

title: McEnroe Upsets Pasarell
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, April 19 (AP)John McEnroe, the country's secondranking junior from New York, upset Charlie Pasarell of Puerto Rico, 63, 61, in the first round of the $100,000 Virginia Beach tennis tournament today.

title: Light Amex Fine Spurs S.E.C. Suit Against Brokers
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, reacting to what it regarded as a series of light disciplinary steps taken by the American Stock Exchange against member brokers, yesterday charged nine Amex brokers with manipulation and fraud.
