title: 2 Thompson Officers Plan Early Retirement
description: Edward B. Wilson 2d, chairman, and John A. P. Treasure, vice chairman of the J. Walter Thompson Company, are taking early retirement at the end of the year. Actually, Ted Wilson planned to retire at 55 years of age and he's 56. Mr. Treasure is 52. Mandatory executive retirement at the company is 60.

title: U.N. Report Criticizes Companies Operating in SouthWest Africa
description: UNITED. NATIONS, N.Y., April 19 (Reuters)A United Nations report said today that foreign companies operating in SouthWest Africa were part of a system that discriminated against black workers, paid them low wages and enforced deplorable conditions.

title: JUSTICES DEADLOCK ON SEX SEGREGATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The Supreme Court announced today that it had deadlocked, 4 to 4, on a case from Philadelphia that raised the question whether a city's public school system may have one college preparatory school solely for boys and one solely for girls.

title: College Results
description: MEN'S BASEBALL

title: Yankees Iron Some Things Out, Then Drop Fifth in a Row, 83
description: First the manager met with the owner.

title: Carter Energy Problem Held Graver Than Predecessors'
description: WASHINGTON. April 19When President Carter presents his energy policy to the nation tomorrow night, he will be facing more serious problems than those confronted by his predecessors, according to energy experts.

title: SchoolAge Pregnancy Problems Reach Crisis Stage, Officials Say
description: PARAMUS, April 19The problem of pregnant school age children has reached crisis proportions, health and school officials said today.

title: Albany Assembly Passes Measure Requiring Licenses And Annual Inspections of SoCalled Medicaid Mills
description: ALBANY, April 19A bill that would require the annual licensing and inspection of socalled Medicaid mills passed the New York State Assembly overwhelmingly today. Its sponsor predicted it could save more than 350 million a year by reducing fraud and abuse in the Medicaid program.

title: Lawyers Push for NoFault Repeal
description: ALBANY, April 19The organization representing the state's trial lawyers, who have lost potential income from automobileaccident victims as a result of the state's nofault insurance law, opened a campaign here today to get the Legislature to repeal the fouryearold law.

title: CAREY URGES BANKS TO INVEST IN HOUSING
description: Governor Carey called on the state's savings banks yesterday to help the state's economy by investing more heavily in residential mortgages. He warned that if they did not, he would try next year to rescind a mortgage rate increase the banks hope to get this year.

title: All About: Dogs and Diet
description: THERE he is, looking at you with those moist brown eyes. He's wellbehaved so he doesn't made a sound. He just looks. You take another forkful, but it doesn't taste so good. Another swallow and you're filled with guilt. All right, you think, you'll give him just one bite. And another . . . and another.

title: Technology
description: A littlenoticed and largely secret technology for enriching uranium using the gas centrifuge is to be given a major role in supplying fuel for United States and foreign nuclear power plants.

title: Assad Ends 2 Days of Consultations in Moscow on the Mideast
description: MOSCOW, April 19 (Reuters)Syria's President, Hafez alAssail, and Soviet leaders ended two days of talks on the Middle East today in advance of separate consultations with the United States.

title: MEETING SCHEDULED ON CURBING OF SMUT
description: The New York City Planning Commission has scheduled a hearing for May 4 on a proposal to renew a moratorium on socalled massage parlors that expired last April 8 after running for 15 months. The Mayor's office has received complaints that two new massage parlors have opened, at 322 East 14th Street and at 644 Greenwich Street, since the ban expired.

title: Major League Scores
description: EBando, Sanguilien. DPMilwaukee 1. Oakland 1. LOBMilwaukee 6, Oakland 10 2BWGross, Page, Moore, Lezcano, Quiox. 3BDThomas. HRCooper (2). Wiliams (2). McKinney (2). SBMoney. Lintz. North, Mallory, MAlexender. SFCooper.

title: Amex Taking a New Look At Disciplinary Measures
description: The American Stock Exchange, stunned by Government fraud charges against nine Amex brokers, is taking a fresh look at its disciplinary procedures to determine whether to strengthen the role of its board of governors, Wall Street sources disclosed today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Board of Education voted unanimously last night to prohibit school officials from hiring, employing or supervising near relatives. The policy, aimed primarily at custodians but applying to all employees, takes effect immediately in respect to future employment. It will require the transfer of scores of present employees under procedures to be drawn up by the School Chancellor.

title: U.S. AND BRITAIN PLAN NEW RHODESIA TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 20The United States and Britain, in a new move to cosponsor a conference on Rhodesia, are seeking to shape a constitution guaranteeing an immediate transfer of power to the black majority as well as assurances of financial aid to the whites, according to diplomatic sources.

title: Solar by the Book
description: Bruce Anderson begins the introduction to his book, The Solar Home Book, with a quote from Socrates about how a house should be designed and sited:  . . . build the south side loftier to get the winter sun and the north side lower to keep out the cold winds. Socrates was advocating building a house to work in concert with nature. Although that kind of logic guided early home builders, it has been totally disregarded in the present century. It's the main reason that the American household is such a voracious consumer of energy today.

title: Samuel H. Schwartz Leaving Theater Post
description: Samuel H. Schwartz will retire as chief operating officer of Jujamcym Theaters, owner of the St. James and Martin Beck theaters, on April 30 Mr. Schwartz, who will be 70 years old in September, will continue his association with Jujamcym with certain of its theatrical investments, according to a spokesman.

title: Marion Gering, StageFilm Director
description: Marion Gering, a film and stage producer and director who directed a number of productions in the 1920's and 1930's with such stars as Bette Davis, Tallulah Bankhead, Sylvia Sidney, Gary Cooper and Cary Grant, died Tuesday evening at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: Jazz: Rare Nagaswaram
description: Charlie Mariano, one of the saxophone stars of Stan Kenton's orchestra in the 50's who has been living in Europe for the last six years, is making one of his infrequent visits to this country, playing with Mike Nock's trio at Sweet Basil, Seventh Avenue near Bleecker Street, through Saturday.

title: Carter's Proposed Halt to Russell Dam Project Irks Some Georgians
description: ELBERTON, Ga., April 19The thing that angers Emerson Turner more than anything else is the memory of that day in 1972 when Gov. Jimmy Carter gave Georgia's approval to the $276 million Federal project to build a hydroelectric dam across the Savannah River, just east of here.

title: Market Place
description: In the old days, when Wall Street brokerage commissions were fixed, there was considerably more money available for research than there is in today's negotiatedrate environment.

title: American Family: At the Crossroads
description: THE American family raising young children in 1977 is at a turning point in the way it regards the parentchild relationship.

title: Makers of Children's Nightwear Ask Delay in Consumers' Refunds
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI)A group representing manufacturers of children's nightwear treated with Tris, the banned flame retardant, asked a Federal court today to halt $200 million in consumer refunds until the Government better defines who must pay the bill.

title: 44Caliber Death Bullets Called an Outside Purchase
description: Police ballistics experts have concluded that the bullets used in the .44caliber killer case were almost certainly purchased outside New York.

title: Tax Credit Plan Makes Sun Power Bargain at Home
description: ENERGY conservation went on prime time with President Carter's energy message yesterday. No one needed to be reminded of the grim reality of ever increasing fuel prices. Last winter, many homeowners' fuel bills soared higher than their mortgage payments. With a national policy of consuming lessadded to an individual desire to pay lesshomeowners are wondering what they can do to save energy at home right now.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Is Expected to Take Up Issue of F16 Purchase by Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 20The United States Congress will soon discuss whether to sell F16 fighters and other advanced weapons to Taiwan, according to Representative Lester Wolff, chairman of the House subcomittee on East Asia and Pacific affairs, who is leading a delegation reviewing United States security interests in the area

title: People in Sports
description: For Al Oerter, the fourtime Olympic gold medalist, the 52d annual Kansas Relays starting tonight in Lawrence, Kan.. will be a sort of homecoming. The former University of Kansas standout, who won Olympic gold medals in 1956, 1960, 1964 and 1968, will be competing in the event named after himthe Al Oerter Discus Throw. It's the first major track meet in eight years for the 40yearold Oerter, who announced his comeback last June and his intention to begin training for the 1980 Olympics in Moscow.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)Army officials, concerned about the apparent lack of interest in President Carter's program to upgrade lessthanhonorable military discharges from the Vietnam period. are starting an advertising campaign to spur the response.

title: Zaire Invasion Halts the Return Of Belgian Role
description: BRUSSELS, April 20The invasion of the copperrich province of Shaba in southern Zaire has temporarily halted an unusual and significant reconciliation.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTONThe term genetic engineering seems straight out of science fiction, but currently it is a subject of real and heated debate among scientists, environmentalists and some of the leaders of the Congress.

title: Gene Wilder  The World's Greatest Lover?
description: HOLLYWOOD GENE WILDER is wearing the Sears, Roebuck catalogue special for 1927onepiece summer underwear with a drop seat. Wilder has spent the day swimming back and forth in a flooded hotel room on 20th CenturyFox's Stage 6; and the soggy underwear clings almost indecently to his groin.

title: Thousands of Harlem Drug Runners, 9 to 16, Find the Rewards Are High, the Risks Low
It's Close but No Cigar for Tiant as Tigers Conquer Red Sox, 32
description: Luis Tiant, Boston's venerable pitching citizen, made his 1977 Fenway Park debut last night. It was not a happy occasion for the unflappable senor.

title: Major Conservative In Canada Defects To Trudeau Party
description: OTTAWA, April 20The Canadian Government's conservative opposition lost a key figure today when Jack Horner, a member of Parliament known for his rightwing views, left the Progressive Conservative Party to join the governing Liberals.

title: Potential ImpactMore Jobs and Inflation'
description: What effect would President Carter's national energy pian, assuming it is adopted, have on the American economy?

title: Foreign Exchange
description: Wednesday, April 20, 1977

title: If the Reds Helped Govern France
description: PARISIt is no longer hypothetical speculation but rather a reasonable forecast to say that the next French legislative elections, barring unforeseen developments, will result in the victory of the leftwing parties, essentially Communist and Socialist, united on the basis of a Joint Charter for a new government.

title: Sound
description: OF ALL THE CONTROLS on stereo receiver or amplifier, the one marked loudness or loudness compensation is beyond all doubt the most misunderstood. Yet when it is knowledgeably used, it can contribute greatly to the enjoyment of music under typical homelistening conditions.

title: Yankees Snap Out of Slump and Win, 75; Mets Beaten, 42, by Rasmussen of Cards
description: ST. LOUIS. April 20Eric Rasmussen of the St. Louis Cardinals, who spent the winter changing his first name from Harry, tamed the New York Nets, 42, today in a businessmen's special.

title: Dance: Dull Swan Lake
description: IF THERE IS ANY DANCER natural to the role of the Swan Queen in Swan Lake, it is Martine van Hamel, and on Tuesday night she proved true to excellent form in American Ballet Theater's staging of the classic at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: TIME TO DRAW LINE
description: WASHINGTON, April 20Saying the time has come to draw the line on unfettered use of energy, President Carter proposed tonight a national energy policy designed to increase the cost of fuels, penalize waste and bring important changes in industrial habits and in some of the ways Americans live.

title: 2 CAPTIVES DISPLAYED BY ZAIRE IN STADIUM
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 20  Two prisoners taken by Zairian troops in the south were displayed here today in a stadium before 60,000 people. The crowd cheered President Mobutu Sese Seko and called for the death of the captives.

title: 76ers Trounce Celtics to Tie Series at 11
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 20  The Philadelphia 76ers turned on the offense they are noted for tonight, added a smattering of defense they are not noted for and defeated the Boston Celtics, 113101, before a capacity crowd of 18,276 at the Spectrum.

title: Soybean Oil Futures Rise Limit on Chicago Board; Brazilian Cutoff Is Cited
description: CHICAGO, April 20 (AP)Soybean oil futures advanced the 100point limit on the Chicago Board of Trade today and lent strength to old crop soybeans, which registered a 25cent gain.

title: Film: Annie Hall, Allen at His Best
Radio
description: Music

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, April 20Officials of the state's municipalities said today that they strongly opposed legislation that would permit police officers, firemen and other government employees who exercise police powers to retire at halfpay after 20 years of service.

title: Oyster Creek Nuclear Plant, Recently Called a Risk, Is Now Ruled Safe by U.S. Standards
description: TRENTON, April 20The State Department of Environmental Protection reported today that the Oyster Creek nuclear power plan, which six months ago was described as a highrisk operation, is now considered safe by standards determined by the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: 9,600 Bottles of Liquor Dumped
description: WELCH, W. Va., April 20 (UPI)Dealers in this flood damaged city poured about 9,600 bottles of liquor down the drain today after health officials said that the unbroken bottles might have been contaminated by flood waters two weeks ago. The officials said that we cannot run the risk of letting people purchase this liquor and become sick.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 21, 1977

title: Home Beat
description: GOOD NEWS for advocates of doctrinaire dcor. The launching of Angelo Donghia's line of furniture designed for Kroehler, the mass manufacturer, will go a long way toward stamping out customer creativity, taste diversity, uncontrolled color schemes and any taste that's not the taste of Angelo Donghia.

title: NICK KOVALCHICK
description: Nick Kovalchick, founder and owner of the Koyalchick Salvage Company, Indiana, Pa., cited by President Franklin D. Roosevelt for its World War II metal contributions for the defense effort, died yesterday in the Indiana (Pa.) Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: HERO'S FUNERAL GIVEN TO DROWNED FIREMAN
description: At the call of Detail, salute, 2,500 whitegloved hands smartly touched caps in front of a tiny firehouse in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, as firemen from throughout the area joined city officials at funeral services for Fire Lieut. Charles Hunt Jr., who fell into creek and drowned last Friday at the scene of a fire on Staten Island.

title: Coptic Leader Visits Carter
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)President Carter met today with Pope Shenuda III, president of the Holy See of St. Mark of Egypt, and praised him for expanding the Coptic Church. The Pope told the President that his faith had 16 churches in the United States and that two more were being built, one on Long Island, N.Y., and the other in East Brunswick, N.J. He also said the faith had about seven million adherents in Egypt.

title: The New Pilot for CBS
description: Earlier this year, a short time after John David Backe had been appointed president of CBS Inc., the new man at Black Rock was talking to a group of CBS broadcast people, introducing himself and at the same time trying to buck them ?? their long winter of poor television ratings. He told them of the time in 1954 when he was taking flight training near a Missouri cotton field, earning his wings in old T6 propeller planes, and how, near the end of his training cycle, he was told that he had been appointed to jet school.

title: Israelis Mourn War Dead, Then Hail Independence
description: JERUSALEM, April 20At 11 o'clock this morning, the dreadful whine of air raid sirens permeated every cranny of Israel and this voluble nation of 3.5 million people and 3.5 million opinions fell silent.

title: Horse Destroyed, 5 Hurt In a Fire at Hawthorne
description: CHICAGO, April 20 (AP)  Pick's Dream, a thoroughbred trying to escape a small fire at Hawthorne Race Course last night, tore his shoulder and was destroyed. Five other horses were injured.

title: U.S. Securities Market Declines For 3d Day on Doubts Over Fed
description: The Government securities market declined for the third straight day yesterday as traders noted the strong economic statistics published this week and wondered whether the Federal Reserve might not be about to nudge interest rates to higher levels. It's ueen a wild and woolly one, a Treasury bond dealer remarked. There is quite a bit of fear in the Street that the Fed is on the verge of tightening.

title: Carey Moves to Cut NoFault Costs
description: ALBANY, April 20 Governor Carey today introduced a new nofault automobile insurance bill that his Superintendent of Insurance said would, if adopted, eliminate 90 to 95 percent of accidentrelated suits and cut the cost of premiums by onethird within the next several years.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Leonard Silk analyzes the potential impact of the Carter energy plan on the United States. Shortterm implications could include some measure of inflation as well as positive effects, observers say. Page B9.

title: Variations on a Modern Theme
description: HIGH POINT. N.C. ANYONE WHO has shopped for furniture lately, especially here at the Southern Furniture Market, where more designs are shown than anywhere else in the world knows that modern has finally arrived.

title: F.D.A. Bureaucracy Scored in Study
description: WASHINGTON, April 20A special advisory panel's twoyear investigation into internal operations of the Food and Drug Administration concluded in a report made public today that some branches of the beleaguered agency were bureaucratic jungles of backbiting and infighting that hamper pharmaceutical regulation.

title: European Gold Price Off For Third Straight Day; Dollar Finishes Mixed
description: LONDON, April 20(AP)The price of gold dipped for the third straight day today, losing nearly 52 an ounce in London and $1 in Zurich, Europe's two major markets.

title: British Merchant Invades American Furniture Market
description: HIGH POINT, N.C. TERENCE CONRAN, chairman of the board of England's stupendously successful Habitat stores, was relishing the attention. After 13 years of success in London, he said, I can go around the furniture exposition there and no one will take the slightest notice of mebut here their noses are twitching already. That's what I love about the States.

title: SCIENTISTS SEEK DATA ON CAUSES OF ICE AGE
description: Using heavy hydrogen in ancient wood as an indicator of past climate, scientists at the California Institute of Technology have concluded that at the height of the last ice age, icefree areas on the North American hinterland were warmer in winter than they are today.

title: At Your Service: A Home For the Bicycle
description: THE BICYCLE, that natty little twist of steel and rubber, guarantees freedom to get up and go  inexpensively  and a storage problem.

title: Conviction on Conspiracy Of Rabbi Is Overturned In CheckCashing Case
description: The United StatesCourt of Appeals for the Second Circuit yesterday overturned the conspiracy conviction of a Queens County rabbi for what the Government said was a checkcashing scheme.

title: Transcript of Speech by Carter on Energy Program at Joint Session of Congress
description: Mr. President, Mr. Speaker, Members of the Congress, and distinguished guests:

title: Minnesota Medical Association Ordered to End Fee Fixing Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission ordered a state medical society today to drop a fee schedule system that it said had the effect of fixing the prices doctors charge patients.

title: The Standings
description: Thursday, April 21, 1977

title: The Upwardly Mobile Adventurers
description: CHILDREN, it seems, were born to climb. Alma Heaton, an associate professor of recreation at Brigham Young University, says that all he has to do is go to a party, hang a rope from a tree, and there will be a dozen kids trying to climb on itthe body cries out for something to hang on.

title: Foes of Auto Tag Messages Gain
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)The Supreme Court ruled today that an automobile owner is not required to display ideological messages such as Live Free or Die that states put on auto license plates.

title: Mr. Bhutto's Last Stand?
description: That was a prom, answer that Pakistan's Prime Minister, Zulfikar All Bhutto, gave at a news conference the other day when asked whether he would consider resigning: Why should I consider to resign? I am legally, politically, morally Prime Minister of Pakistan. The people are with me.

title: Olive Branch Given By Chicago's Mayor To Rival in Primary
description: CHICAGO, April 20After narrowly averting a runoff in yesterday's Democratic primary, Acting Mayor Michael A. Bilandic, the winner by 50.4 percent, moved to heal the wounds between him and Alderman Roman C. Pucinski, who finished second with a suprising 32 percent of the vote.

title: Personal Beauty
description: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y. THE WHITE clapboard house, with its ginger bread gable and dark red shutters, is probably the most delightfulsmelling house for miles around. The sign on the porch tells why: the building houses the company, Weleda, which concocts and sells herb teas and toiletries made from fascinating ingredients such as calendula (marigold), iris root and birch leaves. The house 30 South Main Street in Spring Valley is said to date back to the late 19th century and its original inhabitants undoubtedly used arnica on their bruises, drank camomile tea and patted rose water on their faces.

title: Dr. Beryl Loftman Bailey, 57, Professor of English at Hunter
description: Dr. Beryl Loftman Bailey, a professor of English and a former chairman of the department of black and Puerto Rican studies at Hunter College, died Monday in Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. She was 57 years old and lived at 10 Pilling Street, Brooklyn.

title: Xerox Earnings Increase by 11.7% in the First Quarter
description: Despite heavy price competition from rival makers of office copiers, the Xerox Corporation registered an 11.7 percent earnings gain in the first quarter on a 15 percent increase in revenues, it was announced yesterday.

title: Stage: A Macbeth Swift to the Point
description: CLEVELAND WE TEND TO TALK as if the professional resident theater across the United States were a comparatively recent invention like the jet engine or equal rights. And, by and large, it is. Yet there are exceptions. Perhaps the most notable is the Cleveland Play House, which was founded in 1915 and is now in its 61st season. Remarkably enough, during that period it has had only three directors; the third, now in charge being Russell Oberlin.

title: Columbia's Fromm Swings Hot Racquet
description: He has muscle on his serve and forehand, but what elevates him particularly is his tennis senseknowing how to use the court and make the right shot.

title: Rangers 5, Mariners 2
description: AT SEATTLE  Nelson Briles and Adrian Devine combined on a fourhit pitching effort and Dave May and Toby Harrah hit homers in the Texas victory. May cracked a tworun shot in the third inning, and Harrah collected his fourth home run of the season in the fifth. Briles, 33 years old, pitched nohit ball until Juan Bernhardt hit a homer with two out in the fifth. Devine relieved in the seventh and preserved the triumph.

title: Design Notebook
description: THE COURTHOUSE is almost always the grandest public building in an American town, be it a small hamlet or a goodsized city. Commercial buildings may have told us what we were, but courthouses told us what we aspired to: a certain sense of civic order, garbed in the architectural vestments of history.

title: Bridge:
description: A declarer who is leading equal honors from his hand must remember that some are more equal than others, as George Orwell might have said. The theory is simple: if you want your lefthand opponent to cover, lead high: if you want him to play low, lead low.

title: Royals Tighten Crowd Defense
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. April 20 (AP)The Kansas City Royals, shocked by the rowdyism and violence that marred their first two home games, have beefed up stadium security and banned all liquid containers. Since last Monday night, fans with bottles, cans, jugs, coolers and other containers have been denied admittance unless the containers were left outside.

title: TIME TO DRAW LINE
description: WASHINGTON, April 20Saying the time has come to draw the line on unfettered use of energy, President Carter proposed tonight a national energy policy designed to increase the cost of fuels, penalize waste and bring important changes in industrial habits and in some of the ways Americans live.

title: Film: Animated Evil
description: IF RALPH BAKSHI'S "Fritz the Cat" and "Heavy Traffic" were as explicit as, say, sex and their X ratings, his "Wizards," which arrived in local theaters yesterday avoids that stigma. It offers ample proof once again that Mr. Bakshi has no connection with the sunlit Disney school of animated fantasy. But in concentrating on the distant future and a war between the surviving forces of good and evil in a ravaged world, "Wizards" evolves, at best, as only a mildly interesting mixture of clashing polemics and shoot-'em-up melodrama.Of course, he has fashioned a fable, but one that is as contemporary as Hitler. His "Wizards" are brothers in the persons of Avatar, the leader of the good guys, and Blackwolf, chieftain of the opposing, mutant bad guys, whose techniques of intimidation and attack are literally borrowed from Nazi Germany.Mr. Bakshi's allegory is fairly obvious from the outset, but he and his animators are convincingly professional. They have devised a melange of animation and live footage that gives their feature mystical, slightly scary and, occasionally, comic tones.A couple of frightened elves praying in a Yiddish-Hebrew gibberish is neither relevant nor funny. But Avatar is a bumbling, aged magician, whoshades of Disney!looks a bit like a bearded Grumpy and speaks like Archie Bunker. The film's nubile queen, Elinore, is wispily clad and curvaceous enough to make Snow White blush. And a cadaverous Blackwolf, Avatar's tough, little general, Weehawk, as well as a slew of elves, fairies and a zoo of far-out fauna, are colorful creations."Animation can be used to tell all kinds of stories." Mr. Bakshi said after the arrival of the iconoclastically sexy and hip "Fritz the Cat" and "Heavy Traffic." And, that observation also applied to his ensuing, controversial "Coonskin." With "Wizards" he has ably illustrated his ability to tell another kind of story, but one that merely restates the already all too obvious, dire results of nuclear war and man's inhumanity to man.This film has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") probably because of its violent war scenes.

title: Some Economists Dispute Administration Forecast on Jobs and Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, April 20President Carter's contention that his energy policy would lead to more jobs, more economic growth and only a modest increase in the inflation rate was vigorously disputed by some economists tonight.

title: AntiDefamation League Says Rockaways Klan Plans CrossBurnings
BEAN ASSAILS END OF ANNENBERG PLAN
description: The sudden withdrawal last month of Walter Annenberg's $40 million proposal for a fine arts center at the Metropolitan Museum came under fire yesterday from Mayor Beame and Martin E. Segal, chairman of the city's Commission for Cultural Affars.

title: Paddling Justice
description: The Supreme Court, by a 5to4 majority and a tortuous bit of reasoning, has decided that school children enjoy no constitutional protection against paddling or other corporal punishment, no matter how severe or arbitrary. It ruled in essence that most of the country still favors whacking misbehaving kids, that state laws provide enough safeguards for how it's done, that the schools can be held accountable by community and parents, that teachers should not have to bother with prepaddle hearings and that the kids can always sue if they are hurt too much or by mistake. Each member of the errant majority deserves at least five whacks.

title: Protests Against Pakistan Regime Virtually Paralyze Karachi Port
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, April 20Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto's political opposition today stepped up its campaign to force his resignation with strikes and turbulent protest marches in several parts of the country.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: DETROIT, April 20Roy D. Chapin Jr, chairman of the American Motors Corporation, said yesterday the auto maker was profitable in the JanuaryMarch quarter even though its new car sales were down 28 percent and production was off 38 percent for the period.

title: Wilmer Allison Dies
description: Wilmer Allison, the nation's No. 1 tennis player in 1934 and 1935, died yesterday in Austin, Tex., at the age of 72. An obituary is on Page D21.

title: Backe to Succeed Paley on May 11 as Head of CBS
description: the reins over to Mr. Backe instead of Mr. Taylor.

title: G.M. Signs Accord To Label Its Engines
description: The General Motors Corporation, which has been under attack in several states for putting Chevrolet engines in Oldsmobil, Buick and Pontiac cars, yesterday signed an agreement with the New York State Attorney Genral's office that will require labeling any cars with substitute engines.

title: Economy Advanced at a 5.2% Rate In the First Quarter, Best in a Year
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  Powered mainly by auto sales, the nation's economy grew at an annual rate of 5.2 percent in the first quarter, shrugging off effects of the cold winter to register the best gain in a year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Mr. Warnke's Hit List
description: WASHINGTONBefore the Inauguration, the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency received a demand from Anthony Lake. Mr. Carter's dovish national security helper, for a list of its civil servants and career Foreign Service officers, with information about their careers.

title: 5 Women's Sports at Yale Upgraded to Varsity Status
description: NEW HAVEN, April 20 (AP)Yale University will elevate five women's sports to the varsity level next fall, Yale officials announced today. The move will make the Ivy League school one of the nation's leaders in women's athletic programs.

title: Pop: Betts Reaches Pinnacle
description: DICKEY BETTS brought his new band, Great Southern, into the Bottom Line for a onenight stand Tuesday and proved beyond a shadow of a doubt that he is one of the great rock guitarists.

title: Author Proposes Freedom for Dogs in Offbeat Ways
description: Has your dog mastered the technique of blowing out the candles on his or her birthday cake? If there is a Rover or Lady that can bark boastfully of such proficiency, Carol Benjamin wants to know for her next book. While the author geared her topic to the light and different side of animal training with an outline of 25 ways to Pleasure Your Dog, she also listed many sensible routes to responsible ownership for Dog Fanciers Club's members at a luncheon, yesterday, in the Stetler Hilton.

title: Mulch Advice
description: The soil in large potted plantings will always settle to some degree. A topping layer of organic mulch such as peat or humus helps to compensate a little. Nothing beats leaf mold, if you happen to have a country cousin who can spare some. Leaf mold is rarely sold in garden stores, yet it is the perfect soil conditioner. Used as a mulch layer two or three inches deep. leaf mold or fine peat will not only aid in retaining soil moisturealways a critical factor in pot culturebut as it breaks down, it will add at least some organic matter the soil.

title: 5 Employees of a Plant in Newark Charged With Large Opium Thefts
description: NEWARK. April 20A sixmonth investigation by a Federal grand jury has charged that opium stolen by employees from a chemical processing plant here has been reaching the streets of Newark and New York in quantities large enough for conversion to millions of dollars worth of heroin.

title: Mad Machines On Show
description: A circus of whirling gears, spiraling Archimedes screws, rotating fans, jumping springs, banging hammers, progressively moving ratchets and turning gears is what greets the eye in the current show at the Theo Portnoy Gallery. Accompanying all this madness is a fitting orchestration: chimes, gongs, bell clappers, a fire bell and even the metallic opening notes of Beethoven's Fifth.

title: Order Came From Zaire U.N. Mission
description: ATLANTA, April 20 (AP)A spokesman for CocaCola said today that the deal with the Zairians was set and that all they have to tell us is where to send the canned Coke. The original order, he said, came from Zaire's mission to the United Nations.

title: Landlords Must Pay Interest
description: THOUGH LANDLORDS in New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut are required by law to make annual interest payments on tenants' security deposits, many of them are just not doing so. The official figures are sketchy, but they indicate that renters in those three states are losing out on considerably more than a quarter million dollars a year in unpaid interest.

title: Tiny Gambia Represents One of Africa's Success Stories
description: BANJUL, Gambia, April 16  This microscopic West African nation, with gentle breezes and improbable boundaries, is nothing if not inventively adaptable.

title: Carey Moves to Cut NoFault Costs
description: ALBANY, April 20  Governor Carey today introduced a new nofault automobile insurance bill that his Superintendent of Insurance said would, if adopted, eliminate 90 to 95 percent of accidentrelated suits and cut the cost of premiums by onethird within the next several years.

title: A Better Sweater
description: It isn't often that a fashion makes people smile. Not break into raucous laughterfeel pleasant, mildly glowing, with the amiability of it all.

title: Home Repair Q&A
description: Q: I would like to paint louver shutters that are now finished with a walnut stain. Can you tell me which type of paint would be best to use (latex, oil or lacquer) and how best to apply it?E. P., Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: THEODORE N. EDELBAUM
description: Theodore N. Edelbaum, an aeronautical engineer who was deputy associate director of Charles Stark Draper Laboratory, Inc., Boston, died Saturday at his home in Lynn, Mass. He was 45 years old.

title: Audubon Society in Maine Saves Money With a Headquarters Using Solar Heating
description: FALMOUTH, Me., April 19The conservation of resources is what we've taken as our first lesson, said Erika Morgan, delivering a somewhat conventional message outside the highly unconventional building that serves as state headquarters for the Maine Audubon Society here.

title: PUBLISHERS OFFERED HUGHES DOCUMENTS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 20Papers that may have been stolen from Howard Hughes's archives in 1974 are being offered to publishers in New York as the basis for a book.

title: SPAIN DISMISSES GENERAL TO CURB DISSENT ON REDS
description: MADRID, April 20 (Reuters)A Spanish Army general was dismissed today as Prime Minister Adolfo Surez took steps to curb military dissent over the lifting of a 38year ban on the Communist Party.

title: New York to Spend $7.5 Million, A Cut in Plans, to Spur Economy
description: The 197778 budget that Mayor Beame will reveal tomorrow will allow only $7.5 million for economic development work$2.5 million less than the Mayor pledged to spend on the economic recovery program he announced last December.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 21, 1977

title: FreeForm Jazz From Berlin
description: FOUR EUROPEAN jazz musicians performed at Environ on Monday and Tuesday evenings as part of the Berlin Now series of cultural events that is being presented at various locations around the city. Alex Schlippenbach, SvenAke Johansson, Peter Brtzmann, and Han Bennink have been associated with the Berlinbased Free Music Productions collective for several years now and, unlike most contemporary American jazzmen, they actually play free music, improvising spontaneously without any predetermined structure or direction.

title: Highlights of Energy Program: Taxes, Rebates and Price Rises
description: WASHINGTON, April 20Following are the highlights of President Carter's energy program with references in brackets to the text of a White House fact sheet on pages B10 and B11:

title: Companies List Reports Covering Their Earnings Figures
description: Profits Scoreboard

title: S. E. C. Moves to Curb Abuses Of Rule Exempting a Filing
description: WASHINGTON, April 20The Securities and Exchange Commission moved today to curb numerous apparent abuses of its rule exempting private securities offerings from registration requirements.

title: Panel Urges BreakUp of H.E.W. And Consideration of Education
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)  A Carnegie report suggested today that the Department of Health. Education and Welfare be broken up and that Federal education programs be consolidated.

title: TV: A Winning Sinatra and Friends
description: SOMETIMES, especially with music the direct and uncomplicated appr?? works best. The selfcons?? camera angles and nervous editing of come popmusic formats have quickly become eye irritants. Ocular massages tend to be mere distractions. The music almost demands to be presented without frills.

title: I Started Cutting Dope at 13
description: When she was 15 years old, Janet P. was arrested for selling drugs on the streets of Harlem. At the time, she had $900 and three glassine envelopes of heroin.

title: Carbide Quarterly Falls 19.7% But Sales Climb 11%, for Record
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, the nation's second largest chemical producer, reported yesterday a 20 percent decline in firstquarter earnings, in line with the lower profits so far reported by other chemical producers, including the industry leader, E.I. DuPont deNemours.

title: Pentagon Medical Students Urge Congressmen to Save Their School
description: BETHESDA. Md., April 20The first 32 students at the Pentagon's new medical school are visiting their Congressmen in the hope of keeping the school alive.

title: Cuba Says Lifting Blockade Won't Bring Gush in Trade
description: HAVANA, April 20  Lifting the American embargo against trade with Cuba will not mean an immediate and enormous commerce between the two nations, Fidel Castro and other Cuban officials told American businessmen visiting here.

title: U.F.O. Buffs Want U.S. Help
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, April 20Frustrated by the lack of progress in their research, scientists and other students of the phenomenon of unidentified flying objects are pressing the United States Government to open its files on the subject.

title: New Pollution Reported in Italy
description: SEVESO, Italy, April 20 (AP)Severe new dioxine pollution has been reported south of the sealedoff site of the worst ecological disaster in Italian history, and authorities said today that 19 factories in the area would be closed for checks. The temporary closings mean layoffs for hundreds of workers. Authorities reported that dangerous quantities of the poison were found south of the fencedin and evacuated zone around the Icmesa factory, a Swissowned chemical plant that sent out a poisonous cloud of dioxine last July, killing animals, withering foliage, making many people ill and forcing the evacuation of about 800 residents.

title: Bearne Severs Political Relations With Carey Over Backroom Deals
description: With uncharacteristically tart language. Mayor Beame severed his political relationship with Governor Carey yesterday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Louis Anthony Manna was ordered freed from prison yesterday by a judge who ruled the suspected mob figure would never testify about the workings of the underworld. The State Commission of Investigation immediately appealed the ruling to Judge Brauch Sidman of the Appellate Division of Superior Court, who reserved decision until noon Thursday. Mr. Manna will remain free until he rules.

title: MORE FLEXIBLE PLAN ON GAS TAX HINTED
description: WASHINGTON, April 20Even before formally submitting President Carter's national energy plan to Congress, the Administration today began making concessions to critics of the program.

title: WILMER ALLISON, 72, TENNIS STAR, DIES
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 20Wilmer Allison, a leading tennis player of the 1920's and 1930's, died today of an apparent heart attack. He was 72 years old.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 20, 1977

title: INCO NET ROSE 76% FOR FIRST QUARTER
description: Inco Ltd., which supplies almost half of nonCommunist world supplies of nickel from its Canadian mines, reported yesterday a 76 percent increase in firstquarter net income to $41 million, or 55 cents a share, from $23.3 million, or 31 cents a share, in the initial three months of last year.

title: Arledge Move In Question
description: Rumor continued to swirl yesterday about Roone Arledge, president of ABC Sports.

title: Russians Hold Pacific Exercise
description: TOKYO, April 20 (Reuters)Japanese fighter planes scrambled today when eight Soviet antisubmarine aircraft flew over the Tsushima Strait linking the Sea of Japan with the East China Sea to take part in naval maneuvers off Okinawa in the Pacific, the Defense Agency reported. A Japanese antisubmarine plane was sent to the area and a Japanese destroyer was also on its way, the agency said.

title: Fed Proposing A Basic Reform In Bank System
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York proposed yesterday a fundamental reform in the nation's banking system.

title: Bank Earnings Listed for Quarter
description: For periods ended March 31, unless otherwise indicated. (N) indicates skill is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: KRAUS Jacob. Pauline Bacal Kraus wishes to express her sincerest and deepest thanks for the many expressions of sympathy and understanding which she received upon the death March 16th of her dearly devoted and adored husband Jacob (Jack) Kraus, former senior attorney and special assistant attorney general of the state of New York. His wit, wisdom and good cheer will be cherished forever.

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: Trompe l' Oeil

title: A Test of Leadership
description: WASHINGTON, April 20With his first appearance before Congress since his inauguration three months ago, President Carter signaled to the nation tonight that he had chosen energy as the issue on which to test and build his Presidential leadership. Within the White House and on Capitol Hill, there was a sense that much of Mr. Carter's ultimate authority as President and much of the effectiveness of his Administration would ultimately ride on whether he succeeded in enacting the major reforms he proposed tonight.

title: Utility Gives Night Life a Boost
description: DETROIT When there is a big dinner to be cooked, a cake to be baked, a wash to be done, a handful of families in southeastern Michigan do the work at night. The electric rates are lower then.

title: Reaction: Support, Criticism, an Air of Resignation
description: WASHINGTON, April 20President Carter's energy message left few segments of American society untouched, from the oil producers to the environmentalists, and it provoked a range of reaction as broad and varied as its audience.

title: OutofHat Lineup Collects 14 Hits to Defeat Blue Jays
description: Reggie Jackson could sense it before the game, a feeling that the worst was over, the slump would end. He had hit a dozen balls into the stands during batting practice when a couple of drops fell on Yankee Stadium.

title: 2 Policemen Seized as Harlem Narcotics Extorters
description: Two uniformed police officers who had allegedly been shaking down narcotics dealers in East Harlem were arrestedyesterday morning when they assertedly extorted $1,700 from an undercover officer acting as a drug peddler.

title: Solomon Joins Gottfried for Davis Cup Play
description: Brian Gottfried, who scored two singles victories against South Africa, will lead the United States Davis Cup team against Argentina in the American Zone tennis final in Buenos Aires April 29.

title: Music: Berlin Octet
description: THE FIRST THING that struck one about the playing of the Berlin Philharmonic Octet at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night was its air of unshatterable assurance. This was a group, obviously, that felt it had the music in its blood. No strenuous efforts were made to persuade the listener, either in Mozart's Quintet or Schubert's Octet, the assumption being that these great works could speak for themselves.

title: A Jacobs GeneratorGone With the Wind and Back
description: GATHERING electricity from the wind may sound like a utopian dream to anyone under 30 years old. Memories have to stretch back to the postDepression era to recall the wind generators that dotted the rural landscape of the Plains states. That was before the Rural Electrification Act brought public utility power to the agricultural outposts and shut down many a homepower sourceone of the most popular of which was the wind generator produced by the Jacobs Wind Electric Company.

title: HELEN L. BECK
description: SEATTLE. April 20 (AP)Helen L. Beck, wife of Dave Beck Sr., former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, died yesterday after a long illness with cancer. She was 64 years old.

title: EnergyRelated Stocks and Rails Lead Rally as Dow Advances 3.82
description: Energyrelated stocks and railroad issues led the market higher yesterday as a rally blossomed in midsession. Investors appeared to shrug off doubts about President Carter's energy program prior to learning the details last night in his televised address before Congress.

title: Heroin Found at London Airport
description: LONDON, April 20 (UPI)Five minutes. of furious toilet flushing led to the discovery today of $850,000 worth of heroin at Heathrow Airport. Customs officials said they had been alerted by an airport worker that someone in an international terminal men's restroom was frantically flushing the toilet. When they arrived the man had fled, leaving behind nearly seven pounds of topgrade heroin in plastic bags, the police said. Customs officials said they were working with the New York police to discover the identity of the man.

title: IMPORTS OF CRUDE OIL ROSE SLIGHTLY IN WEEK
description: Crude oil imports on a daily basis rose slightly last week from the week before, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

title: NASSAU CANDIDATES JOUST AT LUNCHEON
description: EAST MEADOW, L.I., April 20In their first joint discussion, three Republican candidates for Nassau County Executive lashed out today at each other while two of them also attacked the fourth man in the bitter primarythe Nassau Republican chairman, Joseph M. Margiotta.

title: Police Officer Fights for His Life After Being Shot by Drug Suspect
description: Police Officer Robert Mandel, one ?? two plainclothesmen of the anticrime unit who were gunned Gown by a narcotics suspect outside a Brooklyn tavern on Tuesday, was still near death in Brooklyn Jewish Hospital yesterday with extensive brain damage from a bullet in the head. His partner, Officer Peter Christ, was listed in fair condition at the same hospital after removal of his spleen.

title: GARDENING: IN AND OUT
description: WHEN the hard work is over getting the soil and planters readythen it's time for the fun: choosing the flowers for a city terrace or balcony, and planting them.

title: Quake Hits Central Yugoslavia
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 20 (UPI)An earthquake struck the central Yugoslav town of Banja Luka and surrounding villages in the Bosnian Mountains early today, damaging buildings and causing residents to flee their homes, authorities said. No casualties were reported.

title: Disks: Rachmaninoff By Soderstrom
description: Rachmaninoff's songs, like his other music, are unmistakably his own. The shape of the melodies, the harmonic patterns, the writing for the piano pat are characteristically rich and Russian, more often than not establishing a passionate or melancholy mood. They were written between 1892 and 1916, and the later ones show an increased sophistication in handling the song form: the texts more subtle, the music more fragmented. A few of the songs have always been popular in this country, but more should be, because so many of them are impressive and beautiful.

title: AngloSaxon Sword Enriches Boy
description: LONDON, April 20 (AP)A 1,000yearold sword once owned by an AngloSaxon chieftainand found by a boy fishing for tadpoleswas auctioned today for $17,000 at Christie's. The sword, found by 9yearold Gary Fridd in a stream, was bought by the Yorkshire Museum of York. The money, except for enough to buy a bike and a metal detector, goes into a trust fund for the boy.

title: Passing of Counterfeits Charged
description: WOODBRIDGE, N. J., April 20 (AP)Two New York men have been arrested and charged with passing counterfeit $20 bills and using stolen credit cards at service areas on the New Jersey Turnpike, according to the state police. The suspects, identified as Wiley Watkins Sr., 56 years old, of Rego Park, Queens, and Doc Billups Jr., 45, of the Bronx, were being held today at the Middlesex County Jail in New Brunswick in lieu of $25,000 bail each. The suspects were arrested yesterday when the state police were called by the manager of the Thomas Edison Service Area here regarding the two men. The state police said the suspects had about 30 counterfeit $20 bills in their possesion, in addition to two stolen credit cards.

title: German Minister Visits India
description: NEW DELHI, April 20 (Reuters)The West German Foreign Minister, Hans Dietrich Genscher, arrived today on a fourday visit to India during which he will have talks with Prime Minister Morarjl Desai and other Indian leaders.

title: Clev Er Tell Suffers Knee Break And Will Miss Wood and Derby
description: Clev Er Tell, who loomed as Seattle Slew's strongest opponent, suffered a knee fracture yesterday and will not confront the acclaimed colt in the Wood Memorial on Saturday at Aqueduct.

title: JUSTICES VOICE DOUBT ON NIXON TAPES LAW
description: WASHINGTON, April 20Several Supreme Court Justices expressed concern and doubt today about some aspects of the 1974 statute that gave the Federal Government control over Richard M. Nixon's residential papers and tape recordings.

title: Ycaza Is Racing Again, This Time It's in a Sulky
description: Wearing kelly green racing silks and a pair of Gucci loafers Manuel Ycaza, the daring Panamanian, signaled his return yesterday to the races.

title: What's New in the Furniture Market
description: What's New in the Furniture Market

title: Big Board Issues Its Reports Of Changes in Stock by Insiders
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest reports of changes in stock ownership by large stockholders, dircectors and officers of their listed companies.

title: In Airborne Gardens, Soil's the Thing
description: SOIL'S THE thingeven more so when you're a rooftop gardener. Down below, there's always a chance to change the ground. In gardens, if the soil is heavy and packs, one can build up the organic content over a period of years by using green manure and mulch. Or one can raise the filth almost instantly with large quantities of compost, with manureeither fresh or baggedand with peat moss.

title: Plainview's Town Board Rejects Application for Y.M.Y.W.H.A.
description: PLAINVIEW, L.I., April 20The Oyster Bay Town board yesterday turned down a plan by the United Jewish Y's of Long Island to convert a vacant school building here into a $3 million branch of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Associated. The Y would have been the first such facility on Long Island.

title: U.S. Says It Will Provide Peaceful Benefits of Atom
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 20A United States Government official today, told a conference on the banning of nuclear arms in Latin America that the Carter Administration would continue to provide the region with the peaceful benefits of atomic energy, but would avoid any actions that could raise the risk that nuclear technology might be used for military purposes.

title: World News Briefs
description: OSHAKATI, SouthWest Africa, April 20 (Reuters)Black nationalist guerrillas abducted 120 black pupils from a Roman Catholic mission school today and took them across the border into Angola, a South African official said.

title: A Tale of Six Squirrels
description: CAN'T explain it, said the town's game warden. Beats me, said the deputy fire chief. Hmmm, said smart friends who usually said more.

title: Cuban Exile Jailed for Refusing To Testify in Murder of Letelier
description: WASHINGTON, April 20A Cuban exile who refused to answer questions by a Federal grand jury investigating the murder of Orlando Letelier, a former Chilean diplomat, was ordered jailed today for contempt of court.

title: Unweiling
description: LISSHenrietta L. A. On Sunday, April 24, at 12 Noon D.S.T., at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah in New Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, N. J. Indoors, no postponements.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: YOUNG AT ART Passersby in the lobby of One World Trade Center can see a new display of 121 paintings and drawings by amateur painters, ages to 15 years. This is the largest assembly of art by Russian children ever shown in the United States, created by members of the Soviet youth organizations, the Palaces of Pioneers. Sponsoring the show is the U.S.S.R.U.S.A. Society, a civic grout based in Moscow. The pictures will be on view daily from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. through May 15.

title: Swiss Medical Academy Issues Guidelines for Doctors to Discontinue Treatment for Dying Patients
Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Judge Issues, Stays, Order Removing Marx Guardian
description: LOS ANGELES, April 20 (Reuters)A Superior Court judge issued today an order removing Groucho Marx's companion, Erin Fleming, as his guardian but stayed the order overnight so that he could call on the ailing 86yearold comedian to get his views.

title: A Bill to Legalize Casino Gambling Is Pushed by Democrats in Albany
description: ALBANY, April 20Democrats in the Legislature opened a drive today for a constitutional amendment legalizing casino gambling in New York State. The Republican leadership immediately threw cold water on the idea. Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut, who will be the principal sponsor of the amendment and its enabling legislation, said: The time has come for New York to protect its competitive posture in this arena.

title: A Believer In Wind Power From 1922
description: Back in 1922, Joseph and Marcellus Jacobs, two brothers in their early 20s, began tinkering with the idea of converting a waterpumping windmill into an electric wind generator on their father's 4,000acre ranch and wheat farm outside the town of Wolf Point, Mont. Using spare parts for the gearing mechanism of an old Model T Ford, they improvised a working model. With further refinements, it evolved into the three bladed Jacobs wind machine.

title: SCRIPPSHOWARD FUND NAMES AWARD WINNERS
description: The Honolulu Advertiser has won the first Edward Willis Scripps First Amendment Award for its 40part series on the role and the performance of the press contributed by readers of The Advertiser.

title: WARNKE WARY OF STAND OF SOVIET ON ARMS PACT
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI)The Chief United States disarmament negotiator, Paul C. Warnke, said today that he thought productive AmericanSoviet talks on strategic arms would be resumed soon, but whether Moscow really wanted a new arms pact remains to be proven.

title: Advertising
description: If television truly wants to win the heart of the department store advertiser it must, among other things, discover ways of reaching desirable segments of the market and provide research on how the medium can affect attitudes.

title: Delivering the Bad News
description: It is clear now that turning the United States Post Office into an autonomous public corporation in 1971 has failed to realize the hopes of its proponents. Mail service has not improved; many believe it has actually deteriorated. The postal deficit is larger than ever; in 1976 the postal operation cost more than twice what it did in 1968. The recently announced surplus for the 12 months ended March 25 is a onetime thing, not likely to be repeated.

title: NURSINGHOME CASE BRINGS 3 INDICTMENTS
description: MINEOLA, L.I. April 20A Long Island physician and his two sons have been indicted by grand juries in Nassau and Suffolk Counties for allegedly accepting more than $1.6 million in illegal kickbacks from suppliers to their nursing homes and illegal reimbursements from Medicaid, Charles J. Hynes, the state special prosecutor for nursing homes, said today.

title: A.C.L.U. Suit Says Honeywell Conspired With F.B.I.
description: The American Civil Liberties Union plans to file a lawsuit today, which charges that top officers of Honeywell Inc. conspired illegally with the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the early 1970's to infiltrate religious and political groups that opposed Honeywell's production of antipersonnel weapons

title: The Cruel Price of Tuna
description: The delightful porpoiseregarded by some scientists and most visitors to marinelands as the mammal closest to man in intelligenceis still being killed off by the tens of thousands in a mayhem wholly incidental to the catching of tuna. In each of the past three years more than 100,000 of these engaging animals have been suffocated in the great nets that the United States tuna fleet uses to ensnare yellowfin tuna. Ironically, it is the porpoise, accompanying the tuna, that helps the fisherman locate his catch.

title: Notes on People
description: NOT MANY YEARS ago the police would have had a hard time controlling the mobs of wildly screaming fans, but when George Harrison, the former Beetle flew into London's Heathrow Airport yesterday there was barely a sign of recognition. If that's George, said a skeptical airline stewardess, he's changed a lot. The 34yearold, curlyhaired Mr. Harrison said: After 16 years in the music business the novelty wears off.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: ANDERSON SHARE BID REJECTED BY GERBER
description: The Gerber Products Company, the World's largest manufacturer of baby foods and producer of a wide range of baby products rejected yesterday the $325.3 million tender offer of Anderson, Clayton & Company of Houston. Anderson, Clayton said that it would continue with its tender offer of $40 a share for more than 8.1 million shares. The offer was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday and will commence on April 28. The offer was also filed with the states of Michigan, Arkansas and the Insurance Department of New York State.

title: Backe to Succeed Paley on May 11 As the Chief Executive of CBS
description: LOS ANGELES. April 20William S. Paley, who founded the Columbia Broadcasting System almost 50 years ago and built it into one of the most powerful communications forces in the world, said today he would step aside as chief executive officer of CBS Inc. on May 11.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 21, 1977

title: Church Has Energy Plan
description: The board for homeland ministries of the 1.8 millionmember United Church of Christ announced yesterday that it would appropriate $1 million to provide lowinterest loans to its congregations for energy conservation renovations in churches, educational buildings and parsonages. In a telegram to President Carter, the Rev. Dr. Howard E. Spragg, executive vice president of the board, urged the President to provide lowinterest governmental loans to nonprofit organizations to help them implement energy conservation programs.

title: House Votes to Bar Compliance in U.S. With Arab Boycott
description: WASHINGTON, April 20The House tonight overwhelmingly approved a measure that would prohibit American companies from complying with the Arab boycott against Israel.

title: Books: An Inveterate Hopscotcher Looks Back
description: AT LAST, Cyrus Sulzberger has done what he should have done long ago: condensed his memoirs to make them digestible. This latest volume Is a combined condensation of four earlier ones, which was too much for any journalist to ask readers to absorb, regardless of all the insight into the lives and philosophies of political and military giants and dwarfs. So now we have the highlights of those four books in one easytoread volume, though still with an overdose of egotism and trivia.

title: House Votes to Bar Compliance in U.S. With Arab Boycott
description: WASHINGTON, April 20The House tonight overwhelmingly approved a measure that would prohibit American companies from complying with the Arab boycott against Israel.

title: Letter From Home
description: NEW HAVEN I NEVER SAW a nematode and never hope to see one. In fact, unless I start going around with a 60magnification microscope which I really don't want to go around with  I never will. Yet this invisible worm is probably nibbling at my lawngrass roots right now as I sit here visibly typing. Every few minutes I look out the window to see if any blades of grass have dropped dead.

title: Fora Busy U.S. General in Korea, Pullout Is Later, Readiness Now
description: CAMP CASEY, South KoreaMorris J. Brady is a businessman. He worries about personnel, energy costs, equipment, training, deliveries, losses and multimilliondollar budgets. He works into the night, carries home sheafs of papers and sees his family only briefly.

title: Former Hoppin Chief Cashier Is Charged With $250,000 Theft of Stock
description: The former chief cashier of Hoppin, Watson Inc., brokers, has been arrested on charges of stealing more than $250.000 from the firm by transferring stocks to a personal account he maintained at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith.

title: Loss by Radicals in Berkeley Tied To Student Apathy and Rent Control
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 20 (AP)Student apathy and a vote on rent control were cited today as key factors in an election setback for radicalism in this university city.

title: A.T. & T. to Allow Secret Proxy Vote
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 20The annual meeting of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today approved a proposal to allow secret balloting by shareholders for the first time, starting next year.

title: President Is Scolded For Vegetarian Meal
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI)A meatless meal at the White House has upset cattlemen.

title: Administration Officials Describe Energy Plan's Effect on Consumer
description: WASHINGTON, April 20Following are questions on how President Carter's energy proposals would affect consumers and answers based primarily on the explanations of the program by Administration officials:

title: 25 Students Drown in Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 20 (Reuters)At least 25 college students were drowned when a tugboat capsized near Suao, East Taiwan, yesterday, the police said today. Seven people are still missing. The tugboat was making a tour of Suao harbor, with 60 students on board, when the disaster occurred. The Education Minister, Dr. Tsiang Yensi, resigned after taking personal responsbility for the accident.

title: Hers
description: IT WAS the night they brought us the Mrs. America pageant live from Las Vegas that the topic of First Ladies came up. For all I known, the topic of First Ladies comes up every year on the night of the Mrs. America pageant, and we just never noticed.

title: Watson Heads Field of 150 In New Orleans Golf
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 20 (AP)Tom Watson winner of the Masters, will lead 150 of golf's lesser lights tomorrow in pursuit of the $35,000 top prize in the $175,000 Greater New Orleans open.

title: Wrigley Service Today
description: CHICAGO, April 20 (UPI)A memorial service will be held tomorrow at the Fourth Presbyterian Church for Philip K. Wrigley, Chicago Cubs owner, who died April 12 at the age of 82. Wrigley Field, home park of the Cubs, will be closed.

title: NEW YORK EXCHANGE
description: ARMCO STEEL CORPORATIONCalvin William Verity Jr., chairman, sold 22,000 shares leaving him directly 3,000 shares.

title: Lebanon Prepares to Rebuild Army
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 20President Elias Sarkis has reportedly completed plans for rebuilding the Lebanese Army into a force of 50,000 men.

title: JOHN J. BAESSLER, 77, GERMANBORN INVENTOR
description: John J. Baessler, a coinventor of the aerosol valve, died Tuesday at North Broward Hospital in Florida. He was 77 years old and a resident of Lighthouse Point, Fla.

title: Text of Fact Sheet on the President's Program Issued by White House Energy Staff
description: WASHINGTON. April 20Following is the text of a fact sheet on President Carter's energy program that was issued today by the White House energy staff.

title: Reading by Schoolchildren Marks New York State's 200th Birthday
description: KINGSTON, N.Y., April 20New York State celebrated its 200th birthday today here in the city where it was born.

title: About New York
description: The police official was asking that cliches be put aside in the case of the 44caliber psychopath. The Mayor does not pick up the phone and tell the Police Commissioner, I want action or else. It doesn't work that way.

title: Jets Beat Mariners, 30; Gain 32 Lead in Playoffs
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, April 20 (AP) Mats Lindh scored two goals tonight to help the Winnipeg Jets gain a 30 victory over the San Diego Mariners and a 32 lead in their World Hockey Association quarterfinal playoff series.

title: In the Royal Box With King George
description: Some people speak in a stream of consciousness, but with George Steinbrenner it's a rapids, sometimes a waterfall.

title: Books of The Times
description: IT WILL TAKE YOU no more than an hour and a half to read this book the first time. The second time will take longer. The third time, you will probably pause at certain passages, having already memorized them, and look around for an ear into which to quote. For instance:

title: Byrne Promises Hard Fighting Campaign; Says Income Tax Should Not Be Key Issue
description: Governor Byrne promised a hard fighting campaign for reelection at a news conference in Trenton yesterday, but he acknowledged there were periods in December and January when he thought he would not run for a secand term. Mr. Byrne said he was disheartened by polls that showed his popularity to be very low and by one pollster's estimation that his rating was so low it could not improve significantly in the months ahead. However, the Governor said subsequent polls, some of them taken by rival candidates, had shown some improvement in his standing and that he made up his mind definitely to run again about two weeks ago when he was shown a poll that was commissioned by Ann Klein, the State Commissioner of Human Services.

title: Genetic Engineering
description: Genetic engineering is not new. It began in 1930almost half a century agowhen a technique was developed at The Rockefeller Institute Hospital to modify in the test tube the hereditary characteristics of the microbes that cause lobar pneumonia. This achievement led to the demonstration that the substance now known as DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) is the carrier of heredity.

title: Jewish Agencies Close As Talks Break Down
description: Efforts to mediate a contract dispute between 20 Jewish groupwork agencies and District Council 1707 of the Community and Social Agency Employees Union broke down last night. The agencies announced that they would not reopen their facilities until an agreement had been reached.

title: U.S. AND BRITAIN PLAN NEW RHODESIA TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 20The United States and Britain, in a new move to cosponsor a conference on Rhodesia, are seeking to shape a constitution guaranteeing an immediate transfer of power to the black majority as well as assurances of financial aid to the whites, according to diplomatic sources.

title: Letters
description: Let's See a Picture

title: O.S.S. Veterans Recall Cloakand Dagger Days
description: All of us old goats is what Michael Burke called the assemblage of fellowO.S.S. veterans who got together Tuesday night to plan a reunion dinner of the menand the few womenwho lived the World War II adventures that became so many movie and television scripts and, more important, provided the blueprint for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: John R. McDermott, Who Served As Combat Artist in War, at 57
description: John R. McDermott, a cartoonist and author who served as a combat artist in World War II with the Third Amphibious Marine Corps in the Pacific, died yesterday in his home, 123 Sturges Highway, Westport, Conn., after a long illness. He was 57 years old.

title: A Test On Wiretaps
description: WASHINGTON, April 20In the next week or so the Carter Administration is expected to give Congress its views on the prickly perennial issue of electronic surveillance for foreign intelligence purposes. The bill it sends up will be taken as a highly significant sign of its attitude on civil liberties generally.

title: A Case of Murder; a Charge of Forced Confessions
description: DAWSON, Ga.The little south Georgia town of Dawson lies just 21 miles due south of Plains, hometown of the President and a iymbol of the socalled New South.

title: P.G.A. Tour Sets Record Of $9,688,977 in Purses
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)Professional Golfers' Association Tour events for 1977 carry purses totaling a record $9,685,977, Commissioner Deane Beman said today.

title: Good Vibes, Will Travel
description: Red Norvo, the jazz vibraharpist, led a notable big band in the 1930's with Mildred Bailey, who was his wife at the time, as his singer. Later, in the 50's, he had a notable trio, with Tal Fallow on guitar and Charles Mingus on bass. But now he travels footloose With only his vibraharp and an assortment of mallets in what he says is a different musical world.

title: Court Blocks an Abortion For TeenAged Student On Male Friend's Plea
description: MAPLEWOOD, N.J., April 21 (AP)A New Jersey Supreme Court justice today blocked an abortion planned by a teenaged college student whose male friend argued it would violate his right to future fatherhood.

title: More South Koreans Are Seized as Government Appears to Build a Case of Communist Conspiracy
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 21The list of President Park Chung Hee's political opponents seized in a nationwide crackdown continued to grow today amid indications that the Government was seeking evidence to build a court case of a Communist conspiracy.

title: Consumers Brace for Hardships, Large and Small, in Energy Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, April 21With four snowmobiles, two motorboats, a sixberth mobile home, one truck, one car, three tractors, one trail bike, one motorcycle, two airconditioners, a heated greenhouse, two food freezers and a sauna bath, the Gene Swanson family of Lake Elmo, Minn., was slightly dismayed after hearing President Carter's energy message.

title: COMPROMISE REACHED ON PORNOGRAPHY BILL
description: Mayor Beame joined with Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens yesterday to push for passage of a compromise zoning measure that would limi pornography to Manhattan, two tiny areas of Queens, two slightly larger areas on Staten Island and one site in the Bronx.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 21. 1977

title: In Land of Plaid Cymru, Wales Is Very Much a Nation
description: ABERYSTWYTH, WalesGreat Britain does not look the same from Aberystwyth as it does from London.

title: AMERICAN MOTORS PLANS SMALLCAR SHUTDOWNS
description: DETROIT, April 21The American Motors Corporation said today it planned to partly shut down some of its smallcar assembly production for a week beginning Monday, making 3,850 workers idle.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: SOMEWHERE BETWEEN the urban stereotypes of mothers shouting from tenement windows and begrimed artist types in overalls lies Prince Street, the SoHo artery that has merged the ethnic and ??rt communities in a kaleidoscope of street life, galleries, food and funk. Prince Street wanders from Greenwich Village to the Bowery, evoking the rhythms of baroque castiron architecture and walkup apartment buildings, and the lacework imagery of fire escapes.

title: The Pop Life
description: QUITE APART FROM his only intermittent commercial success or even from what you may think of his music, Van Morrison remains one of the great innovators and influences of rockandroll. From his rhythmandblues hits of the mid 1960's with Them (Gloria. above all) through his mystical, highly personal extensions of soul signatures into his own form of rhapsodic acid rock (Astral Weeks, Moondance), he set standards and inspired younger emulators with remarkable charisma. In recent months Bruce Springsteen, Southside Johnny Lyon, Bob Seger and Phil Lynott have all paid renewed tribute to the man they regard as one of their prime influences. If anybody can be said to have inspired the late1970's rhythmandblues revival among white rock singers, it is Mr. Morrison.

title: Auto Makers Generally Endorse Energy Proposals, But G.M. Terms Guzzler Penalty Tax Simplistic
description: DETROIT, April 21Thomas A. Murphy's tone was softer this time, and he ringingly endorsed President Carter's general energy initiative. But one important part of the message delivered today by the chairman of the General Motors Corporation was essentially the same as it had been in recent days: The President's proposed tax on cars that waste fuel is chancy, unnecessary and could backfire.

title: French Airlift Backed by African Governments
description: DAKAR, Senegal, April 21 (UPI)The French airlift of Moroccan troops to help the Zairian Government fight invading rebels has drawn strong support from African nations concerned about foreign interference on the continent.

title: The Standings
description: Friday, April 22, 1977

title: The Impact of Carter's Momentous Moves
description: The momentous events of the last two weeks will have profound effects on many segments of the American economy for years to come. What develops, however, will depend on the extent that the public and the Congress accept the perception of the nation's economic and energy problems, and the proposed solutions for them, that have been put forth by the White House. The uncertainty over the reactions and over the timing and the nature of the eventual legislative decisions on the Administration's programs is likely to cloud the domestic economic outlook for some time ahead.

title: Questions on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  Three questions about President Carter's energy program:

title: Mr. Carter and the Car
description: When the President promised a detailed, comprehensive energy policy, he meant it. His plan cuts across American life, from bus fares to uranium enrichment to buying 6,000 vans for Federal commuters. Much as the plan is needed and much as we therefore applaud the President for it, it is too complex for fast or full absorption. It is understandable that the early reaction includes a fair amount of overreactionespecially to the provisions relating to the automobile.

title: Power Failure Cancels AngelsWhite Sox Game
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., April 21 (AP)A power failure forced postponement of tonight's American League baseball game between the California Angels and the Chicago White Sox.

title: Addicted Twin Doctors Endangered Patients, Assembly Panel Is Told
description: Twin gynecologists who died nearly two years ago as a result of drug addiction performed or tried to perform surgery when their hands were shaking and they could barely stand up, a New York Assembly committee was told yesterday.

title: Consumer Prices Rose 0.6 Percent Last Month In New York City Area
description: The Consumer Price Index for the New York Citynortheastern New Jersey area rose sixthtenths of 1 percent last month, largely because of increases in expenses for housing, as well as for transportation and medical care.

title: SouthWest Africa and South Africa Appear to Be on a Collision Course
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 21When a radio request program in South Africa dedicates a record to one of the boys on the border, no section of the 3,500mile frontier with black Africa is identified. To do so would be to violate laws that place tight constraints on reporting military deployments.

title: New York City Is Getting Tougher On Companies Planning to Leave
description: The Mayor's Office of Economic Development is toughening its tactics against corporations seeking to leave the city and is trying to block Federal highway funds for load improvements that make remote suburban sites usable for office centers.

title: Tot Luck' Lineup Again Thrives As Yanks Down Blue Jays, 86
description: It is becoming old hat. For the second straight day, the Yankees, with their new lineupoutofahat look, scored their most runs in a game this season and defeated the Toronto Blue Jays, 8.6, yesterday at the Stadium.

title: Bryan Foy, Vaudevillian and Film Producer, 80, Dies
