description: LOS ANGELES, April 21 (AP)Bryan Foy, one of vaudeville's Seven Little Foys and producer of dozens of films. including the first alltalkie movie and the 3D thriller House of Wax, died yesterday of heart failure at U.C.L.A. Medical Center at the age of 60.

title: Robinson Takes 100Meter Dash in 10.2
description: PISCATAWAY, N. J., April 21The second annual Rutgers University relays got off to a blazing start today when Rey Robinson, a 1972 Olympian, ranu the 100 meters in 10.2 seconds in the first race at Rutgers Stadium.

title: At the Movies
description: FOR TWO YEARS, I drove around in cars, and didn't see anybody, said Alan Rudolph. A sense of isolation came out of that experience, and in that respect the movie is autobiographical. You might call it a multiautohiography.

title: For Lindsay, His Refrement Leaves Little Time for Leisure
description: Good morning, everybody, says the former Mayor of New York in a voice inappropriately cheery for the time of day, 5:35 A.M.

title: H.R.H. to Become Starrett Subsidiary In Merger Accord
description: The Starrett Housing Corporation and the H. R. H. Construction Company announced yesterday that they had concluded then longdiscussed merger agreement.

title: New Face
description: A Broadway Debut for a New Orphan Girl in TownJust about four years ago Andrea McArdle got her start in show business little did she think, a third of a lifetime ago, that she would soon be star, the 13yearold playing the 11yearold title role of the new musical, Annie.

title: Durables Show 7% March Rise In New Orders
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI)New orders for durable goods increased almost 7 percent in March, the biggest gain in three months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: N.B.A. Balks at Mediation in Strike
description: Richie Phillips, the attorney repre senting the striking referees of the National Basketball Association, yesterday charged the league with an effort to frustrate meaningful dialogue by refusing to attend a meeting proposed to mediate the dispute.

title: Cash Prices
description: Thursday, April 21, 1977

title: Whitney Shows Maui. Frank Gillette Video Work
description: Maui, a new work by Frank Gillette that uses four channels of video and nine panels of photographs to depict life on the Hawaiian island of Maui, goes on view today at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street.

title: Pistol Clubs Federation Rewards A Superintendent Who Shot Man
description: I survive, I'm still alive and I protect my life, said Zygmunt Soroka as he accepted a Courageous Citizens Award claque from the Federation of Greater New York Rifle and Pistol Clubs for successfully defending himself, in the words of its president. Gerald Preiser.

title: New Face
description: Like father, like son seems to be working out in the case of Hart Bochner, but his father can't take any credit for it. The handsome, 20yearold Mr. Bochner is impressing moviegoers with his sensitive and solid performance in Islands in the Stream, which is at neighborhood theaters this weekend. The film is an adaptation of the Ernest Hemingway novel, published posthumously in 1970, about a middleaged artist and his uneasy relationship with his three sonsthe offspring of two unsuccessful marriages. George C. Scott stars as the Hemingwayesque artist, while Mr. Bochner plays his oldest son.

title: Zeppo Marx Offers To Be Conservator Of Groucho's Assets
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 21Zeppo Marx may be appointed conservator for his brother, Groucho.

title: Giants Deal Hughes, Get Saints' Pick
description: Pat Hughes, who lost his starting job last season and then demanded that the Giants trade him, was traded yesterday to the New Orleans Saints in exchange for an undisclosed choice in the National Football League draft.

title: Art: Robert Irwin At the Whitney
description: ROBERT IRWIN'S new piece at the Whitney Museum is the sort of thing that drives some people clean out of their minds. It doesn't represent anything. You can't stand at a distance and look at it. You have to be inside it to know what it's about, and by the time you're inside it you're trapped. The conditions of everyday perception are suspended and Mr. Irwin invites you to think about art, and eventually to think about yourself, in quite a new way.

title: Books: Dance From the Heart
description: IT IS NO SECRET that more people are dancing and more are watching dance. More people are writing about it, too. It could have once been said, and not so long ago, that dance critics were content to emulate the historical perspective of John Martin from 1927 to 1962 the critic for The New York Times, or the sinewy clearsightedness of Edwin Denby, who started writing on dance over 40 years ago. Now there is whole spectrum of styles and voices, ranging roughly from the givethekidsabreak school to the danceisreal, danceisearnest contingent.

title: Art: Landmarks On the Color Field
description: THE FIRST THING to be said about the Kenneth Noland exhibition at the Guggenheim (Museum through June 19) is that it must be seen. Mr. Noland is one of the artists who have decisively shaped American paintingor at least some very important elements of itover the last 20 years. The fate of abstract art in America in the 1960's and 70's can scarcely be understood without some knowledge of his work.

title: For Visitors, West Point Is Always on Parade
description: IT WAS REVEILLE at West Point on July 4 last year, and one of the participants, Lieut. Col. John H. Bradley, director of Bicentennial activities at the United States Military Academy, was preoccupied. He had noticed that a flag was already flying over Fort Putnam, a redoubt high above the Plains.

title: Bill Would Curb Tests on Animals
description: ALBANY, April 21Animal shelters throughout the state would no longer be required to turn over dogs, cats and other animals to medical facilities for experimentation, under a bill that passed the State Assembly by a large margin today.

title: Film Forum: Charles Ives And Harry Partch, 2 originals
description: THANKS TO the new program at the Film Forum, the decidedly unusual characters of two gifted, proud, unreconstructed musical loners, Charles Ives and Harry Partch, are brought into colorful focus in screen treatments that, however partial, do them and their innovative work a deserved service.As the more ambitious subject, the feature-length "A Good Dissonance Like a Man" is a dramatization that, through meticulous use of authentic sources and places, leaves the satisfying impression of fact-filled, documentary truth. Charles Ives, in this case, is not a misty legend. He is the boy immersed in music by his father, a musician and experimenter whose diversions from musical norms rubbed off in historic style on the son.If Ives is now regarded as one of America's greatest composers, recognition of his avant-garde tonal works, the film makes clear, came late in his career. The film traces major influences on the composer's lifethe inspiration of the New England countryside, his heritage, college days at Yale, his happy, if illness-plagued, family life, the insurance business that made him well-to-do and free to compose in his own time and own way and, above all, his rebellion against musical regimentationto evoke a three-dimensional, all-too-human artist.The characterizations of the principals are realistic and convincing, as are the taped, narrated reminiscences of relatives and friends. And, they are colorfully abetted by scenes shot at family homes and at Yale. One may yearn for more of the Ives music (and its identification) than we get here, but it is obvious that Theodore W. Timreck, the producer-director, and his associates have given us, not dissonance, but a lucid and vivid portrait of an extraordinary man.The 27-minute study of Partch, filmed in California in 1973, a year before his death, is largely an interview but he, too, emerges as a man decidedly apart from the crowd. White-bearded, thin and casually dressed, he projects his musical and social views simply and directlyrecollections of the hobo's life in the West, his youth, the Depression.The weird instruments he invented and builta 72-string, lyrelike cithara, glass bells cut from bottles, and the likewere designed to fit his individualistic compositions, music often inspired by the times and the places in which he lived. Although the film is merely an excerpt from the annals of a full and fulfilled life, it makes its "dreamer" strikingly real.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 22, 1977

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: RESULTS

title: WHITE HOUSE SHIFTS, SAYS ENERGY PLANS WON'T AID ECONOMY
description: WASHINGTON, April 21In a surprise reversal, the Carter Administration said today that the energy program proposed yesterday would have no significant effect on economic growth.

title: Bridge:
description: For the first time, the result of a major New York knockout team contest has been decided by the semifinal stage of the event.

title: Players and Reviewer Hail Shakespeare
description: Paul Rudd and Pamela PaytonWright, who play the title roles in Romeo and Juliet at Circle in the Square, will join the actress Hattie Winston and the theater reviewer Emory Lewis tomorrow in a conversation to celebrate Shakespeare's birthday. It's the playwright's 413th, and the event takes place at the Mitzi Newhouse Theater in Lincoln Center as part of the city's Youth Theater Festival.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, April 21, 1977

title: TV WEEKEND
description: THE sixth and final portion of WCBSTV's A Woman is . . . with Bess Meyerson begins tonight at 7:30 with a halfhour film called The Amazing Eighties. This will be followed next week, at 9:30 A.M. Monday through Friday, with Miss Meyerson conducting studio interviews of as the title has it, Women in Their Later Years

title: QuarterHorse Opening Set Back a Bit, to May 19
description: YAPHANK, L.I., April 21Dust was being raised in huge quantities today at Parr Meadows. Motor graders spread sand and clay on the track's surface. Bulldozers shoved soil about the parking lots. A crane chugged down the backstretch, getting ready to install a video patrol tower at the far turn.

title: Out of Doors
description: FROM A CHILD's point of view, the big problem with nature is that so much of it runs away and hides. Children walk through the woods, wanting nothing more than to see live animals. Shy animals often refuse to oblige.

title: A Night on Patrol for Illegal Mexican Aliens
description: EL PASO, April 21For Hector Sea, light is the worst enemy. Mr. Sea has remarkable eyes and he shields them, turning his head from the sudden glare of a flashlight, a cigarette lighter or an oncoming automobile. It would take only a second to lose the night vision acquired over several hours, and in Mr. Sea's job as a United States border patrol officer, night vision is almost everything.

title: World News Briefs
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, April 21 (UPI)Gen. Ziaur Rahman, a prominent figure in the 1971 war of independence, became the fifth president of Bangladesh today with the resignation of President Abu Sadat Mohammed Sayem on grounds of ill health.

title: SCHOOLEVENT CURB ON SABBATHS EASED
description: TEANECK, April 21A sixweekold policy to restrict extracurricular school activities on the Christian and Jewish Sabbaths was replaced today by a sche??ling policy calling for maximum sensitivity for all students without reference to the Sabbath.

title: Where to Drive, Rest and Dine at the End of the Long Gray Line
description: The trip itself to West Point is worth the visit, with the Hudson River and the mountains serving as increasingly attractive springtime backdrops. By car, take the Palisades Interstate Parkway, a generally trafficfree artery, to its terminus at a circle facing the Bear Mountain Bridge. Take Route 9W North from there, following signs to Highland Falls and West Point.

title: Zaire Reports Military Offensive
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 21A Government spokesman announced today that Zairian and Moroccan troops had opened a general offensive in the south against the Katangan exiles who invaded Zaire from neighboring Angola on March 8.

title: HIGH COURT REPORTED TO OPPOSE A REVIEW OF NIXON AIDES' CASE
description: WASHINGTON, April 21The Supreme Court was reported today to have voted 5 to 3 last Friday to refuse to review the convictions of John N. Mitchell, H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman in the Watergate coverup case.

title: Flyers Eliminate Leafs in 6 Games With 43 Victory on Jim Watson Goal
description: TORONTO, April 21With a gritty 43 victory tonight, the Philadelphia Flyers eliminated the Toronto Maple Leafs in the quarterfinal round of the National Hockey League playoffs for the third straight season. And they did it after losing the first two games in Philadelphia, then winning the next four, including two in overtime and all three here, where the Leafs failed to win a playoff game this season.

title: A Safety Net for Tumbling Allies
description: Now that the United States is getting a domestic energy policy, it must deal with the dangerous strains in the international monetary system created by the fivefold increase in oil prices since 1973. The increase helped to propel the world into its worst economic crisis in 40 years and is hampering recovery.

title: Restaurants
description: ONE OF THE RESTAURANTS that readers have asked about most often is the Palace, on East 59th Street in the shadow of the Queensboro Bridge described as the city's most expensive eating place. The question come from people who are planning specialoccasion splurges and wonder if the Palace is, in fact, worth its $65 a person prix fixe. The larger question to answer right at the start is whether any meat can be worth that price, and that can best be answered, perhaps, with other questions: Can an ounce of perfume be worth $100 or a lavish but highly perishable floral arrangement $50?

title: Egypt Holds Naval Drill
description: CAIRO, April 21 (UPI)Egyptian warships in the Red Sea staged a major exercise with live ammunition this week, the Middle East News Agency said today. It said the fourhour exercise involved destroyers, missile boats, torpedo boats and minesweepers. It was the second military exercise announced this week.

title: About Real Estate
description: When the 31story tower annex to the cluster of Brooklyn Heights structures known as the St. George Hotel went up in 1929, its huge ballroom could be bathed in light from 36,000 bulbs in any combination of colors on command of a color organ. And it had the largest indoor pool in town40 feet wide and 120 feet lone.

title: Letters
description: New Under The Sun

title: F .D. A . Is Urged to Ban Drug for Diabetics
description: WASHINGTON, April 21The Health Research Group sought today to force the Food and Drug Administration to ban from the market a drug that the agency acknowledges to be dangerous and possiably responsible for 93 deaths.

title: Music: Brazilian Jazz at Environ
description: Brazilian Hotmosphere, a ninepiece band led by the percussionist Dom Um Romao, perforced a refreshing mixture of traditional Brazilian music and jazz at Environ on Wednesday and yesterday. Unlike many contemporary Brazilianoriented groups, Brazilian Hotmosphere does not waterdown its percussion rhythms with rock. And the band's jazz is equally unencumbered by rock stylings.

title: March Sales Gains of 6 City Stores A gain Exceeded Average for Area
description: In March, for the second consecutive month, six of New York City's department stores had sales gains exceeding the average for the metropolitan area.

title: Oilmen Attack Lack of Incentive In Carter Plan to Increase Output
description: WASHINGTON, April 21Oil and gas producers applauded President Carter's energy plan in muted, general terms today, but vigorously criticized some specific elements and its lack of incentives to expand production.

title: Gummo Marx, Managed Comedians
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. April 21 (Reuters)  Gummo Mark, an original member of the Marx brothers' comedy team, died here today. He was 84 years old.

title: Manhattanville Offers Concert Early Music Concert Is Set
description: A free chamber music concert will be offered tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Pius X Hall of the music building at Manhattanvil'e College in Purchase, N. Y., by Lois Wann, oboist, Bella Shumiatcher, pianist, and Susan Hyman, flutist. They will play works by Telemann, Saint Sans and Walter Piston. Information: (914) 9469600.

title: Dibbs Ousts Roche, 76, 63, At Charlotte
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 21 (UPISecondseeded Eddie Dibbs defeated the defender, Tony Roche, 76, 63, and John Alexander beat Harold Solomon. 63, 76, today in quarterfinal play of a $100,000 World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: Brooklynite Won A Pulitzer Prize For Texas Paper
description: The best thing that ever happened to me, says Joe Murray, editor of The Lufkin (Tex.) News (circulation 13,000) was when Ken Herman walked in here talking a language I didn't understand and looking for a job.

title: Broadway
description: STARTING next Tuesday, there will be an exhibition called Frank Loesser Remembered in the Amsterdam Gallery of the public library at Lincoln Center. The exhibition, lovingly assembled by Jo Sullivan, Mr. Loesser's widow, is made up of the composerlyricist's manuscripts, sheet music, photographs, drawings, even the Pulitzer Prize he won for How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying. (At the bottom of it he wrote. This boy can write.) Miss Sullivan, who found the manuscript for Guys and Dolls in an old packing case after looking seven years for it, said the exhibition may be the beginning of a Frank Loesser revival.

title: Lo, Says This Play, Think on the Ending
description: Lechery, Wrath and Gluttony will scamper grotesquely in blotchy blue leotards at the Performing Garage, 33 Wooster Street, at 8 P.M. tonight as they and the other four Deadly Sins lead Mankind from the path of righteousness. It all happens in an adaptation of The Castle of Perseverance, a medieval morality play, by a dance group called the Farthingale.

title: Schlesinger in Key Role Serving 3d President
description: WASHINGTON, April 21Richard M. Nixon once told an aide to never bring that guy in here again. Gerald R. Ford dismissed him from the Cabinet. But James R. Schlesinger has a pivotal role in President Carter's Administration because of the same characteristics of intellectual zeal and moral fervor that so discomfited the two Republican Presidents.

title: REGENTS ARE SCORED ON INTEGRATION ISSUE
description: Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, the only black member of the New York State Board of Regents, charged yesterday that other board members were overwhelmingly hostile to integration and responsible for the failure to integrate Andrew Jackson High School in Cambria Heights, Queens. The high school's student body is 99 percent black.

title: Mansfield Is Endorsed for Tokyo
description: Washington, April 21With humor, accolades, and serious talk about America's policy in Asia, the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations approved today the nomination of its former leader, Mike Mansfield, to be Ambassador to Japan.

title: OldCrop Soybean Futures Climb By 17c but New Crops Are Steady
description: CHICAGO, April 21 (AP)Oldcrop soybean futures advanced by up to 17 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade today, but newcrop months closed about steady.

title: DR. DEMARCO SHOWS SLIDES DEFENDING WONDER DRUG
description: NEWARK, April 21 (UPI)  Dr. Peter T. DeMarco exhibited today slides of patients whose gangrenous limbs healed after they received treatments of his wonder drug, Procaine PVP.

title: Moscow Police Bar Two Russians From a Visiting American Family
description: MOSCOW, April 21The police today barred two Soviet citizens from visiting an American diplomatic family that had invited them to the embassy.

title: Why I Won't Run for Mayor
description: First, no one asked me. After that unimportant fact come the important reasons why I do not choose to run.

title: Operetta: Bubbly Offenbach
description: ANY OFFENBACH operetta is fun, and there was a big turnout Wednesday night at the Fashion Institute Theater, where the Village Light Opera Group's new production of La Vie Parisienne is being given. Everybody came expecting a good time, and nobody was disappointed. Nobody ever is when Offenbach receives a bubbling performance. And it did on this occasion.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)The Army said today that it planned the safe disposal of about 1.500 batches of obsolete chemical warfare agents some of them lethal, once used in training.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Thursday, April 21, 1977

title: Vermont Lottery Bill Voted
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., April 21 (AP)The state legislature took final action today to approve a lottery bill and sent it to Gov. Richard A. Snelling. He has said that he intends to sign the legislation.

title: Utilities in New York City Area Report Some Energy Savings in Effect Already
description: Utility companies in the New York metropolitan area said yesterday that homeinsulation programs and other energysaving measures proposed by President Carter were already in effect and that more would be instituted.

title: Books of The Times
description: FOR THE MOST SUBLIME horror reading, there never has been anything like Berlin for me in 1947, when they used to turn the city's electricity off for an hour or so at duskLichtsperre, they called it; that was an energy programand one got to curl up in an armchair by candlelight and read in the Modern Library giant Great Tales of Terror and the Supernatural stories such as Guy de Maupassant's The Horla or Oliver Onions's The Beckoning Fair One until the shadows seemed to be extruding bloody tentacles. One was young; one was morbid: one was confused about sex; one lacked taste and the faculty of incredulity. There never will be anything quite nice it still, one keeps trying to recapture the experience and gets not too bad a run for the money from these two thrillersMona Williams's The Messenger and Bob Ran dall's The Fan.

title: Art People
description: EQUIDISTANT in Pennsylvania between Nazareth, Bethlehem and Emmaus is Muhlenberg College. Muhlenberg is not large, as colleges go, but it thinks big. When it first thought of building an arts center, close to 10 years ago, its president Dr. John H. Morey, and his colleagues toured the country and made some lists and generally thought things over. Then it turned out that Philip Johnson's name was on top of all the lists.

title: Advertising
description: It would seem that with or without President Carter's proposed tax credit, the manufacturers of home insulation are in for a hot time. Even if Congress doesn't make insulating financially attractive, soaring fuel bills will.

title: Meadowlands Results
description: FIRST$7,000, pace, mile.

title: 10 Artists Downtown Have Open Door Policy
description: For the 10th consecutive year, artists who live and work in lower Manhattan will dispel the popular notion of the artist as recluse by flinging open the doors of their studios, which are in virtually all cases also their homes.

title: For Lindsay, Retirement Leaves Little Time for Leisure
description: Good morning, everybody, says the former Mayor of New York in a voice inappropriately cheery for the time of day, 5:35 A.M.

title: Penn Names Football Aide
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (AP) Thomas Duffy, an assistant backfield coach at Villanova, has been named offensive backfield assistant for the University of Pennsylvania. Duffy joined Villanova as an assistant in 1975.

title: House Ethics Panel Votes Criteria on Gifts, Spurred By Case of South Koreans
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)The House ethics committee, prompted by the scandal over gifts from a South Korean businessman, agreed today that Congressmen who accepted such cash or gifts could be punished even if no criminal act was involved.

title: A Night on Patrol for Illegal Mexican Aliens
description: EL PASO, April 21For Hector Sea, light is the worst enemy. Mr. Sea has remarkable eyes and he shields them, turning his head from the sudden glare of a flashlight, a cigarette lighter or an oncoming automobile. It would take only a second to lose the night vision acquired over several hours, and in Mr. Sea's job as a United States border patrol officer, night vision is almost everything.

title: CARTER DEMAGOGIC, PRAVDA WRITER SAYS
description: MOSCOW, April 21 (UPI)The Soviet press, in its first attack on President Carer, accused him today of sidestepping the demagogic promises to black voters that won him the 1976 election.

title: Winston Hanover's 2:01.4 Triumphs at Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L.I., April 21Winston Hanover, driven by John Chapman, posted the fastest trotting mile of the Roosevelt Raceway season tonight with a time of 2:01.4 in the $10,000 fifth race.

title: P.B.A. HEAD ASSERTS CITY WILL REHIRE 1,372 OFFICERS
description: Samuel DeMilia, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said last night that Mayor Beame planned to rehire 1,372 laidoff police officers with funds to be included in the new city budget that is to be made public today.

title: KEENY MAY BE GIVEN ARMS CONTROL POST
description: WASHINGTON, April 21President Carter was reported today likely to nominate Spurgeon Keeny Jr., a longtime arms control expert as the deputy chief of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.

title: Stadler 2 Shots Ahead
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 21 (UPI)  Craig Stadler, a former United States Amateur champion, birdied four of the first six holes today, then let wind and rain take care of his competitors as he led the field by twostrokes in the rainshortened first round of the $175,000 New Orleans open.

title: ABC Backs Arledge Amid Boxing Inquiry
description: While investigations continued yesterday into the suspended United States Boxing Championships, the president of ABC Television defended as exemplary his network's role in the situation.

title: Short Interest on Big Board, Amex Rose for the Month Ended April 15
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 1,269,128 shares in the month ended April 15 to 28,044,247 shares. The short interest or the year  earlier level totaled 24,728,133 shares.

title: Why Britons Emigrate
description: LONDON, April 21 (UPI)Lower living standards in Britain are causing many talented and experienced people to leave, a report by Overseas Recruitment Services Ltd. said today. The report said that higher salaries abroad, the British tax system and falling living standards were the main reasons why people leave.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The Emmy Award Citation Series University Broadcast lab

title: What Do You Drink With the Most Expensive Food in New York?
description: When you dine at the Palace, what do you drink with the most expensive food in New York? Easythe most expensive wine in New York. A meal at the Palace lasts so long that it is easy for four people to go through three bottles. On a recent visit we started with a bottle of Mayacamas Vineyards 1974 pinot chardonnay as an aperitif. Cost: $40.

title: It Was Italian Style, With a French Accent
description: Strollers along Fifth Avenue in the past week have noticed the same motif in the windows of banks, book stores and airline offices as in fashion shops. Piles of pasta, mockups of the leaning tower of Pisa and bits of red, white and green ribbonsometimes the Italian flaghave turned up from 34th to 58th Street.

title: Ronan Tells Carey He Wants to Quit;Goldmark Advanced for Port Post
description: Dr. William J. Ronan has informed Governor Carey that he wants to bow out as chairmanthe policy chiefof the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and Mr. Carey has put forward his Budget Director, Peter C. Goldmark Jr., to become the agency's administrative head, its executive director.

title: Top State Dept. Aide Likely to Visit Cuba for Talks
description: WASHINGTON, April 21Terence A. Todman, Assistant Secretary of State for InterAmerican Affairs, will probably fly to Havana soon to resume negotiations with Cuban officials on fishing regulations and maritime rights, Administration officials said today.

title: Ronan Is Reported Ready to Quit; Goldmark Advanced for Port Post
description: Dr. William J. Ronan has informed Governor Carey that he wants to bow out as chairmanthe policy chiefof the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and Mr. Carey has put forward his Budget Director, Peter C. Goldmark Jr., to become the agency's administrative head, its executive director.

title: Red Sox Are Up For Sale
description: BOSTON, April 21 (AP)The Boston Red Sox, owned by Tom Yawkey for 43 years until his death last July, were put up for sale by his widow today.

title: For Children
description: Films

title: E. F. Hutton, Bache Testifying at Inquiry On Coffee Futures
description: Two Wall Street brokerage houses said yesterday, in response to questions, that the Commodity Futures Trading Commission had subpoenaed some of their employees to testify about possible improprieties in the coffee futures market.

title: Rifts Occur on Albany Pay Pacts
description: ALBANY, April 21New York State and its largest publicemployees union were at odds today over what they had agreed to last weekend in contract negotiations that yielded a 14 percent raise over two years for union members and averted a strike Monday morning.

title: Television
description: Morning 6: 10(2,7)News

title: John Washington Rallies For Forerunner Victory
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 2 (AP)John Washington, a Kentucky Derby hopeful, rallied from next to last in a field of seven today to capture the $15,000 Forerunner Purse at Keeneland.

title: President's Son Officiates At Lake Placid Ceremony
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., April 21 (UPI) Pledging his father's total support for the Games, Chip Carter broke the first ground today for the 1980 Winter Olympics in this Adirondack Mountain village. Carter, at the controls of a backhoe, ripped up a large chunk of sod on the site of a speedskating rink for the Games.

title: Antiques
description: WHEN THE SouthportWestport Antiques Show opens this morning at the Fairfield County Hunt Club in Westport, Conn., painted furniture will once again be very much in evidence, brightening this popular, threeday event for country furnishings enthusiasts.

title: HIGH COURT REPORTED TO OPPOSE A REVIEW OF NIXON AIDES' CASE
description: WASHINGTON, April 21The Supreme Court was reported today to have voted 5 to 3 last Friday to refuse to review the convictions of John N. Mitchell, H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman in the Watergate coverup case.

title: Moon Church Supporter Charges Coast Parents With Kidnapping
description: ROSS, Calif., April 21 (UPI)A 20year old follower of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon has brought kidnapping charges against her parents.

title: The U.S. and Korea
description: TOKYO  Two developments have attracted our attention. One is a recent press conference given by President Carter in which he reaffirmed his plan to withdraw troops and nuclear weapons from South Korea. Another is the confirmation of his Government's willingness to approach the Democratic People's Republic of Korea.

title: Alcoholism Gets Health Coverage As an Illness Under Trenton Bills
description: TRENTON, April 21The State Senate passed today and sent to Governor Byrne a package of bills that will include alcoholism among illnesses eligible for hospital and medical insurance benefits under Blue CrossBlue Shield and other healthinsurance programs in New Jersey.

title: Jobless Clash With Police at Tent City at Foley Sq.
description: Unemployed workers clashed with the police yesterday as officers tore down a symbolic tent city in Foley Square Park in lower Manhattan. The workers had set up the tents in a demonstration against cuts in Federal unemployment benefits.

title: Nader Feels Carter Overplayed Sacrifice
description: ADRIAN, Mich., April 21 (UPI)President Carter exaggerated the sacrifices that Americans will be asked to make in the name of energy conservation, Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, said today.

title: U.S. ASSURES EUROPE IT WON'T CURB TRADE
description: BRUSSELS, April 21The Carter. Administration today assured America's trading partners in Western Europe that it would strongly oppose domestic pressure to restrict imports, particularly pressure for further curbs on European steel.

title: Thai General Is Shot Without Trial for Leading Coup
description: BANGKOK. Thailand, April 21Thailand's ruling military junta today executed a senior army general accused of plotting an unsuccessful coup and ordered four other military men imprisoned for life.

title: Senators Retain Business Credits In Tax Bill Despite Carter's Stand
description: WASHINGTON, April 21A vote in the Senate today virtually assured business of getting some form of tax break in the economic stimulus package, despite a shift in President Carter's tactics.

title: Donald R. Young, 78, Author, Sociologist And Director of Russell Sage Foundation
description: Donald R. Young, a sociologist and a former director of the Russrll Sage Foundation, died last Sunday at the Sacred Heart Hospital in Allentown, Pa. He was 78 years old and lived in Macungie, Pa., where he was born.

title: Cashew Crisis: Indians Delay Shipments
description: The cashew nut industry in the United States has a deliveryor, more accurately, a lackofdeliveryproblem with roots that stretch to India and Tanzania. Even the Soviet Union may be involved in the cashew affairor so say importers and brokers who are bracing for potential losses of up to $7 million.

title: Proposal to Relax Turkey Arms Ban Meets Resistance
description: WASHINGTON, April 21The Carter Administration's proposal to relax a 1975 embargo on United States military aid for Turkey encountered strong opposition today on Capitol Hill.

title: Dance: Wendy Perron Presents Suite and Quartet at Cunningham
description: It was the simplicity of Wendy Perron's concert that contributed so strongly to its immediate appeal. She offered two pieces Wednesday evening at the Merce Cunningham Studio that used Straightforward jumps, slides and turns that had an innocent athletic joy.

title: News Summary
description: In a reversal, the Carter Administration said that the energy program would have no significant effect on the country's economic growth. The retraction, by Bert Lance, director of the Office of Management and Budget, replaced and contradicted part of an energy fact sheet released Wednesday predicting small, but generally positive impacts on the economy from the energy program. Economists, meanwhile, continued to argue that the program would mean more inflation, less employment and less growth. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Uncertainties of Energy Outlook Help Depress Dow Average 6.79
description: Selling pressure hit the stock market yesterday as numerous bigname issuesincluding I.B.M., Eastern Kodak and Sears, Roebucktraded at their lowest prices of 1977.

title: Bell Promises to Seek Legislation To Curb Illegal Border Traffic
The Show at the Copacabana Brings In The Kids and fiends In the Clowns
description: It's not that the new Copacabana looks so different these days from the famed old nightclub of the past. Palm fronds are everywhere and colored lights still blink on and off. The face of the Copa girl, with her heavily lidded eyes and mop of orange curls, still adorns the bandstand. But instead of a line of strutting longlegged chorus girls, Copa audiences this Saturday and Sunday afternoon will witness the antics of a gaggle of circus clowns who go under the name of the Pixie Judy Troupe.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest, said it was studying possible price increases in a broad range of products to cover the cost of a new contract with the United Steelworkers Union.

title: Ballet: A Contrast For Baryshnikov
description: THE AIR of expectation hanging like pink mist over the Metropolitan Opera House was probably not prompted by the American Ballet Theater's first mixedrepertory program of the eightweek season, but rather the first appearance this season of Mikhail Baryshnikov dancing in contrasted roles in Petipa's La Bayadre and Glen Tetley's Le Sacre du Printemps.

title: Nevada Sheriff Pleads Not Guilty To Income Tax Evasion Charges
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 21 (AP)The Clark County Sheriff, Ralph Lamb, pleaded not guilty today to Federal charges of attempting to evade more than $34,000 in income tax payments.

title: 22 SOCIAL AGENCIES CLOSE THEIR CENTERS
description: Twentytwo agencies, including Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Associations and community and elderly people's centers, ceased operations yesterday because of a union dispute involving 450 employees.

title: Kingston Salutes the State
description: The city of Kingston, halfway up the Hudson River between New York City and Albany, is throwing a 200th birthday party for New York State this weekend, with the public invited.

title: Merrill Lynch & Co. Discloses Payments
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, parent company of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. announced yesterday that it and its 50 percentowned subsidiary, Metal Traders Inc., had made questionable foreign payments. In a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission, the companw said that its payments totaled $74,100 over a fiveyear period, while Metal Traders paid out more than $106,000 and engaged in underbillings and overbillings.

title: Fatal Tornado Strikes Louisiana
description: NINA, La., April 21 (UPI)A tornado today killed one person, injured three ethers and damaged 15 homes, the St. Martin Parish sheriff's department said Heavy flooding struck elsewhere in Louisiana as a result of threeday torrential rains, causing one other death.

title: Critics in Congress Take Cues From Constituents, Objecting Strongly to an Increase in Gasoline Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, April 21From oilstate senators to representatives from suburban commuter districts, critics in Congress of President Carter's energy program took their themes from their constituencies today, even if occasionally they framed them in teems of broader concepts.

title: American Exchange Bond Trading
description: viin bankruptcy or receivership or being reorganized under the Bankruptcy Act, securities assumed by such companies. xiEx Interest, cfCertificates. stStamped, fDealt in flat. xMatured bonds, negotiability impaired by maturity. ndNext day delivery. xwEx warrants. inForeign issue subject to Interest equalization tax. cvConvertible bond.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Butts, Banks in Triple Jump
description: WALNUT, Calif., April 21 (UPI) James Butts, who won a silver medal at Montreal, and Willie Banks, who recently set a University of California, Los Angeles, record at 55 feet 2 inches, will head the triple jump field at the Mount San Antonio Relays Saturday. Other top competitors include Tom Woods of the Pacific Coast Club, Reynaldo Brown of the AllAmerican Track Club and Ron Livers of San Jose State in the high jump and Don Baird of Long Beach State and Kjell Isaksson of the Tobias Striders in the pole vault.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: It must have been heartwrenching to be there. Five young followers of Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church were freed from the custody of their parents by an appeals court in San Francisco.

title: Albany Aides CancelGambling Night Fete
description: ALBANY, April 21A group of legislative secretaries and aides today hastily canceled plans to include gambling at their Bosses Night in New Orleans dinner dance next Monday. Games of chance were advertised for the annual affair at a local hotel sponsored by the Republican Women in the legislature, an even customarily attended by many Senators and Assemblymen of both political parties.

title: Rep. Rosenthal Renews Proposal For 11 P.M. Curfew at La Guardia
description: WASHINGTON, April 21Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens, sought to have flights banned after 11 P.M. again today at La Guardia Airport. He did so as the House aviation subcommittee pondered a new bill to curb excessive noise at the nation's airports.

title: Management
description: A week ago yesterday, they went together to the mountaintopthe businessmen, the lawyers, the legislators, the, judges, professors, and indeed a rabbi. After four days, however, instead of descending with new tablets of moral commandments, they brought down from the mountain what amounts to the first draft of a new constitution for corporations.

title: MONEY SUPPLY DATA UPSETS BOND PRICES
description: Bond prices dropped sharply late yesterday afternoon after the Federal Reserve disclosed that the nation's money supply  after quarterly revisionsrose $900 million to an estimated $321.2 billion in the week ended April 13. To many dealers, especially those who had been predicting a decrease in the total, the steppedup pace of growth in the money supply was a strong signal that the Fed may shortly move to slow down what it regards as excessive nearterm monetary expansion.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney reports that the uncertainty over reactions and eventual legislative decisions on the President's moves on energy, economic stimulus and inflation control is likely to cloud the economic outlook for some time. Pane D9.

title: Notes on People
description: The neighbors complained so the Federal Government has ordered Billy Carter to clean up the debris around his Plains. Ga., service station to meet health and safety requirements. In Washington the Occupational Safety and Health Administration of the Labor Department said yesterday that the President's younger brother had been cited for violations on housekeeping and safety.

title: Proposed Tax and Rebate Scale for New Cars
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)The following table shows the range of taxes and rebates on the purchase of new automobiles, as proposed last night by President Carter in his energy message to Congress.

title: Music: Minnesotans Led Through Familiar Paces
description: WITH FOUR centuries of orchestral music to draw upon, concert planners still manage to give us the same works over and over. Last week at the New York Philharmonic, we had the Bruch Violin Concerto No. 1 in G minor and Wednesday night, the Minnesota Orchestra brought the same piece to Carnegie Hall. Also on the Minnesota program was Berlioz's Symphonie Fantastique, which the Buffalo Philharmonic is scheduled to perform in the same hall. The Mahler Fourth Symphony, another Buffalo offering, was done only last Sunday at Carnegie Hall.

title: Monetary Expansion Accelerates; Rise in Federal Funds Rate Seen
description: Monetary expansion is accelerating, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday. The $6.2 billion increase in M1, the narrowly defined money supply, and the $8.5 billion increase in the broader M2 indicator in the latest two weeks, appear to put the growth rates in these aggregates toward the upper end of the band that the central bank has indicated it is willing to tolerate.

title: Drag Racer Killed in Crash
description: PEWAUKEE, Wis., April 21 (AP)  A drag racer whose car held eight world speed records was killed last night in a crash at a gravel pit near here. Jerry D. Helm, 31 years old, died when the rocket dragster he had built crashed into the side of the gravel pit. The throttle apparently became stuck while Hehn and his associates were testing the engine. The American Dream had set speed records in the unlimited class at the Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A gun used in the ambush slaying of John Iardiere, a reputed mobster, has been traced to a Fort Lee man indicted on charges of illegally buying a cache of guns in Florida, law enforcement officials said. The defendant, Frank J. Viserto, Jr., 30 years old, was arraigned in Federal court here for illegal possession of a different weapon, one that Federal agents found when Mr. Viserto was arrested at his Fort Lee apartment last month.

title: Moscow Science Seminar Is Convened Unofficially With Little Interference
description: MOSCOW, April 21An unofficial threeday symposium organized by Jewish scientists seeking to emigrate was successfully held this week with some surveillance but no interference by the authorities.

title: Test for Congress
description: WASHINGTON, April 21President Carter has had his say on the energy crisis, and the issue now moves to the political cockpit of Congress, with its new leadership, and to the arena of public opinion. Here there is general agreement about the President's ends and a tangle of disagreements about his means.

title: Dollar and Sterling Decline in Europe; Price of Gold Drops
description: BRUSSELS, April 21 (UPI)The dollar weakened today on what London dealers described as profit taking after two days of gains. The pound also turned downward.

title: Profits Climb for Alcoa and Alcan; U.S. Concern's $48.9 Million a High
description: The world's two major aluminum producersthe Aluminum Company of America and Alcan Aluminium Ltd. of Canadareported yesterday huge gains in firstquarter earnings as sales for both rose well above the depressed levels of a year ago.

title: Rate of Inflation Eased in March; Prices Up 0.6%
description: WASHINGTON, April 21The nation's inflation rate slowed in March, partly as a result of somewhat smaller price increases for food, the Labor Department reported today.

title: French Legislator Dead at 33
description: PARIS, April 21 (AP)Aymeric SimonLoriere, 33 years old, France's youngest Member of Parliament when he was elected in 1973, was found dead in his Paris apartment today. Parliamentary sources said he committed suicide. Mr. SimonLoriere, a Gaullist, was critically injured in an auto accident in December 1975, but appeared to have made a good recovery.

title: Carter News Parley On at 10 A. M. Today
description: The three television networks and their local stations  Channels 2, 4, and 7will provide live coverage of President Carter's news conference today, which is scheduled to begin at 10 A.M. Channel 13 will rebroadcast the proceedings at 6:30 this evening.

title: 3M Reports 25.8% Rise in Profits On 13% Gain in Sales for Quarter
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company yesterday reported a 25.8 percent increase in firstquarter profits on a 13 percent gain in sales. The diversified producer of tapes, adhesive chemicals, graphic systems and electric products said net income was $86.7 million or 75 cents a share, a record for the first quarter. The income figures conspared with $68.9 million or 60 cents a share a year ago.

title: EUROPE AHEAD OF U.S. IN CONSERVING FUELS
description: PARIS, April 21France and several other major industrial nations have already established energy conservation programs similar to that proposed by President Carter for the United States.

title: Unveiling
description: FEIGENBERGMaurice Unveiling will be held at Beth David Cemetery. Elmont, N.Y., on April 24 at 12:30 P.M. First Yezlerianer Society; E8 Row j No. 6.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: *As reported; not adjusted for transfers of loans to affiliated companies.

title: WHITE HOUSE SHIFTS, SAYS ENERGY PLANS WON'T AID ECONOMY
description: WASHINGTON, April 21In a surprise reversal, the Carter Administration said today that the energy program proposed yesterday would have no significant effect on economic growth.

title: Where Strings Are Wailing
description: After six months of rehearsals and private showcases in Manhattan living rooms and synagogue halls, a new chamber orchestra called Strings in Exile, composed of 15 SovietJewish migrs, will have its first public performance in New York, on Sunday at 8 P.M. in Temple Israel, 112 East 75th Street.

title: F.B.I. Agents Subpoenaed in New Haven Wiretapping Investigation
description: NEW HAVEN, April 21About a dozen people, including present and former agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, have been subpoenaed by the New Haven Police Commission as part of its investigation into alleged illegal wiretapping by the police between 1966 and 1971, sources close to the investigation said today.

title: Sports
description: Friday

title: Publishing: A Touch of The Pulitzer
description: AT 6:30 in the morning of the day after the news came by telephone this week informing him that he had won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry, James Merrill went to work as usualat home in Stonington, Conn., writing a poem.

title: In Memoriam
description: MILLERJonathan Ira. Your 23d birthday, killed at 22 years. Miss YouMom, Dad, Susan.

title: HACKENSACK DELAYS ON BATTERED WOMEN
description: HACKENSACK, April 21City officials put off strict enforcement today of a court order limiting the occupancy of a shelter for socalled battered women after some women and children left the refuge while local welfare officials sought to relocate others.

title: Homes for the Unadoptable
description: The drop in the birth rate over the past twenty years has brought the number of adoptable children almost to the vanishing point. But there are still tens of thousands of children in need of the love and care that adoptive parents can provide. The problem is that they are not adoptable by the old standards established by social agencies.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: BHUTTO PUTS 3 CITIES UNDER MARTIAL LAW
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 21The Government of Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, cracking down hard on the people who have been trying to force his resignation, tonight assumed emergency powers and imposed martial law on three major cities.

title: Jersey Indians Triumph
description: JERSEY CITY, April 21 (AP)Jim Clancy of the Indians tossed a threehit shutout to lead the Jersey Indians to a 20 victory over the Holyoke Millers in an Easttrn League game tonight. The Indians scored their runs in the third inning when Kris Yoder walked. German de los Santos doubled and Benny Heise walked to load the bases. The Indians' center fielder, Gary Hancock, drove in both runs with a single. Clancy struck out 11.

title: Wow of a Bow
description: An anonymouslooking dog named Sandy is the only member of the cast of Annie to get cab fare from his home in Greenwich Village to the Alvin Theater. Sandy plays Little Orphan Annie's dog, Sandythe reason he got his name was that he had none when the production found him last summer at the humane society's animal shelter in Newington, Conn.

title: Dunne's Panel Refuses to Vote Out His NoFault Bill
description: ALBANY, April 21The State Senate Committee on Insurance, in a highly unusual rebuff, refused today to vote out a nofault automobile insurance bill sponsored by its chairman, John R. Dunne, Republican of Garden City, L.I.

title: People in Sports
description: Joe McCarthy, one of baseball's finest managers, celebrated his 90th birthday yesterday at his home in Amherst, N.Y., just outside Buffalo.

title: Readership Studied On Long Island Press
description: About 69 percent of the readers of the now defunct Long Island Press were reading other area dailies, according to the Market Audience Potential of New York study released yesterday by Three Sigma.

title: Some Experts View Elasticity of Demand. As Key to Success in Carter's Energy Plan
description: Many economic and energy experts expressed concern yesterday that President Carter may have been too optimistic in setting his goals for 1985a 10 percent reduction in gasoline use, together with a cut in the annual growth of energy consumption to 2 percent or less a year from 4.6 percent.

title: With Coach's Job Secure, Boys High Runners Continue on Victory Path
description: It's been difficult: at times it's bean dreadful, says Jim Jackson, the track ??oath at Boys and Girls High in Brook??, on his hard struggle to keep on ??aching so he can keep on coaching. When Boys won the Public Schools Athletic League indoor title last month it seemed as if the track program would disappear, for the coach was about to lose his job. But with the aid of Bernard R. Gifford, the deputy chancellor of the city's schools, Jackson wound up with ?? teaching job and the Kangaroos' track prograrn wound up with a glimmer of hope.

title: U.S. Giving SolarHeating Grants To Homeowners in 3State Area
description: The owners of more than 3,300 homes in New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut will each receive Federal grants of $400 for installing solar water heaters over the next eight months.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Students Get to Know the Elderly
description: Sadie Hertz, who is 76 years old and lives in a middleclass Bronx neighborhood, said that if she had bumped into Andre Ronon, 17, a Dwitt Clinton High School student, on the street a few weeks ago, she would have thought it was a pursesnatching.

title: A Rally Seeks to Save Grand Central Terminal
description: With Cornelius Vanderbilt gazing down from a pedestal, Jacqueline Onassis, Mayor Beame and former Mayor Robert F. Wagner joined actors, singers and thousands of New Yorkers in front of Grand Central Terminal at lunchtime yesterday to urge that the 64yearold building be preserved.

title: DeRose Becomes 11th Democrat Seeking Nomination f or Governor
description: Ralph DeRose, a member of the Bistate Waterfront Commission and a former State Senator, became the 11th Democratic candidate for Governor yesterday.

title: Wallace Considers a Senate Race While Behaving Like a Candidate
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 21The fourth graders filed into his office, their eyes filing on wall plaques and colorful flags to avoid the sight of his legs, immobile in the shiny steel wheelchair.

title: New York City Is Getting Tougher On Companies Planning to Leave
description: The Mayor's Office of Economic Development is toughening its tactics against corporations seeking to leave the city and is trying to block Federal highway funds for road improvements that make remote suburban sites usable for office centers.

title: In Delis, 2d Ave. Is a Palace
description: Martin Schloss was deep in cole slaw one recent Saturday night when he looked up and saw Abe Lebewohl, owner of the Second Avenue Delicatessen. Mr. Schloss lives on the West Side, and before he can get to the Second Avenue he must trek across blighted, deliless wastes. When are you going to open a West Side branch? he asked.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday reported incorrectly that Claude Arpels, the president of VanCleef & Arpels jewelers, had admitted giving an Internal Revenue Service agent jewelry valued at $14,000, Mr. Arpels valued the gifts at $1,400.

title: Jim Farley, the Man in the Middle
description: ABC Sports has hired a private eye to investigate ABC's own boxing tournament; charges of faking fighters' records, slicing up their purses and stealing them away from their managers are flying around like rice at a wedding; Don King, the demon promoter whose United States Championships are under a large dark cloud, has suspended three of his employees, and caught in the crossfire is James A. Farley Jr., the man in the middle. Because he has cooperated by appointing ring officials, arranging for medical protection of the fighters and enforcement of rules, the chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission being accused of conflict of interest in unofficial quarters. The first edition of yesterday's New York Daily News reported that former lightheavyweight champion Jose Torres is considered a likely replacement if Farley exits, meaning if Governor Carey fired Jim from his $35,000ayear job. For later editions the story was rewritten with no mention of Farley.

title: Taking Back the Met's Mink
description: The controversy over Walter Annenberg's proposal for a fine arts center at the Metropolitan Museum is moot now, but acrimony lingers. In a letter to Mayor Beame, Douglas Dillon, the Met's president, laid the blame for Mr. Annenberg's withdrawal on the unreasoned suspicions and hostility of a vocal minority. Annoyed at the implication that the city didn't do all it might have to smooth the path of the proposed center, Mayor Beame and Martin E. Segal, the chairman of the city's Commission for Cultural Affairs, have suggested that Mr. Annenberg decided to take back his $40 million offer for reasons of his own even before the publication of his ultimatum last month demanding overwhelming support from city officials.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Immigration Chief Is Approved
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today President Carter's nomination of Leonel J. Castillo, Houston city comptroller, to be Immigration and Naturalization Commissioner.

title: BHUTTO PUTS 3 CITIES UNDER MARTIAL LAW
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 21The Government of Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, cracking down hard on the people who have been trying to force his resignation, tonight assumed emergency powers and imposed martial law on three major cities.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Dr. John W. Kneller, the president of Brooklyn College, said no formal charges would be lodged against Prof. Michael I. Selzer, a political scientist who said last January that he was connected with the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Summit in London Seen as an Impetus To Talks on Trade
description: GENEVA, April 21Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's special representative for trade negotiations, said today that he expected the summit conference the President is to attend in London next month would give a rew sense of urgency to the stalled world trade talks.

title: Art: Giants of Photography
description: ALTHOUGH the notion persists that photography is somehow a new or a recent interest of the art world, there is an abundant and interesting history to the contrary. In New York, after all, the very first major dealer in modernist painting and sculpture in this century Alfred Stieglitzwas himself a master photographer who showed photographs alongside the works of Picasso, Matisse and Brancusi. And the Museum of Modern Art, founded here in 1929, early on embraced photography as an integral part of its exhibition program.

title: Teaneck School Board Eases Curb on Events Scheduled on Sabbaths
description: TEANECK, N.J., April 21A sixweekold policy to restrict extracurricular school activities on the Christian and Jewish Sabbaths was replaced today by a scheduling policy calling for maximum sensitivity for all students without reference to the Sabbaths.

title: Utilities in Metropolitan Area Report EnergySaving
description: Utility companies in the New York metropolitan area said yesterday that homeinsulation programs and other energysaving measures proposed by President Carter were already in effect and that more would be instituted.

title: The Asian Development Bank Sounds a Somber Note
description: MANILA, April 21The Asian Development Bank, marking its 10th anniversary at the opening of its annual meeting here today, heard a sober assessment by its president that the region's mounting needs were outstripping efforts to meet them.

title: A.C.L.U. Suit Cites Honeywell, F.B.I.
description: The American Civil Liberties Union, as expected, filed a lawsuit yesterday against Honeywell Inc. and the Federal Bureau of Investigation on behalf of individuals and political and religious groups that were opposed to Honeywell's production of antipersonnel weapons in the early 1970's.

title: Dance: A Classic By Limon Troupe
description: THT JOSE LIMON Danceo Company took the unusual step Wednesday night at the Roundabout Theater of giving the company premiere of an international classic.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 22, 1977

title: Utilities Having Second Thoughts on Coal From West
description: WASHINGTON, April 21If President Carter's energy proposals become law, some of the nation's major electric utilities are going to be left with an unwanted home on the range, according to industry sources.

title: Judson Poets to Stage Opera by Gertrude Stein
description: A Manoir, a new opera taken from a play written by Gertrude Stein in 1932, will be staged by the Judson Poets' Theater tomorrow, Sunday and Monday at 8 P.M. in the Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South.

title: FoodDay Dinner at the White House Offers the Meat of Controversy
description: WASHINGTON, April 21I'd like the recipe, said Senator Mark O. Hatfield, the Oregon Republican, as he took a sip of the blackbean soup at the controversial meatless White House dinner tonight. The first thing my wife is going to say is Well, did you get the recipe?

title: Seattle Slew 15 for Wood
description: Seattle Slew was pronounced in perfect shape, as befits a 15 morningline favorite after a halfmile workout yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Canada Downs U.S. Six, 41, in World Hockey
description: VIENNA, April 21 (AP)Canada downed the United States, 41, tonight in a ragged game as the two countries started their bids for the world ice hockey championship.

title: Mrs. Carter's Mental Health Drive Has Tight Budget
description: WASHINGTON, April 21As Rosalynn Carter stepped off a chartered bus in Chicago, a medical student was waving a picket sign: Mrs. Carter, we will improve mental health care if we ever get the chance.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI)In what could be a key to understanding the cause of alcoholism, a scientist today reported finding a substance that apparently promoted excessive drinking by rats when injected into the animals brains.

title: Dance: Ideas Surpass Kinetics
description: Shirley Ririe and Joan Woodbury are two names well known in the dance world for their role in the growth of modern dance in the West. After working together since 1957, they formed the RirieWoodbury Dance Company at the University of Utah in 1964. In 1966, Miss Woodbury helped form the Utah Repertory Dance Theater, a collective established by the Rockefeller Foundation.

title: Celtics. Box Score
description: Technical foul76ers Coach Shun

title: Kings Scoring
description: FIRST PERIOD1, Boston, Middleton(McNab,. Cashman), 3:42; .2, Boston, Jonathan 4 (O'Reilly), 7:35; 3, Boston, Middleton 4 (Milbury, Mr.Nab), 7:46. PenaltiesO'Reilly, Bos, 17:26; Wilson, LA, 17:26.

title: MAIL LAW VIOLATIONS ARE CHARGED TO A.M.A.
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP)The Postal Service has accused the American Medical Association of illegally underpaying its postal bills by more than a million dollars and has asked for the money by Monday.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the review of the new musical Annie yesterday, the role of Molly, played by 7yearold Danielle Brisebois, was incorrectly attributed in some editions to Shelley Bruce, 12 years old, who plays the part of Kate.

title: Pressed by U.S., New York City Plans Rise in Minority Teachers
description: The New York City Board of Education, responding to a Federal charge of discriminatory personnel practices, yesterday proposed broad changes to bring more teachers from racial minorities into the school system and to avoid their concentration in community school districts that are heavily composed of minority members.

title: World and Labor Issues Dominate Annual Meeting Of Manufacturers Hanover
description: International and domestic issues dominated yesterday's annual meeting of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, highlighted by a protest by union members against J.P. Stevens & Company policies.

title: Bell Asks High Court to Uphold Dayton School Order
description: WASHINGTON, April 22The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to uphold a courtordered desegregation plan in the public schools of Dayton, Ohio, that has extensive busing.

title: ExAgent Subpoenaed in Spy Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, April 22Federal District Judge Robert Kelleher issued a subpoena today to Victor L. Marchetti, the former Central Intelligence Agency officer who wrote a book disclosing some of the agency's secrets, ordering him to testify at the espionage trial of Christopher J. Boyce.

title: 9,400 New City Workers to Be Hired
description: Mayor Beame's budget for 1978 envisions a small increase in the total number of city workers, the first gain after three years of cuts, which will enable New York City to halt the erosion of services that is a legacy of the fiscal crisis.

title: Books of The Times
description: Peter Quennell has been a part of the English literary scene for as long as most people can remember: since 1922. that is to say, when at the age of 17 he was included in the last of Edward Marsh's thenfamous anthologies of Georgian Verse. Had he died at 21 or 22, he would scrape into the biographical dictionaries as a shortlived poet of promise.

title: Assad Concludes Soviet Visit
description: MOSCOW,April 22 (UPI)  President Hafez alAssad of Syria concluded a fiveday state visit to the Soviet Union today and flew home from Tbilisi in the Soviet republic of Georgia. Mr. Assad spent two days in consultation with top Soviet leaders in Moscow early this week and then toured Kiev and Tbilisi.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: By The Associated Press

title: Bill Would Broaden New York's DeathPenalty Law
description: ALBANY, April 22A bill to bring New York's deathpenalty statute into conformance with the latest United States Supreme Court ruling and to expand its application to those who commit murder by arson or terrorist bombing was introduced in the Assembly today.

title: People in Business
description: C. Fred Bergsten, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, asserted yesterday that the Carter Administration wanted to promote greater progress in the developing world and to maintain an open trading system. The economy of the United States has become inextricably intertwined with the world economy, he said in a speech to the Chicago Council of Foreign Relations.

title: Dollar Gains and Pound Slips in Trading Abroad; Gold Rallies After Losses
description: BRUSSELS, April 22 (UPI)The dollar gained slightly on most European markets today, while the British pound eased.

title: Events/Sports
description: 1:55 P.M., WMCA: Baseball. Yankees vs. Cleveland.

title: Barber and Stadler Share TwoStroke Lead at 66
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 22 (AP)Miller Barber blasted out of a bunker directly into the hole on the 17th green today, carded a sixunderpar 66 and gained a tie for the firstround lead in the $175,000 New Orleans open.

title: Novelist's Suit Charges Roots Copied Parts of Her 1966 Book
description: One of the nation's most respected black writers filed a copyright infringement suit against Alex Haley yesterday, charging that unspecified portions of his acclaimed book Roots had been largely copied from her novel on black life in Georgia in the Civil War era.

title: Engineer of Train Injured Badly By Stone Thrown in Mamaroneck
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., April 22The engineer of a New Haven train was critically injured here last night when a stone shattered the windshield of his moving train and struck him in the forehead, fracturing his skull.

title: Personal Investing
description: Though electric utility stocks have been outperforming the market as a whole so far this year, there has been no great rush of investor money into them, despite the prospect of taxsheltered current income in some cases.

title: Energy Plan Hits Home in Dayton: Crisis Was Real
description: DAYTON, Ohio, April 22it didn't take much for President Carter's proposed energy program to hit home here.

title: LightWave Communications
description: An improvement in a telecommunications system that uses lightwave impulses sent through hairthin glass fibers has been patented by scientists at the Bell Telephone Laboratories. The patent covers more efficient regenerators, used to keep the light pulses constant in size. Page 27.

title: The Enshrinement of George Washington Carver...
description: More than 200 years after Crispus Attucks died in the Boston Massacre and more than 100 years after the Abolitionist activism of Sojourner Truth, the black population of the Hall of Fame for Great Americans will double todayto a total of two.

title: In Jail, Thinking About the Children
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  Jerome and Frida are not yet two and three years old. 1 am serving three months in jail. By state law, no one under the age Of 16 may enter these premises. Frida seems to understand a great deal. She has seen others in the community go into jail, has known why they were there, has welcomed them home: But until now, no one has been jailed for three months and, when a child has lived short of two or three years, three months is a terrible slice of its life.

title: Singer
description: The Singer Company, which has shown a sharp recovery since the disposal of unprofitable operations, reported yesterday an increase of 20.5 percent in firstquarter net income of $18.8 million, or

title: 4,000 Palestinians Are Told to Move To South Lebanon
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon, April 22  Four thousand Palestinians who were driven out of a refugee camp here during the Lebanese civil war and lodged in a village just south of Beirut have now been ordered to move to the southern part of the country.

title: Dance: Limon Offers G String
description: Doris Humphrey's Work Has Proud Assertiveness as Performed by the Company at Roundtable

title: Notes on People
description: A top Australian rule football player in the 1930's and later a leader of the Church of Christ in Australia, Sir Douglas Nicholls became the first aborigine to be knighted for services to his people. Four mouths ago he became Australia's first aboriginal state Governor. Yesterday, Sir Douglas, who is 70 years old, and suffered a heart attack in January, announced his resignation as Governor because of ill health.

title: Carter Reports Some Stabilizing Of Military Status in South Zaire
description: WASHINGTON,April 22President Carter said today that his Administration had observed some stabilizing of the military situation in southern Zaire.

title: The Last of a Militant Band
description: When Harry Bridges steps down as leader of the West Coast longshoremen at their union convention in Seattle today, his retirement will take from the active labor scene the last of the militant band that joined with John L. Lewis four decades ago in a successful crusade for industrial unionism in steel, autos and other bastions of antiunionism. All the members of that resolute groupPhilip Murray, David Dubinsky, Sidney Hillman and a dozen otherscontributed much to changing the national power balance in economic, social and political affairs.

title: Press Club Elects Bragg
description: Joseph Bragg, a WHN radio newsman, has been elected president of the New York Press Club. Mr. Bragg, the first radio newsman elected to the club's presidency, succeeds Patrick Muldowney, formerly with WABCTV.

title: Hofstra Trustees Accept Law Dean's Resignation Despite Withdrawal
description: HEMPSTEAD,April 22Despite a plea that he be allowed to withdraw it, Hofstra University's board of trustees voted unanimously tonight to accept the resignation of Monroe Freedman, the dean of the Law School. The resignation was made effective immediately instead of Aug. 31, as Mr. Freedman had originally requested.

title: Special Olympics: An Example for All Third Parents
description: In Plainfield yesterday, mentally retarded children ran, jumped, twirled hula hoops, threw balls, and won lots of medals and kind words in the process. It was all part of a growing movement, Special Olympic, designed to foster physical and emotional incentive that makes the ultimate competition worthwhile. The third parents? The agencies that help raise the children.

title: 76ersTriumph, 109 100; Go Up by 2 1
description: BOSTON, April 22With 53 seconds remaining in tonight's game, Joe Bryant embraced Coach Gene Shue, Julius Erving hugged Lloyd Free, and Jack McMahon, the assistant coach, did a little dance with Darryl Dawkins.

title: Allen M. Look, a Retired Lawyer, Martha's Vineyard Conservationist
description: Allen M. Look, a corporate lawyer who retired in 1967 as a vice president and counsel of West PointPepperell, a New York City textile company, died yesterday at the age of 74 in Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a short illness. He lived in West Tisbury on Martha's Vineyard, Mass., where he was a selectman.

title: Going From London to Geneva
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (Reuters)President Carter said at his news conference today that he would meet President Assad in Geneva after he attended a sevennation economic summit meeting in London next month.

title: Closed End Funds
description: Friday, April 22, 1977

title: WITNESS ON F.A.L N. FIGHTING A SUBPOENA
description: A Federal District Court judge in Manhattan heard arguments yesterday on a motion to quash a subpoena for a witness in a grand jury's investigation of terrorist bombings attributed to a Puerto Rican nationalist group known as the F.A.L.N.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 22 (AP)Attorney General William J. Brown asked today that Columbia Gas of Ohio be prohibited from paying dividends to its parent company, the Columbia Gas System, until it corrected what Mr. Brown said were 40 major inadequacies in its service to Ohioans.

title: Judge Names Longtime Friend of Groucho Marx And a Bank the Comedian's Conservators for Now
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 22Nat Perrin, a screenwriter, and the Bank of America were named temporary conservators today for comedian Groucho Marx.

title: A Referendum Is Scheduled for Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, April 22 (AP)Maj. Gen. Ziaur Rahman announced tonightless than 24 hours after he took Over as President of Bangladeshthat a referendum would be held May 13 to seek a mandate leading toward a democratic government.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two Brooklyn men who were charged with killing an offduty patrolman have been freed by Justice Nicholas Tsoucalas in Brooklyn District Supreme Court, where they were scheduled to face a fifth trial on murder charges. Three earlier trials ended in hung juries and a fourth ended in conviction that was overturned on appeal. Justice Tsoucalas declared in dismissing the indictments against Lester Lee, 32 years old, and William Rose, 34, for the slaying of Patrolman Elijah Stroud on March 18, 1972, that the public interest does not equate conviction with justice.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: CAUTION IS ADVISED ON INSULATION WORK
description: President Carter's proposals for a tax credit for those who improve the insulation of their homes or who add solar equipment for heating or cooling purposes brought a word of caution yesterday for New Jersey homeowners from Man K. Levin, directordesignate of the State Division of Consumer Affairs.

title: Asian Bank Members Call for Aid to Vietnam
description: MANILA, April 22Six members of the Asian Development Bank urged at the group's annual meeting today that it resume as soon as possible its development activities in Vietnam and elsewhere in Indochina.

title: Jersey Supreme Court Overturns 2 Gag Orders Against the Press
description: TRENTON. April 22The New Jersey Supreme Court today unanimously struck down as clearly illegal any order by a judge that would prohibit the press from reporting proceedings in open court.

title: OPEC Aides Unworried by Carter's Energy Proposals
description: VIENNA, April 22Officials of the Or ganization of Petroleum Exporting Countries at the cartel's secretariat here do not want to be quoted on President Carter's energy plan, but privately they sound unworried.

title: Roosevelt
description: Horses fisted in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: The Enshrinement of George Washington Carver...

Barazzutti out classed Okker and broke away from a 22 tie in each set.

title: Miss Bradley's 64 Leads by 3
