title: ExSalesman Guilty In 74 Coast Theft Of Hughes Papers
description: LOS ANGELES, April 22Donald R. Woolbright, a 34yearold former automobile salesman here, was found guilty by a jury today on the charge of possession of stolen property, the secret papers of the late Howard R. Hughes. Mr. Woolbright was acquitted of a companion charge of attempting to extort a $1 million ransom from the Hughes organization for return of the papers.

title: Rhode Island Legislator Struggles To Avoid Sentence for Shoplifting
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 22  The Rhode Island Supreme Court is considering a lastditch appeal by an unseated state legislator to avoid extradition to Michigan to serve a twotofouryear sentence for shoplifting 31 record albums.

title: VIRGINIA CLARK STEUER
description: Virginia Clark Steuer wife of Aron Steuer, judicial administrative officer at the Appellate Division of New York State Supreme Court and a former justice of the court, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. She lived at 888 Park Avenue and was 76 years old.

title: 6 New Films by New Directors
description: For those who may want to see some of the entries in the second half of the New Directors/New Films series currently at the Museum of Modern Art, the following comments are presented in the chronological order in which the films will be shown. The series, sponsored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum's department of film, ends Wednesday."Well-Spring of My World," tonight at 8:30, is a sad, gently rueful Danish documentary in which its director, Christian Braad Thomsen, returns to the tiny town where he grew up to interview old friends and reflect on the once rich, fertile countryside that's being gobbled up by housing projects and superhighways. Most of Mr. Thomsen's subjects seem slightly inhibited by the camera, but the stories they tell are occasionally very moving and surprisingly poignant."Rubber Gun" and "The Preparatory, "Sunday, 6 P.M., and Tuesday, 8:30 P.M., is one of the better programs to be offered in this series. "Rubber Gun" is a 90-minute Canadian feature directed by Allan Moyle and written by him and Stephen Lack, both of whom are also actors in the film, which appears to be as much improvised as conventionally planned and directed.The film, a tombstone marking the end of the drug culture, concerns the coming apart of a group of young Canadian druggies and pushers pursued by time and the cops. It's one of those movies in which you're never sure who's giving a performance and who's simply allowing the camera to record him. There is a difference. "Rubber Gun" will be released here commercially later this year, at which time it will be reviewed."The Preparatory," written and directed by Terence Cahalan, an American, is an effective, clear-eyed unsentimental remembrance of life in a Catholic preparatory school. The film, Mr. Cahalan's master's project, shows talent and discipline. Running time: 25 minutes."Brandos Costumes," also known as "Mild Manners" and "Gentle Customs," Sunday, 8:30 P.M., and Tuesday, 6 P.M., is the first feature of a Portuguese director named Alberto Seixas Santos and is by far the most ambitious and interesting feature in the current program.The film intercuts between old newsreel footage and highly theatrical, sometimes melodramatic, tableaux to draw parallels between the late Portuguese dictator Dr. Antnio de Oliveira Salazar and a typical, upper middle-class family man who is a free-thinking liberal outside his house and a tyrant at home. Not all of the associations are clear to someone not familiar with recent Portuguese history, but the film's bold style, which copies no contemporary director I can think of, and its wit and passion are worth attention."Devices and Desires" and "Elizbeth Swados  the Girl With the Incredible Feeling," Monday, 8:30 P.M., and Wednesday, 6 P.M. are a mixed bag.Giles Foster's "Devices and Desires" (55 minutes) is a fond picture of an eccentric, early 19th-century English clergyman named John Skinner. In Mr. Foster's film he is brought up to date, named Granville Moulton and played with fine, understated madness by Frederick Treves. Mr. Moulton is convinced that he has discovered the ruins of the Roman capital of Britain and digs at his site instead of attending to his parishioners.We never know the reasons behind the old man's obsession which eventually alienates even those who would like to help him, but we can appreciate its hold on him, as well as his impatience with the dull world around him. "Weddings, christenings and funerals," says the testy message on Mr. Moulton's telephone-recording mechine, "state your business.'"Elizabeth Swados" is something else. It, too, is a fond picture of its subject, the gifted young woman who sings, plays and composes for the contemporary theater, but it's hardly more than a grab bag of impressions by the director, Linda Feferman.The 37-minute film uses a lot of footage shot by other people, including home movies shot by Miss Swados' loving parents. There is also a quite nice cartoon based on a children's book written by Miss Swados, about a girl who had an incredible feeling, pictured as an amorphous mass that looks like a bag of laundry, which disappeared when it was explained. Something of the same sort happens when you try to explain Miss Swados."L'Affiche Rouge," Monday, 6 P.M., and Wednesday, 8:30 P.M., is one of those movies that sound much more interesting to hear about than they ever are to watch. It's about a group of Parisian actors who plan to make a movie about the Manounchian Band, a group of left-wing resistance fighters, mostly young and mostly foreign, who were executed by the Nazis in the last months of the German occupation.As the actors gather at the studio for a picnic, they try on costumes, dance, act out brief scenes from the film they want to make, discuss the meanings of their roles and generally try to persuade us of the importance of the project.The film, in French, was directed by Frank Cassenti. It strains very hard to look improvised and politically committed, but it only seems phony, arch and self-important. The cast includes Pierre Clementi, who has probably made more appearances in failed avant-garde films than any other actor of his generation.

title: Soviet Renews Criticism of China, Saying Ties Have Not Improved Since Mao's Death
description: MOSCOW, April 22A ranking party ideologist today renewed Soviet criticism of China and acknowledged that relations between the two countries had not improved since the death of Mao Tsetung last September.

title: Nastase and Vilas Gain Final
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., April 22 (AP) Ilie Nastase ended the upset string of 18yearold John McEnroe, and Guillermo Vilas upset topseeded Vitas Gerulaitis tonight in semifinal matches of the Virginia Beach tennis tournament.

title: Hassan Has Been Invited to U.S.
description: RABAT, Morocco, April 22 (UPI)President Carter has invited King Hassan II for an official visit to Washington, Foreign Ministry sources said today. The sources said the invitation was extended to the King last week by Undersecretary of State Philip Habib, but that no specific date had been set.

title: Beame Bid on Pornography Zoning Sent Back to Planning Commission
description: The Beame administration, unable to muster the votes in the Board of Estimate Yesterday to pass a zoning ordinance limiting pornography to specific areas in the city, sent the whole issue back to the City Planning Commission and to an uncertain future.

title: Dance: Natalia Makarova Twice
description: If Wednesday night was Baryshnikov Night at the Metropolitan Opera House, where the American Ballet Theater showed him in two roles, then Thursday was Makarova Night, when Natalia Makarova made her season's debut, dancing in the same two ballets, Petipa's La Bayadre and Glen Tetley's Le Sacre du Printemps, but not, of course, in the same two roles.

title: Order Barring Woman's Abortion Arrives Too Late to Halt Surgery
description: TRENTON, April 22 (AP)A New Jersey Supreme Court justice's order barring a 19yearold student from having an abortion reached her too late to stop the operation, a court spokesman said today.

title: ...and the Flowering of His Favorite Plant
description: ATLANTA, April 22At a New York cocktail party not long ago, the trendy hostessthe kind who has tennis elbow, brushes her teeth with Dr. Bronner's Almond Soap and casts the I Ching on gray daysserved her guests a big bowl of raw peanuts as counterpoint to the dry Gibsons and Tequila Sunrises.

title: Carey, in Ireland, Calls I.R.A. Killers and Marxists
description: DUBLIN, April 22Governor Carey of New York today called members of the Irish Republican Army killers and Marxists and said they should not receive a nickel from IrishAmericans.

Also shown are closing listed market prices or best overthecounter dealertodealer asked prices for the capital shares of each company with the percentage difference (discount or premium) between the net asset value and the asked.

title: Judge Orders Department Store To Remain in Media, Pa.
description: MEDIA, Pa., April 22 (AP)A Delaware County judge issued a special injunction here today to prevent the closing of the Lit Brothers Department Store in the Lawrence Park Shopping Center.

title: Problems Of GhostLaying
description: PARISThe legalization of Spain's Communist Party for the first time since the civilwar republic collapsed attracted much Spanish comment and some ugly undercover stirrings in the armed forces. However, Prime Minister Suarez, backed by the growing prestige of young King Juan Carlos, seems to have succeeded with this audacious step whose symbolic importance is to clear the road for Spain's admission to the European Community.

title: Con Ed Differs With U.S. on Need To Use Scrubbers in Burning Coal
description: WASHINGTON, April 22President Carter said today that his Administration will consider making exceptions to permit utilities to continue using oil in generating electricity instead of converting to coal in some areas of extremely bad air pollution such as New York City.

title: JERSEY COURT VOIDS TWO GAGS ON PRESS
description: TRENTON, April 22The New Jersey Supreme Court today unanimously struck down as clearly illegal any order. by a judge that would prohibit the press, from reporting proceedings in open court.

title: Bhutto Meets Party's Legislators in One of Most Violent Days of Crisis
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 22Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto met with his party's parliamentary caucus here today in a show of solidarity as this country experienced one of the most violent days of its political crisis.

title: 9,400 New City Workers to Be Hired
description: Mayor Beame's budget for 1978 envisions a small increase in the total number of city workers, the first gain after three years of cuts, which will enable New York City to halt the erosion of services that is a legacy of the fiscal crisis.

title: PRESIDENT ASSERTS HE CAN'T VOW REFUND OF ALL ENERGY TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, April 22President Carter said today that he could not guarantee that all money collected by the Federal Government through the taxes proposed in his energy plan would be returned to the American people through rebates and refunds.

title: Bonnett at Pole in 88.9 M.P.H.
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va., April 22(AP) Neil Bonnett of Hueytown, Ala., led a mass assault on the Martinsville Speedway qualifying record today and won the pole position for Sunday's $104,150 Virginia 500 Grand National stock car race. The 32yearold short track expert drove his Dodge to a recordbreaking lap of 88.923 miles per hour that earned him $1,000 and the No. 1 position for the 262.5mile race.

title: Free Mail to Congress Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP)Sen. John A. Durkin proposed today that free mail priveleges be extended to citizens when they write to members of Congress and the President. The COngressional franking system lets senators and House members send mail free to their constituents. A bill offered by Mr. Durkin, a New Hampshire Democrat, would make it a twoway street.

description: WASHINGTON, April 22The Carter Administration today revised downward its projection for economic growth this year while revising upward its projection for inflation, saying that cold weather was in part to blame in both cases.

title: Women Lobby State Legislators For Bills to Aid Battered Wives
description: ALBANY, April 22With the lengthy annual budget battle behind it, the New York State Legislature is preparing to face this year's issue legislation, including several bills intended to strengthen women's rights. But although dozens of proposals are scheduled to be considered  dealing with battered spouses, property settlements in divorce cases, rape, disability payments during pregnancy, and other mattersobservers here believe it likely that only a handful of measures will become law by the time the legislature adjourns for the summer.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CLOSE HARMONY The musicandmingle series Concert Party at the Barbizon, has been drawing enthusiastic responses Saturdays in the Recital Room mezzanine of the Barbizon Hotel, 63d Street and Lexington Avenue. These gettogether evenings, specially planned for musicloving singles, feature preview tryouts of classical programs by reputable artists prior to regular public concerts, with a social session and complimentary wine during intermission. Performances begin at 8:30 P.M.

title: Moroccan King Sees Zaire Aid as Bar to Wider War
description: RABAT, Morocco, April 20  King Hassan II and his aides say that Morocco has sent troops to Zaire to oppose the Katangan invasion because, in their view, a challenge to an African country's territorial integrity carries with it the threat of a continentwide war.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A brush fire near Milburn that spread for some three miles along railroad tracks halted Conrail service in the area. Residents of Millburn, Short Hills and Summit who live near the main route of th'e old Erie Lackawanna line used garden hoses to protect their homes from the flames.

title: YOUNG EXPLAINS HIS STYLE TO GROUP OF EXDIPLOMATS
description: WASHINGTON,April 22(UPI)Andrew Young, the United States delegate to the United Nations, explained his unorthodox style to some retired diplomats today, saying that he is a rebellious child of Korea and Vietnam and a southern black who could not vote until 1965.

title: BRITON LINKS AIR TREATY TO DISPUTE ON CONCORDE
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  Patrick Shovelton, chief British negotiator in talks with the United States over a new airline treaty, hinted today that the dispute over Concorde landing rights in the New York City area could delay an agreement.

title: Commodity Price Index Rose To 221.9 From 221.3 for Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 221.9 from 221.3 last week.

description: CHICAGO, April 22 (AP)Soybean, meal and oil futures prices advanced to daily allowable limits and new contract highs on the Chicago Board of Trade today, then retreated under heavy profit taking

title: Henson's Contract Extended
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., April 22 (UPI)Lou Henson, basketball coach of Illinois, has received a oneyear extension of his contract for the second in a row. The extension was announced today by Cecil Coleman,'the school' athletic director. Henson has been operating under recruiting limits the last two years as a result of a National Collegiate .Athletic Association penalty against Illinois. He can recruit five players this year, and already has signed two high school stars, Mike Jones of Joliet and Eddie Johnson of Chicago Westinghouse.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON  Scientists at the Bell Telephone Laboratories, Holmdel, N.J., who have for some years been working on a communication system that sends light pulses through hairthin glass fibers, have invented an instrument to improve the process.

title: Faulty Wiring Cited In Garden State Fire
description: CAMDEN, NJ.. April 22 (UPI)The New Jersey state police have substantially concluded that the fire had destroyed the Garden State race track last week was causd by faulty wiring.

title: F.A.A Blames Argentine Pilot in Near Crash of a Kennedy Jet
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI).The Federal Aviation Administration has concluded that an Argentine airline pilot was at fault in a January incident in which a Boeing 707 jet nearly crashed into a heavily populated area near New York's Kennedy International Airport.

title: Beame's Budget Includes Money For Design of Convention Center
description: Mayor Beame's $1.36billion capital budget for the coming fiscal year will include money for the design of a longsought convention center, the resumption of construction of two high schools in Brooklyn and Staten Island, the purchase of 225 sanitation trucks, and tree planting.

title: Bank of England Cuts Lending Rate
description: LONDON, April 22 (AP)The Bank of England today cut its minimum lending rate to 8 percent from 9 percent, the lowest level since July 1973.

title: Walter B. Coleman, at 64, Served As Water Supply Commissioner
description: Walter B. Coleman, one of three commissioners of the New York City Board of Water Supply, died Thursday in St. Vincent's Hospital after suffering a stroke. He lived at 55 East End Avenue here. and in Islip, L. I. His age was 64.

title: People in Sports
description: Kevin Loughery has reportedly signed another longterm contract as coach of the New York Nets. A news conference for Monday has been called by the National Basketball Association team to formally announce the agreement, believed to be for five years. Under Loughery, the Nets won the American Basketball Association championship in the 197374 and 197576 seasons. But this past season, after the merger with the N.B.A. and the sale of Julius Erving to the Philadelphia 76ers, they finished with a wonlost record of 2260, the worst in the league.

title: Memorial Services
description: LIESOWITZBenjamin of Lewisboro, N.Y., on January 29, 1977. Memorial services will be held Sunday, April 24th at the Liabowitz home, at 2 P.M., on Lockwood Road, Lowisboro. N.Y.

title: Board Advances Southern Goals But SoftPedals Regional Rivalry
description: A few years ago, when Tom Benson, Tennessee's Commissioner of Economic and Community Development, had to cut his budget severely, the state's $23.000 contribution to the Southern Growth Policies Board looked ripe for the ax.

description: HACKENSACK, April 22The State Public Advocate today criticized, the existence of a barren, green isolation cell on the top floor of the Be?gen County Jail.

title: Against Abolishing Any StudentLoan Programs
description: ARLINGTON, Mass.President Carter's recent request to Congress asking for the abolition of several studentloan programs could be potentially fatal to the education of thousands of college students.

title: 3 Nations Lead, 20, in Cup Tennis
description: Austria, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia were each leading in Davis Cup tennis competition played yesterday in Europe. West Germany and Poland were tied after splitting their singles matches at Warsaw.

title: Three Crews Compete For Childs Cup Today
description: Pennsylvania's crew, winner of the San Diego invitation regatta last month, makes its eastern debut today in the Childs Cup regatta over the Orchard Beach lagoon course in the Bronx against Princeton and Columbia. The lagoon at Orchard Beach has become Columbia's home course rather than the Harlem River because the safety of the oarsmen could no longer be assured against the dropping of missiles and rocks from bridges over the river.

title: Gobbi Falstaff Not Subtle But Singers Show Promise
description: Among the points of interest in the new production of Verdi's Falstaff, unveiled Thursday night by the Juilliard American Opera Center, was the name of Tito Gobbi as the director. Mr. Gobbi has for many years been one of the world's great baritones, and more recently he has been an opera director, but this was his New York debut in that capacity.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, April 22Unemployment in the state declined in March for the fifth straight month to 9.6 percent, the New Jersey Department of Labor and Industry said today.

title: Beame's Message to City Council and Estimate Board on 1978 Budget
description: The 1978 executive expense, revenue and capital budgets of the City of New York present a picture of a leaner and stronger city beginning the long climb back.

title: CARTER TO PROPOSE LIMIT ON INCREASES IN HOSPITALS FEES
description: WASHINGTON. April 22President Carter will send to Congress on Monday a program that is designed to control health costs by placing a ceiling on increases in hospital charges.

title: A Chance to Repair Rent Control
description: The New York State Legislature has returned from its spring recess to find that expiration of the Emergency Tenant Protection Act, which limits rents, is only nine weeks away. The law was enacted in 1974 to restore the regulation of apartments that fall vacant and to permit localities outside New York City to adopt their own versions of rent stabilization. The Democraticrun Assembly has already voted to extend the law for three more years but the Republicancontrolled Senate is holding back in the hope of bargaining for some change the system. Change is needed, but not the frantic kind that will occur if this vital subject is left to the closing hours of the session.

title: Teachers Approve Contract
description: The United Federation of Teachers has voted approval of an agreement under which a contract with the New York City Board of Education originally negotiated in September 1975 was extended for three years, with adjustments to meet the requirements of the Emergency Financial Control Board. The vote was 32,858 to 8,914 for approval. A group of paraprofessionals, represented by the U F.T., voted 5,862 to 155 to approve their contract, which still has to go before the Control Board.

title: Rabin Ends Service as Premier;Peres Is Sitting In
description: JERUSALEM, April 22Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin quietly ended his active service as Israel's leader today by taking an extended vacation that will last until a new Prime Minister forms a majority Government after the country's general election on May 17.

title: Deaths
description: ABBOTTMiss Ruth. The National so ciety of Colonial Dames In the State of New York records with deep regret the death of Its valued member.

title: BERME OFFERS BUDGET TOTALING $13.9 BILLION, SEES LONG CLIMB BACK
description: Declaring that New York City is beginning the long climb back, Mayor Beame yesterday submitted a $13.9 billion expense budget for the year beginning July 1, with a glittering array of electionyear bonuses, including modest tax cuts, personnel increases and construction projects scattered through the five boroughs.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 23, 1977

title: Novelist's Suit Charges Roots Copied Parts of Her 1966 Book
description: One of the nation's most respected black writers filed a copyright infringement suit against Alex Haley yesterday, charging that unspecified portions of his acclaimed book Roots had been largely copied from her novel on black life in Georgia in the Civil War era.

title: OSCAR S. ROSNER
description: Oscar S. Rosner, a New York lawyer and philanthropist who was a trustee of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, died Wednesday of a heart attack. He was 80 years old.

title: MABEL B. ACKERMAN
description: Mabel B. Ackerman, who with her husband, Earl, were among the few husbandandwife teams in the 1950's who were both life masters in contract bridge competition, died Thursday at her home at 20 Sutton Place South. Her age was 71.

title: POLICE HAVE NO SUSPECT IN MURDER IN COOP CITY
description: Bronx detectives said yesterday they had no suspect in the murder of 77yearold Sydel Schwartz, whose body was found Thursday night in her CoOp City apartment at 100 Casals Place.

title: Neville Marriner Is a Virtuoso Conductor
description: If you have ever observed an experienced traffic cop in action, or one of those virtuosic landing officers on an aircraft carrier, you understand how exact and economical nonverbal communication between human beings can be. A symphony orchestra conductor, ideally, is just such a communicator, a dealer in muscular subtleties whose every twitch ought to send currents charging through the musicians he faces.

title: 1,098 STOCKS LOWER AS DOW DROPS 8.73; CREDIT REIN FACTOR
description: Fears of a possible credittightening move by the Federal Reserve Board and continued weakness in bigname glamour issues pushed the stock market sharply lower yesterday across a broad front. With only the preciousmetal group showing firmness, 1,098 issues on the New York Stock Exchange finished the disheartening session lower.

title: Overkill Concern In Access to Press Is Cited by Carter
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP)To laughter from reporters, President Carter said today that there may be overkill in having too much access to the press. But there was no evidence that the prospect disturbed him.

title: Music: 3 Debuts
description: New compositions by Michael Dellario, Hubert S. Howe Jr. and Raoul Pieskow were given premieres at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night in a concert presented by the League of ComposersInternational Society for Contemporary Music.

title: Seattle Slew's Controversial Jockey
description: He's never ridden the winner in a Triple Crown race. But today Jean Cruguet, once a soldier in the French Army, will be on Seattle Slew in the Wood Memorial leading the Kentucky Derby in two weeks. People at Aqueduct yesterday agreed that he's a good jockey. Nobody called him a great jockey. But he has been lucky, beginning with how he was chosen to ride Seattle Slew last year. At any racetrack, being lucky is more important than anything else. But he doeskin't like to talk about how he got the horse. That is not important, Jean Cruguet was saying yesterday. When a jockey like Cordero or Baeza gets a horse, nobody asks how he got it. Jean Cruguet might be sensitive to how he got the horse because he was the second choice. Billy Turner, the tall redhead in the tweed cap who trains the KentuckY Derby's favorite for Mrs. Karen Taylor, wanted Eddie Maple to ride Seattle Slew in a workout at Saratoga last year.

title: U.S. Downs Rumania, 72; Sweden's Six Tops Canada
description: VIENNA, April 22(AP)The United States ice hockey team hit winning form today in the world championship as the powerful Soviet Union and Czechoslovak teams triumphed for the second time.

title: Merck Increases Earnings by 7% From Its Continuing Operations
description: Merck & Company, one of the world's largest ethical drug producers, reported yesterday a 7 percent increase in earnings from continuing operations in the first quarter but a 14.7 percent rise on a netincome basis.

title: HOSPITAL ALLOCATION PUT AT $24 MILLION
description: In an effort to avert hospital closings or widespread reductions of workers in the municipal hospitals. Mayor Beame proposed in his new budget yesterday giving an additional $24 million to the New York City Health and Hospital Corporation.

title: Bill Would Aid Trot Tracks
description: ALBANY, April 22 (AP)Legislation designed to help the Yonkers and Roosevelt harness tracks, which claim to be losing money since harness racing began at the Meadowlands in New Jersey, has been introduced here. The bill would reduce parimutuel taxes for the tracks, give them an extra benefit by adding a 10th race to their programs and increase the amount the Offtrack Betting Corporation pays to the tracks.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: 1. President Carter exhorted the nation this week to confront the energy issue as the moral equivalent of war. From whom was the phrase moral equivalent of war taken?

title: 18 Unaccounted For as Search Ends in Hotel Fire in Galveston
description: GALVESTON, Tex., April 22 (UPI)Officials today ended a threeday search for more bodies in the rubble of a hotel for transients that was destroyed by a fire claiming at least eight dead.

title: Amin Arrives in Zaire, Pledges Aid To Mobutu Against Shaba Invaders
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 22President Idi Amin of Uganda arrived here today to seek first class information about the conflict in Shaba Province and before leaving for home announced he was ready to assist his brother, President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire.

title: Seaver Chased in 8th, Pirates Win in 9th, 43
description: The New York Mets don't pick their lineup out of a hat like the Yankees, but sometimes wish that they did. Take last night, when they lived through the full range of trauma before losing in the ninth inning to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 43, in the first primetime show of the season in Shea Stadium.

title: Taiwan Altering Emphasis of Its Economy
description: KAOHSIUNG, TaiwanHere at the nearly completed plant of the China Steel Corporation, Taiwan's first large integrated steel mill, engineers are putting the rolling mills through their test runs.

title: HENRI BENAMI
description: Henri BenAmi, public relations director for the National Council of Jewish Women, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 48 years old. Mr. BenAmi is survived by his wife, Tamar, and three children. Jonathan, Andrew and Keren.

title: N. B. A. Playoffs
description: QUARTERFINAL ROUND

title: Seattle Agency Director Reported In Line for Urban Transit Office
description: WASHINGTON, April 22The Department of Transportation has proposed to the White House the name of Richard S. Page as the next head of the Urban Transit Administration, according to Carter Administration sources.

title: Zenith Radio
description: Competitive pressures from lowpriced imports amid rising operating costs caused firstquarter earnings of the Zenith Radio Corporation to fall to $6 million, or 32 cents a share, from $7.7 million, or 41 cents a share, in the firstquarter last year. Pretax profits from operations declined to $11.4 million from $14.9 million a year ago, John J. Nevin, chairman and president, noted in his report yesterday. He said fitstquarter prices were $6 million lower than the prices charged in the 1976 first quarter while payroll and material costs were up $9 million.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: SEMIFINAL ROUND

title: BEAM OFFERS BUDGET TOTALING $13.9 BILLION, SEES LONG CLIMB BACK
description: Declaring that New York City is beginning the long climb back, Mayor Beame yesterday submitted a $13.9 billion expense budget for the year beginning July 1, with a glittering array of electionyear bonuses, including modest tax cuts, personnel increases and construction projects scattered through the five boroughs.

title: Milton Helpern, ExChief Medical Examiner, 75, Dies
description: Dr. Milton Halpern, retired Chief Medical Examiner of New York City, died yesterday at University Hospital in San Diego after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: Carey, in Ireland, Calls I.R.A. Killers and Marxists
description: DUBLIN, April 22Governor Carey of New York today called members of the Irish Republican Army killers and Marxists and said they should not receive a nickel from IrishAmericans.

title: GUZZLER TAX BACKED BY PUBLIC, POLL FINDS
description: Americans overwhelmingly approve of new taxes on gas guzzling cars, tax credits for home insulation and solar heating and most other major provisions of President Carter's energy program, but a majority opposes a standby annual increase in gasoline taxes, according to a poll by ABC News and Louis Harris.

title: Reaction to Energy Plan Depends on Point of View
description: To one realestate man, the Carter energy program means more abandoned buildings, more businesses moving out of New York City. To a senior transit official it means a possible new era for buses and subways. To two state legislative leaders, it meas a chance to make some political hay.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, April 23

title: Amerada Hess
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation, the second oil company to report firstquarter results, achieved a 60.4 percent rise in net income to $70.9 million, or $1.81 a share, from $44.2 million, or $1.13 a share, shown in the first three months last year. The increase was the largest for any quarter in about 5 years and the profit appeared to be the highest on record.

title: Letter &Reply
description: To the Editor:

title: Vietnamese Mother, Now in U.S., Denied Custody of Children
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 22  A judge in Superior Court here today rebuffed a Vietnamese refugee who had kidnapped her two children in an effort to reclaim them and ruled that the bachelor who was trying to adopt them would provide a more stable home.

title: About NewYork
description: The all new, purportedly balanced and whiter than white city budget was released yesterday in four big chunks and a man known as Schroeder cast a sad eye on it as a series of dingbats (disjointed paragraphs) in search of a lead (topic sentence).

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Crash in Scarsdale Kills Copter Pilot, Injures an Officer
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 22A Conrail helicopter on a routine flight to watch for fires, vandalism or other trouble crashed onto the Bronx River Parkway today, killing the pilot and injuring a policemanobserver.

title: Islanders Eager and Healthy For Series With Canadiens
description: The nosurprises National Hockey League playoffs are down to the four best teams for the semifinals. The Islanders, who amassed 106 points during the regular season, start a fourofseven game series tonight at Montreal against the Canadiens (132 points), and the Philadelphia Flyers (112 points) face the Boston Bruins (106 points but more victories than New York) starting tomorrow night.

title: ABC and NBC Grant Reply Time to G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI)Two of the major broadcast networks have offered time for Republicans to respond to President Carter's television appearances on energy, a spokesman for the Republican National Committee said today.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: PRESIDENT MAY VETO TAX BILL IF IT KEEPS BUSINESS INCENTIVES
description: WASHINGTON, April 22President Carter said today that he might veto revamped tax legislation, aimed at stimulating the economy, following the Senate's rejection of his request to scrap business tax credits along with the $50 tax rebate that was to be the centerpiece of the program.

title: The Standings.
description: Saturday, April 23, 1977

title: Designers Softly Changing the Way Women Will Dress
description: An enormous change is taking place in the clothes now being introduced on Seventh Avenue for fall, but it's not the kind that will cause women to panic or protest.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI)A Soviet TU95 reconnaissance plane based in ?uba overflew part of a United States ??val task force 60 miles off the Florida coast last week after Air Force interceptors had been unable to track it, defense sources said today.

title: Food Fair Deal With Hill Chain Reported Near
description: Two New York food chains, well known to supermarket shoppers, may be merging.

title: Clearing the Air for Clean Air
description: The Carter Administration's stand on clean air evidences political shrewdness on the part of the President and Douglas Costle, the new administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. To the limited extent that it conciliates the automobile industry and its unions, it recognizes Detroit's importance in the economy. To the extent that it mollifies Capitol Hill critics of the Clean Air Act, it shows an understanding of the difficulties of bringing that law up to date without allowing it to be stripped of the original purpose.

title: PRESIDENT ASSERTS HE CAN'TVOW REFUND OF ALL ENERGY TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, April 22President Carter said today that he could not guarantee that all money collected by the Federal Government through the taxes proposed in his energy plan would be returned to the American people through rebates and refunds.

title: Dollar Is Steady Against Yen
description: TOKYO, April 22 (AP)The dollar remained almost unchanged against the Japanese yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today in relatively quiet trading that saw the American currency move both higher and lower.

title: LIEUT. GEN. IVAN GUREYEV
description: MOSCOW, April 22 (Reuters)A Soviet civil defense expert, Lieut. Gen. Ivan Gureyev, who is believed by Western military experts to have headed the country's early program of constructing nuclear shelters, has died after a short illness, it was announced today. During the mid1950's, he became deputy chief of civil defense and headed the department's military construction section. It was in this role that he was thought to have led the Soviet bomb shelter program.

title: 3 More Named to Energy Panel
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI)Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. named three additional legislators today to the special House committee to coordinate legislative consideration of President Carter's energy program. Representatives Walter. Flowers, Democrat of Alabama; Austin J. Murphy. Democrat of Pennsylvania, and Barry M. Goldwater Jr., Republican of California, were chosen to round out the membership of 27 Democrats and 13 Republicans.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Reports
description: For period ended March 31 unless otherwise indicated. (N) Indicates stock is listed on New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange, and (O) overthecounter.

title: New Labels for Ice Cream
description: WASHINGTON (GPI).The Food and Drug Administration has issued new labeling rules to help consumers know just what they're buying when they shop for ice cream. The agency also recommended, but did not order, that ice cream makers let the public know when food dyes or other artificial colors ara used

title: FOOD
description: LIKE the frenchfried potato, Danish pastry is not easy to translate into colloquial American. the leaden examples usually sold as Danish here would never accompany coffee In Copenhagen. According to Pat Hogeboom of Oakdale, if you want excellent Danish, you must make it yourself, a process that involves a soft yeast dough rolled and folded over butter.

title: Richard Nestto Wed Stacey Leigh Rose
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rose of Oceanside, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Stacey Leigh Rose, to Richard B. Nest, son of Mayor and Mrs. Richard A. Nest of Fort Lee, N. J.

title: COMMENTARY
description: Productivity is the fulcrum on which a great many other economic variables rest, and it is therefore an active topic of discussionbut most of that discussion is loose, oversimplified, distorted and sometimes meaningless. At the very least, we should be clear on what we are talking about when the topic is as crucial to our welfare as this one is.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH SOME brands of exterior paint are advertised as being all purpose finishes that can be used on almost any type of surface around the outside of the house, most experts still agree that this is seldom, if ever, really true. That is why most large manufacturers still make a variety of different kinds of exterior paint for home use. The homeowner who wants to insure longlasting results and provide maximum protection for the outside of his house should familiarize himself with the various types that are available and with the principal characteristics of each.

title: Solid Gold Down on the Farm
description: DAKOTA CITY, IowaIt scared me when I heard this land was for sale at $3,000 an acre, said Marvin O. Bacon, taking a break from spreading nitrogen on his cornfield near here. But if you're in the farming business you've got to own land. And if you're going to get anywhere you've got to take chances.

title: DINING OUT
description: SPANISH cooking has not enjoyed the faddish popularity of Mexican food, yet there is obviously a growing interest in it. We recently visited two restaurants relatively new to the WestchesterConnecticut scene, both of which offer Spanish foodwith quite different degrees of success.

title: Allen M. Look, a Retired Lawyer, Martha's Vineyard Conservationist
description: Allen M. Look, a corporate lawyer who retired in 1967 as a vice president and counsel of West PointPepperell, a New York City textile company, died Friday at the age of 74 in Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a short illness. He lived in West Tisbury on Martha's Vineyard, Mass., where he was a selectman.

title: More and More Schools Are Turning to Formal Courses
description: The patient is almost certainly going to die and the doctor knows it.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE FEDERAL RESERVE reported that the nation's basic money supply, defined as currency in circulation plus checking account balances and known as M1, climbed $900 million in the latest statement week to 021.2 billion. The increase followed the record gain of $5.3 billion, on a revised basis, during the preceding week and brought the twoweek expansion to $6.2 billion, also a record. The more broadly defined money supply, M2, soared $8.5 billion in the same two weeks, according to the Fed . . . analysts suggested that the Fed might act to curb monetary expansion as a result of the unexpectedly big increases, lest they intensify inflationary pressures.. But the Fed was silent on its policy, as is customary.

title: Mr. Byrne, Who Is Governor, Will Run Again but in a Crowd
description: New Jersey's voters should by now find the race for Governor a dizzying affair. When Brendan Byrne, the incumbent, announced his candidacy last week he became one of 11 Democrats in the June 7 primary. Four Republicans and an independent are also running, and the chances are good that the field will become even more crowded before the filing deadline next Thursday.

title: Tribulations of Marriage: The Knicks on Cable TV
description: We decided to sign on for cable television about 20 minutes after we decided to get married. This is not to say that my husband and I wouldn't trade bachelorhood even up for each other, but the building we were moving into was having a run on Cablevision and, at the time, nothing was too rich for us. We were paying mainly to see basketball, agreeing that alsoran Knicks were more exciting than firstrun Wild Kingdoms. Now that the Knicks' season is over, I'm not so sure.

title: Bronx River Boosters' Movement Grows
description: THIRTY miles long and ranging from three inches to 12 feet in depth, the Bronx River is not one the grandest in the world or even in Westchester. But it may be one of the best loved, and if a growing movement that includes New York City and county agencies, private organizations and Gary Hermalyn has its way, it will become even better loved.

title: Daughter to Marshall Field
description: A daughter was born Friday to Marshall Field, chairman of Field Enterprises and publisher of The Chicago SunTimes and The Chicago Daily News, and Mrs. Field at the RushPresbyterianSt. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago. The child, the couple's second, has been named Stephanie Caroline. Mrs. Field is the former Jamee Jacobs.

title: Things and God
description: Dear Editor:

title: Clark Becomes a Victim Of Joe Thomas's Iron Fist
description: The appointment by Joe Thomas last week of Kenny Meyer to be the new head coach of the San Francisco 49ers completed a series of Machiavellian moves involving that franchise. The good guy left out in the cold was Monte Clark, the 49er coach who refused to be bought and thus was discharged. The lessthangood guys in the eyes of the 49er fans are Thomas, the newly appointed general manager who will run the team, and the new fatherson ownership discovered and nourished by Thomas, Edward DeBartolo Sr. and Jr.

title: Returning to the Campus
description: SIX months ago I urged my neighbor, a 35yearold woman, to return to college. She was intelligent but intellectually frustrated, and I knew she would thrive as a mature adult student. She borrowed my Westchester Community College catalogue and proceeded to give the matter serious thought. Each time I have seen her since, however, she has provided a new rationalization for not going back. I didn't do well in high school, so how will I succeed now? My math skills are nonexistent. I'll never keep up with those young kids. Her fears are rampant.

title: Homer at Home
description: OMER, the epic poet, lives and works in an unpretentious cave in the suburbs of Rhodes, where most of his chanting is done beneath a stalactite that has been in his family for years. The cave has only one exposure, but it's on the Aegean, a sea that has paid off handsomely for him. The decor is quiet and contains no papyrus, parchment or slate, so that the casual visitor being washed ashore would not at first imagine that this chubby bachelor of 93 was the author of what many people already consider to be the upper world's two greatest epic poems. Since there are no other epic poems, Homer's position seems secure. in fact, it is the consensus of those at the universities and the docks that his works will do for travel what The Song of Solomon did for spring. cave has only one exposure, but it's on the Aegean, a sea that has paid off handsomely for him. The decor is quiet and contains no papyrus, parchment or slate, so that the casual visitor being washed ashore would not at first imagine that this chubby bachelor of 93 was the author of what many people already consider to be the upper world's two greatest epic poems. Since there are no other epic poems, Homer's position seems secure. in fact, it is the consensus of those at the universities and the docks that his works will do for travel what The Song of Solomon did for spring.

title: Cheryl L. Chevins Married To Bradley Davis, Golf Pro
description: At St. Francis Episcopal Church in Stamford, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Cheryl Linda Chevins was married to Bradley Peter Davis by the Rev. Robert M. Dresser.

title: How Instruments Sounded in Early America
description: The ancient instruments lie all around the rooms, woodwinds stacked in glass cases, what is called a serpent lying on a table, lutes hanging on the walls, cellos leaning against chairs, square pianos in cdd corners. The building might be a museum, but it isn't. It's a town house belonging to Frederick R. Selch, an advertising man who is also a musician by training and avocation. He has been collecting old instruments practically since he was out of the cradle, and from this grew a special interest in instruments made in this ?? during the ColonialFederal years, roughly from 1775 to 1830. This in turn led to his forming two years ago an organization called the Federal Music Society. Its aim is to perform in as authentic a manner as possible the littleknown repertory of that period, and it will make its formal debut in Town Hall tomorrow night.

title: Beckenbauer of Little Value to Cosmos, Chinaglia Says
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., April 23 The talk this week at the Cosmos' training headquarters here has been about Franz Beckenbauer, the elegant West German soccer star who confirmed in Munich Thursday that he would join the Cosmos late next month. Some of the players don't seem worried that their jobs may be in jeopardy; some feel his presence will further elevate their status, and one contends that Beckenbauer will not be much help to the team. What is the use of Beckenbauer to us? Giorgio Chinaglia, the outspoken Italian center forward, wanted to know in the locker room after practice Thursday. He is a great playerdon't get me wrong. But is he going to help us with the crowds? No. He won't draw in this country. He will draw in tours overseas but not in this country.

title: Not So Flaming Youth
description: AS early as 1916 Thorstein Veblen perceived that the passage of colleges and universities from clerical to business control was radically changing their functions and clientele. In his sardonic and prophetic The Higher Learning in America, one of the most brilliant satires of American academic life ever written, he observed that the new competitiveness among colleges was generating a rush for students, and he couldn't help noticing that the increase in numbers has brought a change in the scholastic complexion of this enlarged student body, of such a nature that a very appreciable proportion of these students no longer seeks residence at the universities with a view to the pursuit of knowledge, even ostensibly. Consequently, he notes college sports come in for an ever increasing attention . . . as do other politely blameless ways and means of dissipation, such as fraternities, clubs, . . . and the extensive range of extrascholastic traffic known student activities.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Public Opposition
description: An overwhelming majority of the American public82 percentthinks it should be against the law to employ a person who has come into the country illegally, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: J. L. Shea, Student, And Barbara D. Bell Are Planning Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Christy W. Bell of Berwyn, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Dandridge Bell of Washington, to James Lindsay Shea, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Shea Jr. of Baltimore.

title: Offshore at Elath: In the Midst of the Sea Upon Dry Ground
description: Three millennia after the waters parted for the children of Israel, people are again walking on the bottom of the Red Sea without getting their feet wet.

title: A Manhunt In Ridgefield
description: THE AD, placed inconspicuously among a number of others in classified section of the local weekly newspaper on March 10, was headed by three lines that said:

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (Reuters)President Carter met with key aides today for what informed sources said was a discussion on armscontrol talks with the Soviet Union.

title: Birthday Present: A New Coppelia
description: THEY START to arrive a little after 3 P.M. on weekdays, straightbacked youngsters with bulky canvas sacks slung over their shoulders. Through the marbled front hall the faint sount of hammering can be heard, and the casual visitor who pushes open the door at the top of the stairs will be rewarded with a glimpse of sleek bodies whirling through a pas de deux on a spring afternoon.

title: Home Style
description: Dear Tenant Stockholders of One Happiness Place: During the past year we have made substantial progress toward our goal of utopian highrise living One Happiness Place.

title: Intervention by Courts Arouses Deepening Disputes
description: WASHINGTON, April 23In a deepening constitutional controversy, Federal and state courts have taken over the daytoclay operations of jails, prisons, state hospitals and at least one school district in what is generally considered to be the greatest extension of judicial authority since 1803, when Chief Justice John Marshall enunciated the principle of judicial review.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: She has a dream jobqueen of a store unlike any other in the world. It's the sort of place where New York women take outoftown visitors, for a whiff of that rarefied air that hovers around the pinnacles of Big Time Chic. It's the place for glimpses of Lauren Bacall; where Yoko Ono buzzes through when she's in town, dropping $11,000 in one day: where salesgirls once watched while three glamorous young things tried on nightgowns for the 70yearold man who brought them in and then paid for a pile of lingerie with a Sugar Daddy flourish.

title: REPORTS OF PSYCHOSIS AFTER ERHARD COURSE
description: The discovery of seven persons who suffered serious psychiatric disturbances after participating in a selfhelp program called Erhard Seminars Training has prompted three psychiatrists to alert their profession to the possibility that the experience may have devastating effects on some people.

title: Connecticut Gets Wildlife Area
description: HARTFORD April 22Connecticut has acquired a valued tract of wooded land in Andover, in the rural eastern part of the state, as a wildlife preserve.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: OUR new traffic light in Montclair is very nice. It is made of cast aluminum and steel, and it hangs, suspended from its stillshiny stanchion, over the intersection of Hillside Avenue and Orange Road.

title: Goodwill, Refusing Jumps, Misses Hand of Princess
description: BADMINTON, England, April 23 (AP)  Capt. Mark Phillips's hopes of a record fourth victory in the Badminton international horse trials were dashed today by a poor round in the rainswept crosscountry section on Goodwill, the horse normally ridden by his wife, Princess Anne.

title: Bold Stage Play On Red System Tickles Moscow
description: MOSCOW, April 23Mikhail Bulgakov's novel The Master and Margarita. written during the Stalin era and long suppressed, has now reached the stage as a bold, politically unorthodox play that is causing excitement among playgoers.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: ARMADALE, by Wilkie Collins. (Dover, $5.) The awful fate that befalls Allan Armadale when he defies his father's warning that he mustn't seek out another man bearing the same name: this ripe period piece by a father of the mystery story is reproduced (even to the illustrations) as serialized in The Cornhill magazine 186466.

title: Fishermen Are Wary of Season Ahead
description: STRIPED bass are making their presence known in a number of the state's rivers and bays, and winter flounder also have started to make an appearance. Still, New Jersey fishermen are wary, for they remember last summer, the worst fishing season in memory.

title: Polaroid's Coup: Instant Movies
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.At the Polaroid Corporation's annual meeting in Needham, Mass., Tuesday, Dr. Edwin H. Land, the company's founder and chairman, is expected to launch a technological skyrocketan instant motionpicture system.

title: Pugs' Victory Makes Up for Ordeal
description: Exhibitors lead rugged lives, but every one will agree that pocketing a group one and a specialty in one weekend more than makes up for traveling 1,600 miles, spending 32 hours on the road and getting two flat tires. I'm still up on Cloud Nine, said Shirley Thomas with a laugh after her triumphant return to Flushing, Queeens, from Indiana with th spoils and her conquering pugs. Ch. Shirrayne's Music Man and Shirrayne's Tigeress Twiggy.

title: International Federation in State of Flux
description: The Federation Equestre Internationale, the world governing body of equestrian sports, is undergoingbut managing to live through the process some important changes. The most vital, perhaps, is the fact that a search is on for a successor to Prince Philip, who has served as president since 1964. The busband of Queen Elizabeth has performed admirably, but he announced recently that he plans to retire following the 1980 Moscow Olympic Games.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Nova Scotia from Portland, Me., you can sail aboard the 11,000ton Caribe, which operates from May 4 to Oct. 30, and you can take your car along. The Caribe sails nightly from Portland and each morning from Yarmouth and has accommodations for 726 passengers, two dining rooms, a cafeteria, a casino, swimming pool and dutyfree shopping. The trip takes about 10 hours. From May 4 to June 30 and also in the fall from Sept. 1 to Oct. 30 a special package, called Great Nova Scotia Circle Tour, is offered at $149 a person in double occupancy and includes roundtrip passage for automobiles and passengers as well as five nights' lodging in various Nova Scotia resort areas.

title: Backers of Tennessee Breeder Reactor Hope for Funds From Congress
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 23Despite the Wednesday night announcement by President Carter that the United States will not enter the plutonium age, advocates of the $2.2 billion Clinch River Breeder Reactor are clinging to the hope that their cause can be won in Congress.

title: Oliver Hit Clinches a 65 Triumph
description: Not much of anything, including the weather, went the Mets' way yesterday afternoon at Shea Stadium as they lost again to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 65.

title: India's Images in the U.S. Mirror
description: NEW DELHIOnly a few months ago, one observer said that India had nothing to offer the world except communicable diseases.

title: Reds Stay in Doldrums, Cubs End Losing Streak
description: The Cincinnati Reds, champions of baseball, continue to masquerade as inept alsorans.

title: The Setting, Rome 1941 to 1947
description: THE very title of this enormous novel, hailed by its publishers as the most important Italian work of fiction in a generation or more, is something of a provocation. It takes us back to an age when the novelist could confidently assume that be had authoritatively incorporated the actual movement of history into his imaginative inventionsto such a degree that some of the great fictional productions of the time bore subtitles like A Chronicle of the 19th Century and A Study of Manners in the 19th Century. The technique of History: A Novel also harks back to the 19th century, particularly to the Naturalist novel, with its nearomniscient narrator deploying a huge cast of characters through a series of lowerclass urban scenes. The book also has a distinct affinityapart from one significant exception, to which I shall returnwith the Italian NeoRealist films of the early postwar period.

title: Oradell Welcomes New Post Office
description: ORADELL'S new post office will open for business tomorrow According to Postmaster Garret J. Dykhouse, the new building. which is nearly twice the size of the structure occupied by the post office since 1958, will offer improved customer service and better working conditions for its employees.

title: About That... er... Dog Problem
description: MANIS best friend sometimes becomes his enemy. Behaving just like an animal, he barks, barges in and messes up our lovely suburban landscapes. His toilet habits are more than offensive; in 10 of Nassau County's 64 villages, they're also an offense. Neither local leash laws nor pooperscooper ordinances requiring owners to pick up after their pooches have proven effective, however, in stemming the rising tide of pet pollution.

title: PAL ADDS CULTURE TO SPORTS PROGRAM
description: Those for whom the mere mention of the Police Athletic League evokes visions of offduty police officers showing ghetto youngsters how to shoot layups and throw curveballs better look again. The New York City P.A.L. is getting culture.

title: Dance: Limon's Emperor Jones
description: It's curious how often Jos Limn played off a tragic hero against a conniving subordinate in his works. The Moor's Pavane is the most famous example, but the tension is to be found in The Traitor and The Emperor Jones as well. The latter was given its first performance this season Friday night at th Roundabout Stage One with guest artist Clay Taliaferro as the hero and Lows Solino as The White Man.

title: Andrea Smith Plans A Wedding in August To Jonathan Sprole
description: Dr. and Mrs. W. Russell Smith of Los Angeles have announced the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Patricia Smith, to Jonathan Knapp Sprole, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Sprole of Darien, Conn. An August weddine is planned.

title: Stars Light Up Lights On
description: Bob Hope, Ethel Merman, Cab Calloway, Joey Adams and Melba Moore are among the stars who will do their thing at Avery Fisher Hall next Sunday night to raise funds for international sight research. Tickets for the 29th annual Lights On show, as it is called, range in price from $10 to $50 and can be obtained from Fight for Sight, 41 West 57th Street.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Campus taste. A decade ago this Book Revie periodically published reports on what students at representative U. S. colleges were choosing for their unrequired reading. In retrospect, the accounts from two sectionsNew England and Californiaseem to have been particularly reliable indicators of where the nation's taste was heading. In the late 60's, for example, even as violent campus demonstrations were making firstpage headlines, an Oxford don named J. R. R. Tolkien was said to be piedpipering a growing band of youths to his Middle Earth.

title: Ch. Cathcade Curio Named Best Borzoi
description: VALLEY COTTAGE N.Y. April 23Ch. Cathcade Curio, the third ranking borzoi in the United States for the past two years, gained his third sped cialty award today. He took the top award over 133 other breed specimens at the Borzoi Club of Greater New York. Specialty on the Tolstoy estate.

title: A Bit of Britain In Ossining
description: ARISING at about 6 AM., Ethel Urquhart pedals on the exercycle in her bedroom, then works out on her doorway bar, leaving her ample time to dress and meet her peers for breakfast at 8 A.M.

title: Carter's Best Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 23President Omar has just completed the most strenuous and successful week of his new Administration. At the end of it, he looked tired but composed and satisfied that Congress and the country were finally taking the energy crisis seriously.

title: Snorts Editor's Mailbox: The Cost of Yankee Tickets
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bridal on May 28 Set By Carole Mahoney
description: Carole Jeanne Mahoney, a mezzosoprano, and Clinton John Everett 3d, a Percussionist, who met while performing with the College Light Opera Company at the Highfield Theater in Falmouth, Mass., plan to be married May 28 in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

title: City Council Units Set Hearings for Week
description: The following public hearings will be held by New York City Council committees this week:

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: PRISON GUARDS FOUND NOT TRAINED IN ARMS
description: ALBANY, April 23Fewer than a third of the corrections officers employed by New York State have been found fully trained in the use of weapons, Comptroller Arthur Levitt reported today in an audit of the State Department of Correctional Services.

title: The Actors Who Live With The Intimacies of Ashes
description: Does an actor put on and take off a role as he would a costume, and walk away from the theater unmarked by either one? For some actors, in some plays, that is undoubtedly the case. For the principals in one play currently on the boardsDavid Rudkin's Ashes at the Public Theaternothing could be farther from the truth.

title: Shadyside Trixie Paces jersey Mile in 1:56 4/5
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 23Shadyside Trixie, the 6yearold gelded son of Overtrick, paced the fastest American mile of the season tonight by winning at the Meadowlands in 1:56 4/5.

title: Jennifer Whelan Is Bride Of Jack Craig Smeeton
description: The Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Chapel at Grosse Pointe Academy in Michigan, was the setting last evening for the marriage of Jennifer Ann Whelan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Whelan of Mancelona Mich., to Jack Craig Smeeton, son of Mrs. Lynn Collins of St. Charles, III., and Dr. Jack Cuthbert Smeeton of Sarasota, Fla.

title: William Black, Pianist, At Concert Artists
description: The Concert Artists Guild, which has been helping young musicians for 25 years, celebrated the anniversary last Tuesday night at the debut of one of the 10 winners of its recital awards for the 197677 season.

title: Keeping Secrets Secret
description: PARISThe only allied organization I know of which makes no distinction in its approach to the Soviet and Chinese branches of Communism is that littleknown body called COCOM. COCOM includes all signatories to the North Atlantic treaty save Icelandas well as nonNATO Japan. Its fundamental aim is to preserve for its collective membership a fivetotenyear technological lead over the Marxist world.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: BEAUTY, like a mote, is sometimes in the eye of the beholder, and state government abounds in examples of this. For instance, about 10 days ago, the Department of Environmental Protection was congratulating itself on two new developments in its efforts to clean up New Jersey pollution.

title: Margot S. Dewey Has Nuptials
description: Margot Stilwell Dewey and William James Hust 3d were married yesterday in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Port Washington, L.I., by the Rev. Frederick Rapp.

title: Greek Government Attempting to End Hallowed Custom of Siesta
description: ATHENS, April 23One of Greece's most hallowed and popular customs, the afternoon siesta, seems on its way to disappearing at long last.

title: Vilas Beats Nastase in 3Set Final
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, April 23 (AP)Guillermo Vilas, playing with a scraped knee he received in a spill in the first set, defeated Die Nastase, 62, 46, 64, in the final of the Virginia Beach tennis tournament today. The Argentine southpaw earned 632,000, plus a $50,000 bonus for his performances in this tournament and another seven weeks ago at Ocean City, Mr.

title: INTERVIEW
description: AFTER almost six years as director of traffic in Stamford, Ronald A. Weber says his belief in the venality of public officialsonly some of themhas been reinforced.

title: South Korea: Our Indecent Ally
description: The news from South Korea is dismal and ??miliar President Park is cracking down on political opponents again; midnight raids, arrests, surveillance, breakins. More than 30,000 Americans died in South Korea's defense, and billions of dollars have been spent over a generation to protect it against aggression by Communist North Korea, a police state. But the South remains a police state, too. Must our sense of strategic obligation render us helpless against the most brazen violations of human rights?

title: Rebirth of a Guide for Music Lovers
LUXURY CAR MAKERS DOUBT TAX WILL HURT
description: DETROIT, April 23President Carter's proposal to tax socalled gas guzzling automobiles in order to discourage consumers from buying them and in turn cut back on gasoline consumption occurs at a time when at least two cars in this category are selling as fast as they can be produced.

title: Air Force Says Cruise Missile Will Be Ready by 1980
description: The Air Force plans to deliver the first 40 to 50 longrange airlaunched cruise missiles to the Strategic Air Command in 1980.

title: The Golf Clinic
description: Tom Watson, the 1977 Masters champion and leading moneywinner, has improved immensely in the last two years, and he can tell you precisely why. He has made wellconsidered changes in his game, and they have worked almost immediately.

title: Bank Profits Mixed
description: Although it was a period of general earnings recovery for the nation's banks, the first quarter of 1977 was not kind to the two largest banking enterprises in New York, which reported only modest gains.

title: White House Looks at White Plains
description: A decision by the city of White Plains to open its doors to the public for one month has attracted the attention of President Carter, who is sending Greg Schneiders, a special assistant, for today's opening ceremony.

title: ALFRED R. STERN ELECTED TO HEAD HOSPITAL BOARD
description: Alfred R. Stern has been elected chairman of the Mount Sinai Medical Center Boards, becoming the 18th person to head the board of trustees in the hospital's 125year history and the third chairman of the 10yearold Mount Sinai School of Medicine. He succeeds Sheldon R. Coons, who has been chairman since the death of Gustave L. Levy last November.

title: The Poet's Tale
description: Chaucer scholarship and criticism need some sort of an epiphany right now, and the publication of these two volumes by John Gardner, a professional medievalist who is also a firstrate novelistthe author of Grendel, The Sunlight Dialogues, October Light and other booksraises wild hopes that this may be it. A great phase of scholarship will begin its close this year with the publication by the University of Georgia Press of the first volumes of the longprojected Chaucer Librarya meticulously edited set of books that Chaucer read; and the University of Oklahoma Press has underway a project as definitive and almost as vast, the Chaucer Variorum, an edition that will comprise just about everything known of Chaucer's texts. In criticism, too, we are at a turning point. The New Criticism has shrunk from a religion to an incidental technique, and the more recent wave of exegetical analysis seems also to have run its course, leaving behind it a wake of valuable background erudition, but little guidance to a new understanding of one of the greatest of poets.

title: Pat Bratdley Leads Golf
description: RALEIGH, N. C., April 23 (AP)Pat Bradley clung to the lead today in the $50,000 American Defender Golf Classic by shooting a oneunderpar 71 for a total of 135 for 36 holes. She had a twostroke edge.

title: Charles P. Hackett And Laura Wicker Are Married on L.I.
description: Laura An Wicker and Charles Prescott Hackett were married yesterday afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church, Oyster Bay, L.I., by the Rev. Robert T. Hollett.

title: Tourism: Lagging Industry
description: LEGISLATORS, resort owners and hotel and motel managers ire striving to promote tourism in New Jersey as a means of improving the state's fiscal and employment picture.

title: Architecture Is Luring Women
description: WHEN Cassandra Carroll was applying to schools of architecture in the late 1950's, she was discouraged by both guidance counselors and admissions officers. They told her: Don't enter the field; there are no women in it.

title: BRIDGE
description: FOR the inexperienced bridgeplayer who wishes to venture into duplicate play at club level, there are plenty of opportunities in Connecticut. If he has taken a course of lessons or read a book or two and fancies something more challenging than playing with the neighbors there are 22 club games each week restricted to novice players. These are scattered throughout the state, and details about them may be obtained from the secretary of the state organization, Hilda Silverman, 22 Pioneer Drive, West Hartford, 06117 (Telephone 2327527).

title: Notes: Is the Free Brochure Fading?
description: Over the past few years, more and more service stations have begun dispensing road maps through vending machines (in Florida, prices are as high as 75 cents each). Now travel brochures, the delight of armchair tourists, might be under the gun.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodaySunnyfield. Route 172, Bedford, N.Y. Novice, local, junior and children's working hunters; adult horsemanship, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: The Camps Are Calling
description: THERE ARE few warmweather traditions more solidly entrenched in our culture than the summer camp. For many youngsters, dusting off sleeping bags, gathering up tennis racquets and hiking gear and stuffing duffle bags with nametagged summer togs are annual rituals that come as surely as the Fourth of July.

title: Berlin Captures Rich Bowling Title
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 23 (AP)Wlike Berlin opened with four straight strikes and went on to defeat Mike Durbin, 221205, today and capture professional bowling's most coveted prize, the Tournament of Champions trophy.

title: Mozambique Said to Get Big Soviet Arms Shipments
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The Soviet Union has sent Mozambique substantial shipments of antiaircraft weapons and artillery in recent weeks, according to United States intelligence analysts.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Harry Patterson
description: It took less than 30 seconds for the transAtlantic call to go through from New York on the Hudson to Jersey in the Channel Islands. Surprised, I said Hello, Jack Higgins, when I meant to say, Hello, Harry Patterson. I did not know enough about his writing career to say, Hello, James Graham, or Hello, Hugh Marlowe, or Hello, Martin Fallonall pen names Mr. Patterson used when he was grinding out his early thriller sausages.

title: A Rebuttal On Bridgeport
description: DAVID AUSTIN'S recent comments (Opinion Page, March 20) on the need to retain many of Bridgeport's older downtown commercial buildings call for immediate rebuttal.

title: LETTER FROM FAIRFIELD
description: AT FAIRFIELD UNIVERSITY students are deserting the ivory tower of the liberal arts for the cashgreen fields of business and preprofessional training. At this university the numerous national reports of college students increasingly selecting vocational rather than purely academic majors are confirmed to the letter.

title: Carter Shaped Energy Plan With Disregard for Politics
description: WASHINGTON. April 23Shortly before he was inaugurated, President Carter told a visitor that he was determined to reform the nation's energy habits even if it costs me another term in the White House. There are Democrats in Congress who sense that it could, and some who fear that it might alter their own political horizons. who sense that it could, and some who fear that it might alter their own political horizons.

title: Mr. Vorster and
description: JOHANNESBURGAfter years of trying to minimize the issue, South Africa is no longer disguising the seriousness of opposition to its control of SouthWest Africa and plans to grant the territory independence under a formula that would perpetuate white minority rule.

title: Charles Lindbergh Unexplained
description: THERE are a few facts and episodes here we did not already know, but not many. Brendan Gill had access to many of the Lindbefgh papers in the Yale Library, including a volume, as yet unpublished, said to be a spiritual autobiography of sorts. One must assume either that there isn't much there that is illuminating, or else that Mr. Gill was denied permission to publish such as there was that is.

title: Modern Dimmer Switches Help Save Energy
description: Dimmer switches that can be used to control the brightness of floor lamps, table lamps or permanently installed lighting fixtures in the home have been around for years, but they have become more popular than ever in the last few years due to the increasing interest in saving energy, and in cutting down on steadily mounting electric bills. In addition to cutting down on energy consumption (by reducing the wattage consumed during much of the time that the lamps are in use), dimmers also help extend the life of the bulbs, and thus they save money on replacement costs.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: NEW JERSEYANS have been riding in foreignmade automobiles for a long time now, and in everincreasing numbers. In a few years, they also may be riding in foreigndesign trains on Amtrak's WashingtonNew YorkBoston routethe socalled Northeast Corridorand at speeds faster than they've ever gone before on land.

title: Surrealism at SUNY
description: AN INTERNATIONAL center for Surrealist studies, the first such center in the world, is being developed at the State University College at Purchase. The center will be housed in a $12 million, 120,000squarefoot visualarts instructional facility that is nearing completion on the 500acre campus.

title: A Special Library in Southport
description: I RUN this library the way I always wanted a library to be when I was a child, says Stan ley Crane of the Pequot Library in Southport. For him that means a library charged with warmth and friendly bookishness; reading in front of an open fire, a nook for a scholar to pursue some esoteric research, a refuge for students who come to read or study, open stacks lit by Tiffany stainedglass windows and shelves set off with handsome castiron bookends.

title: Libraries: Branching Out
description: THIS week, Long Islanders will be able to hear a concert of contemporary chamber music in Huntington Station, see an exhibition of drawings and collages called Social Comment in Long Beach, hear the poet Denise Levertov read her works in Great Neck, enjoy a songanddrama potpourri of Carl Sandburg's works in Lawrence, bite their nails through the film classic Z in Dix Hills and catch up with what's new in experimental theater in Franklin Square.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH SOME Brands of exterior paint are advertised as being all purpose finishes that can be used on almost any type of surface around the outside of the house, most experts still agree that this is seldom, if ever, really true. That is why mist large manufac?? still make variety of different kinds of exterior paint for home use. The homeowner who wants to insure longlasting results and provide maximum protection for the outside of his house should familiarize himself with the various types that are available and with the principal characteristics of each.

title: Job Aid Project Is Short of Goal
description: In a few weeks, Tawana Briggs will become a flight attendant, traveling to cities far from her home in Newark.

title: Bach and Then Onward
description: SYOSSET ARMED with his trusty clarinet and ably supported by the other young men and women of his Long Island Chamber Ensemble, Lawrence Sobel of Massapequa, the intrepid musical explorer, is ?? the midst of his seventh season of conducted tours of the dark jungles of modern, longhair composition.

title: Last Week's Energy Plan Was Reminiscent of the Teddy Roosevelt Style
description: WASHINGTONJimmy Carter, someone observed last week, is the best liberal Republican we've had since Teddy Roosevelt. A demurral came from another corner: No, he's a Democratic Eisenhower.

title: The Ever So Delicate Art of Becoming An Operatic Prima Donna
description: Overheard during an intermission notlong ago at the City Opera: An American soprano of note, who never quite made it to the rank of prima donna, snapping exasperatedly to her companion, Just how did Beverly Sills get to be so famous?

title: Walter B. Coleman, at 64, Served As Water Supply Commissioner
description: Walter B. Coleman, one of three commissioners of the New York City Board of Water Supply, died Thursday in St. Vincent's Hospital after suffering a stroke. He lived at 55 East End Avenue here, and in Islip, L. I. His age was 64.

title: It's Because All Sides Have New Perceptions of How Government Should Be Run
description: The metropolitan region, a cradle of the civil service nearly a century ago, is becoming the birthplace of new patterns in public employee relations that are altering perceptions of how city and state governments should be run.

title: Pulitzer Loser Proves Winner In Other Areas
description: To be 74 years old, to have written a first book that is critically acclaimed and chosen by the Pulitzer Prize fiction jury as this year's best, and then to have the Pulitzer advisory board turn down the choicesuch is Norman Maclean's joust with fate.

title: How Recordings Can Create Careers
