description: Records play an important part in any artist's career: The right recording released at the right time, and touted with astuteness and zeal, can drive a performer's name home to the American public far more forcibly than a whole series of concert hall or opera house appearances. But recordings interact with artists' lives in many other ways as well.

title: DINING OUT
description: Le Chateau, 115 County Road, Tenafly. (201) 8711500. IF NEW JERSEY can be said to have the equivalent of what would be considered the latest in restaurant in New York, it would have be Le Chateau. Open only nine months, it has established itself as one of the premier restaurants in the state in very short order.

title: Protests Organized at Columbia Against Eviction of Free School
description: A group of schoolage children ran up to the administration building at Columbia University the other day, threw down a bunch of mats, and, after a tittle instruction, launched into streams of summersaults and cartwheels.

title: OPPOSITION LEADERS
description: A newcomer to Israeli politics, Yigael Yadin is a singular figure: creator of the country's system of army reserves, renowned archeologist, and now political reformerto some, the De Gaulle of Israel. His strategy: to win enough votes to make it impossible for any other party to form a new Government without him.

title: Regional Ballet Is on the March
description: Tonight, 60 American dancers plus a handsome Dane named Peter Martinswill come together at the Barnard College Gymnasium to perform in a gala benefit for the National Association for Regional Ballet.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: They're really killing I. B. M. again, the manager of a New York brokerage office declared Friday afternoon as the stock market, beset by new worries, plunged across a broad front.

title: Barbara Savitt, J. H. Pearson Jr. Set June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Max Maxwell Savitt of Farmington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Joan Savitt, to John Howard Pearson Jr., ?? of Mr. and Mrs. Pearson of ??well, Mass. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on motion to kill tax credits for businesses in the tax bill, was rejected, 74 to 20, April 21.

title: Immigration Service Begins Deportation Proceedings Against 178 Members of the Moon Church
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service in New York has begun deportation proceedings against 178 Japanese members of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's churls who entered the country years ago as temporary visitors for business orpleasure, but have remained here as missionaries without official authorization.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Mets end their Shea Stadium series with the Pittsburgh Pirates with a 1 o'clock doubleheader today, travel to west Point for an exhibition against Army tomorrow, and return to Shea Stadium for 8 P.M. games Tuesday and Wednesday against the Montreal Expos. The Yankees play a threegame series against the Seattle Mariners at Yankee Stadium at 8 P.M. Friday and 2 P.M. Saturday and next Sunday.

title: Advice on Alcohol in Pregnancy
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI)The director of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism wants the Government to warn pregnant women that more than two drinks a day, or a total of about three ounces of whisky, may harm their unborn children.

title: U.S. Hockey Team Waits For a Missing Center
description: VIENNA, April 23 (AP)The United States ice hockey team waited in vain today for news of Mike Antonovich, the lost star whose shooting could make the difference in the world championship tournament.

title: Questions/Answers
description: We are contemplating using woodchip mulch around acid loving shrubs. It is our understanding that the chips absorb soil nutrients. If so, what is the procedure? Mrs. W.A.H., Wellesley, Mass.

title: Free Running Clinics in Park
description: The Road Runners Club of New York is holding beginning runners group clinics on Saturdays at 10 A.M. at the 90th Street and Fifth Avenue entrance of Central Park. There will be sessions on how to stretch, beforerunning warmups and cooloffs, and a 1mile run around the reservoir bridal path.

title: Marriage Counseling for Unwed Couples
description: They started living together because she didn't want to live alone in New York, they were spending all their time together anyway, and it seemed crazy to pay two rents You know how it is, she said It's so disorienting, waking up across town from your clothes and your mail It would he so much more convenient to live together It makes more sense.

title: POLITICS
description: IF anyone should attempt to write a dramatic play about the 1977 New Jersey Democratic primary, a good working title might be Waiting for Brendan.

title: Windsor Rocking ChairsFrom Slovenia
description: Windsor rocking chairs, just like the ones that delighted Americans 200 years ago, were on view last week at a North Carolina trade exhibition. These rockers, however, are not from the Revolutionthey are from Yugoslavia. With Early American furniture all the rage in Europe, the inevitable has happened: imports.

title: JULIUS HALLHEIMER
description: Julius Hallheimer, a deputy attorney general of the State of New York in the 1920's and former counsel for the Yankee Stadium Club, died Friday at Doctors Hospital. He lived at 349 East 49th Street in Manhattan.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Reference is made to the Opinon Page article. Can a Shot of the Secular Bring New Life to Seminaries? (April 3).

title: Forest Fires Laid to Arsonists
description: NEW JERSEY'S firebugs have been out in extra numbers this year and, as a result, large sections of the Pine Barrens, that lovely wilderness area north of Atlantic City, have been charred by forest fires.

title: Young Sex Is Topic of Talks
description: INADEQUATE information on birth control, underdeveloped reasoning about sex, unwanted pregnancies and unnecessary anxietiesthese problems surrounding teenage sexual activity are felt here in the county as in other areas of the nation.

title: Debate on Energy Program Widens As Liberals and G. O. P. Give Views
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The public debate over President Carter's energy program is expanding dramatically, with the voices of oil companies and individual Congressmen being joined by those of liberals arguing for the urban poor, Republicans denouncing big government and environmentalists trying to ward off industry pressures.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford is participating in a unique medallic history of the American presidency that will be offered by the Franklin Mint, it was an nounced today.

title: Avocado Pits Reincarnated
description: AN INGENIOUS New Jerseyan has transformed the lowly avocado pit into a work of art. Lillian Freedgood, a talented painter from West New York, has assembled a small but enviable collection of sculpture fashioned from avocado pits.

title: Maria H. Osterweil Is Engaged to Geoffrey L. Hewitt
description: Joyce Skarbnik Osterweil and Alfred G. Osterweil of River Vale, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maria Hope Osterweil, to Geoffrey Lee Heewitt, son of Jean D. Hewitt of Westerly, R.I., and the late Dr. Eric J. Hewitt.

title: Landfill in the Suburbs: Who Wants It Next Door?
description: When David Sandier and his family moved into their first home in Oceanside Park, L.I., 12 years ago, they didn't think much about it when someone said they would be living next to the Oceanside Park landfill site.

title: Major Revamping Is Expected at Olympic Meeting
description: Five years ago, a prominent member of the United States Olympic Committee likened the complex problems of the organization to the old lady who lived in a shoe.

title: By Map: A Whole World
description: Our Land Rover bounced along a narrow dirt road that hugged the west coast of the island. My guide, a tall, curious figure who called himself Lar, constantly tugged at the brim of a sweatstained hat. We stopped just short of a bend in the road, a precipitous point where the surf lapped at the coral below. To our right, a mangrove swamp. Ahead, a collection of tin shacks. That's a coconut plantation, Lar explained. It used to belong to my father, but . . . that's another story. Let's get going.

title: Meanwhile, in the Ring
description: Ten miles apart in the mountains of Southern California and 3,000 miles removed from the bickering, sniping and snooping around American Broadcasting Company's discredited United States championships, two heavyweights are engaged in an occupation that is almost out of style. Their names are Ken Norton and Duane Bobick, and they are not signing affidavits, giving depositions, running out on their managers or airing charges of corruption, deceit or chicanery. They are training for a fight inside the ring, of all places. On the night of Wednesday, May 11. they go 12 rounds or fewer in Madison Square Garden for cash rewards and a chance to detach Muhammad All from the championship of the world. Although it has not been announced, All has signed a contract to fight the winner, probably in Rio de Janeiro about Sept. 15.

title: Jill Hammer Is Married To Stephen Barry Stanley
description: Jill Martenis Hammer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Levering Hammer Jr. of Princeton, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Stephen Barry Stanley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad Waymond Stanley of Augusta, W. Va.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Princeton, Holy Cross, Alabama and Georgetown were named yesterday as the four basketball teams for the Eastern College Atheltic Conference's 26th annual Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden Dec. 27 and 29. Last year, six quintets competed.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: What They Are Saying
description: David Pearson, a Spartanburg, S.C., stock car driver, after he was rebuked for being critical of New York City: I'll tell you the truth about which place is better. You don't ever hear about people going up north to retire. Never.

title: The Man Who Painted Robert Altman's 3 Women
description: Robert Altman had a dream: two rootless young girls from Texas encounter each other in a barren California desert community and a transference of personality occurs. Out of this dream, Mr. Altman has fashioned one of his most haunting and talkedabout films.

title: A Sentimental Pause
description: THE dream began three years ago, when Arthur S. Schreiber's 12yearold son expressed sorrow at never having experienced the radio shows of the 1930's and the 1940's.

title: Alex Haley Denies Allegation That Parts of Roo Were Copied From Novel Written by Mississippi Teacher
description: Alex Haley said last night that he had not copied any portions of his bestselling book Roots from a 1966 novel called Jubilee, as alleged by the novel's author in a copyright infringement suit flied last week in Federal Court here.

title: The Best of Ernie Kovacs Captures a Classic TV Funnyman
description: The best of Ernie Kovacs? That's what the Public Broadcasting System calls its 10part series of halfhour programs, making its debut this Tuesday evening at 9:30 on Channel 13 and which offers selections from the work of one of television's funniest and most inventive artists.

title: Ruth Brown Spencer Wed
description: Ruth Brown Spencer of Pompano Beach, Fla., and Mystic, Conn., widow of Walter B. Spencer, a real estate developer, was married yesterday afternoon to Gordon Wilson Tasker of Old Lyme, Conn., a senior partner in charge of the Hartford office of Price Waterhouse, certified public accountants. The Rev. Chester M. Wetzel of St. Paul's United Methodist Church of Hartford performed the ceremony in Old Lyme's First Congregational Church. The bridegroom's previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: Afternoon temperatures have reached a balmy 82 degrees, intensity of sky blue is greeted by a familiar statement in New Jersey households: It's such a nice day, let's go shopping.

title: Betting in Suburbia Is a Sure Thing
description: CONTRARY to the current mythology, the favorite game in suburbia is not backgammon, or golf, or wife swapping. It is a universal pastime called We wudda won if . . . Any number can play.

title: BRIDGE
description: FOR the inexperienced bridge player who feels an urge to venture to the lower levels of tournament play, Westchester may be one of the best areas in the country.

title: 1,000 Women and a Parley on Health
description: IT was a nightmare, said the young woman as she described her experiences with a series of doctors in their unsuccessful efforts to treat a cervical complication that turned out to be cancer.

title: The Hands That Type Rule the World
description: When it comes to employment, why are many people, especially women, so down on typewriters? Interview them for a job. Say casually that there'll be some typing involved, and the reaction is swift. I don't type, they say, as if you have insulted them, their B.A. degrees and their inborn worthiness for staff status.

title: Carter's Decision to Abandon Plutonium Worries Western Europe
description: BRUSSELS, April 19Western Europe is worried by President's Carter's decision to abandon plutonium as a future source of nuclear energy for the United States and to restrict its availability to other countries.

title: A Reading and a Mourning
description: You don't throw the kid out, no way! The solo command, bursting from the St. Mark's audience, related to Gregory Corso's baby, who was acting tin in mild baby talk, at an Ash Wednesday reading of Allen Ginsberg and Robert Lowell. The event was unusual, even for St. Mark's Church, that mini Roman Forum of the poetry readout. A crowd of about 500, with another hundred lined up outside the highspired church in Greenwich Village, all with anticipation befitting the oddcouple casting.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Woody Allen is the poet of America's emotionally disenfranchised, urban, upwardly mobile males who seek fame, fortune and girls they can relate to. (Vincent Canby)

title: Long Island/This Week
description: COPIAGUEExhibition of works by Juliann Velasquez; through Saturday; weekdays 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Saturday 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Memorial Library. 314 Great Neck Rd.

title: Summer Jobs: Sunny Outlook
description: SUMMER JOBS. Many highschool and college students in Westchester will soon be looking for such employment, but the weary process of finding a job can often erode a student's elation over several weeks of freedom from the schoolbooks.

title: The Right Price of Energy
description: For all its length, tables, omissions, exhortations and numbing complexity, the Carter Administration's energy program proclaimed a single message: The price is wrong.

title: MUSIC
description: YOU'D THINK that political figures would get enough flack from their constituents without letting music critics have a whack at them too, but Governor Grasso is fearlessly proceeding with plans for her concert debut. It is to take place on Thursday, in the Ives Concert Hall of Western Connecticut State College, in Danbury, at the spring concert of the college orchestra.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: New Woman, Old Jazz, Hemingway
description: THE unexamined life is not worth living, Socrates said, but in reading contemporary fiction one sometimes wonders whether the examined Isn't even worse. It is not unusual to find characters scratching themselves all over, digging for identity like monkeys searching for fleas. The bawl for identity is a second birth trauma. To fully conscious is to suffer from what R.D. Laing called an insecurity of being, to wail, as William Blake put it, along the margins of nonentity. In order to arrive at authenticity, it may be necessary to shipwreck the self, as Kierkegaard suggested, and begin again, like Robinson Crusoe, on some remote existential beach.bawl for identity is a second birth trauma. To fully conscious is to suffer from what R.D. Laing called an insecurity of being, to wail, as William Blake put it, along the margins of nonentity. In order to arrive at authenticity, it may be necessary to shipwreck the self, as Kierkegaard suggested, and begin again, like Robinson Crusoe, on some remote existential beach.

title: Haley's Son: An Adviser to G.I.'s
description: FORT DIX THE PROUD father raised his newborn son to the vast sky and whispered into his ear: Behold the sky and the sun, the only things greater than yourself.

title: HARRY A. SPRAGUE, 91; LED MONTCLAIR COLLEGE
description: Dr. Harry A. Sprague, president emeritus of Montclair State College, Montclair, NJ., died yesterday at the Newton (NJ.) Nursing Home. He was 91 years old and lived in Sparta, N.J.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: About 20 years ago Saul Bellow wrote a sprawling novel named Henderson, the Rain King. It was about a boisterous millionaire who keeps looking for something in life. He drinks too much, he messes up everything he does, he hops from one thing to another. One thing he does have, and that is a lust for life. Finally, in an effort to find himself, he leaves wife and family and goes to Africa. He completely destroys the life of one tribe in an effort to help them. In another tribe he makes friends with the chieftain, learns a great deal from him, and watches horrified as the man is killed by a lion. At the end he returns home with a lion cub, appetite for life undiminished, ready to meet the future in his blundering way.

title: Nostalgia for the Old Germany
description: WITH unrestrained and uncharacteristic enthusiasm, Arthur Koestler in his preface to this slender work of fiction hails it as a minor masterpiece, minor only because it lacks the bulk and panoramic quality of the novel.While the praise seems grossly excessive, Koestler's gut responsenot to be confused with literary judgmentis understandable. He, too, has had his troubles with being Jewish, and Reunion touches a raw nerve in a phantom limb; the fate of the German Jews, most of them German by birth, by language and by ardent choice, but Jewish rather in spite of themselves. This is manifestly not what the author set out to write about. But among his wilted emotions recollected in nostalgia, selfcontempt is the one that comes most vividly alive.

title: Carter Energy Plan: Can the State Cope?
description: PRESIDENT CARTER'S campaign to conserve energy, including his proposed shift from oil to coal as the dominant fuel, will pose special problems for New Jersey. In fact, the state's entire industrial base may depend upon its learning to cope with the situation.

title: Incidents in Lebanon Are Delaying . . Efforts to Restore Peace to Area
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 23The killing of two Syrian soldiers of the peacekeeping force, recurring incidents in the south and an argument about subjecting Palestinian guerrillas to Lebanese restrictions are hampering the effort for peace in Lebanon.

title: Bruce Berman Fiance Of Deborah Sorcher
description: Elaine Sorcher of Fort Lee, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Deborah Gayl Sorcher, to Bruce Martin Berman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L, Berman of Harrington Park, N. J.

title: Catholic Lay Teachers And Eroding Salaries
description: THE Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark manages 13 regional high schools throughout the Bergen, Hudson, Essex and Union County areas of New Jersey. Thousands of students attend these schools. Parents who believe in quality education send their children to these schools in spite of prohibitive tuition costs because they, like teachers, administrators and church officials, truly believe that the education afforded students in these schools is equal to if not in some cases better than, that afforded students in the public schools.

title: Lost in Cambodia
description: On the morning of May 31, 1970, Welles Hangen, a correspondent for NBC News, his cameraman and sound man and their Cambodian driver, left Phnom Penh for Takeo, 50 miles to the south, where fighting was said to be taking place. It had been only about a month since American and South Vietnamese troops had crossed the Cambodian border in the illconceived attempt to eliminate Vietcong and North Vietnamese sanctuaries. The Khmer Rouge had risen in revolt, and the television networks were in hot competition for the sights and sounds of the same old war in a brandnew country.

title: P.S. Kotsher Fiance Of Bonnie A. Balick
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Balick of Wilmington, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bonnie Ann Balick, to Paul Scott Kotsher, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. J. Kotsher of Bronxville. N.Y.

title: Emanuel Sobel, a Lawyer, 78, Dies While Vacationing in Israel
description: Emanuel Sobel, an associate in the law firm of Raphael, Searles, Vischi, Scher, Glover & D'Elia, died last Sunday while vacationing in Israel with his wife, the former Irena Rozinski, it was reported yesterday. He was 78 years old and lived at 165 West 66th Street.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: IN MAY 1915, Louis M. Bloomingdale, an heir to the department store fortune, and his wife, Irma, purchased the Elm Ridge farm in the backwoods of New Rochelle. They were looking for a more relaxed life in the country and they found it: growing vegetables, raising cows and chickens and doing all the other things gentlemen farmers do. Sixty years later, the farm was sold to a developer, and an important and now nearly forgotten era passed into history. The last farm in New Rochelle would soon be just a memory.

title: Soccer Final Reached By Manchester United
description: LONDON, April 23 (UPI)Manchester United reached the final of the Football Association Cup today with a 2.1 victory over Leeds at Sheffield. But its opponent won't be decided for four days as Liverpool and Everton tied, 22, in the other semifinal. The final is on May 21 at Wembley.

title: A Shelter That Isn't a Shelter
description: HAUPPAUGE SUFFOLK County's Children's Shelter isn't really a shelter, and the teenaged boys and girls kept in it probably don't fit most people's idea of what children should be. The county calls it a secure facility. The center is really a jail.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS CAN VIEW STAR IS BORN, NOT READ IT
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 23 (AP)The South African censors have prohibited the book version of Barbra Streisand's latest international boxoffice hit film, A Star is Born, which has played here.

title: Miss Feldman In Fine Recital On the Cello
description: Marion Feldman's program at Carnegie Recital Hall Friday night had certain classic simplicity: three sonatas for cello, one from the Classical repeltory, Beethoven's Op. 5, No. 2; one from the Romantic, Chopin, and one from the 20th century, Shostakovich.

title: Andrea Shay Wed to Edward H. Thaxter
description: The marriage of Andrea Howdon Shay, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Howdon of Baltimore, to Edward Hobbs Thaxter took place yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. The bridgeroom is the son of Mrs. Francis Hopkinson Van Deventer of Greenwich and the late Roger Lewis Thaxter. The Rev. Ashley M. Calhoun performed the ceremony in the Round Hill Community Church.

title: A Resource Center for Women
description: LIFE doesn't end out here in the winter, but it's hard to connect with people, hard is particularly true for women

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
description: Engagements

title: H.E.W. MAY SETTLE NEW YORK'S CLAIM, GRANT $100 MILLION
description: Mayor Beame and Governor Carey have been informed by the Carter Administration that it is prepared to settle a range of longdisputed reimbursement claims dating from 1972a step that could lead to a windfall, in the next year or more, of as much as $100 million for New York City and a like amount for New York State.

title: The Thesis as Creative Writing
description: THESIS. The mere mention of his twosyllable word can strike blind terror into the hearts of most Princeton seniors at this time of year. Whether it is a library research project or an original scientific experimentor a combination of the twoit can easily run 100, 200 and sometimes 300 pages long; meant to be the culmination of the student's four years at Princeton, it often weighs heavily in the determination of departmental honors and prizes.

title: Edmund Fleming, Lawyer, To Marry Nancy Green
description: The engagement of Nancy Ellen Green to Edmund E. Fleming, both of Boston, has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. William S. Green of Manchester, NH.

title: Epilogue
description: An investigation by Brooklyn College has concluded that there is no clear evidence that Prof. Michael Selzer, a political scientist, engaged in covert activities for the Central Intelligence Agency and as a result he will remain on the faculty. Professor Selzer said last January that he was connected with the agency in only a peripheral way in connection with overseas trips and denied the charges made by the political science department that he had violated academic standards in a way that would warrant removal. A faculty investigating committee agreed with Professor Selzer's version and said no formal charges would be brought against him. If the charges had been brought and proven, he could have lost his post.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE  The Fantasticks. Friday and Saturday at 8 P.M.. Sunday at 2 P.M. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Route 6. $5.50 to $6.50. 6281169.

title: Births
description: Arenstein

title: SHOP TALK
description: MARK LEFCOVICH is slender and of medium height, bus he knows a lot more than many people do about clothes for men who are big, tall or both. Three years ago, he opened

title: Only the Boxers Change
description: The fast money attracts the boxers and the schemers. But the boxers bleed, the schemers smirk. The boxers depart, the schemers survive. It has always been that way in boxing, and it always will be. It's the nature of the business and the nature of the people in it. That's why the investigation into the intrigues surrounding the United States Championships, as promoted by Don King at ABC, is really a reminder that boxing is always a potential scandal. House fighters are not new. Neither are kickbacks, wrong records, lax supervision and TV takeovers. The boxers change, but boxing does not. Not that the current investigation should be condoned as part of boxing's scurvy charm. If evidence supports Scott LeDoux's charge that his loss by decision to Johnny Boudreaux was fixed, Federal attorneys will prosecute those responsible.

title: Eliza Chase Jones Is Married
description: Eliza Chase Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald William Jones of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Grover Cleveland Jr., son of the Rev. and Mrs. Thomas G. Cleveland of Milton, Mass., and greatgrandson of President Grover Cleveland.

title: Assad East and West
description: CAIROPresident Hafez elAssad, who was in Moscow last week and will meet President Carter in Geneva early next month, is the only influential Arab leader in a position to speak effectively to both the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
Hugh TrevorRoper: History Is Relevant
description: HUGH TREVORROPER, Regius Professor of Modern History at Oxford University since 1957, was born in 1914. He is married to Lady Alexandra HowardJohnston, daughter of FieldMarshal Earl Haig, and he lists as his clubs the Savile, the Beefsteak and the New (Edinburgh). He has a house in Oxford and a house in Scotland, he has published more than a dozen books, several essays and lectures, and adding a dash of rum to this gentlemanly brew, he worked for British Intelligence during the World War II, a fact about which Who's Who, naturally enough, maintains a discreet silence.

title: Connecticut /This Week
description: AVONLimitededition lithographs by Edna Hibel, daily except Sunday through May 31. Fireside Center, 369 West Main St.. at Rte. 44.

title: Radio
description: Today: Leading Events

title: Special Fee Is Offered For Neutering of Pets
description: The Humane Society is offering a special love fee for all spaying and neutering appointments of cats and dogs made during Be Kind to Animals Week. May 1 through 8. Rates are as follows:

title: County Puts Artist On the Road
description: DANIEL BONACORSI, a 24yearold programmer for MiniComputer Systems in Elmsford, sat in the smokefilled living room and studied the sketch on his easel.

title: INTERVIEW
description: WHATS NEW with Billy Hayes? Always something, it seems. Billy Hayes, you might remember, was a 23yearold dropout from Marquette University in the autumn of 1970 when be was arrested at Yesillcoy International Airport in Istanbul and accused of smuggling hashish.

title: DINING OUT
description: ABOUT six weeks ago, a restaurant called Chili Garden vacated the premises at 96 East Main Street in Babylon. It may be the first time a restaurant has gone out of business soon after a highly favorable review. The subsequent tenant, called the Ultimate Szechuan, is a Chinese restaurant of the neighborhood category, without the inspiration in the kitchen that made Chili Garden so special.

title: Teddy Pendergrass, Soul Singer, at Carnegie Hall
description: Teddy Pendergrass celebrated the amenities of the flesh and then entered a final plea for the salvation of the spirit at his Carnegie Hall concert on Friday evening. The former lead vocalist with Harold Melvin and the Blue Notes, who filled the hall and whose first solo album apparently is about to pass the milliondollar mark in sales, spent much of his performance singing about love or the lack of in his grainy, almost stentorian voice, wiggling all the while inside a tight white stage suit. But he reappeared for his encore in a sparkling white robe and inserted a description of a childhood religious experience into his closing number.

title: Blowout in North Sea Occurred At Critical Period of Maintenance
description: HOUSTON, April 23When oilmen perform a workover on a producing oil well, they subject themselves and the environment to one of the most vulnerable and dangerous periods in the life of the well. They have to force oil to do what it is under great pressure not to dostay in the ground.

title: Back to the Books on School Financing
description: GOVERNOR GRASSO. Attorney General Carl Ajello and the Democratic leaders of the General Assembly agreed last week that they might spend a year or more on an intensive, Federally subsidized study of the inequities in public education in the state before making any bold new moves to remove them.

title: Miss Haskell Becomes Bride Of J. M. Cohen
description: Rebecca Kent Haskell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Kent Haskell of New Canaan, Conn., and James Matthew Cohen, son of Mrs. Budd Levinson of East Hampton, L. I., and Richard N. Cohen of Stamford, Conn., were married yesterday evening at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Just a Beginning
description: President Carter has proposed a complex plan for reducing the nation's consumption of fuels that relies primarily on voluntary responses to higher prices rather than compulsion to ward off what he regards as an impending, acute energy scarcity. Despite his own belief in its urgency, however, persuading Congress to accept the plan is likely to be a severe test of his leadership.

title: Zenith's Ominous Victory
description: The United States Customs Court has ruled that the Zenith Corporation and other manufacturers are entitled to tariff protection against the import of Japanese electronics. As a result, the prices of imported television and stereo sets are expected to rise by Gout 10 percent. But more than that was at stake in the Zenith case. If the decision survives legal challenge, dozens of other industries may become eligible for additional protection. American consumers would end up paying higher prices for hundreds of manufactured goods, and American exporters would probably encounter formidable new barriers to selling abroad.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: The article in the Westchester Weekly on March 13 entitled Is Anyone Protecting the Consumer? provides A myopic view of the status of consumer protection in Westchester County. It completely ignores the affirmative action taken by the Westchester County District Attorney for several years.

title: Realty News
description: New devices are springing up to help landlords of apartment houses sell their properties without incurring a capital gains tax.

title: In Havana, a Look at Cuba's Shopping List
description: Starting May 15, Orbitair International Ltd., a New York travel agency, will offer weeklong inclusive tours to Havana for $399 for American citizens. But there's a catch: the tours will begin and end in Montreal.

title: POLITICS
description: MOST members of the General Assembly seem to think they have plenty of time while they work quietly at restructuring a vital $1.2 billion program the public education of children.

title: Watson 136 In Golf Lead
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 23 (UPI)Tom Watson used his second eagle of the tournament today to help him take a onestroke lead over Stan Lee at the midpoint of the $175,000 New Orleans open.

title: In Triumph or in Defeat, A Good Job Is Still Good
description: In a recent Sunday sports section, there was a picture of Julius Erving sitting on the bench watching his team play. The caption was All for Naught, apparently because the 76ers were losing. It is similarly not unusual to read that . . . a fine performance by Earl Monroe was wasted as the Knicks lost.

title: Ambulance Duty One Yonkers Night
description: THE SATURDAY NIGHT shift begins slowly at the Yonkers Ambulance Corps. There's talk at the volunteer organization's headquarters on Central Park Avenue in the northeast section of the city, of the full moon, and halfserious speculation on whether it portends an unusual night.

title: Levitt Attributes Mismanagement to New York City Housing Aides, Who Respond by Citing Efforts Made
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that New York City housing officials had been lax in supervising the management and operations of middleincome apartment developments built under the MitchellLama housing program, contributing to the financial problems besetting the program.

title: As Easy as Pi
description: IN the fulldisclosure spirit of this postWatergate era, Isaac Asimov's introduction to this book offers a confession. Its contentswithminor exceptionsare old Asimoviana. The essays originally appeared in a magazine between 1959 and 1966. But Asimov is far and away the most successful popular

title: Airline Noise Charge Is Proposed For Operations at Major Airports
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI)  Airlines may have to pay a noise charge for their operations at the nation's major airports if a recommendation by the Council on Wage and Price Stability is adopted.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: We have a lot of great ballet companies in the United Statesand a lot of rather indifferent ones as well. But two companies stand outpartly by their size, their scope, aspirations and international reputations, and partly simply by their age. These are New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater. I said partly by their agebecause neither is, in fact, the oldest extant American company, that distinction going to the San Francisco Ballet. But they are pretty old, and they are pretty wellestablished. Interestingly, however, they are both firstgeneration companies, still being run by the people who founded them. They provide a vast contrast in how to build a ballet company and also how to run a ballet company. For that matter, they provide quite a contrast in audiences. There are some people even some criticswho love one company and abhor the other.

title: THEATER
description: ON Thursday, May 5, the Westchester  Rockland Regionag Theater presents a preview of its third and final production of the season, Hedda Gabler, at the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck. The production opens officially on May 6, plays the 7th and 8th, and the following May 12 through 15 before moving over to the Rockland Center for the Arts in West Nyack for two performances on May 21. So, what's so special about another revival of the Ibsen classic? This one, which uses the Rolf Fjelde translation as its text, will also have Professor Fjelde, America's leading translator of Ibsenand a resident of White Plainsserving as special consultant.

title: Rightist Leader Opposes Vorster as Too Liberal on Blacks
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, April 23Johannes Albertus Hertzog believes, passionately, that John Vorster's racial policies are endangering South Africa. But his similarity with reformers stops there, because Mr. Hertzog, leader of the small but vocal Herstigte Nasionale Party, or Reformed National Party, believes that the Prime Minister's mistake has been to be too liberal with the natives, as he calls the country's 18.6 million blacks.

title: Halting Colorado's DoItYourself Divorce
description: DENVER (AP)A Denver judge has ordered a concern offering doityourself divorces to stop operating in Colorado.

title: OIL SPILL DAMAGE MAY DEPEND ON WIND
description: The extent of environmental damage caused by the North Sea oil spill may well be determined by the winds and weather in a tempestuous region known to sailors as the fiercest sea of them all.

title: College Head Joining Foundation
description: POMONA, Calif., April 23 (UPI)Dr. Robert V. Kramer, president of California State Polytechnic University, has announced that he will resign in July to become program director of the W.K. Kellogg Foundation in Battle Creek, Mich. Dr. Kramer, 56 years old, will oversee and evaluate the foundation's agricultural projects in the United States, Canada, Latin America, Western Europe and Australia.

title: Crimson Conquers Brown on Charles
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 23The battle of the Charles was contested today by all the Boston crews sharing this racing course, and supremacy was gained as much by surviving the rowing conditions as by the quality of the rowing.

title: U.S. Approval Seen for Jet Sale
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)The Carter Administration is expected to approve the sale to Austria of 24 Israelimade fighterbombers equipped with American engines, Administration sources say, However, Austrian officials said that their Government had not yet decided to buy the Kfir jets, which would cost between $110 million and $140 million. United States approval for the sale is required because the jets are fitted with General Electric J79 engines.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONLord John Maynard Keynes conceived of the International Monetary Fund in a bold sweep as a world central bank that would issue legal tender and try to bring centralized economic direction to the stricken globe.

title: Vietnam Asks Help From Asian Bank, but Early Action Is Held Unlikely
description: MANILA, April 23Vietnam asked the Asian Development Bank today to come speedily to its assistance in the task of reconstruction, but the bank's president, Taroichi Yoshida, suggested that it might be quite a long time before such action could be taken.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH SOME brands of exterior paint are advertised as being all purpose finishes that can be used on almost any type of surface around the outside of the house, most experts still agree that this is seldom, if ever really true. That is why most Large manufacturers still make a variety of different kinds of exterior paint for home use. The homeowner who wants to insure longlasting results and provide maximum protection for the outside of his house should familiarize himself with the various types that are available and with the principal characteristics of each.

title: Paul Fargis Weds Dawn Sangrey, Editor
description: Dawn Sangrey of New York and Paul McKenna Fargis of Mount Vernon, N. Y., were married yesterday afternoon in Mount Vernon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Hurzeler. State Supreme Court Justice Bentley Kassal performed the ceremony.

title: Coffee, Tea, Wine and Music
description: ON a side street near the railroad tracks that run along the Hudson River in Hastings, there is a coffeehouse called Fair Harbor, On Friday and Saturday nights people stop by for coffee, herb tea or wine, for a slice of banana cake rich with chocolate icing, or a wedge of coconut custard pie. But mainly they come for the music.

title: A Yankee Pilgrim In the Old South
description: It's called the rise of the New South and it has something to do with serving grits instead of pasta at plush soirees; printing yawl come goldengraved party invitations; squaredancing instead of doing the hustle at your neighborhood disco; actually marrying your livein boy or girlfriend or returning home to your estranged spouse for good this time; acquiring a complete set of Gregg Allman or Dolly Parton records; wearing denims and a cardigan sweater to board meetings. Now combine all of that with our Fret(lent's flannel shirts and a Gone With the Wind telecact which took the ratings by storm, and you've got to admit that the South not only shall rice but has risen and keeps on rising again and again.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: A Quiz on Energy
description: The worst aspects of the energy crisis President Carter has described to the American people probably would not arrive until after he had served eight years, if reelected. Presidents, moreover, particularly those who are narrowly elected, are apt to regard themselves as too weak to make major demands on the American people until after they have won a second termwhen, in any event, they can't run again anyway.

title: Alexis Massad Is Wed To James K. Gleitman
description: Alexis Dee Massad, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Hamilton Massad of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to James Kent Gleitman, son of Mrs. Edwin Richard Gleitman of San Angelo, Tex., and the late Mr. Gleitman. The Rev. Dr. James E. Annand performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: The Region
description: The Connecticut Supreme Court, in line with similar decisions in other states, has invalidated the state's method of financing public schools because, the court said, the method discriminates against poorer districts.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 (AP)City Supervisor Robert Mendelsohn says that his nomination to a key job in the Interior Department is not being delayed because of $150,000 in political debts.

title: Letters: A Volley In Defense of Utica
description: To the Editor.

title: Aimee Enid Randall Is Bride
description: The marriage of Aime Enid Randall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Nathan Randall of Stamford, Conn., to Gerald Lawrence Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Levy of East Meadow, L. I.. took place last evening in the Rye Town Hilton Inn. Rabbi Samuel Silver performed the ceremony. The bride's father is a vice president at Kidder, Peabody & Company in New York.

title: Hughes's Cousin Makes Changes To Keep Assets
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 Behind secrecy as heavy as it was while Howard R. Hughes lived, the companies he left are being managed by men who fear they may lose control unless they increase earnings, according to sources close to the Hughes operations.

title: Jets Owner Aids Mayoral Campaign of Political Unknown
description: Leon Hess, the oil magnate and principal owner of the New York Jets, has contributed $10,000 to a political unknown who is running for Mayor, Louis P. Wein. If that were not unusual enough, Mr. Hess contended, through a spokesman, that he didn't even know Mr. Wein and was not supporting him for Mayor.

title: Policeman Shot During Drug Arrest Dies of Wound
description: Police Officer Robert W. Mandel, who was gunned down with another officer last Tuesday while trying to make a narcotics arrest in Brooklyn at a BedfordStuyvesant tavern, died just before noon yesterday in Brooklyn Jewish Hospital.

title: Yvonne Lebourdais Crimley Wed to L. Ashley Robinson
description: Yvonne M. Lebourdals Crimley, daughter of Mrs. Armand Lebourdais of Port Chester, N.Y., and the late Mr. Lebourdais, was married yesterday afternoon to L. Ashley Robinson, son of Mrs. Leland R. Robinson of Bronxville, N.Y., and the sate Mr. Robinson.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, APRIL 24, 1977

title: Canadian Pianist Shows Technical Strengths
description: On Wednesday night, Jacinthe Couture was presented in Carnegie Recital Hall in the Carnegie HallJeunesses Musicales series. I he pianist represented the Canadian branch of Jeunesses Musicales, an international organization which, among other things, promotes the exchange or young musicians.

title: Clive's Comeback
description: Amid the dark wood, chrome and Lucite of a midtown Manhattan conference room, a baldish middleaged man plays loud rockandroll for other men Just off the tram from places like Scarsdale. It is the Monday morning meeting at Arista Records, and although the gathered executives briefly debate matter, of advertising, merchandising, promotion and production, they mostly just listen. Leaning forward in their chairs, they try to divine what 13yearolds will want to hear, A couple close their eyes and tap time to the music with their pens.

title: EMPLOYEE KILLED BY BOMB AT WASHINGTON AIRPORT
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI)  A springloaded pipe bomb exploded today in a locker room at National Airport, killing an employee of the Federal Aviation Administration. However, the agency said there had been no threat to air passengers and no disruption of airline operations.

title: Spanish Premier Leaving for U.S.
description: MADRID, April 23 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez leaves tomorrow for Mexico and the United States to seek financial support for Spain. Mr. Surez, guiding Spain toward its first free elections in 41 years, will hold talks with President Carter and leading bankers and businessmen in the United States. He first flies to Mexico, healing a 40year rift in relations between the two countries.

title: RENOVATED BUILDING DRAWING ATTENTION
description: Connecticut and Rhode Island officials toured a renovated building described as a vertical industrial park in a devastated area of the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn last week in search of innovative ideas for their own communities.

title: A Schooner
description: SAILING aboard the Trade Wind on a glorious sunny day last week, no instructor ever turned to the 13 high school students and bluntly stated the day's lesson: See, look at this mess, New Haven's harbor is disgustingly polluted and Long Island Sound is in trouble.

title: FISHING
description: SPORT fishing is one of the most important activities on Long Island Sound and its rapid growth in recent years is expected to continue, according to the Sound Study by the New England River Basin Commission. The study estimates that more than one million persons fish the Sound's waters each year.

title: Andretti at Trenton En Route to Indy
description: TRENTON, April 23Want to get Mario Andretti angry? Congratulate him on his comeback for winning the United States Grand Prix at Long Beach, Calif.

title: Mobutu Flies to Zaire Copper Belt To Visit Troops Fighting Invaders
description: KOLWEZI, Zaire, April 23 (UPI) President Mobuto Sese Seko was welcomed by dancing girls and cheerleaders on his arrival today at this copper mining center to review Zairean, Moroccan and pygmy forces that he says are routing rebel invaders.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: MY friend Green Thumb called the other Sunday and peremptorily ordered us to visit him at bis home near New Hyde Park. Green Thumb, for me, is to horticulture what Deep Throat was to politics. He guides me through the mysterious plant world, tipping me off on what bulbs are related, on the relationship of perennials with annuals (I don't think there is any, but I'll check it out with Green Thumb) and on orchids, which are his passion.

title: Sanitarian Begin Cleanup Drive
description: Jules Leon plucked a thermometer from his shirt pocket, sterilized it in hot water and took the temperature of some tuna fish in a midtown Manhattan building. At a barbershop in the same building he borrowed a hand mirror to look at pipes behind a partition. Nearby, at a luncheon club, he watched and then jotted down notes as a waiter broke up pats of butter with his fingers.

title: By Air: Grand Canyon
description: At 6:15 A.M., sealed off by manmade darkness, I stand in the lobby of Caesar's Palace Hotel. In the infinite indoor Las Vegas night, a security guard is chatting with a change girl and, at the slot machines, loners and losers are fighting off daylight and the odds. My younger daughter, 11, looms up in this vast gulp of gaudy dark and asks, only half in jest: Daddy, is this the Grand Canyon?

title: Nancy Goodman Is Engaged to Michael David Morse
description: Dr. and Mrs. Merrill Goodman of East Hills, LI., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Beth Goodman, to Michael David Morse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Morse of Butler, Pa. A wedding in the summer is planned.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Against the Yale Tradition, a Woman at the Helm?
description: NEW HAVEN, April 22Bluffing her way through a summer job as a dictationist for a Yale professor nearly 30 yars ago, Hanna Holborn Gray had visions of New York and a glamorous publishing career. She never dreamed that she might someday have the chance to become president of Yale University, a devoutly male institution which then barred women as undergraduates.

title: The Best Bottle Game
description: When the talk turns to wine, I can usually hold my own. But there is one game of wine oneupmanship that is always difficult to play, that business about the best bottle.

title: When Coal Is Mined, Chessie Will Haul It
description: CLEVELANDAs the nation's leading coal hauler, the Chessie System has consistently been one of the nation's three most profitable railroadsthe other two are the Union Pacific and the Norfolk & Western.

title: Headliners
description: Governor Carey, who is touring Ireland, has denounced the Irish Republican Army as killers and Marxists, and has called on IrishAmericans to halt their support of the organization. Mr. Carey made his remarks following a meeting with Liam Cosgrave, the Irish Prime Minister. Last month, Mr. Carey had joined with other IrishAmerican politicians in a considerably milder statement that asked IrishAmericans to withdraw support for groups in Ireland espousing violence. It is estimated that between 75 and 90 percent of the Irish Republican Army's weaponry is provided by contributions from the United States.

title: School Districts in Suburbs of New York City Are Troubled by Declining Enrollments
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 21Intense passions always flare when neighborhood schools are forced to close because of dwindling enrollments, but even Janet Blake was stunned by something that happened to her recently, something that she says showed her the true extent of the passion in the Valhalla School District.

title: STAMPS
description: Describing the ninth hour of his 33hour solo transatlantic flight from New York to Paris, Charles A. Lindbergh said: I nose the Spirit of St. Louis down to meet the sea. I level out at 20 feet above the water above a rougher, greener, colderlooking ocean, with whitecaps breaking off to a streak. The sun is sinkeng; its brilliance is already fadingnight lies ahead.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: This show is a political act, and thus represents a corruption of the museum's function. (Hilton Kramer)

title: LEFKOWITZ IS SCORED ON OFFICE EFFICIENCY
description: A Federal judge has criticized the office of the New York State Attorney General for having repeatedly failed to respond to a prisoner's petition for release from a state prison.

title: The Nation
description: The Economy: Once More an Uneven Picture

title: Sue Anne Steffey, A Cleric, Is Bride
description: The Rev. Sue Anne Steffey, associate minister of Trinity United Methodist Church in McMurray, Pa., was married yesterday to David Galvin Morrow, a lawyer in Pittsburgh.

title: SelfExpression Without Straggly Ends
description: PORT WASHINGTON THE exhibition by Japanese artists in New York at the Port Washington Public Library drives home a point that we may have been at least tangentially aware of for some time without expressing it: Japanese art may be many other things, but it is usually always wellcrafted.

title: Rubin Carter Asks County to Pay For Transcript Needed in Appeal
description: Judge Bruno L. Leopizzi of Passaic County Court in Paterson. N.J. is considering an application brought by lawyers for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis to grant the two men indigency status so that the county will pay for the trial transcript needed for an appeal.

title: Shore Birds: A Fight for Life
description: IN about two months, the Long Island shore will be invaded by thousands of people bent on simple pleasuresa suntan, a salty swim, a boat ride, frozencustard cone. But right now, another invasion is taking place there, one that has been occurring annually almost since the beginning of the world. The invaders are birds and they are bent on business . . . serious, lifeanddeath business.

title: Little America's Cup: Winds of Dissent
description: While the 12Meter yachts will be racing in the Atlantic Ocean off Newport, R. I., for the America's Cup this summer, CClass catamarans will be dueling in the Pacific off Cabrillo Beach, Calif., for a more modest prize the Little America's Cup. The United States, which won the Cup for the first time in its 16year history last year, will be defending it against challengers from Australia and England. The 25foot CClass yachts are the fastest sailing machines afloat, capable of reaching speeds of 30 knots. And the class is open to innovative concepts because of its few restrictions.

title: Criticism on the Rise As Korean Inquiries Continue in Capital
Retired Teacher, 95, Dead in Apartment, Was Murder Victim
description: A retired, 95yearold schoolteacher, found dead in her Brooklyn apartment four days ago, was the victim of homicide, according to an autopsy report issued yesterday.

title: Week of Rainfall Revives the Midwest Wheat Crop
description: ULYSSES, Kan., April 22Last Feb. 23 this small southwestern Kansas town was entombed in dust as the howling winds swept in tons of topsoil from the wheat and milo fields to the west, eclirising the midafternoon sun and halting all movement over the grimy roads.

title: The OpeningsA Revival and a Premiere
The New Wave in Flair
description: If you've been battling your hair all your life, relax. The fight is almost over, You who have hated your obnoxiously curly hair, your steelwool tresses, your lank locks, are about to be freed from the tyranny of it all, because across the country, au naturel is the new wave in hair styling Reactions range from It's very sexy to You've got to be kidding. But the fashion view is clear This is what's right for now The look of this new wave can be curly or straight, whatever the hair's inclination, but it must never appear styled, rather as if one never did a thing to it. Granted, it's possible to confuse the look with that of a disheveled washerwoman, But the artifice and money spent on achieving the desired state of naturalism is more than was ever expended on the old setwithcurlers, situnderthedryer and tease techniques

title: DRIVERS AND DEALERS ASSESS CARTER PLAN
description: DETROIT, April 23Anna Smith, a cleaning woman from the Watts section of Los Angeles, relies on a 1965 Oldsmobile to get herself and two friends to work. It is unquestionably a gasoline waster from the age of cheap, throwaway energy. I'm just going to have to dig down in my pocket and pay more for gas, she said after listening to President Carter's energy message the other night. My car is big, but I can't afford to buy a small one.

title: Paul J. Elston Plans to Marry Miss Beinecke
description: Mr. and Mrs. William S. Beinecke of Summit, N.J., and Chatham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Frances Gillespie Beinecke, to Paul Joseph Elston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bert Elston of Fort Myers, Fla., formerly of Westport, Conn., and Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Women's Rights, 1977
description: JOCELYN GAGNE, a 28yearold employee of The American Cyanamid Company in Wallingford, is one of the women who found the Connecticut Women's Education and Legal Fund Inc. at a time when she believed people just weren't treating me fairly.

title: Carolyn Afflitto, an Artist, Married to Lawrence Weiss
description: Carolyn Marie Afflitto, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Afflitto of Brooklyn and Yankee Lake, N. Y., was married yesterday evening to Lawrence H. Weiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Weiss of Brooklyn. Rabbi Joseph Adler performed the ceremony at the St. RegisSheraton Roof.

title: Israel Still Prefers Its Peace One Step at a Time
description: JERUSALEM The Israeli concept of peace has always been dual: a vision of reconciliation between Arab and Jews as pure and unreal as the cartoonists' dove combined with improvised arrangements leading ultimately to Arab acceptance of Israel as part of the Middle East.

description: THE office of Governor Ca?? has begun an investigation ?? the twoyearold problem of a small Westchester ?? that has been without formal ?? protection since its beginning in 1948 as an experiment in cooperative ownership.
