description: There was an oldfashioned, sentimental air to Margery Clifford's Offering ?? Songs to the Glory of God last Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital ??.

title: NORTH SEA BLOWOUT CAUSES BIG OIL SLICK
description: STAVANGER, Norway, April 23A pipe on an oil well in the North Sea blew out last night, sending a 180foothigh fountain of oil cascading into the water and creating a 20squaremile slick drifting toward the southern coast of Norway and Denmark's Jutland coast.

title: At Long Last, the Rites of Spring
description: THROUGH the absolutely miserable months of January, February and March it seemed to many that spring was never coming. Rarely aid so many yearn with such desperation for the sight of just one daffodil.

title: Ancient Art Shines In Drew Exhibition
description: THOSE who can't tell a krater from a hydria, or a pyxis from an elf, don't have to worry unduly when they walk into the Drew University Art Gallery in Madison.

title: Patterson's First Day in Big Leagues Proves Troublesome to Yank Pitcher
description: CLEVELAND, April 23  Different players take different routes to reach the major leagues. This is the route traveled by Gil Patterson, the young Yankee pitcher who is scheduled to start against Cleveland tomorrow.

title: Fitzsimmons Cool to Gas Tax
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 22 (UPI)Frank E. Fitzsimmons, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, predicts President Carter's energy program will face rough sledding in Congress. He said yesterday that the proposed gasoline standby tax was a tax on working people, and that it would be awfully hard on the people who must commute some 20 and 30 miles to work. He is here for a meeting of the teamster executive council.

title: For Children, Help by Interdigitation
description: OUR standard dictionary does not define interdigitate, but the working middle manager in government departments can. We learned what the word means when we became a part of an interdigitation in our county that is developing nicely.

title: Cynthia North Wed To John Morawski
description: Cynthia Lois North, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Weir North of Sea Cliff, L. I., was married yesterday to John Morawski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Peter Morawski of Shaker Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Robert C. Bonar performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Sea Cliff.

title: Audrey B. Fleming Sets June Bridal
description: Mrs. Andreas Wolf Jr. of Salinas, Calif., formerly of New York, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Audrey Barclay Fleming, to Matthew Elliot Burton Smitter, son of Mrs. William Charles John Musham of New York and Dr. Yvor Smitter of Sacramento, Calif.

title: CHESS
description: Aqueen sacrifice imparts certain flair to a game, even if the material acquired in return is considerable. The advantage of a queen over rook plus bishop is not enormous, being approximately the equivalent of the advantage of the exchange, or perhaps slightly less, and yet exchange sacrifices are common, while giving the queen for rook plus bishop is not.

title: Wounded Policeman Dies
description: Police Officer Robert W. Mandel, who wag wounded with another officer last Tuesday in a BedfordStuyvesant tavern, died yesterday. Page 34.

title: What's Doing in MOSCOW
description: THE WELCOME  Once Moscow conjured up an image of snowswept, forbidding isolation, but times have changed with the Soviet bid for the tourist market. About four million tourists visited the Soviet Union last year, and most of them came to Moscow. The opendoor hospitality is not entirely altruistic, though. Every spring the official press warns Soviet citizens against the horrors of ideological contamination from Western bourgeois tourists; the incentive is in the dollars and other hard currency that visitors spend. Moscow still cannot compete with the comforts that Western capitals offer, but a genuine effort has been made to ease the tourist's lot. The state travel monopoly, Intourist, has tried to reduce the bureaucratic hassle to modest Soviet proportions. A successful visit to Moscow demands curiosity and good humor but can be well rewarded, particularly this year as the Soviet Union girds up to celebrate the 60th anniversary of the Revolution.

title: GARDENING
description: AT ONE TIME heathers dominated open land in Europe. As much as a fifth of the land in the Netherlands was covered with them at the beginning of the 18th century. And today heathers continue to thrive on the British moors, in spite of their use for grazing, making brooms and brushes and as sods for constructing houses. When you think of an English cottage garden, heathers come to mind.

title: Pupils Given Animal Poster Awards
description: They scribbled with pencils, rubbed with chalk and dabbled with paint. They drew twolegged cats, shapeless guinea pigs and blue dogs with yellow noses. But whatever the medium, the message was clear  he kind to animals.

title: 600.000 Lebanese Fled Abroad
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 16 (UPI)More than 600,000 Lebanese, about 20 percent of the population, fled the country during the recent civil war, the Lebanese World League said in a study made public this week. Almost half the emigrants  272,500  settled permanently outside Lebanon, including 14,515 in the United States, the study said.

title: Economic Indicators
description: Statistics for commercial agricultural loans, carloadings, steel, oil, electric power and business failures are for the preceding week and latest available

title: Academies: Getting In
description: WHEN I was a kid, said the 58yearold Army Air Corps veteran, I wanted to go to West point. But my father had no political pull, and my mother had no political pull, and I couldn't get in. That made me madder than hell, and I became determined to change the system.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: WHEN Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. set up a hot line last year to take weekly calls from his Westchester constituents, his chief aide feared that the idea would never get off the ground.

title: Making MillionDollar Deals
description: STORM LAKE, IowaThe twinengine Beechcraft rolled to a stop at the airstrip here. Duane Sandage bounded out of the plane and strode toward the camper parked by the strip.

title: INTERVIEW
description: DESPITE a ninemonth absence from the bench, during which he served as Governor Byrne's special counsel, and his recent elevation to the New Jersey Supreme Court, the state's highest tribunal, Justice Alan B. Handler feels as if he never left. In fact, the justice his been given the same office in Somerville that he used when he served as a judge in the Appellate Division ?? Superior Court for more than nine years.

title: Art for the Very Young
description: ON a cold, snowy February morning, 12 preschoolers stayed warm, dry and happy while they built an unusual sixfoot snowman indoors, Under the direction of Anne Shengold, assistant to the director at the Children's Art Institute of Jamesport, the children, aged 2 to 4, stuffed old newspapers into brown grocery bags and piled them higher and higheras high as the ceiling, one enthusiastic little boy suggested.

title: Perils of a Public Poet
description: JAMES DICKEY, the Southern poet and novelist who received national celebrity when, as an early Jimmy Carter appointee, he read a commemorative poem on the televised Inaugural Gala, has now become a cultural traveler for the State Department. Last week he was hooked for Mexico City to attend the opening of the Thomas Jefferson  Benjamin Franklin Exhibit under the auspices of the American Embassy. His primary mission, the State Department's Latin American spokesman said, was to talk about American literature and to do some readings for Mexican writers and students. With the same object in mind, he is next off to West Germany in late May, and the hope is, according to the spokesman handling Europe, that he will travel on from there to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. These travels are under State's American Specialists Program; other authors making similar trips this year are Scott Momaday, the novelist; A. B. Guthrie, Western novelist and historian; and Daniel Halpern, poet.

title: Penn State Defeats Villanova in Two Distance Relays
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 23It should have been no contesta breeze. But Mark Belger's mind and body were elsewhere today, perhaps anticipating next weekend's Penn Relays in Philadelphia or his first race against Alberto Juantorena next month in Jamaica.

title: PAKISTAN SEIZES FOES OF BHUTTO IN RAIDS
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sunday, April 24The Government, cracking down hard again in an attempt to end the continuing political crisis, imposed press censorship last night and followed it up this morning with a series of predawn arrests of opposition leaders.

title: A Practical Primer On the Merits Of Peanut Culture
description: Like many northerngardeners I was always under the impression that peanuts were a tropicalor at least, semitropicalcrop and could not be grown in the New JerseyNew York area.

title: No Back Seat for Cauthen in Derby, Says Agent
description: The wonder horse of racing, Seattle Slew, and the wonder jockey of racing, Steve Cauthen, finally had faced each other on the same track yesterday at Aqueduct. But in the minds and wallets of their countrymenand in the 53d running of the Wood Memorialthere was not much that the 16yearold apprentice could do to end the winning streak of the 3yearold colt.

title: INVESTING
description: For investors seeking to cash in on the energy play, there's an intriguing alternative to stocks and bonds.

title: Peter Wyman Fiance Of Amy B. Holzworth
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wendover Peter Holzworth of Shaker Heights, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Blythe Holzworth, to Peter George Wyman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Wyman of New York and Easton, Md. The wedding is planned for June 4 at the Old Wye Church in Easton.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: Even the most vocal critics of President Carter's comprehensive proposals for a national energy policy last week were united in applauding his diagnosis of one of the country's most pressing problems so promptly in his Administration. And there was widespread admiration for his courage in demanding sacrifices throughout the country to try to meet what he termed the greatest domestic challenge that our nation will face in our lifetime

title: Judo Champion Sets Goal For Chance at '80 Olympics
description: Maureen Braziel is the threetime national grand champion in the fifth largest Amateur Athletic Union sport. If you care to venture a guess at which A.A.U. sport, you have 22 choices, ranging from swimming to horseshoe pitching. Though the 31yearold Miss Braziel is a native and resident of Brooklyn, local readers will probably be no more likely to guess correctly than readers in the Midwest. It is at judo that she excels, a sport a novice fan cannot easily appreciate and about which few people know more than a little.

title: LETTER FROM IONA COLLEGE
description: I WALKED out of my 11:30 history class and headed straight for the hill. The hill, or Walsh beach as it is often called, is right across from Spellman Hall, which is the student union building on the Iona campus. In the parking lot between Spellman Hall and the hill some students were playing Frisbee. The hill was covered with students sitting in small groups. Some were drinking beer and listening to the Marshall Tucker Band, which blared from a car stereo. Others were sitting alone studying, while others just talked and relaxed.

title: Peggy Pruett Sings Vibrant Debut Recital
description: Audiences in Carnegie Recital Hall are often so crammed with friends and relatives that cheering and applause can be peculiarly at odds with a stranger's perceptions But the enthusiasm generated by Peggy Pruett's debut recital April 14, was so clearly justified that strangers had no reason to feel out of place.

title: ART VIEW
description: Why should a great art museum in a free, democratic country go to immense trouble and expense to bring before its public a large exhibition consisting, for the most part, of mediocre (or worse than mediocre) paintings, many of which were deliberately designed to serve a malevolent political purpose in their country of origin? This is the question that haunts the exhibition Russian and Soviet Painting that has now come to the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through June 26)an exhibition that, by its very nature, is obliged to give political considerations priority over esthetic discrimination.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Cod Fishing
description: MENEMSHA, Mass.Having delivered fat, succulent oysters raked from Tisbury Great Pond to her kitchen less than a week ago, I was not prepared for my mother's sudden craving for more seafood.

title: Princeton Captures Childs Cup
description: What began as an ideal day for crewracing yesterday turned into the worst conditions in 47 years. That was the opinion of Jack Sulger, who has rowed or coached for the New York Athletic Club for that many seasons.

title: Finding Shelter in Mt. Vernon
description: THE first time Billy was arrested, he was almost 17 years old. The charge was public intoxication. That was not long after his father left home, and a couple of months before his mother went away with two of his three younger sisters.

title: Bicycle Race Next Sunday
description: The 50mile bicycle road race of the Century Road Club Association will be held next Sunday in Central Park at 7:15 A.M. All persons holding licenses in the United States Cycling Federation are eligible.

title: No O.A.U. Intervention Seen
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 23 (Agence FrancePresse)The organization of African Unity has no immediate plans to intervene in events in Zaire, its secretary general, William Eteki Mboumoua, says.

title: HighRisk Urban Insurance Is Under Attack in State
description: This article is the work of GeIvin Stevenson, an economist with Commons, an urban planning group, and Robert Magnuson, a journalist who writes on economic topics.

title: Bhutto Opponents Arrested
description: Virtually all of the top opposition leaders in Pakistan who were not already in jail were reported arrested. Page 17.

title: THEATER
description: ON Thursday, May 5, the Westchester  Rockland Regional Theater presents a preview of its third and final production of the season, Hedda Gabler, at the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck. The production opens officially on May 6, plays the 7th and 8th, and the following May 12 through 15 before moving over to the Rockland Center for the Arts in West Nyack for two performances on May 21. So, what's so special about another revival of the Ibsen classic? This one, which uses the Rolf Fjelde translation as its text, will also have Professor Fjelde, America's leading translator of Ibsenand a resident of White Plainsserving as special consultant.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: There was a time, just over 50 years ago, when it seemed as if the arts had got a grip on the great cities of the world and would never let them go. It was not the kind of grip which Balzac in his novels had on Paris, or which the Dutch viewpainters of the 17th century had on Amsterdam, or which the playwrights of the 1690's had on certain aspects of London: a steady accumulation of detail, that is to say, until we feel that we know just what it was like to be in the city in question.

title: What Are Women Doing?
description: THE had certain advantages which women of far greater gifts lacked even half a century ago. Men were no longer to her the opposite faction; she need not waste her tune railing against them... at any rate, she was making attempt. And as I watched her lengthening out for the test, I saw, but hoped that the did not see, the bishops and the deans, the doctors and the professors, the patri archs and the pedagogues all at her shouting warning and advice. You can't do this and you shan't do that! Aspiring and graceful female no velist this way! So they kept at her like the crowd at a fence on the racecourse... whether she had the staying power I was doubtful, for the clapping and the crying were fraying to her nerves. But she did her best. Give her another hundred years, I concluded, give her a room of her own and five hundred a year, let her speak her mind and leave out half that she now puts in, and she will write a better book one of these days.

title: Byrd Asserts Plan To Reform Welfare Will Be Postponed
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI)The Senate Democratic leader, Robert C. Byrd, said today he had notified President Carter that his welfare reform proposals would be sidetracked in the Senate this year so as to devote full time to energy lesgilation.

title: TV VIEW
description: Whither women? While the Equal Rights Amendment runs into formidable roadblocks at state levels, TV programming for and about women has taken several new turns, reaching a point at which reevaluation is called for. Advances have been regis tered in commercial TV, particularly on local schedules, where content is relatively lowkeyed and unthreatening, yet often surprisingly effective. One fine example is the WCBSTV project called A Woman Is . . . With Bess Myerson, which concludes this week, Monday through Friday, with five halfhours at 9:30 A.M. Public TV, however, tending to somewhat more militant, has entered a period of retrenchment. Sandra Elkins's Woman, a talk show originating in Buffalo, and WNET /13's Woman Alive! series, produced in collaboration with Ms. Magazine, have run into resistance, both financial and ideological. Neither program is likely to return after the current season, in anything approximating its present form.

title: ILLITERACY OF ADULTS CALLED U.S. DISEASE
description: HAUPPAUGE, April 23The lawyer for a 19yearold Copiague High School graduate who contends he cannot read told told a New York State Assembly committee yesterday that adult illiteracy was a national disease.

title: Miss Schultz, Artist, Is Wed To Executive
description: Elizabeth Fraser Schultz, a granddaughter of the late William L. Schultz, founder and president of Shulton Inc., toiletries and cosmeticsmanufacturer, was married yesterday eveping to Derek Edwin Vanderlinde of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fredric Daniel Vanderlinde of Pittsford, N.Y.

title: BRIDGE
description: The annual match in London between the two branches of Parliament, the Lords and the Commons, takes an unusual form. Although duplicate boards are used, the scoring is on rubber bridge lines: Unlike any competition played on this side of the Atlantic, each deal is not scoren as a separate unit. The deals are played simultaneously, and the vulnerability at one table may be quite different at the other; and part scores are carried forward, with consequent effect on the bidding. However, if one table completes a rubber the other is instructed to wind up its proceedings. Thus the two tables are always on an equal footing at the start of the rubber.

title: INTERVIEW
description: IT was in the mid1350's when Katherine F. Niles, a recently widowed mother of five, decided to return to work. Her experience as a member of the Junior League and an active volunteer for many nonprofit organizations was typical of many suburban won

title: Miss Sherrill Becomes Bride
description: Barbara Harris Sherrill, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Henry W. Sherrill of Lancaster, N.H., was married there yesterday to Silas Thayer Wild Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wild of WinstonSalem, N.C.

title: The Redcoats Are Coming
description: CANNON drawn by oxen, nearly 1,000 musketcarrying soldiers in Colonial and British uniforms, staunchly patriotic and heroic Benedict Arnold and his devoted descendants and a town divided in its loyaltiesall these will be represented in Ridgefield next weekend in a reenactment of the first major British invasion of Connecticut 200 years ago.

title: Israel Conducting Inquiry On Allegation That Eban Violated Currency Rules
description: JERUSALEM, April 23 (Reuters)Israeli authorities are conducting an inquiry to determine whether former Foreign Minister Abba Eban may have violated the nation's stringent foreign currency regulations, a Finance Ministry official said tonight.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: When the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey raised Hudson River tunnel and bridge tolls as much as 100 percent in May 1975, the agency portrayed it as a contribution to mass transit. The aim was said to be twofold: to increase revenue, so the authority could finance masstransit projects, and to encourage carpooling.

title: Dr. Frederick Porkolab Weds Dr. Margaret Ragni
description: Dr. Margaret V. Ragni, a resident in internal medicine at the Presbyterian University Hospital in Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Dr. Frederick L. Porkolab, who is completing a secondyear cardiology fellowship at the hospital. The Rev. Galen Hora, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony in the Heinz Chapel of the University of Pittsburgh.

title: GARDENING
description: THE garden centers and supermarkets are bursting with young seedlings for sale. Small flats of pansies, petunias, alyssum, snapdragons are lined up in tidy rows like so many kittens and puppies in an animal shelter waiting for someone to pick them out and take them home.

title: Rye Center Nurtures Local Experts
description: NOW I'll bet you think that means it's dirty here, Joe Semanchik said, pointing to a large spider web festooned between a bison head and the wall of his office, but to me that's beautiful. It soon becomes apparent that this brief comment epitomizes the philosophy of Mr. Semanchik, the man known to area residents as Joe at the Rye Nature Center and that institution's director.

title: 21 Shut Subway Facilities May Open
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is expected to approve tomorrow the reopening of some of the subway token booths and station entrances shut down as part of the recent budgetcutting service curtailments.

title: SELECTION
description: DURING the last months of the German occupation, Rome took on the appearance of certain Indian metropolises where only the vultures get enough to eat and there is no census of the living and the dead. A multitude of beggars and refugees, driven from their destroyed villages, camped on the steps of the churches or below the Pope's palaces; and in the great public parks starving sheep and cows grazed, having escaped the bombs and the confiscations in the countryside. Despite the declaration of open city, the Germans were encamped around the inhabited area, speeding along the consular roads in the clatter of their vehicles; and the disastrous cloud of the air raids, which constantly crossed the territory of the province, spread over the city a great tarpaulin of pestilence and earthquake. The windowpanes in the house shook day and night, the sirens wailed, squadrons clashed in the sky amid yellowish rockets, and every now and then in some outlying street, with a thunderclap, a dustcloud of ruin burst up. Certain frightened families had settled in the airraid shelters or in the labyrinthine basements of the great monuments, where there was a stagnant odor of urine and feces. In the de luxe hotels requisitioned by the Reich Commands and guarded by armed sentries, fantastic suppers were held, where the waste was obsessive, to the point of indigestion and vomiting; and in there, at the supper tables, the massacres for the next day were orchestrated. The Commander, who had himself called King of Rome, was a big compulsive eater and drinker, and alcohol was the customary stimulant and narcotic for the occupiers, both at the High Command and in the lower ranks. In secondary, remote streets of the city, you could remark some little building or villa, in middleclass style, with rows of windows recently walled up on the various floors. They were former offices, or familystyle boarding houses, now converted by the occupying police forces into torture chambers. Inside, all the wretches infected with the vice of death found employment, like their Fhrer, masters at last of living, helpless bodies for their perverse practices. From inside those buildings, day and night, there often came a deafening din of cheap dance music and songs from gramophones turned up to full volume.

title: A Poet,16, Gives Free Rein To Love for Aging Horse And Rides Home a Winner
description: His poem was only 13 lines a sad, sympathetic and loving verse for an aging horse.

title: Seattle Slew Takes Wood by 3 Lengths
description: Seattle Slew galloped to his expected frontrunning victory in yesterday's $110,300 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct, but don't concede the Kentucky Derby to him quite yet.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The day after I saw Woody Allen's new film, Annie Hall, the man with the tape recorder started haunting me, turning upon the next stool at Chock Full o'Nuts, staring dumbly at me from across the aisle on the No. 104 bus when I was trying to read about Zaire, standing in line behind me at the bank with no check or withdrawal slip in his hand, only the damned tape recorder. I made a mental note: if art is life recorded, as now seems to be the fashion, the triumph of our age is the instant replay. The time spent on the creative process has been brought to the irreducible minimum. Eradicated. The man's expression was always the same, a mixture of disbelief and reproach. Because movie buffs are like drunksat any minute they can turn meanI finally submitted to the interview, as much to put my own thoughts in order as to get rid of him. He didn't waste words making his point.

title: IndiaSoviet Pact to Continue
description: NEW DELHI April 23 (UPI)The new government of India said today, two days before a visit by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, that it would not cancel its friendship treaty with the Soviet Union. India stands by its foreign policy obligations undertaken by the government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Should advocates of the total woman be given equal time? Is it all power to the militants? (John J. O'Connor)

title: ILLEGAL ALIENS POSE A GROWING PROBLEM
description: HOUSTON, April 23Federal agents apprehended and expelled today more than 2,000 foreigners who had entered the United States illegally. It was not the least bit unusual. It happens every day. Only the numbers change. They keep getting bigger.

title: U.S. Protests Over Order
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The United States is protesting to the Ethiopian Government over today's order to close five American offices and remove their staffs, the State Department said.

title: Trials of a Jury
description: ITHE JURY? Why not? Therefore, when my number came up I went to the courthouse in Bridgeport to do my citizen's duty. Oh, the innocence of the county residents who are so called. As the days rolled by and we began to learn what was expected of us, we began to realize just what on the jury means. On the face of it, it seems simple enough, but jury service is far from simple.

title: MUSIC
description: YOU'D THINK that political rigures would get enough flack from their constituents without letting music critics have a whack at them too, but Governor Grasso is fearlessly proceeding with plans for her concert debut. It is to take place on Thursday, in the Ives Concert Hall of Western Connecticut State College, in Danbury, at the spring concert of the college orchestra.

title: Transportation Workers Laid Off
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 23 (UPI)About 600 employees of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority were furloughed yesterday because of financial problems arising from a strike against the authority's city division. William R. Eaton, general manager, said the furloughs would remain in force until a contract settlement was reached. The ??ike began March 25.

title: Which Way Stamford?
description: STAMFORD is beginning to wend its way through a maze of development options as city officials, with a remarkable amount of advice from residents, seek to set a course for the future.

title: The Symphony That Hopes to Make Milwaukee Famous
description: MILWAUKEE In 1958, Milwaukee was the only American city with a population of over 500,000 without a symphony orchestra to call its own.

title: Of Autonomy and the Golden Egg
description: HOFSTRA Law School, the Island's only law school, is now on the map. Since its beginnings seven years ago, it has sought a national reputation by attracting top teachers and students and by placing its graduates in a wide spectrum of legal careers. Its students and faculty are proud of what has been achievedthe school's clinical, legislative and litigation programs, and its commitment to removing the trauma and remoteness characteristically assuciated with legal education.

title: ART
description: THE GEOMETRIC paintings of Randall de Leeuw at the Maurice M. Pine Free Public Library in Fair Lawn do not propose the kind of geometry we might associate with the Spartan austerity of Euclidean principles.

title: Prodigals Swim Back to the Hudson
description: FOR commuters who have long since memorized the view through car or train windows along the Hudson, it is a startling sight: hundreds of feet of net floating on the current or hanging from stakes and small boats filled with silvery fish gliding to shore where fishermen are mending their nets and checking their gear.

title: N.C.A.A. Promotes Hunt
description: KANSAS CITY, April 23 (AP)William B. Hunt, a member of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's enforcement staff since 1972, has been named to head that department. He replaces Warren Brown, who has resigned effective May 15 to enter private business.

title: ASSESSMENT APPEALS INCREASE IN SUBURBS
description: A number of suburban communities are becoming seriously concerned about a growing roster of appeals against their property assessments by owners of large commercial properties.

title: Correction
description: A typographical error in Jane E Brody's article on The Drug War on Cancel (April 3) creates the impression that the emergence of chemotherapy as a maim weapon against cancel occulted within the last eight years in fact, her mother died in 1958, not 1968, and it was then that chemotherapy was the poor relation in cancel treatment. By the late 1960's, anticancer drugs had already been shown to cure several otherwise fatal cancers, including a significant percentage of leukemia cases in children.

title: High Stakes Fail To Daunt Him
description: FOR a man embroiled in a heated political conflict in which his leadership is on the line, Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau Republican chairman, acts like a man who is confident he made the right decision in opposing Ralph G. Caso's renomination as County Executive.

title: Blasting Out of the Secretarial Trap
description: If you're one of the millions of female secretaries in industry, you know that your job classification puts you completely outside the structural system in organizations. A secretarial classification does not fit into any standard level in the hierarchy, which explains why the job has no future.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: Some Economists See Only the Dark
description: WASHINGTONThe John and Mary Does, an average American household (2.94 persons and 1.46 automobiles), drive 17,558 miles per year. Their cars get about 14 miles per gallon, and each year the Does buy 1,255 gallons of gasoline from service stations. If Mr. Carter's full 50cent gasoline tax goes into effect by 1985, and if the Does continue driving their cars the same distance each year, they will pay $627.50 in extra gasoline taxes. But a new tax credit will return $735 to them. Net savings: $107.50.

title: Coast Guard, Navy Lose to Elis
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 23The Yale varsity oarsmen did well on the water today, defeating Coast Guard and Navy, but not so well at pitching their coxswain, Andy Fisher, into the Severn River after the victory.

title: FISHING
description: THE RECENT stretch of warm weather has caused fishing to flourish. Mackerel have invaded Greater Peconic Bay and by this week should be around the Island in force. Inshore, flounder fishing has picked up on the muddy flats of bays.

title: Catherine Fogarty Is Bride of James Peterson
description: In St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Noroton, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Catherine Sue Fogarty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Fogarty of Darien, Conn., became the bride of James Walter Peterson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Peterson of Houston, formerly of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Miss Kirkland Lucid In Bayadere at Met
description: Gelsey Kirkland's first appearance as Nikiya, the ballerina, in the American Ballet Theater's La Bayadre on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House found her dancing lucidly and sharply.

title: LastPlace Flag Officer Rallies to Take Illinois
description: CHICAGO, April 23 (AP)Flag Officer, under Leslie Ahrens, charged from last place to win the 20th running of the $104,925 Illinois Derby at Sportsman's Park today.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: The Supreme Court has ruled 5 to 4 that the Constitution does not bar even severe spanking of pupils by school officials and does not require even an informal prior hearing to determine whether spanking is justified.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: I'm still not prepared to give up on Anna Christie, though the day may come. Of O'Neill's earlier workand when we say earlier nowadays we mean virtually everything prior to the last three or four largely autobiographical masterworksit has for a long time seemed me the play most likely to remain playable into the foreseeable future.

title: MABEL B. ACKERMAN
description: Mabel B. Ackerman, who with her husband, Earl, were among the few husbandandwife teams in the 1950's who were both life masters in contract bridge competition, died Thursday at her home at 20 Sutton Place South. Her age was 71.

title: H.C. Barkhorn 3d Weds Karin V. Johnson, Editor
description: Karin Viola Johnson of New York, a legal editor in Port Washington, L. I., for Greenvale Editorial Services, a subsidiary of PrenticeHall Inc., was married yesterday to Henry Charles Bark horn 3d. He is an associate in the corporate finance department of GoldmanSachs & Company, investment bankers.

title: HENRI BENAMI
description: Henri BenAmi, public relations director for the National Council of Jewish Women, died Friday after a long illness. He was 48 years old. Mr. BenAmi is survived by his wife, Tamar, and three children, Jonathan, Andrew and Keren.

title: Janet Gibson Plans Wedding on Sept. 10 To Richard Fricke
description: Jane Mork Gibson of Philadelphia and Andrew E. Gibson of Short Hills, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Philbrook Gibson of Washington, to Richard Martin Fricke of Saddle Brook, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin H. Fricke of Westwood, N. J.

title: Hearings This Week By Legislative Panels
description: The following public hearings will he held in the New York metropolitan area by State legislative committees this week:

title: Young's Loss Was Eaton's Gain
description: CLEVELANDA generation ago the Chesapeake & Ohio Railway, along with the Norfolk & Western and the Virginian railwaysdubbed three Pocahontas Roads after the Pocahontas coal fields of Appalachia that they served not only hauled the coal that warmed the Northeast and Midwest every winter but also paid dividends at a time when many onceproud lines could no longer meet their bond interest.

title: Peyser's Comeback An Obstacle Course
description: PETER A. PEYSER, who found his six years in Congress the most exciting and challenging in his life, faces several obstacles if he tries to get back there as the Representative from his old district, the 23d in the Bronx and Westchester.

title: A Better Habitat
description: ONLY A YEAR AGO they were a small voice crying in the wilderness about the tickytackiness of public buildings. Today they have sprouted into a forceful group, concerned not only with what is wrong with cities, but also deeply involved in what impact concrete, brick and steel have on the total environment.

title: Islanders Succumb to a Rally by Canadiens, 43
description: MONTREAL, April 23  Having vowed that, as Dave Lewis put it, This year it's going to be a different story, the New York Islanders followed a dishearteningly familiar script tonight in losing, 43, to the Montreal Canadiens in the first game of their fourofsevengame semifinal series in the race for the Stanley Cup.

title: GARDENING
description: THE spring wildflower season is really here. More blossoms are popping open every day in New Jersey's woods and fields, along country roads and stream banks and in a number of gardens.

title: At CBS, Paley Picks His Successor
description: One of the founders of a major American industry, 75yearold William S. Paley of the Columbia Broadcasting System, finally stepped aside last week for a man more than 30 years his junior. At the company's annual meeting, Mr. Paley, who started CBS in 1928 with a string of 16 radio stations, announced that on May 11 he would ask the company's directors to elect John D. Backe, 44, (at right) the president of CBS Inc., to succeed him as chief executive officer of the $2.2 billion communications conglomerate.

title: Schappert Takes Iona Mile, but Byrne Steals Show
description: It didn't rain as expected yesterday at the 23d annual Iona Relays at Mount St. Michael Field in the Bronx, but cold, gusty winds hampered performances considerably in the club, college and high school events.

title: All Signals Go as Economy Awakens From Winter Sleep
description: More evidence that the economy was emerging from its winter hibernation appeared last week, with news that the nation's output of goods and services, after adjustment for inflation, increased by a hefty 5.2 percent in the first quarter of the year, twice the rate in the sluggish final period of 1976 and the fastest growth in a year.

title: REPORTERS ARE CRITICIZED IN ASSASSINATION INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI)Congressional Delegate Walter Fauntroy said today that some reporters covering the House assassinations committee were deliberately undermining the investigation and might be agents of the Central Intelligence Agency in disguise.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Readers who still think of science fiction as escapist pap for the semiliterate may be chastened to learn that sciencefiction scholarship has become something of an industry. Hardly a month goes by without the publication of another collection of historical, bibliographical and critical essays about s.f. aimed at an everexpanding highschool and college market. These recent books give an idea of the range of current s.f. criticism.

title: Molly Rubens Has Bridal
description: Molly Rubens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rubens 2d of Scarsdale, N. Y., was married yesterday to Douglas F. Nunnelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. A. Nunnelly Jr. of San Antonio. The Rev. Dr. Alfred Sunderwirth, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale. The bride is a Smith College alumna. Her husband, who attended Texas A & M University, is a field representative for the Texstar Construction Corporation of San Antonio.

title: Some U.S. Facilities Are Ordered Closed by the Ethiopian Regime
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 23The Government today closed down an Americat military mission and three other United States offices, ordering their personnel to leave the country within four days.

title: BRIDGE
description: THIS year will be a notable one for the bridge players of the Island for two reasons: In the fall they are due to achieve administrative independence from New York city and later this week their most important tournament celebrates ?? 10th birthday.

title: The Artist and the PoliticianNatural Antagonists?
description: Around the world today, in dictatorships of varied persuasions, art is taking a beating. If you are a painter in Moscow with a bent for the unofficial, you may have your exhibitions bulldozed. In Brazil or Uruguay, your career may be ended at the whim of a censor. In Argentina, according to Amnesty International, a worldwide human rights organization independent of all ideologies, you may be kidnapped and tortured. In Chile, you may just disappear. If you have an impulse to express yourself through plays or films and happen to live in Czechoslovakia, forget it. In Pakistan, your work had better conform to the moral standards of Islam. If, in China, you do not check the latest wall posters before playing the music of some European composer, prepare yourself for reeducation in the paddy fields. If are an Iranian poet and give offense to the Shah, you are more likely to be invited to one of his jails than to one of his festivals. One could, alas, go on. Such troubles carry to an extreme the adversary relationship between artists and politicians that is a feature of modern society, democratic as well as totalitarian.

title: Preserving But Not Petrifying The Past
description: John Adams (of the Founding Father Adamses) passed through Wethersfield, Conn., in 1774 and inscribed in his diary: We went up to the steeple of the Meeting House from whence is the most grand and beautiful prospect in the world, at least that I ever saw.

title: The StreetWise City Tree
description: Consider the lot of the poor city tree: misused by dogs; abused by cars and garbage trucks; choked by pollution; strangled at the roots by pipes; cruelly parched by concrete pavement.

title: Munson, Nettles Help Sink the Indians
description: CLEVELAND, April 23In weather that seemed more suitable for ice fishing in the Arctic, the Yankees outofthehat lineup continued clicking today, defeating the Cleveland Indians, 93, in the first game of a scheduled doubleheader.

title: Patricia Tobin Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L Tobin Jr. of Hempstead, L. I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Anne Tobin, to Howard L. Adelman, son of Mr. and, Mrs. Alfred H. Adelman of Park Forest, Ill. The wedding is planned for August.

title: How Edison Stumbled On His Phonograph
description: Serendipity, more often than necessity, is the mother of invention, and it was unplanned parenthood of this kind that resulted in the birth of the phonograph just a hundred years ago. Edison wasn't even thinking about music when he hit upon the device that was to prove the crucial turning point in modern musical historya music box more magical than any Emperor's Nightingale. What he had in mind was a gadget to speed up the transmission of telegrams over the newly laid transAtlantic cable. The phonograph happened by sheer chance.

title: SHOP TALK
description: SOME shoppers meander along Main Street or the local mall and figure the wares that are near par for the fare. Others seek out the obscure or unorthodox, certain that life's treasures are sweeter when they're offbeat or outoftheway.

title: CRIME
description: Meyer writes from experience. He is a reporter for The Washington Post, and his novel's hero is a reporter in Washington who investigates the murder of a prominent journalist (a Jack Anderson type). The murdered man had been working on something bigso big that he had not confided in anybody. He had files, which the police and Government agencies would dearly love to get their hands on.

title: National Merit Scholarship Lists In New York, Connecticut, Jersey
description: One thousand high school seniors from the country have been named winners of $1,000 scholarships by the National Merit Scholarship Corporation.

title: FROM JOY TO DEPRESSION
description: Later, when she was well again, Judith could point to nothing special in her life, no marvelous happening that might have triggered the bizarre euphoria. The only event she could connect it to was having received that letter from a friend in California, Frank, Judith, a young film historian, had gotten to know Frank the year before when they were both teaching at the state university. They had become collaborators on a screenplay, to be completed the following summer. There never had been, as Judith recounted, anything remotely romantic about their relationship: I'd never even found him particularly attractive, she shrugged. But now Frank's letter seemed to be invested with erotic double meanings, with intensely sentimental innuendoes. She found herself fantasizing about him. She became, at the same time, increasingly preoccupied by the importance of the screen drama they were writing together. Still, Judith has never believed that it was his letter alone that caused her manic attack: I don't think I'd ever have fastened on him or on the screenplay, she told me, if I hadn't already been getting crazy at the time Frank's letter arrived.

title: Diane M. Driggs Is Engaged to Cameron Adair
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dixon Watson Driggs of Atlanta have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Marie Driggs, to Cameron Adair, son of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus D. Adair Jr., also of Atlanta.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: THERE used to be a sign at the entrance to the enclave identifying it as the Nature Preserve, Village of Lawrence. The sign is gone; the preserve remains, untended. Fifteen minutes from Kennedy Airport. 20 miles from New York City and lightyears away from the technology of either place, this brambled, wooded marshland retreat is in Old Lawrence, aristocrat of the Island's Five Towns.

title: So You Want to Be a Supervisor?
description: IF, for some masochistic reason, you are that one person out of 10,000 who aspires to the job of town supervisor, you must be prepared to take on one of the world's most frustrating jobs. And even if you wouldn't take the job, you ought at least to know what your town supervisor is up against. After all, these 15 men and I woman in Westchester County will spend more than $60 million of your tax money this year.

title: Liberated Apartment Complex Offers Nudity, Frolicking
description: AUSTIN, TexBarely three months ago, the Manor Villa Apartments here were on the verge of being torn down. Fewer than half the 78 units in the dingy complex were occupied, and some of those were being used only as hideouts by local holdup men.

title: Everyday Misery in East Germany
description: THE author of this little collection of quietvoiced sketches and anecdotes about the gray oppressiveness, the deadfaced brutality of life under the East German Communist regime, with its policemen and its police dogs, is an East German poet in his 40's. The son of a miner (the book jacket tells us), Reiner Kunze taught at the University of Leipzig; quit academic are because or the political atmosphere; became a locksmith and then a freelance writer. His verse, which I have only had the briefest look at, is lyrical and tender in the still not expired tradition of German folk poetry. The photograph on the jacket shows a fine face: grave, masculine, without vanity. His publishing this book last year in West Germany took some courage. He has now been expelled from East Germany.

title: ZambiaTanzania Railway Is Monument to Chinese Builders' Prestige
description: KAPIRI MPOSHI, Zambia (AP)The Great Uhuru Railway, China's showcase aid project in Africa, begins incongruously at the end of a red dirt road in this bush town at the heart of Zambia's copper belt, 100 miles from the capital, Lusaka.

title: At Yonkers Horse Sale, Buyers Hunt for Winners
description: YONKERS, April 23I expected to buy only one yearling, said John F. Guadoyer today at the Old Glory Horse Sale at Yonkers Raceway. But I got her at such a steal, I bought two.

title: Electric Fences Shield Vegetables From Animals
description: Wild rabbits, skunks and woodchucks which were once just an occasional nuisance to the home gardeners have now, instead, become real problems. Suburbia is a hospitable environment.

title: Noise: Physical Harm Is Only Part of It
description: A rhesus monkey named Mars recently spent 12 hours a day for 30 days being buffeted by the sounds any passerby might hear at noon outside Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami.

title: $500,000 Gift Aids Community Health
description: A PRIVATE fundraising drive led by sonic of the state's most prominent citizens and corporations in support of the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey has produced a major new financial commitment of $500,000 toward community programs.

title: The Red Orchestra Leader
description: THIS book opens a door. Beyond the door lies that halfforgotten world of violence and cruelty, treason and intrigue, heroism and sacrifice, espionage and counterespionage that flourished from 1935 to 1945.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10 A.M. (Channel 2) Here and Now: New York Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Priscilla Sue is the youngest daughter of an Arkansas hill preacher, and as she sees it, she is an afterthought. Her sisters and brothers are grown with families of their own. Her mother died after giving birth to her, and she's stuck with the unending tasks of cookin', scrubbin', hoggin', cannin', and carin' for her father, who is so involved with prayin' and helpin' folks he takes her for granted.

title: Growing Up American
description: IN the complex and everchanging movement of history there is something undeniably basic, even universal, about the human life cycle. We all start small, grow up and grow old, just as the countless generations of our forebears have done. And yet such experiences are universal only in a biological sense; their context, their inner shape, and their personal significance differ markedly from one time and place to another. A small army of scholars has fastened on these points of difference, making the history of the life cycle into a flourishing research enterprise. The trend was begun some 20 years ago with the appearance of an extraordinary book by the French historian Philippe Aries, published in this country somewhat later under the title Centuries of Childhood. Aries's work quickly raised up a host of followers on both sides of the Atlantic, and histories of childhood have since multiplied rapidly.

title: One Man's Universe
description: LOUIS J. HALLE is not at all a flamboyant writer, and it is unobtrusively that he remarks in his preface to this book: From the beginning of my conscious life I have done my best to command at least a distant view of all basic knowledge. How many other men in the Englishspeaking world could make that claim? Or in any other part of the world, as far as that goes?

title: Finding Nova Scotia's Heartbeat
description: Nova Scotians like to tell you that their land is shaped like a lobster. It's difficult to see that if you're not a marine biologist with a creative imagination, but the Canadian province is, essentially, a long, narrow strip of land (no spot is more than 35 miles from the sea) with maybe a claw here, a claw there, and if you look carefully at all the inlets and tiny peninsulas, several hundred little legs. Dotted with lakes and crisscrossed with rivers, it offers attractions ranging from the rugged, desolate fishermen's coastline of the southwest to the spectacular mountainous scenery of Cape Breton in the northeast. In between are the lush hilly orchards and farmland of the Annapolis Valley. Fall, when the leaves are turning and the bulk of the tourists have left, is an ideal time for a visit. So is the spring, when the fruit bloom.

title: Metros Blank Sting
description: CHICAGO, April 23 (AP)Ivara scored the gamewinning goal on a corner kick from Dinko Zutelija today as the Toronto Metros beat the Chicago Sting, 10, in a North American Soccer League game. The game was the home opener for the Sting, now scoreless in two games this season.

title: Ghost of Bad Henry Pervades Mr. Aaron
description: It is April, a month to be young, and he is being introduced to the class of continuingeducation students as Mr. Aaron. There are buds on the trees and people in shirtsleeves walking through the park across the street, and he is telling the class about his son, the college football player. There is a game just ending at Yankee Stadium, the smell of leather and sweat is in the air, and he is wearing a pale blue suit, smoking cigarettes, one after another.

title: Nyack's Feast Of Antiques
description: MODERN TECHNOLOGY has paved fine new highways to the Hudson River village of Nyack, where peaked, turreted and joyously gingerbreaded Victorian houses celebrate the past.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH SOME brands of exterior paint are advertised as being all purpose finishes that can be used on almost any type of surface around the outside of the house, most experts still agree that this is seldom, if ever, really true. That is why most large manufacturers still make a variety of different kinds of exterior paint for home use. The homeowner who wants to insure longlasting results and provide maximum protection for the outside of his house should familiarize himself with the various types that are available and with the principal characteristics of each.

title: Marcia King Is Married
description: Marcia King, daughter of Mr. and Mrs, D. E. King of Cazenovia, N. Y., was married yesterday evening to John B. Battin Sr. in St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Cazenovia. The Rev. Charles Mosby performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of the late Pauline Neiman Battin and the late Howard H. Battin of White Plains.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodayUnited States Auto Club Trentonian 200 at Trenton (N.J.) International Speedway. Trials: 11:30 A.M.; 100kilometer Super Vee race: 12:30 P.M. 200mile race: 3:05 P.M.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
description: I would like to have you divest me of the alleged power that was given to me in the article on Power in Fairfield: Face in a Crowd on Sunday, March 20th.

title: Mary E. York Is Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Graham of Princeton, N. J., of the engagement of Mrs. Graham's daughter, Mary Elizabeth York, to William Philler Wood Jr., son of Mr. Wood of Haverford, Pa., and the Late Mia Atherton Wood. The wedding is planned for June 10.

title: MAN SAID TO ADMIT SPYING FOR SOVIET
Metropolitan Briefs
description: An 18yearold Queens woman was raped and strangled inside a vacant house in the Hollis section of Queens. The police identified the woman as Jacqueline Carmichael of 135.09 Foch Boulevard in neighboring South Ozone Park. According to police, two men were seen running from the vacant house, at 19038 99 Avenue. Details of the murder were not disclosed.

title: Soul Music Still Lives in a World of Its Own
description: There was a time, just a few years ago, when we could live under the illusion that American popular music was on the way to obliterating racial boundaries. In the 1960's there was a whole host of artists, black and white, who appealed both in record sales and concert appearances to audiences of both races. Since black music was so demonstrably at the root of popular white music, it was easy to extrapolate and say that one day soon stylistic walls would crumble altogether and that we would simply have one American popular music.

title: Mary Jo Giovine Is Bride of Bruce McKleroy
description: Mary Jo Giovine and Bruce Gardiner McKleroy, both of San Francisco, were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Manhattanville College in Purchase, N. Y. The Rev. Paul Wirkus performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Cristina Quezada, Mezzo, Compelling but Studied
description: Christina Quezada, mezzosoprano, brought this season's series of concerts by Mexican artists in Carnegie Recital Hall to a close last Monday night. With Joseph Bloom at the piano, she sang lieder by Schubert and Brahms, Schumann's Frauenliebe and Leben cycle, Ravel's Five Popular Greek Songs, three Russian works and the Seven Spanish Folk Songs of Falla.

title: GARDENING
description: THE GARDEN centers and supermarkets are bursting with young seedlings for sale. Small flats of pansies, petunias, alyssum and snapdragons are lined up in tidy rows like so many kittens and puppies in an animal shelter waiting for someone to pick them out and take them home.

title: Events Today
description: HEROES OF AFRICA, BLACK AMERICA AND AMERICAN INDIANS: Workshop on African culture; 11:15 A.M. to 1:15 P.M.; American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street.

title: Soviet Union Joins Team Tennis This Week
description: AmericanSoviet detente reaches a new plateau this week when World Team Tennis opens its fourth season with a Russian squad as a fullfledged member of the 10team league.

title: The English Mandarin Con Man
description: WHAT does anybody here know of Backhouse? one could say, paraphrasing Thomas Babington Macaulay's famous House of Commons speech about China: Everything is covered by a veil. Now Hugh TrevorRoper has told us everything we need to know, and the result, while it is not a pretty sight, is a book that is a classic of its kind, somewhere between The Secret Life of Walter Mitty and The Quest for Corvo, with an epilogue straight out of Frank Harris's My Life and Loves. It begins as conventional biography, becomes international intrigue, mystery, and, as the contradictions thicken, proceeds on several levels of detection, until the man is revealed. It is as if Professor TrevorRoper were pursuingnot harrying, but stalkingBackhouse through an enormous mansion, room by room, gathering clues. At the end, face to face with his quarry in the last room, he does not shake the incriminating evidence at him, but in the friendliest fashion removes the veil from the aged humbug.

title: Lloyd Free's WildLooking Shots Are Natural for 76er Playoff Star
description: BOSTON, April 23At Howard Park, the Recreation Center and Public Schools 32 and 66, all in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, where the 360degree spin dunk shot is often way of life, Lloyd Free is allWorld. As he walks through the ghetto streets where he grew up bouncing a basketball, other kids, similarly bouncing basketballs, greet their hero with. What's happening, World?

title: Architects Choice
description: Architects, especially famous and successful ones, are popularly supposed to design for themselves in the same style that they design for the public People who build glass houses ought to live in themor so the ?? goes

title: Sports in the 21st Century: Science and Rollerball
description: The Media Arts Department of the School of Visual Arts in Manhattan asked many sports personalities: What changes do you see happening in sports by the 21st century? Their answers and the visual interpretations of them by students, including those shown here, will be displayed until May 12 at the Master Eagle Gallery, 40 West 25th Street, Manhattan. Admission is free.

title: Camping Where to Go, What to Expect
description: WITH early spring flowers already beginning to wilt and daffodils waving their yellow crowns above the Found, officials at state parks and forests arc preparing for the annual onslaught of summer visitors and campers.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayThe Borzoi Club of Greater New York licensed lure coarse, Duke Island Park, Somerville, N.J.; 9 A.M.

title: Iowan Is Successor To Gardner at Helm Of Common Cause
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)A civic activist from Muscatine, Iowa, was unanimously elected today as the new leader of Common Cause, the citizens movement that John W. Gardner founded and led for seven years.

title: Deaths
description: AFROIMSKYAaron, Bay Ridge Jewish Center mourns the loss of ?? member of long standing, and offers sincere sympathy to Pauline and the family.

title: Cucumbers Take Up Little Space If They Are Trained to Climb
description: The expression cool as a cucumber is firmly grounded in fact. Recent tests have shown that the inside of a fieldgrown cucumber registers about 20 de grees cooler than the outside air on a hot day. Perhaps that's why cucumbers have been prized for crisp refreshing summer salads from earliest times. Cucumbers were cultivated in Asia over 3000 years ago and are mentioned twice in the Bible. The Greeks and Romans, among other peoples, valued them highly, so much so that the Roman Emperor Tiberius ordered cucumbers served to him every day of the yearhis gardeners had to force them indoors to satisfy his craving. Columbus introduced cucumbers to the New World and they have been grown here ever since.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: In a celebrated remark about making judgments, Samuel Johnson cautioned against expecting too much of a dog's walking on its hind legs. It is not done well, and you are surprised to find it done at all, he said. I was reminded of this observation when I saw the formalistic photographs of Mark Feldstein, currently at Castelli Graphics (4 East 77 Street, through April 30) and in a new book, Sighting (Chelsea House. $15).

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Five hundred years ago, William Caxton, mercer, translator and, much later, printer, sold his press in Bruges, where he had produced the first English book by an English printer, and

title: The World
description: Misjudgment of the national mood recently cost Indira Gandhi the premiership of India; in neighboring Pakistan a similar misjudgment threatens the hold on office of Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto.

title: CAMERA VIEW

title: 'Jacob the Liar,' a Film About the Polish Ghetto
description: World War II film records of the attenuated terrors of Polish ghetto life are all too familiar now, but "Jacob the Liar" tempers the terrible truth in serio-comic style. Of course, laughter is not precisely what Frank Beyer, the director, and Jurek Becker, who adapted his own novel to the screen, had in mind, but they make Jacob's falsehoods the courageous and often lightly funny stuff that bound a doomed people together momentarily in hope.As an East German production and one of the five candidates for this year's foreign-language Academy Award, "Jacob the Liar," which opened at the Plaza yesterday, is surprisingly devoid of anything resembling Communist propaganda. And, in focusing on Jewish ghetto inmates, the director and his scenarist pointedly stress the togetherness of these inmates as against the callousness of survival in, say, the concentration camp of Lina Wertmuller's "Seven Beauties."Their Jacob Heym, once a cafe owner, is now simply one of the town's downtrodden, unkempt laborers under Nazi occupation forces who, by chance, overhears a radio communiqu in local Gestapo headquarters about Russian victories in the vicinity. And our woebegone hero then passes the happy news to other Jews, stating with underplayed pride that he heard it on his own clandestine radio. Naturally, his neighbors, clinging to this newly found promise of deliverance, demand more news daily and our increasingly reluctant Jacob is forced to invent it.As a series of vignettes, "Jacob the Liar" illustrates recollections of a happier past and the glimmer of cheer as well as the fear of reprisals felt by the ghetto's inmates. Henry Hubchan and Blanche Kommerell, a pretty brunette, grasp desperately for moments of love in a crowded, decrepit room. Dezso Garas and Suzana Gordon, as Miss Kommerell's actor-parents, cower in anticipation of a concentration camp destiny, and, Envin Geschonneck, gives a sensitive performance as a former barber and close friend of Jacob, who resorts to the grimmest solution when hope is lost.Vlastimil Brodsky, a noted Czech actor, is forceful, funny and poignant as the ever helpful, if married, Jacob, whose sad, sagging face mirrors the tragedy of the ghetto's plight. He is nobly abetted by Manuela Simon, an endearing natural, pretty little moppet, playing his inquisitive niece, whom he entertains in one charming scene by imitating Winston Churchill's sonorous voice as it seemingly emerges from his alleged radio.Although English subtitles make the action clear, a viewer may be disturbed by some abrupt transitions and by Poles speaking German. But if there is little doubt as to the drama's inevitable, tragic denouement, "Jacob the Liar" is, in effect, a heartwarming saga and one that illustrates Mark Twain's observation that "courage is resistance to fear, mastery of fear, and not the absence of fear."

title: The Miracle of the Bud
description: Spring is a time of miraculous happenings. The earth itself teems with new roots groping downward into the rich soil to feed and sustain new plants. Young shoots on bush and tree reach for light and sun, to foster growth and fruition. But all around us, in plain sight, is perhaps the greatest miracle of all, the buds themselves. Out of the buds, so countless and so commonplace, come this world's green leaves, its wealth of bloom, its surging growth of twig and branch and stem.

description: ROME, April 24For the first time the net exodus of Italian migrants has come to a halt. Statistics just published for 1975 show that the number of Italians returning to Italy outnumbered those leaving by some 30,000.

title: New York's Precarious Balance
description: After truly convulsive passage, New York City experiencing a moment of fiscal calm. We are merely the eye of the hurricane; there is plenty of heavy weather ahead. But the improbable has occurred: the Mayor has submitted a budget for the year beginning July 1 and is in balance$14 billion in, $14 billion out.

title: Czechoslovak Police Confiscate The Notes of a Canadian Journalist
description: PRAGUE, April 24 (Reuters)The police today confiscated notes belonging to a Canadian journalist as he was about to leave Czechoslovakia after a weeklong visit.

title: Official's Picture Published
description: SAN SALVADOR, April 24, (Reuters)A photograph showing El Salvador's Foreign Minister in captivity was published here today in an apparent attempt by his guerrilla kidnappers to show that he was alive and well. He has been held by a leftist group since last Tuesday.

title: Soviet Poet on First U.S. Visit Fulfills a Passion for America
description: Bella Akhmadulina has just arrived in this country on her first visit, with the prosaic baggage of a Soviet tourist and the poetic aura that is hers alone.

title: Gasoline Tax Seen as Help In Presenting Rural Area
description: PORT REPUBLIC, Md.,April 24Some residents of Calvert County, a rural area in southern Maryland, are shrugging off the threat of more expensive gasoline because costlier fuel may brake a population surge that menaces their cherished rustic way of life.

title: Lieut. Gen.Charles Herron, 100; Commanded Army Units in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU,April 24 (AP)Army Lieut. Gen. Charles D. Herron, who graduated from West Point in 1899 and saw his first combat that year at San Blas in the Philippine insurrection, died here yesterday at the age of 100.

title: Tornado Tops Cosmos by 21 In a Shootout
description: EAST RUTHERFORD. N.J.,April 24After a flu virus had immobilized several players two weeks ago, the Cosmos seem to be afflicted by one of soccer's contagious diseasesthat of playing well and not scoring goals.

title: Alexander Semmler,76, Composer Of Music for TV, Radio and Films
description: Alexander Semmler, composer, piano soloist and conductor for the Columbia Broadcasting System (now CBS Inc..) from the early 1930's until 1951,died yesterday of heart failure in the Benedictine Hospital in Kingston, N.Y. He was 76 years old and lived in Woodstock, N.Y

title: In Havana,Some Flattery for Americans, and Business Talk
description: HAVANA, April 22If a sparrow falls, Fidel knows. A visiting delegation of Minnesota businessmen put on a lunch for Cuban officials here. Premier Castro wasn't at the lunch, but he met with the Americans a few hours later in his office. I heard about that turkey at your lunch today, he said, referring to the big, lean bird the businessmen brought from their state. He had heard reports about the cheeses and the strawberry pie, too. I was even told there was very good beer, he said.

title: Leonard Silk
description: President Carter may have committed overkill upon the American public in seeking to sell his national energy plan last week, as he conceded in one of his news conferences. But he certainly succeeded in dramatizing the end of the era of cheap energy for Americansand the approach of the oilless, or at least the lessoil, economy. Driving this realization into the consciousness of the American people was doubtless the President's main accomplishment. It remains to be seen, however, whether he has the political support to get his program through Congress. On one side, Mr. Carter is likely to be hit for proposing to rely too much on higher prices and taxes to curb the demand for oil and gas. On the other side, he will face attack for not putting enough emphasis on expanding the supply of oil and gas, because of his desire to deny producers higher profits.

title: James Q Again Captures Junior Jumper Crown
description: JERICHO, Li., April 24James Q won his second championship in two weeks today when he captured the junior jumper title at the Highland Horse Show.

title: Bruins Beat Flyers in Overtime, 43
description: PHILADELPHIA,April 24That intense desperation the Flyers use like a hammer to break through their opponent's shell almost worked again tonight.

title: Arthur Godfrey and Others Enter Hall of Fame of Air
description: FREEHOLD, April 24It was almost the same as a thousand other shows in which the frecklefaced redhead played up to his enormous radio audience. There were the same folksy jokes, the same raspvoiced sentimentality and the same lowkey banter about people, places and things.

title: Cubans Admit Their Economy Is in Serious Trouble
description: HAVANA, April 22Cuban officials, in five days of frank talk with Minnesota businessmen, made it clear this week that their Communist nation is in serious economic trouble.

title: DR. WILLIAM W. HAGGARD
description: SEATTLE,April(AP)  Dr. William W. Haggard, former president of Western Washington State College for 20 years, died here yesterday. He was 84 years old, Dr. Haggard in 1939 became president of Bellingham Normal, later named Western Washington State College. He served as president of the National High School Principals Association and the American Association of Junior Colleges.

title: 2 Men, Both Shot in the Head, Found Dead in Bronx Apartment
description: Two men were found shot to death in a Bronx apartment last night, according to the police, who said both men had been shot in the head. A quantity of narcotics paraphernalia was also found.

title: Deaths
description: ALVERSONCatherine M., on April 23, 1977, beloved mother of John and Richard. Reposing Donovan & O'Leary Funeral Home, 322 W. 14th St. Funeral service Tuesday, 10 A.M. Family will receive friends Monday, 1 to 10 P.M.

title: Mr. Nixon's Day in Court
description: WASHINGTON  Before pardoning his predecessor, in September 1974, President Ford approved an agreement with Mr. Nixon making him custodian of all the papers and tapes accumulated during his years in the White House. The vast materials were to be kept in a building near San Clemente.

description: City College and the Board of Education are planning a new experimental high school that would open next fall at the site of the High School of Music and Art, at Convent Avenue and 135th Street.

title: Sleepwear Makers Seek Relief in Recall
description: WASHINGTON, April 24(UPI) Eleven makers of children's sleepwear contend that they may go out of business or lay off thousands of workers if they are forced to buy back $200 million worth of sleepwear treated with a fireretardant chemical, Tris, that has been banned by the Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: Naber Sets 2 Records For U.S. in Japan Swim
description: TOKYO, April 24 (APJohn Naber of the University of Southern California established his second American shortcourse record today in the twoday United StatesJapan swimming meet.

description: OAKLAND, Calif.,April 24 (AP)Abdul Jalil, Brian Taylor's agent, said today that the Kansas City Kings guard wanted to be traded, preferably to the Golden State Warriors.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: There were several errors in the energy fact sheet released by the White House and published in The New York Times Thursday. A corrective artide appears on Page 61.

title: Vietnamese Leader Due in Paris
description: PARIS, April 24 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Pham Van Dong of Vietnam will arrive here tomorrow on his first visit to the West since the end of the Vietnam war. Full honors have been ordered for the official visit, which will last four days.

title: State Spent $461 Above U.S. Average on Each Pupil
description: Before the courtordered change in the method of financing public education in New Jersey led to the new income tax, the state spent $461 a year above the national average on each pupil, according to a survey just released by the New Jersey School Boards Association.

title: Carter's Style Making Aides Apprehensive
description: WASHINGTON, April 24Again and again during his marathon pursuit of the White House last year, Jimmy Carter heard interviewers ask the same question in a hundred different ways.

title: SPANIARDS AWAITING WORD FROM SUAREZ
description: MADRID, April 24Prime Minister Adolfo Surez today left for a visit to Mexico and the United States, where he will meet President Carter. But politically minded Spaniards are less interested in his visit than in the decision he is expected to announce after he returns next Saturdaywhether he will run in what should be Spain's first free election since 1936.

title: Carter Grain Reserve Plan Drawing Bitter Opposition
description: An Administration proposal to create a national grain reserve against possible future shortages is stirring fierce intramural contention in the commodity trade.

description: The Fifth Avenue Association yesterday announced the election of Geraldine Stutz, the president of Henri Bendel, to its board of directors, the first woman to join the board in the association's 70year history.

title: Soviet Bloc Shipping Reddens the Danube
description: BUDAPEST, April 21Experts from the eight countries that are washed by the Danube River are gathered here to discuss shipping on the mighty waterway, and the prospect clearly is an even stronger Sovietbloc role.

description: He is a successful Suffolk County lawyer who went into the Deep South to struggle for the civil rights of blacks before it became fashionable to do so. He doesn't like pat answers. His mind is alive to ambiguities and difficult choices.

title: Marshall, Braves Pitcher, Disqualified After Incident
description: ATLANTA, April 24 (AP)Mike Marshall, the relief pitcher, who bolted the Atlanta Braves for the second time this season last night, was placed on the disqualified list by the National League club today and every effort will be made to trade him, said the club president, Ted Turner.

title: Neighborhoods: Enemy Of Howard Beach Is SST
description: The residents of the Howard Beach section of Queens have taken on a lot of opponents in recent years.

title: Barazzutti Takes Final
description: CHARLOTTE, (UPI)Corrado Barazzutti struggled through the first set but took control in the second and easily defeated Eddie Dibbs, 76, 60, today in the final of a World Championship Tennis event. The 24yearold Italian gained his first victory in two years on W.C.T. tour.

title: Report Blames Surgeons in Many Preventable Deaths
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)A study submitted to a House investigations subcommittee says that 78 percent of preventable complications or deaths that resulted from medical operations in seven states had involved the surgeon.

title: A Soggy Day Gives Mets Time at Other Diversions
description: The Mets spent a soggy, unproductive day at Shea Stadium yesterday as their doubleheader with the Pittsburgh Pirates was rained out just before it was scheduled to start.

title: Yanks Rout Indians, 101, 71; Run Victory Streak to Five
SPANKING RULE FOUND AN AID TO DISCIPLINE
description: The United States Supreme Court's ruling last week that a school paddling incident in Miami did not violate the Constitution's ban on cruel and unusual punishments is being welcomed as strengthening the position of those calling for more law and order in the classroom.

title: Eban Meets With Israeli Currency Aide, Says That Funds in U.S. Bank Are From Literary Activities
description: JERUSALEM, April 24Former Foreign Minister Abba Eban met today with Israel's Controller of Foreign Exchange to discuss a Government inquiry into the propriety of Mr. Eban's maintenance of two bank accounts in New York City.

title: Books of The Times
description: There are several unnecessary things in this fine first noveL The most unnecessary  wanton, in fact  is the death of a child, as if to prove a thesis, as if we might be too thick to grasp the point, or had nodded off. There is too much talk Anya, one half of John Casey's romance, would talk all the time, but Mac, the other half, would not; cleverness illsuits him. And I'm not sure Tassle, Anya', friend, and Henniker, Anya's enemy, should have been dragged back into the book for climactic scene: It is too tidy, according to a stencil at some school for writers.

title: Music: Melding
description: CHICAGO, April 24 (UPI)John Kenneth Galbraith, the Harvard economist, said today that he generally agreed with President Carter's proposed energy program, and he predicted that Americans would not feel its pinch so much as they had been led to believe. Mr. Galbraith, who described the overall program as quite sensible, said that the President's standby gasoline tax would not effectively reduce demand and that there should be more Government emphasis on redeveloping rail freight service.

title: Two Arrests Reported in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, April 24 (AP)The police have detained two more members of a ninemember group in the Ukraine that was formed to monitor Soviet observance of the 1975 Helsinki agreements on human rights, dissident sources reported today. Two other members of the Ukrainian group were arrested in February.

title: HEROIN TRAFFICKING AND BRIBERY FOUND AT JAIL IN BROOKLYN
description: Using undercover agentsone of whom posed as a rogue prison guard and another as a prisonerthe Brooklyn District Attorney's office has uncovered evidence of widespread bribery and narcotics trafticking by guards and civilian employees at the Brooklyn House of Detention.

title: High School Graduation Standards To Be Stiffened by New York City
description: New York City education authorities are planning new and stiffer standards for the attainment of a high school diploma, including a greater emphasis on the mastery of the basic skills of reading, writing and arithmetic.

title: 273 Gives Simons First Golf Victory
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 24 (AP)Unheralded Jim Simons shot a pair of 67's and bead off an even more obscure member of the pro golf tour. Stan Lee, to win the $175.000 New Orleans open tournament today.
