description: WASHINGTON, April 24(AP)King Hussein of Jordan arrived here today for three days of talks with President Carter and his aides.

description: Mayor Beame visited the home area of his newest rival yesterday and observed mildly that a lot of mayoral candidates have been coming out of the woodwork.

title: Italy Is Cracking Down on Violence By Students After Another Killing
description: ROME, April 24A new outbreak of student violence and the killing of a policeman have led to a ban on all demonstrations in Rome, the closing of Rome University and some tough talk from Italy's Minister of the Interior.

title: CITIBANK IS CRITICAL OF NEW YORK TAXES
description: Citibank, the largest bank in New York, warned today that New York State and New York City may drive out the financial community, which it called the only growth industry left in the area, by a policy of excessive taxation.

title: American School in London Is Sued
description: LONDON, April 24Parents of 300 of the nearly 1,600 students at the American School in northwest London have joined together to sue the school's Board of Trustees over its demand that they pay additional fees.

title: California Asks Court to Decide Where Boundary With Nevada Is
description: LOS ANGELES, April 24California has asked the United States Supreme Court to end a century of curious uncertainty, shared with the State of Nevada. over just where the boundary between them is.

title: Brazil's Nuclear Drive
description: BRASILIA  A stone's throw from the spectacular building that houses the Congress in this futuristic capital, one of the former generals who run the Brazilian Government leaned back in his chair in his small and unpretentious office, and smilingly observed: Of course we don't have democracy; we never did. But we have a regime that is moving toward democracy, one step at a time. Less than a week later, President Geisel had suspended the Congressin effect for insubordinationand its democratically elected members were sent packing while the President put through major constitutional changes designed to assure success for the Government party in next year's elections.

description: WALNUT, Calif., April 24 (UPI)Jeff Bennett won the last three events and scored 7,385 points, capturing the decathlon competition at the Mount San Antonio Relays today.

description: DETROIT, April 24The National Organization for Women is 10 years old and is trying to move on to the next stage of its development.

description: Do you like him? Elliott Burch was asked a moment after Seattle Slew romped home in the Wood Memorial.

title: The Brooklyn Junior League Turns Out in Style on the IND
description: A subway station may not be the ideal setting for a dinner dance, but that of course, is precisely why the Junior League of Brooklyn chase one for its Underground Society Bash, Saturday night.

title: FED MAY YET MOVE TO TIGHTER MONEY BEFORE REFINANCING
description: The Government bond market breathed a big sigh of relief on Friday after the Federal Reserve injected some temporary reserves into the banking system and nudged shortterm interest rates down slightly. Nevertheless, some experienced money market economists asserted that the central bank might yet move to tighten monetary policy early this week before the Treasury announces on Wednesday how it plans to refinance $7.9 billion of notes that mature May 15.

title: Poland Ousts West Germany
description: WARSAW, April 24 (UPI)Poland eliminated West Germany, 31, today in a Davis Cup European Zone series and advanced to the fourth round.

title: Zarate Knocks Out Zamora
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 24 (AP) Carlos Zarate, the World Boxing Council champion, knocked out Alfonso Zamora, the World Boxing Association champion, in the fourth round of a nontitle bantamweight battle last night. Zamora went down in the third and twice in the fourth before his father, working the corner, threw in the towel at 1:11 of the round. It was Zamora's first defeat as a pro after 28 victoriesall by knockouts. Zarate won his 47th bout as a pro.

title: McNamara to Get a Third Term As President of the World Bank
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)  Directors of the World Bank today reappointed former United States Defense Secretary Robert McNamara to a third fiveyear term as the bank's president beginning April 1, 1978. The action had been expected.

title: Jessye Norman's Song Program Bares Fine Voice and Technique
description: There can't be too many recitalists who would attempt the kind of program Jessye Norman offered at Avery Fisher Hall yesterday afternoon. Virtually everything she sang was voice orientedthat is, the sort of material that requires, above all, a healthy, welltrained instrument, and in which a singer can never disguise technical limitations behind a smoke screen of vocal subterfuge or interpretive tricks.

title: Birgit Keil Proves Unruffled Swan Princess
description: It was another Swan Lake day at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday, but not just another Swan Lake day. For American Ballet Theater, concluding the first of its eightweek stint at the Met, offered us the New York debut of Charles Ward as Prince Siegfried in the afternoon, and Birgit Keil, making her first appearance with the company as Odette/Odile, in the evening.

title: Justice White Gets Preview At Yale of a Key Racial Case
description: NEW HAVEN, April 24It was only an academic exercise, but the issue before the moot court at Yale Law School today was a real one: Can state universities set up special admissions programs to give preference to minority members?

title: Bhutto's Severity Takes Pakistan Toward a Decisive Confrontation
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 24With the imposition of press censorship and limited martial law and the roundup of almost all the major opposition leaders who were not already in jail, Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto has moved Pakistan's sixweekold political crisis into a new phase in the last few days.

title: Laos's Many Health Problems Include Increase in Malaria
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 21  Eightyearold Lun, the son of a poor rice farmer in Phone Hong, a village about 36 miles north of here, became sick last week and stayed home from school.

title: Moscow Taxis Aren't Hard to Get
description: MOSCOW, April 23Taxi fares doubled in Moscow on April 1, but the cabbles aren't happy. Their pay remains the same: they get nothing from the rate rise except hours to sit dozing or reading behind the wheels of their pale green Volgas lined idly at taxi stands, waiting vainly for passerers.

title: Commission Head Recommends Laws Against Privacy Invasions
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)Congress should protect citizens against invasions of their privacy by employers, insurance companies and the Federal Government, the head of the Privacy Protection Study Commission said today.

title: Miss Durr, McMillan Win Final
description: WOODLANDS, Tex., April 24 (UPI) Francoise Durr and Frew McMillan, representing the San Francisco Golden Gaters, outlasted the Soviet team of Alex Metreveli and Olga Morozova, 46, 63, 64, 46, 75, today to win the World Team Tennis mixed doubles tournament.

title: U.S. DIPLOMATIC OFFICIAL THOUGHT TO FLY TO CUBA
description: WASHINGTON, April 24Terence A. Todman, Assistant Secretary of State for InterAmerican Affairs, apparently flew to Havana today from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to resume CubanAmerican negotiations on fishing and maritime rights.

description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 24 (Reuters)A defiant Pakistani opposition reacted to the arrest of more of its leaders today with a call for a mass march on the home of Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto to demand that he resign.

description: The machine tool Industry is off to a strong start in the first quarter, according to figures released over the weekend by the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

title: G.M. Offers New Auto or Insurance To Buyers of EngineSwitched Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation, bowing to widespread criticism that it swapped engines without informing buyers, agreed yesterday to let buyers of 1977 Buick, Oldsmobile and Pontiac cars equipped with Chevrolet engines exchange their cars or receive a free mechanicalperformance insurance policy.

title: Move to Big Board From OTC Is Due By American Express
description: The overthecounter market will lose its largest company next month when the American Express Company leaves for a listing on the New York Stock Exchange.

description: Garbagelittered lots, many of them in the most rundown sections of New York City, will become vegetable gardens under a program to green the city by creating a thousand farms in lowincome neighborhoods.

title: Cauthen Wins 3 More
description: Blas New Yorkers saw still another remarkable Steve Cauthen riding performance at Aqueduct Monday.

title: Police Trying To OutPsych The .44 Killer
description: The psychological profile being pieced together by Dr. Harvey Schlossberg is an abstraction, but unlike many such abstractions, this one has a real model somewhere in New York Citya model who has already killed five people and wounded three others.

title: VICTOR LAROCK
description: BRUSSELS, April 25 (AP)Victor Larock, former Foreign Minister and a prominent figure in Belgian Socialism in the years after World War II, died last night of a heart attack in a Madrid hospital, Socialist Party officials announced today. He was 72 years old.

title: Egyptian Census Foretells Doubled Population in 30 Years, Negating Economic Gains
description: CAIRO, April 24  Egypt, its land resousces nearly exhausted, will double its population of 38.5 million within 30 years if it continues to grow at the same pace, the first full census in 16 years indicates.

title: SCHEUER BACKS ROLE ON SEGREGATION PLAN
description: Representative James R. Scheuer warned yesterday that placing black students into schools that are now fairly evenly divided between whites and nonwhites would lead whites to flee both the [school] system and the city.

title: Riddick Gets Award
description: Riddick, who won 15 of 16 sprint finals during the indoor season, was named recipient of the Jesse Abramson Award as the outstanding male athlete of the indoor season.

title: Concert: Mendelssohn's Elijah
description: Mendelssohn's Elijah is not heard very often these daysa far cry from when it was a staple in the repertory of all Victorian choral societies a century ago. Its neglect is understandable. Not only does the piece seem a trifle muddled, both in its mixture of Baroque and Romantic styles and overall lack of dramatic focus, but, unlike the sturdier oratorios of Bach and Handel, Elijah only reveals its best qualities under the most favorable performing conditions.

title: College Results
description: MEN'S BASEBALL

title: Gerber Files Suit to Prevent Takeover by Anderson, Clayton
description: Charging that a proposed takeover of the Gerber Products Company by Anderson, Clayton & Company would create a monopoly in baby food, Gerber filed suit yesterday in the United States District Court in Grand Rapids to block the bid.

title: Allon Sees Differences With U.S., but He Doubts Any Shift Toward Arabs
description: JERUSALEM, April 25Foreign Minister Yigal Allon has told the Israeli Cabinet that differences of opinion on questions of primary importance could arise between Israel and the United States in the near future regarding an ArabIsraeli peace settlement.

title: Escaping the Auto Insurance Jam
description: Like cheap energy and the doctor's house call, cheap automobile insurance is becoming a thing of the past. For some young drivers, the cost of the insurance may now exceed the cost of a used car. For a single male in the South Bronx, to take an extreme example, insurance for a 1974 Oldsmobile Cutlass will rise this spring from about $1,200 to more than $1,800. Although liability insurance is mandated by law, increasing numbers of drivers are operating without any insurance at all. At the same time, there have been charges that the insurance industry is making excess profits, not an uncommon charge against any industry when prices rise rapidly.

title: Notes on People
description: Pledging to end what he termed the short circuiting of civil rights by the Nixon Administration, Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, yesterday named David S. Tatel, a 35yearold Washington lawyer, as director of the Office for Civil Rights. The office is respon sible for enforcing laws that prohibit schools and other federally funded institutions from discriminating against minorities, women and the handicapped. Mr. Tatel, a former director of the Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, is an avid jogger and skier although he is blind. To strengthen the office further, Mr. Califano also named two deputy directors Cynthia G. Brown, 34, for compliance and enforcement, and Wilbert A. Cheatham, 35, for program review. Civil rights have been a problem for Mr. Califano, who last month said he advocated quotas to get rid of discrimination. When that brought a strong reaction, he said he had made a mistake and what he really meant was equal opportunity for all.

title: Penn Wails Over Misses In Lacrosse
description: There was an undercurrent of dejection in Jim Adams's voice yesterday. The University of Pennsylvania lacrosse coach was recapitulating Sunday's 178 loss to Cornell that might cost the Quakers the Ivy League title. It also snapped a sevengame winning streak, their longest since 1965. Cornell has won 22 games in a row over two seasons.

title: Abrams Scores Bronx Institutions On Borough Mortgage Redlining
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx charged yesterday that five of the six statechartered savings institutions based in the Bronx had redlined the borough by providing few residential mortgages in the Bronx.

title: BOND PRICES DROP; FED ACTION STUDIED
description: Prices eroded in the bond market yesterday as dealers and investors tried to decide whether the Federal Reserve was tightening monetary policy slightly. The Federal funds rate, generally regarded as the key to the puzzle, rose to 5 percent late in the afternoon, and the Fed, which injected some temporary reserves into the banking system earlier in the day, said it would add more today. The market's discussion over monetary policy, however, still seemed to reach no conclusion.

title: The Indispensable Man
description: STAMFORD, Conn.The announcement that Henry Kissinger will coach the Detroit Red Wings hockey team next season came as no surprise to those who know of the former Secretary of State's longtime interest in ice.

title: 3 Officers of Swiss Credit Branch Arrested in Loss of Up to 100 Million
description: GENEVA, April 25The arrest of the three top officers of a Swiss Credit Bank branch was announced today in connection with a possible loss of up to $100 million in unauthorized loans.

title: 1,000 Farms Planned on Lots in New York
description: Garbagelittered lots, many of them in the most rundown sections of New York City, will become vegetable gardens under a program to green the city by creating a thousand farms in lowincome neighborhoods.

title: Israeli Warns That AntiSemitism May Arise at U.N. Racism Meeting
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 25Chaim Herzog, Israel's chief delegate to the United Nations, said today that Jewish people everywhere were watching to see if Arab countries would succeed in injecting antiSemitic overtones into the planning of a proposed World Conference to Combat Racism.

title: Rebates Or Revenue?
description: The architect of President Carter's energy program, James R. Schlesinger, has raised the distinct possibility that substantial revenues from the new energyrelated taxes eventually would be diverted to tax and welfare reform programs.

title: I.B.M. Foresees Benefits From Price Cuts
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, having just released what analysts found to be disappointing earnings, reassured stockholders today that price cutting in the industry would actually have a beneficial effect.

title: Manes, a Power in City, Weighs Political Options
description: Years ago, when Donald R. Manes was a legislative staff member in Albany, he began one day to tell Assemblyman Stanley Steingut a story about a political maneuver by Mr. Steingut's father, Irwin. Detail followed upon detail. Nothing nefarious, but intelligence that had been very, very private.

title: India's Congress Party Wins Delay Of Move to Dissolve Legislatures
description: NEW DELHI, April 25The opposition Congress Party won a temporary restraining order from the Supreme Court tonight preventing nine state assemblies under its control from being dissolved by the central Government of Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Canadian Salmon
description: American Atlantic salmon anglers are rejoicing that Canada's Province of New Brunswick has announced that it does not contemplate any major changes or cancellations in the present system of Crown leases of salmon rivers.

title: A CARTER AIDE CALLS TIMES ARTICLE UNFAIR
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, said today that an article about President Carter printed in today's New York Times was totally inaccurate and unfair and said that he had asked more than 20 members of the White House staff Whether they had spoken to the reporter who had written it.

title: Stage: Dance on a Country Grave
description: Making a musical play out of Thomas Hardy's The Return of the Native is the kind of endeavor that should give a young author pause. Hardy's novel, with its intertwined characters, folkways and abrupt happenings, not, one would think, easily reduced to a couple of hours on stage.

title: Bearne Is Expected to Move Today To Tighten Rule Over Hospital Unit
description: In an effort to consolidate his control over the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, Mayor Beanie is expected to ask the semiindependent city agency today to make Donald E. Kummerfeld, the city's Budget Director, its top policy maker, and to accept a former critic of the agency as the replacement for Dr. John L. S. Holloman Jr., its ousted president.

title: Money
description: Monday, April 25, 1977

title: Seton Hall Defies Rivals At Penn Relays
description: The big guns will be traveling from Arizona. Tennessee and Florida, bringing their fast times and equally fast talk. But Coach John Moon does not believe Seton Hall will be intimidated when the Penn Relays begin in earnest Friday and Saturday at Franklin Field in Philadelphia.

title: N.A.S.L. Standings
description: SUNDAY'S GAMES

title: Gromyko Begins Visit to New Delhi
description: NEW DELHI, April 25Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union arrived here today for a threeday visit during which he is scheduled to have detailed discussions with the Indian Government on relations between the two countries.

title: Seoul Said to Release 15 Dissidents
description: SEOUL. South Korea. April 25 (AP)The South Korean Government released 15 more Christian opponents of President Park Chung Hee during the weekend, church sources reported today. But it arrested five Christian youths who led an antiGovernment street demonstration after a church rally in Seoul. The sources had reported last Friday that a total of 45 persons had been arrested since the latest Government crackdown, on persons critical of President Park's rule, began on April 12. But they reported is of the 45 had been released.

title: Wildlife Center Keeps Them Flying
description: LAUREL, Md.The whooping cranes are not receiving visitors just now, being otherwise occupied in propagating themselves a bit further back from the edge of extinction.

title: Cooking That Really Beats the Band
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 25They call it the New Orleans Jazz Inheritage Festival, but as far as one eater was concerned, the real subject was food38 stands and about a halfdozen roving carts spread out on the fairgrounds of the city's race track.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERAlex (Amellus), April 24, 1977. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, Third Ave. at 85th St. Services Wednesday 11 A.M.

title: SYRIANS FIGHT GUERRILLAS IN BEIRUT FOR A THIRD DAY
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 25Hundreds of Syrian troops of the Arab League's peacekeeping force battled Palestinian extremists and Lebanese leftists here today for the third day as a result of the murder of two Syrian soldiers last Friday night.

title: Opera on Coast: A Rite of Spring
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 25This city's Spring Opera Theater is this latest and most successful manifestation of a longstanding local urge for yearround operatic entertainment. For 55 years the San Francisco Opera has presented fullscale opera here with international casts in autumn.

title: BELL STANDING FIRM ON F.B.I. INDICTMENT
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell listened today to complaints by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who said that morale in the bureau had been damaged by the indictment of a former agent. But he said afterward that it was not likely he would reconsider his decision to prosecute the case.

title: COURT HEARS APPEAL ON OFFSHORE LEASES
description: A Federal appeals court listened to arguments yesterday on a lower court's decision to void the sale of more than a billion dollars in leases for oil and gas drilling rights in the Atlantic Ocean.

title: 6 New Comedy Programs Added to Fall Schedule by ABC
Companies Report Sales and Earnings Figures
description: Profits Scoreboard (Some of timer Corporations Reporting Yesterday)

title: Widened Disclosure By Banks Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed rules today that would require banks and bank holding companies to make wider financial disclosures, including foreign loan losses.

title: Authoritarianism, BrazilianStyle
description: RIO DE JANEIROAlready angered by President Carter's effort to prevent Brazil from acquiring nuclearweapons technology, the Brazilian military Government reacted with exaggerated fury when it learned of a mildly critical State Department report on the condition of human rights in this country. It rejected American military credits, renounced a longstanding militaryassistance agreement and expressed loud resentment against this latest example of American moral imperialism.

title: CARTER PROPOSES LAW FOR TOUGH CONTROLS ON HOSPITAL CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, April 25President Carter sent Congress a tough hospital costcontrol proposal today amid growing indications that his Administration had serious questions about the type of national health insurance program for all Americans that he promised in his Presidential campaign.

title: SPIRITUAL RENEWAL AMONG JEWS NOTED
description: Although Atherican Jews are largely estranged from traditional belief and practice, there are distinct signs of a spiritual revival among a significant minority of seekers including young people.

title: Books of William Blake Displayed at Adelphi
description: William Blake: The Painter as Poet, an exhibition of the artist's own books as well as illustrations for other works, such as Dante's Inferno, is on view at the Swirbul Library Gallery at Adelphi University in Garden City, L.I. It may be seen, except for Sunday, daily from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. through May 29. Admission is free.

title: Beneficial Finance Use of Tax Slogan Is Upheld by Court
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)The Government's attempt to prohibit Beneficial Finance Loan offices from using the slogan instant tax refund for some loans was denied Supreme Court review today.

title: Detroit Parents Sue to Keep Schools From Withholding Lunch to Punish
description: DETROIT, April 25A parents' group here has asked a Federal court to prohibit public schools from punishing students who misbehave by denying them hot lunch.

title: FORMER AGENT TAKS AT ESPIONAGE TRIAL
description: LOS ANGELES, April 25Victor L. Marchetti, a former officer of the Central Intelligence Agency, testified today that a proposed C.I.A. satellite system was not a serious project but was concocted mostly as part of a dog and pony show to impress Congress.

title: Intelligence Panel, Set Up Last Year, Still Faces Major Battles on Control of Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, April 25One year after the Senate intelligence committee issued its final report, its recommendations for controlling the intelligence agencies still have not become law, the oversight committee it led to still is not fully organized and important legislative battles remain to be fought.

title: Abram H. Stockman Is Dead at 66; A Labor Arbitrator Since 1945
description: Abram H. Stockman, a labor arbitrator, who served during World War H as assistant general counsel for the National Labor Relations Board and as vice chairman of the appeals committee of the National War Labor Board, died Sunday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Bus Plan to Roosevelt
description: WESTBURY, L.I., April 25Roose velt Raceway and Suffolk County's offtrack betting operation are collaborating on a bus promotion to bring in 1,000 fans, to the track Thursday. For $3.25, a bettor will get roundtrip bus transportation, admission and a program. Information is available at Suffolk OTB branches or by calling (516) 3603500.

title: G.O.P. WILL EXTEND RENT STABILIZATION
description: ALBANY, April 25Republicans, who control the New York State Senate, reached agreement on two major issues this afternoon, voting in caucus to extend the Emergency Tenant Protection Act for four years and to make permanent the present 8.5 percent ceiling on homemortgage interest rates.

title: London's 2 Evening Newspapers. Reported to Be Planning Merger
description: LONDON, April 25 (Reuters)London's two evening newspapers, both hard hit by falling circulation, are to be merged into a single publication, U.K. Press Gazette, a trade weekly, reported today.

title: W.H.O. ASSERTS SMALLPOX IS ERADICATED IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, April 25 (AP)The World Health Organization has declared smallpox eradicated in India.

title: SOVIET ALSO SEEKING TO CONSERVE ENERGY
description: MOSCOW, April 25The call to conserve energy has been heard in the Soviet Union, too, these days. But it often sounds like a voice crying in the wilderness, for however urgent the tone, relatively few Russians seem ready to take it seriously.

title: Britain Puts Priority on Pollution
description: LONDON. April 25Energy Secretary Anthony Wedgwood Benn, reporting to the House of Commons today on the Ekofisk blowout, said that dealing with pollution at sea is the first priority. He said that Britain had offered Norway whatever help was needed and I am considering what further action is indicated.

title: Strike Is Settled, N.B.A. Referees Return
description: The strike of 24 referees against the National Basketball Association ended yesterday after 15 days.

title: Bridge:
description: It might seem unlikely that indigent sailors would make a bridge tournament possible, but it happened Sunday in Staten Island. The seamen's involuntary removal to the Carolinas a few years ago allowed their 150yearold home, Snug Harbor, to become a cultural center, and bridge is the first activity to make use of the facilities on a regular basis.

title: City Judge in Newburgh Dismissed On IneptAdministration Charges
description: A Newburgh city judge, Albert S. MacDowell, who delayed cases for months, allowed court mail to pile up for as much as 30 days and who once ordered the arrest of an acting judge seeking access to court records, was dismissed from the bench yesterday for failure to discharge his administrative responsibilities.

title: High Seas and Winds Force Delay In Halting Oil Blowout Off Norway
description: EKOFISK CENTER, in the North Sea off Norway, April 25High winds and rough seas forced the postponement today of efforts to cap an offshore oil well about a mile from here that is spewing hundreds of thousands of gallons of crude oil a day into the North Sea.

title: Dollar Gains in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, April 25 (AP)The dollar gained on the Japanese yen today despite efforts by Japan's central bank to brake the decline of the Japanese currency. The dollar closed at 278.475 yen, up from 277.425 on Friday.

title: People in Sports
description: Mike Pazik, a lefthanded pitcher for the Minnesota Twins, will be lost for the season because of an injury sustained in an auto accident early yesterday morning. He suffered two broken bones in each leg and a bruised forehead. Don Carrithers, also a,pitcher for the Twins, who was driving, suffered a compound fracture of his right knee and a fractured right wrist. He will be unable to play for two or three months. Both players are 27 years old.

title: American Brands
description: American Brands Inc., the nation's fourthranking cigarette producer, reported yesterday a 14 percent gain in firstquarter net income.

title: A.&P. Net Off 37% in Final Period But Chain's Profits Rose in Year
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company reported yesterday a 37 percent drop in earnings for its final fiscal quarter ended Feb. 26. The supermarket chain, however, reported a strong surge in profits for its full fiscal year ended Feb. 26.

title: Carter Retains Envoy in Moscow And Picks Career Man for Paris
description: WASHINGTON, April 25President Carter has selected a career diplomat, Arthur A. Hartman as the next American ambassador to France, and has decided to retain another veteran Foreign Service officer, Malcolm Toon, as the Ambassador in Moscow.

title: N.F.L. Pact With Players Challenged
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 25 (AP)The proposed court settlement between the National Football League Players Association and N.F.L. clubs hit a snag today when lawyers for more than a dozen players sought to intervene.

title: Eren Ozker Is Bride Of William Bogert 2d
description: Eren Ozker and William Russell Bogert 2d were married yesterday in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Robert Duane Pelton. The bride is an actress and puppeteer and her husband is an actor.

title: Trenton Tonics
description: TRENTON, April 25The State Senate approved today a record $4 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1. The vote was 24 to 9, with the opposition coming from Republican members.

title: Bantam Will Redistribute Books in Roots Dispute
description: Bantam Books intends to redistribute two books that have been cited in controversy over Alex Haley's Pulitzer Prizewinning book, Roots, a spokesman for the publishing house said yesterday.

title: Chain Stores Sales in March Show an Advance of 12.6%
description: The nation's chain stores had a 12.6 percent sales gain in March compared to March 1976, according to a compilation by Chain Store Age magazine. For the first three months of the year, sales were ahead 11.1 percent.

title: EXMANSON CULTIST TELLS OF ASSURANCE TO VICTIMS
description: LOS ANGELES. April 25 (UPI)The Manson group members who killed Leno and Rosemary LaBianca told them before the slayings that they were not going to be hurt a former Manson follower testified today.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: San Diego vs. Winnipeg

title: 2 Macbeths Ready For Off Broadway
description: Two productions of Shakespeare's Macbethone with an interracial cast and the other with an allblack companywill be on view simultaneously Off Broadway next month.

title: BUDDHISM RETAINING MAJOR ROLE IN LAOS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 21Sixteen months after the Communists seized power Buddhist monks still file through this quiet capital in the early morning collecting alms. But many people wonder how much longer the 700yearold national religion of Laos will be able to flourish.

title: Weston VernonJr., Former President Of Law Group, 72
description: Weston Vernon Jr., a senior partner in the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy and a past president of the New York State Bar Association, died Saturday at his home on Basket Neck Lane in Remsenburg, L.I. He was 72 years old.

title: BETHE ENDORSES DELAYING ATOMIC BREEDER REACTORS
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)An adocate of the nuclear breeder reactor, Hans Bethe of Cornell University, ondorsed today President Carter's decision to delay the use of breeders as power reactors until ways were found to keep them from posing serious weapons proliferation threats.

title: Defendant, 60, Admits New York Wholesaling Of Child Pornography
description: A 60yearold New Jersey man described by law enforcement officials as a major wholesaler of child pornography surprised New York City prosecutors yesterday by pleading guilty to a twocount felony indictment that could bring him as much as 14 years in prison.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, APRIL 25, 1977

title: Golf
description: AT DENVILLE, N.J.

title: BOY, 7, TELLS COURT OF HIS L.I. KIDNAPPING
description: MINEOLA, LI., April 25Do you know what happens when a person lies? the judge asked the boy on the witness stand.

title: Jazz: Saxophonist Swings to Past
description: Since the period of jazz development preceding World War II came to an end more than 30 years ago, the jazz styles of that period have virtually disappeared except for copies in trad??tional or revivalist groups. For a young jazz musician today to grow and develop on his own as though this growth were occurring in the 30's or early 40's is almost unheard of. But Scott Hamilton, a young tenorsaxophonist from New England who has been playing around town with a variety of groups during the last winter, has managed to make himself a part of such a time warp.

title: West German Rider Wins
description: ROME, April 25 (UPI)  Hendrik SchulzeSiehoff of West Germany won the Grand Prize of Rome today in the main jumping event of the third day of the 45th Rome International Horse Show. SchulzeSiehoff, riding Sarto, won with 2 penalty points in a time of 50.4 seconds.

title: Liberties Groups Back Klan in Dispute With Lefkowitz
description: A statewide KuKlux Klan organization, fighting an effort by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to compel disclosure of its membership, has enlisted the help of the American and the New York Civil Liberties Unions.

title: MAX BREWER
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., April 25  Max Brewer, public relations director at Monticello Raceway from 1964 to 1969, died today of a heart attack at the track. He was 39 years old and resided in South Fallsburg. Mr. Brewer also served as a track announcer. He was associated with harness racing for many years, including service at Roosevelt and Yonkers raceways.

title: Carey Sifts Legal Issue Of Farley Tourney Role
description: Governor Carey said yesterday he planned to discuss with state attorneys the legal aspect of James A. Farley Jr.'s role in the suspended United States Boxing Championships.

title: ZAMBIAN LEADER OUSTS 5, CHARGING ILLEGAL POLITICS
Illinois to Seek Added Options
description: CHICAGO, April 25 (UPI)The Illinois Attorney General, William J. Scott, said today that the General Motors offer was a step in the right direction but did not go far enough.

title: Expected Wheat Surplus Puts Problem of Farm Incomes Before Carter
description: ZENITH, Kan., April 25With the winter dryness throughout much of the wheat belt broken by recent rains, the chance for another bumper crop has been increased and President Carter is confronted with the economic and political problems of a huge, pricedepressing wheat surplus.

title: Restaurant Event Set For June 4 in Park
description: Specialties from more than 100 of New York City's restaurants and food shops will be offered to an expected half a million people at an expanded version of last year's successful A Taste of the Big Apple event to be held Saturday afternoon, June 4, in Central Park.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Columbia Agrees to a Renovation Of Dormitory FireSafety System
description: Nearly five months after a fire swept a Columbia University dormitory, injuring a dozen students, a Fire Department study has recommendedand the university has agreed to implementa major renovation of fireprotection and safety systems on campus.

title: Inmates Should Be Taxed And Be Paid for Work, Bar Group Report Says
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)Prisoners should receive wages and other employment benefits, pay the state for room and board and pay taxes, according to an American Bar Association study Made public today.

title: Swedish, Soviet Sixes Win
description: VIENNA, April 25 (AP)Roland Eriksson, who also plays for the Minnesota North Stars of the National Hockey League, scored three goals today as Sweden routed West Germany, 71, and remained unbeaten in the world ice hockey championship.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, April 25, 19 77

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article last Friday on the cashew industry, Heinz Levi, president of the Hollander Trading Corporation, was incorrectly quoted as urging that the Indian Government subsidize importers of cashews. In fact, he recommended that the Government aid Indian exporters of cashews.

title: Brown Shifting View on Penalties For Disclosing Intelligence Secrets
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)De fense Secretary Harold Brown's initial support for criminal penalties for persons who disclose intelligence secrets has apparently been modified in the face of opposition by President Carter and Vice President Mondale.

title: The Best Time of the Sports Year
description: In sports this is normally the best time of the year. But there's even more action than usual. The baseball season is under way. The basketball and hockey playoffs are building. The pro football draft is approaching. So is the Triple Crown of horse racing. The golfers are moving toward the United States Open, the tennis players toward the. Wimbledon championships. The trackandfield athletes are outdoors, where they belong. The boxers are training for two heavyweight fights. But the headlines provoke other stories. Such as the time more than two decades of the streaking Los Angeles Dodgers. threatened to retire as a lefthanded pitcher rather than return to the minors in midseason.

title: Mandel Undergoes Cerebral Test To Discover Cause of Headaches
description: BALTIMORE, April 25 (AP)Gov. Marvin Mandel underwent a cerebral angiogram test at Johns Hopkins Hospital today, and a hospital spokesman said the risky procedure had been completed with no complications.

title: RESULTS
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% municipal surtax)

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Carborundum Company of Niagara Fa??, N.Y., announced yesterday multimilliondollar capital construction programs in two fields. One is the forming of sintered ceramics into turbine blades and other engine parts, and the other is making activated carbon for treating drinking water and waste water from homes and industry.

title: TV: Rediscovering the Surreal Genius of Ernie Kovacs
description: Defying tidy categorization, the humor of the late Ernie Kovacs is best left to unadorned description. Tonight it 9:30, on Channel 13, unaccompanied by studio audience or phony laughtrack, Mr. Kovacs can be seen presiding over the following routines:

title: Nordiques Rout Racers, 83, And Take 20 Playoff Lead
description: QUEBEC, April 25 (AP)Steve Sutherland scored three goals as the Quebec Nordiques routed the Indianapolis Racers, 83, tonight and took a 20 lead in their fourofseven game World Hockey Association semifinal playoff series.

title: ExNixon Aides Continue to Meet As Informal Group
description: WASHINGTON, April 25It calls itself the February Group. It meets in Washington hotels, irregularly.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An eighthgrade student, irritated by antics in a cafeteria, allegedly shot and critically wounded a classmate yesterday in Newark as he tried to wrest a gun away from him, the police reported. Clarence Taylor, 15 years old, a ninth grader at Webster Junior High School, was reported in critical condition at St. Michael's Hospital with a gunshot wound just below his heart. Another youth, Rickey Manley, 15, was reported in fair condition after he was shot in the right hip.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article last Friday on the cashew industry. Heinz Levi, president of the Hollander Trading Corporation, was incorrectly quoted as urging, that the Indian Government subsidize importers of cashews. In fact, he recommended that the Government aid Indian exporters of cashews.

title: Beame Is Expected to Announce His Candidacy Before End of May
description: Mayor Beame, who started a 10day vacation in Florida on Sunday, is expetted to announce his candidacy for reelection between May 15 and May 25, Deputy Mayor Stanley M. Friedman said yesterday.

title: Roosevelt
description: Horses listed in order of post postions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Republicans Contend Energy Levies Are Designed as General Tax Rise
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The Republican leaders of Congress suggested today that President Carter's proposed energy conservation taxes were a disguised general tax increase to finance welfare reform and help the President meet his commitment to balance the budget.

title: General Mills Approves Sale of Subsidiary
description: General Mills Inc. said it approved a letter of intent to sell its subsidiary. General Mills Chemicals Inc. to Henkel KGAA, a German household careproducts company for about $75 million.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Meadowlands Drivers
description: (Includes races of April 23)

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Joanne Chesimard sat handcuffed in the jury box as Judge Theodore Appleby sentenced her to 26 to 33 years in state prison on assault and weapons charges.

title: Grain and Soybean Futures Drop In Heavy Selling on Bearish News
description: The grain and soybean futures markets were scenes of heavy selling yesterday as a spate of bearish news hit trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Dow Chemical Lists Payments In Amended Statement to S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The Dow Chemical Company paid foreign employees $33.7 million in salaries and bonuses in countries other than where they lived but did not disclose them because no impropriety was involved, an amended company registration statement disclosed today.

title: FREDERICK SCHMIDT, 91, FORMER NEW YORK JUDGE
description: Frederick G. Schmidt, who retired in 1955 as a justice in the Appellate Division of New York State Supreme Court, died Friday in United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y. He lived at 20 Lafayette Drive, Port Chester, and was 91 years old.

title: Jersey Assembly Votes Controls For Atlantic City Casino Gambling
description: TRENTON, April 25After more than eight hours of debate, the State Assembly approved tonight a bill for regulating casinos in Atlantic City that would allow gambling on roulette, baccarat, blackjack, dice, bigsix wheels and slot machines from 10 A.M. to 4 A.M. weekdays and 10 A.M. to 6 A.M. on weekends and holidays.

title: John D. Toft, 90
description: SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., April 25John D. Toft, a pioneer in the fish canning industry, died Saturday in the Maine Medical Center in Portland. He was 90 years old.

title: Utah Aviation Director Admits Error in Crash
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 25 (UPI)Bobby Walker, the Utah state aeronautics director, took full responsibility today for crashing the state's $132,000 Beech??raft Barron at Duchcene Airport Friday night. He admitted that he had misjudged his landing approach.

title: Canto Retains Flyweight Title
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 25 (UPI) Miguel Canto of Mexico outboxed Reyes Arnal of Venezuela yesterday and gained a 15round split decision, retaining his World Boxing Council flyweight title. Canto, 29, weighed 111 pounds for his seventh title defense. Arnal weighed 111.

title: ALTHEA GIBSON IN BID FOR TRENTON SENATE
description: Althea Gibson, the former international tennis champion who resigned last December as New Jersey's Athletic Commissioner, announced yesterday her candidacy for the State Senate as part of a splinter group challenging the Essex County Democratic Committee headed by Harry Lerner. Miss Gibson, 49 years old, said during a news conference that she had to be persuaded to make her first race for political office. She will challenge State Senator Frank J. Dodd, a Democrat who has reprented a section of Newark and East and West Orange as an Assemblyman and a Senator for 11 years.

title: Beame Is Expected to Move Today To Tighten Rule Over Hospital Unit
description: In an effort to consolidate his control over the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, Mayor Beame is expected to ask the semiindependent city agency today to make Donald E. Kummerfeld, the city's Budget Director, its top policy maker, and to accept a former critic of the agency as the replacement for Dr. John L. S. Holloman Jr., its ousted president.

title: CARTER AND HUSSEIN DISCUSS P.L.O. ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, April 25President Carter explored with King Hussein of Jordan today possible ways of allowing Palestinian representation at a Middle East peace conference, a stumbling block that has delayed the reconvening of Geneva meeting.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: A Resurgent Home Construction Industry
description: The automobile industry, whose robust sales have been the major factor in the nation's recovery from its worst postwar recession, has of late been joined in the towing effort by a resurgent home building business. The latest data show that new housing starts of all types last month were at their fastest pace in almost four years, while actual sales of new, completed homes in March ran at the highest level since 1963. In addition, permits issued for future construction, particularly in the singlefamily sector of the market, have jumped sharply in the last two months. And, considering the substantial increase this year in mortgage commitments by savings institutions, substantial volume of building seems assured in the months ahead.

title: Israeli Politician, Cleared of Currency Violations, Files a Libel Suit
description: TEL AVIV Aprill 25  An Israeli politician who has been cleared of charges Prin?? by a weekly that he broke the nafion's currency laws filed a libel suit todau against his accusers.

title: CARTER PROPOSES LAW FOR TOUGH CONTROLS ON HOSPITAL CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, April 25President Carter sent Congress a tough hospital costcontrol proposal today amid growing indications that his Administration had serious questions about the type of national health insurance program for all Americans that he promised in his Presidential campaign.

title: European Team Chess Title Won by Soviet, for Six Straight
description: MOSCOW, April 25 (Reuters)The Soviet Union has won the European team chess championship for the sixth straight time. Its team was led by the world champion, Anatoly Karpov, who won all five of his games, and included two former world titleholders, Tigran Petrosian and Mikhail Tal.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Banks List Their Quarter Earnings Reports
Fall Fashion Euphoria: Lightweight Fabrics Take a Bow
description: The pace of the fall fashion shows quickens this week. The troops assembled yesterday at 8:30 A.M. (Before dawn, insisted one sleepy combatant) at the Hotel Pierre to applaud Kasper's gentle clothes for Joan Leslie. Then buses gathered up the retail executives from stores all over the country and deposited them at Geoffrey Beene's door on Seventh Avenue.

title: American Ouster From Ethiopia May Be a ShortLived Soviet Success
description: WASHINGTON. April 25On the surface, the decision of Ethiopia's military Government to close most American facilities represents a substantial loss of influence for the United States and a dramatic advance for the Soviet Union in the Horn of Africa.

title: Florida Power Failure Upsets Time Shift
description: DE LAND, Fla., April 25 (UPI)Residents of this central Florida community who depend on electric clocks set them ahead one hour to conform with daylight savings time, but still found themselves nearly an hour late yesterday morning.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: MidApril Car Sales Up 3.2%, to Record
description: DETROIT, April 25The auto industry said today that newcar sales gained 3.2 percent to record levels in midApril after an unexpectedly slow pace in the first third of the month when sales were off 14.8 percent.

title: Columbia Refused Permit To Run Nuclear Reactor By the Health Department
description: Citing slight, but what is called potentially grave, risks to the community, New York City's Health Department yesterday denied Columbia University's application for a permit to run a small nuclear reactor on its Morningside Heights campus as a teaching aid and research tool.

title: Canadiens Shift Tactics For Islanders Tonight
description: Last Oct. 30 the Province of Quebec was wrenched by the sad news: the beloved Canadiens had lost a game at the Montreal Forum.

title: Yields on Treasury Bills Rise
description: Yields rose on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: 3 Shoot 67's and Lead Dodge Open Qualifiers
description: DENVILLE, N.J., April 25  Mike Burke of Deal, Mike Ballo of Woodway. and Bill Collins of Brae Burn tied with fiveunderpar 67's and led 60 other qualifiers today for the $55,000 Dodge open golf tournament at the Rockaway River Country Club. The 72hole tournament will be held May 1012 at the same course.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: Public accounting circles are abuzz these days with one proposal or another to restructure the profession and its rulemaking institutions. Thus far the most prominent urgings tend to extremeseither to strip the profession of much of its remaining autonomy and place it much further under close Federal supervision (the Congressional response), or after minor tinkering, to leave things largely as they are (the profession's).

title: School Results
description: BOYS' BASEBALL

title: G. M. Offers New Auto or Insurance To Buyers of EngineSwitched Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation, bowing to widespread criticism that swapped engines without informing buyers, agreed yesterday to let buyers of 1977 Buick, Oldsmobile and Pontiac cars equipped with Chevrolet engines exchange their cars or receive a free mechanicalperformance insurance policy.

title: Yanks Down Orioles for 6th in Row
description: BALTIMORE, April 25Baltimore fans, aroused by Reggie Jackson's return, and a steady rain, falling in spite of the umpire's desire to get the game in, combined tonight to create potentially serious problems for the Yankees.

title: President's Food Stamp Proposal: Boon to Some but Blow to Others Among the Poor
description: DETROIT, April 25I got my pride, says Charles Ream of Pittsburgh whose hip, pelvis and left leg were crushed in a coal mine accident five years ago and who relies partly on Federal food stamps to help support his family. I pay my taxes and everything. It's not my fault I got pinned down there.

title: Isidore Agency Joins General Cigar Team
description: Isidore, Lefkowitz, Elgort has joined Young & Rubicam and Ogilvy & Mather on the agency list of the General Cigar and Tobacco Company division of the Culbro Corporation.

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300: NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT, (2??) 3482767.

title: City Opera Schedules Barabbas Premiere
description: Alberto Ginastera's Barabbas will be given its world premiere by the New York City Opera next spring as one of five new productions it is presenting during the 197778 season. The Brazilian composer, whose Don Rodrigo, Bomarzo and Beatrice Cenci have been done by the company in the past, has based his latest opera on a play by Michel de Ghelderode.

title: Zaire Says Its Forces Recapture a Key Rail Center From Katangan Rebels
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 25Zaire said today that its soldiers, backed by Moroccan troops, had retaken an important southern railroad town from Katanganled insurgents.

title: Curfew Is Eased in Pakistan Cities; Bhutto's Foes Expect Lull to End
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 25The Government considerably eased the curfew in Pakistan's major cities today as the crisis atmosphere in the country lessened, at least temporarily.

title: Sybil Is One of 24 Winners of Peabody Awards
description: The NBCTV production of Sybil is one of the 24 winners this year of George Foster Peabody Awards for broadcasting excellence, it was announced yesterday by the University of Georgia School of Journalism. Sybil was cited as one of the truly outstanding dramatic programs of the year.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: 12.47 Plunge Takes Dow To 914.60, a 15Month Low
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged more than 12 points yesterday, 1977's steepest drop, as the bluechip barometer hit a 15month low.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Freehold Races Tomorrow
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., April 25 (UPI)Racing will resume Wednesday at Freehold Raceway, where parimutuel clerks have ended a sevenweek strike by accepting a new contract.

title: About New York
description: From Inwood and Wall Street, some of New York's IrishAmericans have begun denouncing one of their own. Hugh Carey, the Governor of New York who went to Ireland over the weekend and spoke his mind about the violence in the North and the American money he feels helps feed it.

title: WARNKE ASKS TIGHT REIN ON NUCLEARFUEL EXPORT
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)Paul C. Warnke, the chief United States negotiator for arms control, said today that the country should halt shipments of nuclear fuels to countries that explode nuclear devices.

title: M. R. Gainsbrugh, Retired Economist, Dead at Age of 70
description: Martin R. Gainsbrugh, who retired in 1972 as senior vice president and chief economist of the Conference Board, died yesterday at the age of 70 in Freeport, the Bahamas, where he had his winter home. He was a former resident of New York City and had a summer home in Plessis, N.Y.

title: 7 Chinatown Papers Vie for Readers
description: Just a few blocks from the clock of the old New York Sun, an eclipsed symbol of the days of fiercely competitive newspapers in and around Park Row, a renaissance of feisty journalism is taking placein the seven daily papers of Chinatown.

title: Warrant Issued for Randle Involving Lucchesi Injury
description: ORLANDO, Fla., April 25 (UPI) Lenny Randle, the suspended Texas Rangers' infielder, was named today in Florida warrant charging him with aggravated battery, a felony, for allegedly beating Manager Frank Lucchesi of the Rangers on March 28.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 26, 1977

title: Topics
description: Several Suffolk County communities are reported to be so wary of lowrent housing that they have refused community development funds that they might have gotten from the Department of Housing and Urban Development if they had built some. The department can provide funds only when it approves of a community's comprehensive plan. While poorly run public housing can be a blight on any community, some of the swankiest towns in the region have discovered that public housing can be an asset. The citizens of New Canaan, Conn., decided only last week that people who work for the town ought to be able to find affordable lodging in it and approved construction of a lowrent project. With luck, the news may find its way across the South to Suffolk.

title: Advertising
description: Advocacy advertising, generally by business but sometimes by public interest groups, is booming in the mid1970's. But S. Prakash Sethi, a business school teacher who has extensively researched the matter, doesn't think it's very effective.

title: CORNELIUS W. BROWN
description: Cornelius W. Brown, retired executive vice president of the Pratt and Lambert Paint and Varnish Company, died yesterday at North Central Bronx Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 2968 Perry Avenue, the Bronx. Mr. Brown was associated with Pratt and Lambert for more than 40 years, retiring in 1970. He was a graduate of New York University. He is survived by a daughter.

title: A Primer for Innocents
description: This is the Money of the United States. It is good. Everybody is very happy with the Money. The Money cannot buy happiness, of course. It can, however, buy cars, shoes and the perfect salad bowl, which are the immoral equivalents of happiness. Everybody is very happy with the Money because it buys the immoral equivalent of happiness which, after all, is better than misery.

title: Hussein Is Encouraged
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (Reuters)King Hussein said tonight that his talks with President Carter had encouraged him about prospects for a lasting Middle East peace settlement. He made the statement in a toast before a working dinner at the White House.

title: Market Place
description: The company's runaway well near Stavanger, Norway, has been 4 million tons of mud and oil 120 feet in the air daily and has caused a 100milelong oil slick that is slowing moving toward the coasts of Norway and Denmark.

title: Dance: The First Position Does Of Other Times
description: Ballet attracts more than its fair share of ineffectual but goodhearted volunteers who want to help in some way but ordinarily end up getting underfoot. The First Position, in little more than a year has proven to be the happy exception. It's a volunteer group that regularly stages benefits for one or another worthy company, like New York City Ballet, American Ballet Theater, Denis Wayne's new company: Dancers. Sunday evening, it was the National Association for Regional Ballet that benefited from its work. A pleasingly mixed program was given at the Barnard Gymnasium.

title: McDonnell Douglas
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the aerospace manufacturer based in St. Louis, reported yesterday a firstquarter net income of $28 million, or 73 cents a share, up 10.7 percent from a year earlier. Sales at $759.3 million were down 6.4 percent.

title: A.M.C. Doubled Net In Fiscal Quarter; Total Is $2.5 Million
description: DETROIT, April 25The American Motors Corporation reported today that it more than doubled its earnings in its fiscal quarter that ended March 31, from $1.2 million, or 4 cents a share, to $2.5 million, or 8 cents a share.

title: House Approves $36 Billion Plan For the Military
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The House of Representatives, supporting the main lines of President Carter's defense policy, authorized today nearly $36 billion for weapons procurement and military research.

title: House Approves $36 Billion Plan For the Military
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The House of Representatives, supporting the main lines of President Carter's defense policy, authorized today nearly $36 billion for weapons procurement and military research.

title: Boston Repertory Presents  Formidable Dance of Death
description: BOSTON  One would expect Boston to be a great theater town, and in the past Boston has been a great theater town. Yet in recent years it seems to have had more than the usual difficulties in sustaining highquality, indigenous theater. The latest venture is the Massachusetts Center Repertory Company, which is the brainchild of Janice Cashell, its young but extremely determined producing director. This group has now opened its first season, at the Schubert Theater, with brief series of wellknown plays, all with star casts.

title: Walking the GreekTurkish Tightrope
description: Turkey deserves no tribute for its misguided occupation of northern Cyprus since 1974. The question now is whether it can be persuaded to pull back, then evacuate its forces to permit a fair division of the island between Greek and Turkish Cypriots so that peace can be restored without further damage both allied and American interests in the eastern Mediterranean. The Carter Administration is trying to steer an intelligent middleoftheroad course through the conflict between Greece and Turkey and merits the support of Congress.

title: Suarez Said to Hint Race as Independent In Spanish Elections
description: MADRID, April 25Prime Minister Adolfo Surez was reported today to have suggested strongly that he would be a candidate in the parliamentary elections in Junea decision that could shape their outcome.

title: HORTENSE BUSSE GOODMAN
description: Hortense Busse Goodman, widow of Herbert N. Goodman, chairman of Danskin Inc., apparel makers, who died in 1975, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital after a short illness. She lived at 12 East 82d Street and was 81 years old.

title: Reds Shake Batting Slump By Drubbing Braves, 239
description: On Sunday, after his world championship team had dropped its 10th decision in 14 games, Manager Sparky Anderson of the Cincinnati Reds decided to take a firmer stand with his players.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 26, 1977

title: Venezuelan in Saudi Arabia
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, April 25 (Reuters)President Carios Andres Perez of Venezuela arrived be today for talks with Crown Prince Mid of Saudi Arabia on ways of heeling the rift among major oilproducing countries over their prices. The dispute originated when 11 member nations agreed on a 10 percent increase in the price of crude oil, with an additional 5 per cent rise, beginning July 1. But Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates decided on only a 5 per cent rise from January and refused to go along with the July increase.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Deaths

title: GEOFFREY BING
description: LONDON, April 25 (UPI)Geoffrey Bing, a former Labor Party member of Parliament who became Attorney General of Ghana under the late President Kwame Nkrumah, died at his London home yesterday. He was 68 years old.

title: Gold and Dollar Weaker in Europe
description: LONDON, April 25 (AP)The dollar fell slightly against every major West European currency today. The price of an ounce of gold dropped to $148.375 in both Zurich and London, the two biggest gold markets.

title: OUT GOING Guide
description: THRESHOLD Any presentation of the Young Concert Artists, which features the New York debuts of performers selected through international auditions, is an event of interest Tonight's recital by SungJu Lee, a violinist, is the sixth and final program in the group's 16th series.

title: Manes, a Power in City, Weighs Political Options
description: Years ago, when Donald R. Manes was a legislative staff member in Albany, he began one day to tell Assemblyman Stanley Steingut a story about a political maneuver by Mr. Steingut's father, Irwin. Detail followed upon detail. Nothing nefarious, but intelligence that had been very, very private.

title: Around the Nation
description: KINGS MILLS, Ohio, Apr. 25 (UPI)A mechanical malfunction halted the aerial skyride at the Kings Island Amusement Park near Cincinnati, trapping 45 persons in 19 gondola cars for up to eight hours before they were rescued by use of a crane.

title: JOHN W. GRADY, CASHIER AT THE TIMES, WAS 49
description: John W. Grady, a New York Times accounting department executive, died of cancer Sunday at the St. Elizabeth's division of the St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center. He was 49 years old and lived at 25 Cumming Street.

title: EXXON NET DECLINES 11.6% FOR QUARTER; SALES ADVANCE 92%
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil enterprise, yesterday reported a decline of 11.6 percent in firstquarter earnings, despite a sales gain of 9.2 percent.

title: EDGAR SMITH GIVEN LIFE TERM ON COAST
description: SAN DIEGO, April 25 (UPI)Edgar H. Smith Jr., who spent 14 years on Death Row in the slaying of a New Jersey teenager, was sentenced today to life in prison for the kidnapping and attempted murder of a seamstress.

title: YELLOWSTONE REPORT CITES POOR SERVICE
description: DENVER, April 25An unreleased report severely criticizes the lodgings, restaurants and concessionaire employees in Yellowstone, the oldest and most famous national park in the United States, spokesmen for the Department of the Intenor in Washington and the concessionaire confirmed today.

title: Ethiopian Hijackers Reported Slain
description: LONDON, April 25 (Reuters)The crew of an Ethiopian airliner killed two hijackers trying to escape to Saudi Arabia or the Sudan today, the Addis Ababa radio said in a report monitored here. The radio said that the two. whom it described as members of the Eritrean Liberation Front, had tried to seize an Ethiopian Airlines DC3 that had taken off from Mekele in Tigre Province on an internal flight.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Ethiopia Orders Last 3 Western Journalists to Leave
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 25 (Reuters)The last three Western journalists working in Ethiopia were today given 48 hours to leave the country, and the nation's military Government accused them of distortion and bias.

title: World News Briefs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 (Reuters)King Juan Carlos and the Spanish Government were named as codefendants today in a civil suit filed in federal court here in connection with the collision of two aircraft in the Canary Islands last month.

title: High Court Refuses to Hear Appeal by Manson in 7 California Killings or to Review Death Sentence of Texan
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The Supreme Court refused without comment today to hear Charles M. Manson's appeal from his conviction for the killings of Sharon Tate, the actress, and six other persons in California in 1969. No Justice recorded a dissent.

title: Assault Charges Add 26 Years To Mrs. Chesimard's Life Term
description: NEW BRUNSWICK. April 25Joanne Chesirnard sat handcuffed in the jury box today as Judge Theodore Appleby of Superior Court sentenced her to 26 to 33 years to state prison on assault and weapons charges.

title: Strike at Chrysler Plant Ends
description: TRENTON, Mich. April 25 (AP)A fourday strike by some 300 members of the. United Automobile Workers at a Chrysler Corporation chemical plant has ended while talks continue at a Chrysler facility in Sterling Heights. Workers will Note tomorrow on the tentative agreement reached by negotiators last night at the chemical plant in Trenton.

title: Arson Suspected in Denver Fire
description: DENVER, April 25 (AP) The authorities suspect that a fire that severely damaged the building in which the Colorado Constitution was drafted more than 100 years ago was set. A man was being questioned. The building, constructed as the First National Bank in 1865, housed a hotel and restaurant supply concern. Two firemen were slightly injured in the blaze, which raged for two hours yesterday before it was brought under control.

title: Tennis
description: $250,000 KING CLASSIC

title: Deaths
description: CONKLINAlice V. On April 22, 1977. Of 620 Pelham Rd., New Rochelle. N.Y. Aunt of George Conklin. Committal service on Tuesday, April 26, 1977 at 11 A.M. in the Garden of the Resurrection at Christ Church. Pelhamdale Ave. A Shore Rd., Pelham Manor, N.Y. To be followed by Memorial service In the church.

title: CARTER AND HUSSEIN DISCUSS P.L.O. ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, April 25President Carter explored with King Hussein of Jordan today possible ways of allowing Palestinian representation at a Middle East peace conference, a stumbling block that has delayed the reconvening of a Geneva meeting.

title: DEFENDANT IN SPYING CASE IS DESCRIBED AS PARANOID
description: BALTIMORE, April 25 (AP)Edwin G. Moore 2d was very frightened that the Central Intelligence Agency had bugged the office of Dr. Brian Crowley, a psychiatrist who was helping prepare the defense in his espionage trial, Dr. Crowley testified today.

title: Ancient Town Found in Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan, April 25 (Reuters)A team of Jordanian and foreign students has unearthed a town believed to be more than 3,400 years old in the central Jordanian valley, the official Jordanian news agency reports. It said the students from Jordan, the United States, Italy, Canada and Britain had found grain silos, copper and pottery workshops in the town at Tel Mazar dating from 1,500 B.C.

title: A Summary of Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 The Supreme Court took the following actions today.

title: Moynihan Is Angered by Administration's Delay In Submitting Bill to Reform Welfare Program
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan denounced the Carter Administration today, both on and off the Senate floor, for delaying submission of welfare reform legislation so that it might not take effect until after fiscal year 1979.

title: Yesterday's Pro Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: Strike Grounds Spanish Airline
description: MADRID, April 25 (AP)A strike by 15,000 nonflight employees over wages forced Iberia, Spain's national airline, to cancel all international and domestic flights today. No flights to the United States Are scheduled, but an Iberia spokesman said that the strike could ground tomorrow's Madrid to New York flight.

title: Records of 3 Banks Subpoenaed In New York FiscalCrisis Inquiry
description: ALBANY, April 25The Assembly Committee on Banks today served subpoenas on three major New York City banks for records of their trading in New York City notes during the months just before the fiscal crisis broke into the open early in 1975.

title: Books of The Times
description: From a summary of her life, one would think Cheryl Crawford had quite a story to tell in her autobiography, One Naked Individual: My Fifty Years in the Theatre. In her career as a producer, Miss Crawford has been closely connected with most of the vital theatrical institutions of 20thcentury America, including the Provincetown Players, the Theater Guild, the Group Theater and the Actors Studio. Among the over 100 plays she has produced are Clifford Odets's Awake and Sing and Waiting for Lefty, such musicals as Porgy and Bess, One Touch of Venus and Brigadoon, as well as four plays by Tennessee Williams, The Rose Tattoo, Camino Real, Sweet Bird of Youth and Period of Adjustment.

title: Meadowlands Results
description: FIRST$9,5??0, pace, mile.

title: Measure to Curb Storage Of Nuclear Waste Voted By Vermont Legislature
description: MONTPELIER, VT., April 25The Vermont General Assembly has passed a bill on storage of atomic wastes that is believed to be the strongest in the country.

title: Barons' Owner Hopes To Sell Team Soon
description: CLEVELAND, April 25 (AP)The Cleveland Barons lost more than $3 million in their first season here, but they soon may be sold to Sanford Greenberg, the club's principal owner, Mel Swig, said today.

title: Archeologists Find Wall in Sicily They Think Was Punic War Site
description: MARSALA, Sicily, April 25 (UPI)Archeologists believe that they have found the ancient wall of Lilibeo where the Romans fought the Carthaginians in the first Punic War in 241 B.C.

title: 80's Olympic Ski Jumps Receive Final Approval
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., April 24 (AP) The Adirondack Park Agency has given final approval for construction of the controversial 70and90meter ski jumps to be built just south of here for the 1980 Winter Olympics.

title: Brooklyn 4th Graders Get Close Look at Marine Life
description: Sixty fourth graders from downtown Brooklyn swarmed onto the teach yesterday at Rockaway Point, across Rockaway Inlet in overseas Queens, poking into tidal shallows and the litter line of marine life cast up by the sea onto the sand.

title: Threat of Long Coal Strike And Peril to Energy Plan
description: The prospect of a long coal strike at year's end is among the gravest threats to fulfillment of President's Carter's energy program. White House officials are already pondering what action the Government might take to head off a stoppage that would impede the desired shift from oil to coal by public utilities and other large industrial consumers. For utilities, in particular, the indispensable element in fuel selection is the assurance of uninterrupted supply to guard against any power blackout.

title: $1.2 Billion Standby Fund Offered Swiss Credit Bank to Aid in Crisis
description: GENEVA, April 26A standby credit of $1.2 billion was offered to the Swiss Credit Bank today, to help as needed following the multimilliondollar loss it faces because of irregular dealings at one of its branches.

title: Queens Refuse Piles Blossom in Spring
description: The recent spell of premature summer turned out yesterday to be the chief villain in the slowdown of garbage collection in Queens. Borough President Donald R. Manes and Sanitation Commissioner Anthony T. Vaccarello agreed on this after a meeting at the Borough President's office.

title: The Once And Still King Yul
description: YUL BRYNNER is not the type of person who will throw up his hands in horror if you speak about bringing back or reviving The King and I but he wishes there were some way he could get everyone to stop speaking in terms of revivals.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Careers
description: You still may never get rich by digging a ditch, but the pay in the Army certainly is better now. And the Army is hiring. The high school graduate, thats who we are looking for, said Lieut. Col. Patrick Vitello, an Army spokesman in New York City. He's more trainable and easier to keep.

title: FreeWheeling Fashion for an Easy Ride
description: Few topranking fashion designers concern themselves with bicycling clothes. Too plebian, they might say. Let them wear blue jeans.

title: Soccer's Tiebreaker Shot Down By Most Players, Some Coaches
description: The shootout, this year's innovation by the North American Soccer League to provide thrills and to prevent a tie, is despised by most players and a number of coaches, but advocated by several administrators.

title: Dr. Stanley Berger, Psychoanalyst, Head of Institute in New York City
description: Dr. Stanley Berger, a psychoanalyst who had served as president, dean and training analyst at the Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research here, died Sunday in White Plains Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived in Scarsdale.

title: Carter Approves Pentagon's Offer To Sell Surveillance Planes to Iran
description: WASHINGTON. April 26President Carter as approved a Pentagon offer to sell Iran five of the most sophisticated and costliest radar surveillance planes in the Air Force arsenal at a cost of $850 million. according to military sources.

title: Record Year Ahead For Newspaper Ads?
description: Jack Kauffman, president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, has gained quite a reputation for his fearless forecasts of industry advertising revenue. Yesterday in San Francisco, where the membership is meeting, he said that 1977 was going to top 1976the best growth year yet for newspapersby 10 percent, and reach $11 billion.

title: Teamsters Fund Tax Exemption Restored Under I.R.S. Agreement
description: CHICAGO, April 26 (AP)The teamsters largest pension fund, operating since last year under the threat of losing its taxexempt status, has been requalified under an agreement with the Internal Revenue Service, it was announced today.

title: Canadiens Triumph, 30; Take 20 Playoff Lead
description: MONTREAL, April 26Learning to their dismay that close still counts only in driveins, grenadethrowing and horseshoes, the Islanders dropped their second straight playoff game to the Montreal Canadiens tonight. The score was 30.

title: Chicago U. Denies That Test Drug Was Cause of Cancer in Offspring
description: CHICAGO, April 26 (AP)Drugs given to pregnant women in an experiment in the early 1950's did not cause cancer in their children, the University of Chicago said today in response to a sui? filed by three women who took part in theexperiment.

title: Diners Strike It Rich
description: If Michelin rated American restaurants, the Queens diners would not rate a crossed spoon and fork. But to Queens families out for an evening, nothing could be finer than dinner in a diner.

title: Instant Movies System Introduced by Polaroid
description: NEEDHAM, Mass., April 26The first instant motion picture system, far more compact than advance speculation had indicated, was demonstrated here today to stockholders of the Polaroid Corporation.

title: Advertising
description: Art directors from the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago, took home three of the 26 Gold Awards distributed yesterday by the Art Directors Club.

title: Shift in Balance of SexHormones Linked to Heart Attacks in Men
description: A change in the delicate balance of the body's sex hormones is the major factor that makes men susceptible to heart attacks, according to a major new theory developed by Dr. Gerald B. Phillips of Columbia University.

title: Chrysler's Earnings Gain 4.6% In First Period to $75.4 Million
description: DETROIT, April 26The Chrysler Corporation reported today net earnings of $75.4 million, or $1.25 a share, for the first quartera modest increase of 4.6 percent over the $72.1 million, or $1.20 a share, that the company earned a year earlier.

title: BestBuys
description: RISING PRICES for meat, potatoes and coffee were cited yesterday by the City Department of Consumer Affairs in reporting the highest single weekly percentage increase since the agency began monitoring food prices four years ago.

title: Briton Is Critical of Soviet in Africa
description: CAIRO, April 26Foreign Secretary David Owen of Britain left Cairo for Damascus, Syria, today after two days of talks centering on Soviet activities in Africa and a resumption of the Geneva peace conference on the Middle East.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: CULTURE CENTER SITE DEBATED AT HEARING
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, April 26Representatives of 35 communities and cultural organizations urged members of the New Jersey State Council on the Arts today to establish a major arts and cultural center in their areas.

title: 8 Held as Principals In Smut Production
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office capped a sevenmonth investigation yesterday by arresting eight alleged pornographers on felony charges and seizing 4,000 copies of pornographic films involving children between 8 and 12 years old.

title: Infielder Involved in an Attack on Texas Pilot
McEnroe, 18, on Brink of Stardom
description: Johnny McEnroe had a week of tennis that other 18yearold players dream about.

title: First of Quadruplets Goes Home
description: SAN DIEGO, April 26 (AP)The first of the Dew quadruplets has been released from Children's Health Center and the others are reported getting stronger. They were born 12 weeks prematurely Feb. 24 to James and Diane Dew of Poway. Elizabeth, weighing five pounds, was taken home yesterday.
