title: TREASURY WAIVES DUTIES ON KOREA LEATHER CLOTH
description: WASHINGTON, April 26(Reuters)The United States Treasury today waived duties on leather apparel imported from South Korea, but said it was starting an investigation of such imports from Argentina and Uruguay.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 27, 1977

title: Ycaza Learns Lesson In Harness Race Debut
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., April 26Manny Ycaza, the 38yearold retired jockey, emerged from his debut as a harnessracing driver at rainy Monticello Raceway tonight convinced he has lots to learn before he can create a stir in the standardbred sport.

title: Dow Closes With Token 1.02 Gain, But Other Market Gauges Decline
description: The Dow Jones industrial average clung precariously to a slim gain yesterday and narrowly avoided hitting another 15month low.

title: Soviets Bow to Loves in Net Debut
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 26Natasha Chmyreva came downstairs for her hotel breakfast of pancakes and orange juice this morning wearing the Virginia Slims Tshirt with the motto you've come a long way baby. Indeed she had. more than 10,000 miles.

title: Rockets Win, Even Series With Bullets
description: LANDOVER, Md., April 26(UPI)Rudy Tomjanovich scored 28 points and ignited a fourthquarter rally tonight as the Houston Rockets beat the Washington Bullets, 107103, to even their fourofsevengame National Basketball Association playoff ,series at two games each. The fifth game will be played at Houston Friday night.

title: Deaths
description: BANDELL??a. Beloved wife of the Late Marry. Devoted mother of David, Murray and the late ?????? Adored grandmother and great grandmother. Services Wed., 12 ??? Sc??????rtz Brothers. Forest Park Chapels. Queens Blvd. and 76th Rd., Forest Hills.

title: Laver and Riessen Victors at Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 26 (AP)Rod Laver of Australia and Marty Reissen scored victories over seeded players today in the first round of the $250,000 Alan King tennis tournament.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Four Runs in First DecideOriole Fans Again Ride Jackson
description: BALTIIVIORE, April 26In the second of their threenight foray into Baltimore's hostile wilderness, the Yankees suffered a 62 loss to the Orioles tonightand ended their sixgame winning streak, but they couldn't be altogether unhappy.

title: A Soviet Letter to Israel On Resumption of Trade Is Considered a Signal
description: TEL AVIV, April 26The Soviet Union has offered to trade with Israel for the first time since Moscow severed all relations 10 years ago. The Soviet offer was immediately interpreted here as a signal that the Russians wanted to restore diplomatic relations.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 27, 1977

title: Mets Purchase Randle From Rangers; Yanks Lose, 62, as Holtzman Is Routed
description: Mets Purchase Randle From Rangers; Yanks Lose, 62, as Holtzman Is Routed

title: U.S. AND SOVIET PLAN ARMS TALKS IN MAY
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The United States and the Soviet Union announced today that they would resume formal negotiations for a new strategic arms limitation treaty in Geneva on May 11 in advance of a meeting there later in the month between Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET PLAN ARMS TALKS IN MAY
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The United States and the Soviet Union announced today that they would resume formal negotiations for a new strategic arms limitation treaty in Geneva on May 11 in advance of a meeting there later in the month between Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko.

title: Child's World
description: WHEN SUMMER approaches, the music leaves. The music schools shutter their brownstones until fall. The students take a seasonlong respite. Or they head out to the enormous musicoriented day camp in South Huntington, L.I., called Usdan. Others go off to some lively residential camp where the sounds of music fill wooded valleys.

title: Pirates Top Phils for Candelaria, 50
description: Extrabase slugging by Bill Robinson and Frank Taveras, coupled with the combined threehit pitching of John Candelaria and Rich Gossage, carried the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 50 victory last night over the Philadelphia Phillies in Three Rivers Stadium.

title: Advancing Zairian Units Move On As Mobutu Tours Captured Town
description: MUTSHATSHA, Zaire, April 26 (Reuters)A Zairian military spokesman said today that his country's forces, backed by Moroccans, had pushed swiftly west from here toward the Angolan border, meeting little resistance from rebels who lost control of this key railroad town yesterday.

title: AN ILLEGITIMACY BAN IN INHERITANCE UPSET
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that it is unconstitutional for states to bar illegitimate children from inheriting from their father when the father dies without leaving a will.

title: PUBLIC JOBS PROGRAM VOTED BY CONFEREES AS DEADLOCK IS ENDED
description: WASHINGTON, April 26House and Senate conferees broke a long deadlock and accepted President Carter's $4 billion public works jobs program today by agreeing to detach controversial water pollution provisions from the legislation. The bill, a key element of the President's economic stimulus package, is expected to be on his desk for signature on Friday.

title: Giscard, Seeking to Stem Leftist Gains, Presents Economic Plan
description: PARIS, April 26President Valry Giscard d'Estaing, who is struggling to prevent a SocialistCommunist victory in parliamentary elections scheduled for next year, today unveiled a new economic program that his Government hopes will take the political sting out the country's growing unemployment problem.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: JIMMY CARTER'S energy program may be the stuff of major debate, but whatever controversy is generated will probably never hold a candle to the longrunning Manhattan argument about the merits of the East Side as against those of the West.

title: Bridge:
description: Even for a player of the highest class, some defensive problems may be too difficult to solve in the limited time available at the table. One such situation defeated John Lowenthal of Montvale, N. J., on the diagramed deal, played in the WestchesterNew Jersey Grand National final last weekend, but he was left with two consoling thoughts: in the postmortem he spotted the subtle solution before any of the other players: and his team won the match by a large margin.

title: Well, Who Needs Life Savings?
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill.Some weeks ago, my father survived a heart attack. Now that he is recovering, we are not so much concerned about his physical condition as we are about his financial situation. While he has survived the heart attack, he may not survive the bills.

title: No Carter, No Town Quorum
description: CLINTON, Mass., April 26President Carter put this mill town in the limelight as a showcase of New England democracy when he came here on March 16 for a special staged town meeting. The townspeople drew lots for the honor of crowding into the town hall, the streets were jammed, 300 reporters were in attendance and the event was televised nationally.

title: OTTAWA TO NAME OVERSEER OF GOVERNMENT SPENDING
description: OTTAWA, April 26In a major reform resulting from official charges of laxity in the administration of public funds, the Canadian Government has decided to appoint a permanent overseer of Federal spending programs, with the title of Comptroller General.

title: G.M . Asking Court To End Tax Inquiry By a Federal Jury
description: DETROIT, April 26In a surprise move late this afternoon, the General Motors Corporation filed a motion in a Federal court here today to stop a grand jury investigation into allegations of tax fraud by the company.

title: The Standings
description: Wednesday, April 27, 1977

title: Brown Faces Test in Refusal to Extradite Indian
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 26Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. faces a test in the California Supreme Court of his authority to continue to circumvent a 40yearold state law in avoiding the extradition of Dennis Banks, the militant Indian leader, to South Dakota for sentencing in a felony conviction.

title: VOICE OF AMERICA HEAD SAYS HE WAS DISMISSED
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)The Carter Administration has quietly dismissed Kenneth Giddens, the Republicanappointed director of the Voice of America.

title: FED PUMPS RESERVES INTO BANKING SYSTEM
description: The Federal Reserve aggressively supplied temporary reserves to the nation's banking system yesterday and the credit markets rallied strongly, ending a decline that began a little more than a week ago. When the day was over, however, the debate remained unsettled over whether the central bank had decided recently to shift toward a slightly less accommodative monetary policy.

title: Haunting Homburg On TV
description: HEINRICH VON KLEIST committed suicide in 1811 at the age of 34. Shortly before his death, he wrote The Prince of Homburg, using a 17thcentury story about a Prussian nobleman who disobeys his military orders but nevertheless defeats the invading Swedish forces. The conquering hero is sentenced to death for not following orders. Von Kleist transformed this incident into an exploration of dream and reality, passion and dissembling, cringing cowardice and bravado.

title: TriState Bid for Olympics?
description: ELLENVILLE, N.Y., April 26 (UPI)The tristate metropolitan New York City area could be just the right place for the 1984 Summer Olympic Games, according to Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut.

title: Going Out Guide
description: HEY, LOOK ME OVER! The new storefront at 210 West 44th Street, just east of Sardi's Restaurant, should be well worth investigating for collectors of theater memorabilia. With an allday gala opening this morning at 10:30, and appearances by theater celebrities, who will also serve as regular clerks, the Actors Fund Bazaar hopes to brighten the theater area with regular cornucopia of art objects, jewelry, furniture, autographed programs and photos, books, costumes and gowns. Regular hours will be Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.; and for matinee goers on Sundays, from noon to 3 P.M.

title: PUBLIC JOBS PROGRAM VOTED BY CONFEREES AS DEADLOCK IS ENDED
description: WASHINGTON, April 26House and Senate conferees broke a long deadlock and accepted President Carter's $4 billion public works jobs program today by agreeing to detach controversial water pollution provisions from the legislation. The bill, a key element of the President's economic stimulus package, is expected to be on his desk for signature on Friday.

title: Personal Health
description: SEVENYEAROLD Michael D. was playing Frisbee on the sidewalk in front of his house when a neighbor approached with his Great Dane on a leash. Michael ran to make a catch just as the dog passed by Suddenly. for no apparent reason. the huge animal lunged at Michael and tore an inchlong hole in the cheek.

title: Misusing the C.I.A.
description: In requesting the Central Intelligence Agency to declassify its report on world petroleum resources, President Carter yielded to an understandable impulse with consequences that may do him and the C.I.A. more harm than good.

title: Pakistani Opposition Leaders Drawing Up Demands
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 26(Reuters)The acting president of Pakistan's nineparty opposition alliance met eight jailed leaders of the movement today in a detention center outside the nation's capital. The meeting was arranged by Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto in an effort to negotiate a solution to his country's twomonthold political crisis, in which some 250 people have died.

title: Effort to Discredit Data Concern Chosen Over Citibank Is Charged
description: ALBANY, April 26  New York State's Social Services Commissioner charged today that tactics bordering on the unethical were being used to discredit his choice of the Bradford National Corporation over Citibank to handle computer services for New York City's Medicaid program.

title: Books: World's Music
description: DAVID RECK smiles out from the back flap of his book like some happy totem from the 1960's. And, indeed, from its title onward, Music of the Whole Earth is like some artifact from that loving, ecumenical decade.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Workers Agree on Contract Items, Ending 7Day Walkout
description: Employees and management of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People reached a tentative settlement of a dispute over contract issues late last night, ending a sevenday work stoppage that was the first fullscale walkout in the history of the civil rights organization.

title: Letters
description: Sour Words on Vinegar

title: The Last of Nadjari's Indictments Against Cunningham Is Dismissed
description: The last of four indictments brought by Maurice H. Nadjari against Patrick J. Cunningham was dismissed yesterday by Justice Leonard H. Sandler of the New York State Supreme Court. The judge criticized the case for an insufficiency of evidence and the shockingly improper and prejudicial manner in which it was presented to a grand jury.

title: Mrs. Abzug Puts Her Hat in Ring, But Unofficially
description: Bella S. Abzug declared yesterday that she was running for the Democratic nomination for Mayor even though she had not formally announced her candidacy and could still change her mind.

title: CreditCard Sex Scored by Midtown Citizens Panel
description: Anyone with the right credit card can buy sexon credit, the Mayor's Midtown Citizens Committee charged yesterday, and it called on two major banks and the American Express Company to cancel the creditcard accounts of sex merchants.

title: Music: Americana
description: THE BICENTENNIAL celebrations last year yielded many performances of early American music, but probably none was quite like the concert in Town Hall on Monday night. It marked the debut of the Federal Music Society, an organization created largely by Frederick R. Selch, its president. It is dedicated to presenting music of the ColonialFederal period, roughly the years 17751830. What makes it unusual is the use of instruments surviving from those years, some of them European made, but many of them constructed by American artisans.

title: Why Hamlet Died of Poison?
description: FINE CHARACTERS in Shakespeare's Hamlet die of poisoning: Hamlet's father, mother and uncle, Hamlet's dueling opponent and Hamlet himself.

title: An Aggressive Comeback by Cunningham Expected
description: Reform politicians to the north of him. Puerto Rican politicians to the south of him, Patrick J. Cunninghamfinally free of the legal problems that had hounded him for more than a yearconfronts a political landscape strewn with pitfalls.

title: Gastronome's Gallery: A Great Sandwich Is a Work of Art
description: England's greatest contribution to gastronomy has nothing to do with Brussels sprouts, toad in the hole, bubble and squeak or even rare roast beef and Yorkshire pudding. It is purely and simply the sandwich, that portable edible whose consumption in the United States alone must total in the billions in the course of a year.

title: MetsYanks Game May 9
description: The Mets and the Yankees will meet May 9 in the annual Mayor's Trophy game for the benefit of sandlot baseball in the metropolitan area. The Yanks lead, 86, in the exhibition series.

title: Red Smith
description: When the mailbox in the office could hold no more, a copyperson tossed letters into a carton where they lay unnoticed for many weeks. Among them was an announcement that the Theodore Gordon Flyfishers had chosen Sparse Grey Hackle as the first recipient of the Arnold Gingrich Angling Heritage Award. The announcement was dated March 1 and the presentation was scheduled for March 12, so the chances are that by now Sparse has hung the plaque in a suitable location and spent the $1,000 award on gin and blondes.

title: NEW YORK'S M. A. C. HELD CONSTITUTIONAL BY COURT OF APPEALS
description: The New York State Court of Appeals yesterday upheld the constitutionality of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, removing what M.A.C. officials said had been a cloud driving up the corporation's interest rate and hampering its efforts to meet New York City's financing needs.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Working in pairs according to a meticulously rehearsed plan, with muddy crude oil splattering their coveralls and hard hats, the workmen succeeded in attaching a blowout protector that bad been partly fastened when the well roared out of control last Friday. They also installed hydraulic rams that they hope will pinch off the well and halt the spill of oil into the North Sea.

title: All About: How to Buy The Right Bicycle
description: AS LAST season's bitter cold begins to recede into memory. and longawaited wann weather strikes striking chords in winterweary New Yorkers, one sign of the city's awakening to spring is the sudden proliferation of bicyclists once again freewheeling through the streets and park

description: Tuesday, April 26, 1977

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6  No Title

title: The Gaudi Art That Survived a Fire
description: THE EXTRAORDINARY ORIGINALITY of Antonio Gaudi, the Spanish architect who died in 1926, has made his name a familiar one to people who ordinarily have little interest in architecture; tourists to Barcelona, for example, inevitably make a pilgrimage to the Sagrada Familia, Gaudi's vast unfinished church whose four tall openwork spires and plethora of plastic shapes dominate the cityscape. The Sagrada Familia is a building that the architectural historian HenryRussell Hitchcock called perhaps the greatest ecclesiastical monument of the last one hundred years.

title: NEW YORK'S M. A. C. HELD CONSTITUTIONAL BY COURT OF APPEALS
description: The New York State Court of Appeals yesterday upheld the constitutionality of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, removing what M.A.C. officials said had been a cloud driving up the corporation's interest rate and hampering its efforts to meet New York City's financing needs.

title: STEEL LEADERS URGE AN EARLY PRICE RISE AS PROFITS DECLINE
description: Complaints of poor weather, a lag in the economy and rising steel imports, pl?s an insistence on the need for an almost immediate increase in steel prices, cam? from key industry leaders yesterday as further evidence developed that firstquarter steel profits were in a bad way indeed.

title: Wine Talk
description: EVERY SO OFTEN someone announces that the fashionable wine from California this season will be the zinfandel or the petite sirah or the merlot. Everyone dutifuly hastens to stock up on whatever is supposed to be the rage.

title: More Peabodys Listed
description: More Peabodys Listed

title: Quebec's Plan To Quit Canada Bitterly Resisted
description: MONTREAL, April 26The Quebec government, after five months in office, is engaged in an increasingly bitter battle on four fronts to persuade this province's predominantly French population to accept independence.

title: Indicted F.B.I. Men Must Pay Legal Fee, Bell Tells Senators
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today that the Government ought to but would not pay the legal fees of Federal Bureau of Investigation agents indicted for alleged breakins, wiretaps, mail openings or other illegal activities they carried out in domestic subversive cases.

title: EARNINGS ARE MIXED FOR OIL COMPANIES
description: Texaco, Phillips and Cities Service Lift Profits but Shell, Sun and Continental Report Declines

title: Dressing To Pass The Job Interview
description: MARTHA LOOMIS was walking across the Barnard College campus recently when one of her friends spotted her, stopped still and asked, Martha, is that you? It was Martha, in a new beige linen suit, brown blouse, blue pumps and a fresh haircut, midway in the spring metamorphosis from college to career woman. She was on her way to a Job interview.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON. April 26A report sharply critical of some of New Jersey's local Police Departments was described today as very unfair by the president of the State Policemen's Benevolent Association.

title: Police Officer Found Unconscious In Bryant Park, Revolver Nearby
description: A police officer who had called for assistance over his portable twoway radio was found lying unconscious with a head injury in Bryant Park early today. His service revolver and two spent shells were lying nearby, the police said.

title: Whooping Cranes Fly To Home in Canada
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 26 (AP)Most of the record 69 whooping cranes at the Aransas National Wildlife Refuge on the Texas coast have left for their Canadian breeding grounds, the Parks and Wildlife Department reported today.

title: Carter Cautions, On Geneva Talks; Consults Hussein
description: WASHINGTON, April 26President Carter said today, after concluding talks with King Hussein of Jordan, that unless progress toward a Middle East settlement was evident before a new Geneva conference on the Middle East, it might be better to call off plans for the conference.

title: Week Without Television Tunes Several Families Into Different Channels
description: It began in irony and ended in fiasco. The Upper West Side experiment in not watching televisionNo TV Weekwas made up of equal parts of book promotion and good will, and in the end it proved only that children enjoy taking part in experiments, particularly those that involve getting interviewed a lot on television. It was a story explicitly antiTV, and television loved it, covered it and, ultimately, exploited it.

title: About Real Estate
description: NEWARKA company our size, with 3,000 office employees, would have to have its head examined to go suburban, said Robert C. Lydecker.

title: Byrne Seeks Support for Revamping of Port Body
description: PRINCETON, April 26Governor Byrne met today at Morven, the Governor's Mansion, with three of the six New Jersey members of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to try to line up support for a proposed shakeup of the top posts at the bistate agency worked out by Mr. Byrne and Governor Carey.

title: When the Horse Starts to Tire
description: PARISThe only two states dreamed up by literery men are Israel and Pakistan and both, for entirely different reasons, are in trouble. Israel stemmed from the ideas of Theodor Herzl, a Viennese Jewish journalist, novelist, playwright, who stimulated the political Zionist movement and eventual formation of Israel, where Herzl now is buried.

title: Variety of Corporations Report Operating Results Disclosing Their Sales and Earnings Figures
description: For periods ended March 31. (N) Indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: People in Sports
description: The doctor who performed the sixth operation on the battered left knee of Bobby Orr says the Chicago Black Hawks star will be on crutches the next four months and has told Orr not to think about playing hockey for a year. Orr a former allstar with the Boston Bruins with whom he set National Hockey League scoring records for a defenseman, aggravated his December 1975 knee operation by performing in the Canada Cup series in September. He appeared in only 20 games for Chicago last season because of his continuing knee problems.

title: Concerns Moves From New York Called Drain on Energy in Study
description: Every corporate headquarters job moved out of New York City to a suburb adds a minimum of 248 gallons of gasoline a year to the nation's energy expenditures, according to a study made public yesterday.

title: One Killed in Home's Fifth Fire
description: WARMINSTER, Pa., April 26 (AP)A fire at the Frank Rohlfing home here, the fifth in recent months, killed one person and injured five others early today. Mr.Rohlfing's 42yearold wife, Kay, died in the blaze, which was being investigated by the authorities. The Rey. Glenn Abbott, a neighbor said there had been five fires at the Rohlfing home in recent months. He said the family had returned to their home three days before Easter after being forced to leave it for six weeks when fire destroyed the roof.

title: Bullets Box Score
description: Technical foulJones.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: F.D.A. to Require Warning Label For Fluorocarbon in Aerosol Cans
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it would require a warning label on aerosol containers using fluorocarbon propellants as a first step toward eventual elimination of virtually all such products.

title: Some Companies Express Their Preferences
description: Here is a sampling of what some recruiters say about the young woman's appearance for the job interview:

title: PREGNANCY DISABILITY PAY URGED BY CARTER AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI)The Administration today declared that discrimination based on pregnancy is sex discrimination and urged Congress to pass a bill that would overturn a Supreme Court ruling that lets employers deny disability payments to expectant women.

title: Film: Japanese Suds
description: TORO-SAN, the Intellectual," a new feature which today opens a two-day stand in the Japanese film revival series at the Regency Theater, is proof that East and West can meet on some cultural levels. In the case of this "Toro-San," the Orients customs may still be somewhat exotic but the succession of joys, sorrows and misconceptions are as Western as any soap opera.This is not meant to denigrate the sudsy but obviously profitable techniques of those enduring television sagas. Like them, this latest Toro-San adventure, reportedly the 17th filmed in the last eight years starring the title character, ranks among the most popular film series with Japanese moviegoers. But the work of Yoji Yamada, who wrote and directed many of them, isexcept for a retrospective showing of 11 Toro-San features he presented at the Japan Society here last Januaryfairly unfamiliar in local houses.His current "Toro-San" is the same simple, unlettered, kindly, bumbling wanderer who manages to get himself into and out of scrapes while scattering good deeds along the way. This time, he returns home to the candy shop run by his uncle, aunt, sister and brother-in-law only to find himself accused of being the father of the pretty 17-year-old girl waiting for him.Toro is guiltless, of course; he was only the self-effacing benefactor of the girl and her late mother, whom he befriended when she was deserted by her husband. Those misunderstandings do pile up, however.On a visit to the mother's grave, a priest instructs the nave Toro to "know yourself, it's never too late to learn." And, before you can say sayonara, he's smitten by a demure, attractive archeology student  a roomer with his familyand he's off and running clownishly toward becoming an "intellectual" with her help.Naturally, the results are bittersweet but unrewarding for all. There's a middle-aged, girl-shy archeology professor who thinks he's been spurned by his pupil, who happens to be Toro's teacher. Toro is equally confused by her purely platonic intentions and, obviously, the lady is left unrequited.His script may be convoluted and his direction uneven, but Mr. Yamada is decidedly professional in shaping a colorful and briskly moving story. No amount of English subtitles fully clarifies his opening sequencepresumably a fantasy shoot-'em-up showdown in an old western saloonthat is a larger-than-life lampoon only vaguely related to subsequent events. But there's little doubt that Mr. Yamada and his cast project contemporary Japanese family life and ties realistically and affectionately.As Toro, Kiyoshi Atsumi is an endearing buffoon whose love for his clan and others is unmistakably honest while he endures their jibes about his oafishness, his "square face" and the unnecessary glasses he takes to wearing during his brief schooling.The town, its streeets and shops, the wooded hills, and a pick-up baseball game, add to the color of the comedy-drama. If, like soap operas everywhere, this "Toro-San" seems to be much ado about nothing that is momentous, it generally manages to be genuinely warm and charming.

title: TAX REBATE REVERSAL CRITICIZED BY MUSKIE
description: WASHINGTON, April 26Edmund S. Muskie, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said today that the Administration's change of signals in dropping the $50 tax rebate had created a crisis of confidence in the budget process.

title: BEAME'S FISCAL AIDE GETS HOSPITAL POST
description: Mayor Beame took control of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation yesterday, installing his principal fiscal aide as the corporation's top policymaker and assuring a major administrative shakeup of the semiindependent city agency that operates the municipal hospitals.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Sir Daniel McGarvey, Labor Leader Who Headed British Boilermakers
description: NEWCASTLE, England, April 26 (AP)Sir Daniel McGarvey, who started work as a shoeshine boy and became the tough leftwing president of the Boilermakers Union, died today in Newcastle General Hospital, the union announced. He was 57 years old. The cause of death was not stated.

title: Alleged Soviet Spy Testifies He Was Blackmailed After Telling a Friend of C.I.A. Deception of Australia
description: LOS ANGELES, April 26A 23yearold college student testified today that, while working as a code clerk for a Central Intelligence Agency project, he learned of a deception against the Australians, and that revulsion over this discovery had begun a trail of events that led to his being blackmailed into becoming a Russian spy.

title: Workmen Finish Step in Capping Runaway Well
description: EKOFISK CENTER, in the North Sea off Norway, April 26A team of volunteer workmen completed without mishap today the first phase of its perilous effort to cap a runaway oil well about a mile from here.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Zenith Radio Corporation announced yesterday that it and the Sony Corporation had entered into a settlement agreement that would dismiss Sony from an antitrust and antidumping suit involving Japanese televisionreceiver imports.

title: McBride Margin 80,000 Votes
description: PITTSBURGH, April 26 (UPI)Complete but unofficial returns show that the establishment candidate, Lloyd McBride, defeated the insurgent, Edward Sadlowski, by nearly 80,000 votes in the battle for the presidency of the United Steelworkers union. A spokesman for the union said yesterday that Mr. McBride received 328,861 votes to 249,281 for Mr. Sadlowski in the union's election Feb. 8.

title: HelpWanted Advertising Index Rose 2 Points to 108 for March
description: The helpwanted advertising index rose 2 points in March to 108 (1967100), the Conference Board reported yesterday. The index stands at 3 points above the January figure and 14 points above the level of March 1976.

title: Week Without Television Tunes Several Families Into Different Channels
description: It began in irony and ended in fiasco. The Upper West Side experiment in not watching televisionNo TV Weekwas made up of equal parts of book promotion and good will, and in the end it proved only that children enjoy taking part in experiments, particularly those that involve getting interviewed a lot on television. was a story explicitly antiTV, and television loved it, covered it and, ultimately, exploited it.

title: Candy Heiress Inquiry
description: CHICAGO, April 26(AP)A Cook County grand jury has opened an investigation into the disappearance of Helen Voorhees Brach, the candy heiress. Mrs. Brach, a 62yearold widow, was last seen on Feb. 21, when one of her employees said he dropped her off at O'Hare International Airport. Kenneth Gillis, a deputy state's attorney, said yesterday that subpoenas had been issued for Mrs. Brach's financial records, in an effort to determine whether money had been stolen from her.

title: Stage: Weill's Delightful Happy End
description: LOVERS OF KURT WEILL. arise. Get to see the Chelsea Theater Center production of the Weill/ Brecht musical Happy End, which officially opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night and is scheduled to end there this weekend. The company is confident of transferring the production to Manhattanbut please take no chances. Besiege Brooklyn, in case it is too late.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 27, 1977

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI)The 1.2millionmember women's division of the United Methodist Church said today that it would not hold any national meetings in states that have not ratified the equal rights amendment.

title: It's Not All Sunshine in Florida Condos
description: HALLANDALE, FLA.

title: Hayakawa Finds Senate Friends More Interesting Than Ph.D.'s
description: WASHINGTON, April 26S.I. Hayakawa, veteran academic and novice Senator, paused between bites of his sardineandEnglish muffin breakfast this morning to say, I find Senators an awful lot more interesting people than professors.

title: Gold Off $1.25 an Ounce; Strength Shown by Dollar In Most European Centers
description: LONDON, April 26 (AF)The price of gold dropped $1.25 an ounce in London and Zurich today. The dollar picked up strength in most European money capitals.

title: Pascale Gets Princeton Post
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 26 Joe Pascale, head coach of football at Idaho State University last fall, accepted an assistant coaching job at Princeton University today. Pascale, 31 years old, was added to the Princeton staff as a defensive coach with responsibilities in the line and linebacker areas. He replaces Ron Blackledge. who left Princeton to coach at Kent State.

title: STATUS OF JACKSON HIGH CALLED PITIFUL BY JUDGE
description: A judge in Federal District Court in Brooklyn said yesterday that on the basis of the evidence he had heard so far, segregation in its most pitiful form exists at Andrew Jackson High School in Cambria Heights, Queens.

title: U.N. Experts Agree With Carter On Need to Conserve Oil and Gas
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 26President Carter's warning of a tight world oil supply in the 1980's is in keeping with the analyses that have been made by a number of United Nations experts here.

title: Coal and Oil States, Upset by Carter Plan, Prepare for EconomicWar Over Energy
description: HOUSTON, April 26Instead of the moral equivalent of war, the nation faces what some regional officials are calling the economic equivalent of civil war over President Carter's energy proposals.

title: KENNECOTT COPPER REPORTS SHARP GAIN
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the nation's largest copper producer, reported yesterday a sharp recovery in firstquarter earnings, thanks largely to its Peabody Coal subsidiary.

title: Brazil's Two Nations
description: SAO PAULOIn mid19thcentury England, as the erects of tne industrial Revolution were beginning to be ielt, an aspirmg politician named Benjamin Disraeli described in his novel Sybil how British society was dividing, more sharply than ever berore, into two nations, quite separate and unrelated: the rich and the poor. To no developing countries in the moden industrial revolution is Disraeli's phrase more applicable than to those or Latin Amer icaand most pointedly to the largest, most populous and potentially ricnest of them all, that wonurous rising giant called Brazil.

title: Chrysler Will Close Three Plants Because of Strike at Key Factory
description: DETROIT, April 26 (AP)  Three Chrysler Corporation assembly plants will be shut and two others will operate on half shifts tomorrow because of a srike at a key components factory, company officials said today.

title: Q&A
description: IN REPLY to a recent question in this column as to the difference between light and dark soy sauce, we offered what some readers considered a lightweight explanation. We also stated that to our knowledge bottles of soy sauce are, regrettably, not labeled light and dark.

title: U.S. Sextet Loses, 32, To Finland
description: VIENNA, April 26 (AP)A dramatic goal with 2 minutes 16 seconds left to play, scored while a broken stick was sliding through the goal crease, gave Finland a 32 victory over the United States today in the world ice hockey championship.

title: The Philadelphians
description: ALLRACHMANINOFF programs have been a Philadelphia Orchestra calling card for many years. The composer first performed his music with the Philadelphians in 1909, continued the association as guest conductor and piano soloist for 30 years, and often proclaimed the group his favorite orchestra.

title: A Grand Building Belongs to All
description: There are more ways to destroy a building than with bulldozers. In the case of Grand Central Terminal, the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad is not proposing to tear the building down; the idea is to mutilate it by erecting a 59story tower abovea subtler, but equally effective kind of landmark destruction, if subtle is a word that can be used about so monstrous a proposal.

title: Helpern Is Praised at Services As More Than a Man of Science
description: Milton Helpern; who was internationally known as a medical detective, wrote the definitive text in his field and taught generations of forensic pathologists, was honored yesterday by 700 relatives, colleagues and students who filled the Park Avenue Synagogue to pay their last respects.

title: Carter Cautions On Geneva Talks; Consults Hussein
description: WASHINGTON, April 26President Carter said today, after concluding talks with King Hussein of Jordan, that unless progress toward a Middle East settlement was evident before a new Geneva conference on the Middle East, it might be better to call off plans for the conference.

title: 12 F15's Will Fly to Europe Today
description: Twentyone F15 Eagle fighters, the Air Force's contestant for air superiority, will be deployed across the Atlantic today in what the Pentagon regards as a major qualitative reinforcement of United States air power in Western Europe.

title: Bombing of Guernica Marked by Basques
description: GUERNICA, Spain, April 26 (UPI)Basques today commemorated the 40th anniversary of the Nazi bombing of Guernica.

title: Taste in Replacing the House on 11th St.
description: Six years ago, an architect stood before New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission and argued that a design he had prepared for a new house for himself to fit in the middle of a row of Greek Revival town houses on West 11th Street was an appropriate companion to its neighbors. The commission, after much debate, agreed. The architect, Hugh Hardy, never built the house because inflation had put its costs beyond his means, and the siteon which had stood a house accidentally blown up by young revolutionaries in 1970has remained vacant.

title: Peres, Israel's Acting Premier, Sees Hope for Peace Talks in 1977, but Says There Are Still Great Obstacles
description: JERUSALEM, April 26Acting Prime Minister Shimon Peres said last night that it was still possible to reconvene ArabIsraeli peace talks this year although the path to a speedy solution of the prolonged conflict between Arabs and Israelis was blocked by formidable barriers.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHY HAVE THERE BEEN no great women artists? This deceptively simple and very painful question was confronted in a memorable article by Linda Nochlin, Mary Conover Mellon Professor of Art at Vassar College, in the January 1971 issue of Art News magazine. The answer, Professor Nochlin argued in her complex response, lies in the nature of social institutions and what they denied to women. For one significant example, until the end of the 19th century, women had no access to study of the nude model.

title: Technology
description: In the fastmoving electronics industry, whose expansion is founded on rapid technological change, venture capital financing is a favorite topic of dispute.

title: Chess:
description: The cheapo as it has come to be known, is a surprise tactical shot that suddenly decides a game. The term probably originated with a disgruntled loser who believed that his embattled defense deserved a better fate than to be exploded by a low, cunning or cheap trick.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Speier of Giants Traded To the Expos for Foli
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 (AP)Chris Speier, San Francisco's disgruntled shortstop, was traded today to the Montreal Expos for Tim Foli, the Giants announced.

title: RENT CONTROL PACT REACHED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 26The leadership of both houses of the Legislature announced agreement today on a fouryear extension of both the statewide rent stabilization program and of upstate and suburban rent control.

title: INMATES ATTACK 2 GUARDS AT JAIL IN KEW GARDENS
description: Two correction guards at the Men's House of Detention in Kew Gardens, Queens, were assaulted last night by a group of inmates, but an alarm signal was set off by one of the guards and a possible escape of the prisoners was prevented.

title: Mary Hartman Canceled
description: HOLLYWOOD, April 26 (UPI)Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman, television's hit satirical soap opera, is going into voluntary retirement as of July 1 but will be seen on reruns, and may of its zany characters will appear in two new miniseries, its producer, Norman Lear, announced today.

title: YONKERS TOLD BY LEVITT OF DANGER TO ITS BUDGET
description: YONKERS, April 26State Comptroller Arthur Levitt told an executive session of the Yonkers Emergency Financial Control Board today that the city, which appeared to be emerging from its fiscal difficulties, might find its budget out of balance this year and face continued state supervision of its financial affairs.

title: Stage: Greek Singer
description: WHEN NANA MOUSKOURI, the Greek singer, first appeared in the United States a dozen years ago, Harry Belafonte introduced her to American audiences on one of his concert tours. Since then Miss Mouskouri has made several American concert tours of her own. Last night, when she made her Broadway debut in Nana Mouskouri on Broadway at the Broadway Theater, where she will continue through Sunday, Mr. Belafonte was again on hand, this time in the audience. And, appropriately, one of her most effective songs was a hauntingly appealing melody with a lazy, rolling rhythm, Cou Cou Rou Cou Cou, which she got from Mr. Belafonte on that initial visit.

title: BISHOP FLOYD BEGIN, OF OAKLAND, IS DEAD
description: Roman Catholic Bishop Floyd L. Begin of Oakland, Calif., who sought unsuccessfully in 1954 to get a Knights of Columbus charter for an interracial council in Cleveland, died yesterday of complications from various illnesses. He was 75 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of editing errors, a report on the energy situation in Calvert County, Md., that appeared in The Times on Monday stated erroneously that Thomas Rymer was a former delegate to the Maryland legislature, and that buildings in the county were burned in the Revolutionary War. Mr. Rymer is currently a member of the legislature, and the buildings were burned in the War of 1812.

title: EVENING STANDARD NEARS DEMISE THROUGH MERGER
description: LONDON, April 26The demise of one of Britain's bestloved newspapers. The Evening Standard, is expected to occur this week after days of negotiations.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Fantasia for Five, Purcell; Sinfonia in D, Pereira; Lensky's Aria from Eugen Onegin, Tchaikovsky; Dixiana, Hoffman; Overture to La Contadina in Corte, Sacchini; Trio, C.P.E. Bach.

title: ATOM SAFETY STUDY BY US. IS QUESTIONED
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The accuracy, completeness and purpose of the major United States study arguing for the safety of nuclear reactors have been challenged by internal Government documents made public today.

title: STUDENTS IN STATE U. END NINEDAY STRIKE
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., April 26Students at the State University campus here voted today to end their nineday strike, remove their guards from the campus gates and return to classes tomorrow.

title: Con Ed Income Rose 15.2% for Quarter;50c Dividend Is Declared
description: The Consolidated Edison Company reported yesterday that its net income for the first quarter was up 15.2 percent from yearearlier levels. The utility, one of the nation's largest, also declared an unchanged dividend of 50 cents a share payable June 15 to stockholders of record as of last May 11.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New Jersey employers, acting under a steppedup program to clear the unemployment rolls of people who will not work, have turned in nearly 5,000 people who they say have refused to take jobs, state officials said yesterday.

title: About Education
description: There is good news for those crusty diehards who are concerned about the future of Latin. It refuses to die.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Keep Your Hat On

title: 663 Running for 288 Vacancies On 32 Community School Boards
description: A question of one little word has plagued the residents of Queens who live in School District 28 and are involved in the community school board elections.

title: Perrier, the Snob's Drink, Soon to Come in SixPacks
description: VERGEZE, FRANCE

title: St. John Passion
description: BACH'S ST. JOHN PASSION live in the shadow of his incomparable St. Matthew Passion, but it gathers little moss there. Although it suffers in comparison and can seem strangely loose and uneven for Bach; St. John has grand pages and choral societies choose to investigate them with fair regularity. On Monday night at Alice Tully Hall, with Werner Torkanowsky as guest conductor, the Amor Artis Chorale and Orchestra brought many of its sections to life in a complete performance that made several genuflections in the direction of correct Bach performance practice.

title: Market Place
description: With few exceptions, most of them in the Southwest, bank shares generally are selling at substantial discounts from book valueassets less liabilities divided by shares outstandingand shareholders are upset.

title: Cauthen's a Winner With Crowds As Race Tracks Clamor for Jockey
description: That babyfaced corporation named Steve Cauthen bestowed his favors on Aqueduct yesterday and came away With two winners in seven rides.

title: Discotheque Opens Despite Its Leaking Waterfall
description: The waterfall was leaking almost up to the last minute; the final furniture delivery was made with just three hours to go, and for a while it appeared that the camera crew from the Italian Vogue might never find a place to plug in its lights.

title: Mrs. Abzug Puts Her Hat in Ring, But Unofficially
description: Bella S. Abzug declared yesterday that she was running for the Democratic nomination for Mayor even though she had not formally announced her candidacy and could still change her mind.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Renata Adler Wins Prize
description: The Ernest Hemingway Foundation Award for the best first novel by an American published during the previous year will be presented this afternoon to Renata Adler, author of Speedboat. Miss Adler, a former New York Times film critic and New Yorker writer, is now a firstyear student at Yale Law School.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of editing errors, a report, on the energy situation in Calvert County, Md., that appeared in The Times on Monday stated erroneously that Thomas Rymer was a former delegate to the Maryland legislature, and that buildings in the county were burned in the Revelutionary War. Mr. Rymer is currently a member of the legislature, and the buildings were burned in the War of 1812.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: The First Quarter of Mr. Carter
description: When Jimmy Carter became President 98 days ago he had little to fear except fear itself. His remarkable campaign for the White House showed him to be shrewd and intelligent, dedicated and poised, efficient and humane. He was a man of obvious selfconfidence, but also one who sometimes scared easily; when the race grew tense he not only trimmed but cut and ran from apparent commitments to full employment and social spending toward a balanced budget and increased defense spending. Fear rather than conviction seemed to move him from side to side. It was a fair preview of the leader we have seen so far.

title: The Government's Deadly Omission
description: In 1972 and 1973, the National Institute for Occupa tional Safety and Health collected the personnel records of 2,500 workers who had been exposed to carcinogenic substances at dye plants in five states. The substances, benzidine and betanaphthylamine, have long been known to cause cancer of the bladder. With early warning, the lives of victims of bladder cancer can be prolonged. But most of these 2,500 who had been exposed received no warning.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: FROM MY apprenticeship as a chef in Paris more than 40 years ago. one of the things I remember most profoundly is the occasional trip to the old markets at Les Halles with my mentor and guide, the chef of the Restaurant Drouant, at that time one of the most celebrated restaurants in the city.

title: Evelyn Y. Davis Falls In Scuffle at Meeting
description: Evelyn Y. Davis, a well known figure at annual shareholder meetings, encountered some turbulence yesterday at the Eastern Air Lines meeting.

title: Notes on People
description: IT WILL BE the first trip to Europe for Andrew Wyeth, the distinguished American realist painter, when he leaves Saturday for Paris to be installed as a member of the French Academy of Fine Arts. Only one other American artist, the late John Singer Sargent, has received that honor from the French institution. Mr. Wyeth, who is 59 years old and lives in Chadds Ford, Pa., has remained close to the rural areas of Pennsylvania and Maine where he had done his work. The only trips he has made out of the country so far have been to Bermuda and Nova Scotia. After the induction ceremonies next Wednesday Mr. Wyeth will fly to England where he will be the guest of the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire at Chatsworth in Sherwood Forest. Mr. Wyeth said he was anxious to visit Sherwood Forest because of a deep interest he developed after his father, N. C. Wyeth, illustrated a Robin Hood book years ago.

title: World News Briefs
description: NEW DELHI, April 26A twohow meeting today between Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai was reported to have cleared suspicions and to have enlarged the scope for cooperation.

title: 29 Saved From Burning Boat
description: KODLAK, Alaska, April 26 (AP)Twentynine crew members have been rescued from a burning Japanese fishing boat in Cold Bay, 450 miles southwest of Anchorage, a Coast Guard spokesman said. He said that the crew abandoned the blazing 185foot Fukyoshi Maru No. 85 and was picked up by a Russian cargo vessel yesterday. The Coast Guard in Kodiak sent the cutter Jarvis to pick up the rescued men.

title: Hernandez Hearing Ends
description: The hearing before the State Racing and Wagering Board on the application of Sandino Hernandez to be an exercise rider ended yesterday and the odds were that the case would be heading toward the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: TIMES DOUBLES NET FOR FIRST QUARTER
description: The New York Times Company told its shareholders yesterday that firstquarter earnings had doubled on a 12 percent increase in revenues over the comparable period of 1976.

title: Far From the Cycling Crowd
description: At the first sign of really nice weather, Central Parkwhich is a wonderful place to rideseems to fill up with cyclists as fast as a fishing seine gathering tuna. On weekend afternoons particularly, it can get tightly packed and a trifle uncomfortable. Armed with a good map and a sense of adventure however, it's amazingly easy to leave the crowds behind. You can ride along the Brooklyn Shore Bikeway to Coney Island or even Far Rockaway. Or just take an afternoon's jaunt up to Inwood and the Cloisters.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: WE WILL talk now about benefits, a nice example of one having been held on Monday night. It was for the Hospital for Special Surgery, and its star was Mikhail Baryshnikov, who, along with Frank Sinatra, say, or a musical such as Annie, is as big an attraction as you will get these days for a benefit. Once, a benefit nearly always meant a ball, and while people still hold balls for their charities, they are not nearly so popular as they once were.

title: Outsider's Look at Special South African Jail
description: ROBBEN ISLAND, South Africa April 26 (Reuters)The South African Government, sen sitiv to accusations that it runs a Devil's Island for political prisoners, has finally allowed outsiders to see its maximumsecurity jail. All its inmates are nonwhites.

title: A Butterfly? Dragon? No, It's a Kite
description: This is the time of year when I tell myself: Go fly a kite.

title: ALBANY CHIEFS REACH RENT CONTROL ACCORD
description: ALBANY, April 26The leadership of both houses of the Legislature announced agreement today on a fouryear extension of both the statewide rent stabilization program and of upstate and suburban rent control.

title: Soviet Life and Adventures Of a Kicker of Sacred Cows
description: MOSCOW, April 26When Vladimir Voinovich was summoned for a chat with the K.G.B. security police in May 1975, one agent with intellectual pretensions inquired how the writer went about his creative labors.

title: Controlled Torque Motor Reduces Electricity Use By 20%, Inventor Asserts
description: LOS ANGELES, April 26Major energy savings may result from widespread use of the controlled torque motor, according to its inventor, who said that it reduced electrical consumption by as much as 20 percent while producing the same power output as conventional electrical motors.

title: ROLE OF ENERGY CHIEF CAUSES SENATE FIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, April 26A threesided power struggle involving two Senate committee chairmen and James R. Schlesinger, the Administration's energy chief, has shaped up over what authority Congress will grant Mr. Schlesinger as the nation's first Secretary of Energy.

title: Volunteer Workers Are Honored On Service to Other New Yorkers
description: They have a need to help others, and they gathered yesterday in the Board of Estimate chambers at City Hallhigh school and college students, grandmothers and those with no special labelto be recognized.

title: Toia Is Expected to Become Budget Chief If Gold mark Gets Job With Port Authority
description: ALBANY, April 26Philip L. Toia, the state's active and outspoken Social Services Commissioner, will almost certainly be named to head the State Budget Division if the currenet diredtor, Peter C. Goldmark Jr., leaves as expected to become executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Carter And Europe
description: WASHINGTONJimmy Carter is going to Europe next week for the first time as President, and he is preparing the way carefully, in recognition of the fact that Europe usually takes a highly skeptical view of new American Presidents.

title: Workmen Finish Step in Capping Runaway Well
description: EKOFISK CENTER, in the North Sea off Norway, April 26A team of volun teer workmen completed without mishap today the first phase of its perilous effort to cap a runaway oil well about a mile from here.

title: Bruins Again Top Flyers in Overtime, 54
description: PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, April 27The fans stayed until the bitter end early this morning as the Boston Bruins stole another overtime game from the Philadelphia Flyers, this time scoring after 10 minutes 7 seconds of the second extra period for a 54 victory.

title: Private Lives
description: JUST TO SURVIVE in this city, we need a support system. It is the net and the trampoline, the singing booth and cloister, a wildlife refuge. It consists, of course, of friends, the people we can call in the middle of the night when the gods have dealt us a karate chop or the discrepancies seem to be gaining on us. Listen: they are raining on my parade, there's a microphone in my flower pot, the elevator doesn't stop here any more, Mozart died. According to the Irish, What a friend gets is not lost'a proverb I take to have several meanings.

title: New Chief for Historical Society, But Same Solid Community Role
description: NEWARKDr. Clifford L. Lord, the incoming director of the New Jersey Historical society, laughed when asked recently what approach he expected to take.

title: South Africa Reports Troops Kill 21 on Angolan Border;
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, April 26 (Agence FrancePresse)South African security forces have killed 20 guerrillas of the SouthWest Africa People's Organization and one Angolan soldier in clashes on the border between Angola and SouthWest Africa since April 2, an official army communiqu said today.

title: 8 Held as Principals In Smut Production
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office capped a sevenmonth investigation yesterday by arresting eight alleged pornographers on felony charges and seizing. 4,000 copies of pornographic films involving children between 8 and 12 years old.

title: Court Upholds Some Insurers On Ways They Get Tax Breaks
description: WASHINGTON, April 26(AP)The Supreme Court gave some insurance companies a financial victory today when it ruled that methods they used to obtain favorable tax treatment did not violate the Internal Revenue Code.

title: Signs of Quark Discovery Cited in Stanford Report
description: WASHINGTON, April 26After years of searching, scientists reported here today the first evidence that quarks, those hypothetical building blocks of all heavier particles of matter, may have been discovered.

title: Shift in Balance of Sex Hormones Linked to Heart Attacks in Men
description: A change in the delicate balance of the body's sex hormones is the major factor that makes men susceptible to heart attacks, according to a major new theory developed by Dr. Gerald B. Phillips of Columbia University.

title: Old Crop Soybeans Fall by the Limit
description: CHICAGO, April 26 (AP)Old crop soybean and meal futures fell to permissible limits on the Chicago Board of Trade today for the second straight session.

title: 2 Are Dismissed at C.I.A. For Unspecified Actions Called Harmful to Agency
description: WASHINGTON, April 26Stansfield Turner, the new Director of Central Intelligence, dismissed two employees today for performing services not authorized by the C.I.A. on behalf of former C.I.A. officers.

title: White House Studies Imposition Of Ceilings on Fees of Physicians
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Carter Administration is studying the imposition of ceilings on doctors' fees as a second means of controlling sharply rising medical care costs.

title: SUPREME COURT BARS PORT AUTHORITY AID TO NEW MASS TRANSIT
Carter's Popularity Slips in Poll
description: As President Carter had predicted, his popularity dropped at least 10 percent in an NBC News poll after he announced his energy program, The Associated Press rported yesterday. The poll, taken Monday and Tuesday in telephone interviews with 1,597 adult Americans, indicated that 53 percent thought Mr. Carter was doing a good or excellent job, as against 63 percent who felt that way in an NBC News poll in March.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Stage: Musical Inmates With Dreams
description: ON THE VARIOUS STAGESat last count there were seven in the vast reaches of the Public Theater, Joseph Papp repeatedly tries out shows in workshop and then decides to turn some of them into full productions. David Langston Smyrl's On the Lockin, which opened at the Public last night, is one that should have remained in workshop. The best that can be said for this prison musical is that it has possibilities.

title: Armstrong Resigns From Rolling Stone
description: Joe Armstrong, the ?? ?? Texas boy who found fame in the big city as publisher and chief operating officer of Rolling Stone, has resigned from the magazine. The 33yearold lawyer is seeking new horizons.

title: Caramoor Festival Lists Artists
description: Stravinsky's Persephone, Britten's The Rape of Lucretia and a varied array of chambermusic concerts will be featured in the 32d annual Caramoor Festival, which will open on June 25 and run through Aug. 21.

title: Books: Lafayette
description: THE MARQUIS de Lafayette, despite the image that persists in many minds, was not always on parade. Stendhal the authority for the great liberal champion's ability, at the age of 60, to grab successfully at the skirts of pretty girls. Indeed, he vanquished Stendhal in a contest for the affections of a Portuguese 18yearold when the writer was 40 and in his prime.

title: Crafts: A Mixed Bag
description: In the relatively few years of its existence, the Craftsman's Gallery in Scarsdale has established what has now become a tradition: an annual invitational show The gallery shop aims for a mix of freshlooking work or evidence of new directions, generally by craftsmen that it has recently uncovered. Which is not to say that the people in the show are newcomersbut that time is needed to get around and make discoveries.

title: Agencies Facing Changes
description: Most Federal regulatory agencies face drastic changes if a recent decision by a Washington appeals court is upheld by the Supreme Court. Page D3.

title: Bill for Strip Mining Reclamation Is Cleared for Debate in House
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI)Federal strip mining reclamation legislation, longsought by environmentalists and backed by President Carter, is ready for floor action in the House.

title: Advertising
description: The longawaited Project Payout or the Advertising Research Foundation will get its first test in Julyif all goes well.

description: WASHINGTON. April 27 King H?? of Jodan said today that it was up to the Palestinian people to decide what kind of homeland it wants.

description: NEW DELHI, April 27India and the Soviet Union affirmed today that they would preserve and strengthen their ties and step up cooperation.

Peggy Tanner, a Former Diplomat And Wife of Times Correspondent
description: PARIS, April 27Peggy Tanner, wife of Henry Tanner, chief of The New York Times Cairo bureau, died today in Cairo after suffering a heart attack yesterday. She was 41 years old.

title: PLAN TO CURB DOCTOR FEES SAID TO HAVE BEEN DROPPED
Pines Barrens Bill Introduced
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP)Legisiation that would establish New Jersey's vast Pine Barrens as a national ecological reserve has been introduced by Representative James J. Florio, Democrat of Camden. N.J.

title: S.E.C. PLANS REVIEW OF RULES GOVERNING CORPORATE PROXIES
description: WASHINGTON. April 27The Securities and Exchange Commission today expressed its deepening concern over the apparent ineffectiveness of shareholder democracy by authorizing the first broad review of S.E.C. proxy rules since they were adopted more than three decades ago.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Former Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark, who served half of a 10year jail term for his conviction in a $1.4 million extortion plot was ordered freed yesterday by Judge George H. Barlow in Federal District Court in Trenton. Officials at the Federal Penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pa., said the 63yearold former Mayor would be released as soon as the court order was received.

title: ExCleveland Mayor Says Byrne Waited Too Long for Income Tax
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., April 27 (UPI)Carl Stokes, former mayor of Cleveland, said last night that if Governor Byrne had pushed the state Income tax early in his administration he would have had a permanent income tax.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times on April 12 stated incorrectly that Frederick Canavor had been dropped from the Brooklyn District Attorney's staff in October 1975. Mr. Canavor resigned Oct. 4, 1975, and became a special New York State assistant attorney general on Oct. 6, 1975.

title: Ceiling Fans Return
description: PLAY it again, Sam. The ceiling fan is back. It's been back for years with some decorators who used it as a decorative object, but today, with energy on the mind and the season of perspirationonthebrow fast approaching, the lazy ceiling fanwith its low energy drainis rood for more than just nostalgia.

title: Albany Keeps Curb Of 8% on Interest On Mortgage Loatis
description: ALBANY, April 27Republicans won another victory in the New York State Legislature today when the Senate and Assembly reached quick agreement on a bill extending for two years the 8 percent ceiling on annual interest that lenders may charge on homemortgage loans.

title: 18 Schoolchildren Are Injured When Auto Slams Into Their Bus
description: TRENTON, April 27 (AP)Eighteen children were treated for minor injuries yesterday after a man apparently fainted at the wheel of his car and the auto crashed into their school bus while it was discharging the children, the police said.

title: N.F.L. Is on Jersey's Side With Jets' Home Schedule
description: The National Football League's 1977 schedule, released yesterday, has been designed to permit the Jets to play all their home games in Giants Stadium in New Jersey.

title: Attempt to Choke Off BlownOut Well Is Due Today
description: STAVANGER, Norway, April 27An attempt will be made tomorrow morning to choke off a blownout well that has sprayed more than three million gallons of crude oil into the North Sea, officials of the Phillips Petroleum Company announced tonight.

title: Decorators Have a Field Day, As Show Places Open
description: IT'S CERTIFIABLY spring when May swings into bloom and the decorator showcase houses open their doorsthe annual round of decorating extravaganzas where interior designers show off their talents for charity.

title: Meadowlands Results
description: FIRST$7,500, pare, mile.

title: 3 Top Jockeys Hoping to Get Ride in Derby
description: Ron Turcotte calls Derby fever a sickness in the spring and he knows how Jean Cruguet, Seattle Slew's jockey, feels. Turcotte has already been in the hot seat, aboard a Kentucky Derby favorite.

title: Charles H. Alston, Artist, a Professor At City College, 69
description: Prof. Charles H. Alston, a painter and professor in the department of art at City College, died yesterday in his home at 1270 Fifth Avenue, He was 69 years old.

title: The C.I.A. and Oil
description: CAMBRIDGE, MassPresident Carter's call for energy conservation comes none too early. White some may argue whether it will be 1963 or 1987 when petroleum demand exceeds supply, most authorities agree that if demand continues to grow there will indeed be a shortage.

title: New York Medical Schools Lag In Attracting Minority Students
Film: Good Reading 'Between the Lines'
description: BETWEEN THE LINES???," the second feature by Joan Micklin Silver ("Hester Street"), is an appealing, low-key, counter-culture newspaper comedy, meaning that it doesn't have a great deal of conventional newspaper narrative, though toward the end someone does tell "the kid," a would-be reporter who has just come up with his first scoop, "You're going to nail those punks with that story!"The newspaper in question is The Back Bay Mainline, a Boston weekly that suggests both The Boston Phoenix and The Real Paper, which is not terribly surprising because the film was written by Fred Barron, who once worked on each.Like so many once-underground papers today. The Mainline and the members of its staff are going through an identity crisis. Founded in the late 1960's, when there were easily recognized battles to be fought, the formerly hard-swinging, radical, antiwar paper has grown fat. It's running out of causes. The Mainline is so profitable, in fact, that a newspaper tycoon is negotiating to buy it.Harry (John Heard)???, The Mainline's chief investigative reporter, a fellow who once won a national journalism award for a series exposing nursing home scandals, is suffering from career-bends. He tells Abbie (Lindsay Crouse), a pretty, still-ambitious photographer who is his occasional girlfriend, "It isn't exciting anymore." No matter how many exposs one writes, nothing ever changes.Michael (Stephen Collins), who made his reputation reporting on the activities of flower children, hippies, yippies and druggies, is planning a book on the counterculture years. Even before he has received his advance, he has started to talk in the vocabulary of the literary hustlers who never put finger to typewriter before knowing the probably financial disposition of all of the subsidiary rights. You know he's going to be the perfect talk-show guest.Laura (Gwen Welles), who lives with Michael and says every other day that she's leaving him, is also a reporter but one with no great drive. When Michael decides to move to New York, Laura at first refuses to tag along. She has her own career, her own friends, she says, but then she changes her mind. It's probably her first major compromise. Max (Jeff Goldblum), the paper's rock critic and resident comic, talks big but he, too, compromises at the first sign of a crunch."Between the Lines" is, technically, I suppose, a newspaper film, but what distinguishes it is the gently perceptive way it captures the emotional confusions of its characters. They are young, talented, ambitious people who once had the great good fortune to be enthusiastically committed and to have had professional lives that were the same as their private lives. Just how lucky they were they begin to realize only now that the time has passed. The 1960's have become their roaring 20's."Between the Lines" is about growing up after you've already grown up. Harry, the investigative reporter, experiences his first intimations of obsolescence at 30. He's suddenly baffled by the fact that Abbie continues to enjoy her jobit's as if he'd never really known her. They quarrel, break up and come back together, but each knows that it will never be the same again.Somewhere in "Life on the Mississippi" Mark Twain remembers coming into Hannibal for the first time after he received his pilot's license. The river was no longer beautiful to him. Unusual ripples on the surface had become warnings of new shoals. A brilliant red sunset was simply a weather forecast. He'd lost something very precious and he had to move on.So do Mrs. Silver's characters and "Between the Lines" is at its best when it ambles in and out of their lives, over-hearing lovers' quarrels, professional conflicts, office politics. It's not so convincing when it tries to work along conventional plot lines that have to do with the selling of the paper and with some underworld activities. Then it's awkward and amateurish.Not so the performances, which are uniformly first-rate, the kind of ensemble work in which no actor is more or less important than another. That includes Jeff Goldblum, who has received a good deal of publicity as the nutty rock critic. His is a more colorful role, but Mr. Heard, Mr. Collins, Miss Crouse and Miss Welles are quite special, too.Among other things, "Between the Lines" is one of the few films I've seen dealing with the counterculture years that doesn't rip it off or send it up. Time, says Mrs. Silver, catches up, even with the young.

title: For the Battered Bride
description: If a stranger punches you in the nose, you can swear out a summons in Criminal Court. If, however, you happen to be married to the aggressor, you must head for Family Court. which aims not merely to protect your face but your marriage as well. The trouble is that the complex counseling routines of Family Court tend to deter complainants, which may explain why so many battered wives begin the process while so few complete it.

title: Schools Dismiss 120 Workers on Fingerprint Checks
description: Fingerprint checks of New York City school employees over the last two years led to the dismissals of 120 persons, including 20 teachers, who were found to have been convicted of serious crimes, school officials disclosed yesterday.

title: 154 Americans, Last of Expelled 300, Leave Ethiopia
Signs of Change
description: BOSTON, April 27One of the most remarkable acts of Jimmy Carter's first hundred days as President was a decision not to do something: not to plunge into the situation in Zaire. It was a more difficult decision than has been generally recognized, and said more about Mr. Carter.

title: World News Briefs
description: CAPE TOWN, April 27 (Reuters)Representatives at the United States, Britain, France, West Germany and Canada began efforts today to convince South African leaders that plans to grant independence to SouthWest Africa by 1979 would not be accepted by the international community.

title: DoItYourself Solar Fence Heats Swimming Pool
description: BLOOMFIELD. Conn. AFTER THREE YEARS, my solarheated swimming pool has become respectable. Now I can say that I was never an ecology nut or a mad inventor; I just wanted to be warm. I was not even aware until last week, when President Carter began his heavy campaign for a more sensible energy plan, that I had been acting in the national interest.

title: MARCH OIL IMPORTS PUSH TRADE DEFICIT TO ANOTHER RECORD
description: WASHINGTON. April 27 (AP)A 22 percent increase in oil imports resulting from the unusually cold winter pushed United States trade into a record monthly deficit of 22.4 billion in March the Government reported today.

title: Women Playing Leading Roles in Teaneck Politics
description: TEANECK, April 27When Dorothy Silverstein completes her year next month in the rotated post of Deputy Mayor and returns to her regular seat on the Township Council, the two top offices will no longer be held by women.

title: Cool Summer Classics
description: Janine Rosze is unabashedly proud of Design Research's extraordinarily ordinary furniture. That's because the French designer, a consultant to the store, believes people have grown tired of everything else.

title: G.E. Meeting Dominated by Political Issues

Taxexempt obligations, in turn, were generally on the upside, reflecting in part two court decisions that were Credit viewed with favor in the Markets marketplace. In the interestsensitive Government market, prices were firm at the outset but weakened as the rate of Federal fundsexcess reserves commercial banks may lend one anothermoved up to 5 percent.

title: Lighting Plants Efficiently
description: THERE IS no need to let your pet fern or philodendron die for lack of light because you want to save energy. The simplest thing, of course, is to move all your house plants over to the windows where they will get natural light. They won't fit? Attach shelves to the window frames and get a number of house plants into the sun that way. Or hang them from ceiling hooks close to the windows. If you can afford to be extravagant, have a small greenhouse attached to the outside of your window.

title: Letter: On Zaire
description: It will unfortunately take more than sorting out the Lunda from the Luba to salvage the credibility of your improbably headlined editorial Zaire Made Clear (April 13). In fact, your correction of April 14 compounded your earlier misreading of the situation by implying that, apart from an excusable mixup, the rest of your editorial remained factually sound and analytically valid.

title: Film: Seamy and Shallow Show-Business Types:Pages of an Album
description: WHEN IT STAYS with its pop-music sounds and its recording-studio settings, "Shining Star," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, possesses the instructive quality of a competent documentary on an interest-element of show business.The trouble is that "Shining Star" isn't a documentary at all. As fiction, it is an occasionally choppy looking movie with aspirations toward exposing the seamy side of the recording industrythe marketing of no-talent performers by cynical executives of companies controlled by the underworld. Unfortunately, its people are unconvincingstereotypical characters depthlessly performed.It is a handicap that cannot be overcome, even by the musical contributions of Earth, Wind and Fire, appearing as a relatively unknown act shunted aside in favor of a wretched family group, the Pages. "Shining Star" is, after all, a movie, not a recording. As a moral tract, it offers indignation but cannot kindle outrage, which leaves it long on soul but short on art.Although not shown previously in this area, "Shining Star" has played elsewhere under the title "That's the Way of the World." Scenes of drug use (heroin and cocaine) as well as some standard street language and one lyrical, unrevealing scene in bed are probably responsible for the PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") rating.

title: Absurd Baby Murderer
description: Larry Cohen's "It's Alive," which opened at neighborhood theaters yesterday, is a horror film about a newborn baby who loses no time in making a mess of things. He murders everyone in the delivery room except his mom. Thereafter he lays waste a large part of Los Angeles, getting around town so rapidly you suspect he must have his own Porsche, though when we see him he's always crawling.Mr. Cohen is not unintelligent, but the few interesting ideas in his horror films, including the recent "Demon," are drenched in supreme silliness by way of the dialogue and special effects. The performances in this film are especially unpleasant, and the music score by the late Bernard Herrmann sounds as if it might have been composed to accompany World War II."It's Alive," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains a scene of childbirth that's grizzly enough to put anyone off both motherhood and fatherhood.

title: The Flower That's in Full Bloom
description: As a rookie six years ago, Guy Lafleur's primary concern was living up to the great expectations that the Montreal Canadiens had for him. But because of his potential, he had another problem. Which number to wear? He had worn 4 as a Quebec teenager while Jean Beliveau was wearing 4 with the Canadiens but Jean Beliveau had just retired and 4 was available. The rookie asked his idol for permission to wear it. If you want 4, take it, Jean Beliveau told him. But why add to the pressure already on you? Why not take another number and make it yours? Guy Lafleur took 10 and made it his. And as the Canadiens await tonight's resumption of their Stanley Cup semifinal with the Islanders at the Nassau Coliseum, the hockey player known as Flower (the English translation of his name) is making another number his. A number nobody knows yet. It will be the eventual number of his remarkable record for scoring either a goal or an assist in consecutive games. In hockey's version of Joe DiMaggio's 56game hitting streak, Guy Lafleur has been on the score sheet in 34 consecutive games, including six in the current playoffs.
