The herbicide is called Orange, for the colored identification stripes painted around us containers. It was the best known of several defoliation diemcals sprayed or dropped by airplane on five million acres in South Vietnam. Use of the herbicide was banned in April 1970, and the Air Force stored about a third of its remaining supplies outdoors in oil drums at a naval base in Gulfport. Miss.

title: Loft Music Plugs Into Midtown

Later in the weekon MondayAlvin Lucier will place two miniature microphones in his ears and then plug a tiny metal bird into a wall socket. As the bird begins to twitter, Mr. Lucier will stroll around the ballroom, and the microphones will broadcast what he hears to a bank of amplifiers and loudspeakers. Then next Thursday the Viola Farber Dance Company will perform two dance pieces, Lead Us Not Into Penn Stationwhich should perhaps have been retitled Lead Us Not Into Times Square for the occasion  and Dinosaur Parts.

Mr. Narayan was jailed along with other dissenters when Prime Minister Gandhi proclaimed a state of emergency in June 1975. After being held for five months he was released because of poor health.

title: BOND PRICES DROP; FED FUNDS RATE IS UP
description: Bond prices declined yesterday as traders watched the Federal funds rate the basic rate of the money marketclimb as high as 51/16 percent in the afternoon. From this rise, many concluded that the Federal Reserve had decided to Credit Markets shift to a slightly less accommodative credit posture, and they moved to sell securities before fixedincome prices fell further. The declines in the bond market took place in the face of news that the Government would pay off some $2 billion of maturing securities during May and June. Furthermore, the bond market appeared to pay no attention to news of slight declines in the money supply that were reported yesterday afternoon, and fixedincome prices drifted lower after the monetary figures were released.

title: Screen: A German 'Wild Duck'
description: THE DENSITY of the pain in any Ibsen play has to do not only with the accumulation in time of tragic, misbegotten deeds but also with the playing area of the stage. As his characters are locked into their lives, they are caged in theater sets.Double doors at the rear may lead to an inner room, and stairs at stage left suggest the existence of another floor. Yet there is no true escape from the small, realistically furnished, 19th-century interior landscape that, as often as not in Ibsen, is a living room. In English, if not in Norwegian, that's a joke. By the time we reach the fifth Ibsen act the feeling of confinement has become so intense that violence is inevitable.This is one of the reasons why Ibsen's plays don't easily translate from stage to films, which are as big as all outdoors. It is also one of the achievements of Hans W. Geissendorfer's German-language adaptation of "The Wild Duck" that this physical evocation of emotional pressure is not lost in his very moving film."The Wild Duck," which opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse, has no spectacular performance to equal Glenda Jackson's in the film version of "Hedda Gabler" last year, but its spirit seems truer to Ibsen, even with necessarily foreshortened English subtitles translating the German dialogue.Mr. Geissendorfer, the young German director who created considerable interest here five years ago with an elegant vampire film called "Jonathan," has cut the text a bit and shifted some of it around. The point of his treatment, though, is not to modernize the original in any way but to make us respond to and understand the conventions of one of Ibsen's best-made plays.In no other work by the Norwegian playwright, whom Shaw ranked (along with himself, of course) ahead of Shakespeare, has so much rotten business been going on for so long before the beginning of Act One, which must tempt the film director to find all sorts of cinematic equivalents for the exposition spoken on stage. Mr. Geissendorfer resists all this and sticks to the fury at hand, an ironic self-appraisal by a playwright who had once championed idealism so forcefully.The time is 1884 and the setting is a small Norwegian city where Hjalmar (Peter Kern), a good-natured, self-deluding, former member of the bourgeoisie, lives happily with his wife, Gina (Jean Seberg), his daughter, Hedwig (Anne Bennent), and his disgraced old father.Into this placid family circle comes Hjalmar's old schoolmate, Gregers (Bruno Ganz), whose mission is to make people see the lies they live in order to attain the enlightenment of truth. In so doing he destroys the family and, it seems likely, himself.Mr. Geissendorfer opens up the play but not in such a way that he lets the life out of it. The camera moves freely around Hjalmar's tidily run-down flat, from the studio where Gina runs his photography business to the adjacent attic where the senile grandfather stalks game (penned-in rabbits) and where Hedwig keeps her wild duck.There are brief glimpses of the outside worlda barroom, the courtyard of the apartment buildingbut none of these has the effect of diminishing the drama of financial fraud and concealed parenthood that's being revealed in breathtaking order upstairs.With the exception of Miss Seberg, who is too chicly beautiful to be believable as the sort of waddling, once-ripe housemaid she's supposed to be, the casting is nearly perfect.Anne Bennent is a lovely Hedwig with her open, solemn face and her way of walking with her hands drawn to her sides, as if she were always afraid of breaking something. Peter Kern, who has appeared here in Fassbinder films and looks a bit like Gene Wilder, is less comic than one expects as the foolish Hjalmar, but he has a kind of witty self-importance that makes the character more easily tolerable. The star, though, is Bruno Ganz, fanatically self-assured as the terrifying idealist who, you know, is himself teetering on the edge of suicide.The color photography is uncommonly goodnot so dramatically under-lighted that one feels the need of wiping one's glasses, but soft and a little smoky, as if one should open the windows of the flat. They would do just that except that it's midwinter and the choice is either to have clean air and freeze or to put up with leaky flues and cooking odors to stay warm. The cold finally does invade their lives, but it is bitter truth, which in this film can be physically felt.

Miss Koner explains that dancing is like playing chamber music: No four instruments play identically. The program lists four Koner works: Solitary Songs (which has a homage to the late conductor Fritz Mahler), Time of Crickets, Potme and Concertino. tickets are $3 ($1 for the elderly). title: Broadway

Cohen very nearly neglected to invite him to the party he gave for the opening of Anna Christie, although in a burst of inspiration he then sent the invitations around by limousine. Mr. Zollo, after all, has invested fair amounts of money in Guys and Dolls,' The Shadow Box, The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel and, just the other day, the forthcoming Golds. Moreover, this season he acquired a substantial interest in three Broadway theaters. Mr. Zollo is now a power.

title: Welcome to New York, Len Randle
description: This is to say welcome to New York, Len Randle. Chances are he will encounter some flak before he can settle in as a member of the Mets fairly happy family. Like most people, New York baseball fans don't approve of slugging people and breaking their bones. But New York fans are at least as fairminded as most and maybe a little more so. They are aware that after losing his head and punching his manager, Frank Lucchesi, into the hospital, Randle acceptedthe penalty imposed by the Texas Rangers and waived his right to an impartial hearing. It was not a Sports light penalty. A $10, 000 fine and 30day of suspension without pay cost him $23, 000 The Times altogether. He took it quietly and apologized though Lucchesi rejected the apology. And when some prosecutor in Orlando, Fla.. brought charges a month after the factcould there possibly be an election coming up in Orlando?Randle turned himself in to answer the charges. He shouldn't have broken Frank Lucchesi's face and he knows it, and the burden of that knowledge is still with him. Most New York fans will not add to the load while he tries to win a job with the Mets.

title: Denis Potvin Is 23 and Learning
description: People sometimes forget that Denis Potvin is only 23 years old. He looks older and he plays older. The husky defenseman in the helmet has led the New York Islanders in scoring in each of his four seasons. Twice he's been a National Hockey League allstar and he probably will be again this year. If the Islanders were to be identified with one player, he would be the one. He has helped create an opportunity for the Islanders to even their Stanley Cup semifinal with the Montreal Canadiens at two games each. at the Nassau Coliseum tonight. But inside he's still only learning. Mostly about himself and his teammates. Several months ago some of his teammates put him down. Too much of a loner, they muttered. Too much ego, they whispered. Denis Potvin isn't a tough old pro yet. He's a sensitive young pro. That talk wounded him. In a lockerroom meeting, he stood up and confronted his teammates.

title: Melting the Marijuana Glacier
description: The glacier on marijuana laws seems finally to have broken in Albany, but the movement is by inches. Governor Carey proposed last year to liberalize the laws relating to both the sale and the possession of marijuana, and this year the Republicans have dropped at least some of the opposition that prevented the passage of any reform last session. As a result, the Codes Committees of both houses have voted out reform measures.

title: Naumburg Cello Finals Set for Wednesday
description: The Walter W. Naumburg Foundation is holding the first major American competition just for cellists next week, and the finals in Carnegie Hall on Wednesday will be open free to the public. The event is expected to run from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.

title: Carter to Be on European TV
description: President Carter has agreed to television interviews with three European networks before his scheduled European trip next month, the Associated Press reported yesterday. A spokesman for the British Broadcasting Corporation said that the interview was to be recorded Monday at the White House. The three networks will air the interview by satellite in European prime television viewing time, the spokesman said. Representatives of BBC, ZDF of West Germany and TF1 of France will participate in the interview.

We very much welcome the fact that the United States has now decided not to be a gas guzzler, Mr. Healey said at a news conference. Mr. Healey has been in Washington for several days attending a series of international financial meetings.

title: Pop: Congenial

But her voice is generally undermined by a detached, somtimes even bitter performing persona that robs her work of its uplifting potential.

title: Major Economic Indicators Scored 1.4% Rise in March
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)  The Government's index of leading economic indicators, a barometer of future economic activity rose 1.4 percent in March, the highest monthly gain in 12 months, the Commerce Department said today.

title: New Indian Regime Moves to Hold New Assembly Elections in 9 States
description: NEW DELHI, April 29The Government of India, moving to strengthen its political base, decided after a favorable court decision today to dissolve the legislatures in nine states and hold new elections there. But, according to reliable sources, it ran into a major constitutional obstacle tonight when the Acting President. B.D. Jatti refused to sign the dissolution order immediately, saying he would have to think about it.

description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.A society free from the threat of terrorism is quite attainable. title: Who Dares Touch Rent Control?
description: Governor Carey has reluctantly caught the ball on New York rent regulation. He says he is going to ask his counsel to make rent stabilization and rent control work a little better. Apparently, the Governor was chagrined because Senate Republicans outbid Assembly Democrats for tenant affections by deciding to support without change a fouryear extension of the flawed Emergency Tenant Protection Act. Only the future will show whether the Governor seriously means to stem the decay resulting from rents that do not cover rising costs, or merely to cacapture political advantage by shielding tenants against greater rent increases, at the price of continued housing deterioration and abandonment.
